column2: Record dealers have experienced a Substantial increase in business since the first of the year, according to separate surveys by the trade publications Retailing Daily and Record Sound Retailing.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 23 (AP)--If anybody ever catches up with the mysterious fireballs that are reported frequently over the Southwest, it's a good bet that Lincoln Lapaz won't be far behind.

BUTLER, Md., April 23 (AP) --Ray Quick, Christopher M. Green's 7-year-old gelding making his first start of the year, flashed to a two-length victory over Philstar today in nearrecord time for the Grand National point-to-point race.

EVERY now and again the Museum of Modern Art puts on a "New Talent" exhibition. The latest of these, comprising work by a painter, sculptor and a printmaker, is now being shown in the Penthouse, where members may otherwise solace themselves with sun and sandwiches.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- James Reston, the Washington correspondent of The New York Times, received, the Raymond Clapper Award tonight for Washington news correspondents in 1954.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 23 --There were a few echoes of the race track today when the large Boulder Brook Club spring horse show began. Two former race horses acquired six weeks ago by Irl A. Daffin of Lititz, Pa, both recent converts to showing, figured successfully in open jumper and hunter classes.
NEEDHAM, Mass., April 23 --William H. Carter, president of the William Carter Company and former United States Representative, died here today after a brief illness. He was 90 years old.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 23-- Lebanese authorities released today a 400-ton Israeli freighter, with eight crew members aboard. The ship is due at Haifa tomorrow, an army spokesman announced.
The last week of April brings a wide variety of group and oneman shows into museums and galleries.
CHICAGO, April 23--Will Sewell Avery yield his twentyfour-year reign as chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., now that he has beaten Louis E. Wolfson's bid for his role?
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, April 24--A plane bearing Admiral Arthur W. Radford and Assistant Secretary of State Walter S. Robertson landed here at 11 A. M. today.

PANAMA, April 23--Roman Catholic Church leaders of twenty-three nations proposed today the establishment of institutes of land reform in their countries. The institutes would be composed of representatives of government and private agencies interested in agrarian reform.

Plan a "simple" home and it will have more value. That is the advice of a mortgage expert. Overemphasis of "uniqueness" may prove detremental to the resale value of the property, according to Floyd Cramer, president of the Washington Heights Federal Savings and Loan Association.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Representative Olin E. Teague, Democrat of Texas, said today the House Veterans Affairs Committee, found a widespread "vicious, illegal practice" involving the buying and selling of veterans' housing rights. Mr. Teague is the chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) --Russian Army officers who had tentatively accepted an invitation to attend an "Elbe River reunion" here suddenly changed their minds today. They invited their American hosts to come to Moscow instead.

Asian Lingua Franca Twenty-nine free nations of Asia and Africa conferring in Bandung, Indonesia, having carefully excluded all Western nations, are using English as the official language of their unique gathering.
NEW lenses and lens attachments for increasing or decreasing area coverage have been announced by several manufacturers. The new items are for use with still, amateur movie and stereo cameras.
LONDON, April 23 (AP)-- Chelsea celebrated fifty years, of soccer today by winning the English League title for the first time.

NATURE lovers from many states will gather in Gatlinburg, Tenn., this week for the fifth annual Spring Wildflower Pilgrimage. On Wednesday through Saturday that gateway town to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park will literally be stuffed with hikers, amateur photographers, naturalists and botanists.

Built-in air conditioning is being offered on an optional basis in new apartments and dwellings by the Tywel Manufacturing Company of Brooklyn. The manufacturer makes arrangements with the builder to install sleeve casings when the structure is erected.

THE hitters have been behaving with such ferocity this, season that the Society for the Relief of Bartered Pitchers is likely to apply for a charter any day. It is even possible that agitation will be resumed to restore that outlawed weapon--the spitball. Nothing else could teach the hitters better manners so quickly or so effectively.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 23-- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem made a new move today for civil peace in Saigon and got a sour reaction from the rebel camp.
Frosts in the South late last month nipped retail consumers up North. Retail potato prices doubled in two weeks.

TO THE EDITOR: John Gould's witty and poetic paean in praise of Yankee rocking chair virtuosity-- "Rocking Chair Meditation" (April 10)--gave me great pleasure not only for its tribute to a fine art and great performers, but for its amusing sidelights on life in Maine.

With hardly a ripple, the Senate has cooly authorized a series of public power and reclamation projects for the Upper Colorado basin states at a cost that even the notoriously inadequate official estimates place at more than a billion and a half dollars.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Federal Communications Commission has been reminded dramatically that the public is far from reticent when invited to say what it thinks.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- Arguments that some inflation might be desirable to relieve unemployment were firmly rejected today by William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

Everywhere that spring comes now we look out across the hills, the meadows, the fields and lawns, and say, "How good to see a green world again." And thus pay our tribute to the grasses of this earth, which are even more widespread than the trees and, in some ways, even more closely linked with, mankind's life.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23--The Yale University varsity crew opened its 103d rowing season on a successful note today by easily defeating Rutgers. The winning time for the two-mile race on the Housatonic River was 10:42.

The Dodgers recovered their winning touch yesterday. They did so in the happiest manner imaginable. Their victory was over the hated Giants, 3-1, before a capacity throng of 32,482 spectators at Ebbets Field.

THEODORE BONNET'S story is set in that region north of the Golden Gate between the Pacific and the meandering duck sloughs of the Napa River. It is a stark, sunburned and monotonous land, prinked with nondescript small towns, of which Llagas is one.

A traveling exhibition of building products will begin a crosscountry tour in September under the auspices of the Producers Council. Last year the council, which is a manufacturers association, sponsored a similar exhibition, which completed a tour of thirty-four cities in November.

BALTIMORE, April 23 -- A Baltimore harbor tunnel that will enable through north and south traffic to bypass virtually all the city finally is under construction. Ground was broken Thursday by Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin.
The Cross County Center, mammoth Yonkers retail development, celebrates its first birthday on Thursday.

Brazil is giving a remarkable demonstration of how to be poor in the midst of plenty. Nature has been bountiful, but man has been squandering or misusing her gifts. A few years of wise and sensible living could straighten things out. The question is whether politics and the get-rich-quick mentality of some Brazilian business men will permit the right policies to be taken.

HOT SPRINGS NATIONAL PARK, Ark.--The average visitor "taking the baths" here in an average two or three-week stay will probably use up no less than 1,000 gallons of water in one or another of 500 huge bath tubs in one or another of eighteen luxurious bathhouses.

"BLESSED be shade--if there is not too much of it," is an excellent axiom for the gardener who is planting a new garden or renovating an old one. Though relatively few plants will thrive in extremely dense or total shade there are literally hundreds that not only tolerate, but actually prefer it.

THE concern of artists and others in related fields over the current extremism in painting is clearly reflected in letters occasioned by the discussion last week in these columns dealing with the overlarge canvases basically dependent on color appeal.

THERE may be nothing new about New England for many New Yorkers, but farthest pastures are not necessarily the greenest. For my own part, after several crosscountry tours and trips to Europe, the lovely countryside, the rolling hills and the many interesting things there are to do and see in the New England states were an agreeable surprise.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23-- Two explanations of yesterday's assassination of Col. Adnan Malki, the Syrian Army's Deputy Chief of Staff, were being advanced tonight.

OHORE FOR THE WEEK: It is too early to set into the ground outdoors geraniums and tomato plants and most kinds of annual flower seedlings. Do transplant biennial and perennial seedlings to places where they are to bloom and set out perennials, pansies and forget-me-nots for prompt bloom. Sow seeds of hardy annual flowers and vegetables.

THOSE rear admirals of Second Avenue, T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton, are busily charting next season's course for the Phoenix. And it looks like an ambitious one--with a variety of alluring ports of call.

THE very title of the book, "The Age of Ideas," evokes the eagerness, the daring, the holy intoxication with thought that made the Enlightenment a new and greater Renaissance. It might suggest that the Philosophes dwelt in a world of abstractions: mills of logic grinding the trite into the inane.

THIS one-volume selection from the twenty-five publications of the Texas Folklore Society is an excellent introduction to the folklore and the folkregional spirit of Texas. As such it will please both the folklore audience and the Texas audience, since Texans not only like to read about themselves but have created a readable Texas myth as part of their abundant, living folk heritage.
LONDON, April 23--The two paramount issues on which the British election four weeks from Thursday will be won or lost emerged from the clamor of political dispute this week.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Text of a statement by the State Department today on the proposal of Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier, to negotiate with, the United States over differences in the Formosa irea follows: The Department of State has received press reports concerning the statement of Chou En-lai at the Bandung conference.
ALBANY. A PERPLEXED Councilman of a city in upstate New York telephoned me not long ago to ask. "What kind of pipes will the state let us use for our city sewers?"

TO THE EDITOR: In his excellent article, Mr. Bowles quite rightly did not mention the reciprocity which is necessary in the goodwill business. But there appear to be some very concrete things which I, as an Indian, see can be done on both sides to improve the rapidly deteriorating situation in Indo-American relations.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 17 --A seven-year plan to make Thailand a "full-fledged democracy" has been proposed by one of the country's top leaders.

PARIS. THE sixty-sixth annual exhibition of Independent Artists has opened with 3,748 works on display. And, as the headline in the newspaper Paris Presse I'Intransigeant said: "This is 3,600 too many."

WASHINGTON, April 23-- When Administration strategists look back some day and try to figure out what hit the reciprocal trade bill, they may perceive that it was a combination of factors that included: (1) Their own failure to analyze correctly the growing pressures in the country and the Congress for a more protective policy on trade.
NEW DELHI, April 23 (AP)-- The United States is off to a flying start in an effort to hold its commercial position in India against the efforts of the Communist bloc.

FOR the wildflower enthusiast who plans to start a new garden or expand an existing plot this season, the next few weeks will be busy ones indeed. Because most wildlings are sensitive to heat and drought, planting must be done before the hot weather arrives.

Red China's Prime Minister, Chou En-lai, has extended to the United States a guarded suggestion of direct negotiation on tension in the Far East, with specific reference to the Formosa Strait. His proposal has been forwarded to this country through the good offices of the Prime Minister of Pakistan, one of our associates in the Southeast Asia Defense Organization.

LONDON, April 23--British officals expressed interest today in Chou En-lai's statement that Communist China would be willing to negotiate with the United States about reducing tension in the Far East.
CARROLLTON, Ga., April 23 (AP)--Betsy Rawls today held her 4-stroke lead over Patty Berg after the second round of the $5,000 Carrollton women's open golf tournament. Miss Rawls shot a 74 for 141.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 19--The union of the old and the new in Yugoslavia's struggle for industrialization can be seen at the Zeleznik machinery plant here, one of the show pieces of President Tito's regime.
Tributes to Dr. Albert Einstein were paid by several rabbis in sermons here yesterday.
An "American Arts Festival," a two-day conference on nonliterary arts, will be sponsored Friday and Saturday by the Barnard College American Civilization Committee.

THERE is no such thing as a generic "Asian mind." That myth has by now been exploded. But there are many Asian minds and those minds are doing more thinking along political lines than they have ever done before. If we are to do the job we want to do in Asia we need to know something about those thoughts.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- Two Democratic members of Congress today urged passage of a bill to subsidize industries damaged by foreign imports. In this way they sought to head off "crippling amendments" to the Administration's reciprocal trade bill.

Five policemen fired fifteen shots early yesterday morning at an automobile loaded with stolen traffic signs and speeding in the midtown area. They stopped the car at Twelfth Avenue and Fifty-first Street and detained six youths for arraignment this morning in Felony court.
A crowded fishing boat and an outward-bound fregihter collided in a dense fog off the New Jersey coast yesterday afternoon.

AS everyone now knows-- thanks to Walt Disney's TV series, movie and song about David Crockett --the "king of the wild frontier" was born in Tennessee, "kilt him a b'ar when he was only 3," fought valiantly in the Creek "Injun" War, "patched up the crack in the Liberty Bell" while a Congressman, and died the greatest fighter of all at the Alamo.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, April 12--Changed tourist habits and a new class of travelers have revolutionized the business of companies carrying New Zealanders abroad. Since the war, the largest members of travelers have been young persons in their late teens and early twenties, mostly girls.

BONN, Germany, April 23-- Whatever enthusiasm there may have been in West Germany for armament and alliance with the West has been dimmed by the sudden, sharp upsurge of public opinion on the issue of national reunification.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 23 (AP)--F. Scott McBride, head of the Anti-Saloon League of America for thiriy-two years, died today. His age was 82.
Much has been said about the Modern Young Woman, and not all of it has been complimentary. There is this to be added to the record: Miss 1955 sews not only as well as did her grandmother, but better.

THE curtain of England's romantic tradition is rolled back in "A Villa in Summer" to reveal the little foxes at their busiest. This is an explicit and believable picture of human relationships tossed and torn between pre- and post-war values; between the new struggle for bare comfort, and the old stately maintenance of the decencies.

CLIFTON FADIMAN celebrates his fiftieth birthday, give or take a few months, with this selection of nearly as many critical and familiar essays, culled from his work as a man of letters during the past quarter century.
STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, April 23--Diplomats from sixty-one nations walked in procession through the streets of this market town today to honor its first citizen.

THE season of American dance, enlisting the services of Martha Graham, Jose Limon, Pearl Lang, John Butler, Valerie Bettis and Anna Sokolow with their companies, together with Paul Draper, Pauline Koner, Daniel Nagrin, Iris Mabry, Janet Collins and Ann Halprin as soloists, and Doris Humphrey as a nonperforming choreographer, has announced the full repertory of its two-week season at the ANTA Theatre, beginning May 3.
A decade has passed since New York veterans began borrowing money to go into business.

The 21-year-old Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act (RTAA) permits the President to cut U. S. tariffs in return for like concessions by other countries. The act, whose intent is to increase world trade, is due to expire in June. The consensus is that it has increased trade.
Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Silk Stockings" on Tuesday night at the Imperial Theatre for the benefit of the St. Luke's Hospital Building Fund.

"AROUND the World in Eighty Days," which has been on Michael Todd's agenda since September, "will go before the cameras in Hollywood in four to six weeks," the peripatetic producer revealed last week.

If the third annual Huckins Memorial cruiser contest this season is not the biggest predicted -log event of all time, it won't be because Chairman James S. Stuart of Plandome Hills, L. I., didn't try hard enough.

THE explosive impact of Robert Ruark's "Something of Value" will reverberate for a long time to come on both sides of the Atlantic. Americans --and Britons, too, for that matter-- have hitherto been spared the details of the tortures practiced by the Mau Mau in their uprising against the white man in Kenya.
Employes in downtown business districts represent an important "captive market" for retailers in the areas, since they account for more than one-third of the shopping done there.
NEW CITY, N. Y., April 23-- Mayor Wagner of New York told 600 persons here tonight that Rockland County Democrats were leading the way in an assault on upstate Republican strongholds.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- The political climate of the nation today is a little like the uncertain peace that reigns in the Formosa Strait--a continuing two-way barrage of propaganda underlined at strategic intervals by a hair-raising burst of genuine artillery.

THIS book is a projection of earth-moon commuting as it has already begun (in a rudimentary sense) with such rockets as the "WAC Corporal" and as it will presumably conclude with the establishment of a lunar spaceport.

NAPLES, Italy, April 23-- This city has a reputation for harboring a cult of "sweet loafing." Yet American and Italian industrialists who tried out the Neapolitans as workers found them as efficient as those of the more traditionally industrial North.
The Thomas Alva Edison Foundation announced yesterday that George E. Probst, former assistant professor of history at the University of Chicago, had been named executive director of the organization.
SOME lessons in portraiture by a master photographer, together with some examples by a pupil and friend, were placed on exhibition last week at the Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South.

A program of financial assistance to women's colleges, one of the first of its kind, has been instituted by Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati. This is part of a scholarship program under which the contribution to higher education being made by the company will be increased from the current $328,000 to $650,000 a year.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 23--A commission of the Dutch Reformed Church has recommended that the Strijdom Government take over control of all education in South Africa.

To the Drama Editor: As general manager of "Salute to France," which will be produced in Paris this summer, I want to express to your critic the gratitude of all concerned for his recent endorsement of our play selections.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Government today invited representatives of forty-eight national organizations to meet in Washington Wednesday for a report on available supplies of the Salk polio vaccine.

New Jersey Republican leaders and party stalwarts listened last night to a strong plea for the re-election of President Eisenhower. They also heard a condemnation of the spending policies of Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
Starting salaries of New York University engineering graduates have increased yearly since 1948.

The crunch of peanut shells in "croocial" moments at Ebbets Field may lack some of its old rhythm this season. The cost of the goobers is going up. And their price may soon cease to be ''peanuts," assuming that the consumer goes on consuming.

MAY DAY breakfasts, which have been held annually on May 1 in Rhode Island since 1867, will be served in church and Grange halls throughout the state on April 30, May 1 and 2 this year because May 1 is a Sunday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 20--Sweden is radically restricting credit. Installment buying, principally of automobiles, will be curtailed sharply.
Business men may find bank loans more costly late this summer. That is the opinion of officials in some of the country's leading banks which have headquarters in Manhattan.

What most cosmologists regard as the finest scientific mind that has appeared since Newton formulated his laws of motion nearly three hundred years ago passed on when Albert Einstein died last week. We may have to wait anotner three centuries before another mind like it gives science an impetus as powerful as that given by the theory of relativity.
THE fly rod, once rarely seen away from the trout stream, is now being pressed into service on lakes, bays, coastal rivers, and even in the ocean.

HONG KONG, April 23-- Signs of a spring famine in Communist China are filtering from the mainland. At the same time the Peiping Government is showing a growing concern over the long-range agricultural picture.

OUTER doors may be closed easily against backed-up air pressure by installing an "Easy-close" aluminum door valve. The valve is mounted in a 1-inch hole drilled into a center rail or panel, and allows release of air as the door is closed.
NORFOLK, Va., April 23-- The nuclear-powered submarine, the Nautilus, will soon test the capabilities of the Atlantic Fleet Anti-Submarine Force, which has headquartered here.
Four thousand delegates to the national convention of the Young Women's Christian Association were assured yesterday that the United Nations was succeeding, despite its handicaps.

CAIRO, April 23--An Egyptian spokesman accused Israel tonight of quietly rejecting essential United Nations proposals to reduce fighting on the Gaza frontier while loudly announcing acceptance of minor suggestions to give a false impression of good faith.
BONN, Germany, April 23 -- The United States is joining West Germany's smaller neighbors in demanding a change in this country's policies of restricting agricultural imports.
Auction sales this week focus attention on Queen Anne and Chippendale furniture, pictures and other art property now on exhibition at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

President, Theatre Network Television, Inc. IN a recent article in The New York Times entitled "ClosedCircuit Fiasco," Willard Swire, executive director of the American National Theatre and Academy, said he was disenchanted with closed-circuit television as a medium for bringing the legitimate theatre to the public.

CHUQUICAMATA, Chile, April 5--The extraordinary mineral wealth of Chile is best seen here in the Andes where the Anaconda Copper Mining Company has its huge mine, and down south of Santiago in the same great range where the Braden Copper Company has its famous "mountain of copper" at Sewell.

VIRGINIA BEACH. Va., April 23--Ed (Porky) Oliver of Lemont, Ill., and and Chandler Harper of Portsmouth, Va., fired their third consecutive sub-par rounds today to tie for the 517,500 Virginia Beach open golf tournament lead.
BALTIMORE. "I AM very anxious to find my wife, who has been an amnesia victim for several years," began a recent letter to the Social Security Agency. "Her name is -- and she has been known as --.

PARIS--Napoleon did not have to search across the English Channel for a nation of shopkeepers. He headed one. In no other European country has the small family business become such an interesting institution as in France.

B. U.--Fellowships Boston University announces several fellowships for the academic year 1955-56 to be awarded by the African research and studies, program, a graduate course for research and teaching in the field of African studies.
FEZ, French Morocco, April 23--The signing of a protocol of agreement as a prelude to home rule for Tunisia precipitated mixed reactions in North Africa.
Herman Pilnik of Argentina gained sole possession of first place in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires yesterday.

The edition of Chekhov's letters that has accompanied me since I was a lad is that of Constance Garnett. Mrs. Garaett wrote beautiful English, but even a Russianless reader can see that her Russian was not impeccable.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23 --Senator Lourival Fontes, long a right-hand man of the late President Getulio Vargas, has added his voice to those calling for closer Brazilian relations with the Soviet Union and Red China.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP)--Home runs by Willie Jones and Stan Palys, a rookie, helped the Philadelphia Phillies beat Pittsburgh, today, 8-0.
Even though Johnny Kucks did not go all the way in his first starting assignment in the majors, yesterday was a big day in the life of the 21-year-old right-hander from Stanhope, N. J.
An outdoor boat show will be held for three days, beginning May 4, at the Cryder's Point Apartments, a new $6,000,000 development overlooking Long Island Sound in the Whitestone section of Queens.

The United Nations, which in its early years handed down decision after decision on the most vital issues of peace and war, has taken such a back seat in recent months that the question of overhauling its machinery has almost been forgotten.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) --The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy is quietly sifting "stories and rumors" about Allen Whitfield, nominated by President Eisenhower to the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (Science Service)--Fewer icebergs than usual will plague United States-European shipping this year, Louis A. Post of the Navy Hydrographic Office predicted here today.
HARTFORD, April 23--The Connecticut General Assembly is getting set for a major debate on capital punishment.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (AP)--Hasty House Farms today won the 510,000-added Ben Ali Handicap at Keeneland for the fourth straight year. Sea O Erin galloped home in front by a length and one-half.

Louis Schleifer, a veteran realty trader, yesterday announced that he had formed a new company called Schleifer Hotels, Inc., for the purpose of buying and operating hotels in leading cities throughout the country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23--The Yale University baseball team, bunching all its five hits in a five-run seventh inning, defeated Navy, 5-3, today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Yale Field.

MAX BEERBOHM did a series of drawings -- I know whether to call them caricatures or cartoons-- with captions which were dialogues between the Young Self and the Old Self. In this fashion, always with amusing and sometimes with devastating effect, the budding Shaw, Bennett or Wells--for Beerbohm's specimens were writers--was confronted by his full-blown personality.

THE man of today is exposed to influences which are bent on robbing him of all confidence in his own thinking. The spirit of spiritual dependence to which he is called on to surrender is in everything that he hears or reads; it is in the people whom he meets every day; it is in the parties and associations which have claimed him as their own; it pervades all the circumstances of his life.

WEST HAVEN, Conn., April 23--An investigation into the New Haven County Temporary Home for Children here has cleared the staff of allegations of "brutality." But severe criticism was leveled at the administration of the home by the Child Welfare League of America, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Harold Stassen made his debut this week as President Eisenhower's disarmament chief by asking the nation's editors for help in combating cynicism and defeatism about the possibility of disarmament.

PARIS. AS a citizen of one of those nations of old Europe where the hunt for honorary distinctions is a popular pastime, I would like to offer the benefit of our experience in the delicate matter of handing out awards to deserving citizens.
The Cord Meyer Development Company is adding another apartment project to its long list of building operations in the Forest Hills section of Queens during the past half-century.
COSBY, Tenn., April 23--Former President Truman and 35,000 East Tennessee mountain folk will have a grass roots get together here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Defense Department is studying for possible security violations a report recently issued by the Senate Republican Policy Committee on national defense.

WHETHER you are a gardener who likes to cook or a cook who uses what spouse or handyman gardens, you are going to enjoy and profit by Ruth Matson's "Cooking by the Garden Calendar." Mrs. Matson confines herself to what is perfectly possible in any household garden and she rejects the exotic in recipes.
Dean James A. Pike of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) said yesterday he sometimes felt it was unfortunate that "being a Christian is such a safe thing."
One of the port's most reformminded dock locals is laying the groundwork for a second venture in equipping its longshoremen for better citizenship.
MUNICH, Germany, April 23 --Radio Free Europe will face a challenge in the Bavarian Parliament May 10.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 (AP)--Arthur Lall, Indian delegate who knows business as well as politics, says the Americans are missing a good bet by staying out of the steel race in India.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 23 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Netherlands and Belgium joined today in urging a six-nation meeting on European integration before the end of next month.
The American economic system is continuing to expand and is capable of providing even more jobs and higher incomes in the future, according to the Twentieth Century Fund.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 23 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of New York, said today he had asked Premier Chou En-lai of Communist-China for a conference on the United States fliers imprisoned by the Peiping regime as spies. He has not yet received any answer.

NEWPORT, R. I., April 23-- Historic building's and homes of the eighteenth century, as well as famous estates of a later era, will be opened to the public during a ten-day festival from July 4 through the French national holiday, July 14.
A Communist movement to usurp the church's position in the life of German youth is being opposed strongly by the church there, an American church woman reported last week.
HOLLYWOOD. EDUCATIONAL television's growth, uneven and disappointing though it may be in post sections of the country, has brought forth at least two exceptional programs hereabouts.
The Squadron A polo team defeated the New York A. C., 8-4, in the second game of the national senior indoor championship last night.
The Squadron A polo team defeated the New York A. C., 8-4, in the second game of the national senior indoor championship last night.
LAWRENCE, Kan., April 23 --Rain and hail washed out another bid by Wes Santee for a four-minute mile today. But skies cleared in time for four meet records to be set in the thirtieth Kansas Relays.

THOUGH I have lived for years in New England, I am sure that I get my love for small fruits from my boyhood days on a Pennsylvania hill farm. I always knew where to find the berry bushes and grapevines that grew in fence corners and on uncultivated land.
Mayor Wagner toured Staten Island yesterday to see, first hand, public projects he had seen only on the planning boards.

What will Big Steel show? How will "Bethlehem" do? These are the two big questions Wall Street analysts have been asking themselves--and trying to predict--the last few days in their favorite quarterly guessing game.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 22-- Premier Adnan Menderes has offered to meet with former President Ismet Inonu, Opposition leader, to arrange a political truce. The conference is expected to take place in two or three days.
PARIS. THE familiar division of the New York theatre-Broadway and off Broadway-- has its Paris equivalent in "Theatre du Boulevard" and "Theatre d'essai."

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP)--The Peary family's most cherished possession, the American flag carried by Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary when he discovered the North Pole, will be enshrined permanently here May 6.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 23-- At least $670,000,000 must be spent between now and 1963 by public and private utilities of northwest Washington if they are to meet the area's rapidly growing electric power needs, the Puget Sound Utilities Council was told today.

BONN, Germany, April 23-- Tomorrow's election of a new state parliament (Landtag) in Lower Saxony will provide the first test of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's foreign policy since ratification of the Paris agreements to arm West Germany.
PUTTING up and taking down the familiar woodenframed window screens has been a classic chore over since modern man started to try to keep insects outdoors, where they belonged.
The annual intercollegiate debating tournament last week at West Point focused attention on an extracurricular activity that enjoys great popularity on American campuses.
TRENTON, April 23--The Right Rev. Alfred L. Banyard was installed today as the seventh Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.
TRENTON, April 23--The Right Rev. Alfred L. Banyard was installed today as the seventh Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.

POSSESSION of a possibly rare variety of United States airmail stamped envelopes was announced here last week by John W. Nicktin, a West Forty-second Street dealer who is especially interested in aerophilately.

For Ages 12 to 16. IN her first novel for older girls the author of "Trouble on Old Smoky" and other books for children tackles an ambitious theme--a young Negro girl's determination to be a professional dancer.
An unusual survey of trampship casualties shows that warbuilt vessels are the most likely to meet misfortune. Ships built before 1930 were found less likely to have accidents.

PARAMOUNT'S use of Vista Vision to show "Strategic Air Command" is a sensible application of method to material. So many of he subjects that have been treated in the new wide-screen processes have been so utterly inappropriate to the willfully magnified size that it does the heart good to see one brought forth that is right in the large proportions.
LONDON, April 23--A male dancing star who had deserted the Bulgarian State Song and Dance Company dropped his request for political asylum in Britain and returned to the company today.

BECAUSE Portuguese is an almost unknown language in this country and because so little of the literature written in it has been adequately translated, such books as Fred P. Ellison's brief study of four contemporary Brazilian novelists are especially welcome.
A Bronx physician for a union of delicatessen and restaurant employes administered antipolio vaccine Friday to the 5year-old daughter of a union member.

It is now more than a quarter of a century since Oct. 24, 1929, a day that has been designated by historians of the Wall Street cataclysm of that year as Black Thursday. Oct. 24, 1929, didn't acquire this claim to a dubious immortality because it was either the first or the last of the paroxysms that shook the market place.

A GOOD example of how a nice, unstartling voice can be parlayed into a million -dollar film property lies in the success story of Doris Kappelhoff of Cincinnati, better known, to audiences who demand only a nice, matching smile, as Doris Day of Hollywood.

SUZANNE BLOCK and four of her musical friends celebrated yesterday the 391st anniversary of the birth of Shakespeare in a most appropriate way. They hired Town Hall in the late afternoon and presented a concert of the sort of music with which he was familiar.
GOODWELL, Okla., April 18 --The Southern high plains have gone through another period of drought and high winds. It was as bad in some sections as the one last year.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 23--Chou En-lai announced here today that Communist China was prepared to negotiate directly with the United States over Formosa and Far East questions in general.

KANSAS CITY, April 23-- Chicago's White Sox overwhelmed the Kansas City Athletics today, 29-6, tying the modern major league scoring record for one team for one game as they lofted seven home runs out of the gusty Municipay Stadium.

A YOUNG mother we know came home from the hospital recently with a little baby and a big complaint. "I've been a mother for seven whole days." she said, her first afternoon at home, "but the baby's been mine for just the past four hours.

REPLACEMENTS for some old LP disks of the MahlerBruckner axis have been coming through. A recording of Bruckner's Third Symphony, on a London disk presenting Hans Knappertsbusch and the Vienna Philharmonic, is far and beyond any version previously available.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) --In his speech tonight Senator George said: "I unhesitatingly say that this nation should be big enough and great enough, through its high officials, to sit down and talk. It is high time that we should relieve the tensions of the world if we can."

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- Senator George H. Bender, Republican of Ohio, demanded today an end to what he called "an apparent stall" in the Senate Labor Committee on President's Eisenhower's school construction bill.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (AP)--Scientists have made an encouraging start toward drugs to protect human beings from hydrogen bomb fall-out or radioactivity.

BOGOTA, COLOMBIA. High in the foothills of the Guadalupe Mountain overlooking the plateau of Bogota, a new concept of the dignity and worth of the individual is being made a part of the culture and mores of this South American nation.

AMERICAN-GROWN lilies for the gardens of this country are being produced in the East and North as well as in the extensive fields of the West Coast. Available for planting this year are nine new varieties of garden lilies developed under a United States Department of Agriculture lily-breeding program conducted at the Reedsville Experiment Farm in Preston County, West Virginia.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) --The Defense Department reported today that the number of Negro officers and enlisted men in the armed services had more than doubled since 1949.

THERE is in all of us--isn't there? --a longing for what we fondly believe were "the good old days." Each new generation somehow feels that the current fashions--in women's clothes, in painting, in cars, in literature, in furniture design, in movie queens, in popular songs--are quite mad and quite hopeless; it feels certain that things used to be a lot better before the world began going to hell in a car without a running board.
The college of electors of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans will elect members to the national shrine in October from a ballot of 209 famous persons.
Cardinal Spellman appealed last night for support of the 1955 Archdiocesan Catholic Charities campaign.

On Wednesday the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City will hold its convocation to inaugurate Dr. Lawrence L. Bethel as its second president. The institute is probably the only public college devoted exclusively to the cultural and technological education of the future leaders of the fashion industries.
TRENTON, April 23--The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene here Monday after a threeweek recess for the primary election campaign.
Suez Canal traffic reached a record high in its eighty-fiveyear history in 1954.
Many ideas in home planning that are "catching on" in this part of the country are incorporated in a model going on display today in a community on Long Island's North Shore.

OSWEGO, Ore. SOME two generations of Oregonians have known and grown the magnolia, but in just the last decade there has been a remarkable increase of interest in this genus of beautiful flowering trees and shrubs.
A record was set last week by the City of New York in the sale of tax-delinquent realty. In a four-day sale of properties on Staten Island, bidders acquired 771 parcels containing 1,859 lots.

IN the thirty-seven years of Bolshevik rule in the Kremlin, scores of Russian refugees and escapees, as well as scores of emigres and fugitives of nonRussian nationality, have published accounts of life in the Soviet Union--but no one (I tell you, almost in a shout) has ever written a book quite like this one.

JULIAN SYMONS, English poet, critic and biographer, seems to produce suspense novels only at the rate of one every two years; but infallibly each is among the most satisfying books of its particular season.
BONN, Germany, April 23-- A true capital market, the last major apparatus needed to drive this economy forward under its own steam, has begun to function in West Germany.

Teaching and learning art will be surveyed in a free lecture, "Art Education Today," on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. One of five in a series on art education, the lecture will be by Simon Lissim, artist, ceramist and head of the library's Art Education Project.

VANCOUVER, B. C., April 18 --Delegates to the convention of the British Columbia-Yukon section of Canada's Socialist party, which ended here today, discussed one of the touchier questions in Canadian politics--the reintroduction of provincial income tax.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 23--Whatever else may or may not develop as a result of the conference of twenty-nine Asian and African countries being held in this Indonesian mountain town, it is clear that a lot of nations that never before have had the chance to march in the limelight of world attention are at the center of the stage this week.

BELLPORT, L. I., April 23-- Miss Madge Loughlin was married to Lieut. Robert Mack Hubbard, U. S. A., Corps of Engineers, here this morning in Mary Immaculate Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Loughlin of Bellport and 242 East Seventy-second Street, New York.
VIENNA, April 23--The dismissal and disgrace this week of Imre Nagy, Premier of Hungary, was a logical sequel to the demotion of Georgi M. Malenkov Soviet Premier.

Norwalk, Conn., April 23-- This community joined others in Fairfield County yesterday in tightening its regulations to control outdoor fires. High, losses from uncontrolled grass and brush blazes led to the move.
HOVE, England, April 23 (Reuters)--Basil Gill, whose career as a Shakespearean actor extended over nearly fifty years, died tonight at his home here. He was 78 years old.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 23--Jack Sutphen, Bob Erskine and Arthur Knapp finished in that order in the annual "ocean race" for skippers of Larchmont Yacht Club's frostbite dinghy fleet today. They crossed the line close together after a sail of about 4 1/2 miles from Larchmont to Sands Point, L. I.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Warner Brothers, which got many a motion picture idea out of newspaper headlines during the Thirties, has not lost its interest in contemporary drama. The studio has evidenced interest in the biography of Albert Einstein by filing claim with the motion picture industry's Title Registration Bureau to the following names for a prospective movie: "The Life of Albert Einstein" and "The Story of Albert Einstein."
Although Gertrude Edwards did not devote the best years of her life to painting, she is reaping artistic benefits from it in her old age.
Cardinal Spellman, at mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, invoked God's blessing on the thirty-sixth annual fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities.
The congregation of the Riverside Church will meet May 5 to vote on the proposed construction of a parish house on the south side of the tower of the church.
The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced Yesterday grants totaling $968,000 to help 248 Americans continue their studies in science, education and art.
The Coast Guard and its functions in this port will be the subject of a lecture here today by Ensign T. W. Mahan of the staff of Capt. F. K. Johnson, Captain of the Port.
Blue and gold banners of the Greater New York Fund, the city's most inclusive appeal, are flying throughout the city today as reminders that the 1955 campaign is opening.

The naming of Dorsey W. Woodson, 27 years old, of Newport, Ark., as the winner of the first $500 Borden Graduate Award in Journalism at Columbia University was announced yesterday. The announcement was made by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the university's Graduate School of Journalism.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Following is the text of a speech of Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, to the American Society of Newspaper Editors last night:

The report from Moscow in The Times recently about the dismissal of Georgi F. Alexandrov as Minister of Culture and your report some days before listing the name of Vassily I. Chuikov among Soviet generals promoted to the rank of marshal, carry a morbid fascination for those concerned with the vaccilating fortunes of captive Soviet Jewry.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 24 -- The Government of South Vietnam has protested to Bao Dai, the Chief of State, against his habit of dealing directly with rebel forces.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which operates seventy-five department stores coast to coast, including Stern Brothers in this city, achieved record sales of $543,984,209 in the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31 and increased earnings by $1,421,381 over the previous fiscal year.

COSBY, Tenn., April 24 -- Former President Truman delivered today what he called "a nonpolitical Sunday sermon to help convert some Republicans to the right way of living." His message was spoken on a grassy plateau at the foot of the Great Smoky Mountains in east Tennessee's Republican party stronghold.

PARIS, April 24 (AP) -- Percy Bassett of Philadelphia scored a technical knockout over Seraphin Ferrer, French champion, in the tenth and last round of their lightweight match at the Parc des Princes Stadium today.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 24 -- Scientists from the five continents assembled in the semi-arid Southwest this weekend to discuss a very dry subject -- the one-third of the earth's land mass that is desert.

Programs with domestic, economic or social aims will absorb $12,268,000,000, or about 20 per cent, of the Federal budget for the fiscal year that will start July 1, the Tax Foundation reported yesterday.

PARIS, Monday, April 25 -- By heavier balloting than on the previous Sunday, the French in yesterday's runoff in the cantonal elections returned mostly incumbent candidates, with a slight movement toward the Left.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., April 24 -- The two-day army map maneuver Raindrop II ended here today with a successful United States counter-attack to the Rhine.

In the leading editorial of your April 14 issue your newspaper comments on the fact that the recent report of the Hoover Commission on Legal Services and Procedure failed to recommend an administrative court on immigration matters. The fact of the matter is that nine members of the commission's fourteen-man task force did so recommend in their report released April 18 by the commission.
TAIPEI, Formosa, April 24 -- The Chinese Nationalists declared today through their Foreign Minister they would "never sit at the same table" with representatives of Communist China.

HONG KONG, April 24 -- Peiping newspapers today front-paged the proposal of Communist China's Premier Chou En-lai for negotiations on Formosa and other Far Eastern questions, but no editorial comment or elaboration was immediately forthcoming.

Brown Gold is the name, poetic but justifiably so, of a new coffee being introduced at Fraser-Morris, 872 Madison Avenue, and Charles, 340 Madison Avenue. A blend made up entirely of coffees grown in Colombia, it is potently delicious.
Joshua Logan is planning to set up a professional workshop that will do for musicals what the Actors Studio has been doing for straight plays.

BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP) -- Hoot Evers got a pinch-hit double and scored on an infield grounder in the tenth inning to give Baltimore a 2-1 victory over Washington in the first game of a double-header today. The Senators came back to defeat the Orioles in the second contest, 5 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, said today the United Nations was "completely ineffective" as an instrument of peace and the United States should withdraw "forthwith."
A pop fly that fell safely in front of Hank Bauer some forty feet on the grass behind second base gave the Boston Red Sox a 1 -- 0 victory over the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- An effort is being made within the Administration to "neutralize" the Department of Agriculture security officer who precipitated the Wolf Ladejinsky case.
The Dodgers had a ball game and a series with the hated Giants all wrapped up in the icy setting of Ebbets Field yesterday.
Grain and time charter business pushed rates up last week in the ship charter market.
Michael J. Quill called upon union transit workers yesterday not to report "sick" today. Many are expected to do this before the new state sick-leave law goes into effect next Sunday.
In the New York Times of April 7 the following statement is attributed to Dr. Walter Adams, Professor of Economics at Michigan State College:

The last Wall Street investigation prior to the recent "friendly study" of the stock market by Senator Fulbright's Committee on Banking and Currency was not, as many persons believe, the Pecora inquiry of 1933-34. It was the so-called anti-monopoly

ALBANY, April 24 (AP) -- The State Police today arrested two brothers from Connecticut who, they charged, used a ticket-switching routine to evade a total of $87.40 in Thruway tolls over a three-month period.
AMSTERDAM, April 24 -- A feature in the stock market here last week was a spectacular rise in Philips Lamps.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Hoover Commission's recommendations on food and clothing in Government were based on a report of a task force headed by Joseph P. Binns, managing director of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York and executive vice president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation.
If firemen want to watch a baseball game, prizefight or horse race, they will have to do so on their own time after tomorrow.
ST.-CHAMOND, France, April 20 -- Just before 6 P. M. last Sunday Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, left his house on a hillside and walked down a curving road to the nearest polling place.

The 423 agencies of the Greater New York Fund, in the words of John A. Coleman, chairman of the board of the fund, represent "human kindness so organized that from one end of our town men and women of goodwill can reach out and help a stranger at the other end."
Discomfort became adventure yesterday for seventeen Brooklynites who wanted to learn how the American Red Cross evacuated persons from a hurricane-ravaged area.

Leon Ross and Jacob Cohen, in a purchase for investment, have acquired the store and apartment building at 25 Watsessing Avenue in Bloomfield, N. J. Recently reconditioned, the structure contains two stores and fourteen apartments. It was sold by Henry Rokita and Theodore Jasieniecki in a deal negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP) -- Max Surkont's pitching and Dale Long's hitting finally paid off for the Pittsburgh Pirates today as they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 1, in the first game of a scheduled double-header.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- A warning that if current social pressures for conformity continue, man may well end up as a one-headed monster in a space museum was heard here yesterday.
The threat of cuts in United States import quotas on sugar from Cuba also endangers continuance of the latter's substantial imports from this country, a trade group warned yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Monday, April 25 -- The Social Democrats and their ally the Refugee party, or All-German Bloc, defeated the Federal Government coalition by a thin margin in yesterday's state elections in Lower Saxony.
HANOVER, Germany, Monday, April 25 (AP) -- Complete returns today gave West Germany's anti-rearmament Socialists a victory in the Lower Saxony State election.

Hares Enterprises, Inc., bought the six-story apartment house for fifty-nine families on plot 134 by 100 feet at 3764 Bronx Boulevard, near 219th Street, the Bronx, through Wishnow Horowitz, brokers. The purchase was made subject to mortgages of $200,000.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 24 -- Delegates to the Asian-African conference here looked up from their week's work to note with satisfaction, and some surprise that they had achieved unanimity of a sort from Tokyo to Tripoli.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, urged President Eisenhower today to show the nation's gratitude to Dr. Jonas E. Salk for his new polio vaccine by "loosening the purse-strings" on Federal medical research.

If there had been any lingering doubt that the recession of 1953-54 was now definitely behind us that doubt should be effectively resolved with the publication by the McGraw-Hill Economic Department of the capital investment plans of American business for 1955.
Commercial paper outstanding on the books of dealers at the end of March totaled $681,000,000, a decline of 3 per cent from February and 7 per cent from March, 1954.

The appointment of Dr. Marion H. Gillim, Associate Professor of Economics at Barnard College, as executive officer of the Barnard economics department, has been announced by Dr. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of the college.

ATLANTA, April 26 (UP) -- Southern governors who were unable to end the telephone strike today turned to the Louisville and Nashville Railroad dispute. An L. N. freight train was wrecked yesterday at an open switch and five crewmen were injured.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that a New Jersey manufacturer was making illegal use of the controversial "fair-trade" laws.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., April 24 -- Two 17-year-old boys spent a chilly half-hour in Great South Bay here this afternoon after their outboard runabout capsized. The incident occurred in the same area where a 25-year-old Navy veteran drowned yesterday afternoon in a similar accident.

A twelve-story building at 133 West Forty-seventh Street and a nine-story structure abutting in the rear of 134 West Forty-eighth Street have Been sold by Manral, Inc., to the Ander Hotel Corporation, Eugene Held, president.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 24 (UP) -- The Asian-African conference called today for the suspension of nuclear bomb tests and the prohibition of nuclear weapons under effective international control as the first step toward world disarmament.
The orphan, indomitable hero of much of our folklore, appears to be one of our vanishing Americans.

David Rockefeller has been elected to his ninth successive term as president of Morningside Heights, Inc., the welfare arm of thirteen religious, educational and medical institutions in the vicinity of Columbia University.

The late Dr. Albert Einstein's autobiography, the manuscript of which was originally prepared for the Library of Living Philosophers, will be issued late next month by Tudor Publishing Company. It was the scientist's wish that this material on his early development, the men and ideas who influenced him and his views of the world and his place in it be published as a separate volume only after his death.
Concerted action to preserve Federal regulation of natural-gas rates was urged yesterday by State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits.

Gen. Walter Bedell Smith has been named board chairman and president of A. M. F. Atonics, Inc., a newly formed and wholly owned subsidiary of the American Machine and Foundry Company. This was announced over the week-end by Morehead Patterson, board chairman and president of the parent company.

LONDON, April 24 -- Col. Denis Bates, chairman of the Cunard Steamship Company, said today there was no permitted opening for the line in passenger air traffic over the Atlantic. For the company to embark on a worldwide charter business scarcely seems worth while, he added.
WASHINGTON, April 24, (UP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman announced today he would introduce legislation tomorrow to oust Scott McLeod as head of the refugee program.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 24 -- A quiet improvement has been taking place in Caribbean affairs, thanks to the new policies of President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica.
One of the largest food-plan operators in the metropolitan area has agreed to refrain from "bait advertising" practices, Attorney General Jacob Javits announced yesterday.

Paul Hindemith, German composer, has been selected as the winner of the 1955 Sibelius award, a prize of about $35,000. The award is being offered annually to great men in music of science by the Finnish ship-owner Antti Wihuri. Sibelius was the first winner.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 24 -- The Asian-African parley accepted as a conference paper today a proposal by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India for a study throughout Asia and Africa of radioactivity caused by nuclear weapons tests.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House tonight from a week-end of rest at his country home in Gettysburg, Pa.
CHICAGO, April 22 -- Peabody Coal Company stockholders, at a special meeting today, voted to recapitalize the company.

A conference of representatives of twenty-nine Asian and African states has now concluded. The meeting in Bandung, Indonesia, produced some plain speaking, some controversy, some agreement, many expressions of goodwill and a somewhat smaller degree of general solidarity than was expected. The free men were still free at Bandung and spoke accordingly.
Five films, including imports from England and Russia, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

ROME, April 24 -- Pope Pius XII said today that present-day man lived in an age of monumental scientific development but also in one of intellectual "confusion and anguish." He addressed the Pontifical Academy of Sciences.
MILAN, Italy, April 24 -- The Milan Trade Fair again has set a record in the number of exhibitors.
LONDON, April 24 -- The stock markets are still under the influence of the budget and the general election.
Support of the small Christian colleges of the United States was urged here yesterday by Dr. Gordon K. Chalmers, president of Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (UP) -- Ray Boone drove in four runs with a single and a homer against his former team-mates today as the Detroit Tigers scored a 6-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians. Frank Lary, rookie pitcher, gained his first major league victory.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- An organization of American World War II veterans announced tonight it had decided to accept an offer by Russian Army officers to attend an "Elbe River reunion" in Moscow next month.

Velsicol Corp, chemicals, in the Empire State Building, 350 5th Ave; Gugler Lithographic Co Inc. in 521 5th Ave through Fred F. Management Co Inc; Barclay Co Inc. exports: Arthur Richenthal, lawyer, in the Chanin Building, 122 E 42d St: Harry. J. Zweibel, lawyer, in 7 E 44th St; Harris Trust Savings Bank of Chicago, floor in the new Seamen's Bank for Savings Building, 30 Wall St -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, brokers.
Anger over the difficulties besetting persons eager to emigrate to the United States was expressed yesterday by six college students on the New York Times Youth Forum.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A code of ethics to be observed in setting up and administering employe health and Welfare programs was announced today for the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Uneasiness regarding Far Eastern developments, tightening prices for cash wheat and unfavorable crop news from the Southwest encouraged more active buying of wheat futures last week, with substantial price gains registered.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 -- A technological break-through in atomic weapons' development has occurred during the current series of atomic tests.
The "cream-puff treatment" for juvenile delinquents was decried yesterday by a Queens County Judge.
The National Jewish Welfare Board presented its 1955 Frank L. Weil awards yesterday to three Jewish leaders for achievement in their fields.
ALBANY, April 24 (AP) -- Governor Harriman signed a series of six bills today starting a $337,000 program to combat juvenile delinquency.

MIAMI, Fla., April 24 (AP) -- Forty policemen, assisted by firemen manning hoses, broke up a noisy crowd of about 500 persons last night at the Miami headquarters of the strike-bound Southern Bell Telephone Company.
A New York syndicate has signed a contract for the purchase of a site on South Broadway, Tarrytown, N. Y., for improvement with a taxpayer building to contain seven stores.

It's really simple. You start with Carl Norgauer, Lloyd Moglen and Norman Lebhar. Then you add their younger brothers, John Norgauer, Leslie Moglen and Bobble Lebhar. And presto! You have a formidable tennis squad.
OTTAWA, April 24 -- Two new trains designed to cut the surface distance between the Canadian East and West Coasts left here today for Vancouver.

During most of last week prices of domestic cotton futures moved moderately but steadily downward. At the close of trading Friday futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 3 to 26 points from the week-ago level.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- John Clifford Folger, Washington investment banker, was appointed today chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee. He will succeed F. Peavey Heffelfinger, Minneapolis grain dealer.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission tonight asked private industry to finance and build by early 1957 a nuclear reactor capable of testing larger materials than is now possible.
KARLSRUHE, Germany, April 24 (AP) -- Russia maintained supremacy in Greco-Roman wrestling tonight by winning six of the eight world championships.
The American Tobacco Company, Jack Benny's radio sponsor for eleven years, will drop the comedian's radio show and continue his television program next fall.
Gordon A. Roberts has been named manager of Federal Government activities in the European area for International Business Machines Corporation.

On April 11 the Hoover Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Govern-} ment released a report urging the l separation of the judicial from the administrative activities of the fifty federal boards and commissions such as the Interstate Commerce Commission, the National Labor Relations Board and the Federal Trade Commission.

A special service in celebration of St. George's Day was held yesterday in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine). Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese presided. The attendance was 5,000.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 24 (AP) -- The Indochinese kingdom of Laos and neighboring Communist-controlled North Vietnam signed a pact during the Asian-African conference here not to molest each other.
Twelve special events have been scheduled for the summer season of music at City College's Lewisohn Stadium.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 24 -- A landlocked home in suburban Connecticut seems hardly a proper museum for what is probably the world's largest collection of scrimshaw. Yet 2,000 engraved whale teeth and whalebone carvings cover the basement walls of Meylert M. Armstrong's Greenwich house.

More than $7,000,000 has been donated for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. The announcement was made last night at a dinner of the society of the founders of the college at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

" CLIMAX," the Thursday evening presentation on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has shown considerable improvement recently, but last week the hour-long live drama from Hollywood ran into a de luxe snafu.
Franklyn Russell of the New York Pioneer Club won the Rudolph Horak Memorial six-mile handicap road race through Queens yesterday. Russell covered the distance in 31 minutes 51 seconds.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 24 (AP) -- Tony Trabert routed Victor Seixas, the national champion, to win the twenty-first annual River Oaks tennis tournament today.

EN ROUTE TO EUROPE, April 24 -- Air power has become an immeasureably important arm of our foreign policy. Ability to retaliate against distant enemies has enabled the United States to play a decisive role in world affairs. Land-based and sea-based planes permit us to maintain swift communications between our Pacific and Atlantic allies.
TOKYO, April 24 (AP) -- The Peiping radio said today Red China would not ask Communist parties in Africa and Asia to disband, because that would be interfering in other countries' internal affairs.
March newspaper advertising came to 242,549,475 lines, according to Media Records. This was a gain of 12.2 per cent compared with the same month last year.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- State Department officials said today the next move was up to the Chinese Communists if they were sincere about their offer to negotiate with the United States over Formosa and Far Eastern questions.

Belmont Park, which ran its first racing show on May 4, 1905, will open its fiftieth anniversary meet today.
Two hundred members of the New York City chapter of the National Secretaries Association attended a breakfast yesterday to observe the opening of National Secretaries Week.
CAIRO April 24 -- The holy month of Ramadan in which Moslems are required to fast from dawn to sunset, begun today. Cannon boomed from the Mokattam hills overlooking Elazhar Mosque.
Terminal operators and shipping lines of the port have completed organization of a service to take over the business of loading and unloading trucks on the harbor's piers.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Two Senate leaders said today that Congress was going to show its displeasure with Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson and his farm policies by voting to him many millions of dollars more than he asked for.

A precocious child whose eyes somehow had strayed to the financial pages was overheard to inquire, the other day, "What do banks do besides merge?" After the adults had their chuckles the inquisitive one was told that banks were good places to keep money, and was urged to go forth to enjoy the sunshine and fresh air.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, said today he was "certain" Russia was "far ahead" of the United States in development of an intercontinental ballistics missile.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, gradually is being "encircled,". not by the Russians, but by special foreign policy assistants to the President.
