Two of Uncle Sam's most modern motor torpedo boats, the PT 809 and the PT 811, churned up the slate gray waters of the Upper Bay yesterday afternoon on a peaceful mission.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 24 -- Naute Mia, an 8-year-old brown gelding belonging to the Saxon Woods Farm of White Plains, was the ace of the two-day annual spring horse show of the Boulder Brook Club tonight.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Eddie Miksis batted in both runs as the Chicago Cubs downed the Cincinnati Redlegs, 2 -- 1, in the first game of a scheduled double-header today.

YORKVILLE VOCATIONAL HIGH SCHOOL, at 421 East Eighty-eighth Street, begins today a Shakespeare Festival Week. Miss Blanche Offer, acting chairman of academic subjects at the school, who is running the show, has posted appropriate signs.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The nation's corporations had more capital to work with at the end of 1954 than ever before, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Now the attention of the rebuilders turns to West Side Manhattan, and on the grand scale. Among the six new slum-clearance projects costing about $210,000,000 approved last week by the New York City Board of Estimate for negotiation with the Federal Government for redevelopment aid was one that startles the imagination with its magnitude.

CARROLLTON, Ga., April 24 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls retained her lead through a windy final round today to win the $5,000 Carrollton women's open golf tournament. She shot a 77 for 218 and a 3-stroke margin.
Only two of the nine games scheduled for the fifth round of the Jubilee Chess tournament at Buenos Aires, yesterday, were decided. Seven tests were adjourned, according to reports from South America.
SAN JUAN, P. R., April 24 (UP) -- Gustavo Diaz Gonzales, wanted by New York police for questioning in the slaying of a Brooklyn couple and their 2-year-old son, was arrested here today.
HARTSELLE. Ala., April 24 (AP) -- A tornado smashed through a farming area today, killing two children and two adults and injuring at least fifteen persons.
Parents were urged yesterday "not to become hysterical or panicky" because anti-polio inoculations will not begin today as originally scheduled.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 24 -- Chou En-lai renewed today Communist China's insistence on its right to "liberate" Formosa.
THINGS are seldom what they seem. So says, in this instance, the new, amiably satiric little revue that was presented Saturday night at the Phoenix Theatre.

The Sidney Hillman Foundation announced yesterday educational grants totaling $19,500 for the first quarter of the year. Scholarship grants included: Roosevelt University, Chicago, $4,000; New York State Industrial and Labor Relations School, Cornell University, $2,000; Education Foundation for the Apparel Industry, New York, $2,000, and the Labor Relations Institution of Puerto Rico, $1,000.

ERIC GUERIN was standing just inside the door of the jockey room when Ted Atkinson jubilantly bounced in. This was a few minutes after the running of the Wood Memorial at Jamaica on Saturday, as thrilling a horse race as anyone ever could hope to see. In the last few strides that big 3-year-old powerhouse, Nashua, had carried Atkinson to a neck victory over another big 3-year-old powerhouse, Summer Tan, with Guerin at the controls.

Graham Claytor, director and a member of the executive committee of the American Gas and Electric Company, has been elected a director of the Griscom-Russell Company, Massillon, Ohio, manufacturer of heat exchangers and water purifiers.
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 24 (UP) -- United States soldiers in Frankfurt followed Col. John H. Dilley's order to wear neckties in town tonight with a vengeance that had Germans blinking.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Monday, April 25 -- The Asian-African conference closed last night, and pro-Western spokesmen saw substantial successes in its final decisions.

KANSAS CITY, April 24 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox plummeted from tying a record of 29 runs yesterday to zero today. Alex Kellner limited the Sox to five hits in hurling the Kansas City Athletics to a 5-0 victory.

Leading newspaper publishers indicated yesterday that they favored United States conferences with the Chinese Communists. But they approached the matter of possible peace talks with suspicion and caution.

BOSTON, April 24 -- The National Council of Catholic Men urged the State Department today to "take every possible measure" to carry out the 1949 United Nations resolution for internationalization of Jerusalem.

After some weeks of languishing the bill to provide for the training of a military reserve is expected to get into the status of a full committee hearing in Congress tomorrow. That in itself is a forward step, but there are others to be taken and missteps to be avoided.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., April 24 -- Scientists and engineers will try here at dawn Tuesday to learn what might happen to a typical American community in an atomic bombing.
TOKYO, April 24 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama's Democratic party ran second best yesterday in the local elections, considered a barometer of current Japanese political thought.
TUCSON, Ariz., April 24 (AP) The ancient mystery of how camels work for a week in blazing desert heat without drinking has been solved.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 24 (AP) -- Chandler Harper of Portsmouth, Va., today won the third annual $17,500 Virginia Beach open golf tournament. Harper's great iron shots paced him to a 5-under-par 64 for a 72-hole score of 260.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -- The possibility of a permanent split of western world economy into two rival trade and monetary systems is beginning to be taken seriously by the highest European trade and monetary authorities.

South American Gold and Platinum Company and Pennroad Corporation announced yesterday that they had acquired control of National Department Stores Corporation, which operates a chain of sixteen stores.

The 100th anniversary of the founding of the Young Women's Christian Association was celebrated yesterday with a service at Radio City Music Hall. About 5,000 persons attended, including delegates to the twentieth triennial national convention.

THE four young singers who appeared as "Aristo Artists'' late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall did a lot to increase the prestige of that label. They proved to be one of the best foursomes who have sung under it since the first "Aristo" concert in the spring of 1947.
LONDON, April 24 -- The Moscow radio announced today the release of 613 Austrians serving sentences in the Soviet Union.
UTRECHT, Netherlands, April 23 (AP) -- Japan's Toshiajki Tanaka and Rumania's 37-year-old Angelica Rozeanu won the singles titles in the world table tennis championships today.

THORSHAVN, Faeroe Islands, April 24 (UP) -- Rebellious fishermen of Bordoy Island mined their harbor with dynamite today and threatened to blow up a Danish police ship if it attempts to put men ashort to evict the island's doctor.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Eisenhower, already under fire in the Senate for the reciprocal trade bill, appeared today to be heading into another battle over his proposed $3,500,000,000 foreign aid program.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 24 -- The strong demand for steel continued unabated last week. Most steel concerns found the volume of incoming business somewhat above capacity operations. This meant that virtually all were adding to backlogs, and some

OUTSTANDING on the weekend programs of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was the second performance of Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet" at yesterday's matinee, with Alicia Markova and Hugh Laing in the title roles.
A 43-year-old police captain died of a heart attack in the lobby of the Fine Arts Theatre at 11 o'clock last night while investigating a $2,300 hold-up there.

SANTIAGO; Panama, April 24 -- Twenty-five thousand peasant farmers jammed this town today for a vast open-air mass and blessing of farm animals. The event formally closed the eight-day International Catholic Congress on Rural Life.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Woodrow Wilson's cane, Franklin D. Roosevelt's monogrammed handkerchief, a green and white polka dot tie from Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan, a coonskin cap from Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee:
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- More efficient management in the Government household could save taxpayers $340,000,000 a year in Federal food and clothing bills, the Hoover Commission said today.

Jimmy Carter of the Bronx, the world lightweight champion, agreed yesterday to defend the title. His opponent will be Wallace (Bud) Smith of Cincinnati. The contest will take place in the Boston Garden on June 1.

In a dramatic sequel to his atomsfor-peace proposal President Eisenhower now announces plans to build and send around the world a new atom-powered merchant ship as a symbol of American determination to use the new atomic forces not only for the defense of the free world but also for the improvement of living standards everywhere.

A community blood collection for the New York Regional Chapter of the Red Cross will be held today at the Central Queens Red Cross Chapter House, 92-32 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, from 1 to 7 P. M. Appointments may be made by calling REpublic 9-6880.

TRENTON, April 25 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today the right of the State Highway Authority to build a service area along the Garden State Parkway within a residential section of Bloomfield.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) --The Army is working on a new influenza vaccine that will be "a great improvement" over the "shots" many persons now take.

Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech yesterday at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel as recorded by The New York Times: Mr. McLean, Mrs. Secretary Hobby, Ladies and Gentlemen: Always, I feel it is a special privilege when I can meet with men and women of the newspaper profession.
CHICAGO, April 25--Lower prices were registered for all grain and soybean futures at the opening this morning, the markets being affected by the possibility that the Chinese situation might be eased.
Deckhands and officers on ferryboats and tugboats of eleven railroads won a 3 1/2 per cent across-the-board wage increase yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25--A chronic complaint against President Truman's State Department was that it "shot from the hip," which is bad diplomacy. The same charge has been made against the department under its current management. But in two recent instances our foreign office demonstrated that the habit, if it was one, can be broken.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Dr. Herman J. Muller asserted that "attempts in high places" to deny the damaging hereditary effects of radiation from atomic tests had weakened public morale and led to defeatist propaganda.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25-- As is more common than not in this gaudy gambling center, the laws of chance today swung against the atomic scientists who had been gambling on favorable weather.
NEW DELHI, India, April 25 --The initiative for a solution of the Formosan question now rests with the United States.
What could turn out to be one of television's biggest competitiveprogram battles between two networks is now taking shape.
Cotton futures were strong on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices rose 12 to 29 points (60 cents to $1.45 a bale), with old May leading the advance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent Kennedy Stevenson claims (as does Secretary of State Dulles) that Adlal Stevenson "offered nothing constructive that the Administration has not already been attempting to achieve." If this is so, the titular head of the Democratic party performed at least this great service: he clarified for bewildered millions throughout the nation certain important policies of the Administration and what it is trying to do.

ALBANY, April 25--A vice president of the New York Central Railroad threatened today that the line would abandon Grand Central Terminal if the state persisted in setting an "intolerable" value on its right-ofway along Park Avenue.
LONDON, April 25--Harold Macmillan warmly welcomed today a four-power conference between the Western powers and the Soviet Union as soon as possible and at any level.

Plans for an industrial center at the proposed Harte Haven development in Massena, N. Y., were announced here yesterday. Preliminary planning for Harte Haven by Stanley J. Harte, New York attorney, real estate investor and builder, call for a housing project and a shopping center.
YESTEBDAY (April 25, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Nominated Gen. Earle E. Partridge to be chief of Air Defense Command, and Adm. Thomas Kincaid for another term on National Security Training Commission.
VARIETY seems to be the only common factor in the art exhibitions of this week.
The Government will move quickly to retry two secondary Communist leaders granted a new trial because of false testimony by Harvey Matusow, turnabout witness.
The formal annual report of operations of the Thermoid Company for 1954, which was issued for publication over the weekend, stated that accounts for the three previous years were "manipulated."
Fog and a Presidential whim gave Dwight D. Eisenhower's protectors some bad moments yesterday during his trip to this city for the annual Associated Press luncheon.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 25 (AP)--The Independent Petroleum Association of America forecast today a need for substantial cuts in domestic crude oil production this summer.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) --The United States agreed today to sell Argentina 20,000 metric tons of surplus cottonseed oil valued at $5,800,000.

THE majority of the trout fishing reports indicate that the fishing was rather spotty over the week-end. However, the salt water anglers seem to have found plenty of action, at several points from the Bahamas to Montauk.
MIAMI, Fla., April 25 (AP)-- Gulfstream Park will keep its usual place on the Florida racing calendar next winter, talking the last forty days of the season, President James Donn said today.

United Press staff members were praised yesterday for exploiting their assignments "with new zest and 'understanding." The praise came from executives of the news service at the opening session of its annual two-day meeting.

A former substitute Baltimore magistrate and an ex-convict were arraigned yesterday on a first-degree murder indictment. They are accused in the 'ride' slaying last Feb. 15 of Joseph Aronowitz, 40 years old.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25--The King Brothers, motion picture producers, have opened an office at Churubusco Studio in Mexico City to produce twentyeight television films.
LET'S face it. "Moby Dick" without the monstrous whale himself is just not "Moby Dick."
WASHINGTON, April 25-- A unified East European command under Soviet leadership is expected to be announced about the time an Austrian state treaty is signed, Washington officials said today.

Mrs. Charles Glen King took a stand the other day for a relaxed approach to family nutrition. Rigidity in menu planning, she told us, leads to dull meals and may bring about an unnecessary clash between mother and child.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Senate debate on the reciprocal trade bill, now slated to begin next week, is expected to reflect the activities of several wellheeled lobbying organizations.
A consent decree seeking to insure opportunities for Negroes in the brewing industry was approved yesterday by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
Sailor of the Brookmeade Stable won the Toboggan Handicap at the opening of the Belmont Park meeting yesterday.
Twelve East Side gardens and penthouse terraces will be on view next Tuesday afternoon and on May 10 for the belief of the City Gardens Club of New York.
LONDON, April 25--Influenced by declines in British Government securities, most sections of the stock market finished lower today.

ATLANTA, April 25 (UP) -- Fires that destroyed telephone equipment and damaged a railroad bridge were "deliberately set," rail and communications officials declared today. They made the charges as the twin southwide strikes went into their seventh week.
LONDON, April 25 (AP)--A Royal Air Force ground crew man who never before had flown an airplane circled over London tonight for hours in a stolen plane.

Washington's warning against overspeculation in stocks, expressed by increased margin requirements, was ignored in Wall Street yesterday. After an accumulation of week-end orders had forced prices down as much as 3 points, strong buying brought a rebound.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25--A United Nations commission agreed today to sponsor a standard tamperproof medical prescription that could not be increased by drug addicts or potential addicts.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 24 --The possibility of a coup by the armed forces is being discussed in Brazil as much as is a possible change in the weather, and with as little apparent concern.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Export-Import Bank today authorized "lines of credit" totaling $8,250,000 to aid six exporters in financing sales abroad.
Somewhere today there is a huge, hairy hand with cracked knuckles.

Not every student or teacher who goes from one country to study or teach in another is a good ambassador. But when candidates are as carefully selected as those under the exchange program carried out by the Department of State with the cooperation of the Office of Education it is not likely to go wrong.
Rare cashmere from the Himalayas will be made available to American women in coordinated sweater, skirt and coat ensembles this fall by various manufacturing sources.

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. for its first fiscal quarter, ending April 30, will be about 10 per cent above that of the same period in 1954. Earnings will be about 12 per cent higher, it was estimated here yesterday by Theodore V. Houser, chairman of the board.
ALBANY, April 25--Governor Harriman approved today liberalization of the state's unemployment insurance law.

A group of some twenty-eight managers of trade shows and other types of public exhibition interests have formed the Exposition Management Association. The group is making plans for a public relations program designed to promote the $1,000,000,000a-year trade show industry to exhibitors, trade buyers and consumers and to act as a management - labor clearing house for its members.
TOKYO, April 25--In an effort to face down a largely hostile Diet Premier Ichiro Hatoyama committed his shaky Government today to a policy that he labeled "peace diplomacy."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 25-- A cotton industry spokesman today urged that the Senate approve three amendments to President Eisenhower's trade bill "to protect the American textile industry from competition by cheap foreign goods."

When President Eisenhower observed at The Associated Press luncheon yesterday that "in cooperation there is strength" he touched on one of the basic keys to success not only in international politics but also in the extraordinary news-gathering organization he was addressing.

One of the most helpful and stimulating things to come out of the just-concluded Bandung conference of Asian and African states was the declaration concerning cultural cooperation. This is a fruitful field and the recommendations that were made are sound.
Domestic steel mills are scheduled to operate this week at 96 per cent of capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It would be the year's highest production rate.
BUENOS AIRES, April 25 (AP) --The Standard Oil Company of California signed a contract with the Government today to prospect for oil in Southern Argentina.
NEWARK, April 25--The Government won in Federal District Court today the first round of the Linwood Park test case involving builders' windfall profits.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000 head; market moderately active and uneven; 25 to 50c higher on all weights butchers; sows mostly 25c higher, some sales as much as 50c higher;
WASHINGTON, April 25--The Senate Finance Committee was deadlocked today over amendments that might further limit the President's tariff-cutting powers under the reciprocal trade program.

City Labor Commissioner Joseph E. O'Grady arranged yesterday for a resumption of wage negotiations between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the Transit Authority. He plans to attend the next session Thursday.
NEW HAVEN, April 25--Dr. A. Whitney Griswold enunciated tonight, on the fifth anniversary of his appointment as president of Yale University, seven "operating aims" for higher education.

You'll never see their names in the box scores. However, Frank Bowman of the Giants, Harold Wendler of the Dodgers and Gus Mauch of the Yankees probably will win plenty of games for their teams this year just as they have been doing for the past several seasons.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25-- More than 800 Air Force, Navy and Marine planes have participated in the Teapot series of nuclear tests now nearing conclusion at the test site near here.

BONN, Germany, April 25-- The decision to hold a Western Big Three foreign ministers conference in Paris was due in part to constant urging by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. The West German leader insisted that a serious effort would have to be made soon to demonstrate the determination of the Western powers to carry out their pledge to seek Germany's reunification.
The General Dynamics Corporation, builder of the Nautilus, first atomic submarine, soon may acquire the StrombergCarlson Company, which bears one of the oldest names in radio and television.
The working girl sallies forth to her desk in the cool of the day and often sallies away from it in the cool of the eve for a gay evening out. Her ensemble should suit her coming and going.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, Inc., announced yesterday that its net earnings for the quarter ended March 31 totaled $8,784,563. The net was equal to 88 cents a share on the 10,020,000 shares outstanding. It compared with profits of $7,069,960, or 71 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1954.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) --Gen. Earle E. Partridge, who rose from a World War I Army private to become a combat air general in World War II, was chosen today to head the Continental Air Defense Command.

Wall Street took in good stride yesterday the increase in margins from 60 to 70 per cent, ordered over the week-end. There was some nervous selling early in the morning, but it disappeared quickly and by the close of the market The New York Times composite average of fifty representative listed issues was ahead nearly a point on the day.
A police sergeant was fatally injured in Queens at 6:30 P. M. yesterday in an accident caused indirectly by boys' mischief.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I respectfully dissent from the opinion of Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter which appeared in your letters column of April 17?
VIENNA, April 25--Viliam Siroky, Czechoslovak Premier, and Frantisek Zupka, head of the Czechoslovak trade unions, were dropped today from the politburo of the Slovak-Communist party.
The computing machine may be an accountant's best friend, but it cannot think for business management.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of April 15 on the President's message to Congress on the proposed new Organization for Trade Cooperation (O. T. C.) as the administering body for GATT impels me to offer several observations.

Next to the flesh-and-bone straphanger, one of the fastestwearing items on the IND subway line is the steel rail. No fewer than 8,320 pieces of rail--fifty-two miles worth-- are worn down to a nearfrazzle each year by the remorseless grinding of the 15,680 wheels of the IND's 1,960 cars.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) --The Government today disposed of four more of its synthetic rubber plants in a $37,000,000 transcontinental shuffling of paper.
President Eisenhower announced yesterday plans for an atomic-powered merchant ship to tour the world in the interest of peace.
As the highlight of a day of ceremonials and proclamations, Mayor Wagner yesterday set aside next Oct. 24 as United Nations Day.

ROME, April 25--Neo-Fascists and their adversaries clashed here today. Policemen detained 160 persons after they had broken up a fight in Piazza Venezia under the balcony of what was once Mussolini's office. Later all but thirty of those detained were released.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 25--Middle Eastern delegates to the Asian-African conference, in general, held to their positions despite direct exposure to mildmannered Chinese communism and persuasive Indian neutralism.
Carmine G. DeSapio, New York Secretary of State and leader of Tammany Hall, received last night the State of Israel Bond Organization's Distinguished Leadership Award.

FRED HANEY of the Pirates, a rear-row spectator at the National League pennant race, offered a rather striking comment at Fort Myers in Florida a few days before spring training began. His own troubles hadn't yet descended upon him and so he was at ease and contemplative.
President Eisenhower urged Congress yesterday to adopt his reciprocal trade program without crippling amendments, for the sake of world peace.

Bebind this country's producttive might is a small highly skilled group of men who make the machines used for mass production. These men know before anyone else which way production is going, how industrialists are guessing and what the output curve is going to do.

Net sales and net income of the Armco Steel Corporation for the first three months of 1955 were up 38.9 per cent and 17.8 per cent, respectively, above the results for the three months ended March 31, 1954.

Potato prices soared the 1/4cent-a-pound daily limit in the May position yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The delivery opened at the limit rise and never slipped from that price. There were more than 450 unsatisfied bids in May at the close.
Construction of a $30,000,000 shopping center at Roosevelt Field, Nassau County, L. I., will get under way today when ground is broken for a major branch store of R. H. Macy Co.
The text of the annual report of the board of directors of The Associated Press follows: The Associated Press went forward on many fronts during the past year.
LONDON, April 25 -- Prime Minister Eden conferred for half an hour today with Sir Walter Monckton, Labor Minister, on Government plans to avert a nationwide railway strike set for midnight Sunday.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is back in the White House for some regular social events of spring.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Supreme Court ruled today that Michael J. Regan had not been deprived of constitutional rights when he was convicted of criminal contempt. He had refused to tell a grand jury whether he had taken bribes from gamblers while a member of the New York police force.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Congress has been told that the Soviet Union's Army is "equipped and disposed" to go to war on short notice.
Bremen, Germany's second ranking deep-sea port, will surpass its pre-war cargo-handling potential by 1962 under the terms of a ten-year, $95,000,000 rehabilitation program.
LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., April 25--Peace and courtesy reigned at the Sperry Gyroscope Company here this morning as striking electrical workers settled down to a court-ordered peaceful picketing.
P. J. Byrne Jr has been named deputy to the vice president of the Esso Research and Engineering Company. John W. Packie has been appointed engineering manager of the company.
Rocky Castellani, Cleveland middleweight, beat Chico Varona of Havana in a ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has resold the twelvestory loft building at 11 West Twenty-fifth Street to a client of Seymour Stone, attorney. Nat Fenold was the broker and Louis Gothelf was the attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Senate Democratic leaders exerted pressure on the Administration today to give careful consideration to the Communist Chinese offer to negotiate with the United States on the Far East.

Gifts totaling $3,827,000 have been contributed to the centennial fund of the Young Women's Christian Association of the U. S. A. The organization is seeking $5,000,000 to expand its services to 1,300 units in this country.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 25 (AP) -- Wicomico Ted, driven by Robert Walker, won the $2,500 Greenvale Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:06 2/5.
The motifs of new brass accessories and fabrics at Lord Taylor are keyed to the renewed interest in nature that spring brings.

The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation announced yesterday record sales and operating revenues of $149,467,812 in the first quarter of 1955. That was an increase of 12 per cent over the $133,095,236 in the same period in 1954.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 25 --Harry S. Truman today accused the Eisenhower Administration of having "gone into office with intent to destroy the nation's public power program."

Gusty winds and a cold drizzle greeted members of society who attended the fiftieth spring opening of Belmont Park yesterday afternoon. It wag a day, said old-timers, similar to the one on which the club opened in 1905.
John R, Inglis was re-elected president of the metropolitan section of the Professional Golfers Association yesterday. It marked the twenty-seventh time he was chosen for that office.
The New York County Medical Society approved last night a new "family doctor plan" for paying medical and surgical bills.

A new educational kit composed of a film clip and six copies of a discussion outline concerned with the emotional growth of children has been prepared by the National Institute of Mental Health in cooperation with United World Films.

Michael J. Quill of the Transport Workers Union was busy over the week-end exerting pressure to get Mayor Wagner to intervene against the Transit Authority's decision to halt service on the antiquated Third Avenue elevated line on May 12. He spoke at a mass meeting during which postcards were distributed for mailing to City Hall urging the Mayor to act "before it is too late."
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25-- A hydrogen bomb of the size tested at Bikini Atoll March 1, 1954, would make an area of several thousand square miles dangerous to life.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today there were 4,182,000 business concerns in the nation at the beginning of this year.

When the Sadler's Wells Ballet returns to the Metropolitan Opera House for a five-week season beginning Sept. 11, it will have eight works in its repertory that have not been presented previously by the company in this country.
National Airlines' legal motion to halt the Port Authority's development of a "terminal city" at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, has been denied.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Government's contention that the courts cannot review orders of deportation, except in habeas corpus proceedings, was rejected by the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, April 25--A White House decision has caused the Secretary of State to cancel a long-standing Senate engagement to testify against the Bricker amendment to limit the President's treaty-making power.
Bulk supplies of the Salk polio vaccine were shipped yesterday to four additional states. This brought the total to thirty-three states supplied since the program began April 19.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 25--Use of county parkway lands for a natural gas pipeline across the beltline of Westchester was approved unanimously today by the powerful

Leo Durocher refused to divulge the Giants' line-up and batting order before Sunday's finale at Ebbets Field but there will be no reciprocal move by the Brooks when they drop into the Polo Grounds on the night of May 27.
TRENTON, April 25--The Legislature moved today to assure an equitable distribution of Salk polio vaccine and to prevent black marketing of it in New Jersey.
PANAMA, April 25--Roman Catholics who restrict the practice of their faith to spiritual evercises were taken sharply to task here today by a prelate of the church.

Broadway's legitimate theatres should be resounding next season to more song and dance routines than ordinarily heard and witnessed, thanks to the large collection of musical ventures currently shaping up.
Arthur Larsen has been barred temporarily from competing in any further foreign tennis tournaments.

Visitor With Umbrella The visitor who entered was hidden behind a large umbrella, which was odd not only because most people lower umbrellas upon entering buildings but also because this umbrella, once within the door, promptly turned inside out.

An American edition of "Prince Philip," by John Dean, will be issued tomorrow by Holt. The author, who has been Lord Mountbatten's butler, served the husband of the Queen of England for five years as valet. His story, told in anecdotal form, gives a behind-the-scenes picture of the Royal Family and their guests.

Lulu Perez outpointed Rudy Garcia in a ten-round fight at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Perez, a Brooklyn athlete who was 22 yesterday, celebrated the day by gaining a unanimous decision.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 25--Relations with India have deteriorated further over the issue of more than 300,000 Asians living in South Africa.
A Gay Thirties dinner dance for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York will be held on Thursday in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.
SAN JUAN, P. R., April 25 (UP)--The eighth technical conference of the International Air Transport Association was convened here today.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Western Big Three foreign ministers will meet in Paris May 8 to discuss a Big Four meeting. This was announced today by the State Department.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 25--The mass evacuation of 40,000 pro-Communist Vietnamese from northeastern Thailand is expected as one of the achievements of the AsianAfrican conference.
Laszlo Szabo of Hungary moved up into second place in the Jubilee Chess Tournament at Buenos Aires, yesterday, by defeating Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia, according to a report received from Argentina.
LAUREL, Md., April 25 (AP)-- Willie Hartack again dominated the racing program at Laurel. Today he rode six winners, which included the Triple K. Stables' Blue Volt in the featured Rock Creek Purse.
International News Service has achieved a "magnificent decade of progress" since the end of World War II, the agency declared yesterday.

Senator William F. Knowland emphatically reaffirmed last night his view that the United States should help defend Quemoy and Matsu. To ask Nationalist China to yield these two islands to the Communists would be "surrender on the installment plan," he said.

Protestant clergymen from 1,700 churches in the metropolitan area will be invited to participate in the observance of United Nations Sunday on Oct. 23. It will mark the tenth anniversary of the United Nations Charter.

The Greater New York Fund's 1955 drive was started last night. Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, declared that such a vast, voluntary citizens' effort was "unimaginable" in Russia.
One of the big races of the college rowing season is scheduled this week on the Severn River at Annapolis.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 25 (AP)--Dave Smith birdied the last five holes today to win the qualifying medal in the Fiftyfifth North and South Amateur Golf Tournament with a 67.

MUNICH, Germany, April 25 --Elements of a United States political defeat appear to be building up here among tens of thousands of refugees from the Soviet Union and satellite states now resident in Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Natural gas producers said today they get about 3 per cent of the price paid by New York consumers for their product.

We congratulate Governor Harriman on signing four of the nine bills passed by the Legislature which embody the recommendations of the Temporary Commission on the Courts, of which Harrison Tweed is chairman. All of those the Governor has approved are designed to deal more effectively--and humanely --with youthful offenders.
WASHINGTON, April 25--The tenth anniversary of the meeting of United States and Soviet troops on the Elbe River in Germany was marked today by members of Congress and two veteran groups.

BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)-- The "uncertainty of tenure" of commissioners subject to appointment by their Governors was protested today by Dr. Frank R. Menne, president of the National Association of Racing Commissioners.

Irving Levy, chairman of the board of Century Ribbon Mills, Inc., shot himself dead yesterday afternoon in the company's offices.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 25--Negotiations between Communist China and the United States over Formosa are still possible. This view was expressed here today by Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan, after a luncheon discussion with China's Premier, Chou En-lai.

MILAN, Italy, April 26 (UP) -Italian lawn tennis officials said tonight they considered the Art Larsen incident closed. They also hoped the United States Lawn Tennis Association would revoke its suspension of the San Leandro (Calif.) star.
AFTER glancing over the conflicting reports from waterfowl agencies, the average wildfowler will not be able to make up his mind whether he should sell his gun or stock up on ammunition.

A 24-year-old ne'er-do-well with an urge to stay near places he has attempted to hold up was arrested yesterday. The arrest came four hours after he was thwarted in an attempt to rob the First National City Bank branch at Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue.

Commercial paper dealers increased the yield they offer buyers of some of their notes yesterday by 1/8 of a percentage point. The action was a continuation of a trend started about the first of the year. It also followed the lead taken on Monday by major finance companies when they raised rates on their commercial paper by one-eighth of 1 per cent.
This summer more blind children than ever before will vacation at our mountain-lake camp in Vermont.

Though I have not seen it mentioned in press dispatches, one of the reasons for calling a British election at this time must be the desire to obtain a Government with a fresh mandate to take whatever steps may become necessary as a result of the Formosa Strait crisis.
A twenty-story apartment house will be erected at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Fifteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The American economy closed the first quarter of this year at a level near the record of the spring of 1953, the Commerce Department reported today.

The trend in curtains draperies and blinds resulting from recent architectural developments was discussed yesterday at a meeting of the Home Fashions League. The group met at a luncheon at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

KANSAS CITY, April 26 (AP) -Vic Raschi, one-time pitching ace of the New York Yankees, was signed today by the Kansas City Athletics. Raschi was waived out of both leagues and unconditionally released by the St. Louis Cardinals last week.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas disclaimed responsibility today for the authenticity of his published assertion there were 58,000 police wiretaps in New York City for 1952 alone, but he said that the source "seemed to be a reliable one."
Old May futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 9 points (45 cents a bale) yesterdays, but other months declined 1 to 19 points (5 to 95 cents a bale).

NEWPORT, R. I., April 26 -- Five civilian employes were killed and five injured in an explosion that converted the dynamometer department room into a pile of rubble at the Naval Underwater Ordnance Station here today.
PARIS, April 26 -- Jean Monnet, chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, paid tribute today to William M. Tomlinson, who died Sunday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -New controversy over the proposed $400,000,000 power project at Niagara Falls was brought into the open today as Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, introduced a bill for its construction and operation.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- The policy-making council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association today imposed a two-year probation on the University of Oklahoma and administered a more serious one-year punishment to the University of Cincinnati.
The New York Air Route Traffic Control Center handled more plane movements last Thursday than on any previous day in its history.
Handbags, jewelry, gloves, handkerchiefs and "sundries" are among the good things in Macy's summer collection of accessories.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 26 -- Man was indicted tonight for causing a great increase in the world's desert land. He was challenged to find ways to reverse the destructive trend, despite growing population pressures, and leave nature's resource for future generations "in as good condition as we found it."
HOLLYWOD, Calif., April 26 (AP) -- Susan Hayward attempted suicide early today by swallowing sleeping pills.
LAMAR, Colo., April 26--Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, encountered occasional gusts of soil-blowing today as he toured drought-plagued eastern Colorado. He was in search of...
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Pentagon conceded today that its new rules, designed to block publication of uncleared information, had been evaded by Republicans.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 (AP) -- Dave Smith of Gastonia, N. C., the medalist, gained a 1-up victory over Lieut. Robert Magee of Fort Bragg and Newton, Mass., today in the first round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

Net earnings of the Texas Company and subsidiaries for the first three months of this year amounted to $56,021,212, equal to $2.04 a share, J. S. Leach, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -Senator William F. Knowland predicted today overwhelming Congressional support for President Eisenhower's proposed atomic peace ship.

LAST night was "American Composers' Night" for the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House. Its four ballets were "Capital of the World," with music by George Antheil; "A Streetcar Named Desire," with a score adapted by Rayburn Wright from Alex North's music for the moving picture; "Billy the Kid," with music by Aaron Copland, and "Interplay," with music by Morton Gould and the composer at the piano.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 26 -- The forthcoming nuclear detonation here will be witnessed by nearly 6,000 people, some at very close range.

THE large annual exhibition of paintings and sculpture, of which this is the fourth, at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue, is the closest thing to an advance guard salon the New York art world holds.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- A national dress manufacturer, Jonathan Logan of New York, agreed today not to show favor to certain retailers.
Up in the East Seventies a wan-looking expectant mother sat in her crowded tenement apartment and watched her "substitute" preparing lunch for her four young children.
In dealing with anger, parents should teach a child to control not repress his feelings, a clinical psychologist declared yesterday.

Pre-adoption nursery care by the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will benefit from a preview performance of the new musical "Damn Yankees" on Tuesday. The musical, starring Gwen Verdon and Stephen Douglass, opens May 5 at the Fortysixth Street Theatre.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the New York Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., to compel the publisher of the defunct Brooklyn Eagle to arbitrate demands for severance pay and other benefits.
LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) -- Home to Polly Stewart, 40 years old, has been her tiny back bedroom at Buckingham Palace the six years she has been a cleaning woman.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate voted an $884,433,923 agriculture appropriations bill today. Aproval by voice vote followed the overwhelming defeat of an effort to cut $55,000,000 from a fund for soil conservation payments.

In keeping with President Eisenhower's repeated declarations that this country is always ready for exploratory talks that might advance the cause of peace, Secretary Dulles has now taken up Premier Chou En-lai's proposal for negotiations on Formosa and the Far East with the idea of discovering whether this proposal is sincere or merely part of a propaganda game.
Lilace Reid Barnes of Lake Forest, Ill., president of the World's Young Women's Christian Association, was elected president of the United States association yesterday.

WHEN Sir George Barnes, director of television for the British Broadcasting Corporation, visited this country last fall, he suggested that the advent of color television might prove a mixed blessing. Would there not be a temptation, he wondered, to rely on the splashy effect of color as a substitute for program quality?
The government department faculty of City College has unanimously elected Dr. Donald C. Blaisdell as chairman, it was announced yesterday.
OTTAWA, April 26 -- Canada must be prepared for an attack with nuclear weapons within a few hours after the outbreak of a general war, Louis St. Laurent said today.
The fireboat John D. McKean has been cured of the jitters that have kept it out of service ever since it was delivered more than seven months ago.

STALWARTS who man America's gigantic jet bombers at freezing altitudes are not likely to know that the intricate and delicate coils in their ships' computer systems are hand-wound in many cases by this city's lame, halt and legless men and women.
Teacher morale is getting a big lift in the city schools these days.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today it planned to end soon its guarantees of "no-no down payment" home loans.
Samuel Romppanen took another swig yesterday, looked deep into the bottle and saw himself reflected there as a circus aerialist.
CAMP DESERT ROCK, Nev., April 26 -- This gale-battered little camp, jammed with troops and observers for the next atomic test, was picking up the pieces today.

Two former employes of the Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on a charge of stealing 1,000 gallons of tax-free alcohol belonging to the hospital. The alcohol was never recovered.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A member of The Federal Communications Commissions suggested legislation today to make free radio and television time available to candidates of the major political parties in important election campaigns.

Activity on the New York Stock Exchange remained relatively small yesterday but bullish forces retained command and prices advanced to new peaks of the upward movement. Volume was 2,720,000 shares, the same as on Monday.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 26 (AP) -- Glen Alden Coal Company stockholders today were told the company had purchased Maphes Company of Fort Worth, Tex., for $11,000,000.

KANSAS CITY, April 26 (AP) -- Jim Finigan singled home Spook Jacobs with two out in the eleventh inning and the bases loaded and the Kansas City Athletics scored an 8-7 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- Bob Turley defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 0, with a onehitter today at Comiskey Park. The game was the first one-hit pitching achievement in the majors this season.
Three youths who were with John Sterling when he was shot dead by a probationary patrolman testified yesterday that they heard no warning shouts prior to the sound of gunfire.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -Ambassador Abba Eban told the American-Israel Society tonight that "the Arab world can well afford to renounce a useless grudge against a kindred people."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 26 -- Stockholders of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway voted more than 10 to 1 today to merge with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission is about ready to clamp tighter regulations on promoters of the multi-million dollar boom in penny uranium mining stocks.

On behalf of the Center for International Studies, Dr. Walt W. Rostow has brought out a book in which the effect of communism on Chinese scientists, among other intellectuals, is partially surveyed. It will not astonish anyone to know that China is following the Russian course.

Real estate sales in the Bronx averaged 114 per cent of assessed valuations in the first quarter of this year. The Taxpayers Service Company, which compiled the tabulation, said it believed that this was the highest average for any quarter in the last fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The first comprehensive study of substitute teachers in the United States showed today a total of 160,000, or one to each six full-time teachers.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Soviet Union agreed today that the Big Four ambassadors in Vienna should meet Monday to prepare final terms for an early restoration of Austria's independence.

The brigantine Yankee, out of Gloucester, Mass., for a year and a half, passed through New York harbor yesterday on the last leg of a world cruise. Capt. Irving M. Johnson, in command, told a passing Coast Guard patrol boat that he would go on from Bermuda to the ninety-six-foot sailing vessel's home port without stopping here.

CARNEGIE HALL vibrated with stereophonic sound last night when more than 400 young musicians from three organizations joined forces under the baton of Leon Barzin and gave an extraordinarily fine performance of the Berlioz Requiem.

Lincoln, Neb., borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday to finance public school construction. It sold an issue of bonds at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company at an interest cost of 1.894 per cent. A syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. bid 1.907 per cent.

The refusal of a machinist to join a labor union cost him his unemployment benefits yesterday. A State Supreme Court decision held that he had committed a "voluntary" act when he declined to join the union and consequently lost his job.

The city's streets are getting cleaner, and to keep them so will cost more than $100,000,000 annually, Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain said yesterday. Counting capital budget costs, the budget is nearing that figure now, he added.
Can Rusty Callow do it again? Can he make a second comeback, after having the bottom drop out of his boat? Can he give Navy another champion eight-oared crew?
ALBANY, Aril 26 -- Governor Harriman approved today a bill regulating the use of gas heaters.
ALBANY, April 26 -- The State Health Department announced yesterday a new set of regulations for nurseries to protect newborn babies against infection. They will go into effect Sept. 1.

Monday's total of donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was 450 pints. Included were 141 pints taken at the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, 30 East Forty-second Street; 125 given in a Bronxwood community donation at Evander Childs High School, 800 East Gun Hill Road, the Bronx, and 116 given at St. John's University, Downtown, 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 26 -- Suspension of work on a multi-million-dollar interchange of the New England Thruway here was demanded today by the City Council.
LONDON, April 26 -- Clement R. Attlee bid today for support of Liberal voters in next month's general election. He assailed the Conservatives as a class party wedded to inequality.

The package, which does a lot more than hold the product, is to get even more attention. Manufacturers of packaging machinery plowed back about 7 cents of every dollar of sales last year into research and development of new and better packaging methods.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad declared yesterday a "regular" quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share.

MIAMI, Fla., April 26 (AP) -Finalists in the young artists' auditions were chosen today at the National Federation of Music Clubs convention. They will compete for the $1,000 awards tomorrow and Thursday.
Thomas F. Brigance, winner of the 1955 Cotton Fashion Award, thinks American women are copycats.
Israel's growth establishes new frontiers for democracy, Senator Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, said here last night.

Occasionally, Raymond Massey receives an inspiration to become a dramatist. Responding to that impulse once more, he has purchased the rights to "The Day Lincoln Was Shot," a book by Jim Bishop that is enjoying a best-seller rating, and is proceeding with its dramatization.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Senate Republicans threatened today to "go up the line" in the Administration until they found out who was creating "bottlenecks" in making Federal jobs available to Republicans.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 26 -- Tighter Government controls on business and industrial monopolies and on shipping are being considered by the South African Parliament.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- Otto Preminger has acquired title to the motion picture and stage rights to "Bonjour Tristesse," a recently published novel by a new French writer, Francoise Sagan.

WEST NYACK, N. Y., April 26 -- James Bernard Schafer and his wife, Cecelia, were found dead today, a suicide note beside them in their car. It was parked on a woodland road of the estate from which they conducted a correspondence school in metaphysics.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board attorney recommended today a broad reorganization and expansion of air routes between major cities of the Northeast and South and Southwest.
The Waterfront Commission will start tomorrow a hearing into kickback charges against a New Jersey dock boss. The inquiry will be in the agency's headquarters at 15 Park Row.
A century has passed since children first met, in the storied Kingdom of Paflagonia, the villainous King Valoroso among the other company of William Makepeace Thackeray's 'The Rose and the Ring."
MONTPELLIER, France, April 23 -- The French saying "to put water into one's wine" means to moderate rigid attitudes and accept compromises.
Two passenger liners for the New York-Buenos Aires luxury trade will be built by Moore-McCormack Lines.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and sales of gas, electricity and steam for the three and twelve-month periods ended March 21.
JERUSALEM, April 26 -- The people of Israel celebrated their seventh anniversary of independence tonight in a spirit of confidence tempered somewhat by concern over border troubles.
The board of directors of The Associated Press yesterday reelected Robert McLean as president. He has held that office since 1938.

Edward Corsi urged yesterday that President Eisenhower reaffirm the "emergency character" of the program under which 209,000 refugees are to be admitted by the end of 1956. Only a little more than 1,000 have entered in eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of New York who went to the Asian-African conference independently, won praise on the house floor today from a senior House Democrat.

William B. Given Jr., chairman of American Brake Shoe Company, announced at the annual meeting here yesterday that the company was negotiating the purchase of an unidentified concern. Mr. Given said the move was being made to assure growth in new areas.

By a routine device the Federal Government can help achieve greater popular recognition for the nation's public-school teachers. That device would be the issuing of a 3cent postage stamp honoring the teacher.
Bernard J. Radziewicz, the pistol-packing president of Long Island University's senior class, has a ready answer as to when he first decided to become a policeman.
More than $30,000,000 of new preferred stock in two manufacturing enterprises and a natural gas tranmisssion company will be offered to investors today.
To those lacking the knowhow of where to turn in times of trouble New York appears to be the cold city of tradition, larger and more frightening than most.

GENEVA, April 26 -- A tribunal ordered the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today to reinstate three dismissed Americans or pay them damages totaling $43,800. They were dismissed for refusing to appear before a United States loyalty board.

Just another word to rationalize the viewpoint that rent control as enforced by the State of New York is manifestly inequitable. Column long articles on percentages and statistics only further befog the general public's thinking.

The estate of Russell Goldman has sold three five-story apartment houses at 133-37 East Thirtieth Street to the 133 East Thirtieth Street Corporation, which is headed by Leon Klarfield. The houses, on a plot 60 by 40 feet, have been in the Goldman ownership for about thirty years.
CANNES, France, April 26 (AP) -- After months of negotiation, "Carmen Jones" has a foot in the door of French movie houses.

One hundred and twenty-five years ago today Simon Bolivar, Liberator of northern South America, finally relinquished supreme power in the countries which, after their liberation, he had sought to govern with varying mixtures of democracy and autocracy.
Station WRCA-TV announced yesterday that it had set up a television workshop to present experimental programs.

Abbe Pierre, a French apostle of the poor and homeless, appealed yesterday for a "threefold mobilization" to bring understanding and help to troubled man and nations. His appeal has been widely heeded in France.
SAIGON, April 26 (AP) -- Gen. Paul Ely accused Communist North Vietnam today of deliberately violating the Geneva armistice accords by murdering and torturing former French partisan fighters.

A 1955-56 city budget of $1,782,335,683, exceeded in the United States only by the Federal budget itself, was adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. It is the largest in the city's history. The new budget is $750,874 less than the executive budget submitted by Mayor Wagner to the board on April 1.

We suppose the New York Central Railroad was not understating its case when it threatened in Albany to abandon Grand Central because of higher taxation of its Park Avenue right-of-way. We hardly expect that it will move its terminal up to 138th Street. Nevertheless government, from Washington down to the suburban village, needs to do some straight thinking about the railroads.
CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) -Bob Lemon hit one over the right-field fence today to gain his fourth victory of the baseball season as the Cleveland Indians beat the Washington Senators, 3 -- 2.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., April 26 -- Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey today bowed out of the wage dispute negotiations between the Sperry Gyroscope Company and Local 450, International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.
Indoor polo stars of the East and Middle West played an extraperiod game for the benefit of the March of Dimes last night.
MOSCOW, April 26 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the Soviet note to the United States today on Austrian treaty negotiations. Similar notes were sent to Britain and France.
Today's new film is "Chief Crazy Horse," a Universal-International drama at the Mayfair in CinemaScope and color with Victor Mature, Suzan Ball and John Lund.

JOLLY CHOLLY GRIMM is a cheerful citizen even when his Milwaukee Braves are losing -- as they were at this time a year ago. But his ulcers are quiescent now because his team is doing well. The Braves have been moving at a steady clip and are poised to take command if the Brooks falter. Milwaukee's pitching and hitting have been solid, good signs for the future.
A fashion bundle for Britain is being wrapped by designer Jane Derby, who is opening a London salon.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 26 (AP) -- Gene Jester, a 5-year-old brown gelding owned by Paul Wixom of Chicago, turned in a 2:04 4/5 mile to win the Flatbush Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Igor Youskevitch was knocked out last night by Nora Kaye, his co-star, in a ballet performance of "A Streetcar Named Desire" at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Plans are under way to give a lift to politicians and other citizens working in or visiting City Hall.

VALENCIENNES, France, April 26 (AP) -- A noncommissioned officer crashed a stolen Royal Air Force trainer in flames on two French houses near here early today. The crash killed the pilot and three other persons. Three were injured.

IN 1927 when Chang Iron Lock fell in love with Ch'en Second Lass, the slave girl, life in the Province West of the Mountains and in the Li Family Village was much the same as it had been for several thousand years. The small changes that were to be introduced by the Kuomintang and the big changes that were to come with the Communists were still in the unknowable future.

Atlas Corporation has signed a contract to purchase 562,500 Australian pounds ($1,265,625) of the treasury stock of Northern Australia Uranium Company. Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas, announced yesterday that the commitment is subject to geological and legal examinations by Atlas.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP) -Alex Bower of the American Thoroughbred Breeders Association took horse-racing authorties to task today for failure to answer "straightforwardly and in detail" charges of "not being thorough enough in their efforts to control" doping.

Venerable, peripatetic Andre Simon, founder and president of the Wine and Food Society of London, arrived here this Week for a six-day visit. He is guest of honor at the twenty-first anniversary of the New York chapter of the society.
Clarence L. Coleman Jr. of Chicago, newly elected president of the American Council for Judaism, defended United States policy toward Israel and the Middle East yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L. I., April 26 -- Mrs Bernard Freeman of Inwood captured the low gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A tournament at the Fresh Meadows Country Club today. The competition opened the organization's 1955 schedule.
BONN, Germany, April 26 (AP) -- The 1946 killing of three United States officers in Germany is a "closed case" as far as United States occupation authorities are concerned.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 26 -- Chou En-lai, premier of Communist China, arrived in Jakarta today to be a state guest of President Sukarno.

Atlas Corporation has signed a contract to purchase 562,500 Australian pounds ($1,265,625) of the treasury stock of Northern Australia Uranium Company. Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas, announced yesterday that the commitment is subject to geological and legal examinations by Atlas.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP) -Alex Bower of the American Thoroughbred Breeders Association took horse-racing authorties to task today for failure to answer "straightforwardly and in detail" charges of "not being thorough enough in their efforts to control" doping.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia, by winning two games yesterday, moved into a tie for first place at 5 1/2 -- 1 1/2 with Herman Pilnik of Argentina in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires, according tto a report from Argentina.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Eisenhower Administration is holding back its opposition to the Bricker amendment to avoid dramatizing the Republican split on the issue.
WASHINGTON April 26 -- The State Department, in what seemed to be a change of position, today indicated a willingness to negotiate directly with Communist China for a ceasefire in the Formosa Strait.

The May potato option rose the daily limit of 1/4-cent-apound yesterday for the third consecutive trading session on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The month opened the limit higher, then eased but recovered before the close.
A former Mayor of Austin, Tex., has joined forces with a well-known designer and manufacturer to bring moderatepriced furniture to young families in the $5,000-to-$8,000-a year income bracket.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 26 (AP) -- Earnings of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company in the year's first quarter jumped to $7,975,488, or $2.37 a common share, from $2,989,478, or 89 cents a share, in the same period of 1954, the annual stockholders' meeting was told today.

DOVER, Del., April 26 (AP) -First-quarter net income of Cities Service Company rose to $14,074,633, equal to $1.42 a common share, W. Alton Jones, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -A leading heart specialist reported today that drugs capable of reducing the ability of blood to clot were helping prolong the lives of persons who had had heart attacks.

THE Brooklyn Museum will open to the public today, to run through June 26, its ninth annual print exhibition, nation-wide in its scope. This year only eighty-five offerings passed the jury out of 1,000 submitted, as against last year's total of 150 out of about 1,100 submissions.

Federal, state and municipal health agencies moved yesterday to tighten controls over distribution of the Salk anti-polio vaccine. They expressed optimism that supplies would be available this year for the planned inoculations.

The easing of travel restrictions almost everywhere outside the Iron Curtain countries has increased the flexibility of news coverage by the United Press, executives of the wire service were told yesterday.
Governor Harriman interpreted Secretary of State Dulles' new statement on Formosa last night as a concession that the State Department had blundered earlier.
Stockholders of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., yesterday approved an agreement to acquire Colonial Airlines through an exchange of one share of Eastern for two of Colonial stock.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 26 Sir John Kotelawala, Prime Minister of Ceylon, returned to Colombo today from the Asian-African conference at Bandung, Indonesia. He went from the airport to the House of Representatives to report on the meeting.
Johnny Antonelli, the ace southpaw, of the Giants, still isn't through making the Braves rue the day they traded him to New York.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Senate Finance Committee approved President Eisenhower's reciprocal trade bill today by a vote of 13 to 2. It rejected all amendments to give special tariff protection to specific commodities.
BERLIN, April 26 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer met with his economic cabinet here today to discuss a $740,000,000 aid program for West Berlin.

Congressional action to eliminate red tape in import evaluation was urged yesterday by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, which represents many leading businesss concerns.

Peiping's Chou has, at last, said a friendly word about us. Let's accept it with gladness and not with distrust and cynicism. Let us show good sense, reason and even magnanimity in evincing that quick reciprocity which is itself a salient characteristic in Chinese humanitarian and political tradition, whose eclipse has deeply saddened the many Americans who have intimately known the Chinese people.

All anybody needed to pick the winner of the main race at Belmont Park yesterday was a compass. Preferably one that was de-magnetized. The name of the feature purse was the East Hampton, and it was obvious that a horse named Southarlington must win it.

Daniel J. Riesner declared last night that President Eisenhower's "strong foreign policy and his love of peace" had put on the Soviet Union's leaders "pressure for a change" that resulted in the replacement of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov by Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin.

PARIS, April 26 -- The fishing season opened as usual in Europe this month and as usual that redoubtable angler Mr. Izaak Molotov took out his tackle box and resumed pursuit of his favorite quarry -- Germany and the control of Europe. Having spent a decade trying artificial lures, designed either to frighten or attract, the Soviet statesman, like Mr. Walton, has resorted to live bait.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Administration's plan to build a 2,900,000 defense reserve moved further away from compulsory universal military training today.
The see-saw state of world shipbuilding is reflected in a quarterly report issued yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

The subject of mounting production costs and how to reduce them dominated yesterday's sessions of Press Week. Ideas for solution of the problem were exchanged at the opening of the sixty-ninth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -Prospects for a granting of full statehood to Hawaii and Alaska by Congress appeared to be dim tonight. It was not, however, a complete blackout.

The City Stores Company and consolidated subsidiaries had a record net income of $5,422,119 in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 29, according to the annual report, issued yesterday. This compared with $4,987,000 for the preceding year.

"The Teachings of the Compassionate Buddha," a selection of the basic writings on Buddhism, will be published May 6 by New American Library. It will mark the mid-point of the two year observance of the 2,500th anniversary of the founding of Buddhism.

On a 5.1 per cent sales increase, earnings of the United States Steel Corporation in the first quarter of 1955 climbed 62.1 per cent above the year-ago level to set a first-quarter record of $72,652,402, Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman, reported yesterday.
A new research station in eastern Arizona has been established by the American Museum of Natural History.

LONDON, April 26 -- The firmness of sterling and yesterday's rise on Wall Street encouraged a better tone in the stock markets today. A broadening of business was accompanied by higher prices in Government bonds and industrial shares.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) --The House Banking Committee, after a reported party-line fight, voted, 15 to 11, today to approve a proposed investigation of Federal financial policies.
The International Business Machines Corporation has been selected by the Air Force to produce digital computers of "unprecedented capacity and reliability for the nation's air defense."

NEW DELHI, India, April 26 -- Burma and Ceylon may not attend the Simla conference on the United States Asian aid program. M. C. Shah announced this to Parliament today in comparing the United States and Soviet aid programs for Asia.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Asian-African meeting at Bandung, Indonesia, was a "useful and good conference," George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- A new type of mail service designed to give the advantages of registered letters at a lower cost will go into effect about June 1, Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -An Office for Foreign Investment, to spot investment opportunities abroad for private American capital, has been set up in the Department of Commerce.
According to your paper of April 17 Father Nunez, the Costa Rican Ambassador to the United Nations, stated, in effect, that Puerto Ricans don't love New York and New Yorkers don't love Puerto Ricans.
ALBANY, April 26 -- Three Eastern Governors and the Mayor of New York called today for a searching re-examination of the Federal Civil Defense Act.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 26 -Premier Ngo Dinh Diem moved today to try to break rebel control of South Vietnam's National Police.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, April 27 -- Two high-ranking United States officials left for Washington today after a threeday visit to Formosa.
TRENTON, April 27--Samuel L. Bodine, Republican state chairman, declared here today that the entire New Jersey Republican organization favored the renomination of President Eisenhower in 1956.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- President Eisenhower indicated today that he might go further in protecting domestic industries under the new reciprocal trade bill than "protectionist" members of Congress had hoped.
National advertisers spent $594,120,000 in newspapers last year. While that is 1.2 per cent below the record of $601,224,000 set in 1953, the indications are that the 1955 figure will top it.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 27 (AP)--Jeffrey Scott rushed through the stretch with Stan Adams driving to take the one-mile Whitestone Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:09 1/5. He finished a length in front of Carmel Boy, handled by Bill Haughton.
Olds Ships and New Plans to build an atomic-powered merchant ship need not cause premature mourning among those romanticists with whom tradition dies hard.
The Court of Special Sessions will soon be enlarged by the addition of three associate justices to be appointed by Mayor Wagner.
Israel's seventh Independence Day was hailed yesterday in messages and with special ceremonies that underscored the young state's progress and problems.
YESTERDAY (April 27, 1955) ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on International Commodity Trade -- Named drafting committee to prepare section on commodity trade
GREENWICH, Conn., April 27 --The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church learned here today about a new counter-attack on the menace of paganism in American cities.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 27 --A call for the integration of work skills into economic planning was sounded here tonight at the opening of a four-day conference on skilled manpower.
RAMAT GAN, Israel, April 27 --The armed might of Israel paraded before 30,000 spectator at a sports stadium here this afternoon as tea climax of Indedpendence Day.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday that its estimated consolidated net profits for the first three months of 1955 were the highest for any quarter in its history.

PITTSBURGH, April 27--The United Steelworkers Union, C. I. O., today gave formal notice to ninety-six basic steel and iron-mining companies that it wanted to reopen contracts to negotiate for another wage increase.
ALBANY, April 27--Governor Harriman approved the Republican rent control bill today, but he didn't like it.

The Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company of which Robert R. Young is chairman, is surrendering its control of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., investment company, to Texas interests. In the 1954 annual report, issued yesterday, Mr. Young disclosed that Alleghany is exchanging with Murchison Brothers, a Texas holding company, 212,000 shares of voting common stock of I. D. S. for an equal number of non-voting shares of class A stock.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York is negotiating to buy Carnegie Hall. If it does not make the purchase, it may have to look for a new home.

Domination of all nine track events, including two clean sweeps, gave New York University an 80-60 track and field triumph over Columbia yesterday at Baker Field. The contest was the Violet's only dual meet of the season.

On the front page of yesterday's Times was an Associated Press story from Lamar, Colo., telling of Secretary Benson's trip through the new dust bowl, "in search of ideas how to combat destructive soil erosion in the Great Plains."

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday that American Jews were generally integrated in the community life of towns and small cities, but were limited in their social friendships. It declared also that Jews faced strong prejudicial attitudes in rural regions.

NAHA, Okinawa, April 27-- The first typhoon of the season passed 400 miles east of Okinawa yesterday. For three days the United States' Far Eastern keystone of defense had been bracing itself for 100-to-125-mile-an hour winds.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head: market moderately active, generally steady to weak on butchers:: sows steady: most choice 190 to 230 Pounds butchers $16.75 to $17.25:

LONDON, April 27 -- Diplomatic experts of Britain, France and the United States met here today to prepare an approach to the Soviet Union on a Big Four conference. They are preparing for a meeting of their foreign ministers in Paris May 8, which is expected to tale decisions about any actual diplomatic initiative.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) --Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's press conference today.

The Nation's gasoline stocks shrank 2,123,000 barrels last week. The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that on last Friday supplies were 179,741,000 barrels, compared with 181,864,000 a week before and 178,033,000 a year before.
Bishop Fulton J. Sheen's television program will move from the Du Mont to the American Broadcasting Company network.

President Eisenhower's acceptance of the drastic revision by Secretary of State Dulles of a statement of major Far East policy that the State Department said the President had approved before it was issued is naturally under attack by the Democrats as another proof of incompetence and confusion in the Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The Federal Government acted under the anti-trust laws today against the Conrad Hilton hotel chain. It moved to force the chain to divest itself of four recently acquired Statler hotels in New York, Washington, Los Angeles and St. Louis.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 27--A scientific and engineering Reserve Officers Training Corps to help conserve the technical talent on college campuses is under consideration by the Department of Defense.
Governor Harriman approved yesterday a bill exempting property owned by foreign governments and used as headquarters for United Nations delegations from local realty taxes.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- John M. O'Mara, executive director of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, sharply attacked the New York City Police Department today for its handling of the wiretap scandal.

"Deadening uniformity" in advertising was attacked in rather sharp language yesterday by Miss Lucille Goold, vice president of Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc. In a talk before the Advertising Club of Columbus, Ohio, she said: "Brilliant advertising comes most readily from brilliant minds.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with much interest Dana Adams Schmidt's article on the South Vietnam crisis in The New York Times of April 21.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27 (UP)--The Kansas City Athletics gained their third straight triumph today, defeating the Boston Red Sox, 6--2, behind the three-hit pitching of Cloyd Boyer, a right-hander.
CHICAGO, April 27--Former President Truman declared tonight that failure to face up to the problem of civil right could lead to national disaster.

The Indians presented the white man with corn but, unlike the proverbial Indian giver, they did not take it back. The white man kept the cereal, and today corn is served as appealingly as ever, but in ways the braves and squaws might not have recognized.
A syndicate headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. is offering today $25,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent sinking fund debentures of Sterling Drug, Inc., manufacturer of medicines, toilet articles
Cardinal Spellman received the 1955 gold medal of the Metropolitan Association, Amateur Athletic Union, at a dinner attended by 1,000 persons in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel last night.
THE fisherman's spring is gradually appearing in Maine's northern counties. A few lakes are losing their shields of ice and the rivers are flowing, cold and high.
The economic outlook indicates continuing good business for Mack Trucks, Inc., P. O. Peterson, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting
