NEWARK, April 27--Wheeler Beckett's new opera, "The Magic Mirror," had its first performance this afternoon before an audience of school-age children at the Mosque Theatre.
LONDON, April 27 (Reuters) --The pound sterling rose today to its par value of $2.80 in London and New York for the first time since last November.
A peripatetic Mayor Wagner will culminate a busy three days of traveling this morning when he stops off in Washington to talk about natural gas.

Dr. Lawrence L., Bethel, a 49year-old former Missourian, was inaugurated yesterday as president of the Fashion Institute of Technology. The institute is the only public degree-granting college in the country devoted exclusively to training for the creative and executive techniques of the apparel and kindred arts.

When a country has definitely put the trough of a recession behind it and started to move upward the business statistics sometimes give the appearance of being better than they actually are. This is attributable to our habit of comparing the most recent figures with the comparable figrure of the previous year.

Ever since City Hall lost its stone facing last year, a crew of ninety workmen has been laboring prodigiously to restore it. They are doing this with pneumatic hammers, chisels mallets, circular and drag saws, planer, cranes and 3,500 tons of Alabama gray-veined limestone.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) --Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on the problems at low-income farmers which includes Secretary Benson's aid proposals: President's Message TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: In this wealthiest of nations where per capita income is the highest in the world, more than one-fourth of the families who live on American farms still have cash incomes of less than $1,000 a year.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 27--President Anastasio Somoza is a worried and embittered man. He is convinced that Jose Figueres, President of Costa Rica, is out to dispose of him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27--Dana Andrews and Rhonda Fleming are the first of seven principals to be engaged for "News Is Made at Night." Final revisions in the screen play are being completed by Casey Robinson. Fritz Lang, the director, plans to start filming on June 1.
VIENNA, April 27--Chancellor Julius Raab asked the occupation powers today to leave Austria in time for the opening of Vienna's bombed but reconstructed State Opera House Nov. 5.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- President Eisenhower laid before Congress today a program aimed at helping 1,500,000 farm families bolster their own and the country's economic and social position.
DETROIT, April 27 (AP)-- Frank House slammed his first big-league grand-slam home run today. The blow gave the Detroit Tigers an 11-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

Obviously vinegar is an essential in the well-stocked larder. But the shopper confronted by the wide assortment of this condiment may well ask how many varieties it is necessary to have. The question is particularly timely now, for spring and summer are the seasons when vinegar comes into greatest use--for salads, barbecue sauces and pickling.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- President Eisenhower said today that bringing more workers under the wage and hour laws was more important than raising the minimum wage.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California, today bitterly attacked the Eisenhower Administration's willingness to negotiate directly with the Chinese Communists.

LONDON, April 27--Yesterday's stock-market improvement, the first appreciable recovery since the budget was announced, ended today. Relapse in Government securities turned market prices irregular again.
The Maritime Administration called on shipyards yesterday to bid for the building of an unusual twin-screw drydock type cargo ship able to withstand Arctic ice.
Awards for distinguished service to the community were presented yesterday to three alumni of Dartmouth College.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 27-- Princeton's baseball team scored a run in the thirteenth inning today to defeat Rutgers, 5-4, on University Field.

IT was in 1926 that two remarkable athletes arrived in New York. One was a wideeyed 16-year-old from Louisiana and the other was a dashing 25-year-old from Canada. They charmed the fans with their personalities and thrilled them with their performances. Our town has had few sports idols with the appeal of the kid from Louisiana, Mel Ott, or the man from Canada, Frank Boucher.

A fight over the will of John R. MacKinney, stockbroker and heir to oil millions, was indicated in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The oil wealth had come from Mr. MacKinney's grandfather, John L. McKinney (who spelled the name differently), a pioneer oil producer and onetime associate of John D. Rockefeller Sr.

Defense sales of the General Motors Corporation in the first three months of 1955 accounted for only 9 per cent of total dollar sales, according to the quarterly report soon to be issued to stockholders by Harlow H. Curtice, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman.

Mrs. Ada L. Rice of Chicago collected first money in the Fashion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday --but she didn't collect it with the filly that was supposed to be the varsity member of her two-horse team.

Mayor Wagner delivered his proposed executive budget of $1,783,086,557 on April 1. Beginning on April 12 three days of public hearings were held by the Board of Estimate. Now the board in a meeting lasting five minutes has approved a budget reduced by $750,874 from what the Mayor first suggested, this change reflecting a failure of state aid to meet earlier expectations.

WASHINGTON, April 27--President Eisenhower revealed today he had been in personal correspondence with Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov within the last three weeks. The President declined to disclose what had passed in the mail between the White House and the Soviet Minister of Defense. Nor would he say who had initiated the correspondence.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- Amateur psychiatrists interested in Dwight D. Eisenhower as a person and amateur politicians interested in him as a political phenomenon would do well to study the President's performance at today's press conference.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 (UP) Bob Purkey pitched a four-hitter to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 4--1, today. The victory was the Pittsburgh Pirates' second of the season.
The five-story building containing fifty-eight apartments at 2760 Grand Concourse the Bronx, has been purchased by Arnold T. Milton and Irving J. Salitsky.
Gene Conley, a 6-foot-8-inch pitcher, came close to making pygmies of the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

"THE DIGNITY OF MAN,* by Russell W. Davenport (1899-1954), approaches the ultimate questions of human existence on this planet in the grand manner. It is a research magnificent, written in a mood of somber audacity. There are no easy answers here for those who ask what we must do to be saved, how we are going to resolve the struggle between East and West, between the forces of darkness and the forces of light.
For seventeen minutes yesterday stocks took a beating. They then recovered much of their early strength and closed with only moderate losses.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Administration economists are watching the business upsurge with caution lest the country "get into a false rush and then fall back."

Jazz will ring out this summer in the symphonic precincts of the Berkshires. The Berkshire Music Barn, a summer musical hall devoted to concert jazz, will open July 2. It's location is about a mile down the road from the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, Mass., where the Boston Symphony will hold forth.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The United States Public Health Service today ordered temporary withdrawal from use of Salk vaccine made by Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif. Six cases of paralytic polio have occurred in children who received it.

The final step in parliamentary approval of the Paris pacts by all fifteen signatory nations is now being taken by the upper house of the Netherlands Parliament. As the lower house has already approved the pacts by the unanimous vote of all members except a few Communists, favorable action by the upper chamber is assured.

CHICAGO, April 27--Inland Steel Company's sales and earnings in the first three months this year were the highest on record for a first quarter and production topped any quarter in the company's history, stockholders heard at the annual meeting here today.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP)--Dave Smith of Gastonia, N. C., the medalist, survived two rounds of match play today to lead the way into the quarterfinals of the North and South amateur golf tournament.
Another convicted top Communist leader asked permission yesterday to leave this country voluntarily. The Government has no intention of stopping him.
Cotton, futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices closed 9 points (45 cents a bale) higher to 17 points (85 cents) lower than on Tuesday.
LONDON, April 27--Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan told the House of Commons today that he hoped "the whole situation in the Far East may begin to develop along more favorable lines."
"The Honeys," a melodramatic farce by Roald Dahl, co-starring Jessica Tandy, Hume Cronyn and Dorothy Stickney, has its Broadway premiere tonight at 8 at the Longacre Theatre.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- President Eisenhower said today he had a "sixth-sense" feeling that the outlook for peace had brightened.

Prizes for operating delivery trucks and other vehicles with low accident rates were awarded to twenty-one daily newspapers yesterday at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- President Eisenhower asserted today that he confined security in the news wholly to technical military information that could be of help to a potential enemy.
Louis E. Wolfson announced yesterday that he planned to name Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, merchandising specialist, as a minority director of Montgomery Ward Co.
California borrowed $30,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds to help finance the construction of public schools.

PARIS, April 27--In an effort to clear the way for final French ratification of the Paris agreements to arm West Germany, Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, now seeks a quick agreement on the Saar.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. Y., April 27--Farmers in arid lands have been plagued by droughts for thousands of years, yet scientists have evolved no reliable means of predicting moisture conditions for any specific year or season.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) --The Federal Housing Administration issued a new regulation today requiring all house purchasers with F. H. A. insured mortgages to pay their own loan closing fees.

An industrial plant at 134 Garfield Avenue in Jersey City has been subleased by the Belleville Warehouse, Inc., froth the Owens-Illinois Glass Company of Toledo, Ohio. The Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization was the broker.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 20:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While reading the pros and cons of compulsory automobile inspection the question has often come to me, "Must the government make us do it?" It seems to me that another intrusion on our private lives is unnecessary if we, the owners of automobiles, resort to self-help instead of complaining about the law.

HONG KONG, Thursday April 28--Commanders and soldiers of the Chinese Communist army have been ordered by Peiping to strive for the liberation of Formosa. At the same time a call went out to the world to settle international disputes by negotiation.

A building contractor has purchased the three five-story structures on plot 63 by 100 feet at 329-31-33 East Fifty-fourth Street. Frank Hurd sold the property for conversion into one Building with apartments. Edward C. Sternlight was the broker.
Dr. Adolph G. Anderson, Professor of Chemistry at City College, has blended teaching and music into his own formula for living.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Revision of the restrictive refugee law was endorsed by President Eisenhower today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read your editorial of April 22 "Trade Bill in Danger." In this editorial you say, "Those who are opposing it are in effect saying that we can't stand competition." You also say, "The American economy was built on competitive capitalism."
An era of labor relations "more cordial than we are accustomed to having" was predicted yesterday by A. H. Raskin, labor reporter of The New York Times.
ROME, April 27--The Italian Senate and the Chamber of Deputies will meet in joint session tomorrow to elect a successor to President Luigi Einaudi for a seven-year term.
YESTERDAY (April 27, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Held news conference. Sent to House message for extended programs of education, guidance and credits to farmers.
Bipartisanism in foreign policy is unattainable in any atmosphere short of a shooting war, Arthur Krock, New York Times political columnist, asserted here yesterday.
Sales and profits of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., last year were "adversely affected" by a long strike against its Pittsburgh store, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, said yesterday.
Two industrial and business groups yesterday sharply criticized a proposed tariff covering waterfront loading.

YONKERS, April 27--A $30,000 Cadillac hard-top sports car was exhibited here today. The gold-plated model was a style leader at the $500,000 International Automobile Show that opened at Cross Country Center.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 27-- South Vietnam's new police chief served warning today that the Government would put a direct challenge tomorrow to rebel troops in this city.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- United States policy in South Vietnam's political crisis is still in the balance, President Eisenhower indicated today.

The Administration victory on reciprocal trade won in the Senate Finance Committee should blind no one to the fact that the measure as reported still contains some regrettable compromises and still falls short of the moderate bill originally proposed.

New Yorkers will join officials of the Police Department in hoping that an increase in the number of arrests of automobile thieves will result from recently inaugurated procedures. Now alarms for stolen vehicles and lost or stolen license plates are broadcast hourly to all radio patrol cars.
The American Gas and Electric Company expects to be able, in about twenty years, to handle a peak load nearly five times as large as today's.
Twelve adjourned games in the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament at Buenos Aires were played yesterday, according to a news report from Argentina.

The Young Women's Christian Association of the United States held the final session of its week-long convention yesterday. Its last official action was adoption of a guide to members stressing the interfaith and interracial principle of the movement as basic to world peace.
LONDON, April 27--The Labor party's "shadow cabinet" will recommend tomorrow the readmission of Aneurin Bevan to the Parliamentary Labor party.

THE performance last night by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House brought back two leading dancers from its first season in 1940 to help celebrate its fifteenth anniversary. They were Patricia Bowman and Nina Stroganova, both of whom appeared in "Sylphides," along with Ruth Ann Koesun and Erik Bruhn.

BERLIN, April 27--The United States, Britain and France have vetoed the issuance of pistols to West Berlin customs men. The Western action reversed a move by West Berlin city officials to arm customs guards who patrol the Soviet zone border.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 27 --Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, attacked the State Department's Far Eastern policy here today.

MIAMI BEACH, April 27 (UP) --John Holman, a Chicago Negro, scored a technical knockout tonight over the former heavyweight champion, Ezzard Charles, at 2:48 of the ninth round of their ten-round bout at the Miami Beach Auditorium.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Free liquidation in May deliveries of wheat, corn and soybeans caused sharply lower prices hi these futures today. New crop deliveries of wheat showed a strong undertone, influenced by discouraging weather and crop advices from the Southwest.

WASHINGTON, April 27--A bill to build up a ready defense reserve of 2,900,000 by 1960 was approved by the House Armed Services Committee today. The vote was 31 to 5. It was expected to go to a floor test next week.
LONDON, April 27 (AP)--The Soviet Union has sharply stepped up its orders in Western shipyards for merchant ships.
A high, corked jug, suitable for vinegar or saki wine, won first prize for Nadine Zamichow in the second annual "Pottery for the Gourmet" competition of the Greenwich House Pottery.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 27--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies apologized to the United States in the House of Representatives tonight because Leslie Haylen, a Labor member, had made "gross and improper imputations" against it.

Richard W. Slocum, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, warned the press yesterday to maintain its guard against censorship of news and restrictions on news sources. He said freedom of the press could be lost through lack of vigilance.

The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce charged yesterday that unions in the publishing industry were endangering the nation's free press. The organisation declared that a "monopolistic combination" of labor contravened the Constitution.

Interspersing seven hits among the thirteen walks they received from five rival pitchers, the Dodgers sauntered to a 7-2 triumph over the Redlegs at Ebbets Field last night. The defeat was the sixth straight for slumpbound Cincinnati.

The Health Department reported last night that 2,100 packages of the Cutter anti-polio vaccine, banned yesterday by Federal health officials, had been sent to forty-five wholesale drug distributors in the state.

ONE of the oddest and most intriguing exhibitions to appear in some time is that of "studies in bizarre nostalgia d maritime fantasies" by Stephen Tennant at the Iolas Gallery, 46 East Fifty-seventh street.
A four-point program to raise $162,000,000 for the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation gets under way today.
That exclusive club consisting of American corporations with a billion or more assets had seventy members at the end of 1954. Just after the war ended in 1945 there were only forty-three.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Eisenhower rejected today any compromise of principle with the advocates of the Bricker amendment. The amendment would limit Presidential treaty-making powers.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 28 -- West German armament received its final parliamentary blessing today. The Dutch Senate cast a historic 32-to-2 vote for the Paris treaties.
TRENTON, April 28 -- New Jersey Republican and Democratic leaders gathered here today for the annual state conventions of their respective parties.

MONTREAL, April 28 (UP) -- Sid Smith, 29-year-old Toronto Maple Leaf left wing, broke Red Kelly's grip on the National Hockey League "gentleman's award" today when he was named winner of the Lady Byng Memorial Trophy for the 1954-55 season.
LONDON, April 28 -- The Government failed tonight to obtain cancellation of the nation-wide railroad strike due at midnight Sunday.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation had the most profitable first quarter in its history this year, Eugene G. Grace, chairman, reported yesterday.
CORK, Ireland, April 28 -- Luggage and mail were destroyed in a fire in the hold of the 27,000-ton Cunard liner Britannic three days out of New York.
The decision of the Supreme Court this week in the Pedreiro case has clearly confirmed the right of all aliens to a final federal court review of Immigration Service deportation orders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- The British Board, of Film Censors has issued a general warning to Hollywood to tone down scenes of violence, crime, passion and exploitation of sex or else run the risk of having such pictures banned from distribution in Great Britain.
ALBANY, April 28 -- The State Health Department informed local health officers today that free Salk vaccine for 725,000 children would be available some time during next week.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- New York City's consumers of natural gas deserve protection against "unbearable and unwarranted" price increases, Mayor Wagner told a Congressional committee here today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Port employers threatened today to stop all dry-cargo handling in this port.
An art-loving robber has stolen a statue from an apartment in a Greenwich Village building whose brickwork is not yet all up, the police revealed yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Consumption of zinc in the United States this year is expected to set a new record high of 1,050,000 tons, about 8 per cent above the peak 967,000 tons in 1950.

No matter how one looks at it, the Afro-Asian Conference just concluded at Bandung represents a victory of no mean magnitude for Red China. Chou En-lai was in top form and played the diplomatic game with consummate skill. His closing statement was an amalgam of sweet reasonableness and calculated deceit.

Elisha Hanson, general counsel of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, advised it yesterday to fight the proposed anti-trust action against it. Otherwise, he warned, the Government could put advertising in a straitjacket and control the press as in totalitarian countries.

National Distillers Products Corporation is attempting by means of brand-name promotion and print-media advertising to become "not one of the Big Four distillers, but No. 1." Alynn Shilling, director of advertising for the company, made a statement to this effect at a testimonial luncheon given for him at the University Club yesterday by advertising representatives of the newspaper, magazine and trade field.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Run for Cover." a Paramount drama in Vista Vision and color with James Cagney, Viveca Lindfors and John Derek, is at the Criterion. Jean Hersholt, Grant Withers and Ernest Borgnine head the supporting cast.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 28 -- A new concept of the use to which the nation's educational resources might be put in developing specialists was presented to the conference on skilled manpower at Arden House tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- House farm leaders backed off from a two-price plan for wheat today. The Administration is counting on the proposal to help defeat the bipartisan farm bloc's bill that includes restoring rigid price supports.
Celebrating its fifty years of service, the Travelers Aid Society of New York announced yesterday that through the years it had helped 16,000.000 distressed travelers.

A new organization known as the Union Square Merchants and Property Owners Association, Inc., was formed yesterday at a luncheon in Luchow's Restaurant. Its purpose is to promote and revitalize the Fourteenth Street and the Union Square area.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 28 -- The first debate in Parliament on the Nationalist Government's plan to pack South Africa's highest court ended last night after three days of acrimony.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 28 -- Steps were taken today to form a constitutional convention.
Minus signs were the order of the day in Wall Street yesterday. For every issue that managed to push ahead in New York Stock Exchange dealings, there were about three that fell.
The 1954 Bancroft Prizes, presented annually by Columbia University "for distinguished writings in American history," were awarded last night to Leonard D. White and Paul Horgan.

BOSTON, April 28 -- A coordinated program for restoring paralyzed victims of industrial accidents to usefulness will be undertaken this year in Boston. The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, Boston University and the Massachusetts Memorial Hospitals will participate.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 10 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the Board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1954:
An early resumption of publication by The Brooklyn Eagle eemed possible last night.
Loans to business by major New York City banks in the week ended on Wednesday increased $31,000,000, the first rise in five weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, a "personal and political" friend of Edward O. Lamb, described the publisher-broadcaster today as a loyal and valuable citizen.

The Junior League of the City of New York, Inc., 130 East Eightieth Street, elected Mrs. Carl W. Gram Jr. as vice president and Mrs. N. Edward Mitchell as treasurer at its annual membership meeting yesterday.
After five years, the police got yesterday their first important break in the stubborn Bronx "Sugar Bowl mystery."
At least 219 persons here have been inoculated with the banned Cutter anti-polio vaccine. The Health Department reported this yesterday after questioning 179 physicians who had purchased the vaccine.

A "State of the Union" address today by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, will open the eleventh annual Model Congress at the college's auditorium, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Friday, April 29 -- Civil warfare exploded in Saigon yesterday. This city has become a place of death fire and the hysterical homeless.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- Willie Jones hit a lead-off ninth-inning homer tonight to give the Phillies a 3-2 triumph over the Milwaukee Braves. It was Robin Roberts' third victory against one loss.

The Ford Motor Company is going to stake $625,000,000 more on expanding national prosperity. Henry Ford 2d, president, announced last night that the company would spend that much in the next three years for new property, plants and equipment.
Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke was sentenced yesterday to two to three years in prison for compulsory prostitution.

IDEAS that the homemaker can adapt are liberally scattered through the room settings and vignettes arranged on Gimbel's ninth floor by Ellen Lehman McCluskey, decorator. They will be open to the public on Monday.

A "challenging" view of American history is presented by Oscar Handlin in his newest work, "Chance or Destiny: Turning Points in American History." Atlantic-Little, Brown will issue it May 9. The author, an Associate Professor of History at Harvard University and a Pulitzer Prize winner, points up the role that chance has played in determining the course of this country's history.

GENEVA, April 28 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, warned the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration today against depending too much on the United States "to absorb greater numbers of people."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals today ruled out collection of contingent fees -- 5 per cent or otherwise -- to "drum up" Government business.

The New York Stock Exchange, according to Keith Funston, president, is one of the sights of New York, if not the world. He is urging all and sundry, New Yorkers and hinter-landers, to come see the New York Stock Exchange through new facilities to be opened Monday at 18 Broad Street.
Hugh R. MacMillan Jr., vice president in charge of production of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, Jersey City, has been elected a director.

I wish to commend The Times on its strong editorial opposition to the Echo Park Dam Project. Senatorial approval of this program can only indicate either a complete indifference or a total lack of judgment by those in political power. Surely the preservation of the National Parks in all their primeval splendor is of immense importance in this modern age when natural areas are being decimated with unbelievable swiftness by the onrush of civilization.

THE Dessoff Choirs, under the direction of Paul Boepple, performed Monteverdi's "Vespers and Magnificat in Honor of the Blessed Virgin" at Carnegie Hall last evening. The performance was under the sponsorship of Baron Carlo de Ferraris Salzano, Consul General of Italy.
CAIRO, April 28 -- Egypt has agreed with the Soviet Union and Rumania to trade cotton and cotton yarn for kerosene and crude oil worth 3,100,000 Egyptian pounds (about $9,000,000).
Pach Brothers, photographers, in 673 5th Ave: Tripple Inn Inc, restaurant and cocktail lounge, in 41 W 56th St -- Pease Elliman Inc. brokers.

ARNOLD SOWELL runs just about the same way Ray Robinson used to fight -- with rippling rhythm. Sugar Ray was as sweet to the eye as sugar is to the palate. So is the Saccharin Swiftie from Pitt. He's a delight to watch and the customers at the Penn Relays today and tomorrow will see a lot of him because the 19-year-old boy is scheduled for at least four races.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A right-wing Republican asked the Senate today to repudiate in advance any territorial concession the Eisenhower Administration might make to Communist China.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- James C. Hagerty, Presidential press secretary, says he took a woman reporter to task for taking pay from the Congress of Industrial Organizations while acting as a White House correspondent.
Proposals for development of seventy-eight acres of the Lower Bronx were taken under consideration yesterday by a group of public officials and business and civic leaders.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., April 28 -- Historians of Westchester County, N. Y., and civic leaders of the West began a pilgrimage today over the 350 miles that Washington Irving traveled by horseback in 1832.

Mrs. Raymond Loewy of 605 Park Avenue, chairman of the Vocational Advisory Service Benefit committee, gave a tea in her home yesterday afternoon for committee members. Plans were made for the summer premiere of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Oklahoma!" in the Todd-AO film process.

Electric Bond and Share Company directors yesterday declared a spinoff, subject to the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission. This would consist of a payment to stockholders of 1.8 shares of United Gas Corporation common stock for each 100 of Bond and Share held.

The Bed o'Roses Handicap, named for one of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's fine mares, was the big race on yesterday's program at Belmont Park. Vanderbilt's Sometime Thing, a 3-year-old Discovery-Now and Again filly, went to the starting gate the 3-2 favorite with Ted Atkinson in the saddle.
Answers to such household riddles as how to stop the sound of dripping water from a faucet without calling a plumber are contained in a report from Mrs. Homemaker's Forum.
The text of an address by Elisha Hanson, general counsel of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the association's convention in the Wadorf-Aastoria Hotel yesterday follows:

The acting director of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, Dr. Donal Sheehan, has been named dean of the College of Medicine and of the Post-Graduate Medical School and deputy director of the Medical Center. The announcement was made yesterday by Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of the university.

In their supplemental briefs, requested by the Supreme Court, the lawyers on both sides of the case of Prof. John P. Peters of Yale were meeting an issue which the court pressed but which the lawyers themselves had not raised. This was the question of the authority of the President's Loyalty Review Board to "post-audit" loyalty clearances of Peters by the Board of Inquiry of the Federal Security Agency, where he was a special consultant.
TOKYO, April 28 -- Former Premier Shigeru Yoshida said today that Communist China and the Soviet Union had "extended their clutches toward Japan." He prescribed extreme caution in dealing with them.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A Republican party publication charged today that Governor Harriman of New York, then United States Ambassador to Moscow, "was the real architect of the tragic Far East agreements in 1945 which gave communism domination in Asia."

THERE are two chief varieties of travel books that make equally good reading. One makes you want to go there, too. The other makes you glad you don't have to go there. In the first the author describes his travels in some civilized country where there are hotels and restaurants, cathedrals, castles and history.
Shreveport, La., borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday on two issues of bonds maturing serially over twenty years.

Ten thousand volunteer workers are taking part in the drive of the Greater New York Fund to raise $9,000,000, which began this week. The money will help to make up the operatating deficits of 423 agencies that serve 3,000,000 persons a year.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 28 -- Conversion of arid lands to industrial -- not agricultural -- use was proposed today as an appropriate economic step for twentieth century civilization.

A six-story apartment house accommodating twenty-nine families at 65 Willoughby Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by G. Pearson to the 65 Willoughby Avenue Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $120,000, occupies a corner plot 102 by 62 feet at Clermont Avenue.

KANSAS CITY, April 28 -- The Yankees routed the Kansas City Athletics tonight, 11 -- 4, in as weird a game as ever 32,559 fans paid good money to see. Since this area operates on Central Standard Time it was 1:15 A. M., Friday, in New York when the Bombers regained first place.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 28 (AP) -- Brazil ordered a "temporary" halt today in its coffee price support program. Finance Minister Jose Maria Whitaker said coffee supplies in consuming countries "are short."

RALPH EDWARDS, presiding jumping-jack of "This Is Your Life," at times can be thoroughly trying with his forced enthusiasm and excitement, but it must be conceded he also comes up periodically with television of genuine human interest.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Housing and Home Finance Agency announced today a $725,000 loan to Manhattan College, New York. The money is to be used to build a dormitory to house 182 men students and five prefects.
The trouble in South Vietnam is one part volatile nationalism and one part bizarre and chaotic struggle for power.

Stockholders of Daitch Crystal Dairies, at the annual meeting here yesterday, approved an increase in the authorized common stock from 500,000 shares of $1 par value to 1,000,000 shares. Herbert R. Daitch, president, confirmed reports that a proposed merger with another supermarket chain was in "the talking stage."
DESPITE lowering skies, ing cattle and low-drifting worms, high-principled dry-fly fishermen have managed to entice a few trout from several Catskill streams during the past two days.
VIENNA, April 28 -- The Russians granted the Austrian Government today several minor relaxations of their occupation regime.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 28 -- Professional jealousies that hinder the treatment of the mentally ill were sharply criticized today. The critics were state mental hygiene officials of New York and Connecticut.
YONKERS, April 28 -- The Cross County Center celebrated its first birthday today by adding the three-story department store of John Wanamaker Westchester.
Directors of Central National Bank in Yonkers and County Trust Company in White Plains approved a plan yesterday to merge the two institutions under the name and charter of the latter.

City Labor Commissioner Joseph E. O'Grady expressed certainty yesterday that a wage agreement would be reached between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., without any disturbance to transit service.
LONDON, April 28 -- An immediate end to all tests of hydrogen and atomic weapons was proposed as British policy in the Labor party's election manifesto, issued today.

New York housewives would do well this week-end to acquire that Southern way with chicken, for fryers are being offered in city stores at lowered prices. Supplies increased this week for the first time in several months and, as a result, the city-wide average for young, three-pound chickens dropped from 49 to 45 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George suggested today the possibility that some neutral nation might represent the Chinese Nationalists at any international talks aimed at settling the future of Formosa.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $156,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PARIS, April 28 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of South Vietnam, issued an order today summoning the Vietnamese Premier, Ngo Dinh Diem, to Cannes. He ordered that military power be given to Gen. Nguyen Van Vy, who opposes the Premier.
BONN, Germany, April 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, will discus the Saar and other European problems at their two-day conference opening tomorrow.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc,. had first quarter net earnings of $12,607,000 compared with $11,319,000 a year earlier, Stuart M. Crocker, chairman, told yesterday's annual meeting at Wilmington, Del. Earnings for twelve months ended on March 31 were $1.10 a share, compared with 79 cents a year earlier, he said, adding that earnings for the full year would be about $24,000,000. This compared with $19,550,000 in 1954.

The Giants pulled out a close decision with the Cardinals yesterday, 6-4. Strong pitching by Jim Hearn and Mary Grissom and a couple of timely bursts of hitting turned the trick for the New Yorkers. They also profited from some shoddy St. Louis fielding.
Many persons prominent in society attended the "Gay Thirties" dinner dance held last night in the grand ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.
LONDON, April 28 -- Prime Minister Eden, in a gesture of amity toward Communist China, declared in Parliament today that Britain subscribed to the five principles of peaceful coexistence.

FLORENCE, Italy, April 28 (UP) -- Herb Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., won his opening match today in the Florence international tournament. In another contest Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn was eliminated after an umpire's ruling had sent him stalking off the court in anger.

MILWAUKEE, April 28 (AP) -- The Army Engineer Corps awarded Max Nohl, Milwaukee diver, a contract today to remove and salvage the Dutch motor ship Prins Willem V, which sank in Lake Michigan after a collision Oct. 14.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate Small Business Committee was asked today to investigate the Federal Trade Commission's administration of the antitrust laws.

Congressional circles are said to be alarmed because our military reserve forces, although ostensibly considerable, are actually largely "paper" reserves. The present action of the House Armed Services Committee in reporting out a bill presumably to provide for a trained reserve has certainly done its best to keep those reserves on paper.
The merger of Remington Rand, Inc., and the Sperry Corporation would result in a company called the Sperry Rand Corporation, it was learned yesterday from proxy statements of the two concerns.

Both Corliss Lamont and Columbia University disclosed yesterday that Mr. Lamont had withdrawn as a lecturer on philosophy pending disposition of contempt proceedings against him. Columbia's statement emphasized that the move was a voluntary one on the part of Mr. Lamont "without prior suggestion by any officer of the university."
Net income of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in the first three months of this year increased 16.8 per cent over the corresponding quarter in 1954.

General Dynamics Corporation cleared $3,914,000, equal to 89 cents a share, in the three months ended on March 31, John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president, reported at the annual meeting in Dover, Del., yesterday. This compares with $3,313,000 or 74 cents a share for the comparable 1954 period.
A proposed $800,000 study of rapid transit problems in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area appeared to be threatened with abandonment last night.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 28 -- For the second successive day, some 5,000 soldiers and civilians assembled at Yueca Flat early today to see the biggest demonstration detonation in the nation's nuclear history.

Nobody is really prepared to be President of the United States. Until they have been in office for a year or so our Presidents are of necessity amateurs. But as one reads the transcript of one of Mr, Eisenhower's press conferences -- let us say the one he held this week -- it is clear that if he is not yet a professional he is doing pretty well for an amateur.

Realty men rallied yesterday to the support of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc. At an informal meeting in the offices of Webb Knapp at 383 Madison Avenue, donations of $5,500 were made and others will be sent later.
The Sanitation Department, in a new phase of the anti-litter drive, sought yesterday to put its own house in order.
ALBANY April 28 -- Governor Harriman appointed Grant F. Daniels, a former St. Lawrence County Assemblyman, as a Republican member of the State Liquor Authority today.

Bedtime skirmishes and going-to-sleep battles may comprise the children's hour in many a home. However, a reasonable facsimile of the peaceful hour of poetic renown is possible, two child guidance specialists believe.
The fourth game between Alexander Kevitz and James T. Sherwin in the playoff for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club resulted in a draw yesterday after thirty-two moves.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 28 (AP) -- Dave Smith, the medal winner, knocked off Dale Morey, Walker Cup team player, 1 up, with a birdie in a 21-hole thriller today. This victory sent him into the semi-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament, along with Bill Campbell, Don Bisplinghoff and Ed Gravely.

Burlington Industries, Inc., offered yesterday to purchase for cash the outstanding common stock of Goodall-Sanford, Inc., at $20 a share, Announcement of the offer and tender forms are being forwarded to Goodall stockholders.
Subway riders using the Jay Street station of the IND system saw spots before their eyes yesterday.
Excessive vibration, which has kept the new fireboat John D. McKean out of service since she was delivered to the city last September, has been corrected.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today he would be ready Monday to testify on the Bricker amendment to limit the President's treaty-making powers.
JERSEY CITY, April 28 -- The Hudson County grand jury returned six indictments today against three persons involved in its investigation of municipal "no-show" jobs in Jersey City.
An eighth-place hitter brought he Dodgers from behind to beat he Cubs, 4 -- 2, at Ebbets Field yesterday before 10,871 half-congealed fans.

Next Tuesday many school districts in the neighborhood will hold the annual -- known less formally as The May -- meeting. The notice of this event must be published. The notice also must be displayed conspicuously here and there, which explains the bits of paper now tacked to trees and telephone poles across the countryside.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -The Treasury announced plans tonight for a $6,400,000,000 refinancing operation.

IT was quite the biggest night of the Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The program was an "all-Tudor" one, consisting of four works by Antony Tudor that had been out of the repertory for five years or more until this season.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 28 (AP) -- The United States District Court here has ruled that it has jurisdiction in suits filed against both foreign and America-flag ships passing through the Panama Canal.
It took a jury only ten minutes yesterday to clear a probationary patrolman of a charge of first-degree manslaughter in the slaying of a 15-year-old boy.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee today invited District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York to appear next week and answer critical testimony by John M. O'Mara and William J. Keating.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The names of 330 applicants who passed the examination held March 3 and 4 for admission to the bar were announced today by the State Board of Law Examiners. The tests were taken by 861 persons.

Fred F. Finklehoffe is the latest showman to announce his intention of bringing "The Loud Red Patrick" to Broadway. The others who have expressed similar bents over the years have been Jed Harris, Michael Myerberg, George Abbott and Herman Shumlin.
ALBANY, April 28 (AP) -- Governor Harriman signed a bill today designating seven interstate highway routes and putting New York State in line for millions in Federal highway aid.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28 -- A well-informed source here said today that he had heard an account similar to that reported by Representative Powell regarding American prisoners held by Communist China.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Trade in grain and soybean futures today was largely a matter of evening up on May contracts. There were active spurts of buying in the new crop wheat deliveries as the general tenor of the crop news was disturbing to shorts, but rallies did not hold.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TOLEDO, April 28 -- Because of high salaries paid by industry, the most qualified college graduates are now going into business or research rather than teaching.
LONDON, April 28 -- The threat of a railway strike kept the stock markets quietly irregular here today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Public Health Service today greatly intensified its scrutiny of polio cases in children inoculated with Salk vaccine.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Eisenhower spoke out again today for his trade bill as a great instrument for the promotion of peace.
CHICAGO, April 28 (UP) -- Twelve persons died in fires that swept a hotel and tenement on the crowded Near North Side today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 28 -President Eisenhower's elaboration at his news conference yesterday of the United States attitude toward cease-fire talks with the Chinese Communists apparently did little to allay the fears of the Nationalist Government or the people here.

CORPORATE whimsy isn't easily achieved, but major enterprises keep trying for it just the same. Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road, pouring into the city yesterday. found on their seats a light-yellow printed slip.

When a New York all-star team helps the Nuremberg Soccer Club of Germany open its seven-game tour on Sunday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, the player the Americans will be watching the closest will be Max Morlock. They merely will be following orders.

ALBANY, Calif., April 28 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker, the nation's leading jockey since 1953, apparently escaped serious injury today when he somersaulted over the head of his stumbling first-race mount, Marveco, at Golden Gate Fields.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 28 -- A plan to establish "flexible, all-purpose" church units in areas were there are "critical shortages" of religious facilities was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley criticized President Eisenhower today for having exchanged "friendly correspondence" with Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Friday, April 29 (AP) -- Robert C. Hendrickson, United States Ambassador here, said today it was his impression that President Eisenhower was not seeking a second term "but as a soldier he would not refuse to accept his obligations."

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, today called for dispersal of future airplane and missile factories inland from the East and West Coasts to reduce choice targets for enemy bombers.

MONTREAL, April 28 -- Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Ltd., said today that the recent decision to continue expansion of the Kitimat, B. C., smelter "reflects what appears to be an unrelenting demand for primary aluminum.

Assistant Secretary of the Treasury H. Chapman Rose said yesterday that his department will ask Congress, "almost immediately," to enact further simplification of customs procedures that now hamper import trade.
The United States Supreme Court has abused its power on many occasions in recent years, Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said here last night.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Department of Justice will institute proceedings under the anti-trust laws against the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the Association of American Advertising Agencies, and other groups in the publishing industry.

JUDGING by the feminine laughter in the Longacre there must be a number of wives who would like to emulate the achievements of the wives on stage. For "The Honeys" in Roald Dahl's farce which had its premiere last night, are not so sweet as you may think they are.
ROME, April 28 -- A joint session of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies failed in three ballots today to elect a successor to President Luigi Einaudi for a seven-year term.

Last December we recorded with regret the closing of the John Wanamaker store on lower Broadway. Yesterday there was a Wanamaker opening, of the newly completed three-floor store at the Cross County Center in lower Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The White House finally cleared the political snarl around Ewan Clague today and sent the Senate his appointment as Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 28 -- Communist China today tightened its political, cultural and economic ties with Indonesia, the largest country in Southeast Asia.

The Board of Education has rejected an offer by the Socialist party to sponsor an essay contest in the city schools. The topic was to have been "How Cooperative Enterprise Has Helped to Make America Great."

TOKYO, April 28 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said today he thought the United States fliers imprisoned by Communist China would be released. He talked briefly with Premier Chou En-lai of Red China at the Asian-African conference at Bandung, Indonesia.

Now that the Soviets have agreed to a meeting of the Big Four Ambassadors in Vienna to draft the final text of the Austrian independence treaty it becomes necessary to draw attention to one problem which imposes a moral responsibility on the West.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 26 -- The flight to freedom from behind the Iron. Curtain halts in a camp near here with an iron cot in an old wooden barracks, 26 cents worth of food a day and $3.27 a month for everything else.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that private power companies had no legal recourse against "destructive Federally subsidized competition" that might put them out of business.

RICHMOND, Va., April 28 (AP) -- The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway will earn about $6.15 a share this year, President Walter J. Tuohy told the annual stockholders' meeting today. He added that the figure did not include $2,800,000 received this year as a cash refund on excess profits taxes paid during 1940-45.
A Pulitzer Prize playwright and a high official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation differed sharply last night on the question of national security.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The United States is giving Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam all possible backing in his struggle with the rebellious Binh Xuyen.
The former plant of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation on the East River at Forty-eighth Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold to the 4-63 Forty-eighth Avenue Corporation.
A continued need for new housing, rather than a collapse due to excessive building, was forecast yesterday by Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner.

The eighteen-story loft building on a plot 60 by 98.9 feet at 39 to 43 West Thirty-seventh Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, has been sold by Morris Furman to Frederick Brown. The sale was for cash over a new first mortgage of $450,000 made with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Irving Berlin did not appropriate the song "I Fell in Love" and use it as his own under the title "You're Just in Love," Supreme Court Justice Martin M. Frank ruled yesterday.

The Times has been giving deeply appreciated help to the effort to save our national park system from destruction. Meanwhile, here at home, Central Park is being damaged at such a rate that restoration will soon be possible only at a cost that will never be undertaken.

GENEVA, April 28 (AP) -- Swiss and United States trade experts opened negotiations here today in an effort to compensate Switzerland for the 50 per cent increase in the American tariff on Swiss watches last July.

Just like any householder getting ready to move, a Chemical Corn Exchange Bank branch cleaned out the basement this week and found something it had forgotten it owned. It was at granite block 8 feet long, 2 high and 1 thick, wrapped in hair felt and snugly crated.

A sordid picture of dock-boss rule at the Leonardo Naval Base in New Jersey was painted yesterday at the opening session of a waterfront commission hearing. Kickbacks, gambling and even attempted murder were pictured by a witness.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 28 (AP) -- Ed Furgol, the national open champion, Chuck Harbert, and Gene Littler tied for the lead with 69's today in the first round of the $37,500 Tournament of Champions.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 28 (AP) -- Racing Fool, living up to his name with each passing day as Kentucky Derby time approaches, won the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland today. It was his most important score in four straight victories.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Administration has regained some freedom of maneuver in the Formosa Strait, and it intends to exercise that freedom despite the anguished cries of its own leader in the Senate.
Events today: Columbia University Concert Band, Low Library Plaza, 4:25 P. M.; Down Town Glee Club, Carnegie Hall, 8:30, and Equitable Life Assurance Society Choral Concert, Town Hall, 8:30.

Coffee tumbled the 2-cent-apound limit in the July and September deliveries yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by news that the Brazilian Coffee Institute had stopped buying surplus supplies and rumors that Brazil might abolish its dollar minimum selling price.

The Socony-vacuum Oil Company had record first-quarter earnings of $47,000,000, equal to $1.34 a share. This compares with $46,000,000 or $1.31 a share earned in the first quarter of 1954. B. Brewster Jennings, president, at the annual meeting yesterday said net income in the 1955 quarter would have been even higher except for non-recurring expenses of $3,000,000 to $4,000,000 incurred in starting new refineries.

The Wally Cox show, which will be in the nature of an end-of-the-season experiment, will replace "Mr. Peepers" May 15. The comedian plays the title role in the latter program, which ends its run May 8.

MONTREAL, April 28 (AP) -- Andre Robinson, 21, today was fined $35 for attacking and squashing a tomato on President Clarence Campbell of the National Hockey League during a riot at the Montreal Forum March 17.
Many teen-aged girls, like squirrels, have a mania for collecting things. Not only do they collect -- they insist on carrying everything with them.

Nearly 300,000 children in five states and Hawaii have been inoculated with the banned Cutter anti-polio vaccine. Dr. Hart Van Riper, medical director of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, listed this figure yesterday in reporting on the foundation's nation-wide program.
In her only New York stage appearance this season, Cornelia Otis Skinner, the renowned monologuist, will present "The Wives of Henry VIII" at the Plymouth Theatre tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock.
MANILA, April 29 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo said tonight "the Asian and African peoples were welded together into an active political force" at their conference in Bandung.

The Traffic Department has shortened the time limit for metered parking in downtown Manhattan, and says it has grounds for believing that motorists like the change. The reasoning back of this was outlined yesterday by Lawrence Lawton, the department's traffic planning engineer.

Kalb Voorhis Co, members of the New York Stock Exchange, in 25 Broad St; Lithoprint Co of New York, in 145 Hudson St; Otto Bihr. renovating men's hats, in 299 7th Ave; Samuel Oser. David Leseten, law and accounting; Hargrave Secret Service, detective agency; Alfrebro Corp. flavoring extracts; Jule Gordon, Manfred Evans, sales representatives for toiletries, in 60 E 42d St -- Helmsley-Spear Inc. brokers.
Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia is in undisputed possession of first place in the Buenos Aires jubilee chess tournament according to a report received yesterday from Argentina.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday called on its membership to "stamp out the evil practice" of the hot tip on stocks.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -- The All-German Bloc abandoned today its Social Democratic allies in Lower Saxony and agreed to form a state government with the members of the Adenauer coalition. This decision ended the four-year rule of the Social Democrats in Lower Saxony.
Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in April was the smallest since October, 1954, but represented the largest volume for any April since 1931.
Short uptown stretches of Fifth and Madison Avenues have been temporarily converted to one-way routes while the Third Avenue Bridge across the Harlem River is reconstructed.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 29 -- The Brazilian coffee market was paralyzed today by uncertainty about the Government's policies on prices and foreign exchange rates.

LONDON, April 29 -- The Government will make every effort to arrange a meeting with the Soviet Union, Sir Anthony Eden said today. He also pledged all efforts to reach solutions of international issues that will rid the world of fear.
The idea that academic freedom could not exist in a Roman Catholic college or university was denied yesterday as "far too sweeping and absolutely not true."
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Average primary market prices in the nation rose 0.1 per cent over the week ended April 26 to 110.4 (1947-49 equals 100).

SYRACUSE, April 29 (AP) -- Chico Vejar scored a technical knockout over Giampaolo Melis of Italy tonight when Referee Mark Conn stopped their scheduled ten-rounder after four rounds. Vejar weighed 149 1/2 pounds, Melis 148.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- New crop wheat deliveries were weak for a time early today, although there was no change in the crop news from the Southwest, where dust storms were again reported. Buying improved later, but traders were still taciturn.
DETROIT, April 29 (UP) -- Frank Lary worked his way out of two late-inning jams today to pitch the Detroit Tigers to their sixth straight victory, a 3-2 decision over the Washington Senators.

The feud between New York and Connecticut over motor-vehicle regulations flared into the open again yesterday -- this time over mud flaps. These gadgets dangle behind the rear tires of trucks. They are supposed to keep mud and stones from being thrown against the windshields of automobiles. York truck drivers not long ago, and ticketed them for driving without flaps.
The fifteenth annual observance of National Family Week will be held from tomorrow through May 8.

Today we say good-by to April -- a good month. April is youth. It is hope. It is promise. Couples walking hand-in-hand in the park. Jumping ropes, jacks, marbles, baseball, cries of "Not it! Not it!" It's
DETROIT, April 29 -- The pace of labor negotiations in the auto industry appears to be quickening.
The National Broadcasting Company has embarked upon a multi-million-dollar search for new talent for its television network.

With its "family doctor plan" Group Health Insurance moves into a new area of group protection against the unpredictable economic blows of illness. Also, in promptly adding its approval of the plan to that of the Kings County Medical Society, the New York County Medical Society helps keep the profession in step with progress.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States opposed today President Eisenhower's proposal to raise the minimum wage from 75 cents an hour to 90 cents.

R. C. Ingersoll, president of Borg-Warner Corporation, and E. S. Dulin, president of Byron Jackson Company, announced yesterday in San Francisco that they have agreed and will recommend to the respective boards of directors that the two companies merge.

An observance commemorating the 166th anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as President of the United States was held yesterday in Federal Hall by the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A Texas inventor received a patent this week for a method of logging by helicopter, Clyde E. Bannister of Houston says his chief object is to make commercially feasible the removal of widely scattered dead or diseased trees from a forest without the expense of clearing lanes and dragging logs over the ground.
L. Judson Morhouse, New York Republican state chairman, appealed yesterday for the help of New Jersey Republicans in solving metropolitan New York transit problems.

In Germany and England today the common man is able to buy things which the common man in tile United States has been able to buy for years. The rise of socialism and communism in Europe, which now seems to be on the decline, was helped to a great extent by what one authority has aptly termed "the frozen class barriers" of Europe.
An attempt to improve school penmanship will be started soon by fifty specially trained teachers.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A Senate Public Works subcommittee approved today a five-year road building program calling for Federal and state outlays of $21,739,000,000. The measure differed sharply from the Administration's highway program.

The pace of new securities offerings, although down somewhat in recent weeks, continues to be fairly rapid, and the volume substantial. Momentarily, offerings of new common stock or securities convertible into common are in the foreground, as issuers take advantage of the stock market's popularity with investors.

A New York syndicate headed by Roy M. Syme has purchased the Sayville Shore Club in Sayville, L. I. The property occupies a six-acre tract on Great South Bay at Handsome Avenue. It contains a hotel with 120 rooms and a 300-foot pier.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 29 -- Charles A. Karvwatt, a Sperry picket who was convicted Monday of disorderly conduct, drew a suspended sentence today from Judge Samuel Greason in First District Court here.
HONG KONG, April 29 -- Communist China has moved against the "abnormal, most dangerous" hoarding of food by peasants.

In keeping with the constitutional processes of the new and democratic Italy, the Parliament of that country, enlarged by delegates from regional councils, has elected a President to succeed President Einaudi, whose seven-year term is expiring. The new President, third to be elected since the overthrow of the monarchy in 1946, is Giovanni Gronchi, who was chosen on the fourth ballot by the overwhelming vote of 658 to 81.

PARIS, April 29 -- Decrees to institute a tax reform program were approved by the Cabinet tonight. They will be issued officially tomorrow just within the deadline set by the Assembly for action by decree.

KANSAS CITY, April 29 -- Bobby Shantz was the little left-hander of old tonight, hurling the Kansas City Athletics to a 6-0 victory over the Yankees. The diminutive southpaw, whose career had been jeopardized because of shoulder and arm trouble the past two years, turned in a magnificent three-hit job.
TOKYO, April 29 (AP) -- All newspapers and periodicals in Communist China will begin using simplified characters from this Sunday, the Peiping radio announced today.

Leonard V. Harrison, director of the bureau of public affairs of the Community Service Society, yesterday urged the establishment of a "consolidated family court of comprehensive jurisdiction in child and family cases."

In the enthusiastic reception attending the success of the Salk polio vaccine one fact of import appears to have gone unnoticed. Dr. Jonas E. Salk, who is a graduate of the City College, might never have received a college education and his discovery might not have been made available to mankind, certainly at this time, were it not for the free higher education system of the City of New York.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, explored today the possibilities of furthering the policy of European integration. The discussion at the opening of their two-day conference covered two main points.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 29 -- Finiscope, a closed-circuit television system that furnished a close-up view of the stretch action and the finish, was unveiled tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Sales of three bond issues totaling $43,000,000 were postponed yesterday by local government bodies in California.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- Chairman Ralph H. Demmler of the Securities Exchange Commission called tonight for an expanded, industry-supervised program of policing securities advertising.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Monty Woolley has been coaxed out of retirement by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to portray the role of Omar, the poet-tentmaker, in "Kismet."

FRONAU, Germany, April 26 -- About 130,000,000 anti-Communist leaflets and newspapers have been sent by balloon into Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland in a psychological warfare operation. It is an operation whose first anniversary is being marked this week.

The motion picture "Martin Luther' 'has been banned from public showing in the Philippines Peru and Egypt by the censor boards of those countries, according to the film's producers, Louis de Rochemont Associates. Last year the film biography of the founder of the Reformation movement was banned in the Province of Quebec.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Prices received by farmers for their products rose 1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 29 -- The contents of Dr. Albert Einstein's will were made public today by Dr. Otto Nathan of New York, executor of the famed scientist's estate.

The jazz portion of the jazz and variety concert to be presented at Carnegie Hall next Friday evening for the benefit of The Lighthouse, New York Association for the Blind, will be recorded at the performance by Norman Granz.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 30 (AP) -- The Peiping radio suggested last night, in a back-handed way, "there was no ground for cease-fire talks" between the United States and Red China -- because the two countries are not at war "at present."

WHITE PLAINS. N. Y., April 29 -- Action was taken today by state and county governments toward building a $5,800,000 home for the Westchester Community College. Rented space in Battle Hill School here is now used for classes.
In a fine town in a suburban county two children, checked by group X-ray as a matter of precaution in the school district, were found to have tuberculosis.

Daylight-saving time is with us again and, as usual, train timetables have been changed accordingly. I think that the most convenient system is used by the Long Island Rail Road, where one hour has been advanced on the timetable to correspond with the clocks of the state.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will extend Commodity Credit Corporation loans on farm-stored 1953 crop corn for another year after July 31.

Twice recently in articles covering the question of fluoridation of drinking water you have published the statement that the teeth of children in fluoridated Newburgh were found to be 60 per cent better than those in non-fluoridated Kingston.
BUENOS AIRES, April 29 (AP) -- A pro-Government newspaper accused the Roman Catholic church today of violence in the controversy between the clergy and President Juan D. Peron's regime.

An industrial plot of about 32,000 square feet on Wilbur Street, near Merrick Road, in Lynbrook, L. I., has been sold by Gustave Sabo to the Long Island Holding Company. Greer Brothers, brokers in this transaction, also arranged a lease with the new owner for a factory type building under construction on the property.
ALBANY, April 29 (UP) -- A bill requiring public-school children to salute the flag every day was vetoed by Governor Harriman today.
The Navy lifted from its confidential file yesterday a broadly sketched picture of its offshore radar ship program.

Two high-ranking Indian women visited Lord Taylor a few years ago to display wares from their native land. The store's fabrics buyer was intrigued by saris the women brought. Color and style details were worked out with one of the Indian women (a United Nations delegate) and the store has been selling saris ever since to enthusiastic Americans.
The American Israeli Lighthouse will give a luncheon for the blind of this country and Israel on Thursday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 29 (Reuters) -- The South African House of Assembly voted today, 78 to 50, in favor of a Government bill increasing the Supreme Court quorum from six to eleven judges for cases testing acts of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate Finance Committee gave assurances today that domestic industries would be protected under the new national security clause of the reciprocal trade agreements bill.
Three thousand patrolmen will receive special training, starting next month, in fostering tolerant human relations in the city.
Of the two religious sects that formed a coalition with the Binh Xuyen group in March to try to oust Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, only one appears to have stayed in the fight. And it is of divided loyalty.

FLORENCE, Italy, April 29 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris gained the men's singles semi-finals today in the Florence international tennis tournament, defeating Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy, 9 -- 7, 7 -- 5.
Gambling and boss rule on the docks of the Leonardo Naval Base continued yesterday to highlight a Waterfront Commission hearing.
ROME, April 29 -- Giovanni Gronchi, a member of the left wing of the Christian Democratic party, was elected today as the third President of the Italian Republic.

New financing in April was maller than in either the preceding month or April last year. Bond flotations were substantially below the March level and stock offerings were the smallest so far this year.
LONDON, April 29 -- Feverish efforts to prevent a nation-wide rail strike at midnight tomorrow went on all day today but repeatedly failed. They will be resumed tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The American Medical Association complained to Congress today that physicians in the armed services were employed too much in non-military duties, such as delivering babies.

Gov. Robert R. Meyner of New Jersey told editors of weekly newspapers attending a convention here yesterday of new opportunities for success and service. He spoke of the movement to suburbs of city populations and a decline in the number of daily newspapers as two forces that have created these opportunities.

Dispatches recently published in this newspaper from Costa Rica and Nicaragua show that the wounds of last January's conflict are yet to be healed. The whole of Central America and the Caribbean area was shaken by the fortunately abortive attempt of Costa Rican exiles to invade their country from Nicaragua and overthrow the democratic regime of President Jose Figueres.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Gov. Luis Munoz-Marin talked to President Eisenhower today about letting more refined sugar come into the United States from Puerto Rico.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 29 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon said today a Thai delegation had been invited to tour Yunnan Province in China. It is there that 20,000 guerrillas allegedly are being trained for action against Thailand.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- More than 65,000 of the 210,000 independent automobile service stations in the country went out of business last year, the Senate Small Business Committee heard today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- New York University scored its first championship relay victory here since 1951 as the sixty-first annual Penn Relays began at Franklin Field today. The hero of the occasion was George King, a 129-pound anchorman from Boston.
PARIS, April 29 -- Premier Edgar Faure said today that the Government of Ngo Dinh Diem in South Vietnam was not equal to its task.
With both the Dodgers and Giants rained out of their scheduled games last night, the Brooks made the baseball news for the day by releasing three players.

The Government will not be successful if it files and brings to trial its proposed anti-trust suit against the American Association of Advertising Agencies, counsel for the association declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies scored six runs in the fifth inning tonight to whip Milwaukee, 13 -- 4, and move into a tie with the Braves for second place in the National League.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -- Government leaders acted today to dispel any opinion that neutralism had become rampant in West Germany since the Soviet-Austrian agreement on the terms of an Austrian treaty.
ALBANY, April 29 (AP) -- Governor Harriman squashed today a move to rename the New York State Thruway after his Republican predecessor, Thomas E. Dewey.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 29 -- The Danish Government's representative, Finance Minister Viggo Kampmann, arrived at Thorshavn in the Faeroe Islands by plane today.
DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -- The automobile industry will set up more new high production marks this week.

VIENNA, April 29 -- The Russians took their first step today toward restoring Austria's air sovereignty. They announced in the Allied Council the withdrawal of their opposition to the operation of planes by the Austrian air rescue service.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Tomorrow is the first deadline for something like a million new tax collectors -- the householders who pay a domestic helper an average of $4 a week or more. The new Social Security law that went into effect Jan. 1 qualified domestic help for Social Security if they made $50 a quarter or more from any one employer.

LIVERPOOL, England, April 29 (Reuters) -- Detectives boarded the 27,666-ton Cunard liner Britannic when she berthed at Liverpool today to investigate a serious fire in her hold during the Atlantic crossing from New York.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- Bayuk Cigars, Inc., announced today it has purchased all outstanding stock of Grabosky Brothers, Inc., Philadelphia cigar manufacturing concern. The announcement said the transaction involved about $2,500,000 in assets, and payment for the stock was made in cash.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 29 (AP) -- A hailstorm with winds up to 140 miles an hour struck Fort Lauderdale today. The brief but violent storm caused damage estimated at $200,000, but there were no serious injuries.
The five-story apartment house accommodating forty-one families at 18 Kensington Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the New Jersey Realty Company to Leo Bruck and Milton Schoenholz.

For whatever it may be worth, there has been one development in Moscow since the death of Stalin which deserves Western commendation. This is a greater accessibility of important Soviet personalities to representatives of the outside world -- in particular, to the Moscow corps of foreign correspondents.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Costa Rica called on Vice President Richard M. Nixon today to inquire into charges that hostile refugees from Nicaragua are harbored there and trained for aggressive ends.

Mayor Wagner issued some more proclamations yesterday. He designated May as Cerebral Palsy Month, May 8-15 as Hospital and Blue Cross Week and the seven days beginning tomorrow as Brooklyn Philharmonia Week.

From Messina to Milan, Miss Maria Luisa Taglienti toured Italy in 1952 for regional specialties to include in "The Italian Cookbook" that Random House will publish May 6. Her volume (310 pp., $3.50) deserves space on the kitchen book shelf because of its many typically Italian recipes not readily available elsewhere.
Net income of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and consolidated subsidiaries for the first three months of this year was the highest for any initial quarter in the 153year history of the company.
VIENNA, April 29 -- Austrian officials said today refugees from Communist East Europe need not fear forced repatriation following conclusion of an Austrian state treaty.
Last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House found Nora Kaye dancing her only Juliet of the season in Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet" with Hugh Laing again as Romeo.

PARIS, April 29 -- In many respects this is a propitious moment for talks with Communist China. From our point of view there is much to be gained by relieving tension. The anxious situation forces us to concentrate an abnormal amount of military power in the western Pacific.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 29 -- The English teachers of this state complain that they have become the jacks-of-all-trades of the teaching profession. They say they no longer hold the favored position in the high school program.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator John W. Bricker clashed sharply today with a witness who opposed his constitutional amendment to limit the President's treaty-making powers.

Following only twenty months after the worst earthquake to hit Greece in modern times, and for the fourth time within that period, another quake has brought more death and destruction to that stricken land. It has virtually destroyed the port city of Volos, the fourth largest town in Greece, with a population of 55,000.

CHICAGO, April 29 (UP) -- Nellie Fox hit his first American League home run in Comisky Park today to help a rookie White Sox hurler, Dick Donovan, gain a four-hit, 7-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 29 -- Saigon was two cities today, and one was dying.
Stock market debt is not excessive now but it has been rising fast, according to the New York bankers who lend most of the money to brokers and dealers.

PORTRAITS IN REVIEW, the annual exhibition at Portraits, Inc., 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, is always an enjoyable occasion. This year, sixty-three painters and sculptors participate, and the subjects range in eminence all the way from John Foster Dulles, Mayor Wagner and Thomas J. Watson to "Kate," a miniature dog of some exotic breed.

The regional Red Cross blood program collected 598 pints of blood on Thursday. Included were 200 pints taken at City College at 139th Street and Convent Avenue on the first of two days there and 141st Street and Hamilton Terrace.
