With reference to the article by C. L. Sulzberger in The New York Times of April 18 I feel bound to make the following comment:
HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 29 -- A drastic revision of the role of secondary schools in preparing young people for their life's work was advocated today at the Arden House Conference on Manpower.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 29 (UP) -- Gene Littler, Palm Springs, Calif., golfer, took a three-stroke lead at the half-way mark in the $37,500 Tournament of Champions today. He posted a sub-par 71 for a 36-hole total of 140.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Congress was urged today to authorize removal of "a few thousand" defense plant workers who might commit espionage or sabotage in a crisis.
LONDON, April 29 -- Dr. Igor Sikorsky, Russian-born helicopter pioneer, forecast today a great expansion in the manufacture and use of helicopters.

Today's new film is "The Boys From Leningrad," a Russian-made drama in Sovcolor, at the Stanley Theatre. The Lenfilm Production was written and directed by S. Timoshenko, with a cast headed by G. Vitsen, V. Kuzuetsov and M. Burns.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 29 -- The United Nations was asked today to aid desert lands farmers by encouraging establishment of weather stations in arid zones throughout the world.

Events today: Orchestra of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York and soloists of the High School of Performing Arts, Town Hall, 2:40 P. M.; Program of songs and operatic excerpts, Third Street Music School Settlement, 5; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

By any standard the civil war that has flared in southern Vietnam is tragic. It is necessary to build up a young Government to meet the needs of administration and at the same time to prepare for defense both against external onslaught and internal subversion.

The President's Cabinet Committee's report on transport policy and organization issued by the White House early this month received yesterday the endorsement of the Association of American Railroads. Directors of the organization at a meeting in Washington issued a statement terming the report "an important contribution toward working out . . . changes in transportation policy made necessary by changed competitive conditions."

Trans World Airlines officials estimate that 85 per cent of the passengers now using the company's installment payment plan would not have made the flights they did if the credit system had not been available. T. W. A. put its "time-pay" plan into effect last summer.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders today to a White House conference Tuesday to discuss the Administration's request for $3,530,000,000 to fight communism around the globe, particularly in Asia.
NORTH LAWRENCE, N. Y., April 29 (AP) -- Two State Troopers shot it out with four armed jailbreakers today and captured one, after surprising the four in an abandoned farmhouse.
Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California in the first three months of 1955 amounted to $53,130,557, equal to $1.76 a share, it was announced yesterday by R. G. Follis, chairman.
Left-wing groups held their traditional May Day rally in Union Square yesterday -- two days ahead of the international holiday.
CANNES, France, April 29 (AP) -- Dienbienphu was dying when Bao Dai quit Vietnam on April 10, 1954, for his most recent visit to France.

A Brooklyn electronics concern and two of its officials were fined yesterday for fraudulent practices in the resale of radio and television tubes. The penalty was imposed in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, where the company and men had been found guilty on March 21 after a four-day trial.

The development of segregation in the South is the subject of a new book by C. Vann Woodward entitled "The Strange Career of Jim Crow." The author, Professor of History at Johns Hopkins University, describes the rise of Jim Crowism after the withdrawal of Federal troops in 1877 and the developments later in the fight against segregation.
It has been a long haul for the Flying Scot. It is a haul that started on Feb. 1, 1954, when the Giants traded Bobby Thomson to the Braves for Johnny Antonelli.

CAMP DESERT ROCK, Nev., April 29 -- One of the field telephone relay points here is coded "Angry 26." That code name aptly describes the disturbed mood of more than 1,000 officers who came and went home without viewing an atomic explosion.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- A spokesman for twelve American veterans of the Elbe River meeting of United States and Russian troops in 1945 said today the way had been cleared for the former G. I.'s to leave Tuesday for a Moscow reunion with the Russians.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The United States is not prepared to abandon Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, although it recognizes that his political life may be numbered in days.

CANNES, France, April 29 (Reuters) -- Bao Dai, Vietnamese Chief of State, today ordered Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, former Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese Army, to leave for Vietnam on a mission to leaders of the private armies opposing Premier Ngo Dinh Diem.

Chiefly because she hadn't raced since last December at Bowie, Miss Weesie didn't get a great deal of mutuel window attention at Belmont Park yesterday. She was only the fourth choice in the seven-horse feature. Result: an easy score.

MADISON, Wis., April 29 (AP) -- The Republican-controlled Wisconsin Senate rode out a twenty-four-hour Democratic filibuster today to pass, 14 to 9, a bill that would prohibit labor unions from contributing to political campaigns or candidates.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Government took $81,595,072 in cash today for three huge Port Neches, Tex., rubber plants and thereby substantially completed the sale of its synthetic rubber industry to private enterprise.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The United States is not prepared to abandon Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, although it recognizes that his political life may be numbered in days.

CANNES, France, April 29 (Reuters) -- Bao Dai, Vietnamese Chief of State, today ordered Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, former Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese Army, to leave for Vietnam on a mission to leaders of the private armies opposing Premier Ngo Dinh Diem.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Saturday, April 30 -- South Vietnam's army was winning the battle of Saigon yesterday against rebel forces. But its leader, Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, was fighting for his political life against the Chief of State, Bao Dai.

Early deliveries of coffee and cocoa suffered limit declines yesterday on the New York futures markets. Both commodities were influenced by the news that Brazil had ceased temporarily to stockpile coffee and by rumors that the minimum dollar export price would be lowered.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A rigid embargo against all trade with Japan will be invoked by Korea if Japan engages in trade with North Korea, Dr. You Chan Yang, Korean Ambassador to the United States, warned here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, threatened today to suspend Philadelphia Local 1291 land its membership of about 2,500.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg refused yesterday to order back pay for Dr. Frank S. L. Lloyd, former Professor of Hygiene at City College. Dr. Lloyd was charged in 1952 with conduct unbecoming a teacher because of his alleged activities in the promotion of "big time" basketball at the institution.

LONDON, April 29 -- The stock markets weakened further today under the combined force of a threatened railway strike and the setback in sterling. Only South African gold mining shares and a few selected foreign bonds remained firm.
TETERBORO, N. J., April 29 -- Members of an American expedition to the North Polar basin departed this afternoon in a converted air freighter from Teterboro Airport.

NORFOLK, Va., April 29 -- An official of the Seafarers International Union said yesterday that the union was willing to make adjustments in wage and manning scales to halt the decline in the volume of commercial ships flying the American flag.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 29 -- How to make an attacking enemy mass and thereby provide profitable atomic targets was an underlying concern of the fifth and biggest annual command exercise of the North Atlantic alliance that ended here today.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 29 -- Many mental patients are "mistreated" by state legislation that prevents the use of Federal funds for their rehabilitation, it was charged today.

A burglary suspect stabbed a priest five times yesterday and was captured two blocks away by a patrolman on school crossing duty. The priest was in good condition in St. Vincent's Hospital last night.
DES MOINES, April 29 (AP) -- Four meet records were shattered and Oklahoma A. and M. set the pace as the forty-sixth Drake Relays started today.

A diminutive Brooklyn woman gave birth Thursday night to three diminutive girls -- the "biggest" weighed sixty ounces -- and about the only aspect of the event that measured up to expectations was dad's shock.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 29 -- A 113-acre national wildlife refuge has been established on Jessup Neck, a thin promontory that rises up to about fifty feet between Little Peconic Bay and Noyack Bay, some miles northeast of here.

DESPITE the advances in hand gun design, firepower and velocities since Wild Bill Hickok administered rough justice with his Peacemaker, the demand by hand gun shooters for this antique six-shooter has never abated.

ALBANY, April 29 (AP) -- Governor Harriman approved today bills increasing the state's gasoline tax two cents a gallon and the Diesel fuel tax three cents. For the bills to be effective, the voters must approve a $750,000,000 highway bond issue next fall.

NORFOLK, Va., April 29 -- The Department of Defense has designated Vice Admiral E. Tyler Wooldridge to succeed Lieut. Gen. Howard A. Craig, Air Force, as commander of the National War College in Washington.
ZIRNDORF, Germany, April 29 -- The Zirndorf center for refugees from communism is scheduled to open May 15.

The Bell Telephone Company of Canada celebrated its seventy-fifth birthday yesterday. It recorded a huge expansion of facilities -- and -- something of which it is very proud -- almost complete Canadian ownership.
Turnover on the New York Exchange dropped yesterday to the smallest since April 5 -- only 2,230,000 shares -- but prices advanced briskly.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Richard S. Aldrich, Broadway theatrical producer, was named today to be deputy director of the Foreign Operations Administration mission to Spain.
E. J. Hanley, president of Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, at the annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh said the shortage of nickel is becoming serious.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 29 (AP) -- Harry (Duke) Markell, a Rochester right-hander, pitched a no-hit game today to lead the Red Wings to a 9-0 victory over the Columbus Jets in the International League.
ROME, April 29 -- President-elect Giovanni Gronchi looks youthful for his sixty-seven years. He is also young at heart.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The United States is contemplating a token contribution of ground forces, probably Marines, to the defenses of Formosa.
The Weather Bureau here batted .500 during the first six days of the week. That's good baseball, but bad weather.
PITTSBURGH, April 29 (UP) -- A circus clown and a blind disabled war veteran were among seventeen persons cited by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today for outstanding acts of heroism.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, indirectly blamed the Democrats in part today for dust-bowl conditions in the West.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sunday, May 1 -- A revolutionary committee moved into the palace of South Vietnam's Premier yesterday and announced the ouster of Bao Dai As the country's Chief of State.
Penn's varsity crew retained the Blackwell Cup by defeating Yale and Columbia on the Harlem yesterday.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 30 -- All is quiet in Pumpkin Buttes. A potential "war" between ranchers and uranium prospectors has been averted, at least temporarily.

TRAIL riders hankering for wild places will find a wide selection of summer trips sponsored by the American Forestry Association, 919 Seventeenth Street N. W., Washington, D. C., including Bridger National Forest, Wyoming, July 10-21; Flathead-Sun River Wilderness in Montana, July 5-16; Sawtooth and Boise National Forest out of Sun Valley, Idaho, July 25-Aug. 5, and the Great Smoky Mountains of North Carolina, May 25-June 4.

Syracuse University is offering this summer a traveling workshop for teachers and civic workers through the university's Maxwell Graduate School of Citizenship and Public Affairs. Under the direction of Dr. Phillips Bradley, Professor of Political Science, the course will examine government on four levels -- local, state, national and international.

THE following, selected at random from the field, comprise a representative listing of some current 16mm. non-theatrical offerings, available for either rental or purchase, often both, at the source specified. All are of superior quality.

WHEN Einstein died the other day, this newspaper editorially observed that the great mathematical physicists are the epic poets of our time. "The universe as we conceive it," the editorial remarked, "is their intellectual creation."
PARIS, April 30 -- French relations with the states of Indochina have varied over nearly a century of association.

LONDON -- When the American tourist goes shopping in England this year he can look for some very helpful money-saving facilities -- and a few frustrations. It is vise, therefore, if you plan to buy cashmere sweaters, china figurines, leather goods, tweeds, whisky and the many other things traditionally looked for in the United Kingdom, to make quite sure you know the rules and can make the best of them.

OTTAWA, April 30 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign commodity trade continued to expand in March, but for the first month this year the volume of imports showed a greater percentage gain than exports.

WHO leaked the Brangwyn Report -- a most secret British Cabinet paper containing some explosively anti-French sentiments -- to the British correspondent of Le Monde Populaire, the third biggest daily in Paris? A paid spy? Communists in government, like the ones the Americans are always fussing about? Or who?

Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the High School of Performing Arts collaborated yesterday afternoon to present a free concert at Town Hall. The union arranged the financing and provided the fifty professional musicians who made up the orchestra.

LONDON, April 30 -- Admiral Jerauld T. Wright, United States Navy, Supreme Allied Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty forces in the Atlantic Ocean, paid tribute today to the "vast" improvement in tactical coordination and communications between the Allied navies over the past three years.
A SUCCESSFUL figure on the Finnish literary scene since 1920, Mika Waltari is best known to us over here as the writer of "The Egyptian." Very different is this stylized little tale.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- John B. Hollister of Cincinnati, a law partner of the late Senator Robert A. Taft, was designated today by President Eisenhower to head the new International Cooperation Administration.
Antibiotic "miracle drugs" have proved so effective in the fight against tuberculosis that one of the nation's largest free hospitals will start admitting cancer patients.

First-quarter earnings reports had a strong impact on the stock market last week. Almost all made extremely pleasant reading for shareholders and management alike. There were, however, some exceptions, and these disappointing reports, combined with the psychological effect of the new 70 per cent margin requirement, caused some nervous selling.

IMPRESSIVE evidence of the growing popularity of the print medium -- work both in black and white and in color -- is offered in three of the newly opened shows. The Brooklyn Museum has opened its ninth annual nation-wide survey; the Serigraph Society has put on its sixteenth annual with work from Europe, South America and Japan as well as this country; and The Contemporaries Gallery is showing prints by European and American artists.

SUBTITLED "A Guide to Competitive Coexistence." John Scott's fourth book is informative and often stimulating, but of uneven quality. The author is a much-traveled journalist who spent five years as a skilled workman in the Urals: the most readable and imaginative parts are those analyzing the pattern of Russian power, and suggesting ways and means of exploiting Soviet weaknesses.

JOHN DEAN may have been a valet with, as one of his former employers told him, "a tendency to be temperamental," but the trait stands him in good stead in this account of his five years' service with Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, the carefree young naval officer who has since become the conscientious Consort of Britain's Queen.
The formula for business success is as simple as the one for rabbit stew. Each has two main points:
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 30 -- The Women's International League for Peace and Freedom will observe its fortieth anniversary celebration this week.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Plagued by after-effects of the flu, which she contracted recently, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower today was forced to cancel all social engagements for the next week.

THE debates, speculations and negotiations are settled. Impresario S. Hurok, importer extraordinary of foreign talent -- this coming season he will have close to 400 foreign artists of one sort or another under his banner -- has booked the Broadway Theatre for the long-awaited first visit here of the celebrated Comedie Francaise.
The success story of the New York Women's Trade Union League's clubhouse came full circle last week when members voted to close the thirty-three-year-old institution because its work was done.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., April 30 (AP) -- Three men quit the 1956 United States Olympic bobsled squad today, criticizing the International Bobsled Federation and Donna Fox, the American representative in the international organization.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30 -- Detonation of the long-delayed demonstration atomic explosion was tentatively scheduled today for 5:10 A. M. tomorrow.
MASSAPEQUA PARK, L. I., April 30 -- Three teen-age boys who found a bank unlocked long after it had closed for the day received $25 savings bonds this week as their reward for notifying the polite.

CLEVELAND, April 30 -- Bob Lemon, Cleveland's ace right-hander, registered his fifth straight victory today. He defeated Baltimore with a four-hit pitching effort, 5 to 2. Lemon hasn't been beaten yet, and this was his fourth complete game in the string.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- What promises to be the biggest flop of the Congressional investigative season opens in Washington in mid-May.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Aprli 30 -- A woodpecker with a peck that sounds like an axe stroke has come to the attention of four big power companies in Pennsylvania and New Jersey and half a dozen university professors here.

For the last twelve months the financial world has been watching the remarkable stock market performance of the General Dynamics Corporation. This is the concern that last year launched the world's first atomic-powered means of transport -- the U. S. Submarine Nautilus.
WEST NYACK, N. Y., April 30 -- An effort by three boys from the Monsey Farm School at Monsey nead here to beat their way through the brush to Brooklyn almost ended in tragedy today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 -- A cylindrical brick chapel without windows will be dedicated May 8 at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The first collection of art to be sent from Spain to this country will be put on view on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

SINGAPORE, April 30 -- One of the salient features of last week's Asian-African conference in Bandung, Indonesia, was the fluidity of relationships between the twenty-nine participating nations. Countries in agreement on certain issues differed on others with the result that few clear-cut groupings of states were produced.

EVER since we announced the formation of a Brooklyn symphony orchestra I have been confronted by the frequent question: "Why an orchestra for Brooklyn?" The obvious answer would be: "Why not?" People who ask the question may be victims of the tendency to make Brooklyn the butt of more jokes than are heaped on all the other New York boroughs combined.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The United States is giving away more food than at any time since the heavy unemployment in this country before World War II.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- When Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet Communist party chief, talks about factory methods of building, which he intends to introduce on a vast scale in the Soviet Union, this is what he means.

ARLENE FRANCIS PRESENTS MUSIC APPRECIATION FOR THE HOME: Arlene Francis, commentator, with orchestra (Camden). Analysis, with music, of the Nutcracker Suite and Unfinished Symphony. Miss Francis is a charming speaker and the script by Fred Grunfeld is professionally done. The disk will be warmly received by those who believe music appreciation lectures teach people to appreciate music.

THE fields of psychiatry and mental health may provide the next big trend in television programming. A number of producers are developing shows dealing with psychiatric case histories, but it remains to be seen how they will be accepted by broadcasters an viewers.

HOW are things at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer? Just fine, thank you, declared three of the company's top executives in the course of announcements last week concerning future production activity, a new development in filming technique and the studio's current physical and mental state of health.

The Dodgers concluded the most successful April campaign in the Brooklyn club's recent history yesterday by registering a 7-5 victory over the Cubs. A Ladies' Day gathering of 15,651 watched the game at Ebbets Field.
LOUISVILLE, April 30 (UP) -- Swaps, the third choice for next week's Kentucky Derby, today sped to an eight-length victory in a six-furlong allowance race.

WHEN a New York restaurateur leaves home base to dine out in the big city, where does he go? How does he choose the establishment ? What does he eat ? How is it prepared? Answers to such questions both inspire and inform amateur cooks.

THERE'S a fellow who's been around the inside of the book world for quite a while now name of Richard Taplinger. He went out to Asia a while back and he recently came home all fired up. Now he has a publishing house that will publish from five to ten books a year -- theoretically constituting the best writing being done in the Far East. We shall hope and we shall see.

VOX has been making a specialty of Italian baroque music. Having pioneered with substantial volumes devoted to Vivaldi, it has now come forward with handsome albums devoted to two of his predecessors, Giuseppe Torelli born in 1650 and Arcangelo Corelli, born in 1655.

IN "Headquarters" Quentin Reynolds has written an authentic and continuously interesting account of the New York Police Department. He tells the story mainly through the departmental career of Inspector Francis D. J. Phillips, who is the over-all supervisor of the forgery, narcotics, safe and loft, special service and other units that comprise the Central Office Bureaus and Squads operating out of Police Headquarters.

It was with some amusement that I read Marybeth Weinstein's article "Woman's Case for Women's Superiority" (April 17). I should like to supply a few points that neither she nor John Willig's footnotes provided.

THE season of "American Dance" sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation gets under way on Tuesday at the ANTA Theatre in West Fifty-second Street with the cheering knowledge that already, because of the advance sale, a third week has been added to the two previously announced. It will now run through Sunday, May 22. The repertory for the first week is listed below. (The opening night curtain, by the way, is at 8.)

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower made a terse but emphatic commentary on the subject of refugees this week which ought to -- but apparently will not -- ease the headache this whole question has been causing his Administration the last couple of weeks.

Barnard College will collaborate with the National Broadcasting Company to present the fifth annual Summer Institute of Radio and Television from June 27 to Aug. 5 in the N. B. C. Studios, Radio City.

I have just read Albion Ross' article, "Germany -- Report on a Perplexing People" (April 3). His summation is well informed, and I think he was quite right in arriving at his doubts that the Germans have yet found their compromise with life.
Governor Harriman sought last night to justify his planned vetoes of controversial legislation in apparent anticipation of Republican attack.

Home runs by Gil Hodges, Duke Snider and Jackie Robinson enabled the Dodgers to defeat the Cubs, 7--5, at Ebbets Field yesterday. Russ Meyer went the route for the Brooks and achieved his seventeenth straight success over the Chicago team.

National Airlines will institute on May 15 sixteen-day summer excursion fare schedules that will reduce considerably the cost of flying between several northern cities and the airline's stops in Florida. The new rates will be applicable only to standard- fare flights.
The Maritime Administration is studying a Hoover Commission recommendation that all obsolete, over-age, badly damaged or useless ships in the defense reserve fleet be scrapped.

THE Sterling Professor of French at Yale has written a sparkling and exhaustive guide to the model French novel. It opens with the general European revival of 1910 and goes down to the present day -- that is to say, from the unjustly neglected Martin du Gard to Malraux, Sartre, Camus and Simone de Beauvoir.

ABOUT four years ago a large bathing suit manufacturer discovered that the marines were taking to the Pacific in the briefest of swim trunks. If these boys liked them, reasoned the manufacturer, why not other American young men? Result: A test run on the West Coast about two years ago.
SINGAPORE, April 30 -- Singapore faces tomorrow the most tempestuous May Day in its history.

A New York City health officer is marking this week the fiftieth anniversary of his work as he distributes supplies for the Salk anti-polio vaccine. He started his career half a century ago in Brooklyn and worked through a polio epidemic that struck 4,000 persons.

HORTON FOOTE, one of the pioneer television dramatists, was represented on the home screen last week with a new drama, his first in some time. It was good to have him back because his is always an interesting writing talent.

" I LIKE to blow loud. I like to blow fast and I like to blow high" said Bubber. And when Grandpa warned him against traipsing around with a horn in his hand he thought the old man didn't understand that a lonesome boy needed his silver trumpet.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 30 -- Estates on the North Shore of Long Island, homesites occupying from four to more than 100 acres of land, pose a problem for visitors and delivery men because they completely eschew the number system of identification.
It may be that the Cardinals will prove the surprise team of this year's National League pennant race. Certain it is they surprised Leo Durocher and his Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia defeated Enrique Reinhardt of Argentina yesterday to keep his lead in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires, according to a report from Argentina.
I AM very interested and glad to see that recent articles have raised a number of questions dealing with "Abstract Expressionism." Perhaps the subject can at last be openly ventilated.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30 -- Gene Littler all but wrapped up the $37,500 tournament of champions in the third round today. He fired a 4-under-par 68 to take a 10-stroke lead.

Nineteen college students have been chosen for fellowships for graduate study in the behavioral sciences by the Ford Foundation. The awards are for the 1955-56 academic year. They provide $1,800 for graduate work in fields that contribute to a scientific understanding of individual behavior and human relations.

By order of the United States Public Health Service the Salk vaccine made and distributed by the Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif., has been temporarily withdrawn. The reason is that by the end of last week twenty-six cases of polio were said to have developed in the children that were inoculated with the vaccine.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 12 -- To haul a ton of freight in 1949 from Ankara to the ancient Seljuk capital of Konya, 163 miles to the south, cost 100 liras ($35.71) and twenty-eight hours. Today, the same cargo is trucked to Konya for 25 liras in three and a half hours.
EAST ISLIP, L. I., April 30 -- Skills Unlimited, Suffolk County's first workshop for the handicapped, will open here on Monday.
Washington's "Journal," the first book by the future first President, will be on exhibition this week at the Parke-Hernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
LEWISTOWN, Ill., April 30 -- The lovely valley of the Spoon River, made famous by Edgar Lee Masters and his Spoon River Anthology, went back to the farms last Tuesday.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- The American Furniture Mart will conduct its first spring market since 1942 during the week beginning Monday. The mid-season markets were started in 1926 and continued until 1942. Attendance of about 3,000 buyers has been forecast.

NEWARK, April 30 -- State administration offices serving this city will be centralized later in the year, when reconstruction of the Newark Center Building is completed. This was announced this week by Archibald S. Alexander, state treasurer.

The Fuller Brush Man has a foot in the factory door these days. Unlike his counterpart who calls daily on the American housewife, his "pitch" is directed at plant managers, production men and engineers.

FORT MONROE, Va., April 30 -- M/Sgt. Florence E. Friedman of Queens is scheduled to be the first member of the Women's Army Corps to serve in Indochina. She is the sister of Mrs. Joseph Aisley, 147-35 Seventy - eighth Road, Kew Gardens Hills.

THIS book is in a way a nostalgic, and in another way a slightly contemptuous and self-deprecatory analysis of radical movements and personalities of the Nineteen Thirties. The title comes from Murray Kempton's remark toward the end in speaking of himself and his fellows.
GUATEMALA, April 29 -- The Government has moved to grant relief to the country's coffee growers by altering the coffee tax structure so that lower world prices will be less burdensome for them.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- A Federal Court decree today may have the effect of ending the long and costly war between the National Football League and the Canadian professional circuits.

DURING the past few years there has been a great increase of interest in an aspect of American art history which had long been neglected: the institutional aspect. The latest manifestation of this welcome activity is a history of the National Academy of Design by its secretary, Eliot Clark.

Said George Dewey: "I am convinced that the office of the President is not such a very difficult one to fill, his duties being mainly to execute the laws of Congress." Of course, he was an admiral, and running for the Democratic nomination.

Notable art events in museums and galleries crowd hard upon each other this week. On Wednesday the Metropolitan Museum will open an exhibtion of the work of Goya, including 129 drawings and prints from the Prado and Lazaro Galdiano Museums in Madrid, supplemented by as many more paintings, prints and drawings from its own and other American public and private collections.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 20 -- Turkey is now striving to generate an Islamic reformation.
A former bank clerk said to have "vital information" bearing upon the wiretapping investigation in this city was arrested last night when he arrived by plane from Washington, D. C.
Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Utah Republican, defended the Federal security program last night. He said it did "not neglect the traditional concepts of our democracy and the rights of individuals."
I would like to call to your attention a subject about which I wrote recently to the Federal Communications Commission.

TODAY the curtain falls on the twenty-third flower exhibition known as the Ghent Floralies staged in the Park of Fetes here. This great display, which opened April 23, was established in 1809 and is staged every five years.

THE Ballet Theatre's fifteenth anniversary season at the Metropolitan, which closes tonight, has been very like the little girl with the curl in the middle of her forehead. When it has been good it has supplied us with some superlative performances, but only Pollyanna herself could glow with any genuine delight over the season as a whole.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 30 -- This city is asking Washington for $1,778,000 with which to build seawalls and dikes against the waters of Long Island Sound.

LONDON, April 30 -- The Governments of the United States and the United Kingdom found themselves this week approaching the achievement of two long-desired objectives of Western foreign policy: Russian withdrawal from Austria and rearmament of the West German Republic.
CHICAGO, April 30 (UP) -- Job opportunities and starting salaries for the June college graduate are hitting an all-time high.

The Travelers Aid Society's fifty years of service will be celebrated at a Golden Jubilee Ball on Tuesday at the Ambassador. The Celanese Corporation of America will present a fashion show featuring their fourth international collection of couturier gowns.
SEVERAL years ago in the record library of radio station WNEW, Al Trilling was thumbing through a stack of new disks that had arrived at the studio that day.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- A man who started out as a street lamplighter soon will head one of the nation's three biggest operating utilities.
CANNES, France. April 30 -- The simple, moving story of a Bronx butcher, "Marty," brought the Cannes film festival to its feet last night.
Tomorrow is Pulitzer Prize day at Columbia University.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Manhattan College and Villanova dominated the picture today as the sixty-first annual Penn Relay carnival roared to an exciting close before 25,000 spectators at Franklin Field.

DURING World War II many economists and quite a few other people were concerned about how the economy would behave when peace returned. It was hoped that production and employment would retain at least some of their wartime vigor, and this hope, in turn, was the father of many models or projections which showed how good things would be if only the economic system lived up to its wartime promise.
As welcome as Spring is the annual exhibition of painting and sculpture at The Stable Gallery, a field day for up-and-coming artists, wavelets of the future whose course is unpredictable.
Ten years ago this coming Saturday, at 2:41 A. M., there took place in a small schoolhouse in Reims an event which was heralded in this headline in The New York Times:

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 29 -- Tree hundred educators and business leaders met on the University of Toledo campus this week to consider the implications for education of the manpower shortages in various occupations.
RICHLAND, Wash., April 28 -- The bill to permit the Atomic Energy Commission to sell the real property in this city of 28,000 is being met with some apprehension by the residents.

Moscow will have its usual May Day display of military might today. But it will have little to show for year-old promises of an increased supply of consumer goods and expanded trade with Western nations.

Pravda has advised Austria to model herself on Switzerland, her neighbor, and to seek her fortune as a small neutral state. Pravda's advice is seldom disinterested and in this case it is part of a broad Russian policy for Germany and Central Europe.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 30 -- Westchester's adviser on water supplies believes the county will not go thirsty -- at least until the year 2000.
LONDON, April 30 -- The nation-wide railway stirke, scheduled for midnight tomorrow, was averted today following last minute negotiations.
Man's struggle against the deserts and the spreading drylands which cover a third of the global land area was discussed last week in Arizona and New Mexico by scientists from many countries.

HARTFORD, April 30 -- Minor court nominations this week by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff have caused Democratic party irritations in three of Connecticut's largest cities -- Hartford, New Haven and Waterbury.

TO the picture-book set, a guessing-game is a surefire invitation to looking and listening. Zhenya Gay has provided such a happy diversion in "What's Your Name?" -- a title which is bound to pique the interest from the start.

President Eisenhower brought us measurably nearer the "atomic age," as we call it, when he told The Associated Press meeting last week of his intention to ask Congress for authority and money to build a merchant ship that is to be driven by nuclear energy.
The sun shone from almost cloudless skies yesterday on 20,000 marchers who chose to "parade our loyalty to the United States" down Fifth Avenue.

DO-IT-YOURSELF home painting has been undergoing a marked change in the past few years with the ever-growing popularity of the new alkyd flat wall paints. These new flats, which use alkyd resins as their vehicle instead of linseed oil, have almost entirely replaced the old- fashioned kinds in paint stores throughout the nation.

MEXICO CITY, April 22 -- Officials of the National Railroads of Mexico are making a "desperate effort" to keep the development of the roads ahead of the nation's rapidly advancing economy, according to Arthur H. Gass, chairman of the Car Service Division of the Association of American Railroads.
May flowers and a 1955 business estimated at $30,000,000 in outdoor cooking equipment are bursting into bloom.

J. B. PRIESTLEY is easily one of the most entertaining and wisely serious writers living today. He has urbanity, wit and a highly developed sense of the more ridiculous aspects of human behavior -- etched in lightly with a mellow and twinkling charm that is irresistible even when for the reader it is ruefully lacerating.
The United States Civil Service Commission declared the postmastership of New York City open to competition yesterday.
With each new medical discovery affecting children, such as the Salk vaccine, parents face the future with increased confidence.

IF drilling must be done in the end grain of soft woods, or small holes must be drilled to larger size, standard auger bits are practically useless. Unless there is a firm grip for the lead screw, the bit will not take a good bite in the wood. To overcome this, use a Forstner bit.

THERE apparently is something about a luxurious summer hotel that brings out the worst in its guests. That lugubrious conclusion is to be drawn from Arnold Gifford's novel of sumptuous living in the suites, bars and lobby of a beach hotel in a Cape Cod-like setting.

OF the four non-featured, supporting actors who received recognition in the Clarence Derwent Awards this year, three appeared in off-Broadway productions. In one way or another this must be a pilestone.
DETROIT, April 30 -- A critical month of bargaining lies ahead for the auto workers' union and the two major companies in the industry -- Ford and General Motors.
An 80-year-old woman, who struggled along on $5.40 a month although she had savings of 3,621.59, was found by the police yesterday sleeping in a Brooklyn hallway.
SHAWAN, Md., April 30 (AP) -- Mrs. William J. Strawbridge's Lands Corner was an easy victor today in the Maryland Hunt Cup, finishing eight lengths ahead of Hugh O'Donovan's Lancrel.
A four-man committee has been set up to develop a program for recognizing scholastic achievement in the city's schools.
Two railroads that unload nearly 600,000 tons of perishable fruit and vegetables at North River piers every year will consolidate operations later this year.
HAVANA, April 30 -- A revolutionary change in both vehicle and pedestrian traffic is scheduled for Cuba next week. A new traffic code will go into effect May 6.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- After the President's press conference last Wednesday, this reporter dreamed that Mr. Eisenhower let us go on asking him questions and that he answered every one fully and frankly:

SAY what you will about tenors, they seem to be the people's choice. In the last fortnight, ever since this writer's comment on a recital by Beniamino Gigli appeared in The Times, there has been an outpouring of letters and phone calls. Some of the reactions have been abusive and some were phrased more in sorrow than anger, but nearly all rose to the defense of the tenor and his singing.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The National Geographic Society expects you to believe there is a creature at the bottom of Chesapeake Bay that has a humanlike face, wears a pronged antler, jumps like a grasshopper, and lives in an oyster shell.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 30 -- Britain and Turkey are seeking to attract Jordan to the new Middle Eastern security system. Britain has made clear that he is prepared to revise her treaty with Jordan of March 15, 1948, to conform with the new arrangements made with Iraq in February.

ROME, April 30 -- The extreme left-wing press announced in jubilant headlines today the election of Giovanni Gronchi to the Presidency of the Italian Republic. Both the Communist newspaper L'Unita and the left-wing Socialist newspaper Avanti made a special point of underlining that it was the leftists' votes that elected Signor Gronchi in Parliament yesterday.
Ill and indigent artists will benefit from the ninth annual Artists Equity Ball Fantastique to be held in the grand ballroom of the Sheraton-Astor on the evening of May 13.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., has served notice on shipowners that an industry-wide unemployment benefit plan financed by employers will be a "major objective" of forthcoming contract negotiations.

An anonymous woman tipster spoiled a well-planned gang fight among fifty girls yesterday afternoon when she telephoned the Brooklyn police that a battle over boy friends was to be fought in Prospect Park.
LAS VEGAS, Nev. April 28 -- Many of the defensive techniques in atomic warfare developed by the United States Army in the current nuclear tests are utilized by the Soviet Army.

PARIS, April 30 -- French military strength in the Associated States of Indochina has been reduced in South Vietnam and almost removed in the states of Laos and Cambodia, in accordance with the Geneva accords.
NEW DELHI, India, April 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has assigned V. K. Krishna Menon to go to Peiping to explore the possibility of a peaceful solution of the Formosa question.

IN the Department of Commerce Building in Washington there is a "Census Clock" which tells the country's population each day and hour Of late this clock has been ticking at a faster rate, for we Americans have been adding each month almost 250,000 to our number.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30 -- Wes Santee, the nation's greatest miler, fell more than eight seconds short of the four-minute mile at the Drake Relays today. However, he looked confidently forward to six more chances at the mark this season.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Boys High and St. John's Prep, both of Brooklyn, triumphed in the high school division of the sixty-first annual Penn Relays today. Boys took the mile and St. John's the two-mile championship at Franklin Field.

JUST what is the big news in men's wear this summer? Up to now, color could be counted upon to furnish the headlines. And while color is still of great interest, the biggest news is in practical, under-the-hood values in summer clothes as well as in their line, design and detailing.
The face-lifting which the basic utility plant of Cuba is getting at the hands of the Batista Government is beginning to leave its stamp in the world's investment markets.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (UP) -- An Air Force leader said tonight that small fighter planes could now deliver atomic bombs "much more destructive" than those that big bombers dropped on Japan during World War II.

Fourteen speed-boat championships for inboards have been assigned to various waterways of the nation. This is a chore done by Racing Commissioner Frank Foulke of Essex, Md., vice president for inboards of the American Power Boat Association.
Aggregate earnings of American manufacturers in 1954 were the second highest in corporate annals.
ALBANY, April 30 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today signed a Republican-backed bill providing for a single primary election day next year. It will be June 5.

" Davy Crockett" merchandise, usually found in boys' items, has invaded new lines, the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company reports. The trade-mark of the television hero can now be found in towels, place mats, girls' scarves and bedspreads.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: When cutting tulips and daffodils for bouquets, pick foliage sparingly. After bloom is finished, snap off dead flowers but leave the foliage until it turns yellow. Daffodil bulbs may be left in place indefinitely, fertilizing with 5-10-5 in spring and fall to maintain quality bloom. Tulips and hyacinths are best lifted annually.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 30 (AP) -- Don Bisplinghoff of Orlando, Fla., defeated Bill Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., 5 and 4, today to win the North and South amateur golf tournament in his first attempt.

BIRDIE TEBBETTS has lost virtually everything this season except his sense of humor. As the once proud proprietor of as formidable a collection of fence-busters as there is in the baseball business, the Cincinnati manager has watched in helpless frustration while his musclemen have flailed away feebly at bat. In the first fortnight of the season the Redlegs dropped eleven of thirteen games. They even performed the impossible, plummeting past the Pirates into last place.

GENEVA, April 30 (Reuters) -- The eighty-one-nation World Health Organization is facing a new challenge as a result of the latest discoveries of science and medicine, particularly in the field of atomic research.

GUATEMALA, April 21 -- Former President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, ousted last June for pro-Communist leanings, has lost properties valued at $175,000, expropriated by the present Government. His wife has lost about $152,000.

ARTUR SCHNABEL was the first to record all of the five Beethoven Piano Concertos, and some of them he did several times. To this date only one other pianist can match the feat -- Wilhelm Kempff, whose integral version, which came out about two years ago, suffered from recording that was impossible to reproduce in a satisfactory manner.

FROM the first pages on, when soldier Adam Ember and his comrades are forever marching toward a town called Turka -- never reached -- the reader can't help sensing that "The Night of Time" isn't what it seems to be.

Edward Steichen, dean of American photographers, has been cited by the Urban League "for making mankind proud of its humanity." Mr. Seichen, director of the department of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, received his citation for the creation of "The Family of Man" exhibition in the museum.
SYRACUSE, April 30 -- Many English teachers fidgeted as nervously today as unhappy students in a tough quiz.
Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, which provides a variety of services to the Yorkville area, will benefit from Wednesday's performance of "3 for Tonight".

WHEN children plant a seed, they know that sometime it will be a plant -- the picture on the seed envelope shows them that. But how and when ? In this picture-story a little boy and a little girl find out when they plant a poppy seed.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30 -- Almost 6,000 civilian defense workers, state and Federal officials, military personnel, scientists, and press, radio and television observers spent several sleepless nights near here this week waiting for the explosion that was postponed repeatedly because of unfavorable weather

PARIS, April 22 -- The American Hospital of Paris not only serves the large American colony living here, but also acts as an important link with American medicine. The hospital is situated in suburban Neuilly.

THE outboard motorboat was for years a cockle shell, bobbing on the wash of cabin cruisers and compelled to scurry inshore at first sign of a moderate blow. But now the outboard has attained cruiser class, throws a crested wave of its own, and can ride a sea while sleeping four in comfortable berths.

THE tree wistaria is in a class by itself. Besides being strikingly beautiful when in bloom, it has highly decorative foliage and a symmetry of form and delicacy of line which make the little tree attractive even in winter.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The most controversial recent publication in Washington, besides the Yalta report, is a much shorter work issued by the Senate Republican Policy Committee, the collective mastermind of the party's legislative strategy.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 30 -- Thirteen career civilians in the Federal Government, including a native of New York City, will receive the third annual Rockefeller Public Service Awards. The announcement was made this week by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

NOTWITHSTANDING a report published in a philatelic journal that Panama's announced series of stamps bearing portraits of all the "recognized" popes -- 259 ecclesiastics who became Roman Catholic pontiffs -- would not be issued after all, the legal firm of Arias, Fabrega Fabrega, attorneys for the Republic of Panama, last week cabled authorized representatives of the Panama Government in New York as follows:

DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers protected their slim and surprising hold on first place in the American League today by trouncing the Washington Senators, 11 -- 7. The victory was the seventh straight for the Tigers.
HARRISBURG, April 30 -- The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania completed plans this week for a special ceremony May 10 to honor Dr. Jonas E. Salk.

One of the most intensive and widespread drives of recent years against exceeding the speed limit is now going forward throughout many areas of the nation. Unmarked police cars, helicopters and a wide variety of instruments are being used in this campaign.
ORDINARILY, autobiographies are not written at the age of 22, but Christy Brown has never been ordinary. Crippled by cerebral palsy, he was at birth unable to speak, to use his hands or to walk.

THE American scene, historical and contemporary, is the subject of photography projects for which Robert Frank and Todd Webb were granted fellowships last week by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. Mr. Frank's plan is "to photograph freely throughout the United States, using the miniature camera exclusively, to make a broad picture record of things American, past and present."
One of the last things Dr. Albert Einstein did was to prepare a speech reviewing the achievements in Israel in its seven years as a nation.

GARDENERS who have marshy "problem spots" on their property, as well as gardeners who simply yearn to walk among wild flowers in a natural setting, should try to visit Pennsylvania's Bowman's Hill State Wildflower Preserve. Here an outstanding collection of bog plants has been established.
BALBOA, C. Z., April 3 -- The advance plans for sea and air maneuvers simulating how paratroops might defend the Panama Canal were synchronized this week.
Our President has been entrusted with a decision which no one man should be forced -- or allowed -- to make, i. e., the use of the atomic bomb in tactical warfare.

THE people on Pine Mountain Tennessee resume their gentle flow of life in this second book about Peter Pocket. Now, Peter shares with Granny Messer and his Pickle Pup the hardships of winter (scarcely recognizing them a such) and the adventures of every day.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The United States, while committed to exploring the sincerity of Chou En-lais proposal for direct negotiations on Formosa, was clearly unenthusiastic about V. K. Krishna Menon of India as the intermediary.

IN a recent speech William Faulkner pointed out that in our country success is too easily achieved: "A young man can gain it with no more than a little industry. He can gain it so quickly and easily that he has had no time to learn the humility to handle it with, or even to realize that he will need humility."

National Music Week starts today and the Hospitalized Veterans Service is making a contribution to it by presenting concerts during the week in six of the hospitals in which it works. Each program will feature patients who have received music instruction through the service.

SOME Anglo-American moviemakers, who, like ball players, apparently have come to the conclusion that team play brings happy results, are forming an unprecedented combination, it was learned last week. The tandem is none other than Katharine Hepburn and Bob Hope, who, if all the proper papers are signed, will be co-starred in a comedy by Ben Hecht paradoxically titled, "Not For Money."
LAS VEGAS, New., April 30 -- Who decides whether an atomic test explosion should be set off or not?

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs will hold its first session outside of the United States when it recesses its sixty-fourth annual meeting in Philadelphia May 27 and reconvenes it May 31 in Geneva, Switzerland.

I don't recall arguing that Washington is a "cultural dump." I recall only describing some attitudes toward Washington I had encountered in that city. I have never heard Washington life as sharply and patronizingly discussed in New York as in Washington.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 30 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell declared tonight the United States must keep its advantage in work skills over Soviet Russia.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., April 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has decided to keep the gates of Los Alamos shut. In the city where research in the development of nuclear weapons is being conducted most of the residents are glad of it.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The State Department scanned press reports tonight from Saigon on the turnover while anxiously awaiting official word on the confused events in that city and on the role of Bao Dai.

BY now the 3,000-mile cheek-up is an established procedure in the automotive field. During that time, the new car owner expects a wide variety of minor mechanical "bugs" to become evident. He is also confident that these will be ironed out before his guarantee expires.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 30 -- William Helis Jr's Helioscope had to break the track record to win the Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park today.
Rabbi David B. Kahane called upon President Eisenhower yesterday to establish a commission to bring about peace between Israel and her neighbors.

AN International Photographic Exposition, sponsored by the Master Photo Dealers' Finishers' Association, will be held March 17-30, 1957, in Washington, D. C., according to plans recently announced by this association and two other groups, who initiated the project at a joint conference.

It is all very well for statesmen, politicians and the public to sing loud praises of the Hoover Commission and its work; but the fact is that this great effort to bring efficiency, economy and businesslike administration into the sprawling complex of the Federal Government is in danger of getting nowhere.

I WAS very interested in the article in last Sunday's Times by Paul J. C. Friedlander under the heading "Prevention or Prosecution," and I am in harmony with his conclusions. Recently, Governor Harriman discussed with me the necessity of identifying state police patrol cars so that they could be more easily visible to motorists, and consequently would be more of a deterrent to violators.
A new radar that spots objects at sea and then automatically rings for a crewman has been developed by Miller Associates of Lakeville, Conn.
KATMANDU, Nepal -- The pleasant news from Katmandu for tourists and their agents is that there is a new country to visit. Nepal and tourism have discovered each other.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- Johnny Logan was the big man at the plate today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 2, and took undisputed possession of second place in the National League.
MEXICO CITY, April 28 -- The bitter fight, which has been building in intensity for years between two industrial groups of Mexico, appears to be nearing a climax.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson predicted today that the world's first atoms-for-peace conference "may well blow the whole lid off" much of the secrecy in atomic energy.
AQABA, Jordan, April 30 (AP) -- The 8,027-ton United States cargo ship Steel Scientist today arrived in this port, Jordan's only outlet to the sea.

KANSAS CITY, April 30 -- Department store volume for the Easter season was about 8 per cent larger than a year ago. Trade last week showed gains ranging from about 7 per cent in the metropolitan areas to about 20 per cent in the rural sections.

When Woman's Hospital (now a division of St. Luke's Hospital) holds its 100th anniversary party Wednesday, many women's diseases, once regarded as both incurable and unmentionable, may be considered proper teatime discussion topics for doctors and the hospital's women directors and guests.

TOKYO, April 30 -- Japanese scientists are divided on whether to accept the United States offer of fissionable materials to advance Japan's atomic energy program. The issue concerns possible secrecy regulations that might be required of Japan by Washington.

MONTE CARLO, April 28 -- Greater teamwork between doctors, nurses and social workers was urged here today by Dr. Arie Querindo, chief of Amsterdam's Public Health Service. He was speaking at the closing session of a study group sponsored by the World Health Organization.

According to N. P. Woodruff of the United States Department of Agriculture (in Agricultural Research), wind-tunnel experiments show how good windbreaks and similar protective barriers are. Miniature houses, trees, fences and fields are set up in a tunnel and then subjected to blasts of varying strength.
The Squadron A team defeated the favored New York A. C. trio, 11 -- 8, to win the national senior indoor polo championship at the Squadron A Armory last night.

PERHAPS one reason why video craftsmen tend to settle for mediocrity lies in the "insatiable" need to have something, anything, on the screen for seventeen to eighteen hours a day. This is comparable to certain types of fish which must go on eating twenty-four hours out of twenty-four and so cannot be too particular about the food that comes their way.

DESPITE the tranquillity of its title, "Thirteenth Summer" is a vivid, fast-paced book. It might even be described as hard-boiled. It records a few months in which an intelligent little girl attains not only physical maturity but the terrible knowledge that the well-ordered world which she has never questioned contains horrors of deceit, betrayal, lust and hate.
The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions issued yesterday a May Day declaration against Communist double-talk.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 30 -- Dick Corrigan scored his fourth goal of the afternoon with 5 minutes and 30 seconds to play, giving a 9-8 lacrosse victory today to the University of Maryland over the defending national champion, Navy.
The cornerstone was laid yesterday for Columbia University's first major construction in its third century.
DETROIT, April 30 (AP) -- Competition is getting tougher in the retailing of passenger automobiles. It could bring back some of the razzle-dazzle and hippodrome selling that developed in 1954.
BERLIN, April 30 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to a High Commissioners' meeting to discuss the increase in tolls on trucking between Berlin and the West.

A WESTERN with a psychological slant -- and many have been attempted since "The Oxbow Incident" -- has got to be good or it falls flatter than a tortilla. The observation serves to introduce Richard G. Hubler's THE PASS (Coward-McCann, $3.95), which tells of Coach End, a not-quite-ghost town in the southern Sierras.

The promise of improved family relations, besides diversion, is held out to parents who join their children in playing with paints and crayons. The advocate of parent-participation in youngsters' creative efforts, Mrs. Mary Worley Johnson of City College Extension Division, will speak on "Art Work With Parents and Children" on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

AARON MARC STEIN (also known as George Bagby and Hampton Stone), who long held the national and probably the international record for prolific quality with a steady four or five first-rate novels a year, has recently been on a long sabbatical; indeed, we've gone eighteen parched months with only one book under any of his by-lines.
The 1954 annual report of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Inc., made public last week, emphasizes the positive.
SANFORD, Me., April 30 -- Abandoned by textile interests, this town is tackling the problem of restoring economic security.

DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE statistics point up the strength of business recovery in the last fifteen months and confirm the existence of a genuine boom. The top hat of prosperity, however, rests uneasily on the head of most business men.
LONDON, April 30 (Reuters) -- A prominent Russian scientist solemnly went before a microphone today to allay Russian jitters that a space ship invasion from Mars had taken place.
Studies prepared for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee disclose that the institutional investor has become the dominant factor in today's stock market.

Candidates for employment as overseas investigators in the United States Department of State may apply to a representative of that bureau at the New York State Empolyment Service, 1 East Nineteenth Street, from tomorrow to Friday.

IN springtime gardens are in their best attire. Trees shine with new green leaves, tulips stand erect in neat rows, cherries, peaches, plums and crabapples bloom and everything looks bright. It is no wonder then that gardeners welcome visitors to their grounds. And as each spring rolls around the roster of garden tours lengthens.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- An advisory group of eleven experts, including Dr. Jonas E. Salk recommended tonight that mass polio inoculations be continued despite contraction of the disease by some who received the vaccine.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that labor's responsibility of working for the good of all would be "greater than ever" once the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations merged. The President officiated at the laying of the cornerstone for the A. F. L.'s new headquarters building here.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Reported assurances that Austria does not intend to force refugees to return to Communist East Europe were welcomed here today.

TAKE a rough slum neighborhood with a rising juvenile delinquency rate. add a tough police lieutenant. and what is the result? When this combination occurred in the Bronx and the lieutenant in question was Edward W. Flynn. the result was "P. A. L." -- the Police Athletic League -- which is entering its twenty-fifth year.

AUSTRALIA is more of a bridge center than is generally appreciated in this country. The only annual "bridge olympic" (tournament in which prepared hands are played in various countries at the same time) now emanates from Australia. In the last two international bidding contests. Australia has taken one first and one second place.
CANTON, N. Y., April 30 -- (UP) -- More than 200 state police and civilian volunteers sought to set a trap today for three jail breakers and keep them from escaping across the Canadian border.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Developments in the vaccine picture across the nation today included:

DALLAS, Tex., April 30 (UP) -- A University of Texas quartet equaled the world record of 40.5 seconds for the 440-yard relay tonight in the opening event of the second annual Dallas invitation track and field meet.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- A bronze statue of Honus Wagner, generally acclaimed the greatest shortstop in baseball history, was unveiled today in Schenley Park, adjacent to Forbes Field where he played for the Pittsburgh Pirates half a century ago.

The calculated madness that descends upon Macy's several times a year, usually in the hours when the customers are sleeping and the store is all shadows and echoes, overtook the staff again this week-end.

THE more superstitious elements in the aviation business feel that to make a commotion about safety records is just courting trouble. That is why they were a little appalled a few weeks ago when Colonial Airlines sent out invitations to a party celebrating twenty-five years of operations without a fatal accident.

JUST a centimeter or so from the top of the best-seller list these days is "Bonjour Tristesse," a brisk and compact importation from France. Currently wandering about this country during these same happy days is Francoise Sagan. who wrote it. Mlle.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission got ready to start house hunting this week.
TOKYO, April 30 -- Japan will offer a program to expand trade in free Asia by using a prospective $200,000,000 United States regional aid fund to develop native industries.

VIVID, off-red crabapple blossoms and the more subtle pink blooms of native flowering apples are fully out now in New York City and its environs. Conspicuous, too, in city parks and along state highways is the flowering quince, which is easily identifiable by its distinctive tea rose color.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 30 -- This suburban community is growing so fast that its museum is being forced to move five miles out of the heart of town to observe "nature in action."

Beginning today, fire apparatus will use a special center lane on four one-way avenue in Manhattan while en route to and returning from fires. The lane, marked off in yellow, is along First, Second. Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Its use is designed to speed apparatus through traffic.

THE first major battle in the Eighty - fourth Congress over Echo Park Dam has now been lost, but the war is far from over. In fact, Senate passage on April 20 of the Upper Colorado Storage Project including authorization for the controversial dam inside Dinosaur National Monument has only fortified the determination of its opponents to block the measure in the House.
LAMAR, Colo., April 30 -- Dust clouds were again blotting out the southern Great Plains this week as the winds ripped at the parched fields and rangelands.

Your editorials during the last year dealing with segregation in the schools are a significant contribution to recent thought on this topic. The last editorial, "Education is Color-Blind," on April 17, makes a point of such importance to the American people that certain of its meanings may bear elaboration in your columns.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., April 28 -- Residents adopted a cautious attitude today on a bill in Congress to permit the Atomic Energy Commission to free this community.

AS a usual thing, we film reviewers keep politely and piously away from an area that has considerable importance in the culture of motion pictures, which is the ads. It is a sort of time-honored custom that we confine our comments to the films, without any nimadversions on the sometimes fatuous ways in which they are sold.

ANYONE who has seen wistaria in full flower in spring can easily understand why it is commonly called the queen of vines in Japan and China where it has been cherished in gardens for many centuries. Wistaria has a wide and enthusiastic following among American gardeners too, for few other vines can approach the dramatic quality of its floral effects.

THE intricacies of building a chicken house are explained with great good humor in this picture book story. Mr. Charlie is very fond of eggs and therefore wants to keep a flock of hens. A happy-go-lucky, do-it-yourself home carpenter, he designs and builds a chicken house with loving care.

SAIGON, April 30 -- At noon today the Government of South Vietnam knew it had won a military victory in the smashed streets of Saigon. At noon today the Government of South Vietnam did not know whether it would last another week.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sunday, May 1 -- Gen. Nguyen Van Vy took over control of South Vietnam today in a bloodless coup. He declared himself loyal to Bao Dai, the Chief of State.

PARIS, April 30 -- The French Government is waiting for a decision by Washington on the Indochinese crisis. Meanwhile, it is making no proposals for its solution and intends to make none that do not have the full approval in advance of the United States.

Although it was announced some months ago that Chiang Kai-shek had been "unleashed" -- presumably for the purpose of invading the Chinese mainland -- it may be doubted whether any well-informed American military leader or politician still believes in the possibility of a successful Nationalist attack upon the Chinese coast, unless America is willing to accord logistic support on a scale equal to that of the invasion of North Africa.

LAUREL, Md., April 30 (UP) -- Tahiti, with Tony DeSpirito up, pulled away from his rivals in the stretch to win the $11,620 Maryland Sprint Handicap by six lengths today. The Laurel program attracted 18,703 fans.

The need of religious, recreational and welfare services for Jewish service men and hospitalized veterans last year "was greater than at any other time since World War II," according to the National Jewish Welfare Board.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Twelve Republican Senators spoke out today for cease-fire negotiations with Communist China.

Broadened health education programs in American teachers colleges are necessary, according to a survey by the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education and the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness. The report covers forty accredited teachers colleges.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., April 30 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission unveiled today one of the prime tools in its search for better shielding materials to protect persons from atomic radiation.

" YOU can't trust girls from Homes," the cook warns her mistress. "Bella's a good worker * * * but she's a deep one" And indeed the 15-year-old English foundling makes a model nursemaid. For the first time in her life she feels secure in happiness.

MEXICO CITY, April 21 -- An attempt by Vicente Lombardo Toledano, head of the Communist-dominated Confederation of Workers of Latin America, to unite other labor organizations in Latin America against United States labor legislation has met with an initial rebuff here in Mexico.
ST. LOUIS, April 30 (UP) -- Mrs. Eleanor Elaine Lee Harris, who stretched a dinner invitation into an eleven-year stay at the home of a friend, packed up and departed today on a judge's orders.
15 - year - old parochial school student was ambushed and slain in the Bronx last night, the fortuitous victim of a wanton shooting by a teen-age gang of bicyclists to whom he was a stranger.

THE first American edition of the unabridged memoirs of Russia's Catherine the Great was published almost a hundred years ago, in 1859, in New York. No less a writer than the great liberal and exile Alexander Herzen edited it and penned an introduction.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 30 -- University of California scientists announced today the discovery of another new artificial element, Element 101. It is said to be the heaviest atom known and possibly the rarest on earth in the last 5,000,000,000 years.

May is the year at its first dreamy age, a girl thinking of love and showing it in her sky-blue eyes and sunshiny hair. May comes down the flagged walk with a bouquet of apple blossoms in her hand and the honey-hum of bees in her laughter. May is young, and May is beautiful. May can be very charming indeed.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- It is no longer necessary for a student taking basic training in the Reserve Officers Training Corps to swear that he is not and never has been a member of a subversive organization, the Defense Department said today.

POSTERITY has not been kind to the nephew of Napoleon the Great. It remembers Victor Hugo's characterization of him as Napoleon the Little and Zola's dissection of the Second Empire's tawdry glitter. Bismarck's surmise that Napoleon III (1808-1873) was "a great unrecognized incapacity" gained historical sanction after the debacle of Sedan.

THERE are signs in the Roman spring air that the production slowdown which cut local film-making down to the tune of some 50 per cent under 1954, is due for a let-up. With the extension, until December, of the film law which protects and indirectly subsidizes Italy's otherwise unstable film economy by a system of tax-rebate compensations, a principal reason for production hesitancy has been removed.

SEA GIRT, N. J., April 30 -- At the annual change-of-the-watch here tonight the Shrewsbury Power Squadron installed a new commander. Charles H. Hall, succeeded James Applegate. This busy unit of yachtsmen covers the waterways from Sandy Hook southerly to Barnegat Bay. It was organized before World War II.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 30 -- Bob Monetti, a former national intercollegiate dinghy champion from Yale, defeated thirteen others today in the second annual championship frostbite regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.
WEIRD noises are provided by Emory Cook of Cook Labboratories in his latest recording, Out of This World. The disk is subtitled, "Earthquakes for Home Use."

MUNICH, Germany, April 25 -- Some day they may put up a plaque in the State Department to the diplomatic triumph of the ordinary United States soldier stationed in Germany. Here in a town with a big garrison and a United States Army headquarters you can see the results of his talent for just being people.

Five physicians have administered anti-polio vaccine to seventeen adults here, Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner declared yesterday. They face, at worst, a reprimand for apparently having ignored a voluntary program to abide by age-group priorities.

ONE canny householder hasn't bought a sanding disk for many months now. He gets them for nothing. Actually he gets sanding belts, discarded by professional floor finishers; for nothing and makes his own disks. Usually these belts are but slightly worn.

HONG KONG, April 30 -- Almost since the inception of the Peiping regime, a hostile China, backed by the Soviet Union, has challenged the United States in a fundamental and far-reaching Far Eastern conflict.

BAGUIO, The Philippines, April 30 (AP) -- The United States is stressing a cautious approach toward building up a complex military structure under the Southeast Asia collective defense treaty, informed American sources said today.

The National Planning Association has published a new study of "The Causes of Industrial Peace." The report covers a thorough investigation of labor relations in thirty representative firms in which both management and union have maintained harmonious relations over the years -- to the freely admitted advantage of each.

A GARDEN, whether created around a modern one-story house or a turreted Victorian mansion, always reflects the person who plants it. Not one but innumerable gardens in Dallas, Tex., and the very city itself mirror the ideas of designer J. O. Lambert Jr., president of Lambert Landscape Company.

In your critic's review of "Inherit the Wind," Paul Muni, as the defense attorney, is described as getting inside the character with "the shuffling gait, the un-pressed suit, the ruffled gray hair, the grimace in amazement." This fits Clarence Dar-row perfectly, as I remember him when I was a reporter in upstate New York in the Thirties.
A group of non-operating railway employes announced yesterday a schedule of meetings to consider action against the New Haven Railroad for recent lay- offs.
HONG KONG, April 30 -- The Peiping radio said tonight there was "no reason" why talks between the United States and Red China "cannot prove to be a turning point" in easing Far Eastern tension.

CALDER HALL, England April 21 -- The thick ferro-concrete foundation and exterior walls of Britain's first full-scale atomic power station here are now almost complete. Engineers say that within one year, "perhaps sooner," they will be able to switch between 70,000 and 100,000 kilowatts into the national electric grid system.

Western Germany's re-entrance into the society of free nations will be formalized at meetings of Foreign Ministers beginning in Paris next Saturday, May 7, exactly ten years after Gen. Gustav Jodl surrendered to General Eisenhower at Reims. The time was forty-one minutes after 2 on a Monday morning.

A faculty member of the Northwestern University School of Law, William Lucius Cary, has been named professor of law at Columbia University. The appointment was announced yesterday by William C. Warren, dean of the Columbia School of Law.

MORE and more, a theatrical workshop known as the Actors Studio is contributing top talent to Broadway and Hollywood -- to hit plays like "Bus Stop" and "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," to notable movies like "On the Waterfront" and "East of Eden."

LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) -- The aristocrats of Twentieth Century Britain have been enjoined not to be shrinking violets, but boldly to advertise their blue blood on autos, stationery, sofa cushions and door mats.

Two workshops to be conducted in Israel this summer by the New York University School of Education will enable present and future American educators to make a firsthand study of that country. The projects are the Graduate Workshop in the Land of the Bible and the Workshop in Modern Israel's Life and Culture.
WHEN the off-shore fishing is unproductive the angler always has an alibi -- it was all the fault of the skipper.
LONDON, April 30 -- Welsh nationalists will contest Gower, South Wales, in the coming general election in the name of a jailed candidate.

The back of my hand to Richard Rovere for "Hick Town or World Capital?" (April 17). In which he contends that Washington is a mixture of both -- a global center, but highly parochial -- and manages to end up with some of the best articulation ever produced of the professional New Yorker's provincial smugness toward the trans-Hudson back country.

MANCHESTER, England, April 30 -- The twin supporting towers of Britain's massive radiotelescope have now been raised to a height of 240 feet above Jodrell Bank on the Cheshire Plain twenty miles to the southwest of this city.

The heart of the matter in South Vietnam was symbolized last week in the "two cities" of Saigon. There was the French quarter of tree-lined boulevards, smart shops, sidewalk cafes. There was, all around it, the thatch-roofed city of the Vietnamese, much of it now strewn with rubble and ashes.
