" UNCLE SAM is going hog-wild on paper." Senator Norris Cotton wrote his constituents recently. "He scribbles and doodles on 25 billion pieces each year (not counting tons used in pamphlets)." The Senator from New Hampshire might have added. "And not counting what's used for Congressional newsletters, like this one."

AFTER reaching a peak of artistry and prestige in the Thirties, chiefly on the basis of Sunday recitals, the modern dance now finds itself increasingly beset by financial problems. Production costs have risen prohibitively and the art itself has grown so that it now requires more in the way of an orchestra and scenery.

Vengalil Krishnan Krishna Menon, India's chief delegate to the United Nations, seemed to be an obvious Indian choice for the job of trying to negotiate with the Chinese Communists for a peaceful solution of the problem of Formosa.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- The Philadelphia Phillies, intent on bettering themselves in the league standings and at the box office, negotiated a three-for-three trade with the Cincinnati Redlegs today.
After a week of tears, April bowed out yesterday in a glow of golden laughter. A bright sun raised the temperature to 73.1 at 1:45 P. M., although it sank to 51 during the evening.
This summer's Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., will include five major selections in which singers will be featured.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A member of the Federal Communications Commission declared today that the television networks had a "stranglehold" over the industry through control of programs, advertising and talent.
Columbia University's baseball team made its final Eastern Intercollegiate League appearance of the season at Baker Field yesterday and bowed to Brown, 7 -- 3.
ALBANY, April 30 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today signed a five-bill package clearing the way for a $600,000,000 bridge and highway construction program in New York City.

CLEVELAND, April 30 -- Claims for unemployment dipped to 13,940, representing a decrease of more than 8,000 in eleven weeks to the lowest total in sixteen months. According to a bimonthly survey by the Cleveland office of the Ohio Bureau of Unemployment Compensation, employers in this area expect to continue to add to their payrolls at least six weeks.

EACH morning in the lunchrooms of Chicago's public high schools, youngsters begin gathering at 7:45 o'clock For three-quarters of an hour they congregate, greet their friends, talk over the day's events, hold last-minute conferences on homework and -- miracle of miracles to many a careworn parent -- Eat Breakfast!
BONN, Germany, Sunday, May 1 -- West Germany's Chancellor and France's Foreign Minister reached agreement during the night on the issues pending between their Governments.

LAST September, when Harold Prince, flourishing co-producer of "Pajama Game," slipped into the St. James Theatre he was careful to conceal the book he had just finished reading. He even had reversed the dust jacket to hide the title. For on Broadway, when a man is known to be seeking a subject for a musical, he can't be too careful of spies.

VIENNA, April 30 -- Not only Western ambassadors but Western oil men have been conferring in Vienna in preparation for the negotiations on an Austrian state treaty that open Monday. The ambassadors have been striving, so far without complete success, to achieve a common Western front before discussions with the Russians and Austrians begin.

MYKONOS, Greece -- A sudden rush of tourists could spoil Mykonos. Therefore, somewhat grudgingly the writer recommends that anyone who wants to get a glimpse into the life on a small Greek island in the fabled Aegean Sea should visit here.

The tumultuous events in Saigon during the past few days culminating with the revolt against the Bao Dai and ending early today with what appeared to be a counter-revolution led by Bao's appointee, Gen. Van Vy, leave us today in a tragic uncertainty.

MUSIC Minus One, which created a stir several years ago, has gone on to bigger things -- in musical scope, that is. As you may remember, Music Minus One offers, on an LP disk, an entire chamber work minus one instrument.

Well-known members of the worlds of society, diplomacy and the arts are serving as sponsors of the exhibition, "American and French Modern Masters," comprising paintings from notable private collections and museums.

THIS neat volume makes sincere attempt to pull together the story of fire fighting in America, a long-neglected phase of our sociological history. If there is not much souffle here, there is a plenty of meat and potatoes, all heated up by excellent reportorial accounts of many of America's hottest fires and well flavored by anecdotes and descriptions.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. April 30 -- Scientists of twenty-five nations left here in buses today for a first-hand investigation of desert problems in the southwest.

TOKYO, April 30 -- Japan and the Soviet Union will open peace negotiations in London in June. To the Japanese this represents another important milestone in the painful march back to the eminence that the Island Empire once enjoyed. Reopening of "normal" relations with Russia also advances the Hatoyama Government's ideal of making Japan a bridge between East and West.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The fight over "residual fuel oil," the hottest of the subsidiary battles in the Congressional struggle over the President's reciprocal trade bill, might well serve as a case history of how Congress deals with a trade bill.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., House Republican leader, said today President Eisenhower's compulsory military reserve training plan would pass the House next week "without any trouble.'
Boston Doge's winning streak ended in the $25,500 Swift Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

THE easiest way for a gardener to build up horticultural confidence and have lots of flowers is to grow annuals. Timid attitudes toward flower gardening melt away in the face of these cheery plants thrusting up through the earth. Inexpensive and serviceable, annuals give anyone a chance at an almost guaranteed success.

Some of the world's great art treasures will be shown by the newly-formed New York Antique and Art Dealers Association, Inc., for the benefit of the New York City Cancer Committee. The exhibition will be open from June 16 through June 30 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

A man with three turtles, who was hunting a room in New York, found the Travelers Aid Society knew an obliging landlord. But fifty years ago, the society probably would have been distinctly unhelpful.

Members of the Italian community and of the French and Italian diplomatic corps assembled at Battery Park yesterday noon to pay tribute to the Florentine navigator credited with the discovery of New York's harbor in 1524.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Employment in the Philadelphia area improved moderately during the January-March period, reversing the trend of recent months. Employment in the metropolitan district, according to the Pennsylvania State Employment Service, reached 1,593,000 in mid-March, a gain of 6,900 over January.

IN 1937 J. R. R. Tolkien wrote "The Hobbit," intended for a children's book but touched here and there with terrors which had the darker involvements of myth, and at times even with that "clang and groan of great iron" which Chesterton heard in the medieval chansons de geste.
TAIPEI, Formosa, April 30 -- The Chinese Nationalists continued today to wage a hot if limited war on the Communist mainland.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The University of Washington's action in barring Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer as a visiting lecturer was protested today by the council of the Federation of American Scientists.

JUDGED by illustrations alone, "How to Take Better Pictures" by Arthur A. Goldsmith Jr. (New York: Maco Magazine Corporation. 75 cents, soft cover; Bobbs-Merrill. $2.75, hard cover), is one of the most exiting beginner's books ever published. The book is inspirational, as well as instructive. If it does no more than instill enthusiasm for the medium in the reader, it will have served a valuable purpose.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- The century-old Academy of Music, Philadelphia's leading center of music, has reached a point where it should either be torn down or restored, its stockholders have been informed.

HOW does World War II look, to our Western eyes, in this tenth year after its end? To see the picture in proportion, perhaps we ought first to remind ourselves that the results of all wars have always looked disappointing, in retrospect, to the victors, not to speak of the vanquished.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 17 -- Thirty-five miles of railway track may greatly help two Southeast Asian countries in their fight against creeping communism.
PARIS, April 28 -- The red, yellow and black flag of the (West) German Federal Republic will be hoisted next week at the civilian and military headquarters of the North Atlantic Alliance.

THE abortive attempt to restore the Stuarts to the English throne in 1715 provides the backdrop for this engaging historical romance. The heroine, Mally Lawley, is at first a pure innocent, learning the ways of London's polite society as ward to her social-climbing aunt.
BONN, Sunday, May 1 (AP) -- Chancellor Adenauer and Foreign Minister Pinay, after conferring for two days, made their announcement of agreement at a joint but brief news conference.

WELLESLEY, Mass., April 30 -- Wellesley College expects to meet increased demands for higher education by admitting more transfer and nonresident students. This will mean a 10 to 20 per cent rise in the present enrollment of 1,650.

TO all appearances, President Juan Peron of Argentina lives a public life, a man in a goldfish bowl like our own President or any of the other leading statesmen of the West. In reality, he is a man alone, friendless, unknown, unloved and unloving--the enigma of the Western Hemisphere.
BERKELEY, Calif., April 30 -- California's polio vaccination program, regardless of the type of vaccine, came to an official halt today for one week.

Nearly seven years have passed since the ring of the Russian blockade closed around West Berlin and the U. S. Military Governor, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, said in defiance: "They can't drive us out * * * short of war."
The Federal Government can have its cake and eat it, too, under a major power project proposed last week by three Northwest utilities.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Jim Rivera, who had been sidelined with a .184 average, got off the bench and singled with the bases filled in the seventh inning to lift the White Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

A major development in Western Europe these past few months has been the intensive, coordinated campaign begun by the Soviet Union and its satellites to lure home the hundreds of thousands of refugees from those countries now abroad.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 -- Wisconsin won, but Harvard took the trophy in the Compton Cup crew race on the Charles River today.
THE playgoing public here is reeling under the impact of three hit productions from America. In quick ccession, it has seen "The Bad seed," "The Desperate Hours" and "Kismet."

OF the half-million Americans who ventured to Europe last year, a good 20 per cent had travel diaries hidden among socks and toothbrushes. Makers of "My Trip" books anticipate an increase in sales during 1955 of from 30 to 50 per cent.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 30 -- By the margin of six feet Navy maintained its four-year winning streak on the water today and prevented a Cornell sweep. In an exciting fight Rusty Callow's midshipman eight led throughout the mile and three quarters on the Severn and just barely stood off Cornell's challenge with a powerful driving finish.

Dr. Howard A. Rusk and Dr. Eugene J. Taylor were recently awarded the Order of Merit Jose Fernandez by the Government[ of Colombia, according to word received here at New York University. The honor is the highest health award given by the armed forces of Colombia.

BALTIMORE, April 30 (AP) -- The civil Aeronautics Administration plans to take over policing of more air space. It now operates 140,000 miles of airlines for civilian airplanes up to almost 25,000 feet.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 30 -- Construction activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District finished the first quarter well ahead of 1954 figures, with Minnesota apparently headed for a new high, reports to the Minneapolis Reserve Bank indicated.
The prospect for stable labor- management relations in the waterfront here is better now than it has been in decades, in the opinion of at least one expert.

Peggy Durdin's article "Behind the Facade of Asian Unity" (April 17) was an intelligent recounting of Asiatic differences and cultural and historical areas in which unity may or may not be achieved. However, I feel that the writer dismissed as negligible the unifying factor of color in Asia.

CHRISTENED John Crane, the Mudhen is known only by his nickname to students, teachers and to readers of his earlier exploits. Whether gathering cat's whiskers at midnight, curing a sick horse, or catching a lion he outwits all rivals in his small preparatory school.

TWENTY years ago, when the New Deal was still young and the depression lay like a fog over the land, a vast confusion about politics and economics boiled and bubbled in many a tired brain. Most men were neutral, as they always are. But some grasped at the fraudulent panaceas peddled by outrageous quacks.
The City Symphony Orchestra ended its twenty-ninth season yesterday afternoon by presenting "Madama Butterly" at the American Museum of Natural History.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 --Twentieth Century-Fox moved in fast to tie up movie rights to "Island in the Sun" following a reading of the new Alec Waugh novel in manuscript form by Darryl F. Zanuck, studio production chief.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Events of such importance are now taking place across the world that all major nations, including the United States, are finding that they must look at the future in a somewhat different way.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) --United States trade with the Soviet Union and its satellites increased in 1954, the Commerce Department revealed today in its quarterly report.

New York's newest cooking school is in a reconverted coachman's house, set in its own small yard behind a tall gate, at 248 West Tenth Street. Head and faculty consist of Paul Mayer, alight, 30-year-old former Naval officer, who became so interested in the culinary art that he left radio to devote himself to it.
ALBANY, May 1 -- About 8,100 new teachers will be needed in New York schools in 195556, the State Education Department said today.
LONDON, May 1--Led by Aneurin Bevan, its perennial rebel and most provocative orator, the British Labor party today delivered its first fullscale attack on the election campaign.

A patrolman crawled under a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday to hold a woman down in the trough of the track while the motorman backed the train over them. The woman had fallen or jumped to the track before an oncoming train.

CHICAGO, May 1 (UP)--William F. Knowland, the Republicans' Senate leader, carried his attack on the Administration over Far East policy into the Middle West today. He charged the Chinese Communists were using Formosan peace bids to build up their military power.
An arresting symbol of the lasting sanctity of international contract will make its appearance in the financial world this week.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia maintained a strong hold on first place in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires yesterday, according to a report from Argentina. Ivkov drew in the tenth round with J. H. Donner of the Netherlands in a King's Indian defense in thirty-nine moves for a score of 8--2.

Schools were urged yesterday to develop a sense of intellectual curiosity on the part of their students. They also were asked to build the intangible aspects of education, such as good citizenship and the ability to live in a democratic society.
VIENNA, April 29--The Soviet economy cannot afford to bear the continuing high cost of modern armament production on a large scale, top Soviet officials told Austria's leaders in Moscow.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 1-- Bolivian Labor leaders asked President Victor Paz Estenssoro today to serve a second term. At the same time they listed steps they wanted the Government to take to keep labor's backing.

NO fiction writer would have dared use so improbable an ending for a football game. But it happened in real life and Bob Blackman still winces every time he thinks of it. Blackman is the new Dartmouth football coach and, because he's a stranger to these parts, he was personally escorted to town the other day by Red Rolfe, the old Yankee third-baseman who is the athletic director at Hanover.
PARIS, May 1--West German entry into the North Atlantic Alliance next week will necessitate special negotiations and deliberations by the North Atlantic Council, probably lasting well into midsummer.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1--Governments throughout the world are attempting increasingly to provide well-being for their peoples through legislation, the United Nations reported today.
Mihael J. Quill started issuing orders to the new Transit Authority yesterday without bothering to wait for its appointment.

Just about a year and a half ago, with production sliding off from the high record reached in the second quarter of 1953 and with employment just beginning to feel the effects of the postKorean readjustment, the Administration's anti - recession policies were under heavy attack.
Johnny Antonelli, ace southpaw pitcher of the Giants, hurled sixteen brilliant innings yesterday. His efforts brought the world champions a 2-to-1 victory over the Redlegs at the Polo Grounds.
ALBANY, May 1--Governor Harriman announced today his veto of what the Republicans had called three "humanizing" amendments to the state personal income tax law.

PARIS, May 1--Since the Fourth Republic was established in 1946 Prance has had seventeen Governments. But during most of the time two men, the Popular Republican leaders Robert Schuman and Georges Bidault, alternated at the Foreign Ministry.
The tenth anniversary of the death of the Most Rev. William Apor, Roman Catholic Bishop of Gyor, Hungary, was commemorated yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Descriptions of yesterdays May Day celebrations in Guatemala City tell of parades and mass meetings by the free trade unions far more dramatic than the belligerent circuses of the pro-Communist era. The dark red shadow of Moscow has gone and the black menace of a crushing reaction from the Right has also been overcome in the ten difficult months since the Communist-dominated Government of President Jacobo Arbenz was driven away.
Mayor Wagner and City Council President Abe Stark were asked yesterday to help kill a proposed local law to transfer an expense item of $11,400,000 from the expense budget to the city's funded debt.

The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike warned yesterday that emphasis on national safeguards was defeating the goals of peace and security. He preached the morning sermon at New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

The Guggenheim Memorial Concerts played by the Goldman Band again will be presented this summer as a gift to the people of New York. This has been announced by Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.

In decorating today, attention is focusing on the foyer. This is particularly true in New York apartments, where space is at a premium. With careful planning, an extra room can be created in these long, narrow, windowless areas.
So far only the Giants can beat the Dodgers. The Braves generally picked to win this year's National League pennant, couldn't beat the Brooks yesterday at Ebbets Field.
VIENNA, May 1--The Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will meet tomorrow to begin drafting a new state treaty for Austria.
Coxswains will give their commands in several tongues on May 24 as brawny seamen from many ports vie in New York's annual international lifeboat race.
ALBANY, May 1--Following is the text of the memorandum issued today by Governor Harriman in connection with his veto of Republican "humanizing" amendments to the state income tax law: Not approved.
ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I. May 1 --Word was received here today of the death of Rudolf Pierre Wendel, inventor and business man, in an automobile accident near San Francisco yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, May 1 (AP)-- The Kansas City Athletics scored their fifth victory in their last six starts today as they defeated the Washington Senators, 16 to 10.
Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas cited the racial issue yesterday as the world's basic problem.
PARIS, May 1--The French are the people most addicted to doctrines as guides to action, while the Americans are generally considered to avoid doctrines in favor of practical judgments.
Headed by Max Morlock, the Nuremberg Football Club of Germany began a seven-game tour of this country yesterday by defeating the GermanAmerican League All-Stars, 7--1.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Thomas H. Briggs' thoughtful letter in The Times of April 17 on the need for coordinated effort in curriculum research is most timely. We need urgently the judgment of competent men and women who can devote their full energies to the problem on our national objectives in education and the means to achieve them.
WASHINGTON, May 1-- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has affirmed the essentiality of the jeweled as well as the non-jeweled watch industry to national defense.
The Clark Equipment Corporation of Buchanan, Mich., reported first-quarter earnings 45 per cent above those of the like
Seven hundred persons attended yesterday a May Day antiCommunist rally under the auspices of the Socialist party and several Socialist and labor groups.
BRESCIA, Italy, May 1 (AP)-- Stirling Moss of England drove his Mercedes to a record-breaking victory today in the Mille Miglia (1,000 miles) road race.
WASHINGTON, May 1--United States officials expressed deep satisfaction today that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem had won control of Saigon.

After a firm start, cotton prices here turned downward to close last week with mixed net changes. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were from up 40 points to down 35 points from the level of the week before.

A taxpayer building containing four stores and occupying a Plot 63 by 100 feet at 939 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx was sold by the 939 East Tremont Avenue Corporation to the Grebeiz Holding Corporation for investment.

ONE of the most notable events of the Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House was reserved for the last day. Yesterday afternoon, Alicia Markova made her second appearance in "Giselle" and Erik Bruhn appeared opposite her in his very first Albrecht.
Seven business executives and an actor debated some issues of subscription television yesterday.

Encouraged by more favorable portents than have been present at any earlier time since the war, the Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and Soviet Russia meet in Vienna today with Austrian representatives to draft the final text of the treaty that is to restore Austria to full sovereignty and independence.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) --The Chicago Cubs, powered by the home run bats of Hank Sauer and Walker Cooper, defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 8--7, in the first game of a double-header today. Chicago led, 4--2, in the ninth inning of the second game when Play was suspended because of the Pennsylvania Sunday curfew law.

Week Ended April 29, 1955 British sterling for a brief period last Wednesday sold at $2.80, highest since last November. Strong London markets spelled that centre as the origin of the advance which was due to the "squeeze" on spot to balance accounts for month-end requirements. Oil company buying likewise provided an assist.
A state survey indicated yesterday that three-quarters of New York's industrial workers were protected by employerfinanced welfare plans.

Shipowners increased their margin of profit in last week's charter market. Higher rates were paid for most bulk cargo items, with grain leading the advance. The general volume of business was moderate.
BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (UP) --President Juan D. Peron said today the people must decide whether the Roman Catholic Church should be separated from the state.
"Richard Myers will carry the ball while I'm stationed in Madrid, Spain, working as a deputy director for the United States Government's Foreign Operations economic mission."
PARIS, May 1--The first substantial proposition for the collaboration of German and French private capital in the development of North African resources has been made by a German financial group.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 1--Marius W. Holtrop, president of the Netherlands Bank, strongly advocated last week an early return to convertibility on the basis of fixed exchange rates.
GUATEMALA, May 1--Guatemala under President Carlos Castillo Armas has weathered the great storm of her anti-Communist revolution.

Cerebral palsy is a muscular disability that still baffles physicians. In this city alone there are 30,000 cases. The victims are erroneously regarded as mentally afflicted because of their slurred speech, lack of balance and difficulty in walking. United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, which has its offices at 47 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been doing excellent work in overcoming this misunderstanding.
Increases in employment and non - residential construction since World War II have kept the city's economy in a state of expansion, the Department of City Planning declared yesterday.

Hour of Madness Daylight saving has been in effect for a time now, quite long enough to prove itself again both a snare and a delusion. It is clearly unworkable along the lines set down, for it violates the promises of its sponsors.

An investor has purchased the five-story apartment house at 1600 York Avenue, between Eighty-fourth and Eighty-fifth Streets, from the Zealous Realty Corporation, representing the estate of Leo G. Froman, who was a large owner of reality in Yorkville.

CANNES, France, May 1 (AP) --Bao Dai, Vietnamese Chief of State, cabled Premier Ngo Dinh Diem today that he was interested only in avoiding civil war in his homeland and in getting a government with a broad basis.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Senate Finance Committee is keeping the door ajar, if only slightly, for a possible compromise on repeal of two 1954 tax laws entailing unintended windfalls to business.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Both houses of Congress are squared away to do battle this week over major parts of the President's legislative program.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 1 --Clinging to a first-day lead, 26-year-old Bobby Monetti of the Manhasset Bay Y. C. acquired the frostbite dinghy championship of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association at the Larchmont Y. C. today.

Joseph Cole, tenor who sang a recital at Town Hall last night, made his debut in 1948 as a baritone. This represented a masterpiece of vocal mis-diagnosis on someone's part; Mr. Cole's light and essentially lyric voice is unmistakably that of a tenor.
QUEENS COLLEGE was proud of Karol Rathaus, the Polish composer who joined its faculty in 1940. In 1948, while he was still living, the college presented a program devoted entirely to his works.
A freshman coach at one of the leading universities said recently that there always is one sure way of telling when a baseball season is in full swing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In The Times editorial of April 26 "The Uninsured 10 Per Cent" it is stated that "The first dependable figures available now indicate that nearly one automobile in ten registered in New York State is not covered by liability insurance."

LONDON, May 1--In a week of conflicting influences, the stock markets have been unable to shake off the fear of the impending railway strike, which now seems inevitable, and the possibly paralyzing effects it will have on industry.

CHICAGO, May 1 (UP)--The Chicago White Sox split a double-header with the Baltimore Orioles today. The Sox won the second game under the lights, 6--3, after losing the opener, 9--8, in eleven innings.

RIO DE JANERIO, May 1 -- Complete overhaul of Brazil's foreign exchange policy was again reported imminent by a responsible newspaper today. Official sources have denied repeatedly that such changes were contemplated.
PARIS, April 27--There is still great suspicion and dislike on the Continent of Britain's intentions and motives in the monetary field.
A 17-year-old hoodlum was charged yesterday with the unprovoked killing of a 15-year-old boy in the Bronx.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America presented last night its 1955 World Brotherhood Awards to three prominent persons in recognition of their efforts to create better understanding among all races, creeds, colors and religions.

Brooklyn has calmly announced that it has formed a permanent symphony orchestra, secured a conductor and soloists and is embarking on a three-day spring Beethoven cycle, beginning tomorrow. This announcement will come as a greater surprise to the inhabitants of the other boroughs than it will to the Brooklynites themselves.
So far as is known, Don Mueller's single on what was intended to be an intentional pass yesterday was the first hit of this kind to be made since the new catcher's rule was adopted this year.

ALBANY, May 1--Three bills authorizing the Jockey Club to go forward with its plans for a "dream track" at Belmont Park have been approved by Governor Harriman. Several obstacles remain to be overcome before the dream can take physical form.

FLORENCE, Italy, May 1 (UP)--Fausto Gardini, the Italian champion, beat Mervyn Rose of Australia, 6--1, 7--5, 6--4, today to enter the men's singles final of the Florence international tennis tournament.

DETROIT, May 1--The Tigers, who had a run of seven straight victories, ran into Bullet Bob Turley of the Yankees today and were stopped in their tracks at Briggs Stadium. Turley's four-hit pitching gave the Bombers a 6-1 triumph, the fourth in a row for the former Baltimore righthander.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Governor Harriman of New York said today hewas still for Adlai E. Stevenson as the Democratic candidate for President in 1956.

LONDON, May 1--Drawing on his fund of infinite wisdom, the Lord Chamberlain has forbidden the commercial production of Julien Green's "South." That is one reason why it is now being produced at the Arts Theatre.
The land of the Pharaohs is taking a giant step into the twentieth century.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The April 19 issue of The New York Times carried a report about the changes in the Budapest Government. These changes--a switch back to the Rakosi regime--actually took place some months before.
The Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division in Baltimore has received a contract to convert four Marinerclass cargo ships for the American President Lines.
CHICAGO, May 1--Liquidation of long lines was the dominant influence in grain and soybean futures last week.

PARIS, May 1--Simca, the second largest independent automobile producer of France, becomes tomorrow the first French company to have its shares admitted to listing on a securities exchange in the United States.

A search is under way for the missing second page of some notes written by Dr. Albert Einstein shortly before he died. It was to have been part of an address he had planned to make last Tuesday night at a State of Israel anniversary celebration here.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 1-- A new frontier for economic development has been mapped by seventy leaders of education, labor, industry and government.
A list of glues and pastes for specific household and do-it-yourself jobs has been compiled by the Collapsible Metal Tubes Manufacturers Council.
When the Twentieth Century Fund undertakes a study of something, it fills the fuel tank, slips into low ratio and rides through the underbrush of fact like a sixty-ton tank.

Advertising men from agencies in foreign countries and others stationed abroad as representatives of domestic agencies are arriving here in numbers. They will attend the seventh annual convention of the International Advertising Association at the Plaza Hotel on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that John Fox, publisher of The Boston Post, was about to sell his controlling interest in the North Penn Gas Company.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 1-- Roger Sessions is a serious man of music, and his one-act opera "The Trial of Lucullus" is a serious work. Its production over the week-end at the McCarter Theatre in Princeton emphasized the fact that the aim of the opera was high.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Government economists are about 99 per cent pleased with the business recovery.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May --The car pool has shifted into high gear as a development of modern Suburbia.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Monday, May 2--Premier Ngo Dinh Diem is in control of South Vietnam's army after a struggle with Chief of State Bao Dai's backers.

WENDELL, MAYES is an actor to whom many things have happened rather rapidly. Some time ago he decided to try his hand at playwriting, and now in a matter of two weeks he would seem to have hit the jackpot.
Anti-poliomyelitis vaccine is expected to arrive late this week for the first phase of New York City's school inoculation program.
PITTSBURGH, May 1--When the figures for April steel production are tabulated this week there is a good chance that it will turn out to have been a record month.

Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, said yesterday that a controversial joint legislative "watchdog" committee would be formed in two weeks, but that no grounds now existed for suspecting or criticizing the Harriman Administration
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Surgeon General of the Public Health Service appealed anew today for patience until more supplies of the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine became available.

THE SATURDAY CONSORT, a group of Pittsburgh devotees of early music gave its first New York concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The event showed how much interest there is in such music, for an audience of almost 1,000 turned out to hear the visitors.
Johnny Antonelli tried last night to recall his sixteen innings on the pitching mound at the Polo Grounds and found that four hours of baseball were too much to remember on the same day.
WASHINGTON, May 1--President Eisenhower's announcement that he favors direct negotiations with the Chinese Communists about a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait has been widely misinterpreted.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Reports that President Eisenhower would discuss foreign policy in an address tomorrow circulated here tonight.
ROME, May 1--Pope Pius XII led the main observance of May Day today.

Garage rates here will rise 10 per cent on June 1. The higher tariffs will apply to about 200,000 monthly users of garages in residential areas of Manhattan and the Bronx and about 12,000 daytime garage parkers in business sections of the city.
MOSCOW, May 1--The Soviet Army showed off today a huge new artillery piece that Western military attaches said might be an atomic cannon.

THE more deeply you get into higher learning the more astonishing items you turn up. The New School, downtown, offers in its current catalogue a "Course in Breathing As a Conditioner, Especially in Hot Weather."

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP)-- Bobby Feller hurled his twelfth one-hit game and Herb Score came within two strikeouts of another Feller record today as the Cleveland Indians swept a doubleheader from the Boston Red Sox.
HONG KONG, May 1--A May Day demonstration involving crowds officially estimated at 500,000 persons unfolded in Peiping today before Mao-Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader.
Forty-six widely known Americans yesterday called upon the public for help in obtaining Congressional approval of two bills bearing on international trade.
Gambling and an "alarming" increase in juvenile crime are the most troublesome problems of New York's police, Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said yesterday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 1-- President Chiang Kai-shek today described the situation in the Formosa Strait as tense.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., May 1 (AP)--Babe Zaharias of Tampa, Fla., posted a 76 today to win the third annual $5,000 Peach Blossom-Betsy Rawls women's golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 293, 9 over par.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 (AP) --Gene Littler of Palm Springs. Calif., took the $10,000 top prize today in the $37,500 Golf Tournament of Champions. Littler posted a 72-hole score of 280.
LONDON, May 1 (AP)--Switzerland, Austria, Chile, and Czechoslovakia today advanced to the second round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis tournament today.

The situation in Saigon has been changing and shifting almost from hour to hour. Some type of government will emerge, of course, but just what it is and what it represents cannot now be established. It is clear, nevertheless, that there are dangers and pitfalls that must be avoided if it is to have the chance of real success.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP)-- Ron Kline pitched a seven-hitter for the Pittsburgh Pirates today as they shut out the St. Louis Cardinals, 7--0. In the opening game of the double-header, the Pirates lost, 4--3.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The President's Advisory Committee on Weather Control plans to make its first field tests of commercial cloud-seeding methods.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Eisenhower will hear a report tomorrow on negotiations with President Chiang Kaishek from Assistant Secretary of State Robertson and Admiral Radford.

"I Hear You Singing," a comedy by Greer Johnson, has been acquired for Broadway and summer stock production. It is set in a small Kentucky town and deals with two hymn-singing sisters who become great successes as regional recording artists.

Texas Instruments, Inc., Dallas, announced yesterday it is issuing to its common stockholders rights to subscribe at $25 a share for 165,945 shares of new 4.48 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, series A, $25 par value.
The steel industry has scheduled operations this week at 96.5 per cent of capacity, a gain of 0.9 point over last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
It took a dozen policemen from eight radio patrol cars to extricate two patrolmen who had teen sent to break up a street fight at busy Pacific and Nevins Streets, Brooklyn, last evening.
FREEHOLD, N. J., May 2 (AP) --Superior Court Judge C. Thomas Schettino today ordered a three-month delay in the annual stockholders meeting of Thermoid Company.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 2--Liberalization of the nation's immigration laws was urged today by Rabbi Harry Halpern of Brooklyn, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America.
A sideshow was added to the circus yesterday just after 15,000 children had screamed applause for an annual free performance at Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, May 2--The United States has agreed to provide special "atomic" training for selected Royal Air Force crews flying new strategic jet bombers.

Pulitzer Prize day at Columbia University is always awaited with interest for its recognition of merit, its occasional generation of controversy and the wide range and diversity of subject matter reviewed and recognized. Yesterday's were the thirty-eighth annual awards.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 2 --Benjamin F. Fairless will retire tomorrow, his sixtyfifth birthday, as head of the $2,350,000,000 United States Steel Corporation. He announced plans to relinquish his S259,200-a-year job as chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's largest steelmaking organization at its annual stockholders' meeting here today.

VIENNA, May 2--Ambassadors of the four occupying powers sat down with representatives of Austria today to discuss the final draft of a state treaty. They met for more than four hours and reported their task well under way.

The American advertising principle that selling must continue after advertising has won the first sale has been put before an audience of salesmen in Europe by Irwin A. Vladimir, president of the international advertising agency of that name.
ONE of the sprightliest painting shows of the season presents recent work by that perennially young veteran Gifford Beal, at the Kraushaar Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Virgil Akins of St. Louis ended the seven-year undefeated record of Ronnie Delaney last night with a spectacular knockout in the eighth round of a scheduled ten at the St. Nicholas arena.

Police Commissioner Adams has followed steadily a policy of candor with the people of New York City. His annual report on his first year in office continues this policy and does not attempt to minimize the unpleasant facts.
ALBANY, May 2--Republican bills that would have given Westchester and Nassau an additional county judge each have been vetoed by Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Ezra Taft Benson said today that restoration of rigid price supports on major farm products would be "a step backward" for United States agriculture.
Another flare-up yesterday at the Grace Line's North River terminal -- Piers 57 and 58, at West Sixteenth Street -- halted most of the day's work there.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to approve United States membership in the International Finance Corporation to help strengthen the "partnership of free nations."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In reply to your recent editorial I would like to thank you for the compliments paid to the Daughter of the American Revolution but express regret to your reference what you call our "antediluvia prejudice."
WASHINGTON, May 2--The National Advisory Committee on Poliomyelitis Vaccine voted unanimously today against compulsory controls in distributing the medicine.

The tenth anniversary of the state Anti-Discrimination Law was celebrated here yesterday. Eight hundred and fifty leaders in government, religion and education attended a luncheon held in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 2 (AP) --Archie Moore of California, pounded out a decision over Nino Valdes of Cuba tonight in a bruising fifteen-round fight.

Lack of news from Brazil sent coffee prices soaring yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Many traders had expected a cut in the minimum export price of green coffee over the week-end; when prices were not lowered, heavy short covering, profit taking and purchasing by Brazilian interests in the distant months forced the market up.
WASHINGTON, May 2--After three months of apprehensive Congressional hearings, the Defense Department stood firm today on its decision to cut the strength of the Army.
CHICAGO, May 2--The furniture business is booming for both manufacturers and retailers and there seems to be little doubt that it will continue at a high level, industry leaders said today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2-- Barring an eleventh-hour development, virtually all dry cargo handling will come to a halt here at 8 A. M. tomorrow.

KANSAS CITY, May 2 (AP)-- Roy Sievers and Jim Busby hit two home runs apiece tonight to lead the Washington Senators to a 12-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. Sievers hit both of his home runs with two men on base.

Title was taken yesterday by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to the blockfront property on the west side of Fifth Avenue between Fiftysecond and Fifty-third Streets. The new owner will improve the site with a thirty-eight-story office building from plans by Carson Lundin, architects.
ALTHOUGH the leaf of the willow was much larger than the mouse's ear, both the trout and the flies recognized the arrival of spring weather and reacted in a manner pleasing to many anglers.

A 16-year-old sea-struck boy, waiting last night on a pier end in Brooklyn in hope that his stepfather's barge would come in from Gowanus Bay, saw instead a bright flash of fire from a scow hard by and heard a cry for help.
Shoe production this year is almost certain to establish a record high, spokesmen for the Popular Priced Shoe Show of America said yesterday.

DIETRICH FISCHER-DIESKAU, the German baritone, making his debut at Town Hall last night, performed the considerable feat of holding his audience's interest and close attention throughout Schubert's songcycle, "Die Winterreise."
LONDON, May 2--Two British radioastronomers have tracked down the source of intense radio "signals" from space to a visible and well-charted region of the universe.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Field Marshal Pibul Songgram of Thailand scored a Prime Ministerial first today by playing a round of golf with President Eisenhower. The eighteenhole match was played at Burning Tree Club in nearby Maryland.

CHICAGO, May 2--Grain futures were generally heavy today, while soybeans showed some strength, especially for the May and July options. Scattered rainfall in the Southwest, good in spots but generally unimportant, caused a little selling of wheat in the early trade, but the general demand was indifferent much of the session.

Detroit Edison Company stockholders empowered the directors yesterday to issue up to $60,000,000 of convertible debentures for which stockholders would have pre-emptive purchase rights. Walker L. Cisler, president, at the annual meeting in the company's New York office, 60 Broadway, said there are no plans for their sale at this time nor have terms of the issue been set.
The United States Government gave New York City $11,717,357 yesterday to expedite slum clearance.
The Dodgers' fourth hit off Gene Conley of the Braves at Ebbets Field last night was a two-run homer by Carl Furillo in the twelfth inning of a fivestar thriller.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Admiral Arthur W. Radford and Walter S. Robertson gave a preliminary report today to Secretary of State Dulles on their negotiations with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
"Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" won for Tennessee Williams yesterday his second Pulitzer Prize for drama. The Mississippi playwright had taken the 1948 award for "Streetcar Named...

Six young instrumentalists who are interested in presenting the literature for woodwind quintet and for woodwinds and piano gave their first concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. They solved their billing problems by printing the Contemporary Woodwind Quintet at the top of the program and giving Gilbert Kalish, their pianist, bigger type on the second line.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP)-- Bob Purkey of the Pittsburgh Pirates gave up only seven scattered hits to the St. Louis Cardinals today. Meanwhile his teammates were lambasting three Card hurlers for fourteen hits to chalk up a 5-1 victory.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams stressed yesterday that police promotions would not be influenced by groups in or outside the department.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Edward Corsi predicted tonight that the controversy over the nation's refugee program would have "very deep political repercussions" in New York next year.

WHENEVER Sherlock Holmes felt in need of some stimulation he'd holler for his friend, Dr. Watson. The large Muzz Patrick, the new manager of the Rangers, wasted no time in giving the Broadway Blues the stimulating jab they so obviously require.

There is diversity in the new food products now at the grocer's. They range from tinned cod tongues to an old-fashioned rice pudding in a can. But in one respect, all are alike: they are designed to make kitchen work easier.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- A burst of automobile buying shot new installment credit up a record $3,159,000,000 during March, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
John G. (Steve) Broady was indicted yesterday as the "prime mover" of the wiretap conspiracy here. The case has been under investigation by a New York County grand jury since Feb. 21.
New York City's Democrats have increased the control they will be able to exert at their party's next state convention.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The American Federation of Labor barred its teamster affiliate today from taking in longshoremen.

MIAMI, May 2 (AP)--The police of three states delved for clues today to the mysterious disappearance of Charles Ferri--a Government witness in the Albert Anastasia income tax evasion trial--and his wife.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- Louis S. Rothschild, Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, said today that the law should bar "even the eligibility" of airlines for Government subsidy.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP)-- Early Wynn hurled his first victory of the season today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4--2. Dave Pope hit a three-run homer for the Indians and Jackie Jensen connected for the Red Sox.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 12,000 head; market fairly active, generally weak to mostly 25c lower on butchers; sows uneven, around 25c lower; most choice 190 to 230 pounds butchers.

The New York Athletic Club membership includes many old boys, middle-aged boys and men just graduated from boys whose exploits in the fields of sports live in the record books. Their trophies cover the walls and shine in countless glass cases in the clubhouses on Central Park South and at Travers Island in the Sound.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 --Otto Preminger's problem is not how to find work, but how to squeeze a vacation into his heavy schedule.

MAURICE EDELMAN, a Labor Member of Parliament since 1945, writes so well that one wonders if his fellow M. P.'s take him seriously. Certainly in Washington, any politician who displayed a gift for fiction would be regarded with deep suspicion. Perhaps they arrange matters differently in England where statesmen frequently write books and occasionally great books.
LONDON, May 2--The Western powers propose to ask the Soviet Union to attend a fourpower meeting on German reunification sometime this summer, authoritative sources disclosed today.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 2 --Fred Gronauer, Sands Point Club pro, and Dick Armstrong posted a best-ball score of 32, 31--63 to tie with Roy Jones and Melvin La Boyne of Hempstead for top honors today at the Fresh Meadow Country Club.
New Jersey's plan for a sewage treatment plant has jeopardized New York City's entire $353,000,000 anti-pollution program, Mayor Wagner charged yesterday.
The official "deadline" for unit sale of the strike-closed Brooklyn Eagle passed yesterday without a buyer.

PARIS, May 2--It was confirmed here today that on one important point Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, failed to agree in their meeting Saturday in Bonn.
ALBANY, May 2--The Republican state high command attempted today to pin a "high tax" label on Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, May 2--John Foster Dulles declared today that the Bricker amendment would make the President "unable properly to conduct foreign relations."
CANNES, France, May 2 (Reuters) -- Bao Dai told a French newspaper today he planned to go back to strifetorn South Vietnam with a "plan of action."
PINEHURST, N. C., May 2 (AP) --Negro membership in the North Carolina Medical Society was approved tonight by the society's House of Delegates.

After more than fifty years of distinguished public service one of this country's finest tuberculosis hospitals has changed its name. Henceforth it will be "The American Medical Center at Denver." The change indicates a broadening of the field of service.
The American Museum of Natural History has decided to drop its conservation director, Richard H. Pough, in a policy shift that some conservationists linked to the Echo Park Dam dispute.
The stock market averages rose fractionally yesterday, despite the fact that only about one of every three issues traded ended on the plus side.
Two teen-agers arrested in the unprovoked slaying of a 15-yearold boy in the Bronx Saturday night were arraigned yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation offered $191,659,000 of 3 1/4 per cent, twenty-five-year debentures to stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2--President Eisenhower called for "an enlightened trade policy" today as the Senate began debate on his reciprocal trade bill.
Wanamakers Great Neck, L. I. store will be closed at 5:30 P. M. today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- Following is the transcript of remarks by President Eisenhower today to the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce: Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen: It is indeed a great honor to welcome you here to the Capital City and to have the privilege of spending with you these few minutes.

Amerada Petroleum Stockholders of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation, at their annual meeting held here yesterday, approved a two-for-one split in the common stock. Albert Jacobsen, president, said stockholders would receive one share for each one held, without surrendering their stock certificates.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 2--A thoughtful observer at the Eastern States Antiques Fair, which opened here today at the Westchester County Center, would have no difficulty in reconstructing in the mind's eye the physical surroundings of another time.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 3 to 12 points up, with old May strongest.
BERLIN, May 2--The three Western powers proposed today, that the four High Commissioners in Germany meet Saturday to discuss the increased East German tolls on trucking between Berlin and the West.

Two veteran Park Department men were given citations by the Park Association of the City of New York yesterday and praised by Commissioner Robert Moses for their "common sense" approach to their jobs.
BONN, Germany, May 2 -- The Allied High Commission is scheduled to liquidate itself Thursday morning, several hours before West Germany's sovereignty comes into force.

Stockholders of the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., were told by Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president, at the annual meeting in Clifton, N. J., yesterday that "information about the company's financial picture does not show up on profit and loss statement, or even on balance sheets."

ALBANY, May 2--Two bills under which bus companies would be exempted from state utility taxes have been vetoed by Governor Harriman. Signed, however, were two bills permitting cities and villages to exempt bus companies from local utility taxes.

The Cosmetic Dust The head of the house sat grimly at dinner. Before him was a plate piled high with scraps, and across the way the cook had the expression of one who dared him to inquire just what they were.

LONDON, May 2--General election influences and tomorrow's ending of the current bookkeeping account kept the volume of stock market business small today. On balance, price movements were small and irregular.

Sales of nine New York and Brooklyn department stores last month were 1 per cent greater than in the like month last year, a survey by The New York Times revealed yesterday. If their performances were compared with the ten stores in operation last year, sales would have dropped 5 per cent.
Eight civic organizations yesterday called upon the left-wing Teachers Union to withdraw their names from printed material implying that they were endorsing a union activity.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Fortyfive state Governors agreed today that the Federal Government must assume greater responsibility for Civil Defense in an era when a single bomb can devastate eighty square miles.

ATLANTA, May 2 (AP)--The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that a group of its unions had arranged to lend the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., $1,250,000 to help its fifty-day-old strike against the Southern Bell Telephone Company in nine southeastern states.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The United States is using its influence to avoid an open break between Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and Chief of State Bao Dai of Vietnam.
Now is the time for all good men, and women, to come to the aid of their parties by taking advantage of central registration.
ALBANY, May 2--Governor Harriman's approval of bills intended to improve court administration and to curb the distribution of obscene comic books was announced today.

St. John's University's baseball team remained undefeated and in first place in the Metropolitan Conference by defeating Wagner, 5--1, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens, yesterday. This was the Redmen's fifth league victory.

CHICAGO, May 2--Patrick E. Gorman, secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L., announced today that his union soon could resume talks with the rival United Packing House Workers Union, C. I. O.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Leaders of the two major labor federations agreed today on a constitution to govern their combined organization of 15,000,000 members.
TRENTON, May 2--The State Legislature was urged today to appropriate $11,412,361 next year and larger sums in succeeding years for the building of new school facilities.
Television networks recalled yesterday some of their personnel from Yucca Flat, Nev., after another postponement of the atomic blast demonstration.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- President Eisenhower today asked Congress for $5,000,000 to remodel the Capitol. The purpose would be to bring the east central front in line with the two wings that house the Senate and House of Representatives.
Homemakers who avoided becoming lawbreakers at midnight yesterday have two reasons today for relief.

The armless, winged "Victory of Samothrace" in the Louvre in Paris will soon be reunited with her long-lost right hand, which was discovered in 1950 close to where the "Victory" stood nearly 2,000 years ago.

Twenty-year-old Beverly Butler of Milwaukee has been named winner of the seventeenth summer literary competition for her novel "Song of the Voyager." The story is set in the wilderness that was Wisconsin in the early Eighteen Thirties.
The beginning of the end of the "Tweed Courthouse" just north of City Hall was written yesterday by the Department of Public Works.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 2 (AP) --Ceyway scored her second harness racing victory in five starts this season when she gained a half length decision over Bertram Hanover in 2:05 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Tuesday, May 3--Broken rebel battalions were reported retreating from the Saigon sector this morning after a heavy pounding by 2,000 of South Vietnam's best soldiers.
LONDON, May 2--The British Communist party appealed to left-wing Laborites today in an effort to split the Labor party and elect a small group of Communists to Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A good many people seem to think that Senator William F. Knowland of California should resign as the leader of the Senate Republicans because he is actively engaged in challenging an important section of the President's foreign policy.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., May 2-- The Apawamis Club entry of Jack Patroni and Alfred Schwarzenbach registered 30, 34--64 to capture the opening pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golf Association season today.

CAIRO, May 2 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Premier of Egypt, returned today from a three-week "diplomatic reconnaissance" in Asia. He told welcoming crowds that he had followed an independent policy at the Asian-African conference at Bandung, Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Section 91 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 states that the President may direct the Atomic Energy Commission to deliver to the Defense Department atomic materials and weapons for "such use as he deems necessary in the interest of national defense."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP) --Three horses already booked for Saturday's-eighty-first running of the Kentucky Derby will test their fitness for the $125,000 added turf classic in the Derby Trial tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 2--An American economy in which depressions could not occur and "three-car families" were commonplace was portrayed today by speakers before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Stockholders of the American Viscose Corporation were told at the annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday that sales and profits for the first quarter of 1955 had increased 30 and 263 per cent, respectively, above the results achieved in the corresponding quarter a year ago.
New York City real estate still provides the basis of one of the soundest investments to be made in the country, according to Leffert Holz, State Superintendent of Insurance.
The role of the recanting informer continued yesterday to plague the Government.
Public higher education in this country is threatened with increased governmental control, according to prominent state university presidents.

White Skies, the 6-year-old horse who gained fame as one of the sturdiest sprinters of the past twenty years, was involved in an accident yesterday and had to be destroyed. The thoroughbred owned by William M. Wickbam suffered a compound fracture of his right hind cannon bone during a workout at Jamaica.

The last obstacle to putting the Paris pacts into effect has been removed as a result of the Bonn conference between Foreign Minister Pinay and Chancellor Adenauer, at which the two statesmen reached agreement on "all outstanding questions" between France and Germany.
One financial authority called yesterday for increased caution in the market. Another sang a sweet song of the might-havebeen profits in present levels of growth stocks bought forty years ago.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Tuesday, May 3--Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and South Vietnam's Army chiefs served notice on Chief of State Bao Dai last night that they had taken the power to appoint governments out of his hands.

RYE, N. Y., May 2--Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Lois Hallager of Bonnie Briar shared gross honors, each with 42, 41--83, in the opening tournament of the women's WestchesterFairfield Golf Association today.

A site for an apartment house on the south side of Fifty-seventh Street between Park and Lexington Avenues has been purchased by George M. and Alfred Gross of Gross Brothers. The sellers were Nira, Inc., and Joseph J. Lese.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 2 (UP)--Egypt eliminated Turkey, four matches to one, in the first round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today when Ismail Adel and Baldreldin el Sayed won the final two singles matches.
Although heavy advance bookings indicate a record Atlantic travel year, carryings for the first three and one-half months of this year have been about 6,000 passengers behind the same period of 1954.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 2--The ratio of juvenile delinquents to the general population in Westchester has decreased 25 per cent since 1930. Judge George W. Smyth of the Children's Court reported this today to the County Board of Supervisors.

Sketches of the winners of Pulitzer Prizes follow: Tennessee Williams A dramatist with a poetic command of the theatre, Tennessee Williams has won five major playwriting awards since his first work opened on Broadway ten seasons ago.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Following is the text of the constitution for a combined American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations agreed upon today: PREAMBLE The establishment of this federation through the merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations is an expression of the hopes and aspirations of the working people of America.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) --The Philadelphia Phillies lost to the Chicago Cubs, 2--1, tonight.

DETROIT, May 2--Bob Wiesler, an erratic left-hander whose main drawback with the Yankees has been a lack of control, flunked his first test of the season today. He walked five batters, three in the third inning, and the Detroit Tigers went on to beat the Bombers, 7--1.
The Society of the Silurians elected Charles A. Donnelly president at its annual meeting and sixty-first semi-annual dinner last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Premier Pibul Songgram, a short, dapper, golf-loving Thai of 57, is an example of a militarist who triumphed over his reputation as a Japanese collaborator and became one of the West's firmest allies.
YESTERDAY (May 2, 1955) ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Fifth Conference of NonGovernmental Organizations Migration -- Opened session and adopted agenda.
LONDON, May 2--Big Ben, the clock in the tower of the Palace of Westminster, which houses Parliament, will be renovated.
YESTERDAY (May 2, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Greeted governors attending conference here. Played golf with visiting Field Marshall Pibul Songgram of Thailand.
The writer of the following letter was formerly in the United States Foreign Service, his last post as Vice Consul in Rotterdam.

Sales and earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation were up sharply for the first quarter. The company, the largest domestic copper producer, said it expects capacity operations for the rest of 1955.

GENEVA, May 3--The United States Government is prepared to issue 170,000 immigration visas in the next eighteen months to European refugees, Scott McLeod said today. Mr. McLeod administers the refugee program for the State Department.
WASHINGTON, May 3--President Eisenhower put his $3,500,000,000 foreign aid program before a generally receptive delegation of the Congressional leaders of both parties today.

"South Pacific" will return to the local stage at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center and continue there through May 15. Loaded with such attributes as a run of 1,925 performances, the Pulitzer Prize as well as the Critics Award, the entertainment is receiving its first New York revival.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Regulations under which the House and Senate Committees on Government Operations may obtain individual tax returns for investigatory purposes were tightened today by President Eisenhower.
BALBOA, C. Z., May 3--Buffeted by veering winds that caused some men to land outside the drop zone, about 550 paratroopers "retook" the Rio Hato area today during military exercise Barracuda I.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Freedom-loving people everywhere are prayerfully following, the steps now being taken which it is hoped will lead to liberation of the Austrian people. There is one aspect of this matter which, so far as I know, has received no public attention.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, May 4--Gen. Trinh Minh The, one of the strong men behind South Vietnam's Revolutionary Committee, was killed last night.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, May 4 -- South Vietnam's Government will hold a national political congress today to consider dismissing Bao Dai as Chief of State.

As a result of the Customs Simplification Acts of 1953 and 1954, the customs administration has been freed from many archaic procedural requirements. In the Customs Simplification Act of 1954 Congress recognized the need for modernizing and simplifying the tariff act descriptions, and authorized the Tariff Commission to undertake a two-year study and revision of these which "should go far to eliminate the problems arising from obsolescence."
New securities of the Riegel Paper Corporation, priced at more than $19,300,000, will be offered to investors today in transactions underwritten by investment bankers headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
A bill that would drastically curb the powers of Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley was introduced into the City Council yesterday.

EIGHT days ago, the Phoenix Theatre gave us Herman Melville with its partially successful adaptation of "Moby Dick." And last evening a new group called Masquers, Inc., gave us Melville again. This time it was a thoroughly successful revival of "Billy Budd.''
CHICAGO, May 3 --After sharp declines, with the May option extremely heavy, new crop wheat futures reversed the early trend and moved up well above the previous close.
Sales and net profits of Sterling Drug, Inc., for the first quarter of 1955 were the highest
ALBANY, May 3--The State Advisory Committee On Poliomyelitis Vaccine concluded today that there was no immediate need for rationing Salk vaccine in the state at this time.
YESTERDAY (May 3,1955) THE PRESIDENT Discussed foreign aid with Congress leaders of both parties. Conferred with Admiral Radford and Assistant Secretary of State Robertson on their Formosa mission.

The American democratic process makes the Executive an essential partner in the making of laws. Governor Harriman has now completed action on the deluge of bills left behind by the Legislature when it adjourned. The thirty-day period allowed by the Constitution is an ordeal, but the Governor took this first experience with it in apparently easy stride.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Following is the text of Article 16 of the draft of the Austrian state treaty as submitted by Austria to the United Nations in 1952 and accepted by the United States at the Berlin conference of Foreign Ministers last year:
Mayor Wagner called upon all 8,000,000 New Yorkers yesterday to join in a full-time campaign for a litter-free city.
Unrest among members of the Transport porkers Union, C. I. O., is reflected in a sharp cut in the number of employes authorizing the deduction of union dues from their wages.
The Golden Jubilee Ball to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Travelers Aid Society was held last night in the ballroom of the Ambassador.

TOKYO, May 3 --The Symphony of the Air, formerly Arturo Toscanini's N. B. C. Symphony, received a tremendous ovation in its Far Eastern debut here tonight. A capacity audience included Crown Prince Akihito.

If one is at a loss for after dinner jokes, try shopping for secondhand furniture. One woman's experience, as herein reported, may not be the average, but it supplied her with enough city vignettes to stock a novel. (It also drove her to the department stores.)
A lethal home-made bomb that was found early Monday morning in Radio City Music Hall was deactivated by the police yesterday.
Because of an impending teacher shortage, the nation's colleges and universities will be forced to employ "intellectual cripples," leading American educators warned yesterday.

"IF civilization persists--and let us console ourselves with the thought that it revived after the Dark Ages--a hundred years hence this book will be in the 'World's Classics' and 'Everyman' of the time." This confident prediction was made by Sir John Squire in a recent issue of The Illustrated London News about L. E. Jones' "A Victorian Boyhood."*
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 3--Senator Estes Kefauver tonight accused President Eisenhower of demagoguery in his public statements on the Formosan situation.
WASHINGTON, May 3--The State Department said again today that the United States hoped to avoid an open break between Chief of State Bao Dai and Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Persons now living will see atomicpowered aircraft cross the Atlantic in thirty minutes, an industrialist said today.

Paul A. Pfeffer, 23-year-old former convict involved in an earlier killing case, confessd last night to the fatal beating of a 60-year-old plumber's helper on April 9, according to the Queens District Attorney's office.

It is inevitable that the Japanese should cast longing eyes upon the Chinese market and hope, eventually, to reach some sort of accommodation by which this market could be made to serve Japan. Obviously the Japanese have to export to live. The islands are not self-sustaining.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your two articles on fluoridation covered many of the aspects of the subject but omitted what to me seemed the crux of the whole situation. That is that tooth decay, while prevalent, is a minor ailment, not contagious and within the realm of personal control, and that there are other methods of applying fluorides for those who feel that this will be helpful.

The Advisory Board on the Pulitzer Prizes has again cited Arthur Krock of The New York Times for distinguished correspondence from Washington. It called him a "great newspaper man" and an example to the world of journalism.

Ridgewood took a half-point lead in the New Jersey district as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub matches got under way yesterday. The Garden State defending champion downed Aldecress, 9 1/2 to 5 1/2.

PARIS, May 3--Premier Johannes Hoffmann of the Saar and Foreign Minister Antoine Pinay of France signed today an economic convention reinforcing the customs and currency union between France and the Saar.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 3-- The possibility that the new Salk vaccine may be just a steppingstone to a practicable way to wipe out polio by lifetime immunization was raised here today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)-- Gov. George N. Craig and Senator William E. Jenner, two Republicans accustomed to feuding: in Indians, engaged in a namecalling match in the capital today.
Midday service and evening commuting schedules on the Long Island Rail Road will be increased by the addition of sixty trains starting Sunday.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Following is the statement of Staney N. Barnes, Assistant Attorney General, regarding a proposed antitrust complaint against the American Association of Advertising Agencies and other advertising media, associations:

WASHINGTON, May 3--The Ambassador of Afghanistan, Mohammed Kabir Ludin, denounced today as "utterly false" a Kabul dispatch to The New York Times reporting a Soviet offer of military support to the Afghans.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP)--Timely hitting combined with brilliant relief pitching by Dick Donovan and Sandy Consuegra enabled the Chicago White Sox to rally tonight and defeat the Washington Senators. 5--3.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt suggested yesterday three possible channels that she believes might profitably be explored by diplomats looking for a solution of the recent hostilities in Palestine.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,000 head; market fairly active and uneven; generally 25 to 50 cents higher on all hogs; most choice 190 to 220 pounds butchers. $17.25 to $17.75; several...

The spot (May) potato futures option fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May quotations tumbled 46 points. Almost all the volume was in the spot month. Final prices were off 8 to 46 points on 1,237 car lots.
Research by Allan Roth, Brooklyn's club statistician, has established that the Dodgers have made major league history by winning sixteen of their first eighteen games.

CLEVELAND, May 3 -- The usually carefree Yogi Berra was the saddest person in Municipal Stadium tonight. Yogi's error set up the margin of victory for the Cleveland Indians, who won their first meeting of the season with the Yankees, 7--4.
Nonpayment of "assessments" meant no more work at the Leonardo Naval Base at Earle, N. J., it was testified at a Waterfront Commission hearing into kickbacks resumed yesterday.

First-quarter earnings in 1955 of the American Chain Cable Company, Inc., were 40 to 50 per cent higher than last year, W. F. Wheeler, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
Today is the seventh anniversary of the regional Red Cross blood program. It serves civilians in this area as well as the armed forces and is part of the national Red Cross blood program.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City has elected six new directors, it was announced yesterday by John C. Wood, chairman of the board of the bureau and president of Brooks Brothers, Inc. The new directors, replacing six who have retired, are: DeWitt A. Forward, senior vice president, First National Bank of New York.
A program of contemporary music was presented last night by "Composers of Today, Inc.," at the Town Hall Green Room.
LONDON, May 3 -- Further unrest on the labor front added to the prevailing uncertainty in the stock markets today. Business remained small and price movements again were narrowly irregular.

The charter for the merging A. F. L-C. I. O. Federation sets up a striking benchmark by which to measure the profound change in the philosophy of organized labor in the United States that has taken place since the Eighteen Eighties--one closely tied in with the revolutionary development that has occurred during the same time in the theory and practice of business management.

A THIRD of the ninety-six steel workers putting up the frame for William Kaufman's twenty-story Grand Central Building on the east side of Third Avenue between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets are Indians who commute to and fronm Montreal in Canada on week-ends.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 3 (UP) --President Carlos Ibahez del Campo today signed a law improving conditions under which large foreign copper companies operate in Chile.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP)-- The Army will carve an experimental "arctic subway" in Greenland's huge icecap next month. It will expand the project if it proves feasible.

The J. Walter Thompson Company, biggest advertising agency in the world, is going to have some competition for the $3,500,000 -a-year advertising account of the Florida Citrus Commission. For some years the commission has heard a formal presentation each year from only one advertising agency, and Thompson last year had no rivals.

PARIS, May 3--French argot recently adopted a new word front a gangster film. This is rififi and may be interpreted as meaning violent bust-up with fatal consequences. The current situation in South Vietnam is a fine example of rififi.

OTTAWA, May 3 --Canada charged today that the Communist Government of North Vietnam was evading its obligations under the terms of the aruce in Indochina. She said that the free movement of refugees into South Vietnam was not being permitted.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The United States Government has entered a period of intense diplomatic activity designed to test the sincerity of the Communist world's call for a relaxation of "cold-war" tensions. As evidence of this, responsible officials and diplomats here point to the following: The State Department has instructed Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr. in Vienna to make a determined effort this week to reach an agreement with the Russians on the future of Austria.
KANSAS CITY, May 3 (AP)-- Bill Wilson smacked a home run with two men on tonight to give the Kansas City Athletics a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
Roger M. Blough, a 51-yearold attorney and former high school teacher, is the new boss of the United States Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The Department of Justice announced today that it would file a complaint within the next several days charging six groups in the newspaper and magazine publishing field with violation of the antitrust laws.

ROME, May 3 (UP)--Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., who was permitted to play in the Rome international tournament pending possible disciplinary action by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, reached the second round in men's singles today.
LOUISVILLE, May 3--At Jamaica a couple of Saturdays ago Harry F. Guggenheim was asked what his plans were for his Kentucky Derby nominees, Racing Fool and Flying Fury.

This port is about to put its new labor-management "harmony" machinery to the ultimate test. Jacob Grumet, former assistant district attorney and former Fire Commissioner of the city, has been invited to act as the first arbitrator in a dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.
