The Civil Rights Congress hearing before the Subversive Activities Board was adjourned abruptly yesterday when it threatened to get out of hand.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Republican and Democratic Governors declared today that the Administration had not developed adequate plans to insure effective, equitable distribution of the Salk polio vaccine.

"DARKNESS AT NOON" was brought to the television screen on Monday evening in all its provocative power. Lee J. Cbbb contributed a most impressive performance as the dedicated Red who is devoured by communism.
VIENNA, May 3--After racing through the first fifteen articles of the Austrian state treaty draft yesterday, the Ambassadors of the four occupation powers and Austria struck a snag today.

Gross receivables acquired by the finance companies of the Commercial Credit Company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of this year amounted to $874,859,775, according to the report of operations released yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) --Power-packed Cincinnati got the range on a procession of Philadelphia pitchers tonight and scored a 7-5 victory. Ted Kluszewski hit his sixth and seventh homers of the season for the Redlegs.
TAIPEI, May 3--The situation created by "peace feelers" over the Formosa situation has put a damper on the Chinese Nationalists' psychological warfare against the Communists.

Ten teachers have already resigned rather than submit to questioning under oath on Communist ties. Three others are merely awaiting Board of Education action on their offers to leave the public school system. All were among fifty-seven teachers summoned for questioning or requestioning under the so-called "informer" resolution adopted by the board March 17.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3-- "Flamingo Feather," the novel by Laurens Van Der Post, will be made into a motion picture for Paramount by Alfred Hitchcock.

The situation in South Vietnam remains fluid and subject to sudden change, but for the moment at least Premier Diem appears to be emerging as the victor over his varied enemies. Backed by the more responsible army generals, he has crushed the revolt of the Binh Xuyen ex-pirates, gangsters and racketeers.
PITTSBURGH, May 3 (UP)-- Dick Littlefield, a southpaw, shut out the Milwaukee Braves, 4--0, on seven, singles tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates their third straight victory.

PARIS, May 3--It seemed certain tonight that Indochina would be one of the two main topics to be discussed by the three principal Western foreign ministers when they meet here Sunday. Negotiations with the Soviet Union will be the other.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Senator William F. Knowland expressed concern today over reports that the Soviet Union had demanded that the Austrian state treaty contain a provision that might enable the Communists to retake about 38,000 Iron Curtain refugees in Austria.

The seven-story office and Showroom building at 312 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-second Street, has been purchased by an investing client of Leepson Rubman in a deal negotiated by Williams Co., brokers. It is assessed at $130,000 and is occupied by concerns in the umbrella and handbag lines.

LOUISVILLE, May 3--There was a practice romp at ancient Churchill Downs today. Presumably it didn't mean a thing. It was the annual running of the intriguing Derby Trial, the final warm-up for Saturday's historic Kentucky Derby. The hardboots from the bluegrass country paid it scant heed because the horses in the Trial merely were exercising to see who might win third place on Derby Day, a show for show money.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The Premier of Thailand favors an easing of tension in the Formosa Strait. But he wants this accomplished without causing the Asian people "to lose faith in the strength of the free world."

DETROIT, May 3 (AP) -- Al Kaline of the Detroit Tigers, hammered a two-run homer high into the upper left-field seats today. The blow enabled Billy Hoeft and the Tigers, to post a 4-2 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. recommended today that the United Nations remove the right of veto over the admission of new members.

Stock prices broke sharply in the closing hour of trading yesterday. There were some recoveries before the close but final prices showed losses as large as 5 points. The drop in The New York Times' fifty-stock average was the biggest since March 30.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 3 (AP) --After losing two straight, Jug Chief returned to winning form at Roosevelt Raceway tonight by finishing first in the Rockville Centre Pace. The 4-year-old scored by half a length over Buffalo Street in 2:04 1/5.
Eligible voters in suburban counties went to the polls yesterday in the first day of a twoday balloting to choose school board members and settle on budgets and special propositions.

The Treasury is keeping a sharp eye on the nation's expanding economy to see that it is not based on excessive use of credit, according to Robert B. Blyth, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury. He stressed production of consumer goods.

Fabulist of the High Tide Stable made it easy for the favorite players at Belmont Park yesterday. With Teddy Atkinson in the saddle, the 4-year-old son of Mighty Story was backed heavily, and the horse responded with a smooth winning effort.
TODAY the Brooklyn Museum is opening its eighteenth Biennial International Water-Color Exhibition.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 3--This is Coral Sea Week in Australia.
WASHINGTON, May 3--The Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Monopoly was told today that the Department of Justice would study possible substitutes before recommending repeal of the "fair trade" laws.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3-- A report that the United States was about to grant a "funding loan" to consolidate all of Brazil's outstanding commercial debts was widely circulated here today. No confirmation could be obtained.
GENEVA, May 3--Venezuela intends to withdraw from the International Labor Organization. The Government of Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez has so informed the International Labor Office here.
Radio Corporation of America, the country's largest producer of electronics devices, is this year aiming to break into the limited ranks of billion-dollar corporations.
LONDON, May 3--Several economic developments enhanced the chances of the Conservative party today in the May 26 general election.
LONDON, May 3 -- Add "Time Remembered" to "Thieves' Carnival" and the mystery of Jean Anouilh begins to disappear. No doubt the mystery is largely American.

To THE EDITOR THE NEW YORK TIMES : Recent Times editorials have favored H. R. 1, the proposed new foreign trade program. This letter is intended to bring to your attention reasons underlying the argument of some of us opposing the measure.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Bernard Spindel, New York wiretap expert, gave a curious House Judiciary subcommittee a firsthand demonstration of his methods today.
YESTERDAY (May 3, 1955) ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on International Commodity Trade--Considered proposals by Governments regarding international commodity problems.
To Mrs. Lillian Fischl, caring for twenty-one temporarily parentless children in addition to her own two for six years has been virtually a hereditary affair.

Marriage may be a wonderful institution but it will not cure emotional disorders, a medical authority said yesterday. Dr. Edward Weiss, Professor of Clinical Medicine at Temple University, observed that many physicians were likely to recommend marriage and parenthood as a cure for neurotic and psychosomatic ills.
The City Council called on the Board of Health yesterday to adopt "time periods" within which polio vaccine could be administered only to specified age groups here.
The Prime Minister of Tonga arrived in New York yesterday to scour the detergent and other markets for new buyers of copra.
Station WABD will televise "Shoestring Revue," a stage production, two days before its scheduled theatre closing.
One former teacher succeeded another in the chairmanship of the nation's largest steel corporation yesterday, when Roger M. Blough took the reins from Benjamin F. Fairless.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were strong yesterday. They closed at virtually the best levels of the day up 10 to 25 points (50 cents to $1.25 a bale). The advance was led by the old May contract.

The 500 mark continues to elude the Giants. With an opportunity to balance their record for the season, the faltering world champions meekly submitted to a 6-0 whitewashing at the hands of Chicago's Bob Rush at the Polo Grounds last night.

A bronze statue of Balzac by Rodin was presented yesterday to the Museum of Modern Art as a memorial to Curt Valentin. The great bronze work, set up in the garden adjoining the museum building at 11 West Fiftythird Street, was the gift of 130 friends of Mr. Valentin, a gallery owner and benefactor of artists.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 2--The Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro has just entered the last and probably most difficult year of its four-year mandate.
The Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of New York will study the problems of its aging members. Construction of a research center in Utica for that purpose will start June 19.

Food for an Army It is a hundred and sixty years since Napoleon Bonaparte made up his mind that a way had to be found for armies to carry food supplies with them in convenient form and offered a liberal award to the man who could solve the problem.

The governing committee of the National Association of Insurance Brokers, Inc., reported yesterday that it had recommended that the industry take the bull by the horns in the matter of atomic energy coverage.
On arrival at a children's party recently, each small guest received a toy cooking set, complete with miniature cans of soup, saucepan and spoon.

Maryland has designated May 17 as the date of sale for bond issues totaling $11,269,000. The borrowing will consist of $3,369,000 of school bonds and $7,900,000 of obligations to finance general construction. The bonds will come due serially on June 15 from 1958 to 1970.
THE heavy run of Atlantic salmon that moved up the Miramichi, in New Brunswick, last fall is providing exceptional spring salmon fishing on the big river and its feeder streams.

BALTIMORE, May 3 (AP) -- Thomas D'Alesandro Jr., a Democrat, today won a third straight term as Mayor of this city. Voters also sent a Negro to the City Council for the first time in twenty-four years.

"John Dewey," by the late Irwin Edman, will be published June 29 by Bobbs-Merrill as a volume in its Makers of American,Tradition Series. Mr. Edman, a distinguished philosopher in his own right, had been a pupil of Dewey's and was for many years a colleague of his.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) --Governors who favor President Eisenhower's $101,000,000,000 ten-year road-building program said tonight that it would pay for itself in lives saved and economic expansion.
WASHINGTON, May 3-- Turkey signed up with the United States today as the first qualified participant in President Eisenhower's global "atoms-for-peace" program.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)-- Harold E. Stassen said today that a Senate investigation had disclosed an "effort to play favoritism" in awarding a foreign aid contract. He has barred those involved from another chance to bid for the work.
WASHINGTON, May 3 --A city Democrat appealed in the House today for a "deal" between farm and city members to win high, rigid price supports for farmers and a higher minimum wage for labor.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Secretary of State Dulles talked with the British and Australian Ambassadors today as efforts to arrange a Formosa Strait ceasefire gained momentum.

Attendance has been good at the third semi-annual show of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers at the Roosevelt Hotel, but placement of orders has been spotty. The showing of fall lines opened Sunday and will end tonight.
ALGIERS, Algeria, May 3-- Brig. Gen. Gaston Parlange, who has been appointed to implement a "bold new policy", in the rebel-infested mountains of eastern Algeria is expected to arrive here tomorrow.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 3 (AP)--Two additional New England community development groups have taken title to former American Woolen Company mills, Textron American, Inc., announced here today.
WASHINGTON, May 3--The American Federation of Labor gave one of its unions more time today to purge an affiliate of communism or risk expulsion.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Senate and House conferees agreed today to defy White House veto warnings and call for $178,000,000 of annual pay increases to 500,000 postal workers.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 3-- Foreign Minister George Yeh repudiated tonight a report that he had told the legislature Nationalist China had agreed to a cease-fire provided the United States could get a cease-fire commitment from Communist China.
THE Metropolitan Museum is opening to the public today an impressive exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by Francisco Goya.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 2-- Nuclear detonations may now provide the armed services with opportunities for indoctrination and training, technical tests and weapons tests.
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 3 (UP)-- France exiled today a top leader of French settlers fighting home rule for Tunisia.

BONN, Germany, May 3--The Free Democratic party revolted tonight against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on the question of Germany's reunification. It refused to accept the Chancellor's uncompromising position and published its own detailed plan.

Seven of eight adjourned games in the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament at Buenos Aires were played yesterday. Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia, who was idle, retained his hold on first place, according to a report received through Argentine news sources. His score is 8-2.

Net sales and net income of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the first three months of this year declined 12 per cent and 4 per cent, respectively, from the levels in 1954. Robert E. Gross, president, reported the results yesterday at the annual meeting in Burbank, Calif.
WASHINGTON, May 3--The Senate put on an unexpected burst of speed today and adopted a debate-limiting agreement on the reciprocal trade bill that could bring final passage by tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)-- Mrs. Mildred Blauvelt, a former undercover agent for the New York Police Department, testified today that Brooklyn had a Communist population of about 6,000 in 1946.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court decided yesterday that all justices in Manhattan and the Bronx must observe a rule that prohibits the taking of photographs in courtrooms without the Higher tribunal's permission.

"Damn Yankees," a new musical based on the novel "The Year the Yankees Lost the Pennant,' by Douglass Wallop, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre at 7:45 o'clock.

LONDON, May 4 -- South African gold mining shares shone on the first day of the new trading account. Other sections remained quiet and uncertain, with British Government funds still failing. They lost a further 5 to 7 1/2 shillings (70 cents to $1.05).

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia was held to a draw yesterday by his countryman Dr. Petar Trifunovic in the eleventh round of the Argentina Chess Club's jubilee tournament at Buenos Aires, according to a news report from Argentina.

CAIRO, May 4 -- The National Bank of Egypt has agreed to advance the Government 100,000,000 sterling ($280,000,000) to buy equipment and machinery abroad to construct a high dam on the Nile above Aswan, it was announced today by Dr. Abdel Moneim el Kaissouny, Finance Minister.
LOUISVILLE, May 4 -- The outlook is for a maximum of ten starters, with Belair Stud's Nashua the 4-to-5 favorite, in Saturdays eighty-first Kentucky Derby:

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate passed the reciprocal trade bill tonight. It sent the measure to conference with the House after beating all but one attempt to impose restrictive amendments from the floor.

On the New York waterfront the Seamen's Church Institute for 120, has been host to men from all countries. For thousands of merchant seamen hailing from ships of all flags, 25 South Street is the familiar home-town address. However well-traveled, the seaman always needs a place to come back to.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, May 5 -- Four Chinese Nationalist propeller planes emerged unscathed from a two-minute fight with four Communist MIG-15 jets off the Fukien coast yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower said today the test of Chinese Communist intentions in an assault on the Quemoy or Matsu Islands would be the size of the military buildup on the mainland opposite Formosa.
PARIS, May 4 -- The Radical party approved today a demand by former Premier Pierre Mendes-France for re-evaluation of party policy.

LONG BEACH, L. I., May 4 -- An empty 230-gallon fuel tank came loose from the wing of a Republic Thunderstreak fighter-bomber here this morning and plummeted 12,000 feet into an empty lot, missing a house by fifteen feet.
Buying at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America has been more active than at any time since the rush buying during World War II, exhibitors reported yesterday.
SOCORRO, N. M., May 4 -- Arid lands experts from eighteen countries, "refreshed by spiritual rainfall," projected new lines of research and closer collaboration among the world's scientists today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., attorney general, said today the nation was "taking an unwarranted risk" of dangerous riots in overcrowded Federal prisons.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 4 -- Nassau County's shortest and most harmonious school election was held here yesterday in School District 7. There was no contest because only three persons were eligible to vote and three offices were up for election -- trustee, treasurer and clerk of the board.

OSWEGO, N. Y., May 4 -- This city began today its campaign to become "the port of central New York" by holding a conference attended by 300 persons from key locations in this country and Canada. The movement is tied in with the St. Lawrence Seaway, being built under the joint sponsorship of the United States and Canada.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A conference of Democratic Governors today charged the Eisenhower Administration with complacency toward economic distress.
ATLANTA, May 4 (UP) -- Violence continued today in both the Louisville Nashville Railroad strike and the strike by communications workers in nine states served by the Southern Bell Telephone System.

Your editorial approving the establishment of a Manhattan "Free Trade Zone" was most timely. It can, of course, be operated in conjunction with the projected World Trade Mart as proposed by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which emphasizes the value of this important facility to the Port of New York.
BONN, Germany, May 4 -- The French-German agreement on the Saar was ruled constitutional today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- These were the main points made by President Eisenhower at his news conference today:

GENEVA, May 4 (AP) -- The twenty-six-nation Inter-Governmental Committee for European Migration unanimously approved today a $45,625,000 budget for moving more than 142,000 Europeans to new homes overseas during the current year.

HARTFORD, May 4 -- Rossini wrote something like forty operas, but there's seldom an opportunity to see and hear more than a handful. How many years is it since New York, for example, has encountered any Rossini opera other than "The Barber of Seville" and "Cenerentola"?

Sales volume of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company for the first quarter of 1955 "ran just slightly ahead" of billings of $123,617,280 reported for the first three months of 1954, Robert S. Stevenson, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Milwaukee.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4 (AP) -- Brazil today devalued its cotton export cruzeiro by 16 per cent. The move has the double effect of placing Brazilian cotton in a better competitive position in the world market and meeting demands of growers for more cruzeiros for their product.
Webster's New World Dictionary (1952) defines mix as, among other things, "a prepared blend of various ingredients."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

BERLIN, May 4 -- Key political and military leaders from the Communist world will assemble in East Berlin next week-end ostensibly to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Germany's liberation from the Nazis.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

Parents' sense of self-blame over what they ought to do for their handicapped children, or regret for what they have not done, is difficult to avoid. But such feelings may be destructive, according to Dr. Samuel M. Wishik.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 27, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Socialist party lost a second round yesterday in its effort to promote a school essay contest. The subject, would be "How Cooperative Enterprise Has Helped to Make America Great."

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 4 -- United States officials were said today to regard a constitutional monarchy as possibly the best system for South Vietnam at present in view of the inexperience of the Vietnamese with democratic institutions.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4 -- One person was killed and at least thirteen were injured when commuters battled policemen in the main railroad station here last night.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The American Federation of Labor Executive Council adopted unanimously today ethical standards for welfare funds, including recommendations for legislation.

NEW HAVEN, May 4 -- Merger of the First National Bank and Trust Company here with the Milford Trust Company of near-by Milford has been voted by the boards of both banks, it was disclosed today. The consolidation is subject to a vote of the stockholders, expected in about two weeks, and approval of banking authorities.

Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn Federal Court denied yesterday a motion by James J. Moran, former first deputy fire commissioner, for a change of venue for his income tax evasion trial. Moran pleaded not guilty on March 4 to an indictment charging him with cheating the Government out of $131,307 in taxes for a three-year period.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- The Philadelphia Marine Trade Association announced this afternoon that longshore work on foreign cargo ships would be resumed in this Delaware River port at 8 A. M. tomorrow.

Four members of a five-member panel that participated in the annual Finley lecture series last night at City College agreed that radio and television sponsors interfered little if at all with the news presented on their programs.
Joseph H. McConnell has resigned as president of the Colgate -Palmolive Company, manufacturer of soaps and toiletries. No successor has been named.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals refused today to block the $42,000,000 sale of the Waterman Steamship Company to the C. Lee Company pending a further ruling in the case.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Jean Model, New York business man and husband of Faith Rockefeller, was being flown from South America to New York tonight on a military "mercy mission" after being stricken with poliomyelitis.
The Army's participation in the long-delayed atomic test in Nevada is more important from the point of view of public relations than tactics.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- Market continued today the advance started yesterday. Trade activity broadened and buying interest swung into the May delivery, which moved up faster than the new-crop futures.

John B. Williamson, former national labor secretary of the Communist party, left here yesterday for his native Great Britain on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. As he departed he charged that he was being forced into political exile because of his working-class activities and ideas.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has named Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Salk, parents of Dr. Jonas E. Salk, as the "Jewish parents of the year."

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31, a consolidated net income of $21,207,935, or $1.68 each on the average number of 12,627,045 shares outstanding in that period, P. C. Spemcer, president, reported yesterday.
Two months of quiet scrutiny of meat deliveries to city institutions resulted yesterday in a four-pronged investigation of possible irregularities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Benedict Bogeaus, independent producer, will have his second try at filming "The Bridge of San Luis Rey." He first produced the Thornton Wilder novel of colonial Peru in 1944 for United Artists.

CLEVELAND, May 4 -- Fine relief pitching by Bob Grim and Tom Morgan checked the Cleveland Indians tonight. The Yankees, counting seven times in the last two innings, snapped two Tribe winning streaks with an 11-5 victory.

THE second performance in the season of "American Dance," sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation at the ANTA Theatre last night, found things once again ship- shape -- a good orchestra well conducted, a well-lit stage (it is not surprising to find the name of Jean Rosenthal on the program as production supervisor), and the various numbers beautifully rehearsed and beautifully performed.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey Said today that he planned a 250,000-man draft in the coming fiscal year, which starts July 1. The Defense Department estimates that less than half that number will be needed.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4 -- A Government official said today reports that Brazil was seeking a funding loan in the United States to cover her commercial debts were "completely untrue."

Some of the best customers of J. Partridge of London, Ltd., a New York dealer in antique buttons and jewelry, are men. They buy old cuff links and old buttons made into cuff links and some become avid cuff link collectors.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, well on their way to becoming the "nuisance kids" of the National League, defeated the Milwaukee Braves tonight, 5 -- 4, for their fourth consecutive victory.

The Northern States Power Company expects to earn about $1.12 a share this year on 13,418,408 shares, Allen S. King, president, told the annual meeting in Minneapolis yesterday. This would compare with $1.07 a share on some 1,200,000 fewer shares in 1954.

A meeting in memory of Judge Augustus Noble Hand of the United States Court of Appeals, who died last Oct. 28, was held jointly late yesterday afternoon by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and New York County Lawyers Association.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Gov. Robert F. Kennon of Louisiana said today that if Congress didn't approve the Administration's $101,000,000,000 road building program "we won't get anything."

The American Jewish Congress announced yesterday that its 1954 Stephen Wise Awards of $1,000 each would go to three prominent persons and Yale University. Formal presentation of the awards will be made later this year.
PARIS, May 4 -- The meetings of the foreign ministers of fifteen Western nations that will start in Paris Saturday will be unique if plans drawn up by the North Atlantic Council materialize.

NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- India warned Portugal today that a continuation of what was termed suppression of civil liberties and terrorization in Goa and other Portuguese settlements on India's west coast would lead to "serious repercussions."

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley is a traffic engineer, but he is clearly no politician. Two Brooklyn Councilmen, both Democrats, both lawyers, are displeased with Mr. Wiley. Councilman Thomas J. Mirabile, speaking also for his colleague, Morris J. Stein, says:
ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- The presence of a mysterious material that appears to lower the body's resistance to pain may play a major role in the genesis of some forms of headaches.

The Port of New York's great contribution to international commerce will be stressed in a series of ceremonies starting National Maritime Day, May 22, and continuing six days, which have been designated World Trade Week.

SURABAYA, Indonesia, May 4 -- Two Komodo dragons, lizards with great jaws that can cut a goat in half with a single snap, will be in the Bronx Zoo before the end of the month. Right now the strange beasts, each more than a hundred years old, are roaming rather petulantly in an area bounded by a moat and a fifteen-foot stone wall in this town on the eastern edge of Java.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that he had no personal assurance that John B. Hollister was in favor of the foreign aid program he was recently chosen to direct.

CHICAGO, May 4 (UP) -- Mickey Vernon smacked a three-run homer today to spark the Washington Senators to a 5-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox. Bob Porterfield gained the triumph by limiting the Sox to seven hits.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles and President Eisenhower still oppose a Big-Four meeting "at the summit" in advance of a foreign ministers conference.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 4 (AP) -- A United State Air Force flying tanker, carrying nine men, caught fire in the air and crashed today in the stormy Atlantic ocean.
At least one evening a week dad should lay aside the evening paper and mother should leave her dishwashing chores long enough to sit down for a bedtime "concert."
MANILA, Thursday, May 5 -- Both Houses of Congress approved revision of the Philippine Trade Act yesterday without significant opposition.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 4 -- The test atomic explosion scheduled for today was postponed again because of "unfavorable weather."

A week's "precautionary delay" in starting polio vaccinations for school children in New York City and upstate was ordered yesterday. The new target date will be May 16 as against a tentative start set for next Monday.
Forgotten money is the theme of insurance company advertisements now running in newspapers. They are paging the owners of unclaimed dividends, principal on matured policies and other equities.

The nation has entered an era of increasing prosperity, "the likes of which the world has not known in the last three or four centuries," Dr. Kevin C. McCann, Special Assistant to President Eisenhower, declared last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- A team of seventeen scientists has been named to help run the United Nations' "atoms-for-peace" conference in Geneva. The parley will open Aug. 8.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Federal Government stood ready to take over the entire Salk polio vaccine supply if necessary. The Pre sident told his press conference that "from the start" it had been determined that "there will never be a child in the United States denied this protection for want of ability to pay."
ROME, May 4 (UP) -- Art Larsen, absolved by the United States Lawn Tennis Association on charges that he hit a boy with a ball, advanced to the third round of the Rome international tournament today.
Two hundred and fifty members of Congress and their families will spend this week-end sightseeing in New York.
Two moves were made yesterday in an effort to assure uninterrupted production of the Salk polio vaccine by Parke, Davis Co. of Detroit.

That old friend of the interior decorator, wallpaper, has hidden virtues that are sometimes overlooked in the age of paint-it-yourself. Wallpaper can give a furnished appearance to a room quicker than any other decorating element, a point that might be remembered by those still accumulating furniture.

In The Times recently Stoyan Christowe, in taking issue with Charles Upson Clark, tries to throw Tito's propaganda cloak over the status of Macedonia. It is a sobering fact, however, that with the exception of a few dozen persons the rest of the one hundred thousand Macedonians on this continent definitely do not share Mr. Christowe's views about Tito's "democratic" way of governing the country.
MEXICO CITY, May 4 (AP) -- A shower of flaming chemical solvent from a plastics factory enveloped a bus today and burned six passengers to death instantly.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Pan American World Airways be authorized to provide nonstop service between New York and Ciudad Trujillo in the Dominican Republic.

Another victim of the kickback system at the Leonardo Naval Base told a Waterfront Commission hearing yesterday of losing his job when he refused to pay "assessments" that were being funneled to a union official.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower disclosed today that Mrs. Eisenhower had had "a very serious virus infection" in March. He said her recovery to full health had been delayed because she was allergic to antibiotics.

A decline of 2,982,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 176,759,000 barrels, compared with 179,741,000 a week earlier and 177,058,000 a year earlier.
The "stereotyped idea" that all southerners favor segregation has melted away, a correspondent for The New York Times reported yesterday.
Telford Taylor, lawyer, author, wartime brigadier general and both critic and target of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, undertook a new role yesterday -- that of musician.

After stock margins were increased from 50 per cent to 60 per cent security prices continued their rise. With the recent increase to 70 per cent they are again rising. If these margin increases were supposed to control the upward spiral, then when and if margins eventually, get to 100 per cent and values continue upward the controllers should, according to their own rules, stop all security trading.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4 (AP) -- A jury that offered "apologies to no one" broke a thirteen-hour deadlock today and acquitted Arch Ferrell, ousted prosecuting attorney, of the murder of the crime fighter who had sworn to clean up Phenix City, Ala.

The appointment of Prof. Dennis McNeice Healy as acting dean of the College of Arts and Science of Long Island University, was announced yesterday by Admiral Richard L. Conolly, retired, president of the university.
A car with a dead man at the wheel killed two schoolboys and critically injured a third youth yesterday when it crashed into a Queens theatre lobby.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Hsuan Wei, former Chinese Nationalist marine captain who has refused to return to Formosa, lost out today in the first step of his fight to gain political asylum in the United States. He has said he fears for his life if he is returned to the Nationalist-held island.

Eddie Arcaro returned to racing yesterday, thoroughly refreshed after an enforced absence of twenty days. The master jockey celebrated his reinstatement by winning the one-mile Acorn Stakes aboard the Wheatley Stable's High Voltage at Belmont Park.

THERE is plenty of activity on the salt water front, on both the New Jersey and Long Island shores. The returns include striped bass, flounders, pollock, and the first bluefish and weakfish reported this season.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Mrs. Mildred Blauvelt said today that a Communist leader in Brooklyn had bragged that Communists were behind the protest of some movie actors and directors against, the Congressional investigation of "The Hollywood Ten" in 1947.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Field Marshal Pibul Songgram, Premier of Thailand, told Congress today that "my country will always be on your side."
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The bipartisan farm bloc's effort to restore high, rigid price supports got a serious setback in the House today.
The first of 7,000 panels that will form the exterior surface of this city's first stainless steel skyscraper was set in place yesterday.
To promote progress and peace, America must share her abundance to a greater extent with the rest of the world, a group of religious leaders declared yesterday.
The executives, staffs and facilities of Gotham Advertising Company and Irwin Vladimir Co., Inc., will be consolidated on July 1 to form Gotham-Vladimir Advertising, Inc.

NEW ORLEANS, May 4 (UP) -- The 30-month-old grandson of Dr. Alton Ochsner, New Orleans surgeon, died of bulbar polionyelitis today, eight days after being inoculated with Salk vaccine made by the Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 -- Adnan Menderes, Turkish Premier and Foreign Minister, arrived here this evening on a six-day official visit.

Lady Dhanvanti Rama Rau of India yesterday described her country's 100-village experiment in birth control methods. She spoke as the annual meeting of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America opened at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
PARIS, May 1 -- Western European farmers are getting a lot more out of the land, but the non-farm population is not getting any cheaper food.

A former Army lieutenant and his civilian assistant pleaded guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to conspiring to defraud the Government by submitting false vouchers. They were specifically accused of receiving $3,400 as a 10 per cent kick-back on contracts for printing military manuals.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 4 (Reuters) -- Gen. Nguyen Van Vy, who fled from Saigon Sunday after failing in an attempt to seize control in South Vietnam, has arrived in Bangkok, Thailand, on his way to France, according to the Government news agency, Vietnam Presse.

Norris R. Crump, 51, was elected president of the Canadian Pacific Railroad yesterday, succeeding W. A. Mather, who was named chairman. Mr. Mather was elevated following the retirement of G. A. Walker as chairman. Mr. Walker continues as a director.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday discussed with 400 New York bankers and the city's top police officials new ways of thwarting bank hold-ups.

Three five-story apartment houses at 1424-36 Crotona Park East in the Bronx have been sold by Darb Realty Corporation to Berlac Realty Corporation through Stanley Russell Associates, brokers. The buildings contain sixty apartments and are assessed at $148,000.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 4 -- Premier Adnan Menderes, left today on a political reconnaissance mission to Yugoslavia. He will confer with President Tito on Belgrade's future political course and seek to dispel doubts that have recently clouded the Turks' confidence in the Balkan alliance.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The teacher shortage still is desperate, the National Education Association said today.

TO aid the La Napoule Art Foundation - Henry Clews Memorial in its services toward closer cultural relations between the United States and France an exhibition of paintings by ten leading French and as many American artists opens today at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Wellington Powell, a vice president of the New York Telephone Company, said today 510 telephones in New York City were tapped in 1952 by order of the police or district attorneys.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- Main Co., a Pittsburgh auditing concern, today said A. M. Byers Company, the world's biggest producer of wrought iron, was "fully justified" in lending $550,000 to the Midland Coke Company in 1951.
Not one Hollywood or foreign film appraised by the New York State censors was banned in its entirety during the year ended March 31.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 4 -- The 300 members of Princeton University's Army R. O. T. C. battalion put on an impressive military show today for Thomas E. Dewey, former Governor of New York, and Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
Six bomb threats kept the police on the move for more than eight hours yesterday afternoon and last night. All were false alarms.

Coffee prices opened steady yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange but before the close several positions fell the 2-cents-a-pound limit for the day. The distant options were weakest. Final quotations were off 95 to 200 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 64,250 bags.

The Corsi case, which has reflected anything but credit on the State Department, may yet prove useful if it provokes the Administration and Congress into trying genuinely to improve the operation of the Refugee Relief Act.

LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., which opened a $60,000,000 newsprint mill in Tennessee last July, disclosed plans today for a multimillion-dollar expansion on two continents.
When a twin-engined plane splashed down in a forced landing in Jamaica Bay yesterday at 7:38 A.M. the sole occupant escaped serious injury.

LONDON, May 4 -- Nearly 3,000 London buses, half the total, were off the streets this morning as 14,400 busmen struck in a dispute over schedules. But the strike quickly petered out when union leaders refused to sanction it.

LOUISVILLE, May 4 -- The dew still hung heavily on the grass in the barn area at Churchill Downs but the sun already had begun to fight its way through the refreshingly gentle morning air. Both Nashua and Summer Tan, the two big horses for Saturday's Kentucky Derby, had completed their setting-up exercises.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which on Monday took title to the blockfront on the west side of Fifth Avenue from Fifty-second to Fifty-third Streets, has added 15 West Fifty-second Street, a vacant lot 15 by 100 feet, to the holding.

When the Senate voted last August for the abandonment of high, rigid price supports for the so-called "basic" commodities it marked the culmination of one of the most courageous and politically difficult legislative battles in which the Eisenhower Administration has engaged.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- None of those Democrats who are popularly credited with an ambition and/or a chance to become their party's Presidential candidate next year has joined former National Chairman Stephen A. Mitchell as yet in his proposed purge of the 1956 convention.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower declined today to join a Republican National Committee attack upon Governor Averell Harriman of New York as the "real architect" of the Yalta agreements.
An airline executive yesterday termed the Civil Aeronautics Board's decision Monday to permit three all-cargo carriers to take first-class mail "the end of a monopoly on the mail service."
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 4 (AP) -- The United States team of international one-design yachts won the fourth race of the series with Bermuda today for the Amorita Cup.
"BEGIN with an individual," Scott Fitzgerald said, "and before you know it you find that you have created a type; begin with a type -- and you find that you have created -- nothing."

Some of yesterday's news could have been used as the theme for a song called "Onward and upward with the rails." But there was a rift in the lute in the form of a report of a huge grain traffic on the Mississippi in the barges of American Waterways Operators, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Following is the unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation throughout.
Two days of suburban-county balloting to elect school board members, vote on budgets and decide special propositions ended last night.

Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 7 points higher to 3 points lower than Tuesday except in the old May contract. That delivery was 28 points ($1.40 a bale) higher than Tuesday.
HARTFORD, May 4 -- Increased state education aid to towns advanced in the Connecticut General Assembly today.
The regional Red Cross blood program cut a birthday cake yesterday to mark its seventh anniversary. The ceremony was held at the New York chapter, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.
A German automotive company world famous for its high- powered racing cars announced yesterday that it would soon establish a branch in this country -- to make trucks.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Interrupted Melody," a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer musical drama in CinemaScope and color with Eleanor Parker and Glenn Ford, is at the Radio City Music Hall. Jack Cummings produced and Curtis Bernhardt directed, from a screen play by William Ludwig and Sonya Levien.
DETROIT, May 4 (UP) -- Harry Agganis raced home on Ted Lepcio's infield grounder in the top of the eleventh inning tonight to give the Boston Red Sox a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
KANSAS CITY, May 4 (UP) -- Kansas City posted a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today. The game marked Vic Raschi's first start for the A's.

The Washington Township-Marion County, Ind., School Building Corporation received bids yesterday on $6,600,000 of first mortgage bonds. A syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., submitted the best bid, 100.0463 for obligations bearing interest of 4 per cent and 3 per cent, an interest cost of 3.017 per cent.

It can be argued that the time to take a vacation is not in winter, when skiing presents a threat to bone and sinew, or in midsummer when acute sunburn and poison ivy await the unwary, but in the early spring.

BOISE, Idaho, May 4 (UP) -- Three public health experts said today their research strongly indicated that some of the anti-polio vaccine used for the mass inoculation program in Idaho could be a contributing cause of ten recent cases in Idaho.
Leading medical experts said yesterday that available scientific evidence did not support President Eisenhower's concern over possible provocative reactions from use of the Salk anti-polio vaccine.
The New York metropolitan area accounted for nearly half of the strikes that began in 1954 in the Middle Atlantic states, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

Harvey M. Matusow has been ousted as a member of the New York Young Republican Club. The board of governors decided by unanimous vote that his conduct was "inimical to the best interests of the club."
PARIS, May 4 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of South Vietnam, expressed his intention today to maintain his position.

I was shocked by Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley's criticism of President Eisenhower's correspondence with Marshal Zhukov, and his recommendation of preventive war against the Communist world. "You don't sit down with murderers and discuss business," he said.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (UP) -- The California Medical Association tonight condemned "contrived publicity" surrounding the knck off of the Salk polio vaccine program.

LONDON, May 4 -- The British Government plans to propose soon a conference of the heads of government of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Harold Macmillan, new Foreign Secretary, will put the Cabinet's proposal for a brief, general parley at the summit before Secretary of State Dulles and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, Sunday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Personal income rose to an annual rate of $294,000,000,000 in March, nearly $2,000,000,000 higher than the February level and $9,000,000,000 more than March a year ago, the Government reported today.
Reference is made to the letter titled "Traffic Signs Queried" which appeared in The Times of April 29.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower declared anew today his enthusiastic support of a compulsory military Reserve training plan.

LONDON, May 4 (Reuters) -- World soap and fat markets continued to boom last year, according to the annual report of the giant Unilever organization. It told shareholders today that sales and profits last year soared to a record high.
A fireman who had left the Police Department to join the Fire Department less than two years ago died last night from smoke poisoning and exhaustion suffered at a lower East Side blaze.

SAN SALVADOR, May 4 -- Central America must consolidate and coordinate its cultural, social and economic reserves, President Oscar Osorio of El Salvador said today. He addressed the delegates to the conference of the Committee for Economic Integration of Central America.

One physician was suspended for three months from membership in the Kings County Medical Society yesterday over a polio injection case. Three others were reprimanded by the Medical Society of the County of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower kept Congress guessing today whether he would veto the controversial pay increase bill for 500,000 postal workers.
Ruben Gomez, the Giants' Puerto Rican hurler who has been insisting he can pitch only in warm weather, finally got around to proving his point yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Retail interests waged a futile battle today to prevent the Chamber of Commerce of the United States from endorsing a national sales tax.

DETROIT, May 4 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, staggered in the first round, recovered and was in complete command the rest of the way tonight in gaining a unanimous ten-round decision over Garth Panter of Salt Lake City.
Isaac B. Grainger, executive vice president of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank of New York, was elected yesterday as chairman of the reorganization managers of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

After a long and hard fight against the new upsurge of economic nationalism known in this country as protectionism, the Senate has completed action on the bill, already passed by the House, extending the twenty-one-year-old Reciprocal Trade Act for another three years, thus empowering the President to cut tariff rates by 15 per cent in return for similar concessions by other nations.

Mayor Wagner has taken the crusade against New York's litter and dirt a long stride forward in the appointment of Keith S. McHugh, president of the New York Telephone Company, to head an outstanding "Citizens Committee to Keep New York Clean," and Mr. McHugh deserves the enthusiastic appreciation of the public for accepting.
Corporate insurance managers were advised yesterday to "know exactly what you want in the way of coverage before you set out to buy insurance."
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 3 -- The current slogan of Bolivia's revolutionary Government is "results, not words." In the case of petroleum it is living up to its slogan.
TOKYO, May 4 -- A group of Japanese private business men signed a $168,000,000 trade agreement today with official representatives of Communist China.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 4 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America today called upon Congress to enact promptly legislation granting Federal funds for public schools.
An official of the Consolidated Edison Company predicted yesterday that the cost of nuclear fuels eventually might become cheaper than that of conventional ones.
A device like a vacuum cleaner has indicated that New York's air is far purer than many experts thought.

Irvington House, which cares for children with rheumatic fever, will benefit from the May 24 performance of "Damn Yankees" at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, and a supper dance after the theatre at the St. Regis Roof.
City College reversed an early-season defeat by downing New York University, 8 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Babe Ruth Stadium, the Bronx, yesterday.

CHAPEL HILL, S. C., May 4 -- Mayor Wagner of New York declared here tonight that his Police Commissioner, Francis W. H. Adams, had "succeeded in removing the taint of political influence" from New York's Police Department.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 4 -- The only college in South Africa exclusively for Negro students closed indefinitely today.

Robert R. Young, chairman, and Allan P. Kirby, president of the Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company, were charged yesterday with "conducting the corporation's affairs primarily in the interest of themselves and a small group of insiders."

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has resold the taxpayer building at 893 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. The property was acquired by a customer of Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers in the transaction. It is assessed at $110,000 and was sold for cash above a first mortgage of $65,000. The building, near Church Avenue, is occupied by Nedick's. E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the seller.

The threatened sale and demolition of Carnegie Hall presents a challenge to the music lovers and to the civic-minded people of the City of New York. It is almost unthinkable that a way cannot be found to save this distinguished and historic building.

LONDON, May 4 -- The Duke of Edinburgh gave newspaper men a few pointers tonight on how to do a better job of reporting about Britain's Royal Family. "I fully appreciate the problems which arise under the heading 'the Royal Family and the press,'" he remarked jovially. "Some will be solved in time, while others will always remain a headache."

The Giants retain the distinction of being the only team to have beaten the Dodgers. The Cardinals stepped into the ring against the slugging Brooks at Ebbets Field last night and met the same fate as the Phillies, Pirates, Redlegs, Cubs and Braves.

Among the numerous bills signed into law recently by Governor Harriman there was one in particular which we feel deserves approving comment. The Governor's signature now gives parents the opportunity to exercise considerably more authority over the driving habits of their children holding junior operator's licenses.
The Maternity Center Association will be the beneficiary of the sixth annual Belmont Ball to be held on the night of June 10 at the Turf and Field Club, Belmont Park.
Trans World Airlines had a net loss of $3,898,000 in the first quarter of 1955, compared with a deficit of $3,965,000 in the similar period of 1955.

The Thomas More Association medal for "the most distinguished contribution to Catholic publishing" has been awarded to Doubleday Co. for its series of paper - bound reprint Image Books. The presentation was made yesterday by Bishop Thomas L. Noa of Marquette, Mich., at the sixteenth anniversary celebration of the association in Chicago.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the New York Central Railroad Company, clarified for the company's stockholders yesterday the legal terminology of the proxy statement for the annual meeting in Albany on May 26.
VIENNA, May 4 -- The question of oil rights and a neutrality guarantee for Austria are about the only items that stand in the way of an Austrian state treaty.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., May 4 (AP) --"Ours is a time of spiritual vitality" due to a "general rediscovery of the great Protestant doctrine of the fellowship of all believers," Protestant leaders were told tonight.
Stocks dipped, recovered and closed almost unchanged in light trading yesterday. Volume was only 2,200,000 shares, the smallest since April 5, against 2,630,000 on Tuesday.
Stockholders of the Pittston Company were told at the annual meeting in Richmond, Va., yesterday, that the company had started a multi-million-dollar expansion program.
UP at the City Center, where they have just brought home a handsome winner called "Guys and Dolls," they now are betting on another sure thing, an entrant named "South Pacific."
Despite all the talk to the contrary, it is the "narrowly trained" specialist, not the liberal arts graduate, who is preferred by employers, according to a New York educator.
WASHINGTON, May 5--During the week ended yesterday member bank reserves increased $469,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Forty-three persons were indicted yesterday as members of an alleged automobile accident ring. They are charged with having defrauded insurance companies of at least $100,000 by false claims. A New York County grand jury returned thirty-two true bills against the defendants, who include three women.
Minneapolis Honeywell Regulator Company plans to sell $16,000,000 of new convertible preferred stock through a public offering to be managed by Union Securities Corporation as principal underwriter.
To correct errors in the dates of items in Children's Entertainment as published yesterday, the listings are repeated today.
LONDON, May 5--The Liberal party opened its electoral campaign here today with a manifesto aimed at winning the middle class "floating" vote away from the Conservative and Labor parties.
All that the Giants apparently needed this spring was a good thawing out.
A religious quota system for selecting probation officers for Children's Courts was disapproved unanimously yesterday by the New York State Probation Commission.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the first project in the Traffic Department's six-year plan to construct $94,000,000 worth of public parking lots and garages designed to relieve traffic congestion.

The Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation is faced with the problem of finding profitable use for production facilities built for the construction of steam locomotives, George A, Rentschler, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Eddystone, Pa.
General plans for three federally aided public housing projects to provide apartments for 2,830 low-income families were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5-- The first studies ever made of the reactions of an infant's stomach to conditions, in its environment were presented here today at the annual meeting of the American Psychosomatic Society.

YESTERDAY (May 5, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Ended by formal order the occupation of Germany. Appointed William C. Kern of Indianapolis to the Federal Trade Commission and Frank A. Southard Jr. to serve another term as United States Executive Director of the International Monetary Fund.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The Senate today unanimously passed a bill to give all former Presidents a $22,500 annual pension, an office and a clerical staff. The House has not yet acted on the measure.
LONDON, May 5--The stock markets here were steadier, though still quiet, today.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., May 5--American Protestant leaders representing 30,000,000 churchgoers were told tonight that Christians had "not begun to face up" to their duty to support and to supplement foreign technical aid programs.

The National Broadcasting Company tentatively plans to integrate the Pinky Lee and "Howdy Doody" shows next season and present the one-hour program in color. It probably would be the first time a network had televised a children's program in color on a regular basis of five days a week.

Representative Charles A. Buckley urged the Liberal party to disband last night. If Liberals have any complaints about Democratic candidates or policies they should be fought out in the Democraic party, he said.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 5-- A Princeton University senior, who needs $75.75 to graduate, embarked on a 140-mile bicycle trip tonight in a race against "death and the university store bill."
Loans to business by major New York City banks in the week ended on Wednesday increased $27,000,000, the second weekly increase in a row, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The House of Representatives passed today the Democratic farm bill to scrap the Administration's program and restore high, rigid price supports. The vote was 206 to 201.
BONN, Germany, May 5--The Federal Republic of Germany became a sovereign state at noon today.

BONN, May 5 (UP)--Text of the West German Government's proclamation on its new independence: Today, almost ten years after the military and political collapse of National Socialism, the occupation period ends for the Federal Republic.

PARIS, May 4 (Reuters) -- Genevieve Fath, widow of the famed Paris fashion designer who died last November, established herself as a couturiere in her own right when she showed her midsummer models yesterday.
The wool textile industry is finally emerging from its three- year slump according to Harold J. Walter, new president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

AS shiny as a new baseball and almost as smooth, a new musical glorifying the national pastime slid into the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last night. As far as this umpire is concerned you can count it among the healthy clouts of the campaign.
The city's parents remain overwhelmingly ready to have their children inoculated with anti-polio vaccine, a Health Department survey indicated yesterday.

Yesterday was the hottest May 5 in the city's recorded weather history. In some sections, it was also the wettest and the windiest. In other parts of the metropolitan area, hail as large as marbles fell and dust storms blanketed villages.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 5 -- President Eisenhower was praised today by the Rabbinical Assembly of America for his efforts to solve world tensions by peaceful means.
ROME, May 5 (UP) -- Budge Patty, the defending champion, gained the men's singles quarter- finals today in Rome's tennis tournament by defeating George Worthington of Australia, 6--1, 6--2, 6--3.
CLEVELAND, May 5--The Air Force's new $40,000,000 heavy press plant was dedicated here today and presses started to punch out wing spars for jet aircraft.
Copper Range Company is offering its stockholders rights to subscribe to 282,464 new shares of capital stock at $35 a share at the rate of one new share for each five shares held.
Ham and eggs, the timeless team, provide headlines in market news this week-end. Both sell at prices that benefit budgets, the City Department of Markets reports.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 5 --The Pakistani Government officially informed Afghanistan tonight that it would break relations between them unless there was restitution and apology for attacks. This action was an
BONN, Germany, May 5--The West German state that won its sovereignty today was the product of the East-West struggle that fololwed World War II.
WASHINGTON, May 5--Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, pledged his opposition today to any 1956 convention battle over seating Southerners who bolted the party's ticket in 1952.
The Transit Authority unveiled yesterday a model of a push-button "electronic wayfinder" for the subways.
A reception and dinner will be given for Vincent Auriol, former President of France and now honorary president of the World Veterans Federation, on May 18 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
CHICAGO, May 5 (UP)--A special committee of the American Medical Association proposed today that a yardstick for evaluating medical services be established to help curb fee- splitting.

LOUISVILLE, May 5--If Nashua wins the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, this reporter will feel obligated to send his sports jacket to the National Museum of Racing at Saratoga. Nashua left his teeth marks on one sleeve this morning. It just goes to show what can happen when a guy tries to get his information out of a horse's mouth.

Ancestor, the competent jumper owner by Mrs. Ogden Phipps, made a closing bid to win the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, carrying a gross value of $9,150, was the first jumping stakes of the local season.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., May 5-- The men of Armored Task Force Razor rode out a terrific atomic explosion at close range this morning. Then they demonstrated how to fight with atomic weapons.

WASHINGTON, May 5--"If the Democratic party is realistic enough to look for converts it should be realistic and sensible enough to welcome penitents," said National Chairman Butler today after a conciliatory talk with Governor Shivers of Texas, one of the convention bolters of 1952.
SURVIVAL CITY, Nev., May 5 (AP)--Although badly battered and burned, this civil defense test community stood up surprisingly well against the wallop of a big atomic blast early today.
Port Newark will become an integral part of the New York customs port of entry on May 15, it was announced yesterday by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The House Appropriations Committee approved today the Administration's plan to cut down the armed forces, but with reservations.

LOUISVILLE, May 5 -- The Churchill Downs racing strip paked in the sunshine today. If the baking process continues-- and the weather forecast indicates that it will--there should began extremely frisky running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.
The New York Central Railroad Company reported yesterday net income of $4,523,646 for April, compared with $503,682 for the same month last year.

Cottage by the Lake It is along about now that the cottage by the lake must be visited for the first time this year. There is a compulsion about it. During the summer the cottage gives such pleasure that to dream of it brings the season closer by a degree; therefore to visit it would draw summer right next door.
TROUT fishermen who are limited to week-end angling have been regarding the pleasant weather of this week with scowls, convinced that it cannot possibly carry over until dusk on Sunday.

A century-old dream, stirs, however vaguely, at the meeting of the Committee for Economic Integration of Central America, held this week at San Salvador. This is the union of the five states of Salvador, Honduras, Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Guatemala, briefly joined after the revolts against Spain in 1821.
The groundwork was laid yesterday for the possible disolution or reorganization of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee.

THERE are 21,000 men and women in the Police Department of New York City. Several years ago a few of them accepted bribes from Harry Gross, the bookmaker. Last year a few others were exposed in a courtesy card racket that enabled motorists to violate traffic regulations with impunity. The reputation of the police force was badly damaged.

PSYCHIATRY apparently is going to be a new television vogue. On Monday evening Steve Allen auditioned a possible series on the subject and other shows are in preparation. Coming after "March of Medicine" and "Medic," which look after a viewer's medical ills, these new programs should remove the last need for Blue Cross membership.

Joint Property Owners, Inc., has bought for investment the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy- six families on plot 105 by 162 feet at 235-43 West Seventy- sixth Street. There are seven stores in the property, which is assessed at $1,027,000.

The congregation of the Riverside Church unanimously approved by standing vote last night the "immediate" construction of a six or seven story parish house adjacent to the south side of the church tower.

In an investment purchase near Rockefeller Center, the properties at 111 West Fifty-first Street, 113-23 West, Fifty-first Street, 133 West Fifty-first Street and 112-18 Fifty-second Street have been purchased by the WJG Realty Corporation from the families of Harold Copper and Sol Holstein.
A $1,000,000 libel suit against the former owner-publisher of The Daily Worker was settled yesterday in Federal court for $5,000. The settlement also called for printed retractiins.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., May 5-- A nuclear explosion nearly twice as powerful as the atomic bombs dropped on Japan was detonated at dawn today.
For the first time on record a convertiplane has performed the tricky transformation that is the special talent of this breed of aircraft.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The American Federation of Labor wants a Federal disclosure law to curb abuses in the handling of union welfare funds.

Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the Transit Authority held firm yesterday against union demands for a wage increase of 17 cents an hour for transit workers. He reiterated that the authority would not go beyond 5.3 cents, and that figure was contingent on employe cooperation in effecting economies.

BONN, Germany, May 5-- Foreigners in Bonn remarked today the lack of public interest in the achievement of West German sovereignty. They asked themselves how it was possible for the people to seem so apathetic.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he had recently "intensified" his contacts with Communist China on the release of United Nations prisoners.
Longshore work at the Leonardo Naval Base came under "racketeer control" soon after Gus (Dolly) Wreiole was named hiring boss at the Earle (N. J.) Navy Depot, it was testified yesterday.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that there were "financial and ethical limits" to the extent to which public funds should support volunteer organizations, such as universities, social agencies, hospitals and museums.
None of the 5,000 pounds of meat impounded on Monday at the city penitentiary on Rikers Island bore proper Federal acceptance and city approval stamps, it was learned last night.
There are many confusing elements in the situation in Vietnam. Let us try to get the fundamentals into perspective.
WASHINGTON, May 5--John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that "small but perhaps significant signs" suggest more peaceable attitudes by Communist powers.
The Army's Engineer Corps faces the most serious personnel problem in its 180-year history, Maj. Gen. B. L. Robinson told the Society of American Military Engineers yesterday.

The Fulton's next tenant will be Arthur Miller's "A View From the Bridge," a brace of plays ("A Memory of Two Mondays" and "From Under the Sea"). Not until Sept. 29 will Kermit Bloomgarden and Robert Whitehead deposit the dual bill there.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- The Controller of the Currency took a neutral position today in the current controversy over the increase in bank mergers throughout the nation.

FORT WORTH, May 5 (AP)-- Chandler Harper shot a one- under-par 69 despite a two-stroke penalty on a lost ball and snared the first-round lead in the $25,000 Colonial National Invitation golf tournament today.

The casualty insurance industry stands ready to insure private users of non-fissionable nuclear materials, according to Joseph H. Forest, vice president of Liberty Mutual Insurance Company. These include the radioactive isotopes gaining wide usage in industry.

Commodity prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. This was the first trading day in two weeks that no commodity moved the daily limit. Sugar, cocoa, wool and silk were mixed; coffee, cottonseed oil and soybeans eased, and potatoes, copper, zinc, rubber and hides rose.

Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in the first three months of this year had a consolidated net income of $34,950,826, or $1.08 a share, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, chairman, told stockholders at their meeting yesterday in Chicago.

NOT only were there tour first New York performances on last night's program of the Columbia University Orchestra, but there were additional points of interest. The C. P. E. Bach Double Concerto used a harpsichord and a Clementi piano that probably was built around 1800.

DETROIT, May 5 (AP)--Al Kaline tripled to right center field with two out in the ninth inning today, scoring Fred Hatfield from first to give the Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox. Detroit moved into a tie with the Cleveland Indians, who were idle, for first place in the American League.
MARTHA GRAHAM and her company had the program to themselves last night in the season of "American Dance" being presented by the B. de Rothschild Foudation at the ANTA Theatre.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP)--A Circuit Court judgment of $1,598,315 was returned against a subsidiary of the H. K. Porter Company of Pittsburgh today in connection with Porter's purchase two years ago of the A. Leschen Sons Wire Rope Company of St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, May 5--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 7 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 5--Two national political congresses backed Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and denounced Chief of State Bao Dai today. One demanded the outright dismissal of Bao Dai and the establishment of a republic.
BONN, Germany, May 5-- Sovereign West Germany is awaiting with interest the next Soviet moves in Germany.
YESTERDAY (May 5, 1955) ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Narcotic Drugs--Took number of decisions on procedural matters.
Precautions that should be taken to eliminate poison hazards in the home, as well as simple antidotes, are the subjects discussed in a recent bulletin of the Greater New York Safety Council

WESTBURY, L. I., May 5 (AP) --J. M. H., a 6-year-old brown gelding owned by Edmund Harrington of Felton, Del., and driven by Bob Camper, won the Franklin Square Pace in 2:03 4/5 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

This is a week of intensive and extensive celebration in Australia. It is the annual commemoration of the Battle of the Coral Sea, which culminated on May 8, 1942, with the defeat of the threatening Japanese naval force. To Australians, therefore, it is the memorial to a great deliverance.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 5-- Ezra Taft Benson assailed the action of the House of Representatives to restore rigid price supports tonight as "a step backward" for American agriculture.
Boris Ivkov, Yugoslav master defeated Roman Toran of Spain yesterday in a twelfth-round match in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires, according to a report from Argentina.

A NOTABLE bequest to the New YorK Historical Society goes on view today at the society's museum, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street. This is the Waldron Phoenix Belknap Jr. collection of portraits and silver.
A CURIOUS turn in the evolution cycle has compelled man to bring hundreds of thousands of his "ancestors" out of jungles in India and the Philippines to help fight the polio plague.

MONTAUK, L. I., May 5-- Turn a man loose in the rolling green fields east of town here, without telling him where he is, and chances are he'd never guess. Might say he was in Scotland, on the moors--lots of folks say Scotland's just like Montauk.
The writer of the following letter, a teacher of Social Studies, was formerly a social worker and supervisor at Educational Alliance.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP)-- President Eisenhower's proposed atomic-powered merchant ship met unexpected opposition today when Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of upstate New York, branded it "a waste of money."
PARIS, May 5--It was only at the last moment that France decided today to complete ratification of the Paris accords providing for West Germany's sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, May 5--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 730,137 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 24,289 cars or 3.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 82,212 cars or 12.7 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 51,362 cars or 6.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
BERLIN, May 5--Paralleling the granting of sovereignty to West Germany, Allied, commandants in West Berlin eased their control today over the administration of the city.
The United States Walker Cup team of amateur golfers sailed yesterday for an international match in Scotland.

Don Newcombe, 28-year-old right-handed pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, yesterday was suspended indefinitely for insubordination. For the second time within a week Newcombe had refused to pitch batting practice.
The integration into the Western European Union of the German Federal Republic was hailed by former Governor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday as "probably the greatest effort for peace ever made."

BOSTON, May 5--What if a steward failed to recognize Casey Stengel today and for a moment refused to admit the Yankees' manager to the private dining car on the train that carried the Bombers from Cleveland to the Hub? Casey was in a forgiving mood.

THE Cantata Singers are as modest as they are scrupulous in their scholarship. They performed the complete set of Bach's six Motets at their spring concert at St. Michael's Church last night, and though they felt pretty certain that this was the first such performance in America, they were careful to say only that they believed it was a first.
The average American housewife probably doesn't know it, but events in Brazil are about to affect her food budget.
Prices of cotton futures yesterday closed barely steady, 3 to 14 points (15 to 70 cents a bale) below Friday's final levels. The far months showed the greatest weakness.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The Public Health Service sought today to find out if further safeguards could be developed in the making and testing of Salk polio vaccine.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head: market slow early, later moderately active: steady to 25 cents lower on butchers: most decline on weights under 230 pounds: sows steady to
SAN FRANCISCO, May 5-- Snarled comunications involving thirteen United States B-47 bombers and the Royal Canadian Air Force set off a "yellow" air raid alert over a wide area of the West today.

The forest products division of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation has drawn a bead on the $300,000,000-a-year market for treated lumber for new homes. The company's product, "Wolmanized" lumber, is lumber that has been pressure-impregnated with "Wolman" preservative salts and chemicals to make it termite-proof, rot-proof, leach- resistant, fungi-proof and fire- resistant.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)-- The criminal contempt conviction of Harold I. Cammer, New York attorney who sent a questionnaire to members of a Federal grand jury, was affirmed today by the Federal Court of Appeals.

Stock prices moved irregularly higher yesterday in continued light trading. Much of the interest shown during the session was concentrated on selected steel, motor, chemical, copper and television issues. Aircrafts, recently speculative favorites, were in supply.

In "America's Needs and Resources: A New Survey" the Twentieth Century Fund has again taken a full-length, as well as a minute, statistical measurement of the American economy, and has projected past trends into estimates of what is to come.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Since the end of World War II, the United States has become a party to eighteen major treaties designed to restore peace and to strengthen the free world against aggression.
Ambassadors from five British Commonwealth nations to the United States joined last night in praising the Colombo Plan as an example of successful international cooperation.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The State Department confirmed today the Administration's position that a conference of the Big Four foreign ministers should precede any parley "at the summit."
WASHINGTON, May 5--President Eisenhower, who accepted Nazi Germany's unconditional surrender ten years ago this week, ended the United States occupation today by signing a Presidential order.

The eyes of the copper world are on Northern Rhodesia. Roan Antelope and the Mufulira, big mines that supply a third of Britain's copper requirements, are expected to set a "fixed price" at which they will sell the metal for thirty days.
The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday that it earned more money in the first quarter than it did all last year.
DETROIT, May 5--A Michigan state mediator expressed confidence today that there would be an early settlement of a labor dispute involving one of the major manufacturers of the Salk vaccine.
TRENTON, May 5--The Republican and Democratic parties in New Jersey released here today the tentative drafts of their 1955 platforms.
