The Dodgers had two men thrown out at the plate at Ebbets Field yesterday but still overcame these and numerous other obstacles.
VIENNA, May 5--The Ambassadors drafting a state treaty for Austria vainly sought agreement today over claims of the former Western owners of Austrian oil- fields for restitution.
SAN SALVADOR, May 5 -- The establishment of a paper industry under the direction and control of five Central American republics was agreed to in principle today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5-- Paramount and Michael Curtiz, director-producer of "The Kiss Off," have decided to go the limit in casting new, young players in the romantic suspense melodrama.

Two books, picture and text records of communism and democracy at work, will be published July 11 by Dutton. One is "What Is Communism?" It includes information "never before made public and much more that has never appeared in book form."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In so far as the Asian-African conference at Bandung has affirmed its adherence to the principles of the United Nations Charter, free peoples everywhere will welcome two results of this historic meeting.

Additional storage of surplus grain in cargo ships of the National Reserve Fleet was forecast here yesterday with an application by the United States Maritime Administration to enlarge the fleet's Jones Point, N. Y., anchorage.

CHICAGO, May 5--A stockholders' group asked today for proxies from other Chicago and North Western Railway Company stockholders to elect Morton Weinress, Chicago investment man, as a director. The road's annual meeting will be held here on May 17.

The Peck Advertising Agency, which has joined forces with Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., under the Peck name, announced yesterday that twelve additional key executives and others have joined the agency's staff. Sidney Garfield, former president of Hirshon- Garfield, becomes chairman of the executive committee, as noted.
The city was warned yesterday that "thousands of individuals and families" would he displaced by its proposed multiple dwelling law.

A market so vast as to be "quite literally an invitation to fantasy" lies in the twenty republics to the south, Dr. Carlos Davila, secretary general of the Organization of American States, declared yesterday.
GENEVA, May 6 -- West Europe's energy resources may be the key to whether its economy is to turn the present boom into a steady upward movement of industrial production and living standards.
The Carborundum Metals Company announced yesterday that it had reduced prices of zirconium by as much as 40 per cent.
THE PRESIDENT Conferred with top military and foreign affairs officials.
TAIPEI, May 6 -- Foreign correspondents here protested today to the Nationalist Government and the United States Ambassador against "a condition of effective de facto censorship."
It took Maj. Gen. David H. Baker of the Air Force twenty-five years to earn five rows of service ribbons and decorations. Yesterday he added another award--a high school Arista Society pin.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Federal Republic of Germany joined the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at 2:30 P. M. today.

FORT WORTH, May 6 (UP)-- Chandler Harper equalled three tournament records with a fiveunder-par 31, 34--65 today to pull seven strokes ahead of the field at the halfway mark of the Colonial national Invitation golf tournament.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 6 (AP)--Montgomery Ward Co. today asked the Illinois Supreme Court to reconsider its decision requiring it to elect all nine directors each year.

WASHINGTON, May 6--The United States strongly reaffirmed today its support of Ngo Dinh Diem as Premier of South Vietnam. At the same time the State Department in effect disavowed any intention of trying to save Bao Dai's position as Chief of State.
Mayor Wagner accepted an invitation from Ireland and issued two proclamations in carrying out the duties of his office yesterday.
MACASSAR, Indonesia, May 6--The airport of this city on the southwestern tip of the island of Celebes is bristling with weapons.
American railroads were urged yesterday to cooperate with Atlantic passenger steamship companies in promoting surface travel in their mutual interest.

BUENOS AIRES, May 6 (AP) --Police arrested at least forty persons parading through downtown Buenos Aires tonight in a demonstration of loyalty to the Roman Catholic Church. Churchstate ties are being attacked by President Juan Peron's Government.

LOS ANGELES, May 6--In a surprise announcement today George C. Hoover, International Chief Barker of the Variety Clubs, revealed that Sir Winston Churchill had been selected for the organization's annual Humanitarian Award for 1954.

The atomic bomb that was finally detonated at Yucca Flat, Nev., after repeated postponements lived up to expectations. In comparison the bombs that were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki had only about half the explosive power of this successor. From the equivalent of 20,000 tons of T. N. T. we leap to something of the order of 35,000 tons.

The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs declared its opposition to fluoridation of the city's public water system yesterday. A resolution adopted at the federation's annual meeting at the Sheraton -Astor Hotel opposed the project on the grounds that: Forcing fluoridated water upon those who didn't want it would be a violation of liberty.
New Issues of corporate and municipal securities will come to market in variety next week but not in great volume.
When the second week of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches was completed yesterday, two district champions remained in front.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Census Bureau is planning a country-wide survey of religious organizations next year.
Last February, Alexander H. Cohen was saying that if he found the right director," he would bring to Broadway in the fall "Cyprienne," the Dorothy Monet adaptation of Victorien Sardou's "Divorcons."

BONN, Germany, May 6 -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet Defense Minister, and Mikhail G. Pervukhin, member of the Presidium of the Central Committee of the Communist party, arrived today in East Berlin. They will participate in this week-end's celebration of the tenth anniversary of the destruction of the Third Reich.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged the nation last night to have confidence that President Eisenhower would make the right decision on what must be done to combat Communist designs in the Formosa Strait.

PARIS, May 6--A series of meetings designed to widen and tighten the Atlantic alliance will begin here tomorrow. The participants will be the foreign ministers of the fifteen nations that compose this alliance.
LAST night's program in the "American Dance" season sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation at the ANTA Theatre, was given over entirely to Jose Limon and his company.

By a royal decree of Queen Elizabeth the British Parliament has now been dissolved, and for the next three weeks Britain will be engrossed in a national election campaign, the results of which will be of profound interest to the rest of the world.
LONDON, May 6--A moderate increase in buying encouraged by the flow of favorable company dividend statements gave the stock markets a firmer look today.

NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (AP)--Official Indian sources said today that India and the United States were considering an agreement that would guarantee future American investors in India against expropriation. It also would assure them of convertibility of their profits.
LONDON, May 6--Britain today carried her dispute with Argentina and Chile over the Falkland Island Dependencies to the International Court of Justice.
WASHINGTON, May 6--Three steamship lines asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to be included in any increased freight-rate relief that might be granted the nation's railroads.

CAMP DESERT ROCK, Nev., May 6--Lieut. Col. John G. Wheelock 3d said today he believed his tanks and armored personnel carriers could have been within 2,000 yards instead of 3,200 yards of yesterday's atomic explosion.
Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons has filed with Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa a claim for $20,000 in salary cuts voluntarily taken by him in the depression years 1934-37.

Freedom of inquiry and freedom for communication of ideas and knowledge about human relationships are as important to wholesome family life as similar freedoms are to any other area of living, Patrick Murphy Malin, executive director of the Civil Liberties Union, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6-- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 110.4 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You are to be congratulated on your editorial of April 29 dealing with the military inadequacies of the bill approved on April 27 by the House Armed Services Committee in its halfhearted attempt to establish a ready reserve force of 2,900,000 men by 1960.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6-- The New Jersey Bar Association today approved a committee report criticizing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican and his staff in their investigation of security risks at Fort Monmouth.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 6 (UP)--The Democratic National Chairman said tonight that the Eisenhower Administration had set up a "paper curtain" of censorship to "mask inefficiency" and "cover up blunders."
The Protestant church should concern itself with the problem of alcoholics, the largest mental health problem today, Dr. Karl Menninger told a group of laymen and clergymen yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- The Department of Argiculture plans to put into effect Nov. 1 a new sales policy to speed disposal of Government-owned wools.

WASHINGTON, May 6--A tailor whose family has been outfitting Marine Corps officers for more than thirty-five years got a patent this week on an invention intended to achieve proper display of campaign ribbons.

After the Board of Estimate recently authorized the New York City Housing Authority to construct $100,000,000 of middle-income housing, with no cash subsidy to reduce rents, one of our readers raised, rather skeptically, the question how such housing could break even on the planned rent charge of $20 to $22 a room per month.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams reported yesterday that crime was decreasing in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 6--The American Jewish Committee sharply criticized today efforts to introduce a religious emphasis in the public school system. It said these "may well create divisive intergroup tension."

The Roseben Handicap will be the big race in New York today. Listed for its sixteenth running, the Roseben is one of the better sprints on the Belmont Park schedule. It has attracted a field of thirteen.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., May 6--Proposals designed to bring about a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait were advanced today before American Protestant leaders.

LONDON, May 6--Queen Elizabeth II issued a royal proclamation today dissolving Parliament. Her action, taken on the advice of Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden, cleared the way for the May 26 general election.

PARIS, May 6--Plans for reorganization of French defense took shape today at a restricted Cabinet meeting. Those who attended included Premier Edgar Faure, Finance Minister Pierre Pflimlin, Gen. Joseph - Pierre Koenig, Defense Minister, and the experts of the defense administrations.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., May 6-- The typical American community reproduced on this desert nuclear test site weathered yesterday's atomic explosion quite well.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 6--The red, black and gold flag of Germany will be hoisted here Monday to flutter beside the fourteen banners of the NATO allies in front of General Gruenther's headquarters. Pretty soon the new dark-gray German uniform will be familiar in the corridors of SHAPE.

In a large realty deal in the garment district, Phillip P. Zipes, operator, has contracted to buy the Bricken Arcade Buildings, two seventeen-story showroom and manufacturing structures at 230-38 West Thirty-eighth Street through to 225-35 West Thirtyseventh Street and the twentythree-story building on plot by 100 by 100 feet at 265 West Thirty-seventh Street, northeast corner of Eighth Avenue.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 6-- Tran Trung Dung, Secretary of State for National Defense, tonight accused a French Army officer of having turned over an ambulance loaded with arms and ammunition to the rebel forces.
The nation's record surplus of wheat may be swollen still more by this year's crop. This is a distinct possibility despite a sharp reduction in acreage planted and adverse weather so far.

Mayor Wagner lowered an original copy of the National Labor Relations Act and personal effects of his late father into the cornerstone of the Senator Robert F. Wagner Sr. Junior High School yesterday morning.
JERICHO, Jordan, April 20-- A latter-day Moses, who found water under the salt-encrusted Jordan Valley desert, is teaching Palestine Arab refugees to transform the area into a green haven.

In 1924 Johnny Dundee, then the featherweight boxing champion of the world, was granted a private audience by Pope Pius XI. Some years later James J. Walker, after resigning as Mayor of New York, paid a visit to the Vatican.
Maurice Couve de Murville, French Ambassador to the United States, described Franco -American friendship yesterday as a "living reality."

The rambunctious young Pirates raided the Polo Grounds last night and made the Giants walk the plank. The 3-2 victory was the sixth straight for the Buccaneers. That represents a high-water mark for the five-year Branch Rickey regime at Pittsburgh.
Two teen-agers were indicted yesterday in the unprovoked slaying of a 15-year-old boy in the Bronx Saturday night.

LOUISVILLE, May 6--Eddie Arcaro fell off a horse at Churchill Downs today. A filly reared and ran out from under him just before the start of the second race. While he dusted himself off, and said things like "Oh, fudge!" she raced her shadow around the track. The steward took her out of the line-up.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6--A two-run double by Roy Campanella in the twelfth inning tonight resulted in a 6-4 victory for the Dodgers over the Phillies at Connie Mack Stadium before 22,420 chilled fans.
New York health authorities marked time before deciding what to do about the Federal Government's announcement yesterday that it had suspended further release of anti-polio vaccine.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 6-- A special state committee urged today that the general assembly adopt a $700,000,000 highway expansion program in Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- Washington defeated Baltimore, 2--1, tonight in a game protested by Paul Richards, manager of the Orioles, and Chuck Dressen, the Senators' pilot. Dean Stone held Baltimore to seven hits in edging Saul Rogovin in a mound duel.

Richard Cassilly, the tenor, will sing the role of Michele in the "N. B. C. Opera Theatre" presentation of Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Saint of Bleecker Street." He replaces Davis Cunningham, who asked to be released from the assignment because of fatigue caused by a long and arduous season in opera and on Broadway.
A MEMORIAL exhibition of paintings by Attilio Salemme, who died early this year at the age of 45, is being held at the Duveen-Graham Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, N. Y., May 6 (AP)-- The State Commerce Commissioner said today that 1955 may be a record year for business in the state.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recent events provided unusual occasion for new appreciation of the valuable public service rendered by The New York Times in its complete and candid coverage of important news, without recourse to sensationalism or excitement.
Cotton futures rose 3 to 12 points (15 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday in moderate business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UP) --Julio Mederos, a Cuban heavyweight, scored a technical knockout over an apparently sick Harold Johnson tonight when an attending physician at ringside stopped their scheduled ten-round return bout at the end of the second round.
A recent tour of grocery and delicacy stores revealed a variety of new food products.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 6-- The twenty-fifth annual Festival of American Music of the Eastman School of Music opened tonight with a program in Kilbourn Hall by the Eastman Rochester Symphony Orchestra.
The change of command at United States Steel this week is not expected to result in any major alteration of the corporation's course--at the start, anyway.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger's twentieth anniversary as president and publisher of The New York Times was marked last night at a dinner with close friends and associates.

Thoughts on "Seeing" New York To see New York properly one should be between 15 and perhaps 18 years old, coming into the city for the first time. Most of us who were born here or who have lived here year upon year do not really see it at all.
WYANDANCH, L. I., May 6 --The eventual dependence of the United States on guided missiles for defensive and offensive armament was forecast here today.

"BEAUREGARD: NAPOLEON IN GRAY,"* by T. Harry Williams, is a Pulitzer Prize-caliber biography of the Confederacy's most controversial beau sabreur. Was Pierre Gustave Toutant Beauregard (1818-93) of Louisiana a great general? No, says Mr. Williams, adding thoughtfully, that, after all, there are few great generals.

Continuing his remarkable play in the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament at Buenos Aires. Herman Pilnik of Argentina drew yesterday his adjourned eleventh-round match with Pedro Martin, Argentina. It was an English opening and went forty-five moves.

HONG KONG, May 6--After having been stationed at Port Arthur for almost ten years, Soviet troops were reported tonight to be withdrawing from that Manchurian naval base. The Hsinhua (New China) News Agency said in a dispatch from Port Arthur that large crowds had gathered at the railway station there to "bid farewell to the Soviet officers and men on their departure."
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 6-- An unforeseen development of major proportions would be necessary to prevent 1955 from setting a record for national prosperity, top business leaders agreed here today.

In its annual survey the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East has reported to the United Nations from its headquarters in Bangkok that there has been a "substantial" gain in most of the nations that are in the non-Communist "arc of freedom" that stretches from Japan to Pakistan.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 6 (AP) --Paige Direct, with Bill Myer driving, scored a half-length victory over Steward Lad, piloted by Jimmy Jordan, in the Great Neck Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Third, another length behind, was the favorite, Ima's Watson, driven by Russell Valles Key.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 6-- Federal rental of drought-stricken land was posed before the American Assembly today as a means of combating dust bowl conditions and aiding farmers.

A study of juvenile delinquency is presented by Albert K. Cohen in "Delinquent Boys: The Culture of the Gang," which the Free Press of Glencoe, Ill., will issue May 20. The author is a former director of orientation at the Indiana Boys School, a state institution for delinquents.
Adolf A. Berle Jr., chairman of the Liberal party, spurned yesterday the proposal by Representative Charles A. Buckley that the party disband and join the Democrats.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6-- Radio and television comedians were warned today to think twice before satirizing the plots of motion pictures.

LIVERPOOL, England, May 6 --R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, promised a "great increase in the standard of life" and to "cherish" Lancashire's interests when he opened the Conservative election campaign in this key area tonight.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 6--Henry Berol's pointer, Berol's White Rain, from Chappaqua, N. Y., won the open allage stake as the Southern New York Field Trial Club trials opened today. There will be two more days of competition.
Eelgrass is thriving, black crown heron are incubating and snowy egrets, last seen nesting here at the turn of the century, have winged their way back to the metropolitan area.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- The retiring president of the New Jersey Bankers Association today recommended a change in the state's laws to permit wider banking services in New Jersey's larger towns.

A sixty-acre tract in Westhampton, L. I., has been sold by Basil O'Connor to a syndicate headed by T. Ross Clancey, president of Westhampton Grove, Inc. The property, on Montauk Highway, has a frontage of 2,000 feet on Beaver Dam Creek.

CHICAGO, May 6 (UP)--The Chicago White Sox blanked the Detroit Tigers tonight, 1--0, behind the two-hit pitching of Virgil (Fire) Trucks before 27,234 fans. The Sox scored in the seventh when Ned Garver threw wildly into left field trying to catch Eddie McGhee sliding into third.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed new proxy rules limiting conditions under which brokers could vote stocks held by them for their customers.
It's getting so a man can't find privacy--even in jail.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 6 -- Foreign Minister George Yeh said today Nationalist China would not respect any cease-fire agreement between the United States and the Chinese Communists. He was answering questions on the second day of closed debate on foreign affairs in the Legislative Yuan (Parliament).
CLEVELAND, May 6 (AP)-- Dave Pope and Hank Majeski backed Herb Score's three-hit pitching with home runs tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 4--1.

Ken Bantum sent Manhattan College off to a fast start in the twenty-second annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association championships yesterday. Bantum, a sophomore, captured two of the three events held at Columbia University's Baker Field.

CHICAGO, May 6--The demand for wheat futures was active at times today and prices for the new crop deliveries made new highs for the movement. But there was much week-end profit taking by longs, which was too much for the smaller demand.

Commodity futures were irregular in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges yesterday. Most of the activity was limited to evening of holdings for the week-end. Sugar, soybean oil, rubber, wool and copper moved mixed; cottonseed oil, hides, burlap and zinc closed lower, and cocoa, coffee, potatoes and silk rose.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Senate Public Works committee rejected President Eisenhower's highway program today.
MOSCOW, April 24--The striking defects of Soviet newspapers have been summarized and criticized in the current issue of Kommunist, a journal of the Soviet Communist party's Central Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 6--A House subcommittee began considering today how the Federal Government could best encourage greater civic and private participation in the rehabilitation and preservation of national historic shrines.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Chinese Communists have agreed to accept relief packages for forty-four detained Americans.
Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, went to Wall Street yesterday and reviewed his stewardship of the railroad holding company for the New York Society of Security Analysts.

BOSTON, May 6--The 6-0 victory by the Yankees over the Boston Red Sox today will go into the records as a two-hit shutout for Bob Turley. But most of the 7,033 fans who saw the fireballing right-hander strike out thirteen Bosox insist that he actually fashioned a onehitter.

LONDON, May 6 (Reuters)-- Following is the text of Queen Elizabeth's address today to Parliament: My Lords and Members of the House of Commons: I followed with the closest interest the visits which my dear sister paid recently to my peoples in the Caribbean Islands.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 6-- Ngo Dinh Nhu, brother and spokesman of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, said today General Collins had made no representations to the Premier on possible systems of government for Vietnam.

ALBANY, May 6--A promise of peace within the Republican state organization has led Representative Dean P. Taylor of Troy to reconsider a decision to resign as a member of the party's national committee.
New York was host to seventy members of Congress yesterday --and for three-quarters of them it was the first time they'd ever seen the city.
With rails and a handful of industrials in the lead, the stock market advanced moderately yesterday. Volume remained low.

The House of Representatives has voted, 206--201, for a restoration of fixed 90 per cent price supports for the so-called "basic" commodities. But unless and until the Senate gives evidence that it is prepared to back the House up on this rejection of flexible supports without even a trial it is difficult to take the House action too seriously.

A fine American orchestra, the Symphony of the Air, is on a comprehensive foreign tour with the support and blessing of our State Department, our defense establishment and many foreign sponsors. In Tokyo hundreds of students stood in line for more than twentyfour hours to get tickets at a price that they could afford for the second of a series of concerts there.
With rails and a handful of industrials in the lead, the stock market advanced moderately yesterday. Volume remained low.

The House of Representatives has voted, 206--201, for a restoration of fixed 90 per cent price supports for the so-called "basic" commodities. But unless and until the Senate gives evidence that it is prepared to back the House up on this rejection of flexible supports without even a trial it is difficult to take the House action too seriously.

A fine American orchestra, the Symphony of the Air, is on a comprehensive foreign tour with the support and blessing of our State Department, our defense establishment and many foreign sponsors. In Tokyo hundreds of students stood in line for more than twentyfour hours to get tickets at a price that they could afford for the second of a series of concerts there.

A development of importance to New Yorkers is taking place under the direction of Commissioner Joseph E. O'Grady of the city's Department of Labor. The first two of a series of eight or more public hearings on a proposed code of labor relations have been held.
BALTIMORE, May 6--A new national society of psychiatrists who dissent from the widely accepted Freudian school was set up here today.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,000 head: market fairly active, steady to 25 cents lower: mostly steady to weak on all hogs: most choice 190-240 pounds butchers, $17-$17.75; largely
BUENOS AIRES, May 6--The Argentine Trade Promotion Institute circulated tenders to private traders today for importation of 19,708 tons of badly needed cottonseed oil from the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP)-- A Federal Power Commission examiner recommended today that a license be granted to the Idaho Power Company authorizing one of the three low dams it wants to build in Hell's Canyon.
The port's new campaign to stabilize cargo loading between dock and truck ran into difficulty on two fronts yesterday.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 6-- "Marathan McKinney," who undertook a 140-mile bicycle trip to pay off his debts, zipped across the finish line here today after an all-night ordeal.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A new high level of employment for April was reached last month, the Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce reported today.
VIENNA, May 6--A compromise in the dispute over an article in the Austrian state treaty regulating Soviet economic claims was presented today.
THE fifth annual Coney Island fishing contest opens at Steeplechase Pier on Monday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of May 4 you express disappointment at the action of Governor Harriman in vetoing the Wilson-McGahan Bill, which you describe as "the failure to curb the easy withdrawal of candidates set up as dummies with the intention of later replacement."
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Surgeon General said today that Federal clearance of new Salk poliomyelitis vaccine had been temporarily halted.

CINCINNATI, May 6 (AP)-- The last-place Cincinnati Redlegs, cowed by the Chicago Cubs in five previous encounters this season, tripped the Chicagoans tonight, 4--2, behind the six-hit pitching of Joe Nuxhall.
LONDON, May 6--One way Britons will know the election campaign is on will be the strange way their radio or television sets are behaving.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits commended psychiatrists and civic leaders yesterday upon the opening of the Karen Horney Clinic. The clinic, at 115 East Thirty-first Street, is for the relief of persons of limited means who need psychiatric assistance.

ROME, May 6--A colorful scene was witnessed in the Vatican this morning at the swearing in of twenty-two recruits for the Swiss Guard, which, since the Middle Ages, has been the Pope's traditional bodyguard.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 3--In the past year President Victor Paz Estenssoro has rarely made a major speech in which he has not attacked Bolivia's Communists. His example has been followed by other Government leaders, including Juan Lechin, former Minister of Mines, who now heads Bolivia's Workers Confederation.

The Soviet Union appears to have begun an aggressive propaganda campaign to sell the world on the idea that the Iron Curtain is an American -- not a Russian -- invention. The latest issue of Pravda, the official Communist party newspaper, to arrive in New York reveals what looks like the beginning of a propaganda drive of massive proportions.

ROME, May 6 (UP)--Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., defeated Torben Ulrich of Denmark, 6--4, 6--8, 6--4, 13--11, today to reach the men's singles quarter-finals of the Rome International Tennis Tournament.

ROME, May 6--A colorful scene was witnessed in the Vatican this morning at the swearing in of twenty-two recruits for the Swiss Guard, which, since the Middle Ages, has been the Pope's traditional bodyguard.
LEONCAVALLO's much-recorded I Pagliacci now is available on a new set made at La Scala under the direction of Tullio Serafin (Angel, two disks).
LONDON. NOT so many years ago Ruth Gordon retired from the stage to devote herself to the more austere profession of writing. Retirements from the stage involve one terrible hazard.
WASHINGTON, May 7--president Eisenhower was serenaded by Russia's "Marshal Georgi Zhukov" at the annual Gridiron Club dinner.
East Harlem civic leaders are alarmed about the effect that "a stereotyped approach to housing" is having upon the number of stores in the area.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass.-- In the expanding movement to preserve New England's proud Industrial traditions, a gallery of treasures of the silversmith's art is flourishing in this historic city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7--After three years of invincibility, Navy met its master on the water today. By the margin of a length and a half, the University of Pennsylvania eight defeated Rusty Callow's midshipmen over the course of a mile and three quarters on the Charles.
FORT WORTH, May 7 (AP)-- Chandler Harper carded a par 70 today and that kept him six strokes ahead in the $25,000 Colonial Invitation golf tourney.

THOSE who view the divorce rate as proof of growing disintegration in the American family would do well to take a second look. Unlike the cost of living or the national income, the recent divorce trend is definitely downward.

An encouraging increase in the amount of financial support which graduates and former students of American universities, colleges and secondary schools are rendering to their institutions has been recorded in the 1954 Alumni Fund Survey just published by the American Alumni Council.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The House vote on farm price supports this week, coming on the heels of the C. I. O.'s announced effort to rebuild the Congressional "farm-labor bloc" of New Deal days, has served to revive the question of just how strong such voting blocs are on Capitol Hill.

NAGS HEAD, N. C.--A hundred miles of surfcharged barrier beachland, uninterrupted by a single jewelry or antique furniture auction, lures the early summer vacationist to one of the country's most unusual coastal regions.
A survey of work by European and American painters and sculptors who have come into prominence during the decade since the close of World War II is the major art event of the week.
Pan American World Airways has reported that its passengers have a perfect record in paying their bills.

BONN, May 7 -- To employ vernacular, the restoration of West Germany's sovereignty last Thursday "went over like a lead balloon." The situation, the feelings of the individual and the social group did not alter one whit between 1159 hours and 1201 hours.

SAIGON, May 7--In a country where once they were masters, the defeated French are finding it difficult to adjust to a state of affairs in which they are, to a large extent, discredited, unloved and unwanted.
Retailers are reaching for sales by offering products they ordinarily do not handle. The grocery store now carries nylon stockings, the men's wear shop shaving cream and the drug store hand tools.
CHICAGO, May 7--The American Medical Association issued today a series of "don'ts" in an effort to end public confusion over the Salk polio vaccine and mass inoculations.

NORFOLK, Va.; May 6 (AP)-- Capt. Charles William Whidden, retired commodore and senior master of the United Fruit Company fleet, died this morning in a Norfolk hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

HOLLYWOOD. WHAT price violence? Hollywood is discovering the hard way, through financial loss and lowering of its prestige, that the substitution of brute force and sadism for story invention is a questionable expedient.
Plans for a colony of homes in the North Shore section of Suffolk County were announced yesterday at builders reported the purchase of fifty acres of land in East Northport, L. I.

WHAT the Cabots are to Boston the Biddies are to Philadelphia, and if the Biddle position with respect to the Deity is not quite as clearly defined as the Cabots, they have a distinction of their own; they are known for their charm.

GARDENERS in cities surely have problems that are unknown to gardeners in other locales. Though these problems may seem formidable, they are far from insurmountable. In fact, if they are approached in common-sense fashion they will present no serious obstacle to the creation of a successful city garden.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 7--Cornell's varsity, jayvee and freshman crews easily defeated Syracuse today over Cayuga Lake's two-mile course.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Congressional hunger may change the face of the east front of the Capitol.

On the first anniversary yesterday of the fall of Dienbienphu-- which marked the turning point of the Indo-China war and the division of Vietnam at the Seventeenth Parallel --South Vietnam was in the throes of an acute political crisis. The roots of the crisis lay in the long years of French colonial rule which produced intense nationalism in Vietnam and at the same time deprived the Vietnamese of the institutions and experience of selfgovernment.

STRATEGIC use of a couple of the fragrant annuals can yield pleasure for the gardener and bring a good appearance to odd places at the same time. Two of my favorites, mignonette and nicotiana, lend themselves especially well to several situations.

Eighteen adolescents were held yesterday in $10,000 bail each for unlawful assembly. They had been arrested Friday night in Brooklyn after the police thwarted what appeared to be a large-scale gang fight.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 7 (AP)--Eventual creation of a new episcopal area with a Bishop's residence in Albany, N. Y., was recommended today by Bishop Frederick B. Newell, resident Bishop of the Methodist Church in the New York area.

LONDON. LONDON has been treated to a neatly assorted menu of opera during the last few weeks. The Stoll Theatre is becoming a home away from home for visiting Italian companies, and recently a fine assembly of singers, conducted by Manrico De Tura, rode for us highly spirited steeplechases on some of the old battlehorses.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The 101-year-old battle to make Hawaii a state will resume in the House of Representatives, probably Tuesday. The prospect is dimmed by Hawaii's being coupled with Alaska.

There is a gap of twenty-five years between the stainless steel tower of the Chrysler Building and the stainless steel sheathing which is being installed directly across West Forty-second Street on the new forty-two-story Socony Mobil Building.

The apple is a pome, a fruit, something good to eat in pie or jelly or just as an apple. But before it is any of those things, an apple is a blossom. And what is more beautiful than a tree full, an orchard full, a whole valley of orchards full of apple blossoms on a fine May day?
A group of 154 parcels of land will be offered for sale by the city at a one-day auction sale on June 1. A total upset price of $548,625 has been set for the group.

RANDOLPH, Vt.-The New York-Montreal motoring axis--about 385 miles of first-class highways, running virtually north and south and adorned with some of the finest scenery and historic landmarks to be found in Eastern North America--is understandably a brilliant tourist attraction in spring and summer.
MOSCOW, May 4 (Reuters)-- A song about Soviet-style zootsuiters, long-haired youths with fancy vests who have become the laughing stock of the country, now is on the Moscow "hit parade."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 7 -- In St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church here this morning, Miss. Edwina Carew was married to James Edward Brennan. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Carew of Rockville Centre.
Ralph Diaz of Cardinal Hayes High School sped to a meet record in the 880-yard run at the eighth annual Brooklyn College interscholastic track and field games yesterday.
GENEVA, May 7--Lags in labor productivity and inadequate food production were reported here today to be the key economic bottlenecks plaguing Moscow planners.
THE home craftsman, who accepts the challenge of building a home or a piece of furniture or doing a remodeling job, is faced with the task of choosing the proper wood to work with.

WITH the arrival of warm weather many a city dweller finds himself overwhelmed with an urge to get away from it all and back to primitive, unspoiled nature. Primitive and unspoiled, that is, except for an adequate supply of sanitary facilities, well marked trails and roads and other amenities so essential to the twentieth-century trail blazer.
MORE thorough and more intelligent fertilizing programs for vegetables are especially important in average size backyard gardens where every square foot is precious and cultivated every year.

A big colony of all-year homes with many of the advantages of a vacation spot will rise soon on a picturesque tract of 1,300 acres of woodland and lakes in the historic Delaware Valley, in New Jersey.
PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- Arnie Sowell, University of Pittsburgh track star, ran one of the fastest quarter miles in the history of foot racing today.
MOSCOW, May 7--The Presidium, of the Supreme Soviet today approved a decision to scrap the Soviet Union's friendship pacts with Britain and France.
CLEVELAND, May 7--The Cleveland Indians defeated Kansas City, 9--3, today to gain their second straight victory over the Athletics.

COLORADO SPRINGS--The 120,000 Square miles of the Southern Rockies, from the sweet meadows of North Park under the Rabbit Ears in Colorado, south to Santa Fe's crooked streets in New Mexico, are popping out as merrily as ever with unparalleled attractions and incredible plans.
Coffee men throughout the world expect Brazil to announce reduced minimum export price about the middle of this month.

AS far as most television viewers are concerned, old movies belong in the same contemptible category as pitchmen's commercials. The prints of old films, run regularly on many channels, have been widely condemned as symbolic of a public-be-hanged attitude on the part of broadcasters.
NEW HAVEN, May 7--President Eisenhower has commended plans for the celebration of the anniversary of the birth of Nathan Hale, Revolutionary War hero.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Herbert C. Plummer, director of public information of the General Services Administration, died of cancer at his home here today after an illness of several months. He was 51 years old.

LIVERPOOL, England, May 7 --Ten years ago, when the guns fell silent, the Soviet Army and Air Force were settled in the heart of a divided and broken Germany. This eastward extension of Soviet power was the central problem facing the Western victors.

AS if to refute once again the old adage that lightning does not strike twice in the same place, we have for the second time this year a historical novel which not only deals with the French Middle Ages, but places many of its scenes in the savage Albigensian Crusade, which was one of the most horrifying examples of man's inhumanity to man in the whole story of the human race.

Creatures out of "Alice in Wonderland" are in process of re-creation in dimensions and color that even Lewis Carroll's fantasy did not encompass. These will be in a host of other artful concoctions now shaping up as a suitably fantastic background to the "Bal Fantastique" of Artists Equity Association on Friday evening.
A Brooklyn judge predicted yesterday that juvenile delinquency in New York would be cut by assigning a policeman to every four blocks in the city.
One advantage of rooting for baseball teams instead of corporate factions is that you know the score as soon as the last putout is made.

OTTAWA--Canadian road builders are battling unseasonable weather, rough terrain and Canada's vast distances to put a road across this country. Canadian roads are far above average compared to those of most other countries.

ONCE again, Planting Fields, the famous estate of the late W. R. Coe located on Chicken Valley Road, Oyster Bay, L. I., will be open to the public. This year the big day will be Saturday from 1 to 6 P. M. when the azalea bloom will be at its peak.

ONE of the greatest concentrations of rhododendron culture in the United States is to be found in the Pacific Northwest--Washington and Oregon--where the native rhododendron, R. macrophyllum, laces the coastal forests with springtime color.

AMONG the many books written on Germany after the collapse of Hitler's Thousand Year Reich, this book by Milton Mayer is one of the most readable and most enlightening. An American journalist of German descent and of Jewish faith, Mr. Mayer served for one year on the visiting faculty of the Institute for Social Research at Frankfurt University.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Stephen A. Mitchell, until recently the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, stands steadfast on the burning deck of Democratic party "loyalty" whence all but him have fled. His program--to challenge the credentials of Democratic delegates who bolted the nominee of 1952 if they come as delegates to the national convention of 1956--has now been disavowed, in one way or another, by some of the leaders and Presidential aspirants of the party.

RICHMOND, Va. -- Four states -- Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky and North Carolina--have begun to take on the united pattern of a special kind of vacationland, and this development is becoming more and more evident this spring.
Operators of the 10,000 building incinerators throughout the city were warned yesterday of an impending crackdown for smoke violations by Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control.
IN one of its more grandiose undertakings, the National Broadcasting Company is trying to arrange a color TV presentation of "The Skin of Our Teeth" after it is staged in Paris this summer.

JOHN WILES, a South African with a compassionate understanding equal to Alan Paton's and a remarkable literary gift, has written a first novel of the Bantu people that should be long remembered. Though its subject is the disintegration that comes upon an innocent black boy when he is plunged into the inhuman desolation and spiritual waste of the white man's world, it is not an angry book.
The Chrysler Corporation's dramatic comeback is picking up momentum.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 7-- Brazilian domestic politics have Upset the international coffee pot.

WASHINGTON, May 7 --A sharp indictment of the nation's immigration policies of the last two years was voiced here tonight. The criticism was delivered in addresses by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, and Irving M. Engel, president of the American Jewish Committee.

CHICAGO--The Midwestern States are looking forward to a boom year in tourist and vacationist business. Private and state operators of vacation attractions have been refurbishing hotels, motels, beach and lake facilities and public park tracts this spring with assurances through advance bookings that the 1955 vacation season will be one of the biggest and most profitable on record.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The latest of the complaints that the United States Supreme Court in recent decisions, but notably in the school segregation cases, has usurped the legislative powers of the Congress and the state governments is that of Senator Sam Ervin of North Carolina on April 28 in a speech at the annual dinner of the Harvard Law School Association.

TRENTON--New Jersey resort officials and concessionaires are now making final preparations for what they hope will be their most prosperous season. Programs and plans for the entertainment of the summer's visitors have long since been formulated, and from the white sandy beaches that stretch for more than 100 miles along the coast to the green-clad foothills of the Kittatinny Mountains, preparations are being completed for the official opening of the season on Memorial Day week-end.

MOST observers are now willing to concede that third-quarter business will remain strong over-all and there is a growing conviction that fourth-quarter volume will also hold up. Here and there a hardy soul ventures to predict that gross national product and consumer income will continue at high levels well into 1956.

The encouragement of individuality of children in their art work will be one of the points to be emphasized in a free lecture at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 7-- Three persons drowned off Shippan Point in Long Island Sound this afternoon when their rowboat capsized.

MRS. VINING, who several years ago gave us "Windows for the Crown Prince," an account of her experiences as tutor to Prince Akihito, the Japanese heir apparent, now turns to, American historical fiction.

LEWISTON, Idabo--A stream in northern Montana was given the unlikely name of Milk River on this day, May 8, a century and a half ago, by two buckskin-clad American Army officers, whose shades will be riding Western trails throughout this year.
I. John Billera has been elected vice president and treasurer of United States Industries, Inc.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 7-- To many farmers in the Midwest the debate in Congress this week over price supports was like thunder in the distance--they heard it, but it wasn't close enough for them to go outside and see what was happening.

THE heroine of Margaret Mackay's "The Four Fates" has genius for devotion. Through the four men to whom that genius is dedicated. Iris lives, in turn, the life of the mind, the heart, the flesh and the spirit. Rebounding from a teen-age crush on Lionel, father of her English playmate Monty, she marries the exquisite Leslie.
ALBANY, May 7 (AP)--A fourteenmile section of the State Thruway will be opened to toll use May 27, in time to relieve traffic on Route 17 during the Memorial Day week-end.

Hoe With the Man It is time to use that antique device again time to pick up that dreary, back - breaking gadget, the hoe. Says the encyclopedia. "The hoe is the first distinctly agricultural implement," and then it goes on to say more of what it thinks the hoe is.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--Where the Gold Coast of Florida got that appellation no one hereabout seems to know for certain. The term was applied to a swanky lake shore section of Chicago long before it became a geographical description in Florida.
LONDON, May 7--Britain has asked the Soviet Union to agree to extending beyond May 18 the deadline for the evacuation of political refugees from Communistruled North Vietnam.
BONN, Germany, May 7-- The Soviet bloc nations of Europe are to sign a mutual assistance -treaty in Warsaw next week as an answer to the arming of West Germany.
The new depreciation provisions of the 1954 Revenue Code, as described by an accounting consultant, do not give the taxpayer any greater depreciation allowances than the older provisions.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7--The King of Prussia Inn, a 246-yearold landmark at the near-by Vallege Forge interchange of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, is up for sale again.
Cross Section IN its first possible week to get on the graph at the right. Robert Ruark's "Something of Value" tommy-gunned into seventh place.

JUST a year ago Mrs. Frances Harwood, principal of P. S. 53, an allwhite elementary school in Baltimore, called her teachers into the lunchroom for tea and a talk. The subject was the Supreme Court ruling that racial segregation in public schools was unconstitutional.

MAPS are my business-- and for that reason I often wonder how many of the countless facts laboriously compiled and shown on a map are ever used to advantage; how often, when maps would be most useful, are they completely ignored?
WITH advance reports indicating heavy rail travel in the West this summer, officials are crediting much of the expected increase to the rising popularity of the dome car.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, 80year-old trainer, has won more big stake races than he can recall. And he has lost some big ones, too. So he had no complaints yesterday afternoon when his outstanding performer, Nashua, was beaten in the eighty-first running of the Kentucky Derby at Louisville.
Columbia, Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Boston University crews won a race apiece in a regatta on the Harlem River yesterday.

With one-third of the apartments rented from the plans, construction work has been started on Palisade Terrace, a garden apartment development in Fort Lee, N. J. The proposed six-story building will house 100 families and is scheduled for completion late next fall.

ROME, May 7--Almost 90,000 families aggregating more than 400,000 persons are settled on Italian land made available through land reform. The heads of these families, formerly day laborers, are now small landowners.
After forty-eight years at Barnard College as student and pedagogue, Miss Florrie Holzwasser will retire in June as Associate Professor of Geology.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Pending the United States Public Health Service announcement tomorrow, the anti-polio vaccination picture across the nation today was: ALABAMA -- First shots completed, second round not due until May 16; new vaccine supplies needed.

IN his photograph on the book jacket, Charles W. Morton has an Eisenhower forehead, rimless spectacles, and on his face the expression of a conscientious judge about to sentence the town drunk. He is fingering a few manuscripts which, as an associate editor of Atlantic Monthly, he has every right to do; but the scene-setting is incomplete, for no rejection slips are handy.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 7--Westchester's plans for modernizing its bulging parkways for $35,000,000 now and millions more later are paralyzed.
Five business men walked into a bank here one day last week to discuss their expansion plans. One hour later they left, assured of a $5,000,000 loan.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The operative power of the Republican right wing seems to have fallen to its lowest point since that faction lost in the great contest over the Presidential nomination of 1952.

It is fundamental for the security of the United States and the rest of the free world that the United States take the leadership in promoting * * * high levels of trads * * *. With these words President Eisenhower has stated a central point of his foreign economic policy.
Professional sport has been cast in the role of Horrible Example in a new tax drama about to be played in Washington.

LOUISVILLE, May 7--Californians did some high-decibel whooping today at the Kentucky Derby. And they were joined in their celebrating by those in a crowd of 100,000 at Churchill Downs who had backed Rex C. Ellsworth's Swaps.
A 96-year-old Italian immigrant arrived here yesterday and was greeted by twenty-five relatives.

THE rose will become the official floral emblem of the United States of America, by act of Congress, if that body passes the bills proposed in the Senate by Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine and in the House by Representative Frances Bolton of Ohio.

IN "Egypt's Destiny" we have, above all, the self-portrait of a sincere and sometimes noble man who served as a dignified and popular front for Egypt's recent revolution. "Egypt's Liberation" is a short book of philosophical reflections, "an effort to explore within ourselves," by the man who was the real moving spirit of the revolution.

The New York Life Insurance Company had $1,549,000,000 invested in mortgages at the end of 1954 as compared with $1,421,000,000 in 1953, according to Portfolio, the quarterly publication of the company's real estate and mortgage department.

ALBANY--There exists a seven-mile stretch of New York's Thruway which the most jaded driver cannot avoid noticing. It is the wildest and least populated segment of landscape of all the super-highway's 500 miles.
MOSCOW, Sunday, May 8-- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov today accused the United States of surrounding the Soviet Union and Red China with military bases "designed for waging atomic warfare."
WARRENTON, Va., May 7(AP) --Uncle Pierre, a 9-year-old bay gelding, won the thirtieth running of the Virginia Gold Cup steeplechase by three lengths today.
PHILADELPHIA -- With advance bookings well ahead of those of last year, the operators of vacation centers and resort hotels in Pennsylvania are looking ahead to one of the best seasons in years.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 7-- Rigid price supports for farm products have "lost their political attractiveness," Senator Clinton P. Anderson asserted here tonight.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 7(AP)-- Mrs. Jan Burke's Dedicate scored his fourth consecutive and most important victory of the year today. Under a strong ride by Sam Boulmetis, the Princequillo colt won the Delaware Valley Stakes at Garden State Park.
PARIS, May 7--Edouard Herriot, pre-war Premier and veteran chieftain of the French Radical party, today announced his retirement from leadership of the party.

CINCINNATI, May 7 (UP)-- Bob Thurman, a pinch-hitter, blasted a three-run homer in the eighth inning today to give the Cincinnati Redlegs an 8-7 triumph over the Chicago Cubs. Four other circuit blows were hit in the contest.

TRAVEL, limited a quarter century ago to no more than 15 per cent of the population, has become a multi-billion-dollar business, the third largest industry in the United States. This year some 65 per cent of the nation's workers will receive two weeks--or more --with pay, and 61,000,000 Americans will spend their vacations traveling.
It's one thing to scrape, paint, varnish and otherwise overhaul and fit out a pleasure craft for a yachting season. This is called making a boat snug in Bristol fashion.

TO THE EDITOR: Mitch Miller's rationalization of Tin Pan Alley's current glut of bad music ("June, Moon, Swoon and Ko Ko Mo," April 24) can only be termed ludicrous. How can he seriously compare the latest "rockand-roll" tripe with songs like "These Foolish Things"?

MORAN, Wyo.--An important stage in the development program for the Jackson Hole country as a national park and preserve will be the opening next June 15 of the handsome new Jackson Lake Lodge to the general public.
GENEVA, May 7--To a growing number of Europeans, oil seems to be the best bet for saving the Western European economy from a serious energy crisis.

ON a motoring vacation the old adage, "It's a long lane that has no let-up," applies to both driver and passengers, and anything that can relieve tension is all to the good. There are, as it happens, a quantity of gadgets and devices available which are aimed at lessening fatigue and cushioning long hours behind the wheel or in the back seat.

Newspaper city editors from fourteen states, the District of Columbia, Alaska and Canada will begin tomorrow a two-week seminar at the American Press Institute at Columbia University on the problems of local news coverage.

VANCOUVER, B. C.--For the adventurous tourist, British Columbia's vast interior contains a remarkable storehouse of lakes, rivers, mountains and some of the finest fresh water fishing in North America.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 7 --About 73,300 men will undergo training this summer at Camp Drum.
When the dramatic announcement of the Salk anti-polio vaccine was made a month ago, there was an air of rejoicing and victory.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The President's $200,000,000 special Asian fund which the Administration has included in foreign aid requests would be used to help finance a regional economic organization in Asia. The requests are now before Congress.

Dr. Augustus B. Kinzel is an amiable refutation of the widespread notion that a research genius is probably a hard-totalk-to, absent-minded dreamer with time for little else than test tubes and slide rules.

President Eisenhower has sent a special message to Congress urging approval of United States membership in the proposed International Finance Corporation, to be affiliated with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your news coverage and editorials on the Bricker Amendment have been splendid. Having studied this subject in the League of Women Voters, which has taken a stand against the Bricker proposals, I realize that the issues involved are of vital concern to all citizens.

HOW much does it really cost to own and drive a car? This is a question which is asked at one time or another by most of our 48,000,000 American car owners. Some want to determine how much they should be reimbursed for use of their automobiles on company business.

WHEN in 1915 each state was requested to nominate its greatest living citizen for the Hall of Fame at the Panama-Pacific Exposition in San Francisco, the obvious choice from Minnesota was James J. Hill.

To accomplish the ever-increasing task of supplying outlying American bases in the Far North, the Military Sea Transportation Service is developing designs for four different types of Arctic cargo ships.

JENSON, Utah--The proposal in Washington to permit private utilities to build a 525-foot-high dam at Echo Park in Dinosaur National Monument seems sure to attract masses of tourists this summer to this beautiful spot at the junction of the Green and Yampa Rivers and end its delightful remoteness.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7-- A balanced budget with proposed reductions in individual and corporate taxes will be offered to Congress in January.
Despite the widely accepted belief that the Marquis de Lafayette was an honorary citizen of the United States, the State Department has challenged this as "not at all clear."

In contrast with Central Europe, where the creation of a sovereign Government in Bonn is impelling the Soviet Union to start negotiations with the West that may make history, most of the signs now indicate that there will be no showdown in the Formosa crisis for months to come.

The Amish folk of Pennsylvania should have no trouble at all in winning a popularity poll hands down. These good people, the focal point of a popular Broadway musical, are the inspiration, too, for the theme of the annual spring bridge party for the benefit of the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N. J.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 7-- Political quarters were preoccupied today with plans for reshaping the Government, organizing the National Assembly and deciding the role Chief of State Bao Dai was to play in Vietnamese affairs.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 7-- Appointment of a new executive director of the Rockefeller Brothers Theological Fellowship program, established to encourage outstanding young people to consider the ministry as a career, was announced this week.
New York's Summer Festival again this year will offer an unparalleled vacation program, tailor-made to every age, taste and pocketbook.
The trustees of the Ford Foundation have allocated $15,000,000 to strengthen and extend research in mental health over the next five to ten years.

IF you are one who sits around by the telephone waiting for some action, only you hardly ever get any calls, why one of the best remedies for the complaint, although there is a little work to it, is to write a big, lovely smash Broadway musical comedy.

LONDON. THE current Daily Express exhibition of pictures is an admirable attempt on the part of a British daily newspaper to discover hidden talent in the rising generation of painters between the ages of 18 and 35.
DIXON SPRINGS, Ill., May 7 --The restoration to productivity here of nearly 5,000 acres of worn-out farm land has brought new hopes to one of the most depressed agricultural areas of the nation.
ROME, May 7 (UP)--Budge Patty stroked his way to a fourset victory over Kurt Nielsen of Denmark in the quarter-final round of Rome's international tennis tournament today.

THE proponents of pay-asyou-see television had better get up a head of steam. Their arguments are not standing up too well under the penetrating attack of the opponents of toll TV and do not seem as persuasive as they once were.

The Veterans Administration is referring all applications for direct home loans to its Voluntary Home Mortgage Credit Program regional committees, the agency announced. The procedure has been initiated, the announcement said, in order to give World War II and post-Korean veterans living in remote areas and small communities the advantage of the loan placement facilities of the new credit program.

ONE of the more general disagreements about modern art is where it began. Writers have begun frequently with Cezanne. A good case could be made out for Manet. One historian a few years ago began with Delacroix.

Two engineering educators called yesterday for a re-evaluation of the nation's undergraduate engineering program to meet the demands of the modern world. They termed the curriculum archaic and inadequate.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations approved today the proposed constitution to govern the new organization to be formed by merger with the American Federation of Labor.

OTTAWA--The recent injection of close to $100,000,000 of new equipment into the bloodstream of Canadian railroads is not only expected to give Canadian train travel a good boost but will appreciably reduce the running time between Vancouver in the west and Montreal and Toronto in the east.
MADRID, May 7--The Government is understood to have been assured that French financial assistance to the Spanish Republican Government in exile has been withdrawn.
Domestic shipbuilders are expected to receive contracts within a few days for two 35,000deadweight-ton tankers for the Esso Shipping Company.
Unless there is an eleventhhour reprieve, the Third Avenue elevated will cease operating at midnight Thursday.

IN SPITE of what the facts may say, the truth beneath the facts is that Nora Kaye had only one new role in the recent Ballet Theatre season, and that was in "Swan Lake." "Streetcar Named Desire" was merely another carry-over of the theory that Miss Kaye is an actress rather than a dancer.

OTTAWA. THE Dominion Drama Festival, that unique Canadian institution for the encouragement of the dramatic arts, will be held in the prairie city of Regina, Sask., starting tomorrow and lasting until Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The value of anniversaries--tomorrow is the tenth anniversary of VE Day-- is that they encourage us to take the long look and concern ourselves not with the incidents of politics but with the tendencies of history.

FOR the first time a major work by Junichiro Tanizaki, the foremost living Japanese novelist, has been made available in English. This is a matter for rejoicing not only on the part of the relatively few people who are especially concerned with things Japanese, but for the much wider reading public.

LOUISVILLE, May 7--Swaps raced to victory in the Kentucky Derby today flying the red and black silks of Rex C. Ellsworth. But the 3-year-old chestnut colt has a couple of other owners: Mrs. Ellsworth and the trainer of Swaps, Mesach Adams Tenney.

NEWARK, May 7--The New Jersey Public Utility Commission will lend a patient ear this Tuesday to commuters who are protesting the proposed discontinuence of passenger service on the West Shore division of the New York Central Railroad.

THE Chinese--the old, old Chinese, that is, not either of their present-day posterity --equated the communicative power of one picture to that of several thousand well-chosen words. We bow, gracefully we like to think, to this equation and to our artist for having portrayed so succinctly on this page what this section is all about.

AN educational exhibition, "The Suspense of Time," which deals with early photographic experiments in arresting motion, will open Saturday at George Eastman House in Rochester. The show will continue to June 27.

THE development of new chemical insecticides and fungicides has wrought great changes in the ways and means of fighting plant insects and diseases. But even more important is the development of chemicals that are compatible; i. e., that may be mixed without having their individual properties and characteristics disturbed by chemical reactions, and that will perform just as effectively in a mixture as they would separately.

How effective is cloud-seeding in bringing down rain or snow? News comes from Washington that the President's Advisory Committee on Weather Control intends to find out by putting commercial cloud-seeding methods to tests later in the year at the foot of Mount Washington, New Hampshire.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 7-- Nationalist China's air commander said today his air force urgently needed Sabre Jet fighters if it was to maintain superiority in the Formosa Strait.

LAST year Rodney Garland, a pseudonymous British writer, surprised the critics by creating, in "The Heart in Exile," a book about homosexuals which was no exercise in shoddy sensation, but a serious novel, praised in this book review by Frank G. Slaughter both for its educational value and for its "profound insight into human feelings and sensitivities."

FOR the past ten years a quite ordinary-looking citizen named Harry R. Wilson has been producing exciting sound from the vocal cords of children and youth throughout the country. Dr. Wilson is a conductor of school and college choral festivals.

HAPPY the land, they say, that has no history. Greece has had a history--as often troublous as it has been glorious, one that includes wars against tyranny, oppressive occupation, internal feuding. Passionate politics, like soldiering, is a venerable recreation of Greeks.
BOSTON--The vacationist planning to visit New England this summer will find that the Yankees have counter-planned all manner of attractions to induce the tourist to come early and remain longer.

RICHMOND, Va.--Passenger helicopter service between the Virginia Beach resort area and near-by Norfolk and Newport News, as well as between Richmond and a number of other Virginia communities, is to be launched this summer, it is hoped by early June.

THERE are so many kinds and varieties of azaleas on the market today that it is difficult for the gardener to select those most suitable for his property. So many factors must be considered-- namely, bloom period, color, and height of the plant.

Rea Hannigan of the Woodley Lane Farm made a game finish to win the $31,050 Roseben Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Heliopolis beat the fleet Artismo by a head in the seven furlong dash under a persistent ride by Paul Bailey.

WITHIN the next two or three weeks, regardless of the innumerable chores on the agenda, the gardener might well pause to review his plantings of spring flowering bulbs. With pad and pencil in hand he should ask himself: Did the blossoms come up to expectations?
WESTBURY, L. I., May 7 (AP) --Lord Steward, one of harness racing's top money winning trotters, won the Wantagh Trot by a neck over Gene Mac at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

TO THE EDITOR: Now look what you've gone and done! Without realizing it, of course, you have disillusioned the Youth of America. You have published the picture of the real Davy Crockett (and called him handsome) when everyone knows that Davy Crockett is dashing (but winsome) Fess Parker.
Sales of interest to many kinds of buyers, from the collector of rare books to the householder looking for terrace furniture, are scheduled this week.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) --Federal mediators recessed late today to settle the fiftyfive-day Louisville Nashville Railroad strike, but voiced hope of an accord tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Mrs. Sophie Rosenwald Adler, whose late husband, Max, and late brother, Julius Rosenwald, were executives of Sears, Roebuck Co., died today in her home in Beverly Hills, Calif., after a long illness. She was 84 years old.

WILLIE (The Actor) SUTTON was asked once why he robbed only banks. "Because," replied the Barrymore of the bank circuit, "that's where the money is." In past weeks some of Willie's fellow heist-men have demonstrated that not only is the money there but often it is not too hard to come by, either.

Plans have been enlarged for the proposed Gateway regional shopping center at Vails Gate in New Windsor, N. Y. The office of George H. Beckmann, agent for the Orange County development, explained that an unusual demand for space has caused the sponsors to revise their plans.
Union Settlement House this month is rounding out sixty years of devoted service in one of the city's poorest, most crowded neighborhoods.

LONDON, May 7--Billy Graham, the American evangelist, has become a popular figure in Britain. In turn, this island has a unique place in the affections of Mr. Graham and his team of evangelists. In two consecutive years in Britain, Mr. Graham has had the biggest successes of his career.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 3-- Among the problems the Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro faces are those of graft, corruption, speculation, bribery and smuggling.
AT the ANTA Theatre on West Fifty-second Street, the season of "American Dance," sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation goes into its second week Tuesday.

Manufacturers were beset by rush reorders for women's apparel last week as hot weather set in, resident buying offices reported. At the same time shrewd store buyers began to stock up with fall numbers.
VIENNA, May 7--The editing committee was busy today incorporating in the draft of an Austrian state treaty the changes made during this week's negotiations.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Secretary of State Dulles is expected to stand firm in Paris this week-end against FrenchBritish pressures to preserve Bao Dai's position as Vietnam's Chief of State.

KIAMESHA LAKE--Without a doubt, Sullivan County, a 986-squaremile diamond of countryside escalloped with hotels, is the enfant terrible of the Catskills. It is neither the largest of the four Catskill counties (Delaware and Ulster are bigger, Greene smaller), nor the highest (Ulster, the local Mount Everest, is 4,204 feet tall in one spot), yet it has, nevertheless, experienced the greatest rampage of construction and covered the most architectural distance.

If the sum of $101 billion could still startle us, President Eisenhower's recent suggestion of a national ten-year road-building program costing this amount would certainly have done so. But when the sum was divided by ten, it didn't seem impossible. The need is great.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Keep lawn mower blades sharp and properly adjusted for the weekly cutting. Do not mow lawns too short--one and one-half inches is minimum, two and one-half inches preferable for a thick turf without crabgrass. The first crabgrass is appearing and to prevent more, spray the lawn now with Crag Herbicide 1.

THE handy little 6-foot steel measuring tape is an important part of every tool kit, but there are some times when it is just too short. To simplify problems of marking large areas, a new, longer measuring tape has been introduced.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Jim Wilson snapped Baltimore's four-game losing streak with five-hit pitching that enabled the Orioles to defeat Washington tonight, 5--1. Johnny Schmitz suffered his first defeat after three victories as the result of a twelve-hit attack that included Hoot Evers' fourth home run.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 7 (UP)--Former President Truman turns a robust and vigorous 71 tomorrow. He will celebrate the birthday by presiding over the ground-breaking of the Harry S. Truman Library.

NOT all of our literary expatriots returned home during the great Depression. Some stayed on and ranged over a Europe broader and more tragic than the terrace of the Dome. Among these was Kay Boyle, who has spent most of her adult life on the old Continent, married there, had children there.

Placement directors at New York City's four municipal colleges, noting a peak demand for graduates in the liberal arts, have prepared ten rules designed to help undergraduates find jobs. These are: As a freshman begin a serious study of the field of occupations --there are 40,000.

IN 1904 the English publishers of Baedeker's Handbooks, "in response to repeated requests from British and American tourists," brought out a "Handbook to the United States." It is out of date, out of fashion and out of print; but in all other ways it is probably still the best 760-page combination of guidebook, commentary and appreciation of the United States around.

Record-breaking performances by Charley Pratt, Leu Moore and Jim Doulin sparked Manhattan College to its sixth straight team title in the twenty -second annual Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships yesterday.

IN 1947, when THE NOTEBOOKS OF HENRY JAMES came out, I confess I only borrowed the book because it was a prohibitive $7. For months I kept it beside my bed and, whenever I felt like it, opened it to a random entry.

TIME and people wear down gardens. At the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park, where the Metropolitan Museum of Art's medieval collections are housed, this truism was becoming evident in the garden surrounding the walls.

A business built on confidence will help brighten Mother's Day for thousands of Americans today. In Berlin last week a G. I. wired an order for delivery of a dozen roses today to his mother in New York.

Lieut. Gen. Hubert R. Harmon, superintendent of the newly established United States Air Force Academy, will visit Columbia University tomorrow and Tuesday to study teaching methods at Teachers College and Columbia College.

AS the tremendously impressive accomplishment of climbing the world's highest mountain after thirty years of struggle sinks into its place in time and history, the mountain itself remains pretty much as it was.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Unification of the two labor federations is all but accomplished. Only the most unexpected and extraordinary event could interfere.
THAT persistent and tireless wanderer of the beaches, the surfcaster, is now preparing for his season, and reports from Cape Hatteras to Cape Cod are encouraging.

FOR many years Rockwell Kent has been prominent in artistic, bohemian, and leftish political circles. Now at 73 he has published a gargantuan autobiography which is more than a quarter of a million words long and is illustrated with eight color reproductions besides more than two hundred and fifty drawings, many of them new.

Last week Dr. Albert B. Sabin of the University of Cincinnati's College of Medicine delivered at Atlantic City, N. J., and in New York City a lecture on his recent work with live polio vaccines. The lecture was important because it indicated a new approach to the polio-vaccine problem and because it raised again the question of the relative efficacy of live and dead vaccines.
LOUISVILLE, May 7--William Lee Shoemaker, who won the Kentucky Derby astride Swaps today, is a quiet little man whose earnings are conservatively estimated to be in excess of $150,000 a year.

To the Drama Editor: Re-reading my recent letter to your section, it occurs to me there may be some persons who may have taken my words as a wholesale condemnation of the American National Theatre and Academy, its program and its management. This is not so.

As a direct result of the prospective extension of the Reciprocal Trade Act, New York retail liquor dealers learned last week that the California wine growers are already preparing to increase their prices.

LONDON. WHEN Harold Macmillan moved early this month from the Ministry of Defense to the Foreign Office, he took with him two photographs which have stood on the mantelpiece of the room in which he worked for the last twelve years.

TEACHERS COLLEGE--Nursing A nursing travel course in Europe will be given this summer by the division of nursing education of Teachers College, Columbia University. Countries to be visited will include England, Scotland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Germany, Switzerland and France.

HORSE RACING Swaps, the California speedster, won the eighty-first running of the $152,500 Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs. He defeated the favored Belair Stud's Nashua by a length and a half, with Summer Tan third.

OVER at The Playhouse it is generally conceded that predictions dealing with the long-range durability of "All in One" still would be premature. The novel program of a Leonard Bernstein opera, a Tennessee Williams play and the dancing of Paul Draper, lauded as it was by most of the critics, must yet prove to a large portion of the public that it offers as enjoyable an evening as an orthodox two-act musical or three-act play.

LOS ANGELES--This year a number of projects are under way which bid fair to reshape a considerable part of the landscape of Los Angeles and its environs. To begin with, Hollywood's city fathers have launched an ambitious long-range program to give to their community a little of the glamour it now possesses more in legend than in fact.

WASHINGTON, May 7--On May 1, Stanley N. Barnes observed his second anniversary as head of the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice. During his "anniversary week," that is, between April 27 and May 3, he took on three very tough and powerful adversaries.
Officials of various states reacted differently to yesterday's Federal recommendations to stop inoculations with Salk anti-polio vaccine pending a Federal report expected today.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Washington has begun to awaken uncomfortably these past few weeks to the political reality of neutralist Free Asia.

TAKE a look at your newspaper any day in the year.
