It's a safe bet that you will run across some item reflecting what the King of Siam called "puzzlement" about the pitiful inadequacies or sinister skulduggery of peoples who do not measure up to the standards of life or conduct of the United States midway in the twentieth century.

A luxury-styled beach club is under construction on a sevenacre oceanfront tract at Surfside Avenue and South Essex Street, in Montauk, L. I. Known as the New Montauk Manor Cabana and Surf Club, the property will have a frontage of 500 feet on the beach.

Real estate values in the nation's largest cities and counties showed gains of about $2,000,000,000 in 1954 over the preceding year, according to the National Association of Assessing Officers. The association made a survey of forty-one cities and twenty-six countries with more than 100,000 population.

LONDON, May 7--A common danger, a common heritage and a common objective have forged links that now bind the United States more tightly to Western Europe than at any time in the history of the republic. The danger was and is Russia, the heritage is European civilization, transmitted to the United States by millions of immigrants, English and Poles, Italians and Germans.

BY New York's hopped-up standards of obsolescence, the city's most famous musical structures are ready for the scrap heap. The Metropolitan Opera House was opened in 1883, and Carnegie Hall in 1891. At the ages of 72 and 64, these buildings are considered old. Their life expectancy would seem to be short.

To split or not to split? That stock question has plagued countless corporate officers in this annual meeting season. If it were put to a vote, chances are overwhelmingly in favor of stockholders taking the affirmative.
SOCORRO, N. M., May 5--Reinforcements were called up this week in man's centuries-old battle for livelihood in the world's desert areas.

SINGING in the jazz idiom has not been a particularly flourishing art in recent years, a situation that makes the current appearance of a group of outstanding vocal disks particularly welcome. In at least two instances the material now being issued was recorded a decade ago but it serves as a reminder of the artistry this facet of jazz can produce.

INSECTICIDES will be sprayed during the next several weeks to control the first gypsy moth infestations found in Suffolk County, L. I. This shade tree pest is spreading farther south and west each year.
MIAMI, May 7 (UP)--Wes Santee, America's No. 1 miler, was seven seconds short of the four-minute mile today as he breasted a 12-mile-per-hour breeze in the University of Miami's invitation mile run.

Voters in twenty-five New Jersey municipalities will go to the polls on Tuesday to elect local governing officials. The balloting is restricted to communities with commission, CouncilMayor and Council - Manager forms of government.

AN arm of the Federal Government again is seeking the aid of Hollywood to spread the true word about the United States in Iron Curtain countries. Last week it was learned that the United States Information Agency had requested, through the Motion Picture Association of America, that the major film companies try to send more product to pro-Communist and Communistdominated lands.

NO matter how much they may otherwise differ on matters musical, the three authors listed above are agreed on one thing: no man alive, critic or mortal, could have listened to and judged all the music issued on long-playing records since they first came on the market six years ago.
ALBANY, May 7--The State Thruway Authority plans to spend nearly $100,000 this summer to get motorists off the expressway.

LONDON. ANY American visitor who came to Britain supposing that there was some vast gulf in television taste between the opposite sides of the Atlantic would have a surprise when he saw the topranking program, "Ask Pickles."

THE last time I saw Georgi Konstantinovich Zhukov he was standing with Admiral Kuznetzov the Soviet Navy chief, in one of the halls of Spridonovka Palace in Moscow where the Foreign Office holds its big receptions. Marshal Zhukov was munching a new young cucumber, tender and succulent, with evident relish.
BOSTON, May 7--Miss Helen Sard Hughes, former dean of graduate studies at Wellesley College, died today in Deaconess Hospital. She was 72 years old.
HONG KONG, April 26--An influential provincial Communist newspaper has acknowledged that Communist China's light industry is in bad shape.
DETROIT, May 7--This week, for the first time, the auto workers union made public some of the key cost figures in its guaranteed annual wage proposal.

LONDON, May 7--Prime Minister Eden urged Britain tonight to vote his government back into power on May 26 for a "supreme effort" to see whether the "main differences" between East and West could be resolved.
Split-level houses are offered by Jersey builders in four colonies scheduled for formal openings today. The developments are at Woodcliff Lake, Closter, Colonia and Fair Lawn.

For the first time in nearly a month the stock market last week failed to establish a new high mark since 1929. Instead, stocks were under pressure until the latter part of the week, when they rallied to recover earlier losses.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia, the leader in the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament, defeated Francisco Benko of Argentina in a thirteenth-round game yesterday, according to a report from Argentina news sources.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 7-- Delightful weather drew twentyeight starters for the official opening of the yacht racing season on Long Island Sound today.

MAYBE it is almost as brutal to refer to a gentleman's age as it is to make public comment on a lady's accumulated years. But a steady observer of the movies cannot help but note with some surprise the number of actors of unmistakable seniority who are getting lots of work in films these--days and we don't mean as cracked or creaking ancients.

PARIS, May 7--The foreign ministers of the seven nations in the Western European Union met tonight to organize their defensive alliance. After dining in the British Embassy here, the ministers went into formal session for the first time as the Council of the Western European Union, the supreme governing body of the organization.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Unfair labor practice charges filed under the Taft-Hartley Act are on the rise. This is true of complaints against both unions and employers.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- There were increasing indications today that a month's delay in Salk polio vaccinations would be recommended tomorrow by the Public Health Service pending a thorough recheck on all vaccine now in stock.

"If I were you--" the advertising man says to the client. "But you're not," the client replies. Consider now the story of two advertising men who became the client. The two are Robert H. Stivers, 36 years old, and Robert W. Young Jr., 32.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 7-- A benevolent combination of rain and sun has brought Iowa's early spring crops up in good health and has left the ground in ideal condition for later plantings.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 7-- Findings that indicate the use of carefully controlled diets may lead to marked improvements in infants suffering from phenylketonuria, an inherited mental disease, have been reported here.

FROM 1914, the date of the publication of his first enormous, magenta-covered periodical. "Blast," to the appearance of this novel in 1954 in England, Wyndham Lewis has stood as one of the gigantic, but isolated, figures of modern letters.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 28-- Turkey is striving to reduce the appalling human price she now pays for rapid industrialization.

One of the most dramatic episodes in medical history--the nationwide offensive to wipe out the scourge of poliomyelitis--came suddenly yesterday to a state of suspension. Washington called for a halt, temporarily at least, in the program of mass inoculation with the Salk vaccine, and promised further word today.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Civilian employment averaged 61,200,000 in 1954, the Census Bureau, Department of Commerce, said today in its annual report on the labor force.
TOKYO, May 7 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama's Democratic party urged today the merger of Japan's conservative political forces. The party promised to dissolve itself if necessary to attain that goal.

There is some danger in conditions such as the present one in Vietnam of losing sight of fundamentals. Incidents and episodes make news, as do personalities. These, however, are only the trees and they should not be allowed to obscure the forest.

AVIRTUAL horticultural revolution is taking place among the races of rhododendron. Sparked by certain far-seeing enthusiasts and aided by plant collectors and breeders (both amateur and professional) the future of the rhododendron for American gardens seems assured.

WHEN the section of the New York Thruway north from Suffern in Rockland County fifteen miles to Harriman is opened--authorities now fix the date as May 27--the high-visibility, four-lane thoroughfare will stretch 397 miles across the state to the outskirts of Buffalo, and its first season as a virtually state-wide super-service to holiday motorists will be under way.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 7 --A plan to promote mutual knowledge and understanding among nations was announced here today as part of the function of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty.

Before the makers of U. S. foreign policy there lay last week a panorama of change, of guarded hope. A new phase in the struggle between the free and the Communist nations appeared to have begun. These were the phases that had preceded it as the struggle unfolded in the wake of World War II:
Foundations are going in for a Bronx building that will add 126 apartments to the growing supply of modern housing accommodations along the Grand Concourse.

TO THE EDITOR: READING Harvey Breit's comments on August Kubizek's "The Young Hitler I Knew" brought to my mind an incident involving H. R. TrevorRoper and another of Hitler's relics. I thought you may like to hear about it.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Government should be able to afford a "substantial" tax reduction next year if major increases in expenditures can be avoided, according to a study published today by the Committee for Economic Development.

SEATTLE--One hundred and fifty years ago the Pacific Northwest was claimed for the United States by Meriwether Lewis and William Clark. In 1805 President Thomas Jefferson's Corps of Discovery struggled through a narrow defile called the Lolo Trail in the Bitterroot Mountains of Montana and northern Idaho.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The Rural Electrification Administration celebrates its twentieth anniversary birthday May 11, contending it has led the way in carrying electricity to all but about 5 per cent of the nation's farms.

BONN, May 7--Has Soviet Russia's attitude on world problems really changed? This is the key problem occupying the minds of diplomats and foreign affairs officials in Vienna, Berlin and here, interviewed by this reporter during the past week.

WHEN "The Family of Man" photographic exhibition closes at 7 P. M. today (its doors having opened at 1 P. M.), it will have run up the greatest attendance record at the Museum of Modern Art since the 1940 "Italian Masters" show.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Czechoslovak democratic political refugees, and all refugees from behind the Iron Curtain, are undoubtedly very grateful to the great American newspapers for unanimously challenging the Soviet attempt to "liquidate" in Austria the displaced persons and refugees who escaped Bolshevik persecution from their countries of origin.
MOSCOW, May 7 (Reuters)-- The Presidium took its decision after a speech by Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov.
OTTAWA--About 7,000,000 tourists came to Canada from the United States during 1954. They left behind them some 300,000,000 United States dollars worth 97 Canadian cents each.
The shop steward school of Local 856, International Longshoremen's Association, last week reached the half-way mark of its course and already it is being hailed as a pattern for the port.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago this week John Masefield was named Poet Laureate of England. It was an understandable choice. Yeats, whom Masefield would have been among the first to acknowledge as a greater poet, was still alive, but he was an Irishman.

DANIKLLA, the heroine of "House of Dolls," does not remain in mind as a fictional character but as an actual person, and this record of her life remains as real as the diary of Anne Frank's life. Like Anne Frank, Daniella's last wish was for the hidden notebook, containing her inmost thoughts, to be passed on.

PARIS, May 7--Military unification of the West and of Western Europe, sought for more than four years, was achieved this week, so far as this could be done by ratification of the treaties authorizing West Germany to rearm and to join the North Atlantic alliance.
THAT dogwood are fast coming into bloom along highways and byways in this region will come as no surprise to home owners whose single lawn specimens may have been fully out for a week now.

Canadian and American business interests, in a joint venture, are sponsoring the first merchandise mart in Canada. It will be built in the center of Winnipeg, in the Province of Manitoba. Winnipeg is the market city of Western Canada and is about 450 miles from Minneapolis.
PARIS, May 7--Five days of diplomatic conference of the Atlantic Alliance began here today with a long but inconclusive discussion of Indochina by the leaders of the three principal Western powers.

HIS name was Biarn Turner and he was a tall, gangling, sad-faced Lincolnesque youth who "cast the long shadow of a man." And as he walked into little Delphi, down in the bootheel of Missouri, so is he likely to walk into your heart.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7--A well-posted source said today that Boxer Harold Johnson had not been drugged but that he might have become dizzy from nose drops he used shortly before last night's fight. The source declined to be named.

CHICAGO, May 7 (UP)--Harvey Kuenn and Al Kaline each belted four hits today to lead Detroit to victory over the Chicago White Sox, 7-1. Steve Gromek allowed only five hits as he recorded his fifth triumph of the season.

MUSIC is about to take to the country for the summer and a trend that emerges clearly from advance announcements is that this year the tangy, brassy note of jazz will play a larger role than previously in the nation's summer music.
The Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of Tuesday night's performance of "Damn Yankees" at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 7 (UP)--George Moore of Detroit knocked out John Johnson of the Army at 2:58 of the second to win the heavyweight division of the National Amateur Athletic Union championships here tonight.

SOUTH COVENTRY, Conn. --Nathan Hale, who was born in this village on June 6, 1755, and executed by the British twenty-one years later in New York as a spy for the cause of the American Revolution, is to be widely honored next month in a series of bicentennial programs.

ELEMENT 101-- Element 101 (mendelevium), not found in nature, has been produced in the University of California by Albert Ghiorso, Bernard G. Harvey, G. R. Choppin and S. G. Thompson, research chemists, and Glenn T. Seaborg, Nobel laureate. It is intensely radioactive.

Former Prime Minister Winston Churchill, reporting to Parliament after Yalta, used these words: "There will be a place one day for Germans in the community of nations." He added: "But only when the traces of nazism and militarism have been effectively and finally extirpated."

NEWPORT, R. I.--Inhabitants of this smallest of the forty-eight states now boldly assert that they welcomed the first summer tourists on the North American continent. Aware of the storm this is likely to stir up, they have erected a wall of documentary evidence that could stretch from here to Wolfeboro, N. H.
HARTFORD, May 7 -- The General Assembly, which has only a month before its constitutional closing deadline, is starting to tackle major legislation.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 7--Several walks and an error by the losing pitcher. Charlie Shaw, cost Williams College a ball game today. The visiting Amherst nine triumphed 5--0, in the first Little Three contest of the season between the two teams.

"I STARTED to study piano when I was 11. I did it because my parents wanted me to and because I lived in the kind of society where children just did. It was years before I realized how much music could mean to me."

IN this tale of a woman fated to embody the dreams of others while failing to find expression for her own, Hilda Vaughan returns to the land of her fathers. The scene is Wales. The heroine is a figure from the Celtic Twilight, strayed into the late Victorian era and finally finding reality at the end of a long life--in modern times.

THE motoring vacationist will find fewer detours and delays on the nation's main highroads this summer, particularly if he is willing to trade cash for time and use the ever-widening network of toll roads which account for the bulk of present construction.

THE oldest argument among song writers is, which is more important, the words or the music? and the oldest argument among bridge players is, which is more important, the bidding or the play? The bridge argument, however, has never been a very serious one.

TO THE EDITOR: The enigma of modern Russian history was most clearly interpreted by Thomas P. Whitney in "The Kremlin's Big Problem -- the Peasant" (April 24). The ceaseless struggle of the peasant against his political superiors has been a keynote of Russian problems since the mid-seventeenth century.

Midnight struck for the Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday. After masquerading as bold, bad buccaneers through a six-game winning streak, the Pittsburghers were exposed for the callow youths that they really are by an aroused Giant team.

THOUGH the familiar bronze, maroon and brown of chrysanthemums will not be seen until harvest, low is the time to lay the groundwork for this colorful fall 'loom. For spring is the season when chrysanthemums are beginning to send up soft green growth which may soon be made into cuttings.
Mrs. William B. Jaffe will serve as chairman of special events for the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund for the 1955-56 season.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Still rolling in high gear, the Dodgers and Carl Erskine beat the Phils and Robin Roberts, 6--3, tonight for the Brooks ninth straight triumph. The Brooks have won twenty of their twenty-two games.

SOONER or later most historians ponder the texture of the historical fabric itself. Oscar Handlin, Professor of History at Harvard, has reflected on the subject no less vigorously than his confreres and perhaps more purposefully --as the publication of this volume attests.
TOKYO, May 7--Japan has just gone through the annual "Golden Week" in which every other day is a national holiday.

MYRTLE BEACH, S. C.-- This coastal community, rimmed by its smooth, wide strand, warmed by the near-by Gulf Stream, boasting one of the highest sunshine quotients in the nation, is capping a decade of solid growth as a spring and summer resort with a new boom in tourist facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) --Senator Allen J. Ellender said today that "it would be a mistake" for the Democrats to try to push through the Senate this year a bill scrapping the Eisenhower -Benson farm price program.

POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD announced last week that a 3-cent stamp (color not yet announced) commemorating the sesquicentennial of the discovery of New Hampshire's famous landmark, "The Old Man of the Mountains," will be issued "on the occasion of the celebration recalling the discovery, at Franconia, N. H., on June 21."
Wider cooperation among community agencies to speed the rehabilitation of injured workers was recommended last week by Angela R. Parisi, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board.
Western Europe is showing increasing signs of "going American," according to Irwin A. Vladimir, president of Irwin Vladimir Co., international advertising agency.

Within fifteen years, educator predict, the nation's colleges and universities will double in size. The present record 2,500,000 enrollment will go to 5,000,000 by 1970, according to the best available statistics. The pressures upon the entire system of higher education will be immeasurably increased.

A CHANGE of scene is indicated for Olive York, when her parents are killed in an airplane crash, and the boy she has always loved plans to marry another. At the suggestion of a friend, Olive comes to Yonder Key, a tiny island off the Florida coast, to recuperate.

PARIS, May 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer arrived today to claim the seats of the Federal Republic of Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Western European Union. He also will submit his Government's views on a four-power East-West conference to the Western Big Three foreign ministers.
LOUISVILLE, May 7--"He's an observant horse," said Mickey Tenney the other morning. "He notices everything." The slow-speaking Tenney should know because he trains Swaps, the colt from California.
Rabbi Israel Goldstein proposed yesterday that all unresolved problems between East and West be frozen for ten years during which concerted efforts would be made to seek permanent peaceful solutions.

BOSTON, May 7--The Red Sox took an early lead at Fenway Park today, but they were unable to remain ahead. The Yankees, noted for their strong finishes, erased a 5-0 deficit and won, 9--6, with a three-run uprising in the ninth.

To the Music Editor: I FEEL it will be with Georges Enesco, who died on Wednesday in Paris, as it has been with Bela Bartok--that his deepest contributions to our culture will be appreciated only gradually as the fruit of his life work comes to be heard by an ever-widening public.
New York's pre-eminent position as a center of world trade is a guarantee of sound realty values here, in the opinion of George W. Warnecke, head of the mortgage brokerage firm bearing his name.
Hofstra upset St. John's, the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference leader, 5--3, yesterday at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens.

WHEN the nation's scheduled airlines started operating reduced-rate tourist service seven years ago, they were quite hesitant about it. Looking at their business figures today they must wonder why they were so skeptical.
Operation Cue, last week's atomic test program of the Federal Civil Defense Administration at Yucca Flat, Nev., has focussed national attention on the need for major changes in civilian defense.
Union leaders are showing little eagerness to become capitalists, despite a rapid expansion in union wealth.

A HIGH-SPEED sixty-second film for the Polaroid Land camera that permits one-minute picture taking by ordinary household illumination or similar "available -light" conditions, will be placed on sale tomorrow, according to announcement by Polaroid Corporation of Cambridge, Mass.
The Association of Ship Brokers and Agents has begun work on a new plan to extend formal recognition to individual American ship brokers.

HOLLYWOOD. COMING close on the heels of the underwater trend, the Biblical cycle and remakes of old operettas, the biggest news in Hollywood now is the swing toward biographies of show people, which, when it has run its course, will have come up with the lives-- dull, exciting, or fanciful -- of such diverse theatrical personalities as Benny Goodman and Marjorie Lawrence, DeSylva, Brown and Henderson and Ruth Etting, Eddy Duchin and Evelyn Thaw.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7--Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. expressed confidence today that United States fliers imprisoned in Communist China would be set free.

HOLLYWOOD. IF the nascent film production of "Guys and Dolls" reeks with authentic New York atmosphere it will be due in no small measure to the presence of a performer affecting the name of Joe McTurk.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 7-- The Boston Post Road may not be Broadway yet, but the six miles of it in this town is said to be the brightest, whitest way in all New England.

NEVADA, Iowa. IN central Iowa's Story County, the cultivating disks are slicing into the rich black earth as local farmers get their fields ready for another year's crop. In the barns and farrowing stalls the new issues of spring pigs are constantly petitioning their mothers for more food, and in the feed lots the steers, bulging from a winter's stuffing of corn and vitamins, are being groomed for marketing in the weeks ahead.

The economic outlook for the home-building industry this year will be discussed at the annual spring conference of the Long Island Home Builders Institute at the Garden City Hotel on Wednesday. The topic will be examined at both the local and national levels.

THERE is an old song entitled "Whispering Hope," and that just about expresses the state of mind of week-end handymen right now. They hope, but they are only whispering about it, that good weather is here to stay and that various outdoor projects, long delayed, can be taken in hand.
An off-duty policeman eight months on the force killed a thug Friday night during a hold-up attempt in Brooklyn. Two other men were arrested on a robbery charge.
FORT WORTH, May 8 (AP) -- Chandler Harper conquered erratic irons today to take first money in the $25,000 Colonial national invitational golf tournament. He closed with a twoover-par 72 for 276.
The National Broadcasting Company has taken steps to align itself directly with established theatre groups in order to obtain and develop stage properties for television.
SIMLA, India, May 8--Thirteen Asian nations and colonies meet here tomorrow to talk about a problem common to all of them: how to get the most out of every dollar of United States aid.

PARIS, May 8 -- The foreign ministers of the United State, Britain and France concentrated their attention today on a conference with the Soviet Union and the almost completed Austrian State treaty. The treaty is regarded as a prelude to such a conference.
MIAMI, Fla., May 8 (AP)--This Florida area had today two true tall tales of the sea.

THE Washington Post and Times-Herald, which owns Station WTOP-TV in Washington, undertook yesterday to offer a television documentary on the ten years since V-E Day. To put it as gently as possible, it was not the Fourth Estate's afternoon.
A deficit of $26,000,000 in the care of ward and clinic patients was rolled up last year by the eighty-two voluntary nonprofit hospitals affiliated with the United Hospital Fund here.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP)-- The Washington Senators won a free-slugging game, 15--7, today after dropping the opener to the Baltimore Orioles, 4--3.

CHICAGO, May 8--Directors of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company said today that the company planned to issue 111,836 additional shares of common stock. They are to be offered to stockholders on the basis of one additional share for each ten held.
Following are excerpts from the report "Perspectives on Delinquency Prevention" prepared by Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein. It will be submitted to the Board of estimate at its Thursday meeting.
EAST HAMPTON. L. I., May 8--An airplane doesn't have to come off an assembly line. Eight Long Island flying enthusiasts are building one with their hands.

MASSENA, N. Y., May 8-- President Eisenhower will stand on a platform along the mighty St. Lawrence River here late next month and press a button that will officially start work on the $105,000,000 Seaway.

Following are the texts of statements issued in Washington on the polio vaccine by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, the Surgeon General, as carried by The Associated Press and The New York Times: Official Statement I know that the American people are concerned over recent developments with respect to the nation-wide poliomyelitis vaccination program.
The city's program for vaccinating school children against poliomyelitis faces new delay-- past next Monday's target starting date.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 8--Tulagi Cye, the black and white English setter who won the inaugural New Yorker stake here yesterday, added the amateur shooting dog honors today. The Southern New York Field Trial Club thus completed its annual three-day spring trials.

Following the United States Public Health Service recommendation for delaying polio vaccine inoculation programs, press service reports gave this picture of reactions by states yesterday: ALABAMA -- Planned to begin second round of injections, originally scheduled for May 16, as soon as vaccine becomes available.
THE first of two concerts presenting this year's award winners of the Fromm Music Foundation took place Saturday evening at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
LOUISVILLE, May 8 (AP) -- Swaps, the Kentucky Derby winner, headed back to California today.
WASHINGTON, May 8--The Government urged today that the suspension of inoculations with the Salk anti-poliomyelitis vaccine be extended.
The budget of the Waterfront Commission for fiscal 1956 will fall below the present $2,000,000 mark despite a personnel increase in excess of 50 per cent, it was learned over the weekend.
An offering of 40,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 50,000 shares of class A common stock of Augusta (Ga.) Newspapers, Inc., will be made today.
For a preview of what your old age may be like, survey the way you fill your life outside of working hours.
ROME, May 8--The fate of Premier Mario Scelba's coalition Government, trembling in the balance, will be decided this week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8--No report had been received here tonight from the cease-fire observers on the clash in Kashmir. A message was expected soon.

The Giants concluded their first long home stand of the year at the Polo Grounds yesterday with more than five hours of strenuous struggling. But the monumental task of climbing above the 500 mark still remained unfinished business.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The Dodgers ran their winning streak to ten games with a 9-8 victory over the Phillies today. An uprising by the Phils in the last two innings threatened to end the streak at nine.
PARIS, May 8 -- Herbert Blankenhorn, career diplomat under three German regimes, will represent West Germany as permanent delegate and Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The Fund for the Advancement of Education announced yesterday the granting of $850,000 in fellowship awards to 165 public high school teachers.
The problems presented by the city's "segregated" schools will be studied by a special commission appointed by the Board of Education.
Japan's role in the Orient-- past, present and future--was challenged yesterday by a chema-and-chogori-clad college girl from South Korea.
Nine adolescents, six juveniles and four adults were taken into court yesterday as a result of quick police action that blocked what appeared to be an attempt to "crash" a house party in Brooklyn.

BOSTON, May 8--The Yankees, after blanking the Red Sox, 5--0, at Fenway Park today, found themselves in a dilemma. They didn't know whether to applaud more for Bob Grim's return to form or for their rout of a two-season jinx named Willard Nixon.

The three-story building at 194-96 Broadway, near John Street, has been sold by Henry Goelet to an investor in a deal negotiated by Robert T. Lawrence, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company. Mr. Goelet bought the property last summer, at which time he gave a net lease running to 2011 on the property to the Childs restaurant chain.

One of the matters awaiting the attention of Roger L. Stevens, who gets back today from a five-week trip in Europe, is the status of "The Empress." Contracts already have been drawn for him to tie up the new Elaine Carrington comedy, revolving around Theodora, who cut quite a swath in her day as the Byzantine ruler.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., May 8 -- The historical "George Washington oak" in front of the Elks Club here is an American ash.

BONN, Germany, May 8--Germans from both parts of their divided country joined today to honor one of the greatest of their poets, Johann Christoph Friedrich von Schiller, who died 150 years ago tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (UP)-- Hobie Landrith's second home run of the game gave Cincinnati a 4-3 victory over Chicago today. The Cubs won the first game, 5--3, with Bob Speake's two-run homer in the eighth the deciding blow.
Senator Theodore F. Green declared here yesterday that the Eisehhower Administration had "sabotaged" the Refugee Relief Act.

Three of the seven major New York newspapers had gains and four had losses in the first four months of 1955. The total for the latest period was 14,292,071 lines, against 14,334,138 a year before, which works out as a decline of 0.29 per cent. The figures are based on a study of Media Records data.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 8 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem took to the radio today with his campaign against Chief of State Bao Dai.

Robert Haas' return to Burgundy earlier this spring, he told us the other day, reinforced his previous opinion that the great wines of lesser years may be more interesting than the lesser wines of great years.
ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP)--Lefthander Warren Spahn blanked the St. Louis Cardinals through the last six innings today as the Milwaukee Braves sent the Redbirds to their seventh straight defeat, 6--2.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 8-- Some members of the American Psychoanalytic Association were charged today with violating its standards.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8-- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology dedicated today a $2,000,000 campus and religious center of remarkable design.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 8--With the skill of a Missouri farmer ditching a meadow, former President Truman wielded a gold-plated spade this afternoon to start work on the Harry S Truman Library, Inc., here.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 8-- The American Assembly declared today that farmers should rely more on their own initiative and net income and less on Federal price supports and production controls in solving agriculture's economic ills.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 8-- Ronald Lo Presti of Williamstown, Mass., won first prize in the Koussevitsky Foundation composition competition, established in recognition of the twenty-fifth annual Festival of American Music of the Eastern School of Music.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, warned Congress today that a bill to give an 8.8 per cent pay increase to 500,000 postal workers faced an almost certain veto by President Eisenhower.
Readers of Jerome S. Miller's new book are going to be equipped to give insurance salesmen a mighty hard time. The main problem may be to find salesmen who know as much as the prospects.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8--The valet in the jockey room picked up the bouquet of roses that Willie Shoemaker had carelessly dropped on the bench. He crammed the flowers into Willie's zipper bag. Conn McCreary, a big grin on his map-of-Ireland face, impishly reached in and plucked out one rose.
Seamen recognize that something ails the American merchant marine and allied maritime industries, and they will contribute their share toward any "legitimate" corrective program.
A minister told his congregation yesterday that "the only job for you to do is maintain an avenue to Christ."
PARIS, May 8--Want to visit Russia this summer and see the sights in Moscow and Leningrad? Apparently it is going to be easy, if you are a Frenchman. You also must have the money, of course.

The modern mother must cope with so many contradictory theories of child raising that she has lost sincerity and spontaneity in this occupation, Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New, York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, observed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last fall your paper carried an interesting series of articles by Robert Alden on the hurricane prediction problem. This was followed, as I recall, by an editorial in which you pointed out the need for more research in the general field of weather prediction.

VIENNA, May 8--The ambassadors of the four occupation powers will meet tomorrow with representatives of Austria for what is expected to be their next to the last discussion of the draft of a state treaty for Austria. It is hoped to reach agreement, at least in principle, over the few questions still undecided and to devote Tuesday to disposal of details.

Following is the text of a statement yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, prior to a United States Public Health Service announcement in Washington: The National Foundation is interested in the proper manufacture, testing and administration of the Salk vaccine and in its most effective use to prevent paralytic polio.
Twenty companies shared top honors in the New York Shipping Association's annual safety contest, Alexander P. Chopin, secretary of the organization, announced yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 8-- The billion dollar economic development plan worked out jointly by the United States and Brazil is half paralyzed.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 8-- Tennessee lawyers are debating among themselves an unusual politico-legal controversy--Gov. Frank G. Clement's temporary appointment of his father, Robert S. Clement of Dickson, Tenn., to the State Supreme Court.
Highways dangerously coated by slippery rain and clogged by spurts of heavy traffic took a big toll in dead and injured in this area yesterday.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., May 8 (AP)--The United States Air Force, which bombed Hiroshima nearly ten years ago, today flew in twenty-five Japanese girls scarred by that bombing.

CARNEGIE HALL was filled with the warmth and vitality of gospel singing at a Mothers' Day concert yesterday afternoon. And the singer who filled it the fullest was the star of the afternoon: Mahalia Jackson, a New Orleans contralto with an enormous voice.

One of the most constructive developments in recent times as to higher education is the partnership of interest more and more realized between the private college or university and the business corporation. At a dinner in this city tonight college presidents from all over the state and corporation officials and others interested will meet for a discussion of problems growing out of this partnership and ways of being mutually helpful.

PARIS, May 8--On the tenth anniversary of V-E Day the international political situation has entered a recognizable new phase. Balance of power on this Continent has been achieved. The dynamic forces of Soviet expansion are now offset by democratic resistance to such expansion.
William M. Hunt, a partner in the Putnam Management Company, has been elected a director of the International Utilities Corporation.
LESTER TRIMBLE and Kaljo Raid were the gifted composers whose music was introduced on Saturday night at the final Composers Forum of the season at Columbia University's McMillin Theatre.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 --The Screen Actors Guild has negotiated a collective bargaining contract with the Du Mont television network for actors, singers and announcers who work in filmed TV programs made by the company.

Sizable reductions in off-season Atlantic air travel rates will go into effect with the institution of the family fare plan, the International Air Transport Association has announced. The lower fares, applicable to first-class and tourist services, will become effective Nov. 1.
The Sunderland eleven of the English League opened an eightgame tour of this country and Canada yesterday by beating an All-Star team from the American Soccer League.
ALL, through next week, from a little before midnight until dawn, players for Warner Brothers will enact "Miracle in the Rain" in St. Patrick's Cathedral, mostly before St. Andrew's altar.
On Jan. 15, 1953, the rediscount rate was advanced from 1 3/4 to 2 per cent at the New York and seven, other Reserve Banks. A week later the other four regional banks followed suit.
JERUSALEM, May 8--Four hundred thousand organized workers and their wives voted today on management of the Histadrut, Israel's labor federation.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP)-- Representative Percy Priest, Democrat of Tennessee, said today his House Commerce Committee would begin drafting natural gas legislation this week but he did not yet know whether it would exempt independent producers from Federal regulation.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 8-- An Iraqi official said today that Pakistan would join the IraqiTurkish-British pact within a month. He added that Iran was expected to follow suit by midsummer.

CHICAGO, May 8--Bullish sentiment crystalized suddenly this last week after extremely bullish reports on Southwest crop conditions, which especially affected the new crop deliveries. The fact that shipments of wheat from Chicago have continued heavy, with no deliveries so far this month on May contracts, inspired active short covering of the current month contracts.

Shades of Paul Bunyan! The ninth annual Woodsmen's WeekEnd competition is to be held at Kimball Union Academy next Saturday and Sunday. It looms as a giant undertaking. Even the fabulous Bunyan might nave been awed at the spectacle.
A group of industrialists and prominent constitutional lawyers announced yesterday their continued opposition to the Bricker amendment to limit the President's treaty-making power.

On both sides of the Pacific there is a fresh amount of working and planning for a closer integration of the free Asian countries. At present some of these are neighbors only in the geographical sense. There is a need to bring them closer together in other aspects.

MANCHESTER, England, May 8--The selection of a Bevanite and fellow traveler as a candidate for Parliament over one of the ablest Laborite former ministers has shaken the solidity of the Labor front in Manchester and the critical area around it.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 8-- Nationalist China has notified all governments with which it maintains diplomatic relations that the offshore islands have been mined.
Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck predicted yesterday that Governor Harriman would ask the next Legislature to pass the income tax "humanizing" amendments that he vetoed last week.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Maxwell M. Rabb, Secretary to President Eisenhower's Cabinet, said today that enlightened public opinion was eradicating prejudice and discrimination.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You have done such steady good work over the years in protecting our Central Park from all manner of ruinous encroachments that I am sure you will do the same now for Washington Square.
ROME, May 8 (AP) -- Enrique Morea of Argentina and Italy's Giuseppe Merlo gained the semifinal round of the Rome international tennis tournament.
Prompt action by the city to set up a "priority program" to curb juvenile delinquency was promised yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

Week Ended May 6, 1955 British sterling moved irregularly last week. Mainly on the basis of higher London cables in foreweek, the pound climbed to $2.80 1/16, highest since last November. At this peak offerings proved ample enough to whittle that improvement back to $2.79 27/32, on Friday. Forwards widened with later softness of spot, and transferable sterling closed at $2.77 1/8-$2.77 1/4.

MACASSAR, Celebes, May 8 --The high walls of old Fort Rotterdam here are a tangle of weeds, drying laundry and crumbling stone. Its moat, once wide and deep, is cluttered with the refuse of peddlers who sell their wares near by.
Shipowners drew cargoes and profits in increasing volume last week as the charter market continued to gain.
LITTLE NECK, L. I., May 8-- The fifty-third Annual Dog Show of the Long Island Kennel Club will be held on May 22 on the horse show grounds of the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley.

Before a vacationer loads herself down with souvenirs from faraway lands, it would be wise to inspect the little shops of Eighth Street in Greenwich Village. She need not worry about breakage or customs duty when she shops in her own back yard.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP)--Nellie Fox made his two hits of the day key blows in the Chicago White Sox' sweep of a double-header today. The Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 5--4, in eleven innings and 1--0 in the second game.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 8-- Stanley Ogilvy completed a weekend double today as he sailed Flame to victory in the Star Class race in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Mothers' Day regatta.
Miss Pauline Conrad, a retired bookkeeper, called herself a "fuddy-duddy old maid" last January when she set out from her Hollywood, Calif., home to see the United States.

Cotton prices in New York improved last week. Much of the strength in futures contracts was attributed to strength in the May delivery. By the close of trading Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange prices were up 10 to 64 points over the close for the preceding week.
One cannot build a home based on a card table, a can opener and a cocktail shaker, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell advised in a Mother's Day sermon yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) --The Department of Justice has vetoed the proposed merger of two large cement corporations on the ground that it would "tend to create a monopoly," it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The United States Government hopes to halt deterioration of economic conditions in many of the countries of free Asia in fiscal 1956 with a program for $1,451,000,000 in non-military aid.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 8-- Following are the findings of the American Assembly on the perspectives and prospects of American agriculture: 1. There was general agreement that the United States can meet its domestic food and fiber requirements at reasonable prices for the foreseeable future, providing we have intelligent land use.
CLEVELAND, May 8 (AP)--Al Al Smith hit three home runs and Al Rosen and Dave Pope one apiece today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 9--6 and 2--1.

PITTSBURGH, May 8--If steelmaking continues at the present rate, there is a good chance that the first half of this year will set a new production record. The present peak, a trifle less than 58,000,000 tons, was set during the first half of 1953.
The New School for Social Research at 66 West Twelfth Street announced plans yesterday for a $2,500,000 expansion program, its first development project in twenty-five years.
TRENTON, May 8--Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest gave a repeat performance at the Trenton Kennel Club show today. The boxer was selected for best in show to regain an honor he had taken in 1952.

PARIS, May 8--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is urging his United States, British and French colleagues to seek the reunification of Germany within the framework of a general European settlement with the Soviet Union.

Passing of the Palaces In common with many speaking with more authority, this corner has viewed with modified rapture what is happening to our urban landscape as tall glass cases for offices multiply, with the main concern provision of maximum rental space.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The National Planning Association urged the President today to name a special nonmilitary defense commission to coordinate all types of civil defense planning aimed at withstanding atomic attack.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is noted for conferences closed to the press, at which even department officials must be admitted by badge.
The Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams told his congregation at the Park Avenue Christian Church yesterday that it must invite two Yorkville gangs to use the church's recreation rooms.

LONDON, May 8--Having regard to the unsettling influence of the general election, which will tend to increase in the next three weeks, and another wave of strikes, of which the Yorkshire coal stoppage is by far the most disturbing, the stock markets last week gave fairly good account of themselves.
FOR its first week-end at the ANTA Theatre the season of ''American Dance," sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation, treated us to two days of solid smorgasbord.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Congressional Democrats projected an economic study today that promises to give them an early stockpile of heavy ammunition for a probable election-year battle over tax reduction.

NEW DELHI, India, May 8-- Twelve Indian soldiers were killed yesterday in a shooting incident between Indian and Pakistani armed police. The shooting occurred near the border of Jammu Province of Kashmir State and West Pakistan.
World Sodality Day was observed yesterday on the campus of Fordham University by 25,000 members and friends of the New York Archdiocesan Federation of Sodalities of Our Lady.

A twelve-story-and-penthouse apartment building is planned at 302 to 312 East Seventieth Street, where Sprain Construction, Inc., Robert Beckley, vice president, has assembled three parcels into a single plot. Julian E. Gordon was the broker.

A family biography of the five Eisenhower brothers has been scheduled for June 23 publication by Farrar, Straus Cudahy under the title "The Great American Heritage." Bela Kornitzer has based his book on interviews with the family.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)-- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that he had "good hopes for the future" because people were now willing to sacrifice as much for peace as to win a war.

Because of adjournments, there were few changes in the positions of most of the leaders in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires yesterday. Only three games were finished in the fourteenth round.

OSCAR HANDLIN, the Harvard Professor of History who won a Pulitzer Prize for his book about the impact of this country on European immigrants, "The Uprooted," has been suffering recently from an occupational hazard of historians--speculation about the nature of history itself. Just as theologians worry about the nature of God and physicists worry about the nature of matter, historians brood about the study of man's past.
BONN, Germany, May 8-- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, who led the Soviet Army that captured Berlin in 1945, talked of friendship for both East and West Germany in that city today.

LIVERPOOL, England, May 7 --The continued existence of a vocal, aggressive and disappointed Bevanite faction within the Labor party reflects in this important area a national situation that could lose the general parliamentary election for the Laborites.

Last summer's hurricanes killed 200 people and caused about $800,000,000 damage to property as they tore into the coasts and back country of our northeastern states. They also confirmed the grim presumption that this part of the country is now definitely in the hurricane zone.

The statesmen of the Western World who are now assembled in Paris will need to find it what it has long been called, the City of Light. They will need all their wisdom, for important decisions have still to be taken. But their presence there is proof that some wisdom has been shown, some progress made, since the end of the Second World War.

Because of adjournments, there were few changes in the positions of most of the leaders in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires yesterday. Only three games were finished in the fourteenth round.

OSCAR HANDLIN, the Harvard Professor of History who won a Pulitzer Prize for his book about the impact of this country on European immigrants, "The Uprooted," has been suffering recently from an occupational hazard of historians--speculation about the nature of history itself. Just as theologians worry about the nature of God and physicists worry about the nature of matter, historians brood about the study of man's past.
BONN, Germany, May 8-- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, who led the Soviet Army that captured Berlin in 1945, talked of friendship for both East and West Germany in that city today.

LIVERPOOL, England, May 7 --The continued existence of a vocal, aggressive and disappointed Bevanite faction within the Labor party reflects in this important area a national situation that could lose the general parliamentary election for the Laborites.

Last summer's hurricanes killed 200 people and caused about $800,000,000 damage to property as they tore into the coasts and back country of our northeastern states. They also confirmed the grim presumption that this part of the country is now definitely in the hurricane zone.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- May wheat advanced today to a new high for the current movement, selling at $2.19 1/4, fo ra gain of about 10 cents in the last week.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,500 head: Market fairly active, butchers fully 25 cents higher, in some instances up more: sows around 25 cents higher: most choice, 190 to 230 pounds

PARIS, May 9--Instead of an international arms production pool, proposed by the French Government, the seven nations of the Western European Union have compromised. They have decided to establish a standing committee instructed to "encourage" agreements on "development, standardization, production and procurement of armaments."

CLEVELAND, May 9 (UP)-- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard's plea for a new trial in the bludgeonslaying of his wife was rejected today by Common Pleas Judge Edward Blythin. He ruled Shepyard's "new evidence" was in "the realm of theory."
LONDON, May 9--Of the thirty-four productions now on view in London theatres eight have come from New York. Some of them have been running for a long time.
LONDON, May 9--Ninety women are among the candidates designated by Britain's political parties to fight for the 630 House of Commons seats at stake in the May 26 general election.

"Southeast Asia Between Two Worlds," an analytical study by Tibor Mende, will be issued late in the summer by Library Publishers. The author, a former member of the foreign staff of The New York Herald Tribune, believes that the people of Southeast Asia will choose neither the American way nor the Communist way of life because neither corresponds to the realities of those peoples.
PARIS, May 9 (Reuters)-- Following are the texts of speeches at the opening session of the North Atlantic Council today: John Foster Dulles, United States This occasion will be long remembered.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation has taken steps to maintain production of jet engines in the event its plants in the metropolitan area should be wiped out by enemy action.

The one-story taxpayer building at 63-34 Austin Street in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by the Crescent Garage Corporation to an investing client of Charles H. Kelman, attorney. The property, on plot 120 by 156 feet, is occupied under lease by the Bonded Ford Service, an automobile agency.

Official bankruptcy came to 237 American business concerns in the week ended last Thursday. That number of failures was reported by Dun Bradstreet yesterday even as the nation was enjoying a full-scale boom.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 --Experimental work being done by the Air Force on airplanes, and the test pilots who try them out will be the subject of a screen drama titled "Toward The Unknown." The film will be produced by Warner Brothers.

Publication of the interim report of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on its March inquiry into the stock market is expected next week. The completed text was delivered to Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, yesterday.

South American Gold and Platinum Company and subsidiaries had record earnings last year of $1,388,314, equal to 85 cents a share, it was announced yesterday by Lewis B. Harder, president. In 1954 net income was $1,063,047, or 65 cents a share.

The world sugar contract climbed to new highs for the current upward move yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was the heaviest of the year. Strength was attributed to continued Russian bids for sugar.

Financial negotiations for the construction of a sister ship for the 36,667 - gross - ton HollandAmerica Line flagship Nieuw Amsterdam are expected to be completed next month, Johannes F. Posthuma, director of the Dutch Recovery Bank, said here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., May 9 (AP)--Ted Williams' wife, Doris, was granted a divorce in circuit court today. After the divorce the former Boston Red Sox slugger said he had not made up his mind about returning to baseball.
YESTERDAY (May 9, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Directed in Executive order abolishment of the Foreign Operations Administration and transfer of its affairs to the State and Defense Departments.

California now is harvesting a bumper crop of avocados and sending large quantities here. As a result, this subtropical fruit with a rich flesh and a nut-like flavor may be had for as little as 15 cents each in some chain stores.
RYE, N. Y., May 9--Al Feminelli, Old Oaks aide, took individual honors in the Westchester Country Club pro-amateur golf with a 33, 36--69 today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture, in a final report based on ginnings, today put last year's cotton crop at 13,679,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group made capital outlay of L226,000,000 ($632,800,000) last year, according to the pamphlet report of the Royal Dutch petroleum Company. This compares with L220,000,000 ($624,000,000) in 1953.

ROME, May 9 (AP)--Giuseppe Merlo scored a stunning 6-0, 8-6, 8-6 victory over top-seeded Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris today to advance to the final round of the Rome international tennis tournament.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 9-- A leading British psychiatrist told the American medical profession tonight that mental patients eventually would be treated outside of hospitals by the family doctor.
The death of George Herrick, a one - time operator of lush gambling establishments around town, was reported yesterday by the police.
An auctioneer will put the 114-year-old Brooklyn Eagle on the block tomorrow with a proposal that the new owner--if one turns up--cut in the employes for half of the pre-tax net profits.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 9--A bespectacled German professor of history in a dark business suit stood with his hands at his sides today beside a United States general and a French general while they saluted the red, gold and black flag of West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 10--President Eisenhower authorized Secretary of State Dulles last night to agree to a meeting between the President and the other Big Four heads of government under certain conditions.

TRENTON, May 9--An investigation of Democratic Hudson County and its twelve municipalities was approved today by the Republican-controlled State Assembly. The inquiry would be conducted by a joint legislative committee at a cost of $100,000.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., May 9-- Two teams tied for first place in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at the Brookville Country Club today.
CHICAGO, May 9--Unionized airline pilots will get pensions under a program with built-in safeguards against inflationary pressures.
Teen-age gangsters kept three courts busy yesterday as civic leaders discussed ways of curbing the city-wide upsurge of juvenile crime and delinquency.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9-- Harvard University and the Smithsonian Institution have agreed to pool their studies of the sun and its effect on the earth.
Mr. Wolfson took full credit yesterday for Mr. Krider's departure from Ward. In a statement issued here, Mr. Wolfson said.

If other cities were to follow the lead of New York City in attracting executive operations, the trend of decentralization of modern cities could be reversed, William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., said yesterday.

All nominating committee designees were returned yesterday in the annual election of the New York Stock Exchange. Harold W. Scott was chosen to serve a second one-year term as chairman of the board of governors.

Senator Bricker's assault on the Constitution in the form of an amendment that is unnecessary, unwise and dangerous has begun again. The indefatigable Senator from Ohio was thwarted last year in his attempt to gut the treatymaking power; but he has returned to the attack with a substantially similar proposal.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The Government is taking no chances that the President be cut off from his Cabinet or the nation's military leaders in the event of a threatened or actual nuclear attack.

National Airlines, Inc., in the quarter ended March 31 attained the highest operating revenues for any three-month period in its twenty-one-year history, G. T. Baker, president, reported yesterday. The total of $16,239,252 was a 26 per cent increase over the $12,861,058 revenues recorded in the similar period a year ago.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday. The close was at net gains of 6 to 37 points (30 cents to $1.85 a bale) led by the strength in the old May contract which expires Thursday.
A father and son overhauling their party fishing boat in Sheepshead Bay were badly burned yesterday afternoon when a gasoline stove exploded.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- An agreement to end one of the longest major railroad strikes in history was reached today.

Fifty-one local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration will receive bids on May 17 on issues of loan notes totaling $96,245,000 for the temporary financing of low-rent projects. The notes will come due variously, some on Sept. 9 and on Dec. 9 of this year and others on June 15 and July 13 of 1956.

In Paris yesterday a newly sovereign Germany with 50,000,000 people and a future army of 500,000 men was formally welcomed into the North Atlantic alliance. The ceremony coincided with the tenth anniversary of the German surrender. To Secretary Dulles this coincidence demonstrated the capacity of the Atlantic peoples to submerge their former differences in the face of the new menace threatening them.

IN a corner room on the second floor of the hospital a man lay dying. His name was Louis Saxl. He was 31 years old and a nuclear physicist. If it hadn't been for the accident he would have gone off to the Bikini atomic bomb tests and when he returned from them he would have married his girl. But now there was no hope for Louis Saxl.
The truck terminal property at the northeast corner of St. Paul's and James Avenues in Jersey City has been sold by Miami Lines to Berkshire Associates, Inc. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 9-- Observers agree that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem has emerged strengthened from the warfare and political maneuverings of the last two weeks. He controls affairs in South Vietnam more closely than at any time since he took office nine months ago.

Some readers may have felt rather gloomy about business conditions after reading a Washington dispatch of May 4. It began by saying: "A conference of Democratic Governors today charged the Eisenhower Administration with complacency toward economic distress."

A well-organized force of 300 firemen, policemen and construction workers labored feverishly into the early morning hours at the Coliseum, where possibly one victim lay buried under hundreds, perhaps thousands, of tons of debris.
The first crew to beat the Navy varsity in four years, Pennsylvania yesterday was accorded the position of favorite in the Eastern sprint championships.
Home Life Strikes Out The baseball season is in full sweep now, and it is all too obvious that home life has become a jumbled mass of wreckage. This is the fault of television.

This is the season, like Christmas and birthdays, when Daddy may expect the children to be spilling over with a happy secret. Mother's Day is past and Father's Day is approaching. The large box in the hall closet now contains a handsome summer suit, or perhaps the small box in the desk hides a dozen golf balls.

The main exhibition floor of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle collapsed yesterday while concrete was being poured into it. Dozens of workers on temporary flooring plunged about twenty feet to the street level as steel pipes, timbers and concrete gave way with a roar at 2:45 P. M. About fifteen minutes later a second section of the floor collapsed.

Fordham's baseball team left fourteen runners on the bases yesterday and lost, 7--6, to Wagner at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx. The Rams collected fourteen hits and drew six walks but wasted most of them.

The green of Oregon was seen here yesterday as fourteen young women from Portland, on their way to a concert tour of Europe, landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to change planes for Copenhagen.
Achievement of a third of the $250,000 goal of the New York County Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society was announced yesterday.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday slipped to 2,090,000 shares, the smallest since March 22. It compared with 2,250,000 on Friday. Interest was small, except in a few issues.

Cutting down time in the major leagues approaches -- midnight tomorrow is the deadline -- and some clubs are in what the front office calls "trouble." In this category are the Yankees, who open a sixteengame home stand tonight at the Stadium against the pace-setting Cleveland Indians.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was gratifying that in your editorial of May 4 on Governor Harriman's disposition of new legislation you took at least passing critical note of his veto of the bill which would have provided machinery for the disclosure of detailed data on employe welfare fund operations.

Isaac Logart of Havana, Cuba, gained his sixth straight victory by scoring a unanimous decision over favored Ludwig Lightburn in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Logart weighed 142 1/2. Lightburn, from British Honduras, scaled 138 1/2.

BUENOS AIRES, May 9-- President Juan D. Peron sought Congressional approval today for a contract granting the Standard Oil Company of California forty years in which to explore, develop and exploit a large area of oil lands here.
A television sponsor is shopping for a replacement for "My Favorite Husband" and the most likely candidate is a new series starring Janis Paige.

WASHINGTON, May 9--In this space there was published, April 29, a report of the constitutional argument before the Supreme Court in the case of Prof. John P. Peters of Yale. The President's Loyalty Review Board recommended to the Federal Security Agency that Peters be barred for three years from further Government service because it found "reasonable doubt" of his loyalty.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP)-- House Speaker Sam Rayburn today protested what he termed President Eisenhower's "cruel" displacement of James M. Mead as a member of the Federal Trade Commission.
VIENNA, May 9--The Russians suddenly stymied today the ambassadorial conference working out a state treaty for Austria.
MONTREAL, May 9 (Canadian Press)--Henry Morgan Co., Ltd., which claims to be Canada's first and oldest department store, is celebrating its 110th anniversary.

TOKYO, May 9 -- India has high hopes that her efforts to bring the United States and Communist China together will avert the possibility of war in the Formosa Strait. But New Delhi does not expect to see anything except a stalemate on the disposition of Nationalist - held Formosa itself for a long time to come.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one of the many apartment dwellers who logically would be most affected by the discontinuance of rent control, I feel the need to answer the letter of Arthur D. Koppel, vice chairman, Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The Government soon will test an anti-submarine atomic weapon off the West Coast.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)-- A program to expand and modernize the air transport system of Pakistan was announced jointly today by the Foreign Operations Administration, Pakistan International Airlines and Pan American World Airways.

BACK in 1916 the New York Giants ripped off a seventeen-game winning streak at this approximate stage in the pennant race. Near the end of the same season they set a record of twenty-six consecutive victories. Yet they still finished fourth.

Dr. Jonas E. Salk said yesterday that his poliomyelitis vaccine might provide even greater protection when second inoculations followed first injections by "more than four weeks." This would compare with earlier plans for two-to-four-week intervals.
ELIZABETH, N. J., May 9-- This city's former chief of detectives and one of its fire commissioners committed suicide within an hour of each other today.
WASHINGTON, May 9--Admiral Arthur W. Radford declared today that the foreign aid program was indispensable to the military security of the United States.
An eighteenth century garden, situated almost in the shadow of the Queensboro Bridge, was dedicated yesterday afternoon.

THE influence of a brilliant older brother upon a younger one can be blighting. But Jean Dufy, a selection of whose water-colors and oils is now at Van Dieman-Lilienfeld's, 21 East Fifty-seventh Street, has managed to turn the fraternal shade of Raoul Dufy into a professional asset.

The statement that Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, has issued on the Salk vaccine should reassure anxious parents of more than 5,000,000 children who have been inoculated. Both the Public Health Service and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis have reiterated their faith in the vaccine.
CHICAGO, May 9--Sewell L. Avery, 81 years old, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., resigned today.

Seymour M. Tannenbaum, real estate operator, has purchased the five-story walk-up apartment house at 517 West 151st Street from the Barmack Realty Company. The property, on a plot about 33 by 99 feet, contains fifteen apartments.

American Pulley Company Purchase of the assets of the Safeway Industrial Equipment Corporation of Chicago was announced yesterday by the American Pulley Company of Philadelphia. American Pulley manufactures hand trucks and other materialshandling equipment.
A two-star general and his theatrically experienced son have formed a company for the production of a series of plays and musicals on Broadway next season.

LONDON, May 9--Leading industrial equities were fairly firm on selective demand today, although the best prices were not always maintained. Changes in most cases were in the order of 1 shilling (14 cents) or less.
CHICAGO, May 9 (AP)--A big business drama, packed with the clashes and tensions of human emotions, ended today with the election of John Barr as chairman of Montgomery Ward Co.

A recanting Federal Bureau of Investigation informer testified yesterday that he had received $75 a week as head of a "Committee to Save the Rosenbergs" while drawing his regular pay as a counter-spy for the F. B. I.
Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia maintained his grip on first place in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires yesterday in a fifteen-move draw with Arthur B. Bisguier of New York.

LEEDS, England, May 9 -- Prime Minister Eden asked the British electorate tonight to send a united Conservative Government into negotiations with the Soviet Union rather than a Labor party sunk in "utter discord and chaos."

It costs an average of $6,000, not including living expenses, to educate a Bachelor of Arts, Devereux C. Josephs, chairman of the New York Life Insurance Company, noted last night. The difference between this and the $4,000 a private college receives in tuition, he said, is putting many an educational institution into difficult financial straits.

There's an old baseball story about a rookie phenom who wrote to his family from training camp. "Everything has been going great up to now, folks," he scrawled. "But I'll be coming home soon. They've started to throw curves."
David Sarnoff urged the nation yesterday to wage all-out "cold war" against communism and be willing to accept the same "costs and casualties as a hot war would involve."

WASHINGTON, May 9--Robert Moses, Construction Coordinator in New York City, opposed a "pay-as-you-go" road-building program today. He said it was logical and necessary for the Government to go into debt for a road program.

Humble Oil The operations of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), in the first four months of this year showed a general increase of 9 per cent compared with last year, Hines H. Baker, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held yesterday in Houston, Tex.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The Supreme Court in an unusual action today "dismissed" a case that it had decided last year.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 9-- Admiral Felix B. Stump, commander in chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, conferred today with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on the problems of defending Formosa against the Communists.
Another move, this time in Federal Court, is being made to force the Waterfront Commission to lift the suspension of four New Jersey dockworkers.
WASHINGTON, May 9--District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County defended wiretapping as a "potent crimefighting instrument" that had proved indispensable in getting many important convictions.

BONN, Germany, May 9--The Social Democratic Opposition published today a plan for German unification. It asked for the ultimate withdrawal of foreign troops and the inclusion of Germany in an all-European security system.

The Park Association of New York City held its annual meeting yesterday at 70 Pine Street, and re-elected seven directors whose terms had expired. At a subsequent directors meeting at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, officers were chosen for the coming year.
Twenty-five Japanese girls, who bear the scars of the world's first atom bomb attack, arrived here yesterday hoping that American medical science might erase the blemishes and restore them to normal.

Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, Dr. Ordway Tead and Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham were reappointed to the Board of Higher Education yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The posts are unsalaried. The board is the governing body of the four municipal colleges.
DETROIT, May 9--The automobile union moved today for strike votes by Ford and General Motors employes throughout the country.
TRENTON, May 9--Voters in this city and twenty-four other New Jersey municipalities will go to the polls tomorrow to elect officials.

The Port of New York is "well on its way" to a new era of waterfront labor relations, Alexander P. Chopin said last night. This could mean an end to the quickie strikes, and work stoppages that have plagued the harbor in the past, said the acting chairman of the New York Shipping Association.
BUFFALO, May 9 -- Modern medicine is gradually achieving a greater degree of control over the diseases of the heart and blood vessels, now the leading cause of death in the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The House of Representatives, defying veto warnings, approved today a rise in postal pay averaging 8.8 per cent.
A REDUCTION in fishing pressure coincided with an improvement in fishing conditions over the week-end on many of the Catskill streams.

VIENNA, May 9--Gen. Alexei Cepicka, Czechoslovak Minister of Defense, declared today the Czech Army was equipped to meet attacks "with the most modern weapons and ready to fight under all possible conditions."
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 10-- United States Air Force Sabre Jets shot down two Communist MIG's and probably destroyed another this morning in a battle over international waters, the Air Force announced.

A synthetic chemical that completely checks multiplication of the influenza virus in the test tube, without doing any harm to the normal tissue cells into which it was injected, was described yesterday at the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists.
PARIS, May 9--The Federal Republic of Germany was formally inducted today into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Southarlington contributed an entertaining performance in winning Belmont Park's Hempstead Handicap yesterday. The 6-year-old son of Errard, with Willle Boland astride, beat the favored Paper Tiger by a length and a half before 22,877 racegoers.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., May 8 --In an atomic bomb attack, home furnishings are likely to be for more dangerous than the bomb itself.

After four days of discussion the general conclusions on farm policy arrived at by the sixty delegates to the American Assembly at Arden House were summed up in a tenpoint statement. Noteworthy in the conclusions of these non-politicians is the lack of enthusiasm for such devices as price props, subsidies and proposals for "solving" the problem of the farm commodity surplus by wishing it off at cut rates on friendly neighbor countries.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)-- Harry F. Guggenheim, industrialist, predicted today that the rapid development of aircraft that could take off and land vertically soon might make obsolete many large airports and long runways.
WASHINGTON, May 9--Two Congressional committees prepared today to open hearings on the postponement in the countrywide poliomyelitis inoculation program.
NEW DELHI, India, May 9-- India protested to Pakistan today over the shooting between Indian and Pakistani forces near the Kashmir border Saturday.
JERUSALEM, May 9--The left wing of Israel's trade union movement apparently lost supporters to the center and right in the election held yesterday by Histadrut, the general federation of labor.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9 --An engineer testified today that in his opinion the $2,385,000 dam under construction on the Mianus River would be sufficient to meet the demands for water by Greenwich and Port Chester and Rye, N. Y., only until 1970.
MOSCOW, May 9--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin will head the Soviet delegation to the Warsaw conference of Sovietbloc nations opening Wednesday.

Performances of Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta "The Mikado" will be given on the nights of May 18, 19 and 20 by members of the choir of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church in the church's Community House, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street.
An arbitrational triple - play has put a side issue in one of the city's most vexing labor disputes back where it started nearly two years ago.

Deputy Mayor Epstein's report on juvenile delinquency, and Mayor Wagner's wholehearted endorsement of the program it contains, represent a striking advance on the increasingly active juvenile delinquency front. Mr. Epstein in no way deprecates the necessity of strong police and correctional activities in restraint of the three out of every hundred juveniles who actually run afoul of the law; but he rightly emphasizes the supreme importance of measures of prevention.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 9--A three-concert festival of contemporary music, with twelve twentieth century composers represented, is under way at the University of California's Santa Barbara College Auditorium.
AMSTERDAM, May 9 (AP) -- Two futures markets were opened here today.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The House of Representatives voted 322 to 66 today to combine the bids of Hawaii and Alaska for statehood.
HAIPHONG, Vietnam, May 9 (AP)--Communist Vietminh troops converged on Haiphong today to take control of one of Southeast Asia's biggest seaports.

MOSCOW, May 9 (AP)--Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist party, was asked tonight whether he was the real power behind the throne in the Soviet Union. The question was put to Mr. Khrushchev by an Associated Press correspondent at a Czechoslovak Embassy party.
