Plans for a $4,500,000 hotel in Berlin, Germany--the first major new one since World War II-- were disclosed here yesterday.
PARIS, May 9--The United States appeared tonight to be moving, slowly and reluctantly but inevitably, toward acceptance of the British-French proposal on a conference with the Soviet Union.
The amount of publicity that has been given to the adoption of children from abroad was criticized yesterday as having raised false hopes for countless would-be American foster parents.

That great American institution, two weeks' vacation with pay, will swing into full gear within few weeks. It is probably the most planned-for fourteen days out of the 365 except in one important respect--the home or apartment the traveler leaves behind.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines said today that "by no stretch of the imagination" could Chou En-Lai, Premier of Communist China, be considered the winner at the Asian-African conference.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Government lost a fight in the Supreme Court today to set aside a lower-court ruling limiting the censorship powers of the Postmaster General.

A new issue of Transamerica Corporation capital stock valued at $54,545,400 will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of 276 investment banking houses headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Dean Witter Co.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- The extraordinary conference in San Salvador of the Committee for Economic Integration provided more long-range psychological benefits than direct economic advances in Central America.
Two district champions remained in front as the third round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub matches was completed yesterday.
A woman learning to drive was killed last night in Elmhurst, Queens, by her own car when she got out of it to let her husband take the wheel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- It seems you can't please all the people even some of the time. Today for the first time in 108 years, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company provided a free buffet luncheon for 1,000 of its stockholders who traveled to Philadelphia for the annual meeting.

Career and salary plans for two classifications of city employes were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate in a special public meeting at City Hall. Action on seven other classifications was put off to a special meeting on May 23.
LONDON, May 10 -- One of Britain's leading industrialists urged today a comprehensive review of the entire machinery for handling industrial disputes in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The hard realities of domestic politics in the Western countries are beginning to have a profound effect on international affairs. This is at least part of the explanation why the United States Government agreed to a Big Four meeting of the heads of Government.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from President Eisenhower's informal speech to the Republican Women's National Conference today:
Hugh K. McGovern announced yesterday plans for a twelve-story apartment house on East Sixty-sixth Street, a block east of the Manhattan House development.
PARIS, Wednesday, May 11 -- France appeared ready early this morning to accept the United States view that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam should be supported pending elections.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -Warren Olney 3d, Assistant Attorney General, urged today that Federal election laws be extended to cover state primaries and conventions nominating candidates for Federal office.

ROME, May 10 -- Dropping of charges against Giuseppe Sotgiu, a prominent Communist and a criminal lawyer, was recommended by the Prosecutor today. He informed the investigating Magistrate that the charges against Signor Sotgiu had not been substantiated and that he should therefore be "acquitted for lack of proof."
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Consumers of natural gas enjoy a "luxury" fuel and therefore are not entitled to Government control of its price, Senator J. William Fulbright told a Senate committee today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 10 (Reuters) -- An announcement of plans to increase shipping freight rates between here and Europe today brought a declaration from exporters' representatives that the increase would cripple Australia's export trade.
Civic leaders in the fight against dirt in the city's streets were "amazed" and "astounded" yesterday by the progress of the city's clean-up drive.

Declines covered a broad front on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. With business still low -- 2,150,000 shares, against 2,090,000 on Monday -- 685 of the 1,220 issues traded fell, 295 rose and 240 closed unchanged.
Events tonight: Telemann Society, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:15, and Milton Peckarsky, pianist, and Nicos Cambourakis, violinist, New School for Social Research, 8:30.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 11 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of three resolutions proposed by the Soviet Union for United Nations consideration on "the elimination of the threat of another war," as distributed by the Soviet news agency, Tass:

The First Boston Corporation and associates are placing on the market today a block of 155,324 common shares of the McLouth Steel Corporation, Detroit area producer of hot- and cold-rolled flat carbon steel and stainless sheet and strip.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The House of Representatives sidetracked today the combined bill to give statehood to Hawaii and Alaska. The vote was 218 to 170.
BUENOS AIRES, May 10 -- Roman Catholic leaders visited the Ministry of the Interior today in an attempt to obtain the release of thirty Catholics arrested last week-end.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Representative Clarence J. Brown said today the Navy had 812,179 gallons of ketchup to go with 886,000 pounds of hamburger. He valued the ketchup at $1,016,934.

The entire Board of Education, accompanied by the Superintendent of Schools, is scheduled to pay a visit to City Hall today to talk with Mayor Wagner about teacher salaries. No problem is more basic to the good health of our public school system.
The 174th annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York refused yesterday to permit women to serve on parish vestries or to attend the yearly diocesan conclave as delegates.

Charles H. Silver was re-elected president of the Board of Education yesterday by unanimous vote. This was in marked contrast to his election three months ago by the slim margin of one vote. On that occasion, he succeeded Arthur Levitt, who had resigned to become state controller.
LONDON, May 10 -- Sixyear-old Prince Charles is going outside his home to expand his educational horizons, and his parents have asked the press to let him do so without the spotlight of publicity.

BUFFALO, May 10 (UP) -- Paul Andrews rose from a second-round knockdown tonight to score a decision over Jimmy Slade before 7,000 fans in a ten-round bout, the first major fight to be staged here in five years.

The days of May hint of wilting heat to come, but still a memory of another season's chill remains. The fans hum busily in subway cars, but a little extra warmth is needed at the drive-in movies. Flies dash happily in through windows opened in the daytime, but only the hardiest of the species venture out into the night.
A Brooklyn hoodlum was killed by the police at 10:15 A. M. yesterday after a fifteen-minute, roof-top chase in which seven shots were fired.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, May 10 -- Israel and Jordan agreed today on the treatment of military prisoners. Tonight, the two nations exchanged three persons held in custody.

The Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association's show at the New Yorker Hotel drew the highest attendance on record, officials of the exhibit announced yesterday. The 3,500 buyers that have registered at the five-day event which opened Sunday represent about a 10 per cent increase over the previous high of May, 1953.

THE 82-year-old Oratorio Society of New York did something last night that it has not done in a long time. It gave a concert at Carnegie Hall that did not consist of either Handel's "Messiah" or Bach's B minor Mass. What is more, one of the composers was Stravinsky.

SIMLA, India, May 10 -- The theory that the economic health of free Asia depends in a large measure on the relations between India and Japan is being tested cautiously and almost shyly in this Himalayan mountain town.

LONDON, May 10 (Reuters) -- The London high court refused today for a second time to grant an Injunction to Loew's, Inc., of New York in a copyright action against showmen presenting a revival here of the operetta "The Merry Widow."
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10 -- Two Rio de Janeiro banks have closed their doors in the last two days. One has asked for liquidation but in the other case the closing is said to be temporary.

BUENOS AIRES, May 10 (AP) -- The Monsanto Chemical Company announced today that its Argentine subsidiary would begin construction immediately of a plant near here for the production of polystyrene for the plastic molding industry.
VIENNA, May 10 -- The four Ambassadors conferring on an Austrian state treaty decided today to make one more effort to reach agreement.
From now on, Yale University undergraduates will be expected to place classroom studies ahead of athletics, week-end parties or extra-curricular campus activities.

The Celanese Corporation of America and its domestic subsidiaries made a sharp recovery in the first quarter of this year. There was a 58.3 per cent gain in sales over a year ago and earnings were the highest since the third quarter of 1952.
A major test of one of the late Albert Einstein's most famous predictions will be made next month during the longest solar eclipse in more than 1,200 years.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A team of scientists will begin tomorrow the first laboratory reappraisal of the Salk anti-poliomyelitis vaccine.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.

The American Australian Association, which has its headquarters in New York, would like wholeheartedly to endorse the suggestion in your editorial of May 6 that the anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea should be celebrated in the United States as well as in Australia.

TEANECK, N. J., May 10 -More than 1,200 commuters and officials of eight New Jersey towns facing loss of train service vigorously protested today the planned discontinuance of passenger trains on the West Shore Division of the New York Central Railroad. They made known their views at a four-hour hearing in Teaneck High School during the afternoon and a three-hour evening session.

ALBANY, May 10 (AP) -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits has begun court action to remove John F. Doyle as Surrogate of Saratoga County. The action is a sequel to the state's four-year investigation of Saratoga gambling.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 10 (AP) -- Two racing cars skidded into a retaining wall at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today. One of the drivers was fined for ignoring yellow caution lights. Neither driver was hurt.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Midwest and Far West broke the East's long-time supremacy on the all-America intercollegiate rifle squad today. They won six of the ten places on the mythical squad selected by a board of coaches and National Rifle Association officials.

A man rushing to catch a subway train accidentally upset a scaffolding, causing one painter to fall to his death and another to be critically injured yesterday. The workmen were painting the ceiling of the 181st Street station of the IND Division.
Children to Palestine, a nonsectarian "investment in humanity" that has been functioning since the end of the war, inaugurated its new project last night, an International Cultural Center for Youth.

"First time I ever saw a weenie roast on Park Avenue." This was the comment yesterday of a grocery boy as he squeezed his way past some thirty Camp Fire Girls crowded around a "campfire" in front of the Sulgrave Hotel.

LONDON, May 10 -- Sir Anthony Eden predicted tonight that there would be a series of meetings between the Western powers and the Soviet Union to solve problems that divide Europe and endanger the world.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 10 (UP) -- Gov. George M. Leader said today that Harold Johnson had been drugged before his match last Friday with Julio Mederos, and the Chief Executive suspended professional boxing in the state for ninety days.
PARIS, May 10 -- New negotiations with the Soviet Union, to be opened by the heads of governments accompanied by their foreign ministers, were proposed today by the three Western powers.
A six-hour mediation conference yesterday produced headway toward settlement of the twenty-three-day-old strike at the Sperry Gyroscope Company in Lake Success, L. I.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Eisenhower urged Republican women today to educate and inform their neighbors to make "the Republican party the majority party, and keep it that way."
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Representative Wright Patman charged today that about half of the members of the group that studied the antitrust laws represented clients in pending antitrust proceedings.
NEW YORK'S most interesting sandman is a woman. She sends sand to Saudi Arabia, to Liberia and to Algiers and gets good prices for it, though those places have no sand shortage.

SENOR ALFONSO RAMON LOPEZ is a man beset with pitching problems. All the other managers in the American League would willingly relieve the Indian chieftain of his perplexities. But that's beside the point. The good senor is troubled with the task of fitting into his pitching rotation Bobby Feller and Art Houtteman.

CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- Two stockholders of the fifty-two-story Terminal Tower here today called on their fellow stockholders to reject a proposal to sell the property for $11,460,000 to Roger L. Stevens of Detroit.

MILWAUKEE, May 10 (AP) -Gene Freese's four - run homer, sandwiched between four other runs in a wild eighth inning, resulted in the Pitsburgh Pirates' fourth straight victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight, 9 -- 6.
Premier Pibul Songgram of Thailand declared yesterday that he felt World War III was inevitable and that he expected the free world to win it.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 10 -- Investigators are still hunting motives for the separate but almost simultaneous suicides yesterday of Capt. August F. Winkelmann, retiring head of the Detective Bureau, and Francis B. De Stephan, member of the Board of Fire Commissioners.
CINCINNATI, May 10 -Johnny Antonelli, who had to struggle though sixteen innings to beat the Redlegs the last time he faced them, was able to make it in regulation time tonight.
Public school pupils who do not meet standards in reading will not be promoted beginning next year, the Board of Education said yesterday.

Things went so badly for the Yankees last night even Joe DiMaggio, one of 39,227 spectators, walked out on the season's first after-dark game at the Stadium. The retired Yankee Clipper did not indicate whether he was disillusioned by or disgusted with the New York pitching that led to a 9-6 victory for the Cleveland Indians.
An incumbent ticket in Camden, N. J., of five City Commissioners, led by Mayor George E. Brunner, was swept back into office yesterday. The pluralities ranged from 3,554 votes to 4,823.

The Western Powers have now issued a formal invitation to Soviet Russia to join them in a new top-level conference to discuss problems dividing East and West and if possible to reach some kind of settlement which would banish the specter of atomic war.

Belmont Park's feature yesterday was a two-division six-furlong test for fillies and mares, 3 years old and up. Hedley Woodhouse piloted the Calumet Farm's 3-year-old Bull Lea filly Amoret to victory in the first section. Jockey George Glassner and Nelson Asiel's 3-year-old Black Tarquin filly, Tarquilla, took the second part.

The 963 Kent Avenue Corporation has sold the loft building at that address in Brooklyn to the Petjo Realty Corporation. Assessed at $100,000, the property occupies an irregular plot about 75 by 55 by 132 feet. Saul Kirschner was the broker.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and Stanley Barnes, head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, were accused tonight of being responsible for the department's decision to "haul the press into court."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Samuel Goldwyn confirmed today that he had resigned Feb. 8 from the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- The Senate Public Works Committee voted down today an Administration proposal to issue $21,000,000,000 in special bonds to help finance President Eisenhower's multi-billion dollar highway program.

High automobile inventories and the absence of an atmosphere favoring a strike should prevent a strike in the automobile industry, Herman W. Steinkraus, president and chairman of Bridgeport Brass Company, predicted yesterday.
In the spring it is all too clear that a house should have no windows. They should be abolished for the season, boarded up by duly constituted authority until sometime late in June.
A VACATION wardrobe, depending on vacation and vacationer, can fit in a single suitcase or a wardrobe trunk. Some items are indispensable to both.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A long-delayed and controversial tanker-building program appears to be over the last obstacle and headed for production.
A "summer for children" dinner dance will be held on May 26 in the ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the St. Seraphim Foundation.
LONDON, May 10 -- Although gilt-edge securities lost up to seventeen shillings sixpence ($2.45) on the stock market here today, industrial issues continued to improve.
A producing agreement has been entered into by Stephen Mitchell, British producer, and Huntington Hartford, owner of the Hollywood theatre bearing his name.
THE HAGUE, May 10 (AP) -- Royal Dutch Airlines (K. L. M.) plans to offer its shares to the general public, it was disclosed today.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -- Wives or husbands have been found to be among the least helpful persons to have around when their alcoholic mates are trying to keep from drinking.
KIENAN, Vietnam, May 10 (AP) -- Thousands of flower-tossing Communist-led North Vietnamese troops moved today into this town six miles southwest of Haiphong.

If Premier Diem of South Vietnam succeeds in pulling his country out of the semi-anarchy in which it has been floundering -- and at the moment it seems just possible that he may perform this feat -- the forces of freedom will have gained a new lease on life in a critical part of the world.
As the result of reduced shipping activity and smaller import cargoes, customs collections in the Port of New York last month declined by almost $7,000,000 from the March level.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -President Eisenhower said today that good roads throughout the world would lead to lasting peace. Travel into various countries, he added, creates international understanding and good will.

"VISIT TO A SMALL PLANET," seen on Sunday evening via the National Broadcasting Company, was welcome good fun, something off the beaten path in television drama. Not only was it satirical fantasy, a most rare video commodity but also it was satirical fantasy in which all the pieces fitted together.

The Ford Foundation will undoubtedly sell some of its Ford Motor Company stock sometime, but it won't he until "the latter part of this year, if then," H. Rowan Gaither Jr., president of the foundation, said yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Mo., May 10 (AP) -- One of the strangest battles of the Civil War will be re-enacted this week in a campaign to restore a historical battle site.
A grand jury inquiry into possible bribery of employes of the State Liquor Authority began yesterday.
ROME, May 10 -- Giovanni Leone, a Christian Democratic lawyer from Naples, was elected President of the Chamber of Deputies today.
Hellenic Lines, Ltd., has ordered four cargo ships to be built in the next eighteen months by the Iino Shipbuilding and Engineering Company of Tokyo.

STRASBOURG, France, May 10 (AP) -- The chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community said today new steps toward European unity were needed to maintain the standard of living.
Dan Petrie has been selected as the chief director for the "United States Steel Hour" after it moves to the Columbia Broadcasting System television network July 6.

Directors of the Automatic Canteen Company of America yesterday approved submission of an offer to the Rowe Corporation for the purchase of all of its net assets and business on the basis of four shares of Automatic for five shares of Rowe.

The Port of New York Authority announced plans yesterday for the sale of $30,000,000 of consolidated bonds to finance capital expenditures. The authority will receive bids for the bonds from banking syndicates on May 23. The issue will mature on April 1, 1985.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee voted 24 to 0 today to eliminate from its doctor draft bill a controversial provision that would have created more than 400 Government-paid medical scholarships.
For the second time this month, a greenback with a split personality has turned up in the metropolitan area. It is a genuine $1 on one side and an equally genuine $10 on the other.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 10 -- The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania presented its Meritorious Service Medal today to Dr. Jonas E. Salk in recognition of his "historical medical" discovery -- the anti-poliomyelitis vaccine.

MANILA, May 10 -- An agreement between the United States and the Philippines Governments on the need for activating idle military bases here and constructing new ones, was announced by President Ramon Magsaysay.

Today's new film is "Violent Saturday," a Twentieth Century-Fox production starring Victor Mature, Richard Egan and Stephen McNally, at the Mayfair. The melodrama was written by Sydney Boehm from a novel by William L. Heath. Richard Fleischer directed and Buddy Adler produced.

Newspaper advertising, as well as business in department stores, were sharply affected in April by the fact that Easter fell on April 10, instead of on April 18, as it did a year before. There was thus a week less of promotion and selling in the month.

Investment banking syndicates will make public offerings today of five new issues of securities valued at more than $51,000,000. The offerings include mortgage bonds and preferred stock of public utility companies, debentures of industrial companies and equipment trust certificates of a railroad enterprise.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Michael Sam, an organizer for the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., said today his signature on a 1946 Communist party petition was a forgery. He said he never had been a Communist.
Herman Pilnik of Argentina bowed to Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia yesterday in a game adjourned from the fourteenth round of the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament at Buenos Aires.

The State Power Authority held a public hearing at City Hall yesterday on four proposed contracts for sale at low rates of electric power it will generate on Barnhart Island in the St. Lawrence River.
CHICAGO, May 10 (UP) -- The construction of a full-scale nuclear power plant financed entirely by private funds moved a step closer to realization today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that this year's crop of winter wheat will be one-fourth smaller than average. This reflected the effects of a Federal crop control program and drought conditions in some Great Plains producing areas.

BOSTON, May 10 (UP) -- The White Sox rallied with three late-inning home runs off Tom Brewer today to gain a 4-2 decision over the seventh-place Boston Red Sox. The setback was Boston's fifth in a row and the eleventh in the last twelve games.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The full nine-man bench of the Federal Court of Appeals here will decide the Government's appeal for reinstatement of a two-count perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 11 -- Red China today accused United States planes of provoking an air battle over the Yellow Sea yesterday. Two and possibly three Communist MIG jet fighters were shot down by United States Sabre Jet fighter-bombers in the fight.
The second week of the season of "American Dance," sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation, opened last night at the ANTA Theatre with a large audience in attendance.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The assignment of Gen. J. Lawton Collins as special representative of President Eisenhower in Vietnam will end at the end of this week, the White House announced today.
Meetings of the Democratic county and executive committees are being called for May 23 to set up machinery for the direct election of Tammany district leaders.
THE second of the three programs of contemporary music currently being offered by Composers of Today, Inc., under the direction of Rosalyn Tureck, took place at the Town Hall Green Room last night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad earned more money in the first four months of 1955 than in any comparable period since 1945, James M. Symes, president, told stockholders today at the annual meeting.

With reference to Gladwin Hill's report published April 21 on my speech before the Third National Air Pollution Symposium, I would like to point out a disparity between the story and my actual remarks. The story reads:
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Following is the text of the United States - British - French note to the Soviet Union:
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10 -A series of strikes is plaguing Rio de Janeiro today. The capital faced the prospect of being left without telephone service.

An illuminated manuscript of the Gospels, penned and painted by English monks long before the Norman conquest, is a newly acquired prize on exhibition today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.
LONDON, May 10 -- Chinese Premier Chou En-lai has promised Britain to explain in due course his stated willingness to negotiate with the United States about the Formosa situation.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Eisenhower said today he was ready to "meet with anyone, anywhere" in the hope of advancing world peace. With the President's endorse ment, the United States promptly joined Britain and France in an invitation to the Soviet Union for a two-stage

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., May 10 (UP) -- The State Athletic Commission today announced a session for Friday to hear John Simpson, manager of Don Cockell, on conditions for the heavyweight title fight on Monday against Rocky Marciano.
BERKELEY, Calif., May 10 -- A mixed air of confidence and puzzlement pervades the Cutter Laboratories.
TOKYO, May 10 (AP) -- The text of the United States Air Force announcement of an air battle today with Communist MIG fighters follows:

PARIS, May 10 -- The Soviet Union is probably not anxious to hold Big Four talks right now. The Russians pretend to see no point in a negotiation. Their argument is that the United Nations is the proper body to deal with discussion of arms reduction, that the situation in Germany does not permit present consideration of means to reunite that country.
A future of soaring sales and ever-widening markets was pictured yesterday for the nation's toiletries and cosmetic industry.

Glamorene, Inc., distributor of rug and upholstery cleaning products, has leased a building to be erected on a two-acre tract in the Entin Industrial Terminal at Clifton, N. J. The transaction was negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.
Twenty-nine companies sold a billion dollars or more of goods and services in 1954. There were thirty-three in 1953, according to a United Press survey.

George Washington's first book, a Journal, is going back to Williamsburg, where it was printed. An account of his first military mission to French outposts in the Ohio Valley, it was auctioned last night for $25,000.
PARIS, May 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer indicated today he would assume personal direction of West Germany's program to create a new military establishment.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 11 -- The Soviet Union proposed today a world disarmament plan under which international control groups would keep a watch in all nations to prevent war preparations.

The city has asked the United States Public Health Service whether changes in preserving methods for poliomyelitis vaccine have been "clinically tested." The inquiry was to guide the city's buying of vaccine.

PUNCH opera is a modest enterprise as far as financial resources go, but it is resourceful in ideas and initiative. While other companies seem to cry havoc about the state of contemporary composition, this little troupe manages to find things worthy of its interest -- ours.
Plans for matching Russia's championship crew against top American college eights in the May-September period this year have fallen through, Tip Goes said yesterday.

TULSA, Okla., May 10 (AP) -- The Sunray Oil Corporation and Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation were formally merged today. Simultaneous stockholders meetings approved formation of a $486,000,000 concern to be known as Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Former Representative John S. Wood of Georgia, who has been nominated to the Subversive Activities Control Board, denied today he had ever belonged to the Klu Klux Klan.
Fifty-seven Jewish communities in foreign nations sent greetings yesterday to American Jews on their tercentenary anniversary.
Brooklyn, as befits this proud borough, has its own magic carpet. It's Abraham Straus, turned tomorrow through Wednesday, May 18, into a vast purveyor of travel dreams.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, May 11 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem announced last night the reorganization of his Government into a strongly Nationalist Cabinet. It is dedicated to oppose both communism and colonialism.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 10 -- The Sixth West Indian Conference opened today with a call from Puerto Rico's Acting Governor for a basic change in the character of the Caribbean Commission.

VANCOUVER, B. C., May 10 -- Gov. B. Frank Heintzleman of Alaska called today for immediate establishment of an international body to deal with the regional development of Alaska, the Yukon and Northwestern British Columbia.

William Bridgeman, experimental test pilot for supersonic aircraft, has written an account of his experiences in collaboration with Jacqueline Hazard. It relates his ventures hurtling through the sound barrier and gaining the record altitude of 79,000 feet while testing such planes as the Douglas Skyrocket land X-3.
Mayor Wagner predicted last night a New York City of the future that "will not be a paradise," but will be a reasonable facsimile.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- A House committee approved two more generals for top jobs in the Immigration Service today. Democrats protested that President Eisenhower was loading the Government with military men.

Scores of men worked without let-up yesterday and early today clearing many tons of debris in a search for a man believed buried in Monday's floor collapse at the New York Coliseum on Columbus Circle.

MRS. Ruth B. Shipley, former head of the State Department's passport division, spoke yesterday to the American Jewish League Against Communism. She said that her successor, Frances G. Knight, had been her personal choice for the post.

Six major trucking associations in the New York-New Jersey area and union teamsters denounced yesterday the new pier loading tariffs as "unlawful" and indicated that truckmen would refuse to pay the increased rates.
WATERFOWL prospects are bright on the breeding grounds of the great "duck factory" of Manitoba, Alberta and Saskatchewan, according to a report by Ducks Unlimited.

The twenty-five Japanese girls who will undergo plastic surgery on scars suffered in the Hiroshima atom bomb attack ten years ago went to Philadelphia yesterday morning for a two-week rest. Thoroguhly tired from their jour ney here and their reception on Monday, the girls left by bus, accompanied by Miss Helen Yokahama of the United States Atomic Casualty Commission and John Howes, a Fulbright fellow from the University of Tokyo.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 -Modern journalism was pictured tonight as offering opportunities that were never greater.
The New York City AntiCrime Committee has notified John M. O'Mara, its executive director, and William J. Keating, its former counsel, that their employment by the committee has been ended.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 10 -- Legislation to permit increases in truck weights was introduced in the Pennsylvania Legislature today. It was supported by the Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association and other organizations.
For the first time in its 101-year history W. R. Grace Co. has elected a chairman who is not a member of the Grace family.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 10 -- Development here of one of the major suburban railroad stations of the country is proposed by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Leading merchant ship operators envisioned today a replacement program requiring, by 1966, private investment of $1,600,000,000. The program would mean a total expenditure of $3,000,000,000 funneling into the nation's economy, Arthur B. Poole, vice president of American President Lines, said.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10 -- The Government will submit a bill to Parliament tomorrow to dissolve the Senate and reconstitute it in such a way that it will give the Government a two-thirds majority of both houses meeting together.

TWO exhibitions presenting the work of American and European painters and sculptors who have emerged to prominence in the last decade will open today in the adjoining Whitney Museum and Museum of Modem Art.
Preliminary experiments suggesting the possible development of a serum against cancer were described yesterday at the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A Pentagon turndown apparently has ended any immediate chance that Congress will consider promoting General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to the rank of General of the Armies.

OTTAWA, May 10 -- The Canadian affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor, have agreed to merge. They will form the Canadian Congress of Labor, with 1,000,000 members.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Don Newcombe had what might be called his "finest hour" and 55 minutes at Wrigley Field today. That's all the time he required to hurl a one-hit shutout over the Cubs, the Dodgers winning, 3 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Navy officers told a Senate subcommittee today they planned to ask Congress next year to authorize a $28,000,000 drydock for Bremerton, Wash.
Textron American, Inc., which recently sold several woolen mills in New England, will build one of the largest in the country in the South.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The State Department withheld comment today on the statement made by Premier Chou that he would clarify his views on direct Formosa talks with the United States in due course.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Before Mr. Hensel went before the Foreign Relations Committee today, Chairman Walter E. George said he endorsed the Administration's aim of "attaining complete mobility" of the armed forces.

BONN, Germany, May 10 -- The former Western High Commissioners in Germany have notified the Soviet Union that their posts have been liquidated but that they have kept certain of their responsibilities.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- H. Struve Hensel said today that if military aid to America's allies prevented even one more small war like Korea the cost, "solely as an insurance premium, will be very cheap."

In your editorial of May 5 you suggest that Traffic Commissioner Wiley knows all the answers to New York City's traffic problems. You compliment him for ignoring recommendations for traffic relief made by citizens on the street and particularly Councilmen, the elected representatives of the people.
Roger W. Babson, 80-year-old economist and corporation president, prefers "humble beginnings" to "rags to riches" as a way of expressing the rise to success in the American tradition.

Mayor Wagner in addressing the Citizens Union's fifty-eighth annual dinner last night spoke in glowing terms of the New York of the future. While painting this canvas he admittedly used "pastel colors which never seem to offend the eye," but was candid enough to acknowledge that a city so large could never be a paradise.
The nation's steel industry turned out 9,806,000 net tons of steel last month -- more than in any other April in history -- the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.
BUFFALO, May 10 -- It was suggested today that man might be better off trying to live in peaceful coexistence with bacteria rather than trying to rout them with antibiotics or hormones.

LONDON, May 10 -- Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin sounded in Warsaw today the keynote for a conference of eight Communist nations to establish a military alliance similar to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Secretary Charles E. Wilson sought to put an end today to Defense Department criticism of the (Hoover) Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
MOSCOW, MAY 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today announced a new 32,000,000,000, ruble ($8,000,000,000) non-interest loan, maturing in twenty years.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary George M. Humphrey emphatically, renewed today a Treasury recommendation for retroactive repeal of two 1954 tax laws providing windfalls to business.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- David Wayne, who went to Broadway in 1953 to star in "The Teahouse of the August Moon," will resume movie acting this summer. He has signed with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to co-star with Frank Sinatra and Debbie Reynolds in the studio's adaptation of the play. "The Tender Trap."

Two Brooklyn soldiers who were captured by the Communists in the Korean war will be court-martialed here -- one on a charge of murdering fellow American captives and both on charges of collaborating with the enemy.
The scholarship fund of the National Conference of Christians and Jews will be aided by a cocktail party and reception to be held on Monday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Boris Ivkov drew his semi-final round match yesterday in the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament at Buenos Aires, according to a report from Argentina.
The efforts of the Fordham University Alumni Association to raise money to revive football at Rose Hill were abandoned yesterday. The association began to return contributions.

NEWARK, May 11 -- A New York Central Railroad official indicated today that the West Shore division may be converted into a single track freight line if Government agencies approved the discontinuance of passenger service.

If a group of 12-to-16-year-old thespians did not have to get back to the three R's, there would be no telling how long "Three Tales for Talent" might run at the John Dwyer Junior High School in the Bronx.
GENEVA, May 9 -- Europe is entering its oil age with a pre-dominant coal mentality in most of the places where policy is determined.
LONDON, May 11 (Reuters) -- Following are translated excerpts from the speech by Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin in Warsaw today, as quoted by the Soviet news agency Tass:

Today marks the end of an era in Manhattan, for, subject to last-minute legal action, service on the elevated lines finally is due to stop. Like the trolley cars that once clanged along beneath them, only to make way for the buses, so are the elevated lines finally bowing out before the subways.

Heavy short covering pushed up the May potato option as much as the 1/2-cent-a-pound limit yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Profit taking lowered prices around noon, but renewed short covering closed the market near the highs of the day.

Recipients of the Theatre World's annual citations as "the most promising personalities of the Broadway stage" were announced yesterday by Daniel Blum, editor of the pictorial volume. Of the dozen awards, three were garnered by members of "Plain and Fancy" -- Shirl Conway, Barbara Cook and David Daniels.

Another of the outstanding elder statesmen of our times stepped down from his high office yesterday. President Luigi Einaudi of Italy, like Sir Winston Churchill, can look back on years of noble service to his country and -- at 81 -- can look forward to fresh years of work with pen and typewriter.
Top officials of nine privately owned bus lines and union leaders representing their 10,000 employes met yesterday to discuss ways of stopping an "alarming" decline in passenger riding.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower stirred more speculation today over whether he would be a candidate for re-election.

The part played by Booker T. Washington in the Negro's rise to a place of respect in society is told by Samuel R. Spencer Jr. in his biography of the educator, "Booker T. Washington and the Negro's Place in American Life." It will be published by Little, Brown on May 26 as a volume in its Library of American Biography series. Mr. Spencer is the author of "Decision for War 1917."

I have read with great interest the article in The New York Times for April 24 on the Olivetti plant at Pozzuoli. I should like, however, to amplify one statement of fact concerning the wage rate at the factory.
ALBANY, May 11 -- Governor Harriman and the Republican State Chairman clashed today over charges that the Democratic Administration planned to "short-change" upstate counties on highway aid.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- Psychiatrists, who are supposed to help others achieve happiness, were depicted today as often being themselves misunderstood, friendless fellows desperately trying to make a living.

Best Co., specialty store chain, announced yesterday the election of Walter Strickland as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Philip LeBoutillier, president and general manager, who has been elected to the new office of chairman, continuing as a member of the executive and management operating committees.
The Brooklyn Eagle began to crumble yesterday under the auctioneer's hammer after 114 years of service to the city's largest borough.

William B. Herlands was nominated yesterday by President Eisenhower to be a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York. If confirmed, the former State Commissioner of Investigation would succeed Judge Edward A. Conger, who retired last October.

Florida Power Corporation is offering to holders of its common stock rights to buy 232,557 new shares of common stock at $43 a share on the basis of one new share for each ten held. The offer, which will expire on May 31, is underwritten by a syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- Directors of Federal-Mogul Corporation and Bower Roller Bearing Company today voted to submit to their shareholders a plan to merge the two companies. Both concerns produce bearings of various types.

The market value of the stocks of twenty leading life insurance companies rose 6.9 per cent in the three weeks ending May 6. Morgan Co., Los Angeles specialists in the field, said the rise put the aggregate at a new high.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation in all except twos section, where his remarks are given in indirect discourse in accordance with Whtie House rules.

A near future in which a freer spending but more sophisticated American consumer will compel more subtle sales appeals was forecast yesterday at the Toilet Goods Association's twentieth annual convention. More than 1,000 persons in the toiletries and cosmetics industry are attending the meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 11 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad will build the projected regional rail station here with its own financing "as a last resort" if the city or private capital fails to undertake the Job.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Congress sent to the White House today a postal pay bill that had long been under implied threats of a Presidential veto.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., May 11 -- An experiment of lecturing "moderate" speeders instead of issuing summonses was begun here today.
Jersey City dockworkers were "ordered" to join a Bayonne longshoremen's local if they wanted to get steady work at the Leonardo Naval Base, it was testified yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A West Coast shipping man told Congress today that a maritime dispute was responsible for loss of the liner Mariposa by the American merchant marine.

MAYBE the people responsible for "Safari!", realizing at the last moment that they had spawned a tasteless and spiritless little revue decided that if they added an exclamation point to their title audiences would think they were seeing a sequel to "Oklahoma!" But scarcely anyone at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre, where the offering fizzled into view last evening, was fooled for a minute.
TOKYO, March 11 -- The whistling of a few 155-mm. shells over the heads of villagers on the slopes of Mount Fuji is becoming a big issue in United States-Japanese relations.

PARIS, May 11 -- The first purely political meeting of the North Atlantic Council closed today with a statement welcoming the Western proposal for negotiations with the Soviet Union. It urged careful preparation and patient determination.

ACF Industries, Inc., railroad equipment builder, unveiled its newest product yesterday, a sample railroad passenger section of its Talgo train. The Talgo is a high-capacity, lightweight and high-speed passenger train, which the company first developed after World War II for the Spanish National Railways and which it is now building for two American railroads -- the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific and New York, New Haven and Hartford.
LONDON, May 11 -- The stock markets were irregular here today.
HONOLULU, T. H., May 11 -- Hawaiians expressed discouragement and anger today following word that the House of Representatives yesterday voted to recommit the joint Hawaii-Alaska statehood bill.
Recent favorites took a beating on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. And the market as a whole was hammered down further than in any other session since March 14.
BONN, Germany, May 11 -- The Western European Union Council agreed today to assume responsibility for enforcement of the French-German accord creating a semi-autonomous regime in the Saar.
Henri Bendel, Inc., one of the city's "carriage trade" women's apparel specialty shops for fifty-nine years, has been sold to Nicholas Parker.

PARIS, May 11 -- Franz Etzel, vice chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, announced in Strasbourg today that a new system of coal sales in the Ruhr would replace the existing coal sales cartel.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York obtained $1,850,000 yesterday at five fund-raising meetings.

CALISTOGA, Calif., May 11 -- Rocky Marciano returned to ring action today after a two-day "vacation." The world heavyweight champion stepped four rounds against sparring partners in the indoor ring of the Napa County Fairground.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today the Eisenhower Administration had brought about a fundamental change in government -- a trend back to state leadership in social and economic legislation. He addressed a national conference on state labor legislation.

Plans were discussed here yesterday for training a military- civilian defense team to coordinate the nation's moral, social, political, psychological and economic resources with its military preparation.

A drop last week of 2,516,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 174,243,000 barrels, compared with 176,759,000 a week earlier and 175,874,000 a year earlier.

An example of industry-labor cooperation affecting the public interest on an important metropolitan problem was announced yesterday when transit unions and privately operated bus lines in New York began a study to determine cause and remedy for the sharp decline in riding on mass transportation facilities.
MEXICO CITY, MAY 11 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines officially opened the eighth World Health Assembly of the world Health Organization today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower today urged every community to organize its own conference on education.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 11 -Gov. J. Bracken Lee of Utah today called the National Education Association "the most powerful and dangerous lobby in America today."
PARIS, May 11 (AP) -- The text of the communique issued by the North Atlantic Council today follows:

A tract of forty-six acres in Herricks, L. I., has been sold by T. Ross Clancey and Jacob Gellman through their Searington Holding Company. The buyer is George Haber, who plans to improve the site with houses.

I was surprised by the negative attitude in "Topics of The Times" on May 1 concerning, Austria, an attitude which is not in line with the friendly and positive spirit which The New York Times has always shown toward my country.

The Metropolitan Opera Company will extend its season to twenty-four weeks -- an increase of two weeks -- in 1956-57 as the result of a new contract signed with Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, stirred up a hornet's nest yesterday when he ordered the Board of Examiners to give a second examination to a candidate who failed the first one. Three other persons had qualified for the key position involved.

THE abundance or scarcity of one species of fish can make or break the summer fishing season for the average salt water angler. However, all signs point to an assurance of real action, for the bluefish are early, large and abundant.
Southern California and Chicago appeared yesterday to be among the few areas in which a sizable proportion of parents were withdrawing their children from poliomyelitis vaccination programs.
Into the books at Belmont Park yesterday went a new record for an old stakes race.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Jacob K. Javits said today that Congressional approval of the Bricker amendment would "give a resounding vote of no confidence in the President's conduct of the foreign policy of the United States."

Detectives investigated yesterday a strange case in which one man was beaten over the head with a soda pop bottle by one robber and another said he was forced to withdraw $100 from a savings account and give it to the robber's partner.
The regional Red Cross will collect blood today from employes of two concerns in Long Island City, Queens -- the National Sugar Refining Company and Waldes-Kohinoor, Inc.

Half a hundred food and beverage manufacturers staged exhibits keyed to the popular theme, "Chicken Outdoors," last night at the McAlpin Hotel. The occasion was the chicken-with-allied-foods exposition held annually by the Poultry and Egg National Board, trade agency, in cooperation with the National Pretzel Bakers Institute.

For hollandaise, the sauce so delicious with asparagus, fresh salmon and other warm-weather foods, butter is indispensable. Particularly welcome, therefore, is the recent price decline that brought this golden table fat to 69 cents a pound in many stores.

Thomas J. Curran called yesterday for a meeting of the New York County Republican Committee, which he heads. The group will gather Wednsday at the Central Commercial High School, 214 East Forty-second Street.
Governor Harriman defended last night his veto of the legislative bill that would have amended the Optional Permanent Personal Registration Act.
KINGSTON, R. I., May 5 -- Does the parent exist who, after reading junior's favorite story for the hundredth time, has not aspired to writing a children's story himself? It is unlikely.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- The new Soviet disarmament proposals are generally viewed by Western delegates here as an ingenious attempt to regain the diplomatic initiative from the Western powers.
Students from the North and South revealed yesterday that they differed only slightly on the mechanics of desegregation in the nation's schools, but not on the necessity for it.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Parking congestion was described today as a world-wide problem with no relief in sight.

Television advertisers come and go like shifting winds, but there was more than routine interest in the announcement yesterday by the Aluminum Company of America. It said it would discontinue sponsorship of Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" program after July 5.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 11 (UP) -- Leaders from the United States and Great Britain joined with the City of Rochester tonight in paying tribute to Frank E. Gannett, a farm boy who rose to great power in the newspaper world, and to his wife, the former Miss Caroline Werner.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- Americans put $11,700,000,000 into savings last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
CANNES, France, May 11 -- "Marty," a United States entry, today won the Golden Palm grand prize at the 1955 Cannes International Film Festival. The verdict was a popular one.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

ROME, May 11 -- In his inaugural speech Italy's new President, Giovanni Gronchi, today expressed his belief that the extreme left-wing parties should be admitted into the Government. To admit them peacefully, he said, is a "fundamental interest of Italian democracy.''
Color-fastness is uppermost in the consumer's mind when buying soft goods, a recent survey of 3,300 store buyers and merchandise managers reveals.

The trustees of the Ford Foundation could hardly have chosen a more fruitful field to cultivate with $15,000,000 than that of mental health -- and especially the area of research into which, over the next five to ten years, the funds will go.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower said today the proposed meeting of the Big Four heads of government would be a test of Soviet sincerity about reducing East-West tensions.
NEW HAVEN, May 11 -- Yale University has received a $100,000 grant from the Ford Foundation to help support a training program for young foreign economists.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -President Eisenhower cautiously endorsed arbitration today as a possible device for ending the Southern Bell Telephone strike.

A combination of Southern Democrats and Northern Republicans in the House has apparently killed the chances of Alaska and Hawaii for statehood at this session of Congress. By recommitting a bill to admit both of them together into the Union, the House has effectively blocked the entry of either.
BUFFALO, May 11 -- Stray radiation hazards are increasing as atomic activities increase and it is time to educate the public on how to guard against them.

BOSTON, May 11 (UP) -- Ted Williams, his marital problems settled by a Miami court, agreed today to rejoin the Boston Red Sox for another season. The campaign will be his fourteenth in the major leagues.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 11 -- Twenty young inmates at the Nassau County Jail staged a thirty-five-minute demonstration in the third-floor youthful offender cell block here this afternoon. They were demanding better food and more privileges. Peace was restored by three well-placed tear-gas shells. No one was injured.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power borrowed $6,000,000 yesterday on an issue of revenue bonds due serially from 1956 to 1985.
CHICAGO, May 11 -- United States Gypsum Company increased its first quarter earnings 35 per cent over a year ago, voted an extra dividend of $1 a share and is considering a stock split.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- William J. Sebald, Assistant Secretary of State, declared today that Communist forces in the Far East "are poised for action and remain a constant threat to world peace."

Southern California Edison Company advanced yesterday plans for the offering of up to $40,950,600 of convertible debentures to holders of the company's common and preferred stock, following approval of the proposal by the California Public Utilities Commission.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 11 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali said tonight that Pakistan had accepted the offer of Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egyptian Premier, to mediate in the dispute with Afghanistan.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Right-wing Republican voices were raised today over President Eisenhower's expressed willingness to negotiate with Communist Russia and China. They ranged from skeptical warning to unrestrained denunciation.
LONDON, May 11 -- The Western powers criticized the Soviet declaration on disarmament today as obscure and evasive on the key question of effective international control of nuclear weapons.
Gertrude Berg's determination to return to Broadway next fall has not wavered, but the vehicle will not be the one announced for her last winter.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -President Eisenhower called today for more information before deciding whether to increase current tariff rates on bicycles.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 12 -- The death toll in the sinking of the Japanese railway ferry Shiun Maru, which sank off Shikoku Island yesterday morning, rose to 128 this morning. The National Railway Corporation announced that twenty-nine persons still were missing.
MILWAUKEE, May 11 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves nipped a budding jinx today by trimming the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 3, on the batting power of Ed Mathews and Joe Adcock.

The price of foreign silver was advanced 1 1/2 cents an ounce yesterday to 88 1/2 cents by Handy Harman, leading refiner and fabricator of precious metals. This was the first change since April 4, when the price was reduced by the same amount.
Frank Pace Jr., former Secretary of the Army, yesterday described the Government's security program as basically "orderly, fair and effective."

PARIS, Thursday, May 12 -- Complete agreement on Indochina policy between the United States and France was announced by Edgar Faure, French Premier, early today after a long talk with Secretary of State Dulles.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 4:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Government asked the Federal District Court today to dismiss a suit by the major rubber manufacturers to block a Federal Trade Commission order limiting price discounts on large sales of tires and tubes.
The Yankees, by selling three men and sending one out on option, cut down to the twenty-five-player limit yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Shipyard experts and members of Congress chose sides today at a public hearing involving the award of a $25,000,000 shipbuilding contract.

The body of a man buried on Monday in the collapse of temporary flooring at the New York Coliseum on Columbus Circle was found yesterday. He was identified as Joseph Lombardi, 55 years old, a cement worker, of 172 Lake Street, Brooklyn.
Robbers on the loose yesterday in Manhattan stole more than $6,000 in cash, jewelry and travelers checks from a dentist, a furrier and a travel agent.

Four universities -- Columbia, Harvard, Princeton and Yale -- will receive $290,000 each from the Higgins Trust for a wide range of scientific studies. The total of $1,160,000 is $60,000 more than the total distributed to these universities by the trust last year.
Negotiations are nearing conclusion for the purchase by Universal-International of screen rights to the play, "Teach Me How to Cry."
" IT was a very short night," said Phil Rizzuto, unbuttoning his sports shirt as he jauntily stepped through the clubhouse door at the Yankee Stadium yesterday morning.
Differing city and state views on what should be done about children who received so-called "less effective" poliomyelitis vaccine in 1954 tests were disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, May 11 -- Clement R. Attlee, Labor party leader, put the issue of a two-year conscription term into the forefront of the election campaign tonight.
Cured and smoked beef tongue, both attractively priced, are popular for hot weather meals.
CHICAGO, May 11 (UP) -Archie McBride shook off Bob Satterfield's most potent punches tonight and gained a ten-round majority decision at the Chicago Stadium.

Thousands of refugees from Northern Vietnam are streaming into the port of Haiphong to get ahead of the official closing of the port on May 16. It is the contention of the free Vietnamese that the Communists to the north have made a mockery of the Geneva pledge to allow free exit from that area.

We have become increasingly alarmed by reports that the House may vote a compulsory military reserve bill which obligates all young men to six years of reserve service in addition to the draft and which amounts to giving our country peacetime military indoctrination.

NEWARK, May 11 (AP) -- The strikebound McKesson Robbins, Inc., announced today it had closed its Newark plant because demands of union teamsters "made it impossible to operate with efficiency and economy."

The first-quarter consolidated net income of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., was a record $3,892,677, William S. Paley, chairman, reported yesterday. It was 36 per cent more than the $2,866,365 earned in the corresponding period last year.
This country's tariff system has been described as a maze and a jungle. Its tariff rates, on the average, have also been described as among the lowest in the world.
GROTON, Conn., May 11 (AP) -- The nuclear - powered submarine Nautilus returned unexpectedly today to her maker's yards here at the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

Development of a vaccine against Type 2 dengue fever, a virus disease prevalent in the Pacific that laid low many service men during World War II, was reported yesterday. The report was made at the annual meeting of the Society of American Bacteriologists.

CHICAGO, May 11 - Wheat prices turned irregular today, following yesterday's announcement of the Government's crop estimate for May. The report was about in line with private forecasts. There was a rather heavy tone early today, but prices rallied later on commission buying, although pit business was quiet on the whole.
New increased tariffs for loading and unloading trucks on New York piers were suspended yesterday for thirty-one days ending June 13.
GENEVA, May 11 -- The European Cultural Foundation announced today that it intended to raise $10,000,000 for the support of individual and group cultural endeavor in Western Europe.

VIENNA, May 11 -- The ambassadors' conference on the Austrian state treaty was deadlocked again today. The impasse arose over the Russians' insistence that their original economic claims on Austria remain in the treaty while modifications of those claims be embodied in a separate Austrian-Soviet agreement.
Mayor Wagner will go to Washington next Wednesday to appeal for Federal funds for evacuation planning.
Communist strength in Latin America is weakening and resentment of "Yankee imperialism" diminishing, Herbert L. Matthews, editorial writer for The New York Times, told city teachers yesterday.

LONDON, May 11 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of statements tonight by Anthony Nutting, British Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, and James J. Wadsworth, United States delegate to disarmament talks here on the new Soviet disarmament plan:
An audiometer designed to eliminate guesswork in hearing tests was seen at the dedication yesterday of a new hearing center at the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, 61 Irving Place.
A "French-and-Indian-War" approach consisting of "sporadic forays" will not meet the problem of juvenile delinquency, Mark A. McCloskey, chairman of the State Youth Commission, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- The House voted today to consider President Eisenhower's compulsory military reserve training bill next Tuesday after being assured it was not the openingwedge for universal military training.

Samuel Orlovsky has purchased the store and apartment building at 412-16 Central Avenue in Orange, N. J., from the Damar Company. The building contains seven stores and six apartments. It occupies a corner plot 75 by 90 feet. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
A prisoner serving a life sentence for murder will get a new trial because of mistreatment by the New York police.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries, the world's largest papermaking organization, attained its highest sales for any quarter in the first three months this year. Earnings set a new first-quarter record.
LONDON, May 11 -- The British Council, a Government-sponsored cultural organization, has set up a committee to promote closer cultural relations and mutual understanding with the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- The winning streaks of the Dodgers and Russ Meyer were shattered simultaneously at Wrigley Field today. The Cubs beat the Brooks, 10 -- 8, snapping the Brooklyn string at eleven games.

The B.V.D. Company, which makes men's and boys' furnishings and sportswear, as well as the underwear with which the name is associated, was honored yesterday by the Brand Names Foundation. The occasion was the seventy-fifth anniversary of the trade-mark as an advertising product.
MACASSAR, Celebes, May 10 -- Terror in the southern half of the Celebes has grown, although the region has been under military rule for more than three years.

Bob Turley, the right-handed ace of the Yankees, held the Cleveland Indians to three singles and struck out eleven yesterday at the Stadium. Still the visitors won, 4 -- 3, swept the set here and headed for Washington with a six-game winning streak.

WARSAW, Poland, May 11 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union said today that the Western proposal for a conference of Big Four heads of government would be "carefully studied" by his Government.

Matching or harmonizing the color of kitchen cabinets, walls and appliances with a newly purchased colored refrigerator or range is a problem. It has been solved by at least two appliance manufacturers and a paint concern.
Ontario is willing to resume its agreement with the United States on new mining securities on one condition.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 11 -Admiral Felix B. Stump said today that the Seventh Fleet could "take care of itself" despite the Communist air build-up in the Formosa Straits.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- David Sarnoff's thesis that the United States should not economize too drastically on informational activities necessary to win the "cold war" received today the full support of President Eisenhower.

LONDON, May 11 -- By a majority of one vote the tugmen on the Mersey River decided today to end the week-old wildcat strike, which had virtually paralyzed the port of Liverpool. Full operations will begin tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (UP) -- Police Inspector John F. Driscoll said today no trace of drugs had been found in a piece of rind from a "bitter-tasting" orange that Harold Johnson ate before his bout with Julio Mederos last Friday night.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The main points made by President Eisenhower at his news conference today were:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 11 -- A resolution urging enlargement of the Caribbean Commission was circulated to the West Indian Conference tonight by the Puerto Rican delegation.
The pink and blue world once considered the only appropriate one for children is fast disappearing. And youngsters, it appears, are all in favor of the change.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed his confidence today that the Salk vaccine would wipe out poliomyelitis in the United States "within a measurable time."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The United States protested today against an "unwarranted and illegal attack" by Chinese Communist planes against United States aircraft off Korea yesterday.
DES MOINES, May 11 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. charged his predecessors with "virtual toleration" of men who had "infested and poisoned" relations between management and labor.
Evidence to support perjury charges against two members of the Police Department's narcotics squad was obtained by a miniature portable tape recorder.

The novelty on last night's program in the season of "American Dance" at the ANTA Theatre consisted of a pair of solos by Iris Mabry, to the music of Ralph Gilbert, with the composer at the piano. They are called "Lamb of God" and "Dreams."
BONN, Germany, May 11 -- West German Government circles have reacted cautiously to the Soviet disarmament plan made public today. The Social Democrats, however, hailed it as a "step forward."
As preparations were being made for the last rumble this evening of Manhattan's Third Avenue Elevated, the battle over its continuance was joined again.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- Ned Garver hurled a three-hitter today as Detroit beat the Washington Senators, 7-0. The victory was the third for Garver and snapped the Tigers' three-game losing streak.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 11 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today he had instructed his office to file an antitrust suit tomorrow against the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
" Regretful opposition" to the proposal before the City Council to create a city stabilization fund was expressed yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
CHICAGO. May 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Government received the Soviet Union's disarmament proposals cautiously today. They were described as an important move meriting careful consideration.

Half-and-half was approved recently by the City Department of Health. This is not the half beer, half porter popular in British pubs but a milk product with a butterfat content lower than light cream but higher than milk.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In a 3-to-2 decision the Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Standard Sewing Equipment Corporation of New York to stop selling sewing machines in which Japanese-made "heads" were not plainly marked.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee revealed today it had ordered an investigation of multi-billion dollar defense buying on which the taxpayer was said to be "losing his shirt."
TOMS RIVER, N. J., May 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner led Robert Moses and other New York and New Jersey officials today on an extensive tour of near-by Island Beach.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 11 -Prosecutor H. Russell Morss Jr. today described as a coincidence the suicides last Monday of Capt. August F. Winkelmann, head of the detective bureau here, and Francis B. De Stephan of the Board of Fire Commissioners.
In a further move to recapture business lost to other forms of shipping, the Railway Express Agency announced yesterday a 25 per cent cut in shipping rates on many items of wearing apparel.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- The wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers Union approved plans today to open bargaining here June 7 with the United States Steel Corporation for a "substantial wage increase." annual wage as a "basic and fundamental objective of the[ union, to be negotiated at thel !earliest permissible date." Under] i the present contracts this would[ !be next yea,'.

The Isthmian Steamship Company opened its newly enlarged Erie Basin terminal to public inspection yesterday and 400 visitors saw one of the most modern and efficient shipping and trucking facilities in the port.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 11 -Prosecutor H. Russell Morss Jr. today described as a coincidence the suicides last Monday of Capt. August F. Winkelmann, head of the detective bureau here, and Francis B. De Stephan of the Board of Fire Commissioners.
In a further move to recapture business lost to other forms of shipping, the Railway Express Agency announced yesterday a 25 per cent cut in shipping rates on many items of wearing apparel.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- The wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers Union approved plans today to open bargaining here June 7 with the United States Steel Corporation for a "substantial wage increase." annual wage as a "basic and fundamental objective of the[ union, to be negotiated at thel !earliest permissible date." Under] i the present contracts this would[ !be next yea,'.

The Isthmian Steamship Company opened its newly enlarged Erie Basin terminal to public inspection yesterday and 400 visitors saw one of the most modern and efficient shipping and trucking facilities in the port.

An international festival of music and drama will be held in Athens this summer under the sponsorship of the Greek Government. Dinno Yannopoulos, Metropolitan Opera stage direc-Theatre participating. A special feature will be two concerts by the New York Philharmonictor, will serve as its artistic director.

Former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade cut his wife, Mrs. Lucille McQuade, off with $1, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court. The petition to probate was not filed, hence the value of the estate was not disclosed.

The last train on the Third Avenue Elevated rolled out of the Chatham Square station at 6 o'clock last night. Having served a changing city for three-quarters of a century, the last of the borough's "El" lines itself fell victim to change.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today announced the filing of a civil anti-trust suit against the American Linen Supply Company of Chicago, Frank G. Steiner, its president, and Jonas H. Mayer, its vice president.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Official sources said today that the crucial shortcoming of the new Soviet disarmament proposal was the virtual abdication of controls over the output of weapons.

Two thousand women at luncheons yesterday in nine major cities across the country let others serve them for a change. The group was made up of stewardesses, former and present, who have stood mile after mile in United Airlines planes making the trip comfortable for the passengers.

A collection of excerpts from the books and public documents that were most frequently read or referred to by our Colonial ancestors during the period of the shaping of the American democracy will be published Wednesday by the University of Minnesota Press.
CAIRO, May 12 -- Yemen is planning to open the coffers of the late Iman Yahya of Yemen, assassinated in a palace coup in 1948, to finance an economic development program.

Large numbers of chronically disabled persons can be rehabilitated to the point of self-care and employment, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, said last night.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on last Saturday totaled 740,935 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., May 12 -- The New York Conference of Methodists took up a racial issue at a business session here today.
The possibility that New York may soon be deprived of so world-renowned an institution as Carnegie Hall is most disheartening.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered hearings today on the railroad industry's request that temporary freight rate increases granted in 1952 be made permanent.
The Corinthian Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday was a sort of preview of American stars for the $20,000-added International to be run on May 21.
Stockholders of the National State Bank of Newark have been called to vote on May 23 on a proposal of the bank's directors that issuance of 180,000 new shares of stock be authorized.

HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Friday, May 13 (AP) -- Thousands of Communist Vietminh troops swept into the northwest section of this big seaport yesterday. The occupation of Haiphong will be completed today, ending French colonialism in North Indochina.

NEWARK, May 12 -- Mrs. Hortense Fuld Kessler, head of the New Jersey Public Utility Commission, called on the New York Central Railroad today to produce figures on the cost of freight haulage on the West Shore Division.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to sponsor a two-year liberal arts and science community college for Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Census Bureau confirmed today what every unmarried woman knows: Men are getting scarcer.
CHICAGO, May 12 -- The key to more jobs and higher wages is industrial research, not "contractual devices," Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said tonight that the job outlook was good for the 264,000 students scheduled to graduate from college next month.

The story of the "Household octopus -- and how is grew" is a rather shocking one. As told in a pamphlet, "Improving Your Home's Wiring System," the saga deals with a common situation in almost every house today.

Changes are taking place in European economic policies and practice which don't make news from day to day but which, in their cumulative effect, may some day be recognized as having brought about a profound industrial revolution. Happily, its effects may well be beneficent beyond measure for all Europeans -- except the Communists, whose doctrines it would render increasingly irrelevant.

The city's major drive on juvenile delinquency was opened yesterday with an appropriation of $50,000 to combat teen-age gangs in the southeast Bronx. Justice Nathaniel Kaplan of the Domestic Relations Court, chairman of the Youth Board, promptly announced that a team of thirty social workers would move as soon as possible into the Morrisania-Belmont and Mott Haven-Longwood areas.
The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs opposes fluoridation of the city's public water, according to a recent article in The New York Times, on grounds which appear unsound.

Last night's performance of "American Dance" at the ANTA Theatre was devoted for the second time entirely to Martha Graham and her company. It drew the largest audience of the series, with standees all around.
LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) -- London's most fashionable food store, where champagne and caviar are common fare, opened a new enterprise today -- an American-style soda fountain.

One of six employes of the State Liquor Authority refused to sign a waiver of immunity when called yesterday before a Near York County grand jury investigating the agency. He was identified by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office as Louis Levine, 55 years old of 226-05 135th Avenue, Laurelton, Queens, a Liquor Authority investigator for twenty years.

I would like to call attention to some recent dispatches from Johannesburg relative to the new policies on native education. Last month more than 5,000 Protestant mission schools were taken over by the South African Government when the Bantu Education Act went into effect and within the last few days, the only college in South Africa devoted to Negro education was closed indefinitely by the Government.
