SINGAPORE, Friday, May 13 -- Two persons were killed and about 100 injured in rioting by 2,000 Communist-led bus workers and students.

Net income of the Pure Oil Company for the first quarter this year increased to $9,429,000 from $7,112,000 in the initial three months last year, the report of Rawleigh Warner, board chairman, and Robert L. Milligan, president, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Department of Justice disclosed today that a settlement may be in the offing in its six-year-old antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
LONDON, May 12 -- Diplomats of the five-nation Disarmament Subcommittee today weighed for the first time in detail the Soviet proposals for disarmament.
Events today: Bruce Prince-Joseph, organist, Hunter College, 12:10 P. M.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Mickey McDermott outpitched Herb Score tonight as the Washington Senators shut out the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 0. McDermott yielded four scattered hits in throwing his first shutout of the year.

This is the day, above all others in the year 1955, when prudence urges that we remain indoors, to emerge, if at all, only for the necessities, and to scurry back to safety when these have been obtained.

LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) -- British exports totaling 244,800,000 ($685,440,000) during April brought the average increase of exports for the first four months of this year to 10 per cent above the same period of 1954.
HONG KONG, May 12 -- A drive to purge "decadent elements" is developing among the rank and file of the Chinese Communist party.

PARIS, May 12 -- Negotiations between Mr. Dulles and French Premier Edgar Faure on Indochina were reported to have struck snags tonight. M. Faure said early today there had been complete agreement and this was indicated also in United States quarters.
BONN, Germany, May 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer returned today victorious in his battle to win for West Germany an equal place among nations but faced with new problems.
Not all the trees in Manhattan are outdoors. There is one, a fifteen-foot silver maple, in the center of the third-floor studio apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Max Furlaud, just off Union Square.

LONDON, May 12 -- Clement R. Attlee and Aneurin Bevan fraternized on the same platform tonight in a demonstration that the feud between the two wings of the Labor party had been shelved in the interests of election victory May 26.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The inter-American finance company proposed at New Orleans early this year to stimulate private investment in Latin America is about to become a reality.
BONN, Germany, May 12 -- One of Hitler's most important propaganda instruments will be broken up into at least four independent stock companies, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -Senator Herbert H. Lehman tonight charged President Eisenhower with "utter complacency" and "callous indifference" to what the Senator called encroachments on civil liberties.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 12 -- The emergence of a middle economic class among the Negroes in Leopoldville is regarded as one of the important recent phenomena in Africa.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 12 -- Frank Strafaci and Billy Edwards tied for honors in the qualifying round of the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament today. Each had a 70.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the United States during the week ended on last Saturday were 9 per cent above sales in the same period of last year.
ALBANY, May 12 (AP) -- Jacob K. Javits, the Attorney General, moved today under the state's Charity Rackets Law to stop an Arizona organization from soliciting funds in New York.

The net earnings of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, 95 per cent owned by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), were $75,900,000 in the first quarter of this year, H. W. Haight, president, told stockholders at their meeting held here yesterday. This compares with $61,800,000 in the similar period last year.

THE sleepy New York Public Library lions, forty-four years old today, have become international figures. Not infrequently mail for the staid institution they dreamily guard comes addressed to "The Lion Library."
Salary increases for policemen and firemen totaling $10,000,000 a year were approved last night by the Board of Estimate.

One of the bulwarks of our national defense and a spearhead of our peacetime progress in the air is celebrating the fortieth anniversary of its establishment. This is the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, founded by Act of Congress and first appointed by President Wilson in 1915.
Former employes of The Brooklyn Eagle received a temporary setback yesterday in their effort to get $750,000 in severance pay and notice of dismissal pay from the defunct newspaper.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy was accused of "Ducking and dodging" questions at a house hearing today.

Among the many good selections at meat counters this week, lamb shoulder chops are outstanding. At a most general price of 79 cents a pound, they are cheaper than they have been at this season since 1947, the City Department of Markets reports.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- The run-starved Boston Red Sox ended the famine today by getting fifteen hits -- including home runs by Gene Stephens and Jackie Jensen -- for a 12-7 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
Stocks broke sharply yesterday, going to the lowest levels since April 25, but reduced their losses with a late rally.
Rome, May 12 -- President Giovanni Gronchi was deprived today of any possibility of experimenting with an opening to the extreme left-wing parties for admission to the Government.
Many luncheon parties will be given preceding the opening tour of country kitchens and representative houses in Greenwich, Conn., on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons.

A plot 95 by 100 feet at 318 to 324 East Fifty-fourth Street, between First and Second Avenues, has been purchased by a syndicate controlled by Max Steinberg. It will be improved with an apartment house.
The current campaign of the Greater New York Fund is devoted among other aims, to helping thousands of boys and girls to lead healthier and happier lives.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The sudden spate of forecasts that the President will not accept renomination, unless duty calls next year in tones that cannot be denied by a man of military background, has brought happiness to the Democrats. Because of the sources many politicians surmise that the prophecies were direct relays from the horse's mouth.
GROTON, Conn., May. 12 (AP) -- The nuclear powered submarine Nautilus, a small leak repaired, headed for San Juan, Puerto Rico, today.

At 10:30 this morning the Montgomery Ward score will be posted in Chicago. At that time the penultimate session of the annual meeting will be called to order at Ward headquarters and the election inspectors, who have been tabulating stockholders' votes since the tumultuous meeting adjourned April 22, will announce the result of the election of directors.

Following is the text of a statement by Richard W. Slocum, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, on the Government's anti- trust suit against newspaper, magazine and advertising associations:
The Immaculata Singers, a chorus of about eighty - five young people from the Immaculata High School of New York, gave a program last night in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Indian and Pakistani representatives in Washington resumed negotiations today, under the mediating auspices of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, on division of the waters of the Indus River.

PARIS, May 12 -- Secretary of State Dulles will leave Paris tomorrow morning by plane for Vienna, where he will join the foreign ministers of Britain, France and the Soviet Union in signing the Austrian state treaty Sunday.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 12 -- Joseph A. Lucas of Rutgers won the Metropolitan Golf Association's sixth annual intercollegiate championship today. Playing over the difficult west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club, Lucas carded a 38, 41 -- 79.
The "Omnibus" program, which ended its third season last month, may switch to the National Broadcasting Company television network in the fall.
There are between eighty and 100 juvenile gangs that fight one another in the streets of New York. Yet, there is no such thing as a typical street gang.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "The Prodigal," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in CinemaScope and color, co-starring Lana Turner and Edmund Purdom, is at the Capitol. Charles Schnee produced and Richard Thorpe directed from a scenario by Maurice Zimm.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., May 12 -- Don Cockell, the English heavyweight contender, went through a serious sparring session of five rounds today in preparation for his world championship bout with Rocky Marciano at San Francisco on Monday night.
Following is the text of the complaint in an anti-trust suit filed by the Department of Justice yesterday against six trade associations representing newspapers, magazines and advertising agencies:
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, has ordered the dismissal from the service of a Hollywood, Ill., officer convicted of the murder of a South Korean.

According to a special dispatch received last night from Buenos Aires, Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia drew the last game of his schedule in the jubilee chess tournament against Alfredo Esposito of Argentina. Ivkov was declared the winner of the tournament with a score of 13 -- 4.
PARAMUS, N. J., May 12 -- Giant earth-movers, bulldozers and power shovels rumbled impressively into the 110-acre site of the $60,000,000 Bergen Mall shopping center here this morning.
The head of a $500,000,000-a-year department store network intimated yesterday that "fair trade" was becoming as discredited as Prohibition just before repeal.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House of Representatives approved today a defense budget of $31,488,206,000. In doing so it sustained President Eisenhower's cuts in the strength of the armed services. The vote was 382 to 0.
A LARGE number of one-man exhibitions opening this week keeps the late season lively.

In the first major European settlement between East and West since the outbreak of the cold war, the Ambassadors of the Big Four Powers have now reached complete and unanimous agreement on all articles of the long-delayed treaty for the restoration of an independent and democratic Austria.

President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy started his seven-year term on Wednesday with a flourish. Without quite saying so he gave his listeners to believe that he was suggesting a Government which would include the left-wing Socialists and perhaps the Communists.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -George V. Allen said today that the free peoples of Asia had a better than even chance to make their freedom secure if the United States continued to give them adequate assistance.
ALBANY, May 12 -Recipients of the annual scholarships awarded by the State Board of Regents were announced today.

Eight industrial organizations are joining with the New York Stock Exchange house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane in the "How to Invest Show" that will open on May 24 in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street.
The Institute for the Crippled and Disabled will be the beneficiary of the preview performance on May 25 of "Seventh Heaven" at the ANTA Theatre.

American industry received an opportunity yesterday to display its atomic wares at the International Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy at Geneva, Switzerland, Aug. 8 through 20. Molesworth Associates, a New York public relations firm specializing in the nuclear energy field, has obtained a 10,000-square-foot area for the display, which it will sublease to exhibitors.

The motion-picture industry's Production Code has failed to stem an increase in "objectionable" films, the Rev. Thomas F. Little, executive secretary of the National Legion of Decency, charged yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, May 12 -- America has grown rich too fast too carelessly and too thoughtlessly, James A. Farley of New York said tonight. The former Postmaster General addressed the closing convention session of the Boys Clubs of America.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 12 (UP) -- Mike Souchak of Durham, N. C.; Dow Finsterwald of Bedford, Ohio, and Peter Thomson of Melbourne, Australia, tied for the first-round lead today in the Greenbrier open golf tournament with six-under-par 64's.
Neither Government regulation nor industry self-regulation in the field of securities advertising is proving adequate to protect investors, J. Sinclair Armstrong declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- The third trial of the $200,000 libel brought by Michael Jeffers, actor, against the Screen Extras Guild, A. F. L., began today in Superior Court with the selection of a jury. Judge Harold W. Schweitzer is presiding.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Sam Jones nearly was "yanked" right out of his no-hitter after filling the bases with three walks in the ninth inning today.
THE decision of the Aluminum Company of America not to continue sponsorship next season of Edward R. Murrow's, program "See It Now" marks the close of an unusual chapter in television broadcasting.

For the second time in as many days, a man was forced by a robber to withdraw money from a savings account and turn it over. One hundred dollars was stolen that way in Manhattan on Wednesday; yesterday $300 was stolen that way in Queens.

Somewhat as a housewife might withdraw bank funds to pay household bills, the United States Treasury next week will withdraw some of its money from banks around the country to pay the Government's bills.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 8 to 13 points yesterday, with the old crop months stronger.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 12 -- An international conference on population problems and family planning opened here today.
BUFFALO, May 12 -- Details of a new operation that apparently has helped some cases of cerebral palsy were described here today.
With millions of others I saw Arthur Koestler's "Darkness at Noon" on TV and shared their feeling of fright and repulsion.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Board of Immigration Appeals today ordered the deportation of Cedric Henning Belfrage, a British citizen, on the ground of Communist party membership. It rejected an appeal by Belfrage from an order issued last Dec. 9 by Aaron Maltin, special inquiry officer of the Immigration Service, after hearings in New York.
SIMLA, India, May 12 -- United States hopes that the nations of Asia would get together for regional use of American economic aid are dying in Simla.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- The United States plans to sell the Swiss Government an experimental atomic reactor. The reactor, which is too small for the production of any considerable amount of power from nuclear material will be turned over to the Swiss after the United Nations conference on atomic energy in Geneva in August.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee today approved a bill to clamp tight regulations around big bank holding companies.

"Once Upon a Tailor," starring Oscar Karlweis, has been postponed. Instead of opening next Thursday night at the Cort, the Baruch Lumet comedy has been set back to May 23. Now in Philadelphia, the play will close there tomorrow night and rehearse in New York next week.
FOR the first time since the opening of the trout season, this week-end should find the fly fisherman competing on a fairly even basis with the bait dunkers.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 12 -- The Government is asking France to move her troops to the northern frontier of South Vietnam or withdraw them from the country. A spokesman said Premier Ngo Dinh Diem had instructed the Vietnamese High Commissioner in Paris to take up the matter of the French Expeditionary Corps with the French Government.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it had received subscriptions amounting to $3,177,318,000 to a 2 per cent Treasury note it offered in exchange for a $3,886,051,000 issue of Treasury certificates maturing on May 17.
MOSCOW, May 12 -- The Soviet armed forces' Chief of Staff, Marshal Vasily D. Sokolovsky, sent his "friendly greetings and best wishes" today to President Eisenhower.

A book of sixty lithographs, each designed by an artist as a donation to the welfare fund of Artists Equity Association, will appear tonight in its only edition of 2,000 copies at Equity's annual costume ball.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Lytton's, Henry C. Lytton Co., had a net loss of $23,027 in the quarter ended April 30 compared with net income of $43,069, a year earlier. Willard W. Cole, president, reported on the company's business today at the annual stockholders meeting.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A "free public library" to provide information on alleged subversive organizations and individuals is planned here.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Sam (Toothpick) Jones, towering Chicago Cub right-hander, hurled a dramatic 4-0 no-hitter against the Pittsburgh Pirates today, striking out the entire Pirate side in the ninth inning after walking the bases full.
DURHAM, England, May 12 -- Durham County has become, with South Wales, Labor's chief stronghold in Britain.

The Maryland State Roads Commission is planning to offer an issue of $25,000,000 of highway bonds in mid-June. This will be the second installment of a total authorized borrowing of $330,000,000 under the state's twelve-year highway rebuilding program.
Senator Stuart Symington accused the Eisenhower Administration last night of suppressing facts bearing on the adequacy of American military strength.

LONDON, May 12 -- Jean Anouilh's drama about St. Joan does not shove Bernard Shaw off his pedestal. Anouilh's "The Lark," which opened last evening at the Lyric Theatre in Hammersmith, has neither the size nor the passion of Shaw's "Saint Joan."
Construction is being started immediately on a $1,000,000 expansion of poliomyelitis vaccine manufacturing facilities in Michigan, Parke, Davis Co. reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending yesterday increased $261,000,000 to $18,920,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The principal change increasing reserves was a decrease of $395,000,000 in treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks.
The League of Women Voters yesterday agreed to continue its efforts for state-wide permanent personal egistration and improved primary procedures for choosing party and public officials.

Founded in 1830, Inwood House at 223 West Fifteenth Street, New York 11, is now celebrating its 125th birthday. It has always been concerned with the welfare of girls and young women in New York City. Today it offers its services -- care in a maternity home or in private foster homes together with medical, psychiatric, nursing and casework attention -- to unmarried mothers of any race or religion and from any locality.
LYNN, Mass., May 12 -- A tablet marking the site of the production in 1942 of America's first jet engine was unveiled here today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 12 -- President Juan D. Peron's supporters introduced a bill in the Argentine Senate today to end the Roman Catholic Church's exemption from taxation. The Peronista party holds all the Senate seats.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- sales of sunbeam Corporation, Chicago electrical appliance maker, in the fiscal year ended March 26! reached a record high and net income increased from a year] ago, the company's annual re-] port showed today. L
The Department of Justice began its long-threatened civil suit yesterday against six trade associations representing many the country's newspapers, magazines and advertising agencies.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 12 -- Gen. Juarez do Nascimento Fernandes Tavora has announced his candidacy for President of Brazil.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- The country's mental hospitals are burdened by an increasing number of old persons who have nowhere else to go, a leading psychiatrist said today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The House voted today to put a Congressional checkrein on Administration plans to shut down Government plants that compete with private industry.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Officials foresaw today a further delay of at least one or two weeks in the poliomyelitis vaccination program.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A Democratic substitute for President Eisenhower's highway program cleared, the Senate Public Works Committee today, by a vote of 8 to 5.
WARSAW, May 12 -- Communist China pledged "all its strength" today to the support of the new alliance of European Communist nations being formed at Warsaw.
A fire roared out of control through a two-block industrial section of Brooklyn for nearly three hours last night, injuring eighteen firemen and causing more than $2,000,000 damage.

Madison Avenue seems to be getting a bit tired of the stereotypes associated with advertising -- the Ivy League look, the charcoal suit, the pink shirt, the sincere necktie and, of course, the martini. Currently being heard is the tale of the man who asked a bartender for "a very dry martini -- please don't put any vermouth in it.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Commerce Department officials have complained that "anyone" may stroll through their buildings week-ends even though it houses 21,000 employes whose jobs involve security matters.

Howard S. Cullman became "honorary" chairman of the Port of New York Authority yesterday in a kind of changing of the guard that made a New Jersey commissioner, the also much respected Donald V. Lowe, the new chairman. Mr. Cullman had been in the chair for ten years, but on the Port Authority's board, as he will continue to be, since March, 1927, when he was appointed by Governor Alfred E. Smith.

The Fordham University campaign to raise $4,000,000 for its development program got off to a good start yesterday. It received a gift of $100,000 from the Catholic Archdiocese of New York and a personal gift of $1,000 from Cardinal Spellman.
VIENNA, May 12 -- Austria will get her state treaty.

BUENOS AIRES, May 12 -- A break in the official free exchange rate of the Argentine peso puzzled international bankers here today. The Central Bank, which has rigidly maintained a rate of 13.9 pesos to the dollar since June, 1952, permitted transactions as high as 14.28 yesterday and today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered five major steel companies to stop an alleged conspiracy to fix prices of steel drums.

MILWAUKEE, May 12 -- Del Crandall ran the Dodgers "losing streak" to two games at County Stadium tonight. The Braves' catcher whacked Ed Roebuck's second pitch over the left center-field fence in the twelfth inning for a 2-1 Milwaukee triumph.

WHEN Rockwell Kent was a young man a young woman asked him: "Why do you have to be different?" Like many an artist before him, he did not know. All he knew was that he had to be so. Mr. Kent, who is one of the foremost American artists of the twentieth century, has been different all his life.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Government will divert some 16,000 tons of copper on order for third-quarter delivery to relieve "hardship" cases among civilian producers while copper remains in short supply.

The one-story taxpayer at 501-515 Avenue P in Brooklyn has been sold by the Flagreen Realty Corporation to a syndicate of investors represented by Goodman Mabel, attorneys. The building, erected in 1949, is on a plot 150 by 100 feet. Daniel D. Cantor was the broker in the transaction and Rubinton Coleman were attorneys for the seller. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.
Charges flew at a Board of Estimate meeting yesterday that the city was planning a 375-car $1,200,000 parking garage largely for the benefit of a Bronx department store.
Roadblocks that society puts in the path of maturing adolescents were blamed last night for the spread of juvenile delinquency.

How to build a better-looking New York? This engaging question, of interest to all who live and work here, was discussed at a forum this week sponsored by the civic design committee of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, the Municipal Art Society and the Architectural League.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., May 12 (AP) -- Pennsylvania refused to go along when Civil Defense administrators of six other states agreed today to adopt new air-raid warning signals in connection with a nation-wide test exercise on June 15 and 16.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Leading business organizations argued without apparent avail today against repeal of two 1954 tax laws involving unexpectedly large revenue losses to the Government.

LONDON, May 12 -- The recent dullness of the stock markets here was relieved today by selective buying of industrial shares, some of which rose sharply on profit reports. Government funds recovered part of early losses. The net effect was that several of the medium and long-dated issues fell 2s 6d or 5 shillings (35 or 70 cents).

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 12 -- The Cantata Singers of the Eastman School of Music, a group of thirty voices conducted by David Fetler, gave a program of American compositions tonight as the twenty-fifth Festival of American Music continued in Kilbourn Hall.

A quick-thinking elevator operator pointed out an armed thug yesterday to two patrolmen, who captured him moments after he had taken $15,000 worth of jewelry and $150 in cash from a Fifth Avenue jeweler.

Donald V. Lowe, New Jersey industrialist, was elected chairman of the Port of New York Authority yesterday. He succeeds Howard S. Cullman, who retired at his own request after having served in the post longer than any other incumbent in the thirty-four-year history of the bi-state agency.

Commodity futures moved irregularly on the New York exchanges yesterday in generally dull and featureless trading. Coffee, potatoes, cottonseed oil and wool were mixed; hides, soybean oil and zinc declined, and cocoa, sugar, rubber and copper closed higher.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is completely recovered from the flu and is at Gettysburg, Pa., for the week-end, the White House reported today.
With many a hoot of the whistle, a six-car train of the Third Avenue elevated made a slow and sentimental progress early last evening.

Phillip P. Zipes, operator, bought the fifty-seven-family apartment house at 1522 University Avenue, the Bronx, from University Avenue Associates and resold it to Panzer Hirsch. The property was sold subject to mortgages of $236,720. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in both transactions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Eighteen foreign ministers will attend the tenth anniversary celebration of the United Nations in San Francisco next month.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 12 -- Opposition members of Parliament charged today that the Government would turn South Africa into an undemocratic one-party state with its bill to reconstitute the Senate.
"THE pitchers won't like it," said Casey Stengel, "but everyone else in the league will. It's the best possible thing that could have happened for our league."

CHICAGO, May 12 -- May wheat was strong in futures trading here today, advancing to a new high on the present movement with shorts finding offerings scanty. New crop wheat futures dipped early but recovered with active buying of the December and March options. Support in the new crop futures came despite further rains in the Southwest, including some in the drought areas.

Phillip P. Zipes, operator, bought the fifty-seven-family apartment house at 1522 University Avenue, the Bronx, from University Avenue Associates and resold it to Panzer Hirsch. The property was sold subject to mortgages of $236,720. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in both transactions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Eighteen foreign ministers will attend the tenth anniversary celebration of the United Nations in San Francisco next month.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 12 -- Opposition members of Parliament charged today that the Government would turn South Africa into an undemocratic one-party state with its bill to reconstitute the Senate.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., May 13 -- The Usonia Cooperative Colony near here that Frank Lloyd Wright, exponent of "organic modernism," helped to plan is in difficulties.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- A pinch-hitter, Gene Stephens, was walked home with the winning run in the ninth inning for a 4-3 Red Sox victory over Kansas City tonight. The game was delayed 1 hour 23 minutes by rain and played under protest by the Athletics' manager, Lou Boudreau.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 13 -- Richard H. Balch found "a great deal of merit" today in Democratic suggestions that the Liberal party in New York disband.

Motorists are not the only ones to benefit from the New York State Thruway. As a happy by-product of its construction cardiac patients will benefit too. A new $1,000,000 New York Cardiac Home will be dedicated in Yonkers next month as a direct result of the state's appropriating the site of the former home at Hillburn, N. Y., for the Thruway.

Even those railroad youngsters, now prominent, who never "pounded brass" nor "rode the high iron" will remember when regulatory authorities looked askance at the substitution of fixed maturity debt for equity stock.
MILWAUKEE, May 13 -- The potent bats of Roy Campanella, Junior Gilliam and Sandy Amoros helped the Dodgers today to break even in their two-game series with the Braves at County Stadium.
LONDON, May 13 -- Sentiment in the stock market was strengthened today by Conservative gains in the borough elections and by the improvement in April trade figures.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 13 -- M. D. Clark, a 49-year-old 6-foot-5-inch mink rancher from Woodbury, Conn., proved again that he was a handy man with a shooting iron today.

The reciprocal trade bill -- H. R. 1 -- is now awaiting action by a conference committee of House and Senate; and this is the last practicable chance to improve it. As it passed the House it is a minimum program for continuance of a satisfactory international trade policy.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Following is the text of the statement of Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, before the House Banking and Currency Committee today:

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday that his department's prevention program had caused a reduction of 9,000 blazes in the last eleven months. This, he said, represents the saving of the lives of four firemen or officers.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- Hard drinking and hard feelings are serious dangers in modern, high-speed armies, two Air Force psychiatrists warned today.
Yesterday's clearance of Parke-Davis polio vaccine by the Federal Government does not help New York City or State, which have none on hand.
Stalin had hardly been laid to rest in the Red Square Mausoleum before his heirs to Soviet leadership launched a campaign to re-establish warm and close relations with Yugoslavia.
Senator John J. Sparkman predicted yesterday that Adlai E. Stevenson again would be the Democratic candidate for President next year. The Alabaman said Mr. Stevenson would win this time.

Pakistan's Prime Minister, Mohammed Ali, has gone to New Delhi to open, this morning, a series of discussions with the Indian Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru. The subject is one that has been discussed previously at some length -- Kashmir.
BUENOS AIRES, May 13 -- The Argentine Chamber of Deputies passed a law today banning religious education in the nation's schools.
LOS ANGELES, May 13 -- American Medical Association officials were not allowed to study the Salk vaccine report two weeks before it was made public at Ann Arbor, Mich., April 12.

Samuel Sass, skin specialist; Edward V. Morand, Richard C. Wilson, lawyers; Duradent Porcelain Laboratories Inc, in 250 W 57th St; Warren E. Monroe, commodities broker; Edward De Pianelli, investment broker and financial consultant; Leo H. Raines, lawyer; Chrysler Sales Corp, marine and industrial engines; Harold Hall, Catholic magazines, in 60 E 42d St -- Helmsley-Spear Inc, brokers.
I am fully in accord with Henry Curran's recent letter protesting against the plan to cut Fifth Avenue through Washington Square.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was advised today that Spain, Yugoslavia and West Berlin "face serious economic difficulties" necessitating continued American aid.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Following are texts of documents that were submitted to the United Nations Disarmament Commission subcommittee meeting in London between Feb. 25 and May 9 and made public by the United States today:

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Joseph G. Squarcio, a Denver inventor, is tired of being squirted in the eye by the wedge of lemon that comes with his iced tea. He obtained a patent this week for a disposable fruit-slice squeezer.

The public schools were closed yesterday in Carle Place, L. I., between Mineola and Westbury, and the 2,200 pupils had a holiday. But for the men and women who staff the schools -- principals, teachers, custodians, cafeteria workers and all -- it was something of a busman's holiday.
The nation's privately owned merchant fleet showed a decline in April of ten vessels aggregating 156,000 deadweight tons. This was reported yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 110.4 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended on Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The Philco Corporation had a net income of $2,447,000, equal to 62 cents a common share, in the first three months this year, James H. Carmine, president, reported yesterday.
THOSE interested in the early, ice-out fishing on Maine's northern lakes should be able to leave almost any day now, for even the northern waters are clearing rapidly.
Shipments of refined copper to domestic fabricators dropped to 119,863 tons last month from 131,354 in March, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Defense Department said today that the Soviet Union was making formation flights with intercontinental bombers. The Russians also are speeding production of other military aircraft, according to the announcement.

Eduardo Lausse, the 27-year-old middleweight from Buenos Aires, gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night. This was the Argentine boxer's twenty-eighth straight victory.

Following is a summary oil how the states that hold the released Salk polio vaccine plan to use their allotments, with the number of shots available shown by parentheses. About 1,000,000 shots have been made available by the Government's action in clearing eleven lots of Parke, Davis vaccine:
The fastest six-furlong race of the meeting was run yesterday at dear old Belmont Park. Walter M. Jeffords' 5-year-old gelding Tahiti won the main event -- a sprint for a $5,000 purse -- in 1:10 4-5.

Mickey Mantle went on a batting rampage yesterday to pace the Yankees to a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers. The muscular 25-year-old center fielder clouted three home runs and a single to drive in all the Bomber runs.

WASHINGTON, May 13--President Eisenhower filled two vacancies on the Federal Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit today. He nominated J. Edward Lumbard Jr. for the place that had been held by John Marshall Harlan before his elevation to Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- The world heavyweight champion, Rocky Marciano, and his challenger, Don Cockell of London, will wear eight-ounce gloves when they meet here in Kezar Stadium Monday night.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits made clear last night that he had refused to speak before a state teachers' conference as a protest against what he considered a discriminatory guest policy of the Lake Placid Club, where the meeting is to be held.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 13--Frank Strafaci and Billy Edwards, the co-medalist advanced through two match-play rounds in the William Richardson Memorial golf tournament today. Other favorites were not so fortunate at the Sea wane Harbor Club's course.

Net profit of the California Packing Company for the fiscal year ended Feb. 26 amounted to $8,868,955. This includes $2,281,780 derived from sale of Calpak's equity in an affiliated concern and from income tax refunds. In the preceding fiscal year, the net profit was $6,676,211.
A purported conversation involving two detectives of the Narcotics Squad and an informer was played back in Kings County Court yesterday in support of perjury charges against one of the policemen.
A young New York woman hurtled to her death from the New York Central's Pacemaker early yesterday just south of Peekskill, N. Y.

DARMSTADT, Germany, May 13 (AP)--The Rev. Martin Niemoeller notified German Evangelical Church leaders today that he was resigning from all his duties in the Church's governing organization. However, he will remain as head of the Church in Hesse.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Matthew Bunker Ridgway, whose retirement as Army Chief of Staff was announced today, was an "Army brat." The son of a Regular Army colonel was born at Fort Monroe, Va., on March 3, 1895. He was graduated in 1917 from the United States Military Academy at West Point.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The State Department ordered an immediate investigation today into the death of Mr. Symonds.
Manufacturers of combination storm windows were warned yesterday to order raw materials well in advance of anticipated production.

Had William A. Tomlinson, who died in Washington on April 24, lived another twenty years he might have reaped some of the rewards and enjoyed some of the recognition rightfully due to one of the most influential Americans in Europe.
VIENNA, May 13 -- The Big Four foreign ministers are expected to discuss tomorrow a four-power conference to solve major European problems, including the reunification of Germany.
The United Cerebral Palsy of New York, Inc., officially opened its 1955 campaign yesterday with an appeal to industry to contribute toward its research program and local goal of $1,250,000.

Paul Draper provided the element of novelty in last night's performance in the season of "American Dance" at the ANTA Theatre. On a program consisting otherwise entirely of works by and with Martha Graham, he tapped his way through three of his favorite numbers, and nobody in the house seemed to view the change of style with any artistic alarm.

GENEVA, May 13 -- The idea that Austria can be made neutral now in the sense that Switzerland is neutral is regarded by the Swiss as both funny and dangerous. Since they have had almost 700 years of experience in developing a concept and practice of neutrality, the Swiss views on the subject are not offhand.
FORREST CITY, Ark., May 13 (AP) -- This little town in the East Arkansas flatlands settled down today after thousands of children, fleeing from a mock atomic attack on Memphis, flooded in for refuge.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club team matches neared the last stage yesterday. The finals will be played next Tuesday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 13--The Ministers of Interior, Justice and Information in the reorganized Cabinet of Premier Diem have been ordered to start immediately to organize general elections in South Vietnam, the Government said today.

Last month, for the eighth consecutive time, sales of the nation's chain and mail order houses were higher than a year before. A gain of 7.9 per cent was recorded in April over April, 1954, while for the first four months of the year sales registered an increase of 8.4 per cent, according to a survey by The New York Times.
Marketing of new securities is continuing in wide variety but moderate volume. There was no significant addition during the week to the backlog of corporate securities being prepared for sale.

As one who, with the late William Harvest Harkness, brought back to the Bronx live specimens of the Varanus Komodoensis, popularly known as Komodo Dragons, I was interested to note in The Times of May 5 that another two are scheduled to arrive from Indonesia by air.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 13 (UP) -- Dutch Harrison of St. Louis and Mike Fetchick of Yonkers fired four-under-par 66's in a steady rain today to share the lead at the halfway mark in the Greenbrier open golf tournament.

Stockholders of the Hupp Corporation, at their meeting in Cleveland yesterday, approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 4,000,000 shares and creation of 200,000 shares of new $50 par preferred. The company produces stampings and assemblies for the automotive, refrigeration, air conditioning, radio, heating and farm equipment and appliance fields.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower nominated Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor today to succeed Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway as Army Chief of Staff June 30.

PASADENA, Calif, May 13 (AP) -- The 40-year-old heir to an auto parts fortune was killed today in a twelve-foot plunge over an embankment on his mother's estate. Tonight his estranged fourth wife said through her attorney she suspected foul play.

The strong, positive wording of your editorial of May 11 on teachers' salaries must have met with the approval of thousands of interested parents and teachers. I am sure you will understand why some of us whose hopes so often have been frustrated by piddling compromise will continue to keep our fingers crossed until we see results that face up to the realities of the present situation.
The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has no plans for new financing over the next five and a half years except for equipment purchases, according to David C. Bevan, vice president in charge of finance.
The General Public Utilities Corporation and all subsidiaries, foreign and domestic, reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three and twelve months through March.
PARIS, May 13 -- The terms of two compromises on the Saar were made public today.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 17 points (15 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday.

BOSTON, May 13 (UP) -- Ted Williams signed a one-year contract for an estimated $100,000 today. Then he promptly announced he would be ready to play "any position" for the Boston Red Sox in "a week or so."
The latticed shadows of the Third Avenue elevated fell yesterday on the street below, undisturbed for the first time in seventy-seven years by the bulkier shadows of passing trains.
NELSON, B. C., May, 2--A Royal Commission will soon sit here to determine the disposition of land on which many Dukhobors, members of Canada's most difficult minority group, have settled.

The Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory at Bar Harbor, Me., will benefit from a special showing of paintings and sculpture at the National Academy Galleries at 1083 Fifth Avenue on Tuesday at 3 P. M.
The proprietor of a Brooklyn clothing and tailoring shop was shot and critically wounded yesterday as he tried to chase two thugs from his store following a robbery attempt.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies, which is being sued on charges of anti-trust violations, said yesterday that it was ready to make any changes in its activities that were required by law.
How sound is the business boom? Ask a dozen analysts and you'll probably get a dozen different answers.

Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia yesterday defeated Raul Sanguineti of Argentina to gain runner-up honors in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires, according to a report received from Argentina.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Representative Clark Thompson, Democrat of Texas, told a rice millers' convention today that a two-price plan for rice "ought to work."

Remember, many years ago, when the stillness of a summer afternoon would be broken by the "ding-ding-ding!" of a bell and the chugging of a tired four-cylinder motor? And the bell, and the motor, would signal the daily arrival of "the ice cream man"?

A new ownership has taken over the Alberta Apartments at 191 Main Street, East Orange, N. J. The four-story building containing sixty-nine suites was sold by Leo Bruck and Milton Shoenholz to Mount-Clair-View, Inc., represented by F. H. Miller, attorney.

President Eisenhower's address on May 24 before the annual convention of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters will be carried on both television and radio. His speech, which will originate in the new Sheraton Park Convention Hall in Washington, is expected to last fifteen minutes.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 13 (Reuters) -- The Pakistani and Afghan Governments announced tonight they had accepted a Saudi Arabian offer to mediate in the dispute between them.
Barbecuing, the oldest and most primitive form of cookery, is becoming one of the American family's most popular pastimes.

Fried shrimp is as common in eating places along the Florida keys as "hot dogs" at Coney Island. Unfortunately, it is almost as common in Florida and elsewhere to overcook the shellfish till it is tough and unpalatably dry.
The Fifth Avenue Cinema has announced a series of film programs devoted to British directors. The current series on American directors is nearing an end. The schedule follows: ...

MOSCOW, Saturday, May 14 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin, Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief, and other Soviet leaders will confer in Belgrade at the end of this month with President Tito. An announcement of the visit was made today by the Government newspaper Izvestia.
A huge tarpaulin in a remote section of the grounds cloaks one of the secrets of Roosevelt Raceway's success.

Brooklyn College marked yesterday the twenty-fifth anniversary of the signing of its charter. In its first quarter of a century this municipally supported institution has grown to be the largest liberal arts college in the country. It has 21,159 students in the regular day session, the School of General Studies at night, and the Division of Graduate Studies.

Cedric H. Belfrage, editor of The National Guardian, a leftwing weekly, was arrested yesterday by the Immigration Service and placed in the Federal House of Detention. He will remain there until his deportation to England early next week.

THIS morning's books are humorous. Let us not stress that, though, for fear of stirring the miasma of apathy that runs (like a tame fire) around a table when someone with a Halloween-pumpkin grin says he is going to tell us all a veryveryvery funny story. The books deserve better of discerning citizens in this affable Republic.
LONDON, May 13 -- Leaders of the National Amalgamated Stevedores and Dockers Union, which caused a nation-wide dock strike last fall, have recommended another walkout May 23.

Artists created a storybook world for 2,000 persons in the grand ballroom of the Sheraton-Astor Hotel last night. A Bal Fantastique, the annual costume event of the Artists Equity Association, merrily continued until the night was gray at the edges.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Representatives of the Maritime Administration endorsed today the idea of having the Government build a prototype atomic-propelled merchant ship.
FUJI-YOSHIDA, Japan, May 13 (AP) -- Violence flared today in the boiling protest against the United States Army's using the slopes of sacred Mount Fuji for artillery practice.
Today the Army will put on a group of shows at Governors Island, if the weather permits. In case of rain, the open house will be held tomorrow.
SIMLA, India, May 13 -- Thirteen nations at the Asian economic conference rejected today the idea of setting up a regional organization to plan the use of United States funds for East Asia.

INDONESIAN art is featured in an exhibition of unusual interest at the Carlebach Gallery, 937 Third Avenue. Sculpture, bronzes, textiles and religious objects, from the ninth century A. D. to the present day, show how the islanders gradually fashioned a native art, stimulated on and off by Siam, Japan and China.
Mayor Wagner's office moved back from the doomed Pulitzer Building to the historic City Hall yesterday. His staff was undaunted by Friday the Thirteenth.
LONDON, May 13 -- Aneurin Bevan described Conservative hecklers tonight as "damn robots'' and advised them to "join the Fascists."

Two vacant plots comprising 11,000 square feet on the corner of Stuart and Barry Avenues in Mamaroneck, N. Y., have been purchased by Norman Lerro, home builder, of the Bronx. The property was sold by Home Trading Corporation through Finnerty's Real Estate, broker.

PARIS, May 13 -- It is now possible to conceive of abatement in Europe's cold war tensions. The first step in this direction will be attempted tomorrow evening when the Big Four Foreign Ministers dine and converse together in Vienna. Undoubtedly this will be a rather gingerly discussion.

The Third Avenue "El," like the other "Els" and the stage coach, has gone where the woodbine twineth. It is one with the roses of yesteryear. We may stroll along Third Avenue if we wish, and look up, and the structure will still be visible, but no train will come.

VIENNA, May 13 -- The text of the Austrian treaty of independence was approved today. With that act the conference of the Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union ended its labors.
Ebbets Field in Brooklyn is expected to attract tomorrow the largest crowd of the season -- but not for a baseball game.
Shopping in the "good old days" was as slow and placid as the horses that pulled the Fifth Avenue buses. But it had a few drawbacks too.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- Two film officials answered today criticism of movie morals and the administration of the industry's Production Code made yesterday by the Rev. Thomas F. Little, executive secretary of the National Legion of Decency.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on the appeal by William J. Keating, former counsel to the New York City Anticrime Committee, against a five-day sentence for contempt of court. He had been ordered to jail for his refusal to reveal his source of information about a wiretap raid.
WASHINGTON, May 13--Salk vaccine sufficient to give another 1,000,000 children their first shots against poliomyelitis was cleared today for immediate use.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 13 -- Puerto Rico's insistence on revising the four-power agreement that established the Caribbean Commission stems mainly from a belief the agreement is outmoded.
EL PASO, Tex., May 13 (AP) -- A supposedly "dead" target rocket was fired into life by an acetylene torch at Fort Bliss today, killing three men and injuring three.
BOSTON, May 13 -- An order to a Jewish couple to give up custody of a child of Roman Catholic faith was sustained in a higher court here today.

The world of journalism now mourns another victim of our dangerous age. Gene Symonds of The United Press, at 29, had seen much danger in his short career from the Korean war to riot-torn Singapore where he met his death yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- Pibul Songgram, Premier of Thailand, said today that a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait "depends on the Communists, not on the free world."

TRENTON, May 13 -- Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, urged, here today that insurance companies be permitted to issue and sell variable annuity contracts in New Jersey.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- The arduous task of counting the proxies voted three weeks ago at the annual meeting of Montgomery Ward Co. stockholders is over. As predicted then, the management retained six places on the nine-man board and the insurgent forces of Louis E. Wolfson won three.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- If business conditions continue favorable, earnings of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad are expected to rise to an equivalent of $4.50 a share this year, Clair M. Roddewig, president, said today at the annual meeting of stockholders.
TOKYO, May 13 -- General Taylor said today he would take to his new post an appreciation of the global nature of the free world's conflict with Communism.
Events today: Queens College Orchestral Society, Jamaica High School, 2:30 P. M.; Brooklyn Music School annual spring concert, St. Felix Street Playhouse, Brooklyn, 8.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 13 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower entertained a family gathering at their Gettysburg farm today to celebrate the seventy-seventh birthday anniversary of Mrs. Eisenhower's mother, Mrs. Elivera Doud.
ROME, May 13 -- Rebellion flared in the Christian Democratic party again today. The Cabinet, the position of which seemed to have been made secure yesterday, was in danger once more.
Public interest in the stock market fell away yesterday and, with some of the steels, rails, aircrafts, coppers and liquors finding limited support, some modest gains were recorded.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today proclaimed rigid marketing quotas for the 1956 wheat crop. He called for a referendum of growers on June 25 to approve or reject them.
PARIS, May 13 -- Another step toward a common French-United States policy toward Vietnam was taken today, officials said.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Justice Department is studying from the antitrust angle newspaper mergers that leave one paper in possession of the field.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 13 -- The Hudson Valley's new "dream hospital" on a sixty-six-acre riverfront estate here is approaching completion.

The Broadway Manhattan Corporation, an investing client of Max B. Cane, has purchased the twelve-story loft building at 840 Broadway, at Thirteenth Street. The 840 Broadway Corporation, headed by Joseph Rosen, was the seller.

SINGAPORE, May 13 -- Strike-ridden Singapore saw only minor disturbances today following a day of terror, during which three persons were killed and several score injured. A United Press correspondent, Gene Symonds of Dayton, Ohio, died of injuries inflicted by a mob. a recently repealed curfew into the emergency regulations, but it will be lifted as soon as conditions warrant.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 13 -- The American Book Publishers Council, Inc., denounced today new state laws against comic books, charging they opened the way for censorship of "books of distinction."

In pursuit of their zigzag policy, which can zig and zag not only successively but also simultaneously, the Soviets are now ready to sign two treaties which they undoubtedly regard as further steps toward their unchanging goal of a Communist world.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 13 -- The last French troops pulled out of Haiphong today, abandoning North Vietnam's main port to the Communist Vietminh.
ST. LOUIS, May l3 -- As the Giants winged out of here late this afternoon Leo Durocher was in high spirits, and with good reason.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- An Administration bill to let the Government bar potential spies and saboteurs from defense and defense-related plants was assailed today as "police state" and "un-American."
The top section of steel was riveted into position yesterday on the third 303-foot antenna tower at WQXR's transmitter site in Maspeth, Queens.

WARSAW, May 13 -- After sitting for only eight hours in three days the Warsaw conference of the East European Communist states came to a quick end today. At a thirty-minute session the delegates representing eight governments approved the final text of a military treaty that they will sign tomorrow.
Prodding by Manager Casey Stengel, conscientious extra practice under Coach Bill Dickey and a couple of borrowed bats figured in Mickey Mantle's homerun explosion of yesterday.
Emotional stress may cause mouth disorders, medical scientists reported here yesterday.

OLEAN, N. Y., May 13 -- Governor Harriman warned tonight that increased profits and productivity in the state and national economy could not compensate for a level of unemployment that continues "too high."
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The United States made public today a three-week-old Western proposal that in policing disarmament goes far beyond the Soviet plan broadcast this week.
PARIS, May 12 -- The slump on the Paris stock market in the last few days was described today as an inevitable "correction" of a too rapid and in some respects excessive rise in quotations.
Pleased with the way the anti-litter drive has been progressing, Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain said yesterday that it would continue on a year-round basis.
MONTAUK POINT, L. I., May 13 -- The naval radar picket ship Lookout, second of a squadron of World War II Liberty ships to be converted for such duty, will visit Montauk Point tomorrow.
As is his custom, Pulitzer Prize dramatist Robert E. Sherwood has sent his latest play, "Small War on Murray Hill," to his longtime friend and adviser, Alfred Lunt.
Paul A. Pfeffer, who was to go on trial June 6 on a manslaughter charge, was indicted yesterday for first-degree murder by a Queens grand jury.

" U. S. Military Doctrine," an examination of present viewpoints, has been written by Brig. Gen. Dale O. Smith and will be published Tuesday by Duell, Sloan Pearce-Little Brown. The study begins with General Washington's "Sentiments on a Peace Establishment" and proceeds through military theory and doctrine as expounded by Clausewitz, Jomini, Emory Upton and Alfred Thayer Mahan.
HOLLYWOOD. METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER staged a Communist rally here last week-- all in the interest of moviemaking, of course -- that was carried off with real capitalistic flourish.

HOUSTON, May 14 (UP)--The Southwest Conference put Texas A. and M. on two years' probation and voided all of the school's letters of intent with prospective athletes today in a heavyhanded slap at Athletic DirectorCoach Paul (Bear) Bryant's recruiting practices.

UTICA, N.Y., May 14--Business men along Route 20 across the state organised this week at West Winfield the Cherry Valley Turnpike Association to see what they can do to win back business that the parallel Thruway has taken away.
WASHINGTON, May 14--Secretary of State Dulles will report to the country by television and radio Tuesday evening on the outlook for peace and relaxing East-West tensions.

CALGARY, Alberta, May 2 -- Half the world's Hutterites have congregated in the rich farm lands south of here. Prolific and hard-working, more than 5,000 of them have bought about 400 square miles of holdings and together are among this prairie province's wealthiest landowners.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., May 14--City College today captured the third annual Collegiate Track Conference outdoor championship, scoring 50 points.

DINOSAUR NATIONAL MONUMENT, a beautiful 200,000-acre Y-shaped land preserve, straddles the Utah-Colorado line and extends up the courses of the Green and Yampa Rivers. This preserve has been the center of a long controversy between conservationists and the proponents of a vast water storage project on the Colorado River.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 14--Members of Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom's Nationalist Cabinet are attacking Adlai E. Stevenson for condemning race segregation.

THE world of Dr. Carl Sholto, central figure of this fine character study, encompasses his work as chief eye specialist of a large hospital, his son (now grown) and the wife he no longer loves. Then, almost simultaneously, two things occur that threaten to destroy this compact universe.
Manufacturers of swimming togs got their first rush of orders last week, resident buying offices report. Deliveries of popular and medium priced summer dresses tightened.

A pair of English soccer teams that twice played ties in league games at home will meet today at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. Sunderland and Huddersfield Town are the teams. Their two meetings in the First Division of the English League resulted in 1-1 deadlocks.

THE latter two-and-a-half centuries of the French monarchy (from Francis I of the Renaissance to Louis XV) were remarkable for a series of women who gained the king's favor and achieved a political influence that often made them the real rulers of France.

LONDON, May 14--Sir Winston Churchill today said the proposed meeting between the heads of government of the Soviet Union and the Western powers could lead to easing of world tension and reduction of armaments.

A "heightening of the moral level of our age" was advocated last night by Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, parent body of 500 Reform congregations in this country.

WASHINGTON--The promotion of international motor travel got a big boost from representatives of thirty countries who met here last week and compared notes and suggestions on how to improve highways throughout the world.

THIS brief and breezy monograph is based on four lectures which the venerable and distinguished British composer Ralph Vaughan Williams delivered at Cornell University last fall as visiting professor. It concludes with an epilogue adapted from a lecture at Yale.

THE most famous feat in the world, casually planted on a hotel room rug, couldn't keep still. Even as their owner spoke, sounding exactly like his screen self, one shoe beat a rhythmic tattoo. A chat with Fred Astaire, here to promote Fox's musical remake of "Daddy Long Legs," at the Roxy, leaves little doubt as to why, in the course of thirty-one films, he has seldom reaped one bad notice, on or off screen.

"I HID all my feelings in the innermost cage of my personality, keeping it under lock and key," says Frances Siddorn in her bitter hour of self-revelation. Miss Talbot's beautiful heroine is a charming and successful novelist.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The University of Pennsylvania crew that ended Navy's four-year winning streak carried off the sprint championship of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges for the first time today.
EASTON, Pa., May 14 (AP)-- Five records were broken today as St. Joseph's of Philadelphia dethroned LaSalle in the fortythird annual Middle Atlantic collegiate track and field championships.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 14 (UP)--Bo Wininger pitched and putted himself into a three-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the $15,000 Hot Springs open golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 202.

MARIETTA, Pa. ALTHOUGH there have been delays in the polio immunization program, production of the Salk vaccine is being pushed as rapidly as possible. On these pages is a picture report on how the vaccine is made at the vaccine "farm" of Wyeth Laboratories in Marietta, Pa.

ALTHOUGH there are definite proportions established for a fireplace, practically every mason in the country has his own ideas about it. No particular attention is paid to the size of the fireplace opening in relation to the size and height of the flue, with the net result that many a good-looking fireplace smokes and reeks instead of burning briskly and steadily.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 14 (AP)--Yugoslavia today hailed the coming Belgrade conference of Yugoslavia and Soviet Government leaders as another step in an attempt to improve world relations.

THE recent introduction of faster Kodak and Ansco color films for small cameras has opened up many new possibilities for amateur color photographers and suggested uses outside the range of the color film available until now.
American Airlines is expanding its credit ticket selling system.
The King Ranch's High Gun carried the top weight of 130 pounds to an easy victory yesterday in the sixty-second running of the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON. POLITICAL managers of both parties, as they look toward 1956, are puzzled by a seeming paradox that is embodied in this question they are asking one another: "Can the Democrats win all the battles and lose the war?"

THE German auxiliary cruiser Pinguin, or HK-33 as she was officially known, was a big, powerful ship, fitted with diesel engines able to drive her at a fast seventeen knots, more than half around the world without refueling.
ARE television's established stars, especially the comedians, beginning to slip and lose their hold on the public fancy? Are they paying the price of a shortened life because of too many appearances?

HERE'S another book, and a good one too, on the cattle industry from its early beginnings in Texas on down to the present day by the author of "Cattle Empire." The focal point of "Great Roundup" is the formation of the Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association in February, 1877, by forty honest, hard-bitten cowmen who met by previous appointment in the little village of Graham on the frontier of Northern Texas.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- Federal clearance of individual batches of Salk anti-poliomyelitis vaccine appeared today to have intensified the fight over the Federal Government's role in handling the "new blessing to mankind."
Women headed by Mrs. Robert Moore are serving on the hostess committee for the garden party to be held on the afternoon of May 26 for the benefit of the Army Young Men's Christian Association.

Although the Western powers seized the initiative with their proposal for a Big Four meeting "at the summit," it will be impossible to avoid discussing the three issues listed in the Soviet riposte. These issues are disarmament, Germany and the Far East.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Set out seedlings of annual flowers and vegetables when ever it is convenient. Work a little dry fertilizer into the soil at the bottom of each hole or water with a starter solution of liquid fertilizer. Water and press soil firmly around each seedling. If not transplanted on a cloudy day, protect from the sun for a day or two.

FLENINGE, Sweden--One of the most automobileconscious nations in Europe has opened its first ultra-modern, American-style motel. And more are on the way. Built by the Royal Swedish Automobile Club, the new structure is intended as a model for future motel developments in Scandinavia.

CINCINNATI, May 14 -- A grand slam home run by Carl Furillo and a two-run blast by Duke Snider featured today's 13-2 swamping of the Redlegs by the Dodgers at Crosley Field. The Brooks added a game to their National League lead and now are nine in front of the runnerup Giants.

ROME, May 14 -- Giovanni Gronchi, Italy's new President, will surround himself with his own group of advisers. This is further indication that he intends to play a more active role in Italian politics than his predecessor, Luigi Einaudi, who employed only a few aides at Quirinal Palace, his official residence.

With a grant of $250,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation, the University of Wisconsin will engage in a four-year study of solar energy. Dr. Farrington Daniels, a leading authority on solar energy and its utilization, will direct the project. He is not one of the wild enthusiasts who thinks that sun power will compete with atomic power in regions which are flooded with sunlight but which have no fuel.
Mr. Ashworth is acting director of the Traffic Institute of Northwestern University.
ALBANY, May 14 -- A longsanding state program to reward veterans of the armed forces shows signs at reacting against its beneficiaries.
AN unusually large and varied number of photographic exhibitions are currently on display or announced for the near future. The shows include both one-man and group displays.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 14-- Verdi's "Macbeth," not heard in this city for many years, is to be performed by the San Francisco Opera Company next fall during its thirty-third season.
A State Department adviser urged last week that LatinAmerican countries settle disputes over deep-sea fishing rights by international agreements on control and conservation of fisheries.

The bees are out and humming, and at evening the whippoorwills are calling; the orioles are loud and happy, there's shade in the woodland, lilacs are fading and peonies are in bud. It's mid-May, and only yesterday it was March.
LONDON--Soho, the colorful square mile in the center of London, with a better reputation than it deserves for good food and Continental indiscretion, is devoting the week of July 10 to a Soho Fair.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 14-- The Sierra Club took a new tack this week in its war upon the proposed "invasion" of the national park system by the Federal Bureau of Reclamation.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Harold E. Stassen, Special Assistant to the President on disarmament matters, has completed his staff of advisers.

THIS is not a systematic study of freedom of the press in the United States. Most of the book is something more interesting than that. Nine out of the thirteen chapters comprise accounts of early American newspapers, largely up to the end of Jefferson's presidency, interspersed with the informal reflections of a seasoned journalist on the relations between newspapers and the Government.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 14 -- The combination of Mrs. Jan Burke's Dedicate and jockey Sam Boulmetis prepped for the Prcakness Stakes by winning the $50,000 added Jersey Stakes at Garden State Park today in record-breaking time.

To the Screen Editor: I judge that as of now Cinerama has shot its wad: its second production accomplishes nothing more than its first one did. To me that seems like a shame because Cinerama has something that none of the other widescreen productions has: three panels to work with, plus sound.
PARIS, April 28--The major industrial countries of Western Europe are suffering from shortage of common stocks.

SAINT PAUL, in a letter written in a day when an apparently triumphant empire was in fact dying, gave a diagnosis relevant to our recent history: when man is substituted for God as the center of meaning, this humanism does not long abide.

THOUGH "Open Sesame" was a magic phrase to unlock treasures in storybook land, it might be similarly used by the home gardener. For all that he would need to do would be to open a packet of sesame seed to find a new, interesting herb to try in his backyard plot.
MAKE one change and you find yourself confronted by a whole series of unexpected results.

BUENOS AIRES, May 14-- Roman Catholic organizations asserted today that the Church would agree to plans for separation from the Argentine State if the state would restore properties taken from the Church. The statement indicated a value of $142,860,000 on such properties.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Come August, home building since World War II will have reached the ten million mark. This is a phenomenal record. Since 1950 the number of new houses built has been running ahead of the number of new households formed.
JERUSALEM, April 20--Jordan has begun a campaign to get rid of all of her hundreds of thousands of goats. The goats are commonly called "black locusts" by non-goat-owning Jordanians.

CHICAGO -- Many persons unjustly condemn a home air - conditioning system because it fails to keep the rooms as cool and comfortable in hot muggy weather as they think it should. This may be unfair.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) --The House of Representatives will open a second round of debate on military policies, probably Tuesday. It will consider a new billion-dollar program to increase the active reserves fourfold.
The National Institute of Arts and Letters has announced the selection of sixteen non-member artists, authors and composers to receive $1,000 grnts.

KATONAH, N.Y., May 14--A northern Westchester art group, dedicated to exhibiting the best work of "The Neighbors," will celebrate its first anniversary next month. The neighbors include many nationally known artists living in Katonah and surrounding communities.
COPENHAGEN -- It is a good thing for tourist budgets that there are other things to do in Scandinavia besides shop. Not that what is for sale here is expensive, because much of it is not.

TO THE EDITOR: In "Ideal Size for Our Population" (May 1), Kingsley Davis advances the thesis that if Americans continue to multiply as they have done in the past five years, they will constitute in the near future a threat to our power, security and national well-being.

RARELY has New York had such an opportunity to compare European and American art over a period of a generation as is provided by three coincident exhibitions. The Whitney Museum and the Museum of Modern Art have just opened complimentary shows of painting and sculpture by artists who have come into prominence in the last ten years --Americans at the Whitney, Europeans at the Museum of Modern Art.

A SELECTION of photographs by the late Werner Bischof from his book, "Japan," will be placed on exhibition Thursday at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue. The event is sponsored by the center in cooperation with the Japan Society, "a nonprofit organization of Americans and Japanese interested in furthering cultural relations between the United States and Japan."

SAN FRANCISCO--An aerial tramway is being completed here in time to offer this summer's visitors a spectacular ride over a stretch of Pacific surf to Point Lobos, the extreme western tip of this city and the southern pillar of the Golden Gate.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 14 --The network of superhighways already planned for this section of the Midwest was taking shape this week and several new extensions were in prospect.

KILL the insects, but spare the fish and wildlife! This is the theme of a number of sports and conservation groups throughout the country following serious losses to fish and game as a result of illadvised insect control programs.

MOST industrial designers are faced with this dilemma: They are judged by their clients (the manufacturers and so forth) in terms of whether their new designs will increase sales; and they are judged by their critics (the museum directors and so on) in accordance with fairly absolute esthetic standards.

Stock prices last week, on the lightest volume of the year, sustained the largest losses in about two months. Some technicians were inclined to believe that if offerings became heavier on the decline, the averages could challenge the lows of the first quarter.
West Germany, which has sustained a remarkable production and trade boom for nearly seven years, now faces the task of adjusting its economy to a rearmament program.

DAMASCUS, Syria -- Now linked directly with the United States by Pan American World Airways, Damascus is looking forward to an even greater number of visitors this summer--especially during the Damascus International Fair during September.
The determination of the nation's two merging labor bodies to work for strengthening of civil rights and to combat racial and religious discrimination was stressed yesterday by a labor leader.

NEW HAVEN, May 14--The Municipal Parking Authority received clearance this week for its most ambitious project--the provision of 500 parking spaces in the midtown block bounded by Elm, State, Court and Orange Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The French word "detente," meaning a slackening of international tensions, reappeared in the vocabulary of official Washington after a long absence as the Administration dropped its objections this week to a Big Four conference of the heads of government.

An off-duty patrolman and a hold-up man were seriously wounded in a pistol battle in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section last night after the holdup man and two companions sought to commandeer the policemen's car to escape the scene of a robbery.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) --Philadelphia police continued their investigation of the Harold Johnson-Julio Mederos fight today, working on the theory that big money was bet on Mederos.
CAMPINAS, Brazil, May 14-- President Joao Cafe Filho formally inaugurated today the $10,000,000 plant here of the Singer Sewing Machine Company. The capacity of production is 50,000 machines yearly.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) --Senator Henry M. Jackson announced today that there would be an investigation of his charge that the Navy was "dragging its feet" on shifting to atomic-powered submarines.
Dr. Robert Cushman Murphy, ornithologist associated with the American Museum of Natural History for thirty-five years, has retired as the museum's Lamont Curator of Birds, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR: This is my addendum to Rene Sedillot's article "Now, Medals for Civilians, Too" (April 24), in which, from a country long accustomed to awarding its citizens for distinguished non-military achievement, comes sage and witty advice to the proposed American venture along the same line.

FRANKLY, we are always worried when literature gets into the hands of the politicians. They only see the immediate practical thing: will it show us in a favorable light? If it will, the literature is great; if it will not, the literature is evil.

KYOTO, Japan, May 13--Far Eastern observers are convinced that Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China is as anxious as the United States for settlement of the Formosa Strait issue. The question is whether Premier Chou's minimum terms, balanced against those of Washington and of Nationalist China's President Chiang Kai-shek, will offer hope of a solution.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 14--Ch. Dirdon's Durk Donder, a keeshond owned by the Dirdon Kennels of St. James, L.I., was named best in show in the Springfield Kennel Club event today. The chief award was the first for the Dirdon dog.

A bill is before the City Council which would permit the use of bolts instead of rivets in the construction of big buildings in New York City. Bolted steel framework has been limited by the city's Building Code to structures not more than ten stories high. Riveted steelwork was prescribed for higher structures because it was believed only rivets could withstand the variable pressures of weight and wind.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 14--Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, president of Columbia University, will open Williamsburg's sixweek "Prelude to Independence" celebration tomorrow.

AN Ernest Hemingway novel became involved last week in an issue that continually plagues television networks and sponsors. It pertains to motion picture companies who refuse, in many cases, to waive their film rights to a story when it is to be presented live on most stations but by kinescope film recording on a few others.
BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP)-- High Voltage carried the Wheatley Stable colors to a length victory today in the $20,000-added Black-Eyed Susan Stakes.
Social sciences and the humanities, as well as aviation, mathematics and the physical sciences, will be stressed at the United States Air Force Academy.

HONG KONG, May 14--Sixty thousand Chinese peasants were officially reported tonight to be moving from impoverished areas in Shantung Province to reclamation projects in inner Mongolia and Heilungkiang in northern Manchuria.
BOSTON, May 14 (AP)--Jackie Jensen's two-run homer off Johnny Sain in the thirteenth, inning beat Kansas City, 3--1, for Boston today. The defeat was the eighth in nine games for the Athletics.
