LAST year Americans sent nearly 331 million personal letters abroad. Most of these, according to postal authorities, were written to friends and relatives of the thirty million Americans who are immigrants or children of immigrants.
HARTFORD, May 14--Connecticut's historic pay-as-you-go policy in highway construction may be changed this year.
EVANSTON, Ill., May 14-- Jim Golliday, a slender speedster from Northwestern, tied the world record of 0:09.3 for the 100-yard dash today.

ANYONE fortunate enough to own--or to see--a tree peony is fortunate indeed this third week of May, for it is now that these uncommon woody-stemmed tree (really shrub) peonies bloom. Delicately textured, crepe-paperlike flowers resemble those of lateblooming herbaceous varieties, but can be had in a wider color range -- from purest white through pale pink, deep rose pink, vermilion, scarlet, crimson, maroon, purple and yellow.

LAST week this column mentioned the Edgar award bestowed by Mystery Writers of America on Charles Boswell and Lewis Thompson for "The Girl With the Scarlet Brand" and the consistent excellence of their contributions to factcrime writing.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14 --Behind the six-hit shutout pitching of Ken Mackenzie, a southpaw, the Yale baseball team gained its seventh consecutive victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate League today by downing Princeton, 3--0, at Yale Field.
AMERICAN SCENE STEEL TRAILS AND IRON HORSES. By Lamont Buchanan. Illustrated. 159 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $3.95. A pageant of American railroading.

SINGAPORE, May 14--The Singapore police denied tonight that policemen had watched without helping as Gene Symonds, Southeast Asia manager for The United Press, was attacked by a mob during rioting on Thursday.

AS a humorist even down to the general locale of her writings, Betty MacDonald fits one of our lustiest traditions, that created by Mark Twain. It was Mark who went West and panned a richer lode from his experience than any placer miner who ever saw colors in a creek.
WASHINGTON, May 14--The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would give the nation a blueprint Monday for the equitable distribution of Salk polio vaccine on a voluntary basis.

A HIGH school photography instructor, Mrs. Lois Vinette of the Alexander Hamilton High School in Los Angeles, has emerged as the most outstanding figure in the 1955 Scholastic-Ansco Photography Awards, which were judged here recently and will be announced tomorrow.

THE prototype of the low, lightweight Talgo train, which A.C.F. Industries is building for the Rock Island Railroad and the New York, New Haven Hartford, was displayed last week over tracks of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western out of Hoboken.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 13--The big question before the Dutch Government today is whether it will be in office next week.
James F. Geraghty, a Democratic district leader in the Bronx for the last forty-one years, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, the Bronx, at the age of 77.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- United States officials today viewed the Khruschev-Bulganin mission to Belgrade as a Soviet effort to make Yugoslavia the southern anchor of a neutral belt running north to Finland and Sweden.
An optimistic report on the progress toward integration of Negro and white children in the nation's schools was issued yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 14 --Governor Harriman made it clear today--for the record-- as he closed a three-day swing through western New York that he was not running for the Presidency. He made little effort, however, to convince anyone that he was running away from it.

BASEBALL The Yankees overhauled the Tigers, 7--6, at the Stadium yesterday as Elston Howard's triple capped a three-run rally in the ninth inning. In Cincinnati the Dodgers collected sixteen hits to rout the Redlegs, 13--2.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14-- The Educational Testing Service of Princeton has taken steps toward a major expansion of its facilities. Henry Chauncey, president of the organization, reported today that the project would cost about $2,000,000.
Air conditioning is still in its infancy abroad. But in cold as well as warm weather countries, both the use and manufacture of air conditioning equipment is on the increase.

CHICAGO, May 14--Most everything went into reverse for the Giants today. They blew the opener of their threegame series to the Cubs, 8 to 0, before a crowd of 17,818. That snapped a four-game winning streak. It also snapped Leo Durocher's temper a bit and, to make matters worse, it was that big fellow, Bob Rush, who shut them out again.

Artis a language that must be learned to be understood, in the opinion of W. Stanley Wyatt, painter, designer, graphic artist and teacher at Columbia University. He will speak Tuesday at 6:15 P.M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Katharine Cornell announced last week the appointment of a committee of representatives of education, religion, business, industry and the arts to arrange a celebration of the seventy-fifth birthday of Helen Keller. The blind and deaf teacher and author will be honored on June 27.
The Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites held a big meeting in Warsaw last week to "accentuate the positive" or to ratify the obvious.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, May 1-- The Gold Coast Government, eager to establish the country as the leading industrial center of West Africa, has embarked upon an ambitious development program. It includes some of the biggest harbor installation, agricultural research and power projects on the Continent.

To the Music Editor: IN the spring of 1953 there was quite a spate of performances of Viotti's music to celebrate the supposed bicentennial of his birth. In a radio interview a famous violinist voiced his pride at having played a Viotti concerto on the exact 200th anniversary of his birth, which occurred, according to the dictionaries, on May 23, 1753.

When Paul Horgan's "Great River" was reviewed on page one of the Book Review of Oct. 10, 1954, it was praised "for the bounty of life and beauty it holds." Now the book has gone on to win the Pulitzer Prize and the Bancroft Prize--tributes to its bounty and beauty.

LONDON, May 11--Part of the intricate chemical "heart" of the ultramicroscopic influenza organism has been isolated and analyzed by two Australian medical researchers. This has enabled them to demonstrate that different strains of this world-wide disease have different chemical constitutions.

Several distinctive homes and gardens in Greenwich, Conn., will be opened to the public on May 26 for the benefit of the Patients Welfare Fund of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

WHAT philatelic authorities call the most valuable privately owned stamp collection in the world, put together by the late Alfred H. Caspary, a retired Wall Street financier, is to be sold at public auction.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14--Govindan Ramachandran, an educator-sociologistjournalist from India, who is on his way home from here, is intent on trying to correct some false impressions in India about the United States.

TO THE EDITOR: Thomas P. Whitney in "The Kremlin's Big Problem--the Peasant" (April 24) makes some statements that I must take issue with. [The theme of Mr. Whitney's article was that today's failure of Russia's food supply to keep pace with its population growth was rooted in an old problem --the historic struggle of the peasant for freedom and for land.--Editor.]

East Side boys and girls, decked out in Dutch costumes, danced in wooden shoes yesterday in the open square at Second Avenue and Tenth Street. To the clumping of wood against pavement and music of accordion and guitar, they revived the customs of old New Amsterdam for the opening of the annual Tulip Festival of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church In-the-Bouwerie.

THE Pulitzer Prize-winning "Cat On a Hot Tin Roof," which, incidentally, also received this year's Drama Critics Circle Award, appears destined to strike it rich again. Four major film companies-- Paramount, Warner Brothers, Columbia and Twentieth CenturyFox--are interested in acquiring the Tennessee Williams hit drama at the Morosco Theatre and "a deal is imminent," according to the playwright's, spokesman.

HOUSTON--The dynamic, unstoppable city of Houston, with a population of more than 800,000 and a metropolitan area in which at least 1,000,000 persons live and work, again claims the title of "The Most Air-Conditioned City."
MENADO, Celebes, May 11-- The military stood at attention on the airstrip. All the leading citizens of the town had turned out.

DARTMOUTH--Economics Dartmouth College's economics department will offer next year an honors program of five courses. Two new courses will be added to strengthen the department. The emphasis will be on student discussion and research.
BUFFALO, May 14--Substantial benefits from the St. Lawrence Seaway have been envisioned for the Niagara frontier if a $27,000,000 improvement program for the Port of Buffalo is adopted.

"Fertile in Doubts" Some years ago John Bassett Moore wrote of a "method of interpreting the Constitution" that he said could "be described as the apprehensive." This method of interpretation, "fertile in doubts," treated "powers as subjects of abuse rather than as national necessities for sources of advantage."

ADMIRERS of the early seventeenth-century French graphic artist Jacques Callot are numerous and fervid. The remarkable etchings in which he illustrated, on the one hand, the sophistication of court life and, on the other, the ravages of war at their most hideous foreshadow Watteau and Goya.
A leading New York rabbi called yesterday for a "top-level meeting" of the heads of the world's great religions.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 10--The rich Belgian Congo may soon be opened to large-scale investment of foreign capital.

LAHORE, Pakistan. GEORGE CUKOR is one person another perspring American would not expect to meet sipping late afternoon tea like a burrah sahib under a whirling punka in Faletti's Hotel, 10,000 miles from air-conditioned Hollywood.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 14 --Gen. J. Lawton Collins expressed hope tonight that the Vietnamese, French and Americans would work together to save Vietnam from communism.

THOUGH the ballet season is over, there is never an end to plans and counterplans in the ballet field. At the moment the whole thing is rather like the Mad Hatter's tea party, with everybody moving one place on, from company to company.

Fordham strengthened its position for a National Collegiate Athletic Association berth in District II by beating Columbia University's nine, 2-1 at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday. The victory was the eleventh for Coach Coffey's team against only two setbacks.

THE report in our Hollywood column last week that the British film censors have been slapping bans on American movies that have run towards reckless violence and needless brutality probably caused some quiet rejoicing among readers of similar mind.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- When Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith, the senior Senator from Maine, said this week that she had the impression President Eisenhower wasn't going to run for re-election, some of the Republican ladies bristled as if she had suggested an amendment to the Ten Commandments.

DETROIT--The auto industry reports that more and more comfort - conscious motorists are purchasing air-conditioning units for their cars. Although the relatively high cost of such installations-- $345 to $600--has kept, automobile air conditioning in the luxury class, sales this year are expected to set a record.

LOVE and marriage offer such exotic combinations of character and situation that when a novelist chooses to make his protagonists average and middle-aged we can be pretty sure his intentions are serious. Gilbert Phelps doesn't disappoint us.

PAUL GREGORY, the young producer who seems able to hold his own on precarious Broadway even with Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin (five hits, no errors), has a new--and, of course, unorthodox --musical project for next season.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (Science Service)--Some books published by the Government are being withdrawn from further publication, to take them out of competition with private publishers.

SIMLA, India, May 14--To most Americans it would all seem quite logical and as laudable as virtue, this idea of regional economic cooperation for Free Asia. In Simla this week, Free Asia, proving once again that suspicion is a universal commodity, turned a polite shoulder.

IF a faucet, usually the one for hot water, has begun to leak around the handle, it's a sign that the spindle packing is worn. First, try tightening the packing nut. If this does not stop the leak, the washer must be replaced.

SINCE most of the literary reviews today are dominated by the formalist critics. Thomas Wolfe's work has been curiously neglected. He is on a sort of critical "gray list," if not absolutely cast out into the limbo of the vulgar.

NOMINATIONS are in for the twelfth election to New York University's Hall of Fame for Great Americans. The prize that awaits each of the winners is his likeness in bronze placed between two columns in the open-air colonnade that stretches high above the Harlem' River at the west end of N.Y.U.'s Bronx campus.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo.--Since the discovery of uranium in caves along the Osage river in the central Missouri Ozarks, a new type of tourist is flocking into that region. Instead of carrying fishing tackle, these visitors are equipped with geiger counters.

A full century of educational work in New York will be observed by the Academy of Mount St. Ursula tomorrow. In the chapel of the convent and school at East 200th Street and Marion Avenue, the Bronx, a mass of thanksgiving will commemorate the centennial of the arrival in New York on May 15, 1855, of the first members of the Ursuline.

SANTA FE, N.M.--There are nine sites in New Mexico administered by the National Park Service. At each of these places preparations have been made to handle larger numbers of visitors this summer than has been the case formerly.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14-- Rocky Marciano, heavyweight champion of the world, will defend his title against Don Cockell of London on Monday night. The fight, scheduled for fifteen rounds, will be held in the open air Kezar Stadium.

MILWAUKEE, May 14 (UP)-- Milwaukee's Del Crandall, who was hitless in twenty-three attempts up to two days ago, walloped a three-run double today to help the Braves post a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

St. John's, in first place in the Metropolitan Conference, increased its lead to one-andone-half games today by trouncing Manhattan, 15-6, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens. Three four-run innings highlighted the Redmen's baseball victory.
FORT DIX, N.J., May 14-- At the opening of Armed Forces Week here today, the Antique Automobile Club of America staged a rally of 160 vintage cars on the parade grounds.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 14--An uneasiness has infected Bangkok's huge Chinese community since the Asian-African conference. It resulted from discussions at Bandung, Indonesia, between Thailand's Foreign Minister, Prince Wan Waithayakon, and Communist China's Premier and Foreign Minister, Chou Enlai.

Dr. James E. Perkins, vice president of the National Citizens Committee for the World Health Organization, deplored yesterday the suggestion that the organization sought "to force socialized medicine on the citizens of all countries."
New York City and State have been assured of enough Federally approved anti-polio vaccine tomorrow to inoculate 600,000 school children.

WARMER weather is proving stimulating to retail trade. Both metropolitan and suburban shopping centers are drawing larger crowds seeking to supplement their summer wardrobes and showing more interest in garden furnishings and equipment and so-called summerizing products.

TODAY'S accent on informal, easier living is reflected strongly in the multitude of labor and time-saving conveniences found in the home. Espepecially is this apparent in the kitchen. The changing habits of the American family have focused attention not only on food storage and its preparation but also on its refrigeration, and changes in this field are many.

Four decorated and furnished apartments are being shown in the cooperative building at 1025 Fifth Avenue. Scheduled for September occupancy, the twelve-story structure will provide accommodations for 167 families.
BERLIN, May 14 -- Today's signing of a mutual defense pact in Warsaw is not expected to result in a substantial East German contribution to the strength of the Soviet camp.

HEARTS and flowers provide the romantic theme for wedding cakes this spring. New York caterers are following a newer, freer design, producing cakes that look more graceful than those of previous seasons.

LONDON, May 14 -- British hopes for the forthcoming meeting of the heads of government of this country, the United States, France and the Soviet Union are directed toward the creation of a favorable atmosphere for further international negotiation.

KINGS POINT, L.I., May 14 --An Adviser to the Korean Merchant Marine Academy has been spending the last fortnight here conferring at the United States Merchant Marine Academy on the technique of conducting such an institution.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The Eighty-fourth Congress is writing a calm, rather relaxed, middleof-the-road record in which domestically there has been little of passion and rather less of crisis.

Members of New York City's 100 juvenile gangs have defined seven degrees of hostility with a rival gang. They are: Sounding--a dirty or questioning look. Roughing--a jostling of one member of a gang by a rival gang member.
St. Francis Prep, sparked by Tom Sheehan's record-breaking mile victory, captured the team title yesterday in the third annual Mount St. Michael track and field games at McGovern Field, the Bronx.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 14--Playing spectacular golf, Jack Lyons gained the final of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament today. He scored a 1-up triumph over Frank Strafaci, the Metropolitan amateur champion.
KINGSTON, R.I., May 14 (AP) --Two field records and five conference marks were set today as Rhode Island University won its eighth straight Yankee Conference track title.

Bricker, Republican of Ohio.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 14-- The opening next week of the International Airport at Isla Verde will be in the nature of a huge Hemispheric Fair. The ceremonies will be held Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
PARIS, May 14--No capital has hoped and pushed more than has Paris for the conference with the Soviet Union proposed this week by the United States, Britain and France.

Probably without knowing it. President Eisenhower voiced the opinion of most medical men when he told newspaper correspondents last week that the program for the inoculation of millions of children was adopted hastily and under pressure. SPRING seems to bring out the exhibition talents of gardeners. Flower shows, big and small, are scheduled in most every hamlet, town and city throughout the country. Some are devoted solely to one flower, others are for arrangements only, and others include all the best of garden finery.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 14-- Fine putting gave Dutch Harrison of St. Louis the undisputed lead in the Greenbrier open golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 199.
PHIL SILVERS and Thomas Mitchell, both of whom will be in filmed shows on television before the fall, were in town last week making preparations for their forthcoming productions.

In the heart of Saigon, surrounded by vast, tree-shaded grounds sits a big, nineteenth century structure that looks like a run-down French chateau. Formerly Norodom Palace, it is now known as Independence Palace, headquarters of the South Vietnam Government of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)-- The Navy, which in a pioneer venture uses atomic energy for propulsion of the submarine Nautilus, is exploring new possibilities for the use of such energy.
PRINCETON -- A revolution in the modern Ice Age may be in the making with the development here of the first electronically operated refrigerator. The machine is noiseless, without moving parts.

IT has been apparent in recent years that Igor Stravinsky's mind has been turning increasingly to religious themes. In 1949 he composed his first setting of the Roman Catholic mass. And the longest section of his Cantata, written three years ago, is devoted to an account of the life of Christ.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 14--A pair of triples by Jack Riley led Seton Hall to a 7-3 victory over St. Peter's at Setonia Field today.

SAN FRANCISCO. A CURIOUS sort of truce ground in the theatre, a Panmunjom of the arts, has been established in San Francisco, first in a place called the Theatre Arts Colony, now in a theatre called The Show Place.

STEPS may be one of the most attractive features of a property--or one of the ugliest. Whether the steps lead up to the front door, connect terrace to lawn, lawn to garden or simply the kitchen door to the driveway, they should be planned not only for comfort and safety but also for appearance.
A New York University class studying Comparative Cultures has decided that the best way to learn about people is to meet them.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- "File No. 11279" in the seventhfloor offices of the Federal Communications Commission is probably the most "active" in town.

Every household has to have its own basic tool kit, ready for instant and frequent use. But then comes the one occasion when--for example--a steam radiator has to be disconnected.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., May 14--Historic homes and landmarks and several gardens in this resort and the surrounding vicinity will be opened to the public for a tour to be held on June 25 under the auspices of the Southampton Colonial Society for the benefit of the Southampton Historical Museum Members of the summer colony and descendants of the founders of Southampton are furthering the success of the event.

French provincial and English period furniture, Japanese furniture and Oriental decorations, old English silver and Old Master etchings are among the items that will be offered at auction sales this week.

The Yankees rallied for three runs with two out in the ninth inning to win a 7-6 thriller with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday. Elston Howard decided matters with a two-run triple off Al Aber, who was called in from the bullpen to face him.
The idea that Royal Little expounded in pressing for the triple merger that formed Textron American, Inc., made many textile men shake their heads in doubt.

MASSENA, N.Y., May 14-- A quiet banker from Duluth, Minn., with steel-gray hair heads the $105,000,000 St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation, which is directing the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Conversations in Paris have led to the plan of issuing "parallel directives" to both French and Americans in Vietnam expressing unity of purpose. Some "difference in emphasis" is reported, with the French urging a broader base for the Government of Premier Diem and the United States stressing the need for competent Ministers.
WILTON, Conn., May 14--It will be business as usual tomorrow along Route 7, despite a move by the state to enforce Connecticut's blue law forbidding commerce on the Sabbath.

THIS third novel by Richard Scowcroft is a richly textured, scrupulously written piece of prose. It deals with a natural young man who, in the final weeks of his wife's first pregnancy, is urgently tempted by curiosity, elegance, riches and lust; and who drifts-- quite reluctantly but by natural swing of circumstance--into an awareness that his own ordinary, monogamous, newly paternal life is a meaningful and good one.

IN the years since television began to bring professional baseball into homes by day and night (thus creating a situation in which housewives, intellectuals and schoolgirls know as much about the game as the average sports announcer) a number of baseball novels have appeared.
To the Music Editor: I am deeply affected by the death of Georges Enesco. But there were some discrepancies in the obituary notice.
ATLANTA, May 14--A behindthe-scenes movement to put former Gov. Herman Talmadge in the 1956 United States Senate race against Senator Walter F. George is in full swing in Georgia.

OF all the different types of iris that are available the most suitable for gardens in Eastern states are the tall bearded and the Siberian varieties. They are the easiest to grow and they put on a most extravagant show when the average garden is likely to be bereft of color.

IN August, 1914, and between March and November, 1917, lie the beginnings of our "time of troubles." The war of 1914 has been fully recorded, but the Russian Revolution of 1917 that grew out of it is still cloaked in obscurity, buried under doctrinal disputation, subject to systematic falsification by all the resources of a great government.

INTERLAKEN, Switzerland-- The first motel in Switzerland, and one of the first in Europe, will be opened here next month. Situated in a flower-carpeted meadow on the bank of the Aare River just outside Interlaken, the motel will contain twenty-one double livingsleeping rooms, each with private bath and kitchenette.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) --Senator John L. McClellan announced today that his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations would begin public hearings Monday on alleged corruption in military uniform contracts totaling "several million dollars."

REGARDLESS of where your house is and when it was built, there is now available a variety of cooling equipment designed to fit virtually every conceivable type and shape of house. If you want to air condition only one or two rooms, of course, the room air conditioner is the unit to use.

Five weeks from tomorrow there will open in San Francisco an international meeting which will differ from most other international meetings in that it can take no action on any controversial point. This meeting, at which representatives of all the U.N.'s sixty member nations are expected to be present, will be in commemoration of the signing of the Charter ten years ago.

FROM the beginning of this century until about the middle of its third decade the status of the Victor Talking Machine Company was somewhere between a monopoly and a national archive. In its own studios here and in Camden, and in those of its European affiliates, Victor recorded incessantly the greatest musical artists of the day.
LONDON, May 10--A German who has built a flapping wing that he reckons could generate enough lift to carry a man by his own exertions has been interviewed by aeronautical research groups here.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14Officials found themselves up to their elbows in fractions this afternoon as the twenty-first annual Heptagonal track and field games ended at Palmer Stadium. Only one twenty-eighth of a point separated the first two teams at the finish.
The four-masted Spanish training ship Juan Sebastian de Elcano arrived here yesterday for a week's visit before returning home on the last leg of a cruise that began last October.
The Tompkins County Trust Company of Ithaca, N.Y., will receive next Friday the first stock certificate of an investnent company that has caught the eyes of bankers throughout the country.
Drought in the Southern Ukraine has showered good fortune on other sugar-producing areas.

THERE is a good chance that some day a plaque will be unveiled at the Orchard Farm (Mo.) Airport, forty-five miles northwest of St. Louis, known as Smartt Air Field. It was there a few days ago that an unusual-looking aircraft, the McDonnell XV-1 Convertiplane, made the first known conversion from a helicopter to a more or less conventional plane, and back again.
North Shore areas of Long Island continue to play a leading part in the construction boom flourishing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

A spring fitting-out season that had too much cold, rainy, damp weather has handicapped pleasure boating. Paint and varnish won't always dry smoothly if moisture and humidity are high. Craft that should have rolled down the rails a month ago are still on chocks in a yacht yard or behind a club house.

FRESNO, Calif., May 14 (UP) --Wes Santee, the long-striding Kansan, failed in his bid for the four-minute mile again today. He was clocked in a so-so (for him) 4:06.5 as he won the invitation mile in the twenty-ninth annual West Coast Relays.

RAINMAKING-- Artificial rainmaking successfully passed an eighteen-month test in Puerto Rico, Dr. Horace K. Byers, professor and chairman of the University of Chicago's department of meteorology, reports to the American Meteorological Society.

THERE was a time when those who temporarily forsook civilization to picnic, hunt or fish relied almost entirely on a cake of ice wrapped in layers of newspaper, or perhaps a thermos jug, to keep their liquid refreshments cool.
The Soviet Union is rushing to completion an entire new rail network serving the grain areas being developed in southwestern Siberia.

Slums and the housing blight in the United States can be eliminated in ten years through the expenditure of $100,000,000,000, Maj. Gen. Frederick. A. Irving (Ret.), president of the American, Council to Improve Our Neighborhoods, said last week.

The Mahogany Association, Inc., cautions prospective home buyers to be on the alert against the practice of designating architectural woodwork as mahogany or genuine mahogany when it is only a substitute finish to look like mahogany.

IT is impossible to find shrubs that do not require some care. There is a group, however, that does remarkably well without a great deal of attention, the viburnums. There is a long list from which to choose.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 (AP) --Jerry Hoyt of Indianapolis, a race driver since his kiddie-car days, won the pole position for the thirty-ninth 500-mile Memorial Day auto race today by bucking gusty winds in a qualifying run at 140.045 miles an hour.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 14--The General Electric Company announced today that it had designed a new atomic power reactor, which it described as a "major advance toward the economic generation of electricity from atomic energy."

WARSAW, May 14 -- The greatest sensation in Warsaw today was not the signing of a mutual defense pact among the eight Communist states of Eastern Europe. It was the news that a senior Soviet delegation would be going to Belgrade at the end of May.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 10--South African sport is facing a delicate problem in the color question with international repercussions.

CAIRO, MAY 14 -- Two soldiers, an Egyptian and an Israeli were killed today in an hour-long machine-gun fight south of the Gaza airstrip, Egyptian Army sources said. They reported three Israelis wounded.

Since increase in film speed continues to bring with it the old disadvantages of coarser grain and poorer tonal gradation when the results are compared with relatively slower film, two questions can be asked: (1) Is it worth it?

More business is in the offing for American food exporters and processors in the British market. It is a result of two companion trends in that country --increasing acceptance of self-service and the erection of supermarkets.
Governors Island, observing its 200th anniversary as a military installation and also the approach of Armed Forces Day next Saturday, put on a rousing show for 7,000 visitors yesterday.
Additional office space for the financial district and a luxurystyled apartment house at Fiftyfifth Street and Sutton Place are to be provided in two new Manhattan building operations.
LAWRENCE, Kan., May 14 -- The University of Kansas said today that Wilt Chamberlain. Philadelphia high school basketball star, would enter the school this fall.

To the Radio-Television Editor: JACK GOULD'S column "Toll TV Troubles" in your section last Sunday is a valuable stimulant to clear thinking on the issue of subscription ("box office in the home") television.

THREE photographers whose pictures are concerned primarily with people are currently exhibiting in local galleries. Dan Weiner's show at the Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, is a personal report on life in Italy as Mr. Weiner photographed it last year.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska -- Diminishing returns from Alaska's construction, fishing and gold mining have given impetus to plans for development of the tourist industry --and this is good news for anyone thinking of coming north this spring or summer.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 14 (AP) --Torrid overtook Meadow Rice in the last twenty yards to win the Kings Pace in 2:02 2/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Ima's Watson was third.

STRATFORD, CONN. A SQUIRREL ping-ponged across the front lawn of the large, white, old-fashioned house and ran up an elm tree; a robin scratched around for worms or other edibles; blue jays screamed somewhere overhead, adding somehow to the scene's peacefulness.

THE break with the past made by progressive twentieth - century art has roughly, two major aspects. NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 14--With George King and Mel Heichman leading the way, New York University won a triangular track meet today.

This is the great week for the British general elections and the big guns will be going full blast, starting with the resounding Sir Winston Churchill at Woodford tomorrow. A week from Thursday it will be all over, and Britain will have 630 new Members of Parliament, or at least members with a new mandate for five years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 (AP) -- Pennsylvania's 150-pound crew moved to the front after a half mile and then held off all challenges today to win the Eastern intercollegiate lightweight sprint championship on the wind-swept Charles River.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y. May 14--George Van Wyck of Nyack, N.Y., won the singles trapshooting title today as the forty-sixth annual amateur championship of America continued on the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island range.

THE long-discussed plan to move the capital of Brazil from Rio de Janeiro to a new Federal District some 550 miles inland is nearing the action stage. A detailed report on the project is to be delivered to the Brazilian Congress by the end of the year.
BONN, Germany, May 14-- Perhaps the most significant aspect of German reaction to the swift succession of events this week has been the lack of opposition to negotiations with the Russians.
TRENTON, May 14--It appears doubtful that the proposed investigation of Democratic Hudson County by the Republicancontrolled Legislature will get under way soon.

THE basis of eloquence is knowledge, and "Nectar in a Sieve" has a wonderful, quiet authority over our sympathies because Kamala Markandaya is manifestly an authority on village life in India. Because of what she knows, she has been able to write a story without reticence or excess.

PINKS can truly be said to belong in the realm of antiquity, yet they are as charming in modern gardens as they were in those of long ago. Those who are setting out some of these fragrant perennials in a rock wall or flower border this month might like to know that their culture goes back to the days of the early Tudors in England.
Westchester County police were still baffled yesterday by the strange case of a 24-year-old woman who, it is believed, jumped to her death Friday from a New York Central train near Peekskill, N.Y.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) --Dartmouth's varsity eight made a fast finish to beat Rollins University by three inches and gain its second straight victory in the Dad Vail Regatta on the Schuylkill River today.

Construction work will be started within two weeks on the Sayre Woods Shopping Center, a retail development with thirtyfive stores and parking for 1,500 cars in Madison Township, N.J., just south of the Amboys in Middlesex County.

SAN SALVADOR, May 9 -- Former Foreign Minister Roberto Canessa has purchased the daily newspaper Nueva Patria. The purchase is generally considered his first move in a campaign for the Presidency next year.

ONCE again food freezer plans are under attack. The charges are: False advertising, misrepresentation by high-pressure salesmen, and even fraud regarding the freezer, the food or the services promised.

ANYONE thinking of buying a room air-conditioning unit, or any other large piece of electrical equipment, should first look into the wiring situation in his house or apartment. Listen with skepticism to the story that you can buy any major appliance, plug it into any outlet and get satisfactory results in the average dwelling.

A HANDY, plastic - handled reamer quickly enlarges holes through steel and other metals to enable them to fit available screws and bolts. Made of extra-tough steel, the reamer enlarges 1/8-inch holes to 5/16-inch size and is used like a screwdriver, $1.25 at hardware stores.
MORE than 1,000,000 room air conditioners may be bought this year by Americans determined to banish "heat waves" from their homes permanently.

SO MUCH is said about cutting gardens that the words acquire a certain allure. Soon these plots are put into many back yards. And it is no wonder because these gardens not only produce specific flowers for indoor use, but they also provide a proving ground for new and old varieties.

ON Tuesday the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, a private foundation in Williamstown, Mass., will open its doors to the public with an exhibition of thirty-five paintings, seven bronzes and forty-one items of American, Dutch, English and French silver.

WARSAW, May 14--Marshal of the Soviet Union Ivan S. Konev was named today chief of the unified military command formed by the Communist states of Eastern Europe.
VIENNA, May 14--The Big Four foreign ministers approved tonight the Austrian state treaty after having deleted from its preamble the clause implying Austrian war guilt.

THE "American Dance" season sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation will close on Saturday at the ANTA Theatre. Features of the final week are Anna Sokolow's "Rooms," Jose Limon's "The Moor's Pavane," and Pearl Lang's "Rites," with the Juilliard String Quartet assisting.
Progress in the plan to enlarge and modernize Lenox Hill Hospital without cessation of service is reported in the hospital's annual report for 1954.

LARCHMONT, May 14--The Star Class once more mustered most starters in the third of a series of special regattas conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club today. There were fifteen of them and the winner was Skip Etchells, with Shannon.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt sent a short, encouraging message saying "good man" to Neville Chamberlain, British Prime Minister, the day before the Munich conference in 1938.

THIS book could hardly be so moving were it not also unintentional. It wasn't "written" to be published in volume form. Kim Malthe-Bruun was simply a Danish boy who became an apprentice seaman at 17 and whom the Nazis executed at 21.
The Hudson River Day Line, New York's biggest cruise passenger carrier, will begin its daily short-haul season next Saturday.

RABBITS may look lovable, but in a garden setting they are a decided nuisance. When they become frequent visitors and are joined by hosts of relatives and friends, these hungry, foot-loose animals can do real damage to a garden.

LONDON, May 14--The Visit of Soviet Premier Bulganin to Yugoslavia the end of this month is interpreted here as an important part of a general effort to strengthen Russia's political defenses in Central and Southeastern Europe.

WARSAW, May 14--Warsaw this week was temporarily the center of the Communist campaign against United States policy in Europe. Three of the most important figures in the Soviet Government--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin, Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, and Defense Minister Georgi K. Zhukov--here as delegates to a conference of Eastern European Communist countries, announced receipt of the invitation from the United States, Britain and France.

HOUSTON, May 14--A plan under which a group of Houston millionaires would buy $20,000,000 worth of right-of-way for future city projects and sell it to the city at cost when needed has been proposed here.

VIENNA, Sunday, May 15 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov announced here last night that his government was agreeable to a Big Four conference this summer.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- About the dullest political campaign in Philadelphia's recent history came to lift this week when twenty-three Republic ward leaders unexpectedly switched their allegiance to independent candidate for the party's mayoralty nomination.

IRIS flowers can be enjoyed an a virtually unbroken schedule throughout the year. This seeming miracle depends on two definite requirements, (1) a garden located along the coast of California or in a region blessed with the same mild growing conditions; (2) selection of the proper varieties for the climate.
WASHINGTON, May 14--The Smithsonian Institution's famous collection of "First Ladies" will be publicly presented in a resplendent new setting this week.

TRENTON, N.J.--The State Legislature here is expected to approve tomorrow an appropriation of something in the neighborhood of the $100,000 requested by conservation officials. This sum will assure to the residents of New Jersey--not to mention outof-state visitors -- a virtually unique, free, wilderness playground conservatively 150 square miles in area, known since the middle of the last century as the VVharton Tract.

WASHINGTON--The Federal Housing Administration now considers air-conditioning an element of sound value in new houses, and is willing to extend mortgage guarantees to cover the additional costs involved.

PARIS, May 14--The North Atlantic Alliance has been called the world's major deterrent to war. It has permitted fourteen countries of the free Western world to present a common defense to Communist imperialism. The number grew to fifteen last week, when the German Federal Republic acceded to the alliance.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12-- Vincent Hallinan, Progressive party candidate for President in 1952, submitted to the United States Senate this week a plan for prison reform.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 14 (AP)--In a village on the University of Utah campus more than 400 dogs are helping humans find out what radioactive elements are potentially harmful.

MATCHING the artist to the repertory is not always easy to manage, these LP days, but Columbia has no problems when it comes to Casadesus and Debussy. Robert Casadesus ranks with Gieseking as one of the world's two great Debussy players.

To the Screen Editor: I WOULD like to enter a slight note of protest against your recent review of "Land of Fury," a New Zealand film based on John Guthrie's novel "The Seekers." You criticized this film too flippantly and in considerable part, I think, for in considerable part, I think, for the wrong reasons.

The report on the Salk vaccine issued last Sunday by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, leaves us about where we were on April 27 when he ordered the withdrawal of the particular vaccine made by the Cutter Laboratories, or on May 8 when all Salk vaccine was withdrawn, Dr. Scheele "associates" the suspect Cutter vaccine with fifty-five cases of poliomyelitis that followed its use.
MILFORD, Del, May 15 (AP) -- A new four-man school board, dedicated to continued racial segregation, was elected today.
VIENNA, May 15 -- The treaty signed today will bring to Austrians an immediate gain in morale.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The ailing coal industry has pulled out of the doldrums.
CHICAGO, May 15 -- Wheat interest centered largely in the May delivery last week, the expiring future moving up to the highest levels in many weeks as shorts covered.
STRATFORD, Conn., May 15 -- More than five hundred persons attended the tree-raising ceremony conducted by the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre here this afternoon.

Note has been taken already in this corner of the progress of business in replacing in Park Avenue between Sixtieth Street and the Grand Central Terminal the procession of composite palaces which made that stretch the abode of wealth and fashion in the Nineteen Twenties.

KYOTO, Japan, May 15 -- For a few hours today the old Japan shone through the garish modern overlay of the present generation. This quiet hill-girt city, once Japan's capital, seemed to remember its past glory as Shinto priests marched through the streets in ceremonies both modern and 1,400 years old.
BALTIMORE, May 15 (UP) -- Mike Garcia shut out Baltimore, 5 -- 0, today to earn an even break for the Cleveland Indians. The Orioles won the first game from Bob Lemon, 4 -- 1.

PARIS, May 15 -- The coming week is viewed with anxiety in official financial circles and on the Paris Bourse. This is the result of the squalls that shook the market in recent days and pulled some shares down as much as 35 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Home building and heavy consumer buying, particularly of such durable goods as automobiles, refrigerators ad television sets, proved major factors in restoring national output to top levels in the first three months of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A last-ditch fight to give to Federal postal workers an 8.8 per cent pay increase was shaping up in the Senate today. The test will be on President Eisenhower's expected veto of the bill passed by Congress last week.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox moved to within one game of the league-leading Cleveland Indians today by sweeping a double bill from the Washington Senators, 3 -- 0 and 5 -- 4, before a crowd of 15,111.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -- Rocky Marciano broke camp today at Calistoga and motored to San Francisco. The Brockton (Mass.) heavyweight, holder of the championship of the world, came through his training in excellent style and is ready for the defense of his crown against Don Cockell of London.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Sixteen Democratic Representatives from New York today called for the ouster of Scott McLeod, State Department security chief, as administrator of the refugee program.

THANK heavens, that week-end is over! Two whole days with nothing but in-shine and more sunshine. If the weather doesn't break soon, what's going to happen to the American way of life? Television never faced a more perilous hour.

The ban against theatre or benefit parties at the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d shows has been lifted. The new policy will go into effect with their next presentation, "Pipe Dream," opening Nov. 30 at the Shubert, and therefore nullifies the one they have been operating under since they produced "Annie Get Your Gun" in 1946.

RAILROAD bugs and other relic hunters who thought they'd swarm over the Third Avenue "El's" sooty corpse and carry off whatever they could wrench or lift out are going to find the looting isn't that simple.

TOKYO, Monday, May 16 -- Business leaders from forty-two countries, including a large delegation from the United States, opened the Fifteenth Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce here today.

Making a fine comeback after being two goals down, the Sunderland soccer team topped Huddersfield Town, an English League rival, 3 to 2, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday, before a crowd of 9,324.
The municipal beaches will open for bathing and swimming Saturday and seventeen outdoor swimming pools will open May 28, the Parks Department announced yesterday.

HEWLETT Harbor, L. I., May 15 -- Gordon Stott, the husky Nassau Country Club golfer, won the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament today. The former Long Island amateur ner of the event that is sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association in honor of the late sports writer of The New York Times.
Radio is still "the constant companion of the American people." That is the first conclusion of a second study in depth of the radio audience by Alfred Politz Research, Inc., made public yesterday.

Dr. Albert Einstein was eulogized last night as a great humanitarian, a scientist and a stanch upholder of civil liberties.

The postal salary bill now in the President's hands to approve or veto stems from a thoroughgoing review by the Postmaster General of the duties and responsibilities of all postal employes in relation to their compensation. These relationships had, through the years, become notoriously distorted.

"Omnibus" will remain on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. The National Broadcasting Company had made a strong bid to obtain the program, which is produced by the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation.
Women captured top honors in the Parks Department's fifth annual Coney Island fishing contest that ended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered two oleomargarine makers today to stop using advertising that might give an impression that theirs is a dairy product.
Brooklyn Felony Court dealt gently yesterday with a young man who had confessed voluntarily to a $25 robbery.
ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals got three-hit pitching from Gordon Jones today as they won their second straight over the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 -- 1.

NOT even distance can lend enchantment to tonight's fight for the world's heavyweight championship. Rocky Marciano will square off against Don Cockell, an Englishman who bestirs memories of the Fat Boy in Charles Dickens' "Pickwick Papers." The battler from Battersea was chosen carefully by Al Weill, the over-solicitous protector of the Brockton Blockbuster, to be bombed on the San Francisco proving grounds.
The Brooklyn Diocesan Union of Holy Name Societies held its annual rally yesterday afternoon in Ebbets Field, Brooklyn.

Christopher Awards were announced yesterday for the production of high-quality entertainment during the six-month period ended March 31. Twenty- five producers, directors, writers and a composer in the film, television, radio and song-writing fields were named.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- Detroit collected fifteen hits, including home runs by Jim Delsing and Ferris Fain, to beat Boston, 9-3 in the second game of a doubleheader today. The Tigers' victory snapped the Red Sox' five-game winning streak.

Among the numerous impersonal items that the mail has brought to this writer's desk in the last few days was the regular letter of a well-known firm of investment consultants. The salutation of this particular communication was: "Dear Speculator."
"The Official Directory of the City of New York," familiarly known as "The Little Green Book" because of its vestpocket size and Kelly - green velour cover, is published today by the city.

PARIS, May 15 -- Technically speaking it is impossible for the Big Four chiefs of state to hold a meeting "at the summit" for the simple reason that there is no longer any summit. This statement is not to be interpreted as casting doubt upon the legitimacy of Western Governments.

MILWAUKEE, May 15 (AP) -- Robin Roberts held Milwaukee to seven hits as the Philadelphia Phils pounded out a 9-1 victory over the Braves tonight in the second half of a twin bill. This snapped the Phils' thirteen-game losing streak.
Cotton futures prices moved in a narrower range last week than in the previous week, and active contracts closed 21 to 26 points -- or $1.05 to $1.30 a bale -- higher on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The concept of redemption through the "blue-throated God" of Hinduism was contrasted here yesterday with the Cross by the Rev. David G. Moses of Nagpur, India.

Weather aside, there is no way of telling that the ship charter market is approaching what used to be called the slack season. Rates are rising, and the forecasts are for fair and pleasant sailing for shipowners for some time to come.

At a late hour the United States Army has "suspended" its artillery practice on the slopes of Mount Fuji, in Japan. It is still indicated, however, that firing will be resumed at a later date. We hope that better sense will prevail.

Six college students and an experienced diplomatist weighed the advantages and disadvantages of secret diplomacy yesterday at the New York Times Youth Forum, televised from a Du Mont studio over station WARD-TV.

The Spanish Minister of Marine, the commander in chief of the Spanish Navy and the commander of the Spanish Marine Corps headed a group of Spanish dignitaries who were guests of honor yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

VIENNA, May 15 (UP) -- Secretary of State Dulles said today he had sent telegrams of gratitude to his predecessors, Gen. George C. Marshall and Dean Acheson, as soon as the Austrian treaty had been signed.

Irv Noren clouted an inside-the-park homer with the bases filled in the sixth inning of the second game at the Stadium yesterday. That blow broke a 1-1 tie and led Bob Turley and the Yankees to an 8-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
VIENNA, May 15 -- The Austria that received her freedom here today is the second Austrian republic.
Students at La Salle Military Academy are calling their varsity baseball diamond Ebbets Field.
VIENNA, May 15 -- Following is the official text of the Austrian state treaty, which was signed here today:
LONDON, May 15 -- The stock markets are endeavoring to maintain a fairly steady tone while more or less marking time pending the result of the general election
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Union leaders are speculating that the groundwork for getting John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers Union to join in the proposed labor merger may be prepared soon in Europe.
The Veterans Administration issued yesterday rules dealing with the starting deadline for training under the Korean G. I. Bill.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 15 -- Joint industry-union study of the guaranteed annual wage issue was agreed to by the nation's two leading glass manufacturers and the United Glass and Ceramic Workers, C. I. O.

In The New York Times of April 24, Thomas J. Hamilton quoted former Presidents Hoover and Truman, saying: "The Soviet Union would use its veto to prevent any important amendments to the U. N. Charter."

Rogation Sunday -- a period of thanksgiving for the abundance of the spring season -- was observed yesterday in several New York churches. At Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, a Rogation procession wound through the churchyard after the morning worship service.

Mousse au chocolat and pot de creme au chocolat are the French versions of our chocolate pudding. In keeping with tradition, they are served in dainty little pots designed especially for that purpose in France and available here in several shops.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Soviet Union's signing of the Austrian state treaty, coupled with Moscow's proposals on disarmament, have led policy-making officials here to give serious consideration to the idea that the Russians would like to end the "cold war."

MAINZ, Germany, May 15 (AP) -- Today's Christian Democratic victory in Rhineland-Palatinate insured firm control of the Federal Bundesrat (Upper House) for Dr. Adenauer during the crucial period when the Chancellor will submit legislation for the arming of 500,000 West Germans in the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Western European Union.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- The Post Office Department announced today that a new certified mail service replacing "no value" registered mail will be started June 6.
CINCINNATI, May 15 -- Don Newcombe continued his fine pitching today as he chalked up his fifth triumph in the Dodgers 7-1 victory over the Redlegs in the first game of a doubleheader.
DETROIT, May 15 (UP) -- Thousands of Catholics were shocked here today by a false report that Pope Pius XII had died.
Today, in enlightened countries, most senior citizens don't worry about the common cares. Modern communities take care of basic necessities, in one way or another.
ALBANY, May 15 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission took steps today to drive "gyp operators" out of the moving business in the New York City area.

ABINGDON, Va., May 15 (AP) -- Mary Martin was named today as the recipient of the annual Barter Theatre of Virginia Award, which includes a ham and an acre of land, for her performance in "Peter Pan."
American industry will spend $300,000,000 in the next four years on atomic energy research.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 15 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem abolished today Chief of State Bao Dai's Imperial Guard. A leader of the pro-Diem National Revolutionary Committee told a cheering crowd of 40,000 that Bao Dai was a "traitor to the country."
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today hailed the signing of the Austrian state treaty.
A 27-year-old carpenter was held by the police last night on a charge of beating a 10-year-old boy.
PARIS, May 15 -- Parisians came in such force today to look at an exhibition of the accoutrements of middle-income American life that they had trouble seeing anything at all.
The 141st anniversary of the adoption of the Norwegian Constitution was marked yesterday by a parade in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The borough has the fourth largest Norwegian community in the world.

BERLIN, Monday, May 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic party won a clear majority in the Legislature of Rhineland-Palatinate in yesterday's election in that southerly West German state.
Senator John J. Sparkman promised small business men last night a Congressional battle against any attempt to make monopolistic mergers by big business easier.
VIENNA, May 15 -- Five thousand Viennese wept, laughed, waved and cheered at the Belvedere Palace as the Austrian treaty was signed there today.

An option to purchase the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 975 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-third Street, has been taken by Harold Hunter Given, vice president of the Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., realty organization.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the award of thirty-five medals for heroism by department members last year.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson said today that the United States must continue to stockpile atomic weapons until Russia agreed to a foolproof armament-inspection plan.

BONN, Germany, May 15 -- The reborn Lufthansa, West Germany's commercial airline, opened its international service today with flights to Madrid and London. Commercial operations of the Lufthansa in West Germany were resumed on April 1 with flights between Hamburg and Munich.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 -- Despite some earlier expectation of a dip in steel ordering for the third quarter none has yet appeared. As a result, some steel companies that overbooked in anticipation of cancellations are being forced to extend delivery dates on certain products.

THE last new work to be presented in the season of "American Dance" sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation at the ANTA Theatre, was Anna Sokolow's "Rooms," with a score by Kenyon Hopkins, which had its premiere at yesterday's matinee.
Clyde T. Cadwallader has a lot of fun with real estate. A Buffalo lawyer, he got into it as a hobby, buying near-by run-down farms, improving them a little and selling them off in chunks.

ROME, May 15 -- A plan by which surplus foods held by the United States and other Governments could be used to aid the economy of underdeveloped countries was made public today. It would give a profit to the countries making their surpluses available.

We read with great interest and approbation your editorial of April 26 in which you urged restoration of the cuts in the foreign-student exchange program. The false economy which prompted such cuts is not only injurious to the foreign relations of our country, but it hinders our intellectual growth.
In Central America, a difficult reclamation project is nearing successful conclusion.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The key man in the Government's preparations for the high-level conference of the Big Four is Livingston T. Merchant, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.
VIENNA, May 15 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov served notice today at the signing of the Austrian state treaty that the Soviet price for Germany's reunification would be German neutrality.

CAIRO, May 15 -- Egypt is suffering from economic jitters. The principal fear haunting Egyptian commercial and financial communities is inflation. This fear was spurred on May 4 when the Government authorized loans totaling 150,000,000 Egyptian pounds ($444,000,000) for short-term development projects and cotton purchases.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 15 (UP) -- Dutch Harrison of St. Louis survived a shaky start today and then carded a par 70 to win the Greenbrier open golf tournament. Harrison had a 72-hole score of 269.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15 -- Two Harvard golfers, Ted Cooney and J. Brock Stokes; Yale's Jerry Fehr, and Tony Cullinane of Georgetown reached the semi-final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association's championships at the Yale course today.
CHICAGO, Bray 15 (UP) -- The Moral Re-Armament Movement is "the key to a new age." Dr. Frank N. Buchman, said today.

Financing has been arranged for a housing development in the Crestwood section of Yonkers with the placing of mortgage loans amounting to $916,250 on the Berkeley Homes tract on Scarsdale Road. Burger Katz, the builders, plan houses with eight rooms and two bathrooms. Albert E. Berkeley Co. arranged the loans.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 15 -- An explosion just before dawn today wound up the 1955 atomic test series. Supersonic planes participated for the first time.
Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein said yesterday that $508,000 could provide the proper number of city youth projects in the next two or three years to combat juvenile delinquency.
William J. Keating, former counsel to the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, expressed the opinion yesterday that it soon would cease to operate.
Between twelve and sixteen ships flying the flags of at least seven nations will enter crews in the annual international lifeboat race here May 24.

The national executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations adopted yesterday a program designed to enhance the nation's spiritual values and to "prevent inroads of domestic and foreign paganism."

Ruggiero Ricci, violinist; Rose Bampton, soprano, and Salvatore Mario de Stefano, harpist, presented a program last night at Hunter College Assembly Hall for the benefit of UNISOMI, Inc., an organization that is working for a world symphony orchestra.

ALBANY, May 15 -- Following are the allocations by the State Health Department to county and city health departments, stated in cubic centimeters, of 600,300 C.C.'s of polio vaccine. The 176,319 cubic centimeters for the New York City Health Department and the regional reserve of 633 C.C.'s in case of breakage are included in the total but not listed.
VIENNA, May 15 -- The foreign ministers of the Big Four and Austria signed the Austrian state treaty today.
CHICAGO, May 15 -- The Giants, struggling to keep the nigh-flying Dodgers within sight, had to settle for an even break today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- President Tito explained today his motives in deciding to receive top Soviet leaders here for talks on improving Yugoslav-Soviet relations.
A "large proportion" of the 54,000,000 Protestants in this country are Christian in name only, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken charged yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

Planning for United States aid to Asia on a "regional" basis has received something of a setback at the just-concluded Simla conference. The Asian states that would have been the beneficiaries of American help could not agree upon any program in which they could share as parts of a regional whole.
The first shipment of steel for a $50,000,000 industrial development in the Dominican Republic has arrived on the Rio Haina near Ciudad Trujillo.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 15 -- Britain was cautioned today that she would fatally jeopardize her own position in Asia if she should talk the United States into appeasement in the Formosa Strait.

Events tonight: Vera Lowy Ernst, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, and Fleetwood Singers, James Fleetwood, conductor, Beatrice Krebs, Robert Price, Charles Kuskin, Charles Wadsworth, soloists, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, both at 8:30.
VIENNA, May 15 (AP) -- Austria's foreign minister, Leopold Figl, and Secretary of State Dulles got lost for a time tonight in Vienna's 1,441-room Schoenbrunn Palace.

The cause of freedom won another important triumph when the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, France, Soviet Russia and Austria signed and sealed in Vienna yesterday the long delayed treaty which makes Austria again a sovereign and independent country.
Botany Brands, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Botany Mills, has been purchased for an undisclosed amount of cash by Clinton Smullyan. The company will be operated under its present name.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 15 (AP) -- Dr. Grayson L. Kirk called today for a rededication to "the common moral law of men of goodwill everywhere." The president of Columbia University spoke as Williamsburg celebrated the United States concept of religious freedom with ceremonies at the reconstructed Capitol building of Colonial Virginia.
A law banning loss leaders would scarcely curb evils in the market place. John W. Dargavel, chairman of the Bureau of Education on Fair Trade, said Saturday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 15 -- This capital city of the Belgian Congo presented a colorful spectacle today as it awaited the arrival of King Baudouin of Belgium.
Ten films will open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (AP) -- Jack McGrath again earned a spot in the front row of the 500-mile Memorial Day auto race today with a record-smashing ten-mile qualification run. His time was 142.58 miles an hour.

Shirt-sleeved New Yorkers gathered at the oval in Washington Square Park yesterday to spend the bright Sunday afternoon singing songs of the Old West, the mining camps, railroading and unrequited love.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 15 -- Elbert Johnson, a tall, raw-boned one-time baseball pitcher, captured handicap honors today as the three-day amateur trapshooting championships of America ended at Travers Island.
Perhaps more than any other room accessory pictures on the walls provide an insight into personality and taste.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- An incredulous 12-year-old schoolgirl opened an envelope from London here yesterday to find a personal note from Great Britain's former Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill.
Cedric H. Belfrage, editor of The National Guardian, jailed Friday in deportation proceedings, is on a hunger strike in Federal Detention Headquarters, 427 West Street.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, urged the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, today to make the Foreign Service less foreign.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 15 -- Dutch imports have been continuing on a high level. The danger of inventory depletion consequently no longer exists.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 15 -- Poor sailing weather marked the final spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Forty-nine craft struggled over courses with spotty help from winds that rarely reached more than three miles an hour.
ALBANY, Ga., May 15 (UP) -- Divers found today the body of a Navy lieutenant and veteran "skin diver" who had died in an underwater cave he was exploring in Radium Springs.
New York City learned yesterday that it would receive today 176,319 cubic centimeters of anti-poliomyelitis vaccine -- enough for that many individual doses.
Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Democratic leader of the Senate, called last night for the "greatest political offensive in history" to win the "cold war."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 15 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower worshipped today at a vine-covered Presbyterian Church. It was the same church where Abraham Lincoln attended a patriotic service after having delivered his Gettysburg Address nearly ninety-two years ago.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday a change in departmental procedure on citizens' complaints.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- An indication that the logjam on United Nations membership might be broken through the admission of Austria appeared today with publication of the text of the Austrian state treaty. Support for Austria's application is pledged in the preamble by both the Soviet Union and the Western powers.

Every seat in Town Hall was taken for the Saturday evening concert of the Jewish Peoples Philharmonic Chorus. Eugene Malek, the conductor, led the group through its thirty-second concert, which honored the Jewish tercentenary celebrations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -- Jack Lemmon, Columbia's new leading man, will step into the role made famous by Clark Gable in the studio's musical remake of the comedy "It Happened One Night."
NORFOLK, Va., May 15 -- The fifteen Ambassadors who carry on the day-to-day business of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization arrived here today on their first visit as a body to the United States.
The melancholy days are almost here again for New York City's motorists.
The "genius of Christianity" is that it is capable of resurrection in an instant, John J. Mullery, Professor of History at Manhattan College, said yesterday.

MADRID, May 15 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Spain has been authorized by the Vatican to set up a "secretariat on the board of Archbishops" to coordinate the attitude of the Spanish hierarchy on questions affecting both church and state.

VIENNA, May 15 (AP) -- Following are the texts of statements made today by the foreign ministers of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France at the signing of the Austrian state treaty:
LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- France edged Argentina, 3 -- 2, today to join India, Sweden, Belgium, and Chile in the quarter-finals of the European zone Davis Cup tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- All the Salk vaccine manufactured by the Eli Lilly Company of Indianapolis and previously released in the anti-poliomyelitis campaign was recleared by the United States Public Health Service today.

Unusual stories of escaped war captives in Korea are the subjects of a new book by Clay Blair Jr., entitled "Beyond Courage." Each of the four stories, based on "secret files" of the War Department, describes how an American airman through his own bravery and ingenuity returned alive to his home and family.
By 1970 New York will have nearly 2,000,000 children under 15 years old, Morgan Dix Wheelock, president of the Children's Aid Society, estimates.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Trade volume in Board of Trade futures of grain and soybeans slipped a little last week compared with the preceding week. And the week showed an even bigger dip from the year-ago level The following table gives the purchases of grain and soy-I beans, in thousands of bushels, with comparisons:
Dr. Emanuel Neumann, chairman of the executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America, urged the United States Government yesterday to enter "into mutual security negotiations with Israel."
LONDON, May 18 -- The British election campaign passed the half-way mark today with the Conservatives enjoying a lead so large that even Labor politicians recognize it.
A gratuitous insult at a high school water fountain sent violence smoldering through Brooklyn's teen-age gang world over the week-end, and resulted in a wanton attack on a passer-by.
The nation's steel production exceeded expectations last week and set a record high of 2,345,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -The nation's 527 mutual savings banks on March 31 had 51.3 per cent of their $30,000,000,000 assets invested in home mortgage loans. This was the highest in two decades, in percentage and in dollars.
The United States Steel Foundation will give $1,052,000 this year to colleges and universities in forty-three states.
Early risers and night workers, once denied the opportunity of attending evening education classes, now will be able to continue their education under a new system at New York University.
New York City will have a multitude of problems in the next ten years, and the greatest will be housing, the Welfare and Health Council of New York City predicted yesterday.

MONTEBELLO, Que., May 16 (UP) -- At least three Canadian provinces should be using atom-generated electricity within twenty years, J. A. Fuller of Montreal, president of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company, predicted today.
TOKYO, May 16 (Reuters) -The congress heard appeals for free trade, convertibility of currencies and "ample" capital investment to provide economic liberty for Asia's millions.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16 (AP) -- An American engineering concern will supervise construction of a massive T. V. A.-type project in Lebanon's Litani River Valley.
IN his first show in several years Jon Corbino, at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue, has done a number of paintings of racing, together with several of the circus and of ballet dancers.

Stock prices suffered a sharp setback yesterday but the market -- as was the case last week -still showed no great participation by the general public. Volume was only 2,160,000 shares, against 1,860,000 on Friday.

Sir Winston Churchill, who among other things is the greatest parliamentarian of the century, made his major bid for re-election in his home constituency of Woodford, near London, last night. As is usually the case with Sir Winston, the speech is commanding, world-wide attention, especially as it dealt with the forthcoming Big Four meeting "at the summit."
The Sweet Briar Alumnae Association of New York is conducting a "Flowers for Funds" drive to raise funds for scholarship students at Sweet Briar (Va.) College.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 5 points lower to 8 points higher than last Friday's close.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- The White House today endorsed all but one of the "protectionist" amendments written into the Administration's liberalized trade bill by the Senate.
GUAM, May 16 -- This 225 square miles of Pacific real estate has finally succumbed to the global concept of modern war.
Just as an Age began when the Alamogordo atom bomb went off, another Age (still adolescent, too) was born fifteen years ago, May 15, when nylon stockings first appeared in stores across the nation.

A one-story industrial building with a railroad siding at Fiftieth Avenue and Twentyseventh Street, in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Eastern Cold Storage Insulation Company. The building will be used for the warehousing of insulation material.

LONDON, May 16 -- Don't give "Kismet" a second thought. It is a big success at the huge Stoll Theatre in the Kingsway, where gigantic photographs of Alfred Drake, Doretta Morrow and Joan Diener are contentedly smiling.

SAN SALVADOR, May 16 -- El Salvador has drawn a "cotton curtain" across its Honduras border, forbidding the import of cotton shirts from the neighboring republic until additional cost studies are made.

ROME, May 16 -- Recent political developments in Italy have convinced United States military authorities of the need for a review of Italy's position regarding the West, particularly the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -President Eisenhower called today for $28,000,000 in Federal grants to states to make sure that children in families unable to afford Salk vaccine would get the anti-poliomyelitis shots.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)--Following is the list of air cadets named to the first class:
THERE are rare days, treasured in the memory of anglers and hunters, when every cast seems just right or every shot finds the bird in the center of the pattern.
NEWARK, May 16 -- The opening of a Congressional investigation of alleged Communist infiltration here touched off a three-hour demonstration late today by 1,200 union members.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Supreme Court decided today three cases involving the liability of tugboat companies for accidents in towing operations.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams promoted seven men yesterday, transferred fifteen, dismissed two and added 183. The additions brought the department's strength to 21,587, the highest on record.

Four witnesses, including three dockers, corroborated previous testimony last night as the Waterfront Commission continued its investigation into alleged gambling and kickbacks by longshoremen at the Leonardo Naval Base, Earle, N. J. The commission held an extra session to speed up the hearing, which is now in its third week.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- Extension of the Pulitzer Prizes to include motion-picture writing was advocated today by Jack L. Warner, vice president of Warner Brothers.

The acceptance of fluoridation for the reduction of tooth decay "marks a great victory for the people in their fight against disease," the president of the New York State Dental Society reported here yesterday.
This letter is in reference to the implied invitation in your editorial "Business Bad or Good?" in the issue of May 10.
WOODFORD, England, May 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill predicted tonight that the new attitude of the Soviet Union might speed the making of peace between East and West.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- Rocky Marciano was born Rocco Marchegiano in Brockton, Mass., on Sept. 1, 1924. He is the son of Pietro Marchegiano, an Italian immigrant who was employed as a shoe worker in Brockton through the years that Rocky was growing up.
Up popped Clifford Mooers' Traffic Judge in the last sixteenth to win the sprint for 3-year-olds that headed Belmont Park's program yesterday.
Fifth Avenue Motors Inc, sales agency for German-made Volkswagen automobiles, store at 11 E 58th St in the Savoy Plaza Hotel -- Charles F. Noyes Co, broker.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 16 -- The South for the most part continues to present a picture of widespread inconclusiveness in plans for racial integration of its public schools.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -Maine Central Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue $3,114,500 of 5 per cent first mortgage and collateral bonds, dated to mature in 1980, without the usual competitive bidding.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 16 (AP) -- Early Goose came home in 2:04 2-5 tonight to win the Seacliff Pace at Roosevelt Raceway by a neck over Amber Ann.
PARIS, May 16 (AP) -- Stocks turned upward today in a lively session at the Paris Bourse, after last week's severe drop.
DALAT, Vietnam, May 16 (AP) -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem presided in Dalat today over ceremonies marking the completion of South Vietnam's territorial and military unity.
The United States must adopt a strong, long-range military and economic program if it is to maintain leadership in a free world, Senator Styles Bridges said here last night.

Your editorial of May 12, "Statehood Will Come," seems to infer that I voted against statehood for Hawaii and Alaska on the grounds of opposition to civil rights legislation. Certainly my record in support of civil rights is clear enough, and I cannot believe that this inference was intended.
Knowing what to wear where has been Mrs. H. Alwyn InnessBrown's special field since she was knee-high to a suitcase.
