Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for April and for four and twelve-month periods ended April 30. Operating revenues were $113,604,923 for twelve months against $108,122,712, while net income of $21,342,247, equal to $3.20 a share, compared with $19,616,805, or $2.90 a share, a year earlier.

New York City and Buffalo unexpectedly obtained allocations yesterday for enough extra poliomyelitis vaccine from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis to complete a series of first injections.
Denmark, England and Italy won their second-round matches yesterday to complete the quarter-final bracket in the European zone Davis Cup tennis competition.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said last night that New York's law of arrest was more than a century behind the times and utterly unrealistic for a large city. He suggested that civic and legal groups study it and make recommendations for modernizing it.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury suggested today that the price of the Administration's highway program be treated as an official part of the national debt.
NEWARK, N. J., May 16 (AP) -- Stockholders of Daystrom, Inc. and Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation held special meetings today and approved the merger of Weston into Daystrom.

NEW HAVEN, May 16 -- The Salk vaccine inoculation program started today among the first and second-grade pupils in this city's public schools. It was marked by a flood of last-minute cancellations of parent consents. There was also an abnormally high absenteeism.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., looks upon its proposed nuclear power plant as "the only way we can see of bringing about lower electricity costs over the long pull."
STUTTGART, Germany, May 16 (AP) -- leading West German industrialist urged the nation's big business men today to continue close economic ties with the West under newly won sovereignty.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Dr. Otto Suhr, Mayor of West Berlin, declared today that neutralization was a price Germany never would pay for unification and freedom from occupation.
Nine men and two women were cited yesterday for outstanding contributions to the growth of New York City.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. last night accused George A. Mooney, State Superintendent of Banks, of conducting a "whitewash investigation" mortgage loan discrimination against Negroes.
The Screen Directors Guild in Hollywood agreed yesterday to participate in the production of a television series titled "Screen Directors Playhouse."

Closed-circuit television audiences in seventeen theatres in the metropolitan area watched Rocky Marciano retain his world heavyweight crown against Don Cockell last night. The New York network of movie-television exhibition was part of a nation-wide hook-up of eighty-three theatres in fifty-nine cities.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Luis Arroyo pitched a six-hit shutout tonight for his third straight victory. Behind Arroyo's pitching the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 0. The Pirates have scored only one run in their last thirtysix innings.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 535 pints of blood at Fort Monmouth, N. J., last Friday. The day's total was 744 pints. On Saturday, 147 pints were donated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Pascal Baylon, 112-43 198th Street, South Hollis, Queens, and 116 pints at Cornucopia Masonic Lodge Hall, 137-70 Northern Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens.

One year ago today the Supreme Court handed down a unanimous decision that will serve as a historic landmark in the development and protection of civil rights under the Constitution. The outlawry of segregation in the public schools was a turning point in the long and inevitable process of granting true equality of opportunity, so far as the law can do so, to all Americans.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Justice John Marshall Harlan delivered his first opinion today as a member of the Supreme Court. It held that Ohio had no right to levy an intangible property tax on obligations of the Federal Government held by two mutual savings banks.

A BEAUTIFUL, thrilling and sometimes gruesome travel experience for the explorer who prefers to be transported in a theatre armchair rather than in a bouncing jeep is being offered on the screen of the Little Carnegie. It is "Green Magic," a Ferraniacolor travel film that recounts in bold and vivid details a 7,800-mile jeep trip across the midriff of South America.
TRENTON, May 16 -- The New Jersey Legislature moved today to establish a guaranteed hourly wage and to increase unemployment compensation and temporary disability grants in the state.
Antonino Rocca, 224, Buenos Aires, and Verne Gagne, 222, Excelsior, Minn., drew in the feature wrestling match before 7,500 at Madison Square Garden last night.

The five-story apartment house accommodating forty-eight families at 460 Audubon Avenue has figured in a quick resale. Max B. Cane contracted to buy the property from the 460 Audubon Corporation, of which S. Rubin is president, and resold it to the Bedlow Holding Corporation, headed by Morris Schwartz.
PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 16 (AP) -- Barbara Romack, the United States amateur champion, battled from behind today to gain the second round of the British women's golf championship.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 16 -- A woman accused of willful refusal to yield a party line telephone in an emergency was placed on trial today. If convicted of the charge of having caused a three-minute delay in the reporting of a fire, she could be jailed for a year, fined $500, or both.

BONN, Germany, May 16--The Western Big Three still insist that a reunited Germany "must be free to arrange for its own future in Europe." This will be the Western position at the proposed four-power conference, Dr. James B. Conant, United States Ambassador, said today.
PARIS, May 16 -- There is much confusion in France about what some persons call Moscow's gratifying concessions and others call Moscow's maneuvers for a neutral Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The commission, headed by Herbert Hoover, which was unanimously authorized by Congress to check the Federal Government for bureaucratic bloat and the virus of statism is steadily reporting many instances of both disorders. Already it is being attacked at the Capitol for locating them in certain Government units. But it has given Congress enough work to occupy a considerable period of its next session.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board said today that industrial production rose in April to within one index point of the record high reached in mid-1953. It reported that "economic activity generally expanded further in April."
LONDON, May 16 -- Russia's agreement to a four-power meeting cheered the stock market here today.

Columbus may have introduced Italians to tomatoes, which once grew only in this hemisphere. But the Italians taught us the possibilities of tomatoes in sauces for spaghetti, meat, fish, fowl and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The organization of an advisory corrections council to conduct broad studies in the penal field was announced today by Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General. He said that he had named Dr. Hurst R. Anderson, president of American University here, as chairman.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -The Administration followed the recommendations of the President's National Advisory Committee on Poliomyelitis Vaccine in assigning top priority to children aged 5 through 9.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Bullish crop estimates from the Southwest appeared today to have lost their effect in the wheat market, especially as there have been scattered showers again over the drought portions of Kansas, Texas and Oklahoma.
ALNWICK, England, May 16 -- Prosperity, peace and political apathy are the keynotes in this lovely rolling region of north England.
RALEIGH, N. C., May 16 (UP) -- A husband and wife team of Harvard anthropologists went to court today to see their son charged with slaying a woman with a shot fired from a hotel room.
Joseph B. Cavallaro was elected last night to his third one-year term as chairman of the Board of Higher Education, governing body of the municipal colleges.

Volume was unusuall ylight yesterday on the New York commodity futures markets. Trading generally was confined to the evening-up of holdings in the May position before the contract expires. Prices moved irregularly, with coffee, sugar, wool and burlap mixed; potatoes, cocoa, rubber and lead lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, zinc and copper higher.

WASHINGTON, May 16--Following is the analysis of the distribution problem of the Salk vaccine and recommendations from the report to the President today by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare:...
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- Rocky Marciano called his beaten British opponent tonight "an underestimated fighter."

The ship owner's desire to reduce operating costs and a union proposal for industry-wide unemployment benefits characterized yesterday's opening contract session between ship operators and the National Maritime Union, C. I. O.

AKMOLINSK, U. S. S. R., April 25 -- One of the main streets of Akmolinsk, a dusty, uneven thoroughfare that lurches past the City Hotel and the town's only department store, is named for two men from Boston, Sacco and Vanzetti.

A forecast that 1955 will bring to the auto industry a wage increase of 15 to 16 cents an hour and adoption of a five-year plan for the guaranteed annual wage -- both without a strike -- was presented yesterday to the American Management Association.

Two non-fiction works, one dealing with problems in Africa, the other with the southwestern United States, have been named winners of the 1955 AnisfieldWolf Awards. The prizewinners, each of which won $1,000, were "Report on Africa," by Oden Meeker (Scribners), and "Cultural Difference and Medical Care," by Lyle Saunders (Russell Sago Foundation).

Staten Island, bracing itself for inevitable economic and cultural transformations, dedicated yesterday a fastness of 260 acres as a a wildlife preserve. The shadow of the projected bridge across the Narrows reached into the wooded glen off Travis Avenue where thirtyfive persons gathered before a sour gum tree.
Stockholders of the MerrittChapman Scott Corporation will be asked at a special meeting on June 22 to approve an increase in the authorized stock from 6,000,000 to 10,000,000 shares.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 16 -- King Baudouin I of the Belgians received an enthusiastic welcome here today from 200,000 cheering subjects.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, May 17 -- Premier Chou En-lai, in a statement released today, renewed Communist China's offer "to sit down and enter into negotiations" with the United States to ease tension in the Formosa area.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on a motion to compel License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey to issue a license for burlesque shows in the Orpheum Theatre, Brooklyn.

The Board of Education is experimenting with a private alarm system in two public schools in an effort to discourage illegal entry. No incidents have occurred at either of the schools since the alarms were installed almost a year ago, and the experiment may be widened.
PARIS, May 16 -- Premier Edgar Faure and Finance Minister Pierre Pflimlin are worried lest the drop in United States orders for defense materials in France should lead to the closing of factories.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- Harold Johnson, No. 1 light heavyweight contender, three handlers and a matchmaker, Pete Moran, today were accused of covering up a "fake" boxing match.

TOKYO, May 16 -- The chief of the United States delegation to the International Chamber of Commerce meeting here said today that he favored expanded trade throughout the world, including that with Communist nations. He added the proviso, however, that such trade should not be in strategic goods that would strengthen the Communist war potential.

The New York Central Railroad disclosed yesterday that it planned to start immediately preliminary work to convert the system's four-track main line between Cleveland and Buffalo to a "more efficient, economical, double-track 'C T C' road." "C T C" is an abbreviation for centralized traffic control, the most modern type of signaling system.

Following is the text of yesterday's statement by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, City Health Commissioner, announcing plans to begin inoculations with poliomyelitis vaccine from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis:
A major cooperative promotion and advertising program designed to spur soft-drink sales in the Northeastern United States is in the offing.

OTTAWA, May 16 -- The United States is pressing its surplus disposal program to the point where it is having a disturbing effect on the world wheat market, Clarence D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, told the House of Commons here today.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Chesser M. Campbell, president of The Chicago Tribune, today was named publisher of the newspaper at a meeting of the board of directors. The newspaper had been without a publisher since the death April 1 of Col. Robert R. McCormick.

New York City's policemen and firemen are getting a deserved increase in pay. Their work is hard, and at times dangerous. The protection to life and property that they furnish expertly, intelligently and often without thought for their own safety is appreciated by the public.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- The Administration urged today continued economic and technical aid to Latin America.
PARIS, May 16 -- The French Government is wrestling with three difficult North African questions at once.

Privately owned United States shipyards now have contracts for only fifteen vessels, aggregating 223,760 gross tons, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday. The council said that only eight keels were still to be laid, and that work schedules included only one ship to be completed after next summer.
FORT MYER, Va., May 16 (AP) -- Medals of Honor for two men who died in the Korean War were presented here today to their next of kin.

THE first white man who gave the river its name called it the French Broad. Broad for a mountain river where he saw-it somewhere west of the Blue Ridge, it flowed northwest through a gorge in the Great Smoky Mountains into territory claimed by the French.

BOSTON, May 16 -- The names of seventy to one hundred persons considered by a special commission to be either Communists or subversives are expected to be read on the floor of the Massachusetts State Senate this week.

A syndicate headed by Webb Knapp, Inc., and Roger L. Stevens has contracted to purchase three hotels from the National Cuba Hotel Corporation which is owned by the Kirkeby Hotels. The properties are the Gotham in New York, the Beverly Wilshire in Beverly Hills, Calif., and the Nacional de Cuba in Havana.

In a report from its headquarters in Rome the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has made some thoughtful concrete suggestions as to how surplus food stocks in some countries can be used to feed the hungry in others.
Close cooperation between the police and liquor control authorities was described yesterday by an expert in both fields.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Tomorrow is the first anniversary of the Supreme Court decision against school segregation, but the day still has not earned its red letters on the calendar.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -Members of a House committee today proposed a second atomic-propelled merchant ship. The group's chairman called the one previously proposed By President Eisenhower an "international sideshow or a Mississippi River showboat."

Through the years enthusiastic producers have attempted to offer a musical version of Al Capp's popular comic strip "Li'l Abner." Although their efforts have come to naught thus far, the idea is still blooming. Herman Levin was the last producer to concentrate on the venture. Obstacles intervened, however, and his option lapsed.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 (AP) -- Manuel Ayulo, 33, second-ranking race car driver in America last year, was injured critically when his car smashed into a wall on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today.

You ask this rather petulant question about the Lincoln Square Slum Clearance project: "When Government is building a whole group of structures the consistency of architecture can, of course, be controlled now through official bodies and informed public opinion. But take the case of the Lincoln Square development.
The possible relationship between cigarette smoking and lung cancer and other afflictions is still an unknown factor, Dr. Clarence Cook Little emphasized here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -Jacob K. Javits called tonight for a mutual-defense agreement between the United States and Israel.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., May 16 -- A Swiss biophysicist and a Puerto Rican chemist, working in an abandoned barn on a process for making industrial diamonds, have developed techniques that may prove valuable to the science of metallurgy.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -Secretary of State Dulles returned from Europe today with a declaration that the forthcoming Big Four conference held "some promise of constructive accomplishment."
Bill Crowley, Fordham's pitching ace, scored his third victory in three starts by setting back Manhattan, 11 -- 2, at Jack Coffey Field yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 16 -The Brazilian Government revealed today that it had conferred last week with Mexican, Salvadorean and Costa Rican representatives on fixing quotas of coffee to be withheld from the world market to support prices.

ONE of the nice things about those recent visitors to our town, the Detroit Tigers, is that they bring with them their own built-in loudspeaker. The booming non-stop voice is attached to Dizzy Trout, a reformed Bengal pitcher, who now handles the broadcasting chores for the Tigers. The colorful Diz is merely doin' what comes naturally.
The Panama Canal Company is "subsidizing" its commercial operations by refusing to lower canal tolls as required by law, the Association of American Ship Owners charged yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- Rocky Marciano knocked out Don Cockell of England in 54 seconds of the ninth round tonight to retain the heavyweight championship of the world.

Completion of the major phase of a long-range expansion program in the South by the Robert Gair Company, Inc., of New York, was announced yesterday by George E. Dyke, president, after the acquisition of the Great Southern Box Company of New Orleans.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Success of the voluntary Salk vaccine distribution depends on the "goodwill and faith" of the medical profession, Senators were told today.

AMHERST, Mass., May 16 (UP) -- The New England Golf Coaches Association and the Yankee Conference have decided to go along with two other groups in banning Susan Inman, University of Massachusetts freshman, from participating in freshman or varsity golf competition.
NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- Officials of Pakistan and India reached agreement tonight on a plan to eliminate border fights in Kashmir.

In officially designating this as Letters from America Week Mayor Wagner has urged all Americans with relatives and friends abroad to use their letters to spread the true story of the United States. Such letters, it is felt, will combat Communist propaganda and enable other countries to know us better.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 16 (UP) -- Willie Hartack continued his exellent riding at Garden State Park today when he rode four winners, including both ends of a $54 daily double.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -A permit to fly from four cities of the United States West Coast direct to London and other European points over the polar route, has been asked by Pan American World Airways.
MADRID, May 16 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said today Moscow's signing of the peace treaty with Austria was an act of "political convenience."

Consumer goods from twenty-seven countries, reflecting higher living standards as well as a desire to improve them by selling more to this country, were featured yesterday at the New York International Trade Fair.

Every American community should study its school needs and determine how to meet the educational crisis, Neil H. McElroy, chairman of the White House Conference on Education, said yesterday. He warned 500 educators and business men at the opening luncheon of Chemical Progress Week at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel that the rising birth rate would add to the school problems now confronting the nation.

Mrs. Irving J. Sands, member of the Board of Education received a special citation yesterday for distinguished community service. The scroll was presented by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, at a luncheon sponsored by the Brooklyn Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.
Maj. Gen. Roger Browne, commanding the First Air Force, warned yesterday that victory in any emergency might depend on how well we conserved our national resources.
Bakers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States decreased seasonally during April by $39,647,000, to $767,321,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
An unusual meeting is taking place in Tokyo this week. The fifteenth Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce is in session in the Japanese capital.

The Board of Higher Education voted at its annual meeting last night to dismiss Dudley David Straus, suspended Queens College English instructor, for his refusal to answer questions relating to membership in the Communist party.

VIENNA, May 16 -- Former German property in Eastern Austria, whose confiscation by the Soviet Union was the chief factor that held up the Austrian state treaty, is now affecting Austrian-German relations.
Paddy DeMarco, former light weight champion, gained a split decision over Lippy Manzo in the main bout of ten rounds at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The April in Paris Ball, held last month in the WaldorfAstoria, netted $90,000 for various Franco-American charities.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Supreme Court rejected today the appeal of three Cleveland newspaper men convicted of contempt for taking pictures in a courtroom contrary to a judge's orders.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- It was a balmy -- for San Francisco -- spring evening when Rocky Marciano climbed into the ring with Don Cockell tonight. The temperature was in the high fifties, according to The New York Times' 39-cent fight thermometer, but things warmed up considerably, at least in the ring, shortly afterward.
Companies that don't want to emerge from annual meetings with unwelcome board members might learn from yesterday's experience of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Treasury reported today that its short-term borrowing costs had declined slightly.

Akron, Ohio, announced plans yesterday for the sale of $4,000,000 of sewer bonds. Bids will be opened on the obligations on June 6. Dated June 1, 1955, the bonds will come due serially on Sept. 1 from 1956 to 1975.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- The round-by-round description of the Rocky Marciano-Don Cockell fight at Kezar Stadium tonight follows:
Reflecting increased sales in the quarter and six months ended March 31, earnings of the Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries improved substantially over a year ago.
The Avco Manufacturing Corporation has elected Chester G. Gifford as president of the Crosley and Bendix Home Appliances Divisions.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Supreme Court let pass without notice today the first anniversary of its decision that racial segregation in the public schools was unconstitutional.
Sir Winston's assertion that the new look group in the Soviet Union has "powerful forces behind it" apparently is an allusion to the rising Army group headed by Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov.
ALBANY, May 16 -- The Harriman Administration is planning a top-to-bottom investigation of the efficiency of the state's government.

VIENNA, May 16 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, who stayed on in Vienna today after the three Western Foreign Ministers had departed, spent the day seeing the sights and ingratiating himself with the public.
MENADO, Celebes, May 13 -- An armed struggle to establish the Republic of the South Moluccas continues on the Island of Ceram.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 16 -One of the most extensive collections of American historical documents went on public display for the first time today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Internal Revenue Service filled key positions in Philadelphia and New Jersey today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Eisenhower today suspended all quota limitations on imports of shelled peanuts until July 31.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 16 (Reuters) -- Hundreds of thousands of Britons tottered sleeping to radio sets just before 4 A. M. (11 P. M. Eastern Daylight Time) today to tune in on the Marciano-Cockell championship fight.
A person not connected with the American Stock Exchange opened that market for business yesterday for the first time in its history.
MOSCOW, May 16 (Reuters) -- Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin announced today a toplevel reorganization to separate future and present economic planning.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -A Federal court jury, after twenty minutes' deliberation, found Mrs. Marie Natvig guilty today of lying under oath.

RAMAT GAN, Israel, May 10 -- Bar-Ilan University, a new institution sponsored by the Mizrachi Organization of America, has almost completed its home in the rolling fields outside this town. It is to be a university devoted to the teaching of Judaism combined with general education on the lines of colleges in the United States.

RAMAT GAN, Israel, May 10 -- Bar-Ilan University, a new institution sponsored by the Mizrachi Organization of America, has almost completed its home in the rolling fields outside this town. It is to be a university devoted to the teaching of Judaism combined with general education on the lines of colleges in the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- Summer clinics appeared today to be the only answer to completion of the mass vaccination of first and second grade school children before the peak of the poliomyelitis season.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 17-- The Federal housing chief issued an ultimatum today to the nation's private lending industry to meet the home-financing needs of remote areas and small communities and of minority groups.
CINCINNATI, May 17 (AP)-- Lefty Joe Nuxhall tonight beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9--2, to lift the Redlegs into sixth place. Big Ted Kluszewski hit his ninth homer of the season for Cincinnati.

The Committee of One Million, which opposes the admission of Communist China to the United Nations, issued a statement last night supporting "the President's desire to promote a peaceful solution to the crisis in the Formosa Strait."
WISLEY, England, May 17-- The first of a fleet of sixty Vickers Viscount airliners was delivered to Capital Airlines of the United States at a ceremony here this morning.

Edward Schwartz and Edward Maltz, operators, have purchased the two four-story apartment houses at 718-22 East 212th Street, the Bronx. The buildings contain thirty-nine apartments. They were sold by a client of Leepson Rubman, lawyers, subject to mortgages totaling $55,000.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 13 points yesterday.

Resident Wrens Wanted What the garden needed, said the lady of the house some weeks ago, was a resident wren. It would be recalled, she said, that in previous years one had been enjoying only the visits of wrens belonging to neighbors.

Amid charges by the minority of extravagance and waste, the City Council adopted yesterday without change the record city budget of $1,782,335,683 for 1955-56. In one verbal onslaught Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican-Liberal, charged that even before the Board of Estimate holds its mid-April statutory public hearings, it "meets and decides how it will vote on every item."

BERLIN, May 17--Georgi M. Pushkin, the Soviet High Commissioner for Germany, agreed today to meet the three Western Big Three Ambassadors to West Germany Friday to discuss East German tolls on trucking.
Fifty-four local housing and redevelopment authorities subsidized by agencies of the Federal Government borrowed $98,272,000 on short-term notes yesterday at interest costs of 0.97 to 1.18 per cent.
Two new district champions were crowned in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches yesterday.

In a flurry of eagle feathers and shrill hoots directed to the Great Spirit in thanks for protecting their journey, three little Hopi Indians arrived at Grand Central Terminal yesterday. It was their first time away from their Arizona reservation.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The National Military Reserve plan met a heavy attack in the House of Representatives today. But its principal proponents, largely Democrats, retained confidence that the House would approve it, probably tomorrow.
ALBANY, May 17--Governor Harriman served notice today that his investigation of state government efficiency would include a check on semi-independent commissions.
BALTIMORE, May 17 (UP) Billy Cox slammed his second homerun of the season and Hal Smith drove in two runs to place the Baltimore Orioles to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

There was a deceptive informality about the broadcast that came last night from the Oval Office in the White House, with President Eisenhower asking a question now and then and Secretary of State Dulles giving the replies. Nor did the listening and watching millions learn much that they had not known before.
MILWAUKEE, May 17--The bottom fell out of everything for the Giants on this frosty night before a gathering of 29,139 hardy onlookers.

Commodity futures moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, potatoes, hides, burlap, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined; sugar, cocoa and wool were mixed, and rubber, zinc and copper ended higher.
General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein dismissed yesterday a bribery indictment against George Scalise, union racketeer, and two other men.

The decision of the Board of Estimate to establish, in cooperation with the State University, a twoyear liberal arts and science community college on Staten Island is a welcome one. It will be named Richmond College and will have rented quarters at St. George for several years, awaiting construction of a $4,500,000 plant.

IF anyone needs to be reminded of the terrible things that occurred following the historic dropping of the first atomic bomb on Japan, he might go to see "Hiroshima," a semi-documentary Japanese film that recounts the fate of the people of that city.

CHICAGO, May 17--An estimated $100,000 was raised tonight at a dinner commemorating the 100th anniversary of the reform, movement of Judaism in the United States. Dr. Samuel S. Hollender, Chicago philanthropist and civic leader, named last month as Judaism's "man of the year," was honored at the dinner.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With all the clamor for some relief in the congestion of the trial of cases in our courts, it would seem that a simple amendment of the Constitution might afford it.

A two-volume study of Indian art will be published Monday by Pantheon Books. The scope of "The Art of Indian Asia: Its Mythology and Transformation" covers from 3000 B. C. to the present, drawing on legend and myth, the psychological, philosophical and religious lore.

When the conferees on the reciprocal trade extension bill meet today to consider the Senate and House versions of H. R. 1, their deliberations will be overshadowed by one all-important fact: the White House has given up the fight to keep its own bill intact as it passed the House and instead is accepting-- save for one particularly dangerous amendment--the considerably weakened measure approved by the Senate.
The press of the free world today faces the greatest challenge in its history, Ogden R. Reid, recently named president and publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, said last night.
The illegal practice of dentistry by dental laboratory technicians is said to be increasing and to represent "a serious menace to public dental health."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 --Guy Madison is moving into the star-producer category under terms of a six-picture contract negotiated with Columbia.
Consolidated net earnings of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and wholly owned

The third of three programs of contemporary music was presented at the Town Hall Green Room last night by Composers of Today, Inc. New works heard were Humphrey Searle's "Threnos and Toccata" and a violin sonata by Robert Starer.
WASHINGTON, May 17--A bill to repeal two unexpectedly costly provisions of the Administration's general tax revision law of 1954 was unanimously approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

A housing development is planned for the Holderer Nursery property in Whitestone, Queens, which has been purchased by Garland Homes, Inc., of Hollis. Comprising about thirtytwo lots, the property is bounded by Nineteenth and Twentieth Avenues, east of 154th Street.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The Army gave the public a glimpse today of the Nike anti-aircraft guided missile batteries that are guarding major cities against atomic attack.

Three robbers escaped yesterday morning with $50,000 worth of mink furs from the Bobby Brown Furs, Inc. Five men and a woman were bound during the robbery of the wholesale shop at 307 Seventh Avenue, near Twentyeighth Street.
The Inter American Press Association warned yesterday that an increase in the price of newsprint would undermine democracy in the Western Hemisphere.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 17--The coalition Government of Premier Willem Drees fell today.
United Aircraft Corporation in the first quarter this year had a net income of $6,996,757 against $6,509,059 earned in the corresponding period last year, it was reported yesterday.

TOKYO, May 17 -- Business leaders from America, Asia and Europe today prescribed increased trade as the surest cure for the world's economic ills and the best preventative against depression and social unrest.
AKMOLINSK, U. S. S. R., April 27--A visitor to Akmolinsk wanted to see the "new lands" about which so much is now written and spoken in the Soviet Union.
The stock market closed irregularly lower yesterday. After an easy opening, prices recovered mildly, but in the afternoon they sagged again. Most gains and losses were held within narrow limits.

The preliminary figure on the gross national product in the first quarter of 1955, which appeared in late April, showed this over-all index of the country's output of goods and services to be running at a rate of $369 billions a year. Over the past week-end the Department of Commerce revised the estimate upward by a billion dollars, to $370 billions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your April 2 editorial "Taxing Away the Railroads" discussed the attempted increase of New York Central's taxes resulting in threatened abandonment of Grand Central Station. If Central feels squeezed, the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad feels strangled by taxation and state-sponsored competition which entices our passengers to public river crossings with tolls reduced by tax exemption and subsidization.
MOSCOW, May 17--Two Columbia University professors today deplored restrictions in both the United States and the Soviet Union that limit exchanges of visits by their citizens.

American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., is considering going into phonograph records and electronics, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Former President Vincent Auriol of France was formally welcomed to New York yesterday by Mayor Wagner. M. Auriol, accompanied by his wife, arrived Monday for a visit in behalf of the World Veterans Federation, of which he is honorary president.
Issues of $60,000,000 of new securities of W. R. Grace Co., shipping and chemical enterprise, and of Ohio Edison Company, will be offered for public subscription by underwriting syndicates today.
YESTERDAY (May 17, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Republican Congressional leaders; received officials of the American Bar Association and met with Secretary of Defense Wilson.

WINCHESTER seems to have done it again. Now that most big game hunters have changed, many reluctantly, from the lever action to the bolt-action rifle. Winchester designers have come up with a new leveraction model.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- The Senate Armed Services Committee is preparing an inquiry into the strength of United States air power in the light of an apparently significant rise in Russian capabilities.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The Democratic donkey issued its own racing form chart today. It was designed to prove the party must be regarded as the favorite over any Republican elephant in the 1956 Presidential sweepstakes.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The scheduled visit of top Soviet leaders to President Tito of Yugoslavia late this month has caused serious concern among State Department officials.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 18--W. Thacher Longstreth, a political amateur making his first bid for public office, won the three-sided battle for the Republican mayoralty nomination.
The New York City Center Light Opera Company will capits 1955 spring season of musical presentations tonight with "Finian's Rainbow" at the City Center. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today an investigation of transactions that put Malcolm McLean, a major figure in the trucking industry, into the intercoastal steamship business.
THE Society for the Protection of Gisele Mackenzie must meet in emergency session.
TRENTON, May 17--Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, seized the initiative today from the Republican-controlled State Legislature and opened an investigation of Democratic Hudson County.

PARIS, May 17--The student, of volcanoes knows that an eruption is generally preceded by certain standard symptoms. There are subterranean rumblings and changes in the flow of springs. The surface of the earth remains quiescent but the volcanologist is aware of a deep stirring.
Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, the Soviet Minister of Defense, has made a public bid to President Tito for restoration of Soviet-Yugoslav friendship.
Having developed an effective and time-tested program for economic expansion, Puerto Rico is aiming at more rapid progress, the Sales Executives Club of New York was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) --Alex Kellner, a sore-arm lefthander most of last season, pitched an eight-hit shutout and drove in the run tonight in leading the Kansas City Athletics to a 1-0 victory over the Washington Senators.
Whitey Ford, back in the sharp form he showed at the start of the season, pitched the Yankes to a 1-0 victory over the White Sox last night at the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 17--One by one the members of President Eisenhower's Cabinet have come under sharp political attack, the latest being the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The prospect of a dramatic decrease in hospitalized mental cases through the use of two drugs was presented to Congress today.

The 7,000 member stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association were urged yesterday by its president to support the summer promotion campaign of the Bureau, of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17-- Owen J. Roberts, a former associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, died today at the age of 80.

Plans to extend the international interchange agreements of the David D. Doniger Company, producer of McGregor sportswear, were announced yesterday. The company intends to sign licensing agreements with Asian concerns.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The Controller of the Currency said today that recent big bank mergers had increased rather than reduced competition.

PRETTY soon, now, the last block of small houses on Park Avenue below Ninetysixth Street, with little specialty shops downstairs and apartments above, will go to dust under wreckers' battering, and George Engler's thirty-story office building will soar from the ruin.
The city's teachers rejected yesterday a salary increase plan proposed by Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- Secretary of State Dulles' report on his trip to Europe concerned momentous issues, but had the air of an informal, chatty discussion.

The Health Department named 115 public and nineteen private schools yesterday in which polio vaccine injections will begin tomorrow. Health officers worked on plans to use available doctors, nurses and volunteers for probably sixteen more schools.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The United States officially invited ten Soviet agricultural specialists today for a month's visit to Iowa and other farming states in July and August.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A four-paragraph article published in The New York Times of April 28 entitled "'Found Money' for City," in addition to indicating a fiscal technique which may be of value, serves also to point up a problem, which has disturbed city and state taxpayers for some time.
BIRMINGHAM, England, May 17--This "city of a thousand trades" is taking the parliamentary election campaign calmly.

Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that "nothing can be further from the truth" than the idea that this city's schools were "literally crawling with juvenile delinquency."
Textron American, Inc., is negotiating for its largest nontextile merger, it was made known yesterday by Royal Little, chariman.
NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, May 18--Pakistani negotiators have come to India with a new proposal for settlement of the Kashmir controversy.
The wonderful lobster from icy waters off Maine and the coast of eastern Canada has put many a cook on his mettle and inspired him to turn out some luscious dishes.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) --Complaints of a severe shortage of aluminum and demands for Government counter-steps were voiced here today before a House Small Business Subcommittee headed by Representative Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois.

ROCKY MARCIANO is a gentle, kind, thoughtful and tender-hearted man. His innate decency and wholesomeness shine through in a dedicated glow. That's outside of the ring, however. Once he is inside the ropes the heavyweight champion is an uninhibited roughneck, a crude machine of destruction that goes out of control.
The Sunderland football club of the First Division in the English League and Nuremberg of Germany played a 1-all soccer tie at Ebbets Field last night.
BUENOS AIRES, May 17-- The provincial police of Cordoba have ordered Roman Catholic authorities not to hold any Benediction services in churches without obtaining police permits.

Hot, flaky cheese sticks are a versatile quick bread that may accompany fruit salad for a spring lunch, breakfast bacon and eggs or the firstcourse soup at dinner. The savory bread has other possibilities, too.

CHICAGO, May 17--Stockholders of the Chicago and North Western Railway today sat through a turbulent two-andone-half-hour annual meeting that brought forth suggestions: qThat the road's entire board of directors resign, qThat across-the-board salary cuts be made, and qThat "dead wood" employes be weeded out in favor of "young blood."
CAIRO, May 17--Gen. Nuri as-Said, Premier of Iraq, asserted today that public opinion in the Arab world was ready to sanction alliances with the major Western powers.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 17-- Poplar Bill, the 2-1 favorite, won the one-mile Hewlett Pace in 2:06 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Billy Myer drove the 3-year-old colt across the line a half length ahead of Greentree Cathy.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- President Eisenhower expressed tonight the cautiously optimistic view that a new day of peace might slowly be dawning for the world.
Two directors of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee resigned from the organizaion yesterday.

Jackson A. Edwards and others, in a purchase for investment, have acquired the two five-story store and apartment buildings at 1055-57 Third Avenue. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet on the east side of the avenue between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets.
CHICAGO, May 17--Interest on the Board of Trade centered today in May futures of wheat and soybeans. Trade in deferred grain deliveries was rather light.

The Companas Stable's 5-yearold mare Ros Clag, ridden by Willie Lester, won the High Fleet Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. It was an afternoon that will go down in the history of favorite players as Black Tuesday.
A sextant believed to be the first in the world capable of "shooting" sun or stars automatically was introduced yesterday.
The Board of Education is the sponsor of two essay contests a year, and that is quite enough, in the opinion of Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh will be reappointed for a full ten-year term on May 31, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

Following is a list of the 134 schools thus far designated out of 150 public and private schools in the city where free inoculations will take place tomorrow. The injections will be given tinder a Health Department program with vaccine from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis:

OYSTER BAY COVE, L. I., May 17--After having arranged for his own funeral, an interior decorator whose son is in jail on rape charges committed suicide here today. He was found dead of carbon monoxide fumes in his garage this morning.

LONDON, May 17--The Conservative party instilled new life into the election campaign tonight. Prime Minister Eden ana his top ministers were cross-questioned by a panel of editors on a nation-wide television program.
The House of Representatives debate last week on next year's military appropriation bill was neither enlightening nor distinguished.
A new fifteen-member Intergroup Relations Commission would be set up under a local law unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council.

The chairman of a large British tin-smelting organization has charged that there were "glaring inaccuracies" in a report prepared by a Senate subcommittee investigating the advisability of extending operation of the Government-owned Texas City tin smelter.
An organization of 128 business, civic and taxpayer groups yesterday denounced Mayor Wagner's proposals for increases in real estate, gross business and financial taxes.
"Entertainment," WABC-TV's two-and-a-half-hour daytime variety show, will be cut to a halfhour during the summer months. Tom Poston, master of ceremonies, will not appear on the new version.
The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries is circulating among labor and management a draft of a measure to be known as the Maritime Labor Stabilization Act.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 17--Scotland, with its 3,500,000 voters, seems remarkably free of election fever. The Scots, proud of their sober traditions, are calm as the election of May 26 draws near.

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 7.500 head: market active, 25 cents to 50 cents higher on butchers: mostly 50 cents higher on weights under 230 pounds: sows 25 cents to mostly 50

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 17--The main committee of the West Indian Conference approved today a statement calling on the United States, Britain, France and the Netherlands to revise the Caribbean Commission agreement.
LONDON, May 17--The apple of Britain's "fistic" eye, Don Cockell, has reinforced the old maxim here that there is no victory like a gallant defeat.

A seventeen-story, block-long building is to be erected on Riverside Drive between 119th and 120th Streets as a united church center for Protestant and Orthodox denominations. It will house the headquarters of the National Council of Churches of Christ in America and a number of its thirty member communions, their boards and agencies.
NEWARK, May 17--A union leader was threatened with deportation here today as he and four other union officials refused to say if they were or had been Communists.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 17 (AP)--Former President Truman said today the United States must help keep the United Nations going or face the prospect of a third world war "ten times more destructive than World War II."
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 17--A Dutchess County housewife was convicted tonight of refusing to yield a telephone party line so a neighbor could report a fire.
Many dinners will be given at the Spring Party for the benefit of Boys Harbor in East Hampton, L. I., which will be held on the night of June 1 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17-- Jesse W. Tapp, a 55 - year - old agricultural economist, was elected chairman of the board of the Bank of America today.

Following is the text of the broadcast dialogue between Secretary of State Dulles and President Eisenhower in which Mr. Dulles reported to the nation last night on his recent trip to Europe, as transcribed by The New York Times: PRESIDENT EISENHOWER --Foster, it's good to have you here to tell us something of the significant events that took place during your recent visit to Europe.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 17--King Baudouin of the Belgians declared today that the welfare of both the white and black races in the Belgian Congo had been a key factor in this colony's development.
A size 44 dress is the bestselling women's size at Lane Bryant. That store chain will tell you that one out of three American women wears a size 18 or over.
JERUSALEM, May 17--Two discoveries by an Israeli scientist were announced today with an accompanying prophecy that they would lead to economic production of steam power from the sun.

LONDON, May 17-- Apart from steel issues, which were as much as 2 shillings 6 pence (35 cents) lower on profit taking, industrials generally closed firm on the stock market here today. Engineering, motor and store issues finished with gains of fractions and increased buying of shipping issues on the strength of an improvement in freight rates lifted prices as much as two shillings (30 cents).

Federal Reserve Bank observers are on the whole pretty well satisfied with the show of strength which the economy is putting on. As the calendar approaches the third quarter, the nation's business is held likely to level off at a high rate of activity, with the further probability that the fall will come through with its usual upward spurt.

Adlai E. Stevenson returned to New York yesterday from a four-week tour of Africa. Despite reports to the contrary, he insisted he was still undecided about seeking the Democratic nomination for President again next year.

THE moderns, Europeans and Americans, painters and sculptors, are in force this week in a number of important group exhibitions. That at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, comprises work by the "old masters," Matisse, Picasso, Leger, Braque and Derain, along with several whose reputations have been made during the last decade--Riopelle, MacIver, Reg Butler and Marini.

WHEN the cawing of the crows awakened me I opened my eyes and looked out the window into a mass of dogwood blossoms. There was a fragrance of lilacs in the bedroom. The sun was shining brightly. It was going to be a fine day for almost anything, for gardening, for admiring the lovely look of the world in May, or for writing a column for this space.

BONN, Germany May 17-- United States military assistance to West Germany will be on the "same pattern" as that now given to other members of the Atlantic Alliance, the United States Embassy here said today.

It's the little extras--toys, play equipment, summer vacations-- that brighten life for the fiftyfive boys and girls at the Divine Providence Temporary Shelter for children at 225 East Fortyfifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The White House announced today plans by President Eisenhower for a six-day trip to New England in late June. The program includes a week-end of fly fishing for trout and landlocked salmon.

A new chief executive officer and a new board of directors were installed yesterday in the National Department Stores Corporation. Frank L. Kellogg, 38year-old former vice president of John Wanamaker New York, was elected board chairman and chief executive officer.
When does regulation become strangulation? For years that has been a prime question agitating the transportation industry.

QUEMOY ISLAND, China, May 17--According to Chinese Nationalist commanders here, only absolute command of the air will allow the Communists to conquer this fortress island less than five miles off the mainland.

LOS ANGELES, May 16-- Failure to make productive use of leisure time is one of the important early signs of dangerous development in children, Dr. Helmut Otto Lechler, German psychiatrist and child guidance expert, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) --The United States has successfully exploded a small atomic underwater device in the Eastern Pacific, it was disclosed today.

Stockholders of ContinentalDiamond Fibre Company agreed to sell most of its assets to the Budd Company at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del. The sale will take effect at the close of business June 30, and Continental's name then will be changed to Haveg Industries.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox, embarrassed by eleven straight losses to Cleveland last season, ended the Tribe's mastery in Fenway Park today. The Red Sox blasted the American League leaders for a 10-3 victory.
ST. LOUIS, May 17 -- "The Dodgers can be beaten," said Manager Eddie Stanky today. Tonight, proving their pilot is a good prophet, the Cardinals proceeded to down the Brooks, 3--0.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 17 --A school of theology may soon be constructed on the grounds of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here, it was disclosed today by Bishop James P. DeWolfe of the diocese of Long Island.
ALBANY, May 17 -- However safe Salk vaccine is, a number of New York State children who receive it -- probably more than 100 -- will get paralytic poliomyelitis this summer.
Sixty per cent of the waterborne dry cargoes that move in United States foreign commerce are carried by tramp ships, and foreign tonnage now gets more than 80 per cent of this business.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday that clearing the streets of undesirables required modern legislation.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17-- A calm and poised Rocky Marciano outlined his future boxing plans today, under the supervision of Manager Al Weill. Showing no signs that he had been in a nine-round fight the night before, the world heavyweight champion from Brockton, Mass., declared that he was willing to give Don Cockell a return bout.

The New York State Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Constitution yesterday announced its opposition to the Bricker Amendment. The committee includes constitutional lawyers of both the Democratic and Republican parties.

A 25-year-old Queens auxiliary policeman who allegedly set at least fifteen minor fires in New York during the last eight years was sent to Kings County Hospital yesterday for psychiatric observation.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 3 to 16 points yesterday.
CAIRO, May 18 -- Egypt is unlikely to return to partisan parliamentary democracy within the predictable future, Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser said today.
Everything is growing too fast this spring. It is an abnormal year. Usually, along toward the second half of May, everything is straining at its seams a little, but straining without doing damage.
EAST LANSING, Mich., May 18 -- Community-minded citizens were told today that they should relieve the police of the load of preventive activities in the field of juvenile delinquency.

The city administration's "social-mindedness" in dealing with juvenile delinquency was acclaimed yesterday by Dr. Kenneth D. Johnson, dean of the New York School of Social Work at Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A formula for harnessing the United States' international trade position to the cause of world peace was enunciated by President Eisenhower today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Mayor Wagner of New York disclosed today that his city would undergo a hypothetical attack with a hydrogen bomb equal in power to 5,000,000 tons of TNT as its part of the nation-wide civil defense tests next month.
CHICAGO, May 18 (UP) -- Hal Jeffcoat, a relief pitcher, won one game and saved another for the Chicago Cubs today in a double victory over the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 2 and 7 -- 5.
The Twenty-third Annual Flower Mart of the Outdoor Clpnllness Association will be held on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral on June 7, from 9 A. M. to 5 P. M. '
VIENNA, May 18 -- The People's party will suggest an Austrian Parliamentary appeal to th efour occupation powers to ratify the Austrian state treaty before the summer holidays.

Everyone sits up and takes notice of such spectacular developments as the first introduction of "instant-use" products, frozen specialties and aerosol dispensers. But day-to-day shifts in population, consumer income and consumer buying habits, for instance, often go unnoticed because they are gradual.

Sam Levene, who has been playing a rich merchant of Yonkers in the London production of Thornton Wilder's "The Matchmaker," will return to the Broadway stage next fall as a harassed minor league baseball manager.
BANBURY, England, May 18 -- The weather is going to play an important part in deciding who gets the parliamentary seat for Banbury.
Coffee futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, following news that Brazil had abandoned the export price minimum.
LOS ANGELES, May 18 -- The Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach have the lowest labor productivity record in this country, Clarence G. Morse said today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Former Attorney General J. Howard McGrath testified at a Federal Communications Commission hearing today that a Toledo, Ohio, resident had told him in April, 1954, that he had been offered $1,000 if he would testify against Edward Lamb, publisher-broadcaster.

NOTTINGHAM, England, May 18 -- The Conservatives think they will win two parliamentary seats, possibly three, from the Labor party in the East Midlands in the May 26 election. They also believe they will hold all the seats they won in 1951.
ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- Tonight the Dodgers gave away a game to the Cardinals in the first two innings. They couldn't quite get it back in the ninth, although they made a noble effort.

The hidden virtues of a fabric sometimes are overlooked because of its more evident decorative appeal. In fabrics, the homemaker has one of the easiest methods of home improvement available, says the Celanese Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Senate-House conferees of the reciprocal trade bill indicated today they would probably agree on a compromise measure by tomorrow or Friday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Eisenhower renewed today a campaign pledge that his Administration "will never wreck" the Tennessee Valley Authority.

One more attempt to settle the dispute between India and Pakistan over Kashmir has ended in failure. The discussions between the Prime Ministers and their staffs that started last Saturday and were concluded yesterday were "cordial and full," according to the final communique.
TRENTON, May 18 -- Commuters told an amazed Public Utilities Commission here today that a requested commutation rate increase was only fair, considering how costs had been rising.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 18 -- The Junior Class Prom Committee of Manhasset High School has scored a brilliant coup in arranging for lavish floral decorations at its dance on May 27. The teen-age project has been personally commended by the Governors of twelve states.

Both the A. F. L and C. I. O have now adopted specific programs to deal with the shocking abuses in union welfare fund administration now all too familiar. The federations have met this challenge to clean house with specific recommendations for action which do them great credit.

ALMA-ATA, U. S. S. R., May 1 -- There probably never was a better day than today for a foreigner to see the population of Alma-Ata, capital of Kazakhstan, the second largest republic in the Soviet Union.

SOMEWHERE IN FORMOSA, May 18 -- United States Sabre Jet pilots are participating in "a clasroom of the air" over the Formosa Strait. They are becoming familiar with a region where some day they may have to fire in anger.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Manhattan Democrat, said today he hoped the slaying of Gene Symonds, United Press reporter in Singapore would "shock us out of our smug complacency'' about the Far East.

More than a month has passed since Mayor Wagner asked the Board of Health to make its third study of the wisdom of fluoridating New York City's water supply. The study is under way, and we are told that it may require some weeks more to complete what we hope will be the study to end all studies of this subject.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18 -- The decision of the Subcommittee on Disarmament to recess its session in London and meet here next month was regarded as a hopeful indication that some progress had been made.
LONDON, May 18 -- Aneurin Bevan demanded today that Britain seek a united, neutral and disarmed Germany at the coming four-power conference. His stand struck a new note in the election campaign.
Isaac Ezagui, suspended member of the Police Department narcotics squad, was found guilty of perjury in the first degree last night in Kings County Felony Court.
NEWCASTLE, Australia, May 18 -- Four United States Thunderjet fighter-bombers set a non-stop record for single-engine jets of 4,840 miles from Japan to Australia today.
OTTAWA, May 18 (AP) -- Dyed ducks will be flapping along Canadian flyways this year.

CAMBRIDGE, England, May 18 -- Prof. J. Bartlet Brebner of Columbia University said today he had detected signs of new intellectual freedom in the Soviet Union. Professor Brebner, a historian, has just returned from a visit to the Soviet capital as a guest of Moscow University.

The American Library in Paris and the Frefich Student I Fund will benefit from the Oct. 26 performance of "Le iBourgeois Gentilhomme," a comedy ballet to be given by the [French National Theatre, the Comdie Franaise, at the Broadway Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Justice Department filed today its fourth anti-trust action in less than a week against American Linen Supply Company of Chicago, described as the nation's largest manufacturer of paper-towel dispensing cabinets.

One of the largest commercial leasing transactions in midtown Manhattan since the end of World War II was announced yesterday when the 1VL Vr. Kellogg Company, engineers and contractors, took seven floors in the building rising at 711 Third Avenue, at Forty-fourth Street.
New York Harbor should have an active and far reaching safety program for its waterfront workers, Angela R. Parisi, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, said. yesterday.

Edwards to a mothers' group at the Eastern Parkway Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, where Miss Edwards is in charge.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 18 (UP) -- Barbara Romack, 22-year-old United States women's amateur golf champion, reached the final of the women's British open amateur tournament today. She will meet Mrs. George Valentine of Scotland for the title in a 36-hole match tomorrow.
PITTSBURGH, May 18 (AP) -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk declared today cases of polio reported after injection of anti-polio vaccine were "clearly coincidental."

CHICAGO, May. 18 -- The Illinois Central Railroad expects to spend $40,000,000 in the next three years to complete Dieselization by 1958, Wayne A. Johnston, president, said today at the shareholders meeting.

Announcement of the projected visit of the highest Soviet leaders to Belgrade later this month has understandably aroused misgivings among many in Western Europe and here. WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Eisenhower made it plain today he had no anxiety that the Soviet Union had seized or would seize general command of the air.

BONN, Germany, May 18 (AP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer called home his'ambassadors to Washington, London and Paris tonight for urgent consultation on big power political moves. Bonn's new envoy to France had arrived in Paris only this morning.
Marriages, they say, are made in heaven. That may apply to humans, but it doesn't hold true for busines mergers. Compelling economic reasons lie behind the present wave of corporate amalgamations.

LONDON, May 18 (Reuters) -- Britain's Conservative Government and union groups supporting the Opposition Labor party made strong bids today to avert a threatened dock strike. The walkout is scheduled for Monday, three days before the country's general election.
Between mid-April and mid-May the aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell 114,668 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday.

ANACONDA, Mont., May 18 (AP) -- Cornelius F. Kelley, one of the captains of modern industry, announced his retirement as chairman of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company at a meeting of stockholders today.
General plans for four Federally aided public housing projects for 4,000 low-income families were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

More rhubarb is received in New York during May than in any other month of the year. This seasonal vegetable, used like a fruit, abounds not only in markets at this season but also in suburban backyards. Locally it is as sure a sign of spring as baseball and jump ropes.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- Herb Score, Cleveland's ace rookie left-hander, shut out Boston on three hits today. The Indians battered the Red Sox for eleven runs in the fifth inning and a 19-0 victory.

LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- Wintry gales whistled across much of northern Europe today. They brought snow and ice and sent dozens of small ships hurrying to safety. Ice and snow drifts crippled road traffic in parts of northern England and Wales.

The New School for Social Research, long a respected and welcome member of the educational life of this city, is now to add to its usefulness. The expansion program will provide additional opportunities for thousands of men and women -- young and old -- who seek more learning.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 18 (AP) --A brief clash between a State Representative and a sergeant-at-arms has become a full-scale feud between the Missouri Senate and House.
JERUSALEM, Thursday, May 19 -- The Israeli army announced early today that it had attacked Egyptian positions in the Gaza strip and blown it up.

Greengrocers obligingly play into the hands of the good cook at this season, supplying her with the makings of some inviting salads. The list of abundantly available ingredients is long. It includes unctuous avocados, lively tasting radishes, proverbially cool cucumbers, crisp onions and sweet-acid oranges and grapefruit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Milton Berle will produce a motion picture based on the life of his mother. The late Mrs. Sandra Berle had been prominently identified with the comedian in his professional career. The picture will be titled "Sandra."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 18 -- Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks announced here today that the Anthony Wayne recreation site, a new $2,000,000, thirty-five-acre center, would be opened June 18.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson spoke out today on the "loyalty" of Democratic delegates to the party's 1956 national convention.

Jack Westrope had an extremely pleasant ride down Belmont Park's Widener chute yesterday. He had the mount on Claiborne Farm's Doubledogdare in the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes. She carried him to a six-length score.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 18 -- The accomplishments of Dutch industry and enterprise in the ten years since World War II went on display in a huge national exposition today.
Vincent Auriol, former president of France, proposed last night that the Big Four meet at San Francisco on the anniversary of the founding of the United Nations or soon thereafter.
SOMEBODY, maybe that old devil time himself, like that old devil moon, has played some tricks on "Finian's Rainbow," the third and last in the series of musical revivals at the City Center.

Nassau and Westchester Counties inoculated more than 15,000 children against polio yesterday with what appeared to be normal responses to the beginning of their vaccine programs. The city's Health Department distributed supplies for a start today in 151 schools with 30,000 pupils.

A new irrigation system, constacted at a cost of $40,000.000, will begin operation next month in Israel for use in the parched northern Negev.

TOKYO, May 18 -- An American industrialist warned today that only a massive program of atomic power development in Asia under the aegis of the free nations could prevent this part of the world from falling under the "economic and political tyranny" of communism.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- Scientists attending the world's first "atoms for peace" parley will be able to relax with music.

SONOMA, Calif., May 18 (AP) -- Tests show a vaccine made from live viruses -- and administered through milk shakes -- produces immunity to two of the three kinds of polio in fourteen to twenty-three days, it was reported here today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Eisenhower disclosed today that Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby might have to quit his Cabinet soon for personal reasons.

Another Broadway show seems headed for television. "3 for Tonight," now at the Plymouth Theatre, is expected to be presented over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Wednesday, June 22, from 10 to 11 P. M.

At this season New York's labor force is swelled by the arrival of 1955's crop of college graduates. The young women who come now to take the starting jobs in the city's businesses may in ten years be the junior executives hiring 1965's college girls.
Mayors and other officials of the leading cities began arriving here yesterday for the annual meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors that starts today.

NEW DELHI, India, May 18 -- The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan ended their talks on Kashmir today without agreement. However, some new ideas have been thrown into the hopper and there is a live desire to continue the negotiations.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- W. Thacher Longstreth, Republican, will oppose Richardson Dilworth, the Democratic nominee, in the mayoralty election here next fall.
CHICAGO, May 18 (UP) -- Most of the nation's parents have retained their faith in the Salk polio vaccine. They will allow their children to have further shots, a survey showed today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 18 (AP) -- Royal Little, chairman of Textron American, Inc., said today that the company would be earning at least $1,000,000 a month by next September if present business volume and profit margins continued.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the United States' exhibit at the United Nations' atoms-for-peace conference would be "something that no one can laugh off." He deprecated the idea that the conference, scheduled for Geneva in August, would become a contest between East and West.
A vertical lift bridge to Welfare Island from Vernon Boulevard and Thirty-sixth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, was officially opened yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren asserted today that increasing emphasis should be put on "enlightened systems of probation and parole" as a means of salvaging delinquents from lives of crime.
MILWAUKEE, May 18 -- Charlie Grimm's Braves suffered two jolts today.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Hog prices jumped sharply for the second straight session today, the top rising to $19.25. This was the highest price since Dec. 28, 1954, when the same figure was recorded.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- The president of the United States Savings and Loan League suggested today that commercial banks were harming their own interests by opposing mutual savings institutions.

Schlesinger Jr.'s fine book, "The Age of Jackson," you will be interested in Mr. Ward's contrasting and yet complementary exploration of Jackson's emergence through ritual and romance.

A drop of 3,109,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 171,134,000 barrels, compared with 174,243,000 a week earlier and 175,750,000 a year ago.
BALTIMORE, May 18 (UP) -- Al Kaline dissolved a 3-all tie with a tenth inning single today that was the key blow in the Detroit Tigers' 6-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 18 -- Latin America appeared today to be in the first stage of a coffee price war. The battle should benefit the North American housewife's budget, but it will damage all the Latin countries involved.
Plans to fight the city's business and financial business taxes as they apply to food were announced yesterday by the Coordinating Committee of the Food Industries.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Eisenhower defended post exchanges and commissaries as necessary privileges for the armed forces.

When the spotlight flashed on him during his reign as Mr. Shortstop for the Cardinals, it was only a flash and he had no chance to feel uncomfortable. But he doesn't like to do his thinking in public. It embarrasses him.

BUENOS AIRES, May 18 (Reuters) -- All sixteen leaders of the Roman Catholic lay organization, Catholic Action, who were arrested on May 7 following Catholic demonstrations here, have been released without charges.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The Navy announced today that its second atomic-powered submarine, the Seawolf, would be launched at Groton, Conn., in July.
