Plans for a large apartment building at Park Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street adjoining the Ritz Towers, were announced yesterday by Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder.
LONDON, May 18 -- Prices rose further today as expectations strengthened that a Conservative Government would be re-elected next week.
Alvin Shapiro has been named Washington representative of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

BONN, Germany, May 18 (Reuters) -- A lawyer for former Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, Hitler's successor as Fuehrer at the end of World War II, has asked the West German Government to intervene for his release from prison.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 18 -- The highway that is haunting men from one end of Connecticut to the other will soon emerge out of the mist, ten months late.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 18 -- Queen Juliana began consultations with parliamentary and political leaders late today in an effort to form a new Dutch Government.
MIAMI, Fla., May 18 -- The Southern Baptist Convention opened today with speakers emphasizing the call to a world ministry that would curb atheistic communism.
The City Housing Authority is distributing loyalty oath forms to its 30,000 families in twenty-eight Federally aided housing projects here.

Brenda de Banzie, introduced to American screen audiences in "Hobson's Choice" and most recently seen in "The Purple Plain," has been signed by Alfred Hitchcock for a featured role in his remake of "The Man Who Knew Too Much."

I The best application of modem dentistry can now enable people to have their natural teeth fca, a lifetime, it was emphasized here yesterday at the close of the eighty-seventh annual meetling of the New York State Denital Society.
Television, though essentially a medium of compromise," is improving, in the opinion of Jack Gould, radio and television critic of The New York Times.
ATLANTIC CITY, lVfay 18--Reversals suffered by Western churches in the Far East may be "the judgment of God" upon their failures, according to a leading churchman.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- By a one-vote margin, the Senate Agriculture committee dealt a setback today to forces seeking a showdown on a House-passed bill to restore rigid farm price supports.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -President Eisenhower outlined today his formula for negotiating with the Russians: Speak from strength, proceed cautiously, reject appeasement and don't expect too much.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today granted station WMAL-TV in this city authority to set up an experimental "pay-as-you-see" television service beginning May 25. The special authority exxpires June 25.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- The chief planner for the. United Nations atoms -for-peace parley reported today that "considerable new material" had been spotted in the scientific papers offered by Soviet and Western scientists.

The State of North Carolina announced yesterday plans for the sale of $11,000,000 of bonds to finance construction of mental institutions. Bids of banking syndicates will be received on June 1. The bonds will be dated April 1, 1955 and will come serially on each April 1 from 1957 to 1975.

Merger of the Standard Factors Corporation and Nathan Straus-Duparquet, Inc., has been approved by directors of the two companies, it was announced yesterday. Theodore H. Silbert, president of Standard Factors, and Samuel R. Sperans, president of Straus-Duparquet, said the new concern would bear the former name.
Sixty years of tailoring men's fashions has taught William P. Goldman Bros., that men with the most colorful careers often prefer quiet suits.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout:

JAMES RESTON of The New York Times -- Sir, you told us two weeks ago, I believe, that you were proceeding, or the Government was proceeding, with direct conversations with Communist China about the situation in the Formosa Straits.

The Waterfront Commission yesterday sought to prove racketeer control of dock workers at the Leonardo, N. J., Naval Base through testimony of Mrs. Anna Genovese, estranged wife of gangster Vito Genovese. The commission is investigating kickbackc by longshoremen who worked at the Navy depot.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The release of military information particularly intelligence information about a potential enemy, for service advantage is "old hat" to Washington.

You recently published a letter from the general counsel of the Association of Casualty Companies taking exception to your editorial of April 26 on "The Uninsured 10 Per Cent." It is a tragic fact that at least 10 per cent of those driving cars and causing accidents are financially irresponsible.
The directors of the Brown Company, pulp and paper manufacturer with plants at Berlin and Gorham, N. H., voted yesterday to redeem the company's 140,293 shares of $5 convertible preference stock.
LONDON, May 18 -- The disarmament talks that have been held here for twelve weeks were suspended today. They probably will be resumed in New York June 1.

The roads of Manhattan are paved with good intentions. But sometimes repairs designed to keep them in prime condition produce chaotic traffic jams. A crew from the Borough President's office demonstrated this convincingly yesterday.

The appointment of Andrew J. Seidler as executive director of the New York City Council for the Development and Promotion of the Port of New York was announced yesterday by Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.
MOSCOW, May 18 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today he and Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin were going to Belgrade for negotiations with President Tito "with open hearts and pure souls."
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Following are the main points made by President Eisenhower at his news conference today:

HANOVER, N. H., May 18 -- Yale shut out Dartmouth, 2 -- 0, today and tied Harvard for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. The Elis and the Crimson, unbeaten in circuit competition with eight victories apiece, will meet in the title-deciding game at Cambridge on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- A Navy clothing inspector testified today that a Connecticut raincoat maker had paid him $50 a week for three months in 1952 while he was rejecting some of the coats.
Pearl Lang's "Rites" had its only performance in the season of "American Dance" sponsored by the B. de Rothschild Foundation at the ANTA Theatre last night.

Mickey Mantle clouted a 400-foot grand-slam homer in the seventh inning at the Stadium yesterday. This big blow nailed down an 11-6 triumph over the White Sox for the Yankees. The victory elevated the Bombers to second place, displacing the Chicagoans.
Plans of two child agencies for,establishing office centers on the East Side were disclosed yesterday when sales of private dwellings in the area were reported.

DETROIT, May 18 (AP) -- The former world featherweight champion, Willie Pep, capitalized on fifteen years' ring experience tonight by unanimously outpointing Gil Cadilli of Los Angeles in a ten-round nationally televised fight at the Olympia. Pep, of Hartford, Conn., weighed 128 3/4 pounds, Cadilli 126 1/2.

TORONTO, May 18 -- In an apparent goodwill gesture to counter Canadian-American friction on the trade front, the United States is sending a seven-man team of experts to the Canadian International Trade Fair opening May 30.
A hearing to determine the disposition of the $100,000 estate of Dr. and Mrs. William Fraden was held yesterday in Bronx Surrogate's Court.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (UP) -- A boxing hanger-on with a criminal record visited Harold Johnson's dressing room before his bout with Julio Mederos on May 6, the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission was told today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -The Government assigned a committee today to write a code of conduct for United States military personnel who might be captured and tortured by an enemy.

With the momentous events of the last two weeks out of the way, the attention of the world now turns to the next big steps in prospect -- the projected Big Power conference at top levels and any collateral negotiations with the Chinese Communists.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The National Military Reserve plan became snarled in the House of Representatives today

OTTAWA, May 18 -- Recent Soviet diplomatic moves justify satisfaction and some optimism but the West should proceed with caution. Lester B. Pearson. Secretary of State for External Affairs. said today upon his return from Paris.
ANOTHER two weeks should find the varmint shooters stalking the grassy pastures in search of woodchucks. Chucks seem to be as plentiful as ever this year.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- General of the Army George C. Marshall, former Secretary of State, has joined the Atlantic Union movement.

A letter from the late Dr. Albert Einstein amplifying his opposition to the methods of Congressional investigating committees was made public yesterday by Mrs. Rose Russell, legislative representative of the Teachers Union.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The House Commerce Committee approved today a proposal to give natural gas consumers some protection against unwarranted price increases.

The earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation in 1955 should make a "creditable showing" as compared with the $74,500,000 reported for last year, P. C. Spencer, president, told stockholders at their meeting held here yesterday.

Now that the Army has permitted public inspection of one of its Nike sites near Washington perhaps it will do the same in other areas, such as New York, protected by this guided-missile defensive weapon against invading enemy aircraft.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A management man in the automobile industry said today the guaranteed annual wage demand was not popular even in the labor movement.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- A preliminary agreement for the sale of Mandel Brothers, Inc., 100-year-old State Street department store company, to a group of Eastern investors was announced tonight by Leon Mandel, chairman.

"The Sea Wolves," an account by Wolfgang Frank of Germany's U-boats at war, will be published June 30 by Rinehart. The author was an officer on the staff of Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz. He has based his book on material taken from the secret files of the German High Command.

With no notable expansion in volume to give it life, the market checked its downswing yesterday and rebounded sharply. Volume rose to 2,010,000 shares, topping Tuesday's figure of 1,900,000 only because of activity in aircraft issues in the final thirty minutes.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- A squabble over minimum wage proposals broke into the open today when the Labor Department refused to recommend that specific new groups of workers be included in the minimum wage law.
r The city's academic high] schools are in serious plight,I their principals warned yes-I terday.

The New York County Republican chairman urged last night the addition of 1,000 specially trained foot patrolmen to curb juvenile delinquency. Thomas J. Curran told a special meeting of the Republican County Committee that the best way to fight crime and delinquency was to prevent it.

NEWARK, May 18 -- Two former union officials told a Congressional hearing today how they joined the Communist party in 1946 to obtain information they used later to get Communists voted from power in their local.

A more practical and positive approach is being taken in waterfront labor relations, aimed at "solutions instead of derogations," Alexander P. Chopin, acting chairman of the New York Shipping Association, asserted last night.
ROME, May 18 -- Italy will stay with the West and if necessary fight at its side, Premier Mario Scelba declared today.

MOSCOW, May 18 (AP) -- Strong orders went out today to Soviet farmers to end an "unbearable" delay in the planting of corn. The farmers were told to get their assigned quotas of the grain in the gorund within the next three to five days.
GENEVA, May 18 -- The United States has prepared a demonstration of the production and utilization of nuclear energy for the United Nations' atomic energy conference here in August.

The New York Times deserves congratulations for its editorial of May 17, entitled "Surpluses for the Hungry." You rightly point out that there are millions of persons who go to bed hungry every night, and there are millions of children who will regard one good meal in the course of the week as a combination of Christmas and Thanksgiving.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. said today that he was preparing legislation to encourage investment in middle-income housing.

Events today: Claire Coci, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; New School Recorder Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Ascension Day Festival Service, Church of the Ascension, 8:15.

Events tonight, all at 8:30: Program of one-act operas, "What Men Live By," "Bad Boys in School" and "The Farmer and the Fairy," Hunter College; Queens College Orchestra and Choral Society, Jamaica High School Auditorium, and Queens Symphony Orchestra, Forest Hills High School.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower's proposal to speed completion of the Inter-American Highway ran into a legislative cross-current today. One committee in the House of Representatives approved it and another refused to vote the money.
NEWARK, May 19 -- Charges of Communist infiltration into the New Jersey school systems were aired today, the fourth of a Congressional hearing on subversive activities in the Newark area.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -Greatly improved techniques for children suffering from deafness, loss of limbs and epilepsy were reported to Congress today.
DALLAS, Tex., May 19 (AP) -- Five persons were dead and more than 2,000 homeless tonight as floods swept parts of four states.

CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- A new 1955 peak price of $19.50 for hogs went to about 100 head today in an otherwise mixed trade. Butchers of quality were steady to strong, but lower grades were 25 cents lower and sows registered weak to 50 cents less.

A twelve-story showroom building at 389 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-sixth Street, has been purchased by a manufacturer of novelty jewelry from the Gustave and Sarah Roth Foundation and the Group Realty Corporation.

Nearly three-fourths of the children for whom their parents had asked polio vaccine inoculations in New York City appeared for injections yesterday. The showing in 141 schools was termed "excellent" by Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner.

A collection of the short stories of Isaac Babel, one of the foremost modern Russian writers, will be issued June 24 by Criterion Books, entitled "Collected Stories." The volume will contain "Red Cavalry" and "Tales of Odessa," as well as many hitherto untranslated stories.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company and its corrugated-box division, the Hinde Dauch Paper Company, increased sales and earnings in the six months ended last April 30 over the corresponding period a year ago.

GREENOCK, Scotland, May 19 -- American overseas investment and American advertising technique are playing an indirect part in the general election campaign now in full swing in this busy river port, one of Scotland's greatest.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson endorsed today the American-Korean Foundation's campaign to rebuild and broaden the 4-H Club movement in South Korea.
Rising newspaper circulation and increased consumer-goods advertising were credited yesterday with bringing about new records in production and consumption of newsprint.
BERLIN, May 19 (AP) -- The East German Government was asked today to institute "severe punishment" for citizens found with Western comics in their possession.

Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the board of W. R. Grace Co., has been elected a public representative on the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. He succeeds Clarence Francis, former chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, who had been a public governor since 1952.
The Columbia Broadcasting System took a strong stand yesterday against subscription television. It also announced big plans for new programs that the public can see free.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department today moved in two directions to ease an expected shortage in grain storage facilities when this year's wheat crop is harvested.

THIS will be a race for the genuine "lovers of the breed" rather than for those refugees from indigency, the hoss players. It's the fifty-eighth running of the International Steeplechase at Belmont tomorrow. The aristocrats of the turf love any test over the jumps but the peasants view such proceedings with jaundiced eye.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 19 -A prelude program to the Bethlehem Bach Choir's forty-eighth festival was presented this evening in Packer Memorial Chapel on the Lehigh University Campus.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 -Brazilian official sources continued today to deny that there was any danger of a coffee price war.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 (AP) -- A virtual shutdown of major trucking operations in eleven Western States, affecting 100,000 workers, was ordered by employers tonight after American Federation of Labor teamsters struck three leading carriers.
The noted Peabody Home, 1000 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, is celebrating the tenth anniversary of a new achievement this year. This is a project called non-resident aid.

PARIS, May 19 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra under the direction of Eugene Ormandy, performed in Paris tonight for the first time. Its gala concert at the Paris Opera was arranged as part of the American "Salute to France," a tribute in the form of an artistic festival.
The city's teachers who are negotiating with Mayor Wagner for a salary increase sent new proposals to City Hall yesterday.

A former longshoremen's union official took refuge in the Fifth Amendment yesterday at the Waterfront Commission hearing into kickbacks at the Leonardo Naval Base in Earle, N. J. He refused to answer questions about the finances of his local.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- United States corporations offered more new common stock for sale in the first quarter of this year than in any comparable period since 1929, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Changes that will do good for Montgomery Ward Co. will be made, but no changes will be made just for the sake of change, John A. Barr, Ward's new chairman and president, said today.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., May 19 -- The ninety-eighth Newark annual conference of the Methodist Church today called upon President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles to "humanize" the administration of the Refugee Relief Act.
PORTSMOUTH, England, May 19 (UP) -- The British Admiralty decreed today that sailors aboard Her Majesty's warships were entitled to keep cats as pets.
ALMA-ATA, U. S. S. R., May 2 -- To hear tell around Kazakhstan, some Soviet farmers are getting rich under the new order of agriculture instituted by the Communist party in 1953.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended on last Saturday were 11 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Archbishop Stepinac High captured the team title yesterday in the track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools A. A., Bronx-Manhattan and Westchester division.
Governor Harriman belittled the popularity of President Eisenhower last night.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 19 (AP) -- Top-seeded Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert gained the quarter-finals in the Wiesbaden international tennis tournament today, but the main applause was reserved for Sidney Schwartz of New York.
Lamb, that favorite meat of the good cooks of the Middle East, stars at butcher counters this week-end, the City Department of Markets reports.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower vetoed today an average 8.8 per cent pay increase for 500,000 postal workers. He said the rejected measure was "unfair" and too expensive.

TOKYO, May 19 (Reuters) -A top British business executive today told the International Chamber of Commerce that he thought there was little chance of any future "catastrophe" similar to the 1930-31 slump, but a French delegate predicted "one of the worst crises we have yet experienced."

Aluminum production is at a record high, and the Governmen has reduced its stockpiling by many thousands of tons. Yet manufacturers have been testifying all week in Washington that their businesses are threatened with shutdowns because of the aluminum shortage.

May 18, a deadline in Vietnam set at the Geneva conference, has passed. The French have retired from the Haiphong perimeter, last major outpost in the North. The Communists have retired from a coastal strip south of the Seventeenth Parallel where they have been in control for several years.
TOKYO, May 19 (AP) -- United States artillery practice on the slopes of Fujiyama, which touched off Japanese demonstrations last week, will resume May 25, the Army announced tonight.

VIENNA, May 19 -- West German labor joined today in a pledge of action with the free unions of seventy-four other countries to build up the military strength of the Western world against the Soviet Union.
The majority of the children who were inoculated with the Salk vaccine here yesterday took it calmly.
PITTSBURGH, May 19 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Aldo Icardi, former Army lieutenant, for having attempted to influence a court witness.

The Florida State Turnpike Commission announced yesterday plans for the sale of $74,000,000 of turnpike revenue bonds to finance construction of a 110-mile expressway connecting Fort Pierce and Hollywood. Thomas B. Manuel, chairman of the Commission, said that bids would be taken by the Authority on June 7 at its offices at Dania, Fla.
A son has the right to renounce an inheritance from his father, Surrogate William T. Collins ruled yesterday.

Many persons, perhaps, have thought of the rise in share prices in this country over the past year and a half as a localized American phenomenon. It is perhaps unfortunate that the most spectacular recent reminder that this was by no means the case should take the form of last week's news of the severe setback of prices on the Paris Bourse.

The chemical industry seems assured of continued rapid growth for at least five years -but probably at a slower rate than in the last five, when expansion was spurred by war shortages, the Korean conflict and unusual population increases.

BUENOS AIRES, May 19 -The Argentine Government signed a trade protocol with the Soviet Union today to cover this year's interchange of goods between the two countries. Although the protocol contained no statement of the over-all value of the trade expected, Foreign Minister Jeronimo Remorino estimated that it would amount to more than $100,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 757,333 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- The recent London disarmament talks resulted in agreement on "a few new points of great importance," Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today.
CHICAGO, May 19 -- Board of Trade activity today consisted largely of evening up contracts in May futures of grains and soybeans and of closing spreads involving the May futures.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Directors of the Quaker Oats Company have approved the company's purchase of the assets of Flako Products Corporation of New Brunswick, N. J., manufacturer of baking mixes. Donald B. Lourie, president, announced today.
ALBANY, May 19 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad today lost its bid to hold the line on state valuation of its right-of-way along Park Ave. in New York City.
Prince Regent, a 5-year-old Princequillo gelding, won the eighth running of the Belmont National Maiden Hurdle race at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, may attend the United Nations tenth anniversary meeting in San Francisco next month, the State Department said today.

It was an all Limon program at the ANTA Theatre last night in the season of "American Dance" presented by the B. de Rothschild Foundation. It also included the first presentation of the season of "The Moor's Pavane," which made it a doubly distinguished occasion.

URBANA, Ill., May 19 -- University of Illinois trustees voted today to permit nominees for President and Vice President of the United States to make political speeches on university property during the 1956 campaign.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 10 -- One hundred and fifty legislators gathered in the Taipei City Hall this morning for Nationalist China's experiment in democracy: a session of the Legislative Yuan.
PARIS, May 19 -- A showdown on European economic integration at a supranational level appears near.
MILWAUKEE, May 19 -- Jim Hearn today became the first National Leaguer to win six games this season.
Uncle Sam is due to take a more penetrating look at the tax-exempt status of charitable foundations from now on, tax lawyers agreed yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 (AP) -A University of Pittsburgh spokesman said today "that a certain statement attributed to Dr. Jonas E. Salk from a scientific talk he delivered yesterday evidently was misunderstood by some writers covering the meeting."

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Business mergers, while still well below the predepression levels of the late Nineteen Twenties, are running at three times the 1949 rate, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
ALBANY, May 19 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad bridge carrying passenger trains across the Hudson was damaged by fire today. It was put out of service for eight hours.
BONN, Germany, May 19 -- West German diplomatic representatives are to be instructed to oppose neutrality as the price of Germany's reunification.

GUATEMALA, May 19 (AP) -- Five men were jailed here last night on charges of plotting to upset the regime of President Carlos Castillo Armas. A sixth man sought political asylum in the embassy of El Salvador.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 19 -- The Government of South Vietnam wants a conference here with the United States, Britain and France at the foreign ministers' level.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Helioscope, owned by William Helis Jr., proved his class in the stakes field today by holding off the driving finish of Alfred Vanderbilt's Social Outcast for a halflength victory in the twenty-first Massachusetts Handicap. Helioscope raced the $54,100 mile-anda-quarter event in 2 minutes 1 second, a track record.
PARIS, May 19 -- The French Cabinet is sending heavy reinforcements to Algeria in an allout effort to quell the rebellion there.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -This year's high school graduates got word today from James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, that job prospects were good.

Tomorrow is Armed Forces Day, the high point of more than a week of tribute and attention to the nation's military men and women. In New York and around the country, Army installations, Navy ships and bases, Air Force bases and Marine Corps and Coast Guard installations are holding open house.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -Senate-House conferees approved today a proposal to protect the textile and chemical industries from any increased competition from Japan.
ALBANY, May 19 -- The New York State Education Department announced today 150 scholarships at Cornell University.
The State Supreme Court gave the cue here yesterday for burlesque shows to raise their curtains in New York again after almost two decades of darkness.

UNITED NATIONS N. Y., May 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold raised the possibility today that the Big Four foreign ministers might have "at least an informal contact" on East-West issues during the United Nations meeting in San Francisco June 20 to 26.

Apparently it takes absence and adversity to get Dodger fans excited about the Dodgers. The Brooks, all but ignored during their last all-conquering home stand at Ebbets Field, spent the last ten days touring the West. They lost five of nine games and arrived home yesterday with a three-game losing streak.

With more than half of their output going to grocery and drug stores, candy manufacturers must pay more attention to modern merchandising methods. They face fierce competition, not only from the products of others in their field but from other taste-appealing foods.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 -Responsible German bankers are prepared to invest a billion dollars in Brazil, it was reported here today.

The winners of the 1954 Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards are Alton L. Blakeslee, Associated Press science writer in New York; John Robert Coughlan, Life magazine staff writer, and Milton Silverman, science editor of The San Francisco Chronicle and free-lance writer.
DERBY, England, May 19 -Marcus Richard Kimball, 26year-old Conservative candidate for one of the two constituencies here, appears to have almost no chance of winning. But he won't admit it.

Despite increasing competition from synthetics, wool is still the ideal carpet fiber, Paul Jones of the Carpet Institute told members of the National Home Fashions League this week
At the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board, held in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, Langbourne W. Williams was elected chairman.
A woman whose third finger, left hand, is embellished with a wedding ring may one day feel inclined to keep her gloves on if the findings of a recent sociological study are proved generally true.
LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- A noted Presbyterian asked his church today to approve the ordination of women as fullfledged ministers of the Gospel.
ELMIRA, N. Y., May 19 (AP) -- Elmira College found the long-sought cornerstone of Cowles Hall by the use of a mine detector today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- After two years of domestic respectability, the food freezer was welcomed back to Capitol Hill today as the symbol of Government corruption.
LONDON, May 19 (Reuters) -- Poland today became the first Soviet-bloc state to ratify the eight-Nation Communist mutual security pact in Europe.

A young man accused of possessing a sub-machine gun in violation of the Sullivan Law won acquittal yesterday in Queens County Court. The prosecution's case had been undermined accidentally by a campaign against juvenile delinquency known as Operation Checkmate.

The first "permanent" licenses to do contract stevedoring work in the Port of New York have ben authorized by the Waterfront Commission. Samuel M. Lane, executive director of the bi-state agency, made the announcement yesterday.
TOKYO, Friday, May 20 (AP) -The International Chamber of Commerce was told yesterday that no nation had "a completely adequate highway system."

DAVENPORT, Iowa, May 19 (AP) -- An agreement with the Air Force to install the world's largest aluminum plate stretcher was announced today by the Aluminum Company of America for its big fabricating plant here. It will be a $10,000,000 installation.

Directors of United States Foreign Securities Corporation and United States International Securities Corporation announced yesterday that they had called special meetings of stockholders for June 30 to vote upon a merger. United States Foreign will be the surviving firm.

The vacant blockfront on the east side of Katonah Avenue, between East 234th and 235th Streets, in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx, has been purchased by a builder. According to HoulihanMartocci, brokers in the sale, the buyer plans to erect either a cooperative apartment house or one-family dwellings.

The city has made a wage offer to the 670 members of Local 373. Marine and Aviation Government Workers. C. I. O., who man the municipal ferryboats. John Power, the union's regional director said yesterday.
A seven-pound boy was born in an East Side garage last night.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- If elections were held now in South Vietnam, "without any question" the Communists would win, Wells Klein, director of the Saigon office of CARE, Inc., said today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -The Post Office Department announced today that it expected to move some 428,000,000 first-class, 3-cent letters by air on the West Coast alone by the end of this year.
Merger of existing telegraph and cable companies would improve service, William H. Harrison, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, May 19 (UP) -- Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., limping on an injured foot, lost her bid for the women's British open amateur golf championship today. She took a 7-and-6 walloping from Scotland's Jessie Valentine in their scheduled 36-hole final.

Last Friday it was recorded that "Janus" was uppermost in Margaret Sullavan's mind. Don't consider the matter unsettled any longer, because Miss Sullavan has been signed by Alfred appear in the comedy by Mrs. de Liagre Jr. to appear in the comedy by Mrs. Carolyn Green.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Morton Weinress, Chicago investment man, and five management nominees for directors of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company were elected for three-year board terms, election inspectors announced today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 19 -- High winds did not aid the scoring in the qualifying round of the annual Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today. No one in the field of 134 starters equaled par.
The use of whips to curb juvenile delinquents was likened yesterday to vigilante tactics.
MIAMI, Fla., May 19 -- A "Crusade for Christian Morality" to help spur the country to a broad "moral awakening" will be undertaken by Southern Baptists next fall and continued through next year.
Funds for a study of American foreign policy were included in grants made by the Rockefeller Foundation in the first quarter of 1955.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -A boom in church construction unequaled since the pioneer days was disclosed today at the American Baptist Convention.
Packard, last survivor of the old "Big Three Ps" -- Packard, Pierce and Peerless -- yesterday proudly issued its first production and sales figures for this year.
Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther warned yesterday against endangering the military position of the free world through a political compromise brought about by Soviet propaganda.

THIS week has brought a further White House experiment in television technique: the dialogue on Tuesday night between President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles. As a video producer, official Washington would appear to have a way to go.
Following is a list of the 151 public, parochial and private schools in the city, where free inoculations will be given today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Government asked the Supreme Court today to determine that the seaward boundary of Lousiana is three miles from its coastline.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- Andrei A. Fomin of the Soviet delegation recommended today to the Social Commission of the Economic and Social Council that it continue attempts to draft an international convention on freedom of information, "in view of the present slackening of world tensions."
BUENOS AIRES, May 19 -- Argentina's Chamber of Deputies voted, 121 to 12, tonight to eliminate Roman Catholicism as the nation's constitutional religion.
LONDON, May 19 -- Civil strife between rival docking unions confronted Britain tonight with the threat of a major waterfront strike for the second time in eight months.

Premier Mario Scelba said something obvious and natural on Wednesday when he told a meeting in Rome that Italy will stay with the West and if necessary fight by her side. This is a truism. Nevertheless, Signor Scelba was right to say what he did.

DEPENDING on the reference book consulted, one can learn that the "Nibelungenlied" is a Middle High German epic composed by a South German poet about 1160 or by an Austrian monk about 1200. Scholars differ whether it is mostly myth with a dash of historical truth or mostly history distorted by myth.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- The moral danger contained in motion pictures was criticized today by James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Archbishop of Los Angeles.
Three appointments to top commands in the Seventy-seventh Infantry Reserve Division in New York have been announced by Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman, division commander.
IT will be almost impossible for the trout fisherman to make a bad stream selection over the week-end, weather remaining constant. The salt water prospects also are extremely bright.

LAKEHURST, N. J., May 19 -- Two forest fires whipped through 5,000 acres of tinder-dry pitch pine in central Jersey tonight, destroying at least twelve houses. More than a thousand Lakehurst firemen, members of the state fire-fighting service, soldiers, sailors, civil defense volunteers and others battled the flames.
TOKYO, Friday, May 20 (AP) -Sweden's Ambassador to Moscow yesterday called on Premier Chou En-lai in Peiping, possibly to discuss the question of United States-Communist Chinese negotiations.
James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, told the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday that he did not know of any boycott against Vince Martinez, a Paterson welterweight.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- President Eisenhower tonight received an 8-month-old Virginia heifer from the capital's newspaper women -- right in the main ballroom of the Statler Hotel.

WHEN spring and summer suns burn ardently on city pavement and walkways, most townfolk think how delightful it would be to have green shade to soften glare. A group in Eighty-first Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, though, took the cool thought beyond the thinking stage.

The Transit Authority police force reached a record high of 754 yesterday with the graduation from the Police Academy of 220 patrolmen and five policewomen. Another sixty-five recruits are still in training. They will bring the force to 819 men and women.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A Senate subcommittee asserted today that the United States was so unprepared that "possibly millions of lives" might be unnecessarily lost in a hydrogen bomb attack.

BUENOS AIRES, May 19 (UP) -- When President Peron came to power in 1946, his Government granted the Roman Catholic schools vast subsidies and made teaching of religion in public schools mandatory. The Church in turn gave its support to President Peron.

Benjamin Coates, Philadelphia financier, has won his fight for control of W. J. Sloane. The annual report yesterday of the 112-year-old nation-wide quality furniture store chain revealed that eight new directors favoring Mr. Coates had been elected to replace seven who had resigned.

The twenty-six-story office building at 99 John Street has been sold by the Insurance Company of North America to the Great American Insurance Company. Completed about twenty years ago by the seller, the building contains 456,000 square feet of space.
The City Council bill proposing to strip Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley of some of his powers came in for both criticism and support yesterday.

Commissioner Sidney S. Sheiner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, announced at 12:35 A. M. today that "substantial agreement" had been reached between the Sperry Gyroscope Company and striking Local 450 of the C. I. O. International Union of Electrical Workers.
A radio transmitter and receiver that handles only the electrical signals and sounds of the ailing human heart was demonstrated by the Navy here last night.
St. John's University clinched the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference title yesterday. Coach Dusty DeStefano's Redmen whipped New York University, 11 -- 2, at Ohio field in the Bronx.
Any one who does not own a sample of Ligustrum vulgare is, at this time of year, fortunate. For Ligustrum vulgare is more than just an oleaceous shrub. It is a fast-growing thing.

KANSAS CITY, May 19 (AP) -Hard-hitting Henry Ransom blistered the Hillcrest Country Club course for a seven-under-par 65 to set the first-round pace in the $20,000 Kansas City Open golf tournament today.

New York City has had more than its share, perhaps, of the pleasure and honor of entertaining the United States Conference of Mayors. We are delighted to have them here again for their three-day meeting. The occasion is stimulating and constructive for New York as well as the delegates.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Administration's National Military Reserve plan was sidetracked and perhaps derailed in the House of Representatives today on the issue of racial segregation.
PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Harold Johnson told the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission today that he did not "throw" his May 6 nationally televised fight to Julio Mederos.

Loans to brokers and dealers by leading New York City banks on non-Government securities increased $55,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to an eleven-year high of $1,870,000,000, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A detailed report is being prepared for President Eisenhower on the technical and scientific problems that have held up the mass vaccination of school children with Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message vetoing the postal pay raise bill:
LONDON, May 19 -- Prices on the Stock Exchange continued to behave today as if a Conservative victory at the general election were assured.
JERUSALEM, May 19 (UP) -An Israeli archaeological expedition reported today the discovery of scores of skeletons from the second century in a cave near the Red Sea.
LONDON, May 19 -- A Soviet reply received here is in some degree favorable to the British proposal to extend the period when Vietnamese refugees can leave the Communist-held North.
LONDON, May 19 -- "You must see the Crazy Gang," London playgoers are likely to remark as an aftermath to discussions of art in the theatre. They say it warily.

Mayors of American cities were urged yesterday to consider new forms of income tax to help solve their financial problems. The suggestion was made by Dr. Luther Gulick, New York City Administrator, with the explanation that his proposal "reflects my own views and not necessarily those of Mayor Wagner's Administration or of the Government of the City of New York."

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- If Adlai E. Stevenson were not the Fowler of present-day American politicians (Fowler is-the Oxford authority on the usage of modern English words), it might be argued that he didn't realize the scope of the tolerance he expressed toward past and. potential Democratic party bolters when he got back to Chicago from Africa.

With preparations for the projected Big Power conference under way on both sides of the Iron Curtain, there remains one item of unfinished business that should be finished as quickly as possible, and that is ratification of the Austrian independence treaty to permit its being put into effect.
Another wave of strength surged through the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and carried prices to the best levels since last Friday. Aircrafts rode the crest of the wave.
CAIRO, Friday, May 20 -Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Premier and chief of the ruling army junta, told Egypt last night he would establish a "national Parliament" next January.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Strange Lady in Town," a Warner drama in CinemaScope and color with Greer Garson, Dana Andrews, Cameron Mitchell and Lois Smith, is at the Victoria.

Coffee futures soared as much as the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by denials of price war rumors and reports that Colombia would maintain its minimum selling price.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 19 (AP) -- High winds and cold rain whipped St. Andrews today as the British and United States Walker Cup team captains named the players for the opening foursomes of the fifteenth international golf competition.

Your editorial of May 10 on delinquency prevention illustrates the gradual crystallization of ideas on how to get at the roots of delinquency growth. No doubt home influences come first, school second; but in the writer's opinion there are scores of other influences which are so much a part of our way of life that they are overlooked or ignored.
More than 500 varsity athletes, alumni and faculty attended the ninth annual All-Sports Nite in City College's main gymnasium last night.
A Federal prison sentence was voided yesterday by the application of an ancient English common law.

KING'S LYNN, England, May 19 -- This ancient town, once a gateway to the medieval wool trade and today the political center of the constituency that takes its name. is warming up for a stiff fight over its seat in Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- After drawing a rebuke from his chief, Brig. Gen. Woodbury M. Burgess of Air Force Intelligence denied today he had said Russia's air force was as good or better than this country's.

A story and picture on the front page of this newspaper yesterday illustrated what can happen when municipal obstacles are put in the way of midtown traffic. The Manhattan Borough President's Office sent out a work crew on a busy weekday to make six separate street repairs in the midtown area.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, construction and marine salvage organization controlled by Louis E. Wolfson, is planning a trip to Wall Street. The company disclosed last night that it intends to market $25,000,000 of convertible debentures.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending yesterday decreased $67,000,000 to $18,853,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Sun Oil Company's tanker Louisiana Sun and her thirty-eight-man crew were honored yesterday for a daring sea rescue last year,

An experiment by the New York City Youth Board indicates that potential juvenile delinquents, may be spotted, Nathaniel Kaplan, chairman of the board and Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, declared yesterday.

SINGAPORE, May 19 (Reuters) -- Three thousand Chinese students drilled inside high school walls today as their Communist leaders pushed a "stay-in" strike against government attempts to break their power.

The New York Investors Mutual Group, Robert Morman, president, sold three Third Avenue properties with a total assessed valuation of $324,000. The parcels were sold to three different buyers in a deal negotiated by E. Rene Frank of Ruland Benjamin, Earle Calhoun, Inc.

LONDON, May 19 (Reuters) -- World production of natural rubber in 1955 will be about 1,845,000 long tons, according to a statement issued here today by the International Rubber Study Group's Management Committee.
Herbert Hoover announced last night that he would complete in the next few days recommendations for Governmental reorganization that could save Federal taxpayers $6,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- When Secretary of State Dulles returned from Asia in March, he told the people: "I came back from this trip to the Far East with a sense of deep concern."
CHICAGO, May 20 (UP)--Art Ditmar, a right-hander, limited the Chicago White Sox to two hits tonight as the Kansas City Athletics gained a 1-0 victory before 18,008 Comiskey Park fans.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- It appeared today that the Senate might insist that the nation's military strength be held at levels higher than the reduced manpower asked by the Administration.
BERLIN, May 20--Pvt. William T. Marchuk, former prisoner in the Soviet Union, was sentenced today to twelve years at hard labor by a United States Army court-martial.

WASHINGTON, May 20--The Consumer Price Index for the United States dropped a tenth of 1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today this was the first change since December.
Robbers took a $10,000 payroll in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday and a $4,000 payroll in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

A conversion to apartments for the two five-story buildings at 311-13 East Forty-third Street is planned by Fred H. Hill. As president of the Danfred Realty Corporation he has entered into a contract to purchase the buildings from the New York Society for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled Children, which has used the structures for a nursing residence.

BERLIN, May 20--Big Four representatives failed today to agree on a formula to resolve the dispute over highway tolls between Berlin and the West. The question may be taken up by the Big Four foreign ministers.

WASHINGTON, May 20--The Public Health Service tonight rejected smaller doses and a different technique of injecting Salk poliomyelitis vaccine as a means of stretching the short supply. The standard dosage now is a cubic centimeter.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- Two men from Putnam, Conn., obtained a patent this week for a modernized tap shoe with molded plastic nylon toe and heel.
CHICAGO, May 20--A shipping tie-up in Chicago ports was threatened today.
The Fund for the Republic has appropriated $100,000 to establish a Commission on Race and Housing to study the housing of minority groups.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- United States coffee imports from Latin America fell 21 per cent in 1954, it was reported today.

A PROPER critic, George Saintsbury observed, "can administer sequins as well as lashes, and send a man to ride round the town in royal apparel as well as dispatch him to the gallows." In something of this spirit Marianne Moore has collected a chapbook of her mercifully discerning essays on books and characters.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- Bob Porterfield and Johnny Schmitz combined to restrict Boston to six hits tonight as Washington defeated the Red Sox, 3--1. Porterfield, who gained his fifth victory, was forced to retire after five innings when his right arm stiffened after being hit by Billy Klaus' line drive in the second inning.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Declines in average prices for farm products and processed foods caused the decrease.

Distributors of new issues of securities face a period of intense activity. In the corporate field there is a perceptible stepping up in the rate of offerings of all types of securities--bonds, convertible debentures and preferred and common stock.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 20-- The Communist air build-up along the mainland coast opposite Formosa is still in a preliminary stage. As of today not one jet strip in that region is operational.
VIENNA, May 20 -- United States union leaders decided today to press for an effective world boycott of slave labor goods.
LOS ANGELES, May 20-- Unity negotiations among the three largest Presbyterian bodies in this country will remain in abeyance for at least two years.

LONDON, May 20--The railway and dock strike threats acted as a brake on business in the stock market here today. As buying fell, yesterday's gains were wiped out and losses were recorded among British Government stocks and industrials.

Although the atomic era on the high seas promises progress and prosperity, this country's concern now should be with the gainful employment of its present ships, Seaborn P. Collins, national commander of the American Legion, asserted last night.

MIAMI, May 20--President Eisenhower was commended today by the Southern Baptist Convention for "patient diplomatic conduct" that indicated a "purpose to exhaust every possible means toward peace without war."
The Texas Turnpike Authority announced yesterday plans for the sale of $58,500,000 of revenue bonds on June 14 to finance construction of a toll expressway to connect Dallas and Fort Worth.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 20-- Lung cancer was reported identifiable today more than 90 per cent of the time through a microscopic method.

Lamb, one of the best meat buys this week-end, is traditionally served in England with a sauce flavored with capers. The pungent, slightly bitter flower buds of the caper bush are a timely seasoning because they enhance not only lamb but also many warm-weather foods.
LOS ANGELES, May 20 (UP) --Wes Santee set a Coliseum Relays mark in the mile tonight, but his time of 4:05.5 was far from the four-minute mile that he has set as his goal.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- Congress heard today that lethal amounts of radioactivity would persist for long periods in land areas dusted with fall-out from a hydrogen bomb.
WASHINGTON, May 20--The Louisville and Nashville Railroad will pay the total cost of an employe health and welfare plan under the terms of a referee's decision issued today.
IF the composers keep on writing operas and the workshops go on producing them, we may discover one fine day that we have a contemporary repertory.

As Feridun C. Erkin, Ambassador of Turkey, prepares to leave Washington after nearly seven years of service there, he can look back with satisfaction on the excellent relations built up between his country and curs.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 20 (AP)--Tony Trabert's long winning streak was snapped today by Orlando Sirola. The Italian player beat the United States Davis Cup ace in a quarter -final of the Wiesbaden international tennis tournament 6--2, 4--6. 6--4.

The lives of two Roman Catholic Bishops are told in books scheduled for publication Thursday by P. J. Kenedy. "Ambassador in Chains," by Raymond A. Lane, Superior General of Maryknoll, is a life of Bishop Patrick James Byrne, who became Prefect Apostolic of Kyoto in 1937.

KANSAS CITY, May 20 (AP) --Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., today fashioned his second straight five-under-par 67 for a 134 total to lead at the halfway mark in the $20,000 Kansas City open golf tournament.

CHIGWELL, England, May 19-- There are no burning issues in Britian's general elections and only three outstanding voices, all offstage. One is that of Sir Winston Churchill, who spoke here last night in favor of "Tory Democracy." Another is that of Aneurin Bevan, whose ebullience and lack of party discipline have probably cost Labor any chance of winning Thursday's vote.

QUINCY, Mass., May 20--The Air Force "launched" today a man-made island. It is the prototype of some thirty installations that win stand offshore with radar aircraft detection equipment. They will tower far above the sea but be rooted to the bottom.

Motoring, High Speed The motoring season is here again, and if there are any changes since last fall all seem to be along the then indicated lines. A cursory look around suggests that the winter's men-at-work have been reducing grades, clearing obstructions to the vision and rendering less acute the angles to sharp turns.

WASHINGTON, May 20--Advocates of the Eisenhower highway program carried their fight for its adoption to the Senate floor today. A Democratic substitute was called up for what promised to develop into one of the session's sharpest debates.

SANDS POINT, L. I., May 20 --The Apawamis Club won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team championship today. It defeated rivals from New Jersey and Long Island over the Sands Point course.
ALBANY, May 20--A former Democratic State Conservation Commissioner proposed today an investigation by the Republicancontrolled Legislature of Governor Harriman's Conservation Department.
The rate of polio vaccine inoculations in New York City, slipped yesterday to 69 per cent, or slightly fewer than seven out of every ten children whose parents had approved their taking the shots.
BONN, Germany, May 20-- The West German Government has decided to rush the armament bills through Parliament before this summer's Big Four conference on German reunification.
TOKYO, May 20 (AP)--The fifteenth congress of the International Chamber of Commerce voted solid backing today to a permanent international organization to liberalize world trade.
TOKYO, May 20--The Japanese Government decided formally today to accept the United States offer of uranium concentrates if acceptable conditions could be worked out by the two Governments.
Commodity futures rose irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light in most markets, generally limited to evening of holdings for the week-end.

Often in the business world women find themselves steadying the ladder while male coworkers climb to success. The retailing field, however, seems to provide career girls with express escalators to the executive floor.

BARNAUL, U. S. S. R., May 5--The sum of more than 12,000,000 rubles of Soviet Government money is now being invested on a grassy hilltop on the Siberian steppe about twentyfive miles southwest of Barnaul.

Baruch Lumet's comedy, "Once Upon a Tailor," appears to be having more than the usual amount of pre-Broadway difficulties. When the attraction opens Monday night at the Cort Theatre, it will be minus the services of its featured player, Jennie Goldstein.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Government labor mediation forces, keeping a close watch on Chicago negotiations between the railway conductors and the railroads, believe a showdown on a strike will come within the next few days.

The Phillies finally beat the Dodgers last night at Ebbets Field after failing in seven previous efforts this year. The 5--3 loss ran the Brooks' losing streak to four games and cut their league lead over the runner -up Giants to six and a half games.
Thirty thousand men and women will march down Fifth Avenue today, highlighting New York's Armed Forces Day tribute to the military services.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20-- The current financial plight of public and private higher education has become serious but the future appears bright. For some of the colleges it will be a question of trying to hang on.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 20-- A ten-year period of prosperity for American shipyards was predicted today by Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and Maritime Administrator.

NORWICH, England, May 20 --According to geologists, Norfolk has some of the most remarkable tertiary formations in the British Isles. Students have found that its politics are equally remarkable, and almost as hard to crack.

The seventh biennial convention of the Seafarers International Union of North America, A. F. L., will open Monday at Montreal. Harry Lundeberg, president of the union, will preside. The union represents crews of ships and fishing boats and employes of canneries and other industries affiliated with the sea.
A Brooklyn policeman in uniform emerged yesterday with a bloody face and a fractured nose and cheekbone from an encounter with a group of teen-age youths at the Prospect Park B. M. T. station.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20-- The American Baptist Convention heard today that its student program was sufficient to provide only half the leadership the denomination needs. The convention was asked to consider a capital campaign for $5,500,000 to bolster the program.

The struggle between President Peron and the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina is one of the most curious and interesting phenomena in contemporary LatinAmerican history. It has puzzled the best-informed students of Argentine affairs and is incapable of a clear and agreed explanation even by Argentines themselves.
WHILE the big Goya exhibition continues at the Metropolitan Museum, the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue, has put on an interesting show of that Spanish master's prints and drawings.

Miami Copper Earnings of the Miami Copper Company for the first half of 1955 are expected to exceed the $2.18 a share reported last year for the same period, E. H. Westlake, president, told the annual meeting of shareholders here yesterday.

Corporation Counsel Peter Campbell Brown had not decided yesterday whether he would appeal a court decision granting a burlesque license to a Brooklyn theatre. He said he wanted to "study the whole situation."
Clarence Francis, chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report, predicted yesterday that if all its recommendations were promptly adopted the Federal budget could be balanced overnight.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,500 head: market moderately active, steady to 25c lower on butchers: mostly steady on weights 230 pounds and over: sows, steady to mostly 25c lower: most choice 190 to 220-pound butchers.

The hydrogen bomb and its attendant fall-out are such fantastically destructive weapons that the first offhand reaction of many citizens --perhaps most of us--is that there's no use talking about civil defense against them because no effective civil defense is possible.

ATLANTA, May 20 (AP)--The long, costly and strife-ridden strike against Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company was settled tonight. But it may be several days before workers return to their jobs in nine Southeastern states.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eisenhower's $200,000,000 special fund for Asia was the target today of efforts to cut the $3,630,000,000 foreign-aid program.
NEWARK, May 20--A union official who had invoked the Fifth Amendment when he appeared before Congressional investigators here on Wednesday was suspended today pending a union trial.

Thousands of children, acolytes and junior choir members from all the parishes in the Episcopal Diocese of New York will pass in review before Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan this afternoon. The processon will form in the close of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) at 2 o'clock.

A Defense Department supply official revealed yesterday that the Government is planning with 28,000 industrial plants which make kiddy cars, gadgets and similar civilian frills, to convert to war production in an emergency.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 20--The forty-fifth annual meeting of the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America opened here today with more than 1,700 adult Scout leaders from all parts of the nation attending.

YESTERDAY (May 20, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Nominated Selden Chapia of the District of Columbia to be Ambassador to Iran; Richard Lee Jones of Chicago to be Ambassador to Liberia, and Harold C. Patterson of Arlington, Va., to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 20-- The official Government news agency said tonight French authorities here had agreed to withdraw their troops from Saigon. The agency, Vietnam Presse, stated an accord concerning the withdrawal had been reached in talks between French and Vietnamese officials.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 20 (AP)--America's young amateur golfers crushed Britain's hopes of winning the Walker Cup today when they swept all four of the opening day's foursomes matches in the fifteenth international team competition.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 20 --Joe McBride, former metropolitan amateur champion, was among the players who reached the semi-final round of the Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament today.

Aircrafts, which had led the stock market for two days, lost a bit of momentum yesterday. But steels, motors, chemicals and rails took over and prices made another considerable advance to the best levels since May 11.

The Yankees struggled to a 7-5 triumph over the Orioles before 16,614 spectators at the Stadium last night. It took 3 hours and 20 minutes to complete the dreary affair, marked by eighteen bases on balls, two hit batsmen, two wild pitches and other mound malfeasances.

A weird 10-cents-a-day shakedown by a 16-year-old high school student was revealed yesterday in Felony Court. The accused is alleged to have obtained the sum by forcing a younger classmate to redeem a stolen fountain pen.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 20-- A General Assembly committee voted a favorable report today on a bill that could curtail water supplies furnished by Connecticut to Westchester County, New York.

A succession of withdrawals by listed speakers and participants forced this postponement late yesterday of an Einstein memorial. The meeting, which was to have been held tomorrow in Carnegie Hall, was put off until June 26.

The first annual report of the Union Chemical and Materials Corporation, formerly known as the Follansbee Steel Corporation and now controlled by the Murchison Brothers, a Texas family holding company, showed a net loss of $328,134 for the two months ended Feb. 28.
The Consolidated Electronics Industries Corporation and the Alliance Manufacturing Company agreed yesterday to merge.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- Senator Richard L. Neuberger told the Senate yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration "could learn a lot from our neighbors in Canada" about a polio vaccine program.
Gil Turner, Philadelphia middleweight, and Ramon Fuentes of Los Angeles battled to a draw in the feature test of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
TWENTIETH century art has invented nearly as many new techniques as new forms. Indeed, it seems only proper that new wine should go into new bottles.
Pravda has indicated that the Yugoslav political and economic system is now accepted in Moscow as a variant type of socialism.

PARIS, May 20 -- President Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia was quoted in today's issue of the French weekly L'Express as having called the Atlantic Pact and the Soviet bloc swords of Damocles hanging above humanity.

BRIGHT salmon have made their appearance at the mouths of several new Brunswick rivers. The spring salmon fishing that has attracted many visiting anglers to the province during the past month will close on Monday.

An explosion and fire that officials termed "suspicious" wrecked a three-room office in lower Manhattan late yesterday. Three persons were injured slightly. The adjoining offices of four concerns were damaged.
President Eisenhower has rightly based his veto of the "S. 1" postal pay bill primarily on the deep disturbance it would cause in the complicated relationships between salaries and job requirements.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Dryweather reports from the spring wheat country as well as from some northern portions of the Corn Belt stimulated buying of wheat and oats futures here today. Other grains and soybeans also advanced.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers routed their old nemesis, Bob Lemon, and went on to trounce the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 11--4, tonight before a crowd of 50,004. Five runs in the seventh broke open what had been a nip-and-tuck contest.

TRENTON, May 20--Frederick M. Raubinger, State Commissioner of Education, today ordered the City of Englewood to end discrimination against Negro children in its public schools. He charged that there was segregation in both elementary and junior high schools.
ILANOTH, Israel, May 17-- Tree-planting, which for forty years has almost epitomized the Zionist dream, is today changing the face of Israel.

George A. Sloan, the industrialist, died shortly after 5 P. M. yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after an operation. Mr. Sloan, who resigned in March as chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, would have been 62 years old on May 30. He had been ill for several weeks and had undergone several other operations.
The Immigration Service has revived its controversial plan to process the entry papers of passengers while ships are on the way here from Europe and the Mediterranean, it was learned yesterday.

MADISON, Ind., May 20--The Atomic Energy Commission will be on the receiving end early next year of a million-dollar annual "gift" in the form of reduced power costs at its Portsmouth, Ohio, gaseous diffusion plant.
Foundations will never shy from controversial projects because of political criticism, Dean Rusk predicted yesterday.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was small yesterday. Prices were unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) lower than on Thursday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 20--The Pravda editorial on the

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20--James J. Wadsworth said today that further progress on the principles of disarmament could not be made "without some change of attitude on the part of top-level Soviet thinking."

BOSTON, May 20--An Air Force general officer asserted today that the United States appeared to hold the edge in qualitative superiority over Russia in a "slide-rule" concept of war. He described this concept as the race to maintain technological superiority.
A skeptical view of Russian peace moves was recommended to American Mayors yesterday by Senator William F. Knowland of California.

Bill Daly and Tex Pelte, fight managers, were suspended yesterday. The action was taken during the fourth hearing by the New York State Athletic Commission on charges by Vince Martinez, Paterson (N. J.) welterweight, that he was being boycotted.
OTTAWA, May 20--Ten per cent of Canadian children have been inoculated with the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine without a single outbreak of the disease so far.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 --The motion picture industry does not "plan making any concessions to anybody on anything," Eric Johnston declared today.
The Federal Trade Commission is often referred to as "the policeman of business." As such, its beat encompasses just about every nook and cranny of economic activity.
The citizens of Nashville, the second largest city in Tennessee, have embarked on a novel campaign to attract industry to the area.
WASRINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption from April 3 to April 30 averaged 35,402 bales for each working day.
A flagpole commemorating the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in the United States was given to the city yesterday at a ceremony in Battery Park.
BUENOS AIRES, May 20-- The Argentine Congress completed action today on two laws designed to make the Roman Catholic Church and the Argentine state separate.

The Welfare and Health Council of New York City has recently been looking backward and forward, with constructive purpose and results. It is celebrating its thirtieth anniversary of service, to the community and those who serve the community, as a coordinating and planning organization for voluntary and public welfare and health agencies.

Radio and television coverage of the British elections will get under way tomorrow. Throughout the week and until election day on Thursday, all stations will carry the latest campaign reports on their regularly scheduled newscasts.
LOS ANGELES, May 20-- Russia has a new supersonic day fighter-plane model in operational quantities, Gen. Nathan F. Twining. Air Force Chief of Staff, said today.
Thursday's total of 578 pints of blood given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program included 214 pints received at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 20 (AP)--Harlow Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, told stockholders today that this would be G. M.'s biggest production and sales year "if current labor negotiations are concluded peacefully."

WASHINGTON, May 20--The executor of the estate of Dr. Albert Einstein asked the Federal court today to order the State Department to issue him a passport so he could fulfill the trust imposed upon him by the will.
MILWAUKEE, May 20 (AP)-- Rookie Bob Speake's tenth-inning homer off Warren Spahn, with Eddie Miksis aboard, gave Chicago a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.

Vincent Auriol, former President of France, recalled yesterday how the bitter Dreyfus Affair had caused him to enter public life at the age of 18 and join those who wanted to fight "savage racialism."

CAIRO, May 20--The Premiers of Egypt and the Sudan have completed four days of intensive discussions seeking a basis for resuming negotiations on the division of the Nile waters. The waters are the lifeblood of both nations.

New York City's need for the Police Athletic League, better known as the P. A. L., is underscored by the realization that last year young people constituted a large percentage of those arrested for robbery, burglary and auto theft. Of 132,639 arrests in 1954 just 12,470, or 9.4 per cent, were between the ages of 16 and 21, while 6,012, or 4.5 per cent, were under age 16.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20--The Northern Rhodesia European mineworkers union has agreed to surrender to Negroes thirteen categories of jobs now done by whites.

JACKSONVILLE, Ala., May 20 (UP)--Two bandits seized a bank executive's wife and children as hostages in their home today while two others forced the official to open the bank and stole almost $90,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20-- --J. Howard Edgerton, president of the United States Savings and Loan League, today called for legislation to permit the nation's savings and loan associations to take an active role in the war against slums.

ALBANY, May 20 -- New equalization rates for New York City were announced today by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. That may or may not mean changes in the tax bills of individual property owners.

This is the only Saturday of the New York racing season on which a steeplechase heads a program. The over - the - jumps feature at Belmont Park is the $20,000 added International. The eleven-horse line - up includes jumpers that have been flown here from England, Ireland and Italy.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 20--A keen international rivalry exists between the twin cities separated by the Congo River. They are Leopoldville, capital of the Belgian Congo, and Brazzaville, capital of French Equatorial Africa, directly to the north.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board today liberalized its policy on trans-Atlantic charter flights.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) --The Defense Secretary, Charles E. Wilson, said tonight the United States was building military forces of "tremendous power" in an "unremitting effort to achieve world peace."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As we await the Supreme Court's further ruling on its decree on segregation in education and recommendations for its implementation, those of us who look forward to the early end of segregation in all areas of our national life might do well to prepare for something less than what we seek.

If one is going to tell people how to stand up for their rights against a policeman, why not tell them that the policeman, too, has some rights and difficult duties? Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams put that question to the New York Civil Liberties Union with the result that the policeman's side has been added to the union's forthcoming pamphlet, "Your Rights If Arrested."
WASHINGTON, May 20--The current political champ gave a free lesson in political strategy today.
Charles Frederic Chapman is America's first-ranking skipper.
LONDON, May 20--Prime Minister Eden warned Britain tonight that threatening dock and railroad strikes could cause widespread unemployment and bar continued prosperity.

JERUSALEM, Jordan--More than 100 new hotel rooms make this holiest place in Christendom even more attractive as a tourist center. The new sixty-room Hotel Ambassador opened its doors during the Christmas season last year, and other hotels are rushing new wings to completion for the summer travel season.

A grant of $78,970 has been made by the National Science Foundation to the University of Indiana for the construction of a 100-ton cloud chamber which will advance knowledge of cosmic rays and of atomic structure.

PARIS. THERE is, it seems, a steady, fairly profitable business in tracing family trees. The same impulse that makes certain people seek the security and respectability of "ancestors" apparently motivates certain adherents of modern art from time to time.

WHEN Yeats said "I must lay aside the pleasant paths I have built up for years and seek the brutality, the illbreeding, the barbarism of truth," he was speaking as an old man who had explored many of the ways of life and all of the forms of poetry.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 21-- Premier O.K. Yui said today no government had the right to discuss the fate of Nationalist China behind its back.

TO THE EDITOR: The trend in many periodicals seems to be away from controversial articles. Hence, it is refreshing to see your publication of Vera Micheles Dean's stimulating article, "A Basic Fallacy in Our View of Others" (May 8).

WASHINGTON, May 21-- President Eisenhower's veto this week of the average 8.8 per cent pay raise for 500,000 postal workers sent a sudden chill down the backs of 1,000,000 other Federal workers who have been promised fatter pay checks this year.

THE Union of South Africa likes to refer to itself as "the other U. S. A." and its people pride themselves on their American go-aheadness. In this informal portrait of his country. Alan Paton shares that feeling: unlike some of his less critical fellow-citizens, he looks beneath the surface to basic differences between the two countries.
LAKE MOHEGAN. N.Y., May 21--Seven New Yorkers today had scores of 2-0 in the amateur championship tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation at the Mohegan Country Club.

LONDON, May 21--The evident intention of the Greek Government to protest over treatment that Greek airmen received in Cyprus aroused the British Foreign Office today to the unusual step of expressing pained comment even before the protest had been received.

THIS is a hard book to categorize. It is perhaps the only full-length account of life at the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth. Although cast in fictional mold, the mark of truth is on it. For, fifteen years ago, talented British author John Lodwick was himself a cadet there.

LAKE GEORGE--This peacegful resort village will call up from the past next month the figures that made it one of the bloodiest crossroads in the country in the days of the nation's infancy. For four days the residents of this vacation center at the southern tip of the shimmering blue lake will re-enact the highlights of 300 years of history, complete with the great names that walked the village street in Colonial days.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21 Sixty-eight sailing craft, the largest first-day fleet in a number of seasons, opened the Yacht Racing Association's sixty-first year on Long Island Sound today.
Overwhelming the Orioles with a barrage of three home runs, the Yankees defeated Baltimore, 9-4, at the Stadium yesterday. It was the fifth straight victory for the Bombers.

FILLED with romance and intrigue, treacheries and bloody battles, yet adhering in the main to recorded fact, this story of a queen who dared all for love ought to make another popular historical novel.

MOSCOW, May 21--As yet it cannot be foreseen what proposals on Germany, if any, the Soviet Union will make to the forthcoming conference of the Big Four powers. But whatever the proposals may be the aims of Soviet policy are clear enough.

Despite their warnings against over-optimism, President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles are clearly elated at the turn affairs have taken in Europe. Their satisfaction is understandable, since the Austrian treaty, together with the Soviet proposal for a unified Germany, means that the Kremlin--ten years after the victory over the Axis--is at last on the point of ordering Russian divisions to march back East.
MADISON, Wis., May 21 (AP)-- A bill prohibiting labor unions from contributing to political campaigns has become law in Wisconsin.
