A recent proposal by a Congressman for a Federal Department of Urban Affairs, with Cabinet rank, has been endorsed by Henry Cohen, senior management analyst for the City Administrator of New York. The suggestion was put forth by Representative J. Arthur Younger, Republican of California.

The President has not only exonerated Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for any delay in the general introduction of Dr. Salk's vaccine but praised her for energy and competence. Nevertheless, medical men, opponents of the Administration and anxious parents continue to complain of the delay.
The blood pressure of a giraffe has been measured for the first time by modern medical specialists.
Two former estates are among acreage tracts which Long Island builders are converting to housing colonies. One of these is in Brookville and the other is in Huntington.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 21 -- St. John's College reaffirmed today belief in its controversial ''great books" curriculum.

HONG KONG, May 12--A nation -wide campaign on the "rectification of food sales" is going on throughout Red China. The Government has decreed a reduction of at least 20 to 30 per cent in state sales of rationed food to rural consumers.

From the outset of the British general election campaign, it was apparent that the preeminent interest of the voters was in peace. As the campaign reached midpoint last week, the "competitive peacemongering," as the London Economist put it, had become almost ferocious.
LONDON, May 21--Sir Anthony Eden tonight declared his willingness to attend a second meeting of the Soviet and Western heads of government should this prove necessary in the interests of world peace.

FATHER VIKENTY, a strapping yet humble Russian Orthodox priest, had had for thirty-six years as his New York parish a flock rather vaguely contained in an area north of Fourteenth Street and extending to parts of Westehester and Connecticut.

THE problem of mounting, framing and displaying fine photographic prints to best advantage has received a fresh solution in the Minute-Mount kit just introduced on the market. The kit consists of a 16x20-inch hard composition board backing oneeighth-inch thick, cardboard mount (white on one side, moss green on the other), smoothedged cover glass and plastic mitred framing channels.

SAN SALVADOR--The Legislative Assembly of El Salvador has received a bill exempting new hotels from the compulsory 20 per cent discount to employes of the nation's municipal and federal governments. This bill is recognized as the final step before construction is begun on a new 103-room luxury hotel for San Salvador.
The thump of an African drum and the clatter of a linotype machine are equally familiar sounds to Eric G. K. Adjorlolo.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Neutralism, an old word in the lexicon of the "cold war", was dressed in new colors this week as Washington prepared for a summer that may alter profoundly the global strategic and political picture.

THE suggestion in this department that neighbors "pool up" on the more specialized (and expensive) tools led to some group reminiscences about capitalizing even further on near-by resources. All present confessed to a highly reprehensible practice, but a very fruitful one. The routine goes like this:
Many cerebral palsied adults are said to have vocational aptitudes that go unrecognized for lack of adequate testing procedures.

BY the time the dogwoods bloom the vegetable garden should be well under way. This applies particularly to such hardy plants as lettuce, carrots, onions, peas, spinach and radishes. Even the less hardy kinds such as string beans, corn and lima beans can be put in the ground now in the metropolitan New York area.

HOW do Soviet engineers and doctors, teachers and peasants, live their everyday lives? Sharing the same basic human needs and hopes with people everywhere, do they have the same kind of lives as they would in another kind of society, or has the impact of Soviet totalitarianism molded them to an entirely different pattern ?
WASHINGTON, D.C.-- Tourists who like to view their history in the rough and a little off the main stem will find a chunk of it at Fort Washington, near here.

GRASS, it is well known, is a plant which grows practically everywhere except in one's own front yard. It covers many parts of the earth like a green three-day beard, adding much to the beauty of suburban and country property.
There isn't a steel mill within fifty-five miles of the city, but New York this week becomes the nation's steel capital.

NEW HAVEN, May 21--A statement by a City Administration official that New Haven is a "dying city" that needs a new department store to help revitalize it, has brought sharp denials from leading business men. A controversy has developed that is certain to continue until the municipal election in November.

WASHINGTON, May 21--New political controversy swirled this week over the heads of the Hoover Commission members. In their latest series of reports they moved out of the field of simple governmental reorganization into the controversial area of proper government function.
EASTON, Pa., May 21--Outstanding students can begin college work at the age of 16 with only two years of secondary school preparation, a four-year experiment at Lafayette College shows.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 16--The Unionist party said today it would seek to unseat any Sinn Feiners who won a seat in the British general election. There are twelve seats at stake in Northern Ireland.

RESERVATIONS in hand, bags packed, pets boarded with neighbors -- all set for a vacation. But what about the garden? How will it look at vacation's end? This worry will be common again this summer, both for the allsummer vacationers and the two-week variety, but it can be alleviated if steps are taken now.

THE big news in television last week concerned the Columbia Broadcasting System's whopping program plans for the 1955-56 season. Columbia announced ten different hour-and-a-half "Saturday night specials," the majority to be in color; referred to seventeen new series of weekly half-hour programs (some had been announced previously) and promised to deliver such boxoffice attractions as Noel Coward, Mary Martin and Bing Crosby.

The Dodgers yesterday snapped their losing string at four games by beating the Phillies, 6-4, at Ebbets Field. A Ladies Day crowd of 28,141 (13,401 paid) watched the game and cheered the outcome wholeheartedly. The victory kept the Brooks six and a half games ahead of the secondplace Giants.
HARTFORD, May 21--The General Assembly is heading into one of its worst pre-adjournment jams.

THE recent publication of a new edition, the ninth, of H.S. Newcombe's "35mm Photo Technique" (London: The Focal Press; New York: American Photographic Book Publishing Company, Inc. $3.75) returns to the field one of the most helpful books on this popular subject.

"A four-power meeting 'at the summit' may be a good idea, but who is the Soviet summit?" Thus, succinctly, a diplomat expressed last week a major puzzle confronting Western policy makers as they looked forward to the projected Big Four meeting this summer.
The 1954 edition of The New York Times Index, which records the day-by-day history of the world, has just been published.

TO THE EDITOR: I wish to congratulate your paper for the very valuable article entitled "School Desegregation: A Case History" (May 8) by Gertrude Samuels. The process of desegregation has been going forward steadily not only in Baltimore [about which Miss Samuels wrote.--Editor.] but in school districts throughout the country.

THE Cinerama process, which sparked the socalled wide-screen "revolution" in film-making some three years ago with the release of "This Is Cinerama," may be used by M-G-M and other studios, it was learned last week.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21--Political leaders in Westchester County are wrestling with the toughest problem in year. Their decisions will have broad consequences, and the time of crisis has arrived.
CINCINNATI, May 21 (UP)-- For the second time in two games the Cincinnati Redlegs came up with a six-run inning today as they trounced the St. Louis Cardinals, 9-6.

MAJOR festivals, by attracting thousands of entertainment - hungry persons to given areas, often lead to the establishment of subsidiary festivals that are operated independently in the area of the main one.

THE title of this book is the clarion call of the annual 500-mile automobile race at Indianapolis, Ind. The late Wilbur Shaw, who died in an aviation accident last year, won that race three times and was president of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway at the time of his death.
Soviet satellites are actively campaigning to improve their relations with Greece and Turkey. Apparently this is part of a drive by Moscow to create a neutral strip through the heart of Europe.

A forty-acre tract in the Madison Township section of Sayreville, N. J., has been selected for a retail center to contain fifty stores. To be known as the Morgan Shopping Plaza, it will occupy a site on Route 9 at the southeast corner of Ernston Road.
Industrial development is on the increase in northern New Jersey, according to Joseph L. Rusch, executive vice president of the Alexander Summer Company.

Six receiving clerks of the ABC Freight Forwarding Corporation, 201 Eleventh Avenue, and four truckmen were arrested yesterday. They were accused of obtaining more than $150,000 through fraudulent delivery charges.

AS time goes on, I find myself increasingly aware of the parallels and divergences between literature and the other arts, and more and more interested in their manifestations. Often, if they are not pushed too far, these likenesses and differences help to explain how a particular work succeeds or fails in its purpose;

THE battle is on! The Columbia Broadcasting System, bestirring itself after a winter's slumber, has served notice on the National Broadcasting Company that two can play at the game of spectaculars. One of the most fiercely competitive eras in the history of the entertainment world is almost here.

It is now forty days since the Federal Government took over sole responsibility for testing and releasing the Salk anti-polio vaccine. These are the main steps the Government has taken since then: April 12: Licensed six pharmaceutical houses to produce the vaccine under Federal standards.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- A spurt of activity among public and private utilities in the Pacific Northwest is pointing up the overriding issue--political and economic--that now is gripping the basin of the Columbia River.
LOS ANGELES, May 21-- World trade will never become really liberalized until sea transportation is freed from cargo preferential rules, a Norwegian shipping executive said here this week.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Congress will begin work next week on legislation for a two-year renewal of the Defense Production Act, which will expire June 30. Representative Brent Spence, Democrat of Kentucky and Chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, said today that he would act "about the middle if next week" to set hearings on renewing the law.

Tomorrow New York State's 116,200 teachers will have a "day" of their own. For the first time an official Teacher Recognition Day has been set aside by the Governor, to pay tribute to the men and women who serve the state's millions of pupils.
MOST gardeners still have a lot of planting to do for bloom this summer and fall. By now the hardy annuals are growing nicely and the half-hardy kinds have been planted either as seed or seedlings.

IN the pursuit of fame, that last infirmity of noble minds, the food that dead men eat, architects suffer both advantages and handicaps. The products of their creative genius and business management are not hung away from the crowd, to be sought out in quiet galleries, or squeezed into corners of dusty shelves in libraries.

The final free art lecture in the New York Public Library's spring series, "Art Work with Adults," will be held at 6:15 P. M, Tuesday in the main building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The artist-lecturer, James A. Ernst, will speak on greater appreciation of art through reading and gallery visits, as well as through participation.

A blueprint for a good junior high school program, particularly at the seventh and eighth grade levels, is set forth in a ninetynine-page study issued by the United States Office of Education. The report is based on an analysis of seventy-six schools in twentythree states.
Revisions of the United Nations Charter are needed to promote universal disarmament, Gen, Carlos P. Romulo, special envoy of the Philippines to the United States, said last night.
DERBY, Conn., May 21-- Princeton University won the Big Three rowing title on the Housatonic River today. The Tigers easily defeated the Harvard and Tale 150-pound crews.

NEW HAVEN, May 21-- Thirty-four students, survivors of a special group of fifty-two admitted to Yale four years ago although only a few had completed high or preparatory school, will be graduated next, month.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21-- Penn's unbeaten varsity crew led all the way to gain a length-anda-half victory over Rutgers today. The oarsmen competed over the Henley distance of a mile and five-sixteenths on the Schuylkill River.
Civil defense is "too big a jot for the military," Val Peterson told American and Canadian Mayors yesterday.
A bitter struggle over May potato futures ended Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

A parcel of several hundred acres fronting on Lake Champlain at Crown Point, N.Y., has been purchased from the estate of J.F. Nadeau by W.R. and Kirana L. Slack of Hague, N.Y. Mr. Slack developed the Indian Kettles Club at Lake George.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the many official discussions of problems faced by the colleges today, one situation is never mentioned --the severe unemployment among college teachers in the liberal arts. On the contrary, the publicity about a general teacher shortage gives the impression that college jobs are actually going begging.

GENEVA, May 20 -- Some West European economists and business men wonder if the apparent Soviet desire to settle disputes may not have, at least in part, a simpler explanation than is generally assumed.

The Yankees trounced the Orioles, 9-1, yesterday and moved into first place in the American League as the Tigers defeated the second-place Indians, 3-2. The Giants beat the Pirates, 3-2, and the Dodgers downed the Phils, 6-4.
A tire manufacturer recently stopped advertising "they won't blow out" and a fire detection equipment producer ceased using "scare" tactics to sell his product.

The Berkshire Music Center's supply of scholarships and prizes has been increased by two new contributions this year. High Fidelity, the magazine published in the Berkshires, is offering an annual $250 scholarship to an outstanding student.
E. Kenry H. Simmons, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at his home, 164 East Seventysecond Street, at the age of 78.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today that some opponents of his proposed constitutional amendment to limit the treaty power "deliberately confuse the legal issues."
CAMDEN, N.J., May 21 (UP) --Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Subahdar set a Garden State Park track record of 1:47 2/5 for a mile and a furlong today in the 534,650 Camden Handicap.

MAYAGUEZ, Puerto Rico, May 19--A 43-year-old native New Yorker, an economic geographer by profession but a horticulturist by preference, is gambling here that he can grow black pepper commercially in the Caribbean islands.

ON May 5th, the Columbia University Orchestra under Howard Shanet's baton performed Louis Moreau Gottschalk's symphony "Night of the Tropics," which was received most enthusiastically by the audience.

The early arrivals of the annual American tourist invasion of Europe are already to be seen in the sidewalk cafes, the shops and night clubs of the big cities, but they are even more noticeable in the art galleries and museums. These institutions, with their great treasures of the past, rank high on the guided sight-seeing tours and in the itineraries of most travelers.

A GOOD lawn in the New York area usually requires a lot of water during the hot, dry, summer months. Supplying that water has always been a time-consuming job for the average homeowner, requiring endless moving of sprinklers and handling of wet hoses.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 (AP) --Cal Niday of Pacoima, Calif., one of the country's top auto race drivers despite an artificial leg, set the pace today in the third qualifying session for the 500-mile race on May 30.

THE two simultaneous exhibitions of paintings and sculpture by artists who nave sprung into prominence in Europe and America in the ten years since the war-- Americans at the Whitney Museum and Europeans at the Museum of Modern Art--present so many points of interest that they repay many visits.

HERE is a first novel written under the sign of Taurus and the spell of Flamenco by a former British newspaper man turned aficionado and muy simpatico. All clear? This means that Mr. Winn became the repository of so much lore about the esoteric customs and historical traditions of Spain that he decided to get it all down in a book.

To some, a corridor is just a means of getting from one place to another, but to space-conscious John J. Meng, dean of Hunter College in the Bronx, it represents a means of acquiring needed instruction rooms.

VASSAR--Mature Students Freshmen of unusual ability and maturity who enter Vassar College next fall wil have an opportunity to elect courses on a more advanced level than those ordinarily open to entering students. Under a new plan adopted by the faculty, students of exceptional ability, who have taken advantage of one or more special advanced courses set up by their preparatory school for the senior year, will be eligible for special placement.
VIENNA, May 21 -- United States, British and other Western oil concerns may share in the development of the east Austrian oil fields.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The immediate future of the mass anti-poliomyelitis inoculation program remained in doubt today.
Suggestions that a large amount of mortgage credit tends to unbalance the nation's economy are challenged by a Jersey realtor.

One or the most encouraging aspects of our national life is the growing awareness placed on the values of health, medical and hospital care. As a result of this awareness, there is an ever-increasing demand for all health services.

MARS-- An electronic camera was used to photograph the planet Mars during its closest approach last summer. The camera, which is similar in principle to TV cameras, was developed by the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions of Baltimore, Md., for use as a fluoroscopic screen intensifier for medical X-ray use.

FOR the great majority of woodworking jobs the householder undertakes he uses the softwoods--for his bookcases, shelves, plant boxes and so on. But for certain other projects hardwoods are required. The two terms are somewhat misleading, as explained in an earlier article in these pages, in that some so-called softwoods are comparatively hard and some hardwoods are comparatively soft.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 21 -- Manhattan's track and field team overwhelmed Army today, 101 to 39. In running up the biggest score ever made against a cadet squad, the Jasper contingent broke five meet records and one track mark.

The Long Island Home Builders Institute reports that it has had remarkable success with its lecture courses to aid prospective home buyers. The next one is scheduled for June 6 at the Flatlands Post American Legion Hall at 2295 Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn.

MARSEILLES, France, May 21 (AP)--Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, founder of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women and its president since 1930, died here last night at the age of 74.
Man grows in stature as he works toward God's goal of universal peace, Rabbi Zev Zahavy said in his sermon yesterday.

ONE of the more striking changes in the European travel pattern in the last three years has been the dramatic development of a system of youth hostels in Italy. Starting almost from scratch, the Italians are endeavoring with eagerness and energy to match, or outmatch, some of the countries that have been hosteling for years.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 21-- Raynham Hall, one of the few pre-Revolutionary homesteads on Long Island, will benefit by a tour called Homes and Hobbies on Land and Sea on June 4 when interesting houses and some yachts will be opened to the public.
J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigations, defended himself yesterday against charges that his questionnaire to 290 State Liquor Authority employes was unfair.
LONDON, May 15--The restrictions imposed by British law on campaign expenditures by and on behalf of candidates for Parliament would make many a United States politician shudder.

The annual meeting of the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York has re-elected its present slate of officers, headed by Thomas F. Horan, as president. The election was held at a meeting Thursday in the organization's offices at 17 Battery Place.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 21--Cornell's field event strength carried it to an 82 1/3 to 52 2/3 victory over Princeton in a dual track meet today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- The United States took a look today at its military strength.
NEW DELHI, India, May 21 --Communist China's campaign to take over Asian trade union movements has received a major setback.

THE art season is ending with a series of bangs. One by one, at museums and dealers, the detonators are at work. There is the Goya time-bomb at the Metropolitan, the latest explosives a the Whitney and the Modern, and now the smaller galleries are turning into position to deliver broadsides.

GENEVA, May 21--The International Tracing Service is to be taken over by the International Committee of the Red Cross. The agency has the task of trying to find out what happened to millions of persons who died, or simply disappeared in Nazi concentration camps during World War II.
WASHINGTON, May 21--An estimated 4,000,000 students hunting summer jobs were assured today that their prospects were "quite good."

NEARLY all Europeans are amazed (or profess to be amazed) that the International Match Point system of scoring has never been adopted for team matches in the United States. The IMP's have been used in Europe for nearly twenty years, but American matches have continued to be based on cumulative, or total-point, scoring.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 21-- Meadow Rice won, with the previously undefeated Adios Harry, the 1-2 favorite, finishing third tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the four-horse field racing in the Babylon Pace.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --A special Hoover Commission task force headed by Gen. Mark W. Clark has completed an exhaustive investigation of highlevel United States intelligence operations around the world.

A SCOTTISH bid, late in the seventeenth century, for a place in the New World sun is the springboard for this new historical novel by the author of "Buccaneer Surgeon." Men born to hard tunes and bred to caution risk all for a New Scotland.
The City Council of Milwaukee, Wis., has passed an ordinance aimed at preventing investors from improving land the city plans to acquire for public projects.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- The Housing and Home Finance Agency announced today its approval of New York City's continuing program to eliminate slums.
A dangerous factor in the street gang problem is the mentally unbalanced boy who steers his companions into acts of spectacular violence or depravity.
TREDEGAR, Wales, May 21-- Aneurin Bevan returned to his home constituency today, after three weeks of speaking for other candidates, to fight the politician's worst antagonist-- apathy.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --Ed FitzGerald's infield grounder scored Pedro Ramos from third base in the twelfth inning tonight to give the Washington Senators a 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox. The game was marked by a fist-fight between Jackie Jensen and Mickey McDermott.
WASHINGTON, May 21--Presumably fifty million kids can't be wrong, but Davy Crockett has finally been called on to do something beyond his powers. He has been asked to reform Congress.
RECONFIRMATION, a system that has detonated the temper of many an air traveler, will be abandoned June 15 on a majority of airline routes.
Austria, whose population is a little more than 6,933,000 and whose area of 32,366 square miles is slightly less than that of Maine, will pay a high price for her newly won independence.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 17 --In an effort to increase the 2,000 California bighorn sheep in the province, the British Columbia Game Commission this summer will move a number from the Chilcotin district to the milder climate of the south Okanagan Valley.

The costly research conducted by the refining branch of the oil industry in recent years is paying off. With the new facilities that have been developed, the industry has reached the point where it can produce only such major products as it wants, and of a higher quality than formerly.

BLOCH: Four Episodes; William Masselos and the Knickerbocker Chamber Players conducted by Izler Solomon; BRITTEN; Sinfonietta, Op. 1; Solomon and M-G-M Chamber Ensemble (M-G-M, 10-inch). Two first LP's, recorded with exceptionally brilliant sound.
SYDNEY, Australia--Most Americans have at least three preconceived ideas about Australia--that it is a long way from home, that it is a big country and that its hotels leave something to be desired.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 21--The United States took the Walker Cup for the fourteenth time in fifteen tries today with a 10-2 golf victory over the British.

EVERY woman reporter is asked once if not one hundred times during her career how she came to enter the newspaper business. The questioner is nearly always of the same sex; frequently a girl with vague ambitions to become a reporter herself.

THAT William Ellery Channing was a commanding figure among the great of his own time is well known. What is not so well known is his importance as a molding influence in the early and most formative years of American independence.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --Government action and improved airline business have made a big cut in airline subsidies during the last year. Aviation experts expect the trend to continue.
Louis A. Wehle, State Conservation Commissioner, defended himself yesterday against charges of dismissing personnel on a partisan political basis.
Hofstra College defeated Brooklyn College, 10-7, yesterday and took second place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference. The game was played at Brooklyn College Field.
An adolescent accused of attacking a policeman in a subway station on Friday was held in $25,000 bail yesterday for felonious assault.

Stores continued to besiege manufacturers for all kinds of Davy Crockett items last week, resident buying offices report. Demand has expanded from Davy Crockett boys' wear to linens, toys, novelties and women's apparel and accessories bearing the name of the famous frontiersman.
ETA-JIMA, Japan, May 21-- United States Army officers were hosts today to more than 8,000 Japanese, many of them from atom-bombed Hiroshima.

A prime reason for waterfront turbulence is the lack of understanding between the clock worker and his employer. One local of New York's International Longshoremen's Association has proposed to do something about it.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 21 (UP)--Rex C. Ellsworth's El Drag set a world record of 1:20 for seven furlongs before 42,000 racegoers at Hollywood Park today in the $15,000 Crenshaw Handicap.

An old Bergen County truck farm is the site of a development that will provide homes for 107 families. It is a forty-acre tract in Clifton, N. J., once operated by the Hamilton family and now a bustling scene of housing and road building.
VIENNA, May 21 -- James Caesar Petrillo made his debut on the world stage today as a self-proclaimed spokesman for culture.

CANNES. AFTER seventen days of festivities during which thirty -five features and fortyfive documentaries from thirty-seven countries passed in review, the 1955 Cannes Festival went into the records as the year of "Marty" and of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 21--A cease-fire seems to have settled over the Formosa Strait. Defense officials said that in general terms their intelligence reports agreed with a dispatch to The New York Times from Formosa, published today, to the effect that the Communist air build-up was still in a preparatory stage.
Office buildings without elevator operators is a trend that has been steadily growing over the last five or six years.
DETROIT, May 21--The tempo of bargaining on the guaranteed annual wage issue is expected to increase next week.
Federally chartered savings and loan associations soon may be able to make bigger loans to help small home building organizations to finance residential developments.

The City College track team gave its 70-year-old coach, Dr. Harold Anson Bruce, a goingaway present in the form of an 87-to-53 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. It marked City's first undefeated outdoor season under the retiring coach.
Like most successful businessmen, Lewis S. Rosenstiel has to look ahead. In his case, however, the look ahead extends twelve years or so.
ATHENS--A question often asked is: "What can you do with just one day in Athens?" "Nothing. Anyway, not much," is the usual answer. It does not happen to be a correct one.

WHO would care to meet James Boswell, age 25, in Italy today? That young man would have lately battered down the door of T. S. Eliot's flat in London, have lunched with Sir Winston Churchill, notebook in hand. He would be on his way to visit Albert Schweitzer in Africa, and have debated in his own mind a proposal of marriage to Isak Dinesen (because of her Gothic tales).

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 21-- The National Revolutionary Committee sent cablegrams today to the heads of forty-three Governments, including President Eisenhower, announcing that the Vietnamese people had "pronounced the dismissal of Bao Dai as Chief of State of Vietnam."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 (AP)--Ohio State University is in its fifth year of an export program on engineering "knowhow."
HOLLYWOOD. THE National Broadcasting Company is working on plans to originate four of the ninety-minute "Producers' Showcase" programs from its big production center in near-by Burbank.

FOR thirty-eight years the statisticians have been short-changing Napoleon Lajoie on his batting average. But the Big Frenchman has just received a rebate and all is serene again. Instead of hitting a miserable .405 in 1901, he actually batted .422, a figure that now becomes the highest in American League history and that now supersedes the .420 jointly held by Ty Cobb and George Sisler.
WASHINGTON, May 21-- For the present the United States must retain its air bases in Europe and maintain its military strength there, Senator Walter F. George said today.
KANSAS CITY, May 21 (AP)-- Dick Mayer of St. Petersburg, Fla., took over the lead in the $20,000 Kansas City open golf tournament today with a 204 after a third-round 68.
TO THE EDITOR: The article on school desegregation in Baltimore stirred up nostalgic memories. I happen to have spent several happy years in P.S. 53, one of the schools Miss Samuels mentioned.
Three Government agencies are cooperating in a comprehensive survey of current and potential supplies of the nation's scrap iron and steel.

HOLLYWOOD. HOLLYWOOD still was anxiously awaiting some measured words of defense from Eric Johnson, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, to the blunt criticism of movie moral standards by the Rev. Thomas F. Little, executive secretary of the National Legion of Decency, when this section went to press.

MILWAUKEE, May 21 -- George Crowe's pinch homer with one out in the ninth ruined a no-hit no-run game today for Warren Hacker of the Chicago Cubs. However, Hacker finished with a one-hitter and a 2-1 triumph over the Milwaukee Braves.

CAIRO, May 21--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser eased the Egyptian press censorship laws slightly today. He permitted free discussion and criticism of the form of government to be established next January when "transitional" rule by the military junta is scheduled to end.

MOSCOW, Sunday, May 22-- Pravda charged today that the United States was indulging in endless talk and making unrelated demands on the Soviet Union concerning the projected top-level Big Four conference. It denounced ideas expressed on the Eisenhower-Dulles television presentation to the American people last Tuesday night.

AFTER an unusually strenuous spring burst, the dance season is now settling down in the direction of normal summer doldrums. There are still, however, a few recitals current and in the offing. Those for the present week are as follows:
ST. LOUIS, May 21--A vast storehouse to enclose the mountain of personnel records accumulated by the armed forces in the last five decades is now being built in a suburban field near here.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 9-- Turkey has embarked on a farflung railroad construction program reminiscent of the early days of America's transcontinental rail lines.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Diplomatic documents held secret for seventeen years showed today that Hermann Goering, Nazi air chief, had accused the United States of "deliberate unfriendliness" in refusing to sell Germany helium for its Zeppelin airship.

St. Francis Prep swept the three divisional titles yesterday in the thirty-ninth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium. The Terriers captured the senior, junior and midget honors.
Soviet refugees in the United States, including some now United States citizens, have become objects of a Communist campaign to induce them to return to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --Harold E. Stassen, retiring foreign aid director, said today that old-time conservative capitalism in the United States had evolved into a peoples' capitalism shared by all.

A funeral service for George A. Sloan, industrialist and former president and chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will be held at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street.

A long holiday week-end drawn out to an extra day will find speed-boat regattas on many a waterway. Some will conflict and overlap, so eager are the steering-wheel daredevils to resume racing after the long winter's layoff.
WASHINGTON, May 21--A study group of prominent political students urged the United States today to chart a foreign policy embracing close economic union with Western Europe.

WHAT is one to think of the season of "American Dance" that has just closed at the ANTA Theatre? What did it think of itself? What did it have in mind to begin with, and did it achieve that end? Did it, indeed, have a mind--that is, a single mind ?

AN amateur who has scored a long series of club and contest successes has been rewarded with the opportunity to hang a show of her own. Anne Brennan, who won the honor as the result of having received the 1954 "Printof-the-Year" award, opened her show last Sunday at the Village Camera Club, 65 Bank Street, where it will hang through June 5.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox hammered five doubles today to help Dick Donovan gain his fifth victory with a 7-4 decision over the Kansas City Athletics.

Members of society gave many luncheons yesterday at the Turf and Field Club and at the restaurant in the club enclosure at Belmont Park before the fiftyeight running of the International Steeple Chase and the Withers.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21 --Joe McBride of Arcola rallied to win the Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament today. The New Jersey player turned back Frank Graven of Sands Point by 1 up at the nineteenth hole.
A New Jersey realtor is trying to find out what buyers are looking for in new and used homes.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21 --A 22-month-old Kerry blue terrier from California became the first big winner of the Metropolitan area outdoor all-breed dog show season today.

AT least sixteen and probably nineteen of the twenty-one pieces of fiction in the present collection were written between 1934 and 1939. The title piece, which consists of the first eighty pages of an unfinished novel, was composed some fifteen years after.

A two-day conference designed to acquaint business school deans with the mortgage banking industry will be held at the University of Michigan School of Business Administration in Ann Arbor, Mich., beginning June 21.

A YOUNG Australian novelist now living in England. Catherine Gaskin published her first novel. "This Other Eden," at the age of 17. Her sixth book of fiction, a historical novel, is the work of a conscientious craftsman, but it is lacking in that sharpness of insight and intensity of emotion needed to lift its kind beyond acceptable competence.

ST. LOUIS, May 21--The Boy Scout movement in the United States has assumed new importance in the struggle against juvenile delinquency, Charles W. Froessel, Associate Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, declared today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- The man behind the atomic plane is almost unknown. He would like to keep it that way.

SAN JUAN, P.R.--On what was once one of this island's largest coconut plantations, huge army and civilian airplanes began landing this week-end to celebrate the inauguration of the new Puerto Rican International Airport.

HONG KONG, May 21--Recent developments have created the impression here that there is less danger now of an immediate Chinese Communist attack against the Nationalist-held offshore islands than was the case a few months ago.

LONDON--Tourists who have twelve days to a fortnight to pass in an unusual offbeat excursion--much of it spent at sea--might well consider a trip from here in a cargo ship across the North Sea and back.
CHICAGO, May 21 (UP)--Most State Legislatures have gone allout this year to increase financial aid to public schools, underwrite new school construction and raise teachers' salaries.

Associates from college days and through his fifty-one years as a teacher and principal joined yesterday with public officials in paying tribute to Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz on the eve of his retirement from the city's school system.

PITTSBURGH, May 21--The Giants racked up their fourth straight victory today, beating the Pirates, 3 to 2. But it took a deal of doing before Fred Haney'a young Bucs finally went down to their ninth straight defeat.

ON April 22 Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden was named Conservative leader by a large gathering of Members of Parliament, Peers and other party notables. Following tradition, the vote was unanimous. "Great leaders of parties are not elected, they are evolved," a Conservative M. P. is quoted as saying in "British Political Parties": "The leader is there and we all know it when he is there."

LONDON, May 21--The British election campaign, now nearing its end, has been, serious and decorous. But the campaign itself is only half, and the less important half, of the story. Absence of bitterness among a majority of the candidates and the electorate's calm approach to the issues are balanced by the probability that Thursday's decision will be as important to the political development of this conntry as was the Labor landslide of 1945.

WASHINGTON, May 21--There are several reasons why President Eisenhower has been able to shift our foreign policy attitudes toward a Big Four conference at the summit and toward East-West trade, and quietly notify dissenters that they must adjust themselves to these changes, without raising the political and popular storm of protest that would have followed similar procedures by his predecessor.

BOISE, Idaho, May 21 (UP)-- Leonard W. Hall, Republican national chairman, defended tonight President Eisenhower's "partnership" water and power policy, which has been under Democratic attack in Congress. "The partnership policy," he told a Republican fund-raising dinner, "means we want local agencies, either public or private, to develop as much energy as they can.

GLAN-CARLO MENOTTI'S latest opera, The Saint of Bleecker Street, now makes its appearance in in "original cast" recording (R. C.A. Victor, two disks). Thanks to this recording, operagoers unable to make up their minds on what they think of "The Saint" may hear and rehear the score at their leisure.
BOSTON. WELL along the way to hardened arteries is the generation that sat clutching hands, first in a Broadway theatre and later in movie houses across the land, under the spell of "Seventh Heaven."

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that he was more confident than ever of victory for the Democratic road construction bill he is sponsoring. The Senate has debated the issue for a day.

Fordham University will hold its 110th commencement exercises June 8 at the Bronx campus, Third Avenue and Foardham Road. Graduate and undergraduate degrees will be conferred on 1,300 students. Eight honorary degrees also will be given.

DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia-- This resort is proving one of Yugoslavia's major tourist attractions. Every year, thousands of foreigners are visiting the tiny walled city on the Adriatic which once rivaled Venice as a commercial power, and now is enticing tourist trade from the French and Italian Rivieras.

TO meet the challenge of a constantly hungry, ever more populous world, the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization was set up in 1945. The FAO was charged with, stimulating agricultural production wherever and however it could.

SAIGON, May 21 (AP)--Premier Diem's Government and its nationalist supporters struck new blows today at the absent Chief of State Bao Dai. Both moves strengthened the drive for the playboy former Emperor's eventual ouster.

IN his first novel, Joseph Viertel has set himself an ambitious goal, the odyssey of a typical Central--European family before and during World War II. When Debbie, the pretty daughter of a wealthy Viennese family, married Vie Mamorek, engineer, tennis champion and man-about-Prague, the horizon seemed cloudless.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --The sponsor of the compulsory military reserve bill shelved by the House proposed today that state Governors help work out an acceptable substitute.

WATER LILY leaves are beginning to show in pools and ponds where hardy varieties of these plants are growing. Other water plants, too, are sending up green spikes. Now is the time to clean out ornamental pools, before plants put forth too much growth.
The fifty-eighth running of the International Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday resulted in a one-two-three finish for horses trained by G.H. (Pete) Bostwick.

THE story of the Brownings is romantic enough to bear countless retellings. Mrs. Burnett has told it with delicacy and perception. She shows us Ba Barrett as a precocious child, alternately pampered and chilled by her inflexible father.
Both sides in the cold war were maneuvering for position last week as the meeting at "the summit" drew nearer.
ROME, May 21--Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce will leave for Washington by air Friday to consult with the State Department. She will also take a vacation and return to Rome in July.

WHEN young Mrs. John Smith of Toronto was suddenly widowed, with an invalid mother and three small children to support, she eked out a meager living from dressmaking by taking in roomers. One of them was the stage manager of the Cummings Stock Company.

IN the House and Senate, companion, pieces of legislation are now pending which, if enacted into law, will be helpful to those stamp dealers who for twenty years have been cooperating with the Government in disposing of the $1 and $2 hunting-permit (the so-called "duck") stamps that are required on the licenses of hunters of wildfowl.
ATHENS, May 21--A Foreign Office spokesman said tonight Greece would cancel courtesy calls by the British Fleet until further notice.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21-- The American Baptist Convention has found its ten-yearold juvenile protection program "embarrassingly successful." The program is based on the premise that juvenile delinquents need more than "teaching and preaching."

AUCKLAND, New Zealand-- The first thing to remember in planning a New Zealand visit is that the seasons here are reversed. When it is spring in the United States, it is fall in New Zealand; the northern summer coincides with the New Zealand winter.

THE Annapolis Valley Apple Blossom Festival, which is scheduled for next Friday, Saturday and Sunday, is the opening gun of Nova Scotia's summer season. A highlight will be the Acadian Bicentennial celebration. Motorists will for the first time cross the new Canso Causeway that links the mainland of Nova Scotia with Cape Breton Island.

WITH the aid of William Congreve and Jean Anouilh, Proscenium Productions has, after two hits in a row at the Cherry Lane Theatre in Greenwich Village, achieved an identity all its own in the random off-Broadway world.

SOME of the highest peaks and largest mountain mosseast of the Rockies lie in the great Southern Appalachian Mountains. And a gem section of that range is the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a 500,000-acre wonderland visited by more than a million visitors every year.
WASHINGTON, May 21--Informed Washington officials expressed the belief tonight that the meeting of the Big Four heads of government would be arranged despite the Pravda attack.
DETROIT, May 21 (AP)--Duke Maas, a rookie, pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 3-2 victory over Cleveland today. The setback knocked the Indians out of the American League lead.
Work is under way on the transformation of the former John Wanamaker store at Broadway and Eighth Street to a merchandise mart for hard goods.

ONE of our thoughtful readers was suggesting in our letters column last week that a plausible use of Cinerama, the three-panel mergedimage screen, might be for presenting something like "pictorial symphonies."

What new services would be required and how much would they cost if 100 families moved into a medium-large city? The American Society of Planning Officials has been making a study of the matter and has prepared some answers.

Sun-Sapped Spring Without doubt the sun is the most ruinous thing about spring. Everything else can be borne. In the spring the grass grows like Jack's beanstalk, and daylightsaving gives an extra hour in which to cut it before supper--two misfortunes, but bearable.
The latest apartment development in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan's East Side is the twenty-story building at 30 Park Avenue, which is now receiving tenants.

STRONG right arm of the cook-in-haste is the frozen food industry, which calls attention these days to its completely prepared products. For women who have constant or occasional need of help in the kitchen, 330 packers are now freezing more than 100 precooked preparations.
Despita electronic sounding equipment, the best way of finding shoals is by throwing the old-fashioned lead over the side, according to the Navy Hydrographic Office.

PROFESSOR TOYNBEE has called Lord Acton "one of greatest minds among modern Western historians." Yet, besides a number of essays and book reviews, mostly written in his younger years, Acton left, when he died at the age of almost 70, no work to bear witness to his reputation.

LONDON, May 21--Billy Graham, the young, handsome, intensely sincere American evavgelist who struck London's curiosity and sympathy last year, has been back here the past week, preaching to the largest night-by-night crowds of his career.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Representative Frances P. Bolton, who has been working for fifteen years on the problem of a national nursing shortage, now hopes to see it solved by a joint commission of Congress.
Diamonds flashed again in the news last week--artificially produced diamonds. The diamonds were unimportant. Much more important were the discoveries made in the effort to produce them.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21--Belgrade is busy and excited over the forthcoming visit of the Soviet leaders.

THE Supreme Court is pondering its decision on how and when to carry out its ruling of a year ago that public school segregation is unconstitutional. It is therefore timely to examine the relationship between law and mores, between the decrees of courts and Legislatures and the vast body of community beliefs which shape private action.

ANKARA. TURKEY'S state radio is beginning to speak with an American accent. Programs patterned on Arthur Godfrey's "Talent Scouts," "Information Please" and other staples of American broadcasting rapidly are being introduced to the delight of the radio-conscious Turks.

The writer of the following letter has been admitted to practice before the Board of Immigration Appeals and the Immigration and Naturalization Service by the Department of Justice. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Russian propagandists talk about the "American Iron Curtain" which, of course, exists only in their imagination.
Under a blue sky and a glinting sun, 30,000 uniformed men and women paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon in observance of Armed Forces Day.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y.--With the aid of science, the New York State Thruway Authority now believes it can foil practically every attempt by toll collectors and drivers to rob it of its revenues. There are said to be at least 139 ways in which collectors and Truck drivers have cheated toll roads, bridges and tunnels across the country.

IT'S helpful, we suppose, for social scientists and students of the past to have a nice flexible phrase to wrap around a period of history. Terms like "The Age of Reason" or "The Age of Elegance" sum up neatly (though incompletely) certain characteristic qualities of a time.

SUSAN, aged 18, poorly trained but courageous and fired with zeal, sets out to teach a one-room school in Pickwick Mills, a rundown community in the Southern Mountains. She soon finds herself obliged to remake the community.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 21--Home runs by Dan McFadden and Charley Broll paced Lawrenceville School's nine to a 7-5 triumph over The Hill School today. The victory avenged a 7-6 setback handed the Lawrentians by the Pennsylvanians last week.

SWIMMING pools, though not yet standard home equipment, are steadily moving closer to that status. Thanks largely to modern plastics which permit low cost installations and easy maintenance, swimming pools are to be found each year in many more thousands of "average" back yards from coast to coast.

THERE are so many virtues to this magnificent retelling of the Nibelungenlied--the saga of Siegfried and Brunhilde-- that it is difficult to list them all. It is a joy to watch Edith Simon's superior mind at work filling the bare outlines of a familiar epic and embroidering with deft fingers.

While some twenty art exhibitions are to open this week, the signs of the close of the season are nevertheless at hand. The first announcement of an exhibition to run through the summer is among the events scheduled.

THE signs and portents, noted, examined and translated by seers between Cape Hatteras and Cape Cod, all indicate that coastal anglers between these points will enjoy one of the best fishing seasons in years.

GROTON, Conn.--The world's first submarine library has been open here at the General Dynamics' Electric Boat Division shipyard for less than two months, but already many visitors have discovered that submarine lore can be fascinating.

AT 59, from obscure semi-retirement at his tree-lined estate in California, Paul Muni has returned to frenzied Broadway in "Inherit the Wind," for a second fling with fame. Theatrical crepe-hangers who had been reciting Muni epitaphs for ten years or so have been confounded by his portrayal of Clarence Darrow that critics have hailed as "superb," "brilliant," "magnificent," "inspired," "unforgettable."

INDUSTRIAL activity is hitting a new peak. The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity has again gone through the ceiling and now is more than 13 per cent ahead of a year ago. Steel production is at record levels and is up 37 per cent from a year ago.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 21 --Haaren High's John Gibson set a meet record of 6 feet 4 3/4 inches in the high jump at the ninth annual Englewood memorial interscholastic track and field games today.

LONDON has jumped into the zarzuela field with both feet. In two or three mass releases it has issued no fewer than twelve complete zarzuelas and an additional orchestral disk that gives Preludios e Intermedios from a number of others.
FRAMLINGHAM, England, May 21--This quiet town, where in 1553 Mary learned she was Queen of England, is the center of an odd fight for a seat in Parliament.
NEWARK, May 21 (AP)--Frederick C. Breidenbach, who had been Mayor of Newark between 1922 and 1925, died in Martland Medical Center today. He was 78 years old.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Apply a threepurpose spray to roses to prevent aphids, chewing insects and diseases. Destroy tent caterpillar nests by spraying with a DDT aerosol bomb. Dust with rotenone to check flea beetles that chew neat holes in foliage.

MIAMI, Fla., May 21--The Southern Baptist Convention approved today a report that "noted with gratitude" recent developments that promised more emphasis on separation of church and state, especially in Latin American countries.

The irresponsibility that has been displayed in the House of Representatives on the question of a pretrained and adequate reserve force makes it necessary for the Senate to take prompt action. The House has played politics with our national safety and we cannot afford this diversion.
The initials "B.V.D." have a very special meaning in this country and abroad, and the company sporting the famed three letters is both happy and worried about the situation at the same time.

REMEMBER Martin? He's the imaginative young New Yorker whose strange experience was recorded last year with word and camera in "The Secret of the Two Feathers." Well, now Martin has rigged up a tele-spacer (as if TV isn't enough!) and reaches a pretty little girl named Aknele-Alpha, who lives on one of nine moons revolving around Saturn.

There is a common and accepted fiction that fishermen go fishing to catch fish. Some do, of course; but more don't. The fish caught are really only a lesser part of the catch. The greater part is the day in the open, the little things that feed the eyes, the ears, and the soul, though we are so perverse and so practical that we seldom talk about them.

THE Potsdam Conference of the heads of the British, United States and Soviet Governments met in July, 1945. It was just a few days later that the world formally entered the atomic age. Then came the "cold war." New nations, including such a giant as India, were officially born and came of age.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 11--A cold war between motorist and cyclist is going on in this deceptively serene town. Coexistence is no mere political abstraction but a prerequisite to maintenance of life and limb.

Inoculation of the city's public school children with Salk antipolio vaccine will be resumed tomorrow. Thirty-five thousand children in 164 public, private and parochial schools are scheduled to get the shots during the day.
The New York chapter of the Steamship Historical Society of America "took apart" an 11,000ton passenger liner here last week.

THE title of John Stewart Collis' new book is from Keats: "The moving waters at their priestlike task of pure ablution round earth's human shores." As in his memorable "The Triumph of the Tree," Mr. Collis again interprets natural miracles in a style and manner all his own.

EVERY student of our history is familiar with the moving words of "New Englands First Fruits": "After God had carried us safe to New England, and we had builded our houses, provided necessaries for our livelihood, reared convenient places for Gods worship, and setled the Civil Government:

LOS ANGELES, May 21--A National Guard jet pilot flew coast-to-coast round trip in less than eleven and one-half hours today. He realized the air age dream of breakfast in Los Angeles, lunch in New York and home again in time for supper.
The New York Employing Printers Association, representing 843 member companies in the metropolitan area, will observe the ninetieth anniversary of its founding tomorrow.

PROKOFIEFF: Suite from Semyon Kotko; Rolf Kleinert and Symphony Orchestra of Radio Berlin (Urania). A suite taken from Prokofieff's opera, composed in 1940. It is nationalistic and powerful, with sections suggestive of music like the composer's "Alexander Nevaky."
An untried venture in insurance --the public offering of variable annuities--is under consideration in New Jersey. It has aroused wide interest in insurance and investment circles.
VIENNA, May 21--A bid by the Soviet-controlled labor federation for a united front with the free trade unions was spurned here today.

GEORGE JESSEL, or Georgie Jessel, is among the last of a wonderfully florid and magnificently ungrammatical body of performers whose freedom from inhibition, hoarse voices, dangling participles, egomania and splendid, although sometimes inexplicable, talents endeared them to a generation, most of whose members are pushing at least 45 now.

LOS ANGELES, May 21--The increasing emphasis of the Roman Catholic Church on the role of the Virgin Mary has "widened the breach" between that faith and "all other Christian communions," it was declared here today.

A cautiously optimistic report on foreign affairs set the stage for a midweek recovery in the stock market. Earlier, prices had sagged in continued slow trading to the lowest levels in more than a month.

MODESTO, Calif., May 21 --The University of Texas sprint relay team broke the t 18-year-old world record for the 440-yard event tonight with a clocking of 0:40.2 seconds. This was three-tenths of a second better than the old world mark.
VIENNA, May 21--United States and European trade unionists do not speak the same language. This is as true with regard to the British as it is of the French, Italian or German.
CHICAGO, May 21--Hope of averting a strike by members of the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen against most of the nation's major railroads appeared bright this week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21--A lively battle for Mayor at the general election next fall has been assured by the results of this week's primary. The Republicans and Democrats both nominated strong candidates.

LONDON. BRITAIN'S first "TV election" will be held Thursday, and to say that the two contending parties, Conservative and Labor, are worried is to put it mildly. At the previous general election in October, 1951, there were only 1,000,000 television licenses in the country.

MIKHAIL SOLOVIEV is unusual among post-war immigrants from Russia. He is a writer of certain merit, and in the years between 1930 and 1941 he occupied a minor role in the ever-shifting world which is known in Russia as that of the "Soviet intelligentsia."

LOS ANGELES. As the fourth major Eastern orchestra to display its accomplishments to the West Coast in recent years, the New York Philharmonic -Symphony Orchestra was recently as warmly received by southern Californians as the Philadelphia Orchestra had been in 1948, the N.B.C. Symphony in 1950 and the Boston Symphony in 1954.
THE iris reign is a long one, stretching across seasons with bloom on Reticulatas in late March to the Dichotomas in August (not to mention second bloom on some spring varieties in the fall).

A NEW, colorless liquid paint additive prevents skin formation on half-used cans of paint, enamel or varnish, according to the manufacturer. The liquid works by preventing oxidation of the dryers in the paint, but is claimed not to affect the drying rate or color of paint when it is applied.
Former and present members of the Parnassus Club joined yesterday to end the club's thirtysix -year history on Morningside Heights.

CHICAGO, May 21--Chicago's attack on slums and the housing shortage added 64,972 dwelling units from 1950 through 1954. This was almost double the volume of construction from 1945 through 1949, when 33,034 units were built.

TORSION bar suspension as a means of increasing a motor car's riding comfort and readability has caught the attention of virtually all the automotive manufacturers in this country. While the principle involved in this type of car construction dates back many centuries, the modern application to motor vehicles is comparatively new.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 21-- Transportation and planning experts met here today to discuss San Francisco's master plan for coping with the traffic maze that affects most cities.

LIKE any United States Army paratrooper, the American beaver is hitting the silk these days on a mission financed by the taxpayers, for the public good. How did this 40-pound specimen of castor canadensis get such an assignment, and why will others be picked for similar jobs in California this summer?
GUATEMALA, May 21--President Carlos Castillo Armas is facing growing restiveness over his policies. This is true of his supporters as well as opposition groups.
LONDON. SINCE September the scarcest theatre tickets in London have been those giving entrance to Terence Rattigan's "Separate Tables." In England, Mr. Rattigan's plays are usually popular.

SOME people enjoy gardening and others enjoy their gardens. In the long run it does not matter which attitude gives the greater pleasure, for both are based on the planting and the upkeep of a garden or property.

On Thursday the British people will go to the polls in a general election to vote for a new House of Commons. Such an election is the equivalent of a Presidential election in the United States, but there the resemblance ends.
An increasing number of cities throughout the country have adopted regulations to curb the excessive display of commercial signs in downtown business districts.

MANHATTAN, Kan. SINCE 1929 the United States has experienced what the quantitative -minded call a "religious boom." Though some churchmen doubt that the figures measure any genuine spiritual growth, statistics nevertheless show that our total church membership has gone up 90 per cent while our population has increased only 31.4 per cent.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 --Ken MacKenzie hurled a fourhitter today as Yale won the Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball championship by halting Harvard, 8 to 2, on Soldiers Field.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May, 21--Italy's Nicola Pietrangell and Orlando Sirola, two long shots in a field that included the United States and Wimbledon champions, won their way into the final of the Wiesbaden international tennis tournament today to cap a wave of upsets.
One of the auction sales this week pays exclusive attention to outdoor decor. On Friday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, a recent shipment here from France will be offered.

Fordham University's basketball team will return to Madison Square Garden this December after an absence of a dozen years. The Rams are scheduled to participate in the Holiday Festival tournament at the Eighth Avenue arena, Dec. 26, 28 and 30.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP)--Harrison J. (Doc) Weaver, trainer for the St. Louis Cardinals baseball Club for the last twentyeight years, died of a heart attack early today at his apartment at the Forest Park Hotel. He was 68 years old.

The writer of the following letter is a consultant in medical research planning and a lecturer in biostatistics at the Columbia University School of Public Health and the New York Medical College. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Waldemar Kaempffert's column on the Salk polio vaccine in The Times of May 15 presents several interesting facts and opinions.
LOS ANGELES, May 21 (AP)-- Tom Courtney of Fordham says track officials "robbed him of victory" in the 880-yard run at the Coliseum Relays last night.

ANYONE with an old ouija board in the attic would oblige by rescuing it for Mary Martin. To understand her need for wisdom, regular and occult, it is only necessary to indicate that there are at least four projects vying for attention, each packing enough enticement to keep her in an airy state of indecision:

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 21 --At a tea yesterday at the home of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. John Tupper Cole in Halesite, plans were furthered and committees named for the Huntington benefit horse show for the Young Men's Christian Association on July 17.
The prospect of a preacher's life seems promising to three young women who are to be graduated Tuesday evening from Union Theological Seminary, Broadway at 120th Street.

IS there a public for modern works of quality? One likes to think so. But there are times when one does not find out for the simple reason that the public does not get a chance to see and hear for itself.
BALI, Indonesia, May 15-- Balinese believe that if one has lived a life free from sin he will be reincarnated after death and rewarded by being allowed to be born again in Bali.
HONG KONG, May 21--V.K. Krishna Menon, Indian diplomat, ended today a ten-day mission to Peiping to sound out top Chinese Communist officials on how to relax "tension" in the Formosa area.

At the age of 40 Lin Yutang was already an ancient Chinese sage, and he continued to practice the profession gracefully as the years began to catch up with him. Now turning 60, he has cast his eye upon the future and described, tongue in cheek, a Utopia established on a remote Pacific island by a group of polyglot refugees from that Ten Years War which followed World War III.
PARIS, May 20 -- Officials here consider France will be unable to agree to further economic or political integration of Europe until after the Parliamentary election next year.
BUENOS AIRES, May 21-- The Greek-Argentine shipowner, Aristotle Socrates Onassis, has offered to put part of his tanker fleet under the Argentine flag.
The National Council for U.S. Art, Inc., completed last week plans for its first competition among painters and sculptors for art to be placed in the United Nations Building.

It is refreshing to be told that, in spite of Representative B. Carroll Reece's jitters about such matters, American foundations are going to deal increasingly with "controversial" issues--especially when this opinion is expressed by those who know most about foundation activities.
FOR the next six weeks, when she is not appearing as "Mama" on television, or rehearsing for the program. Peggy Wood will be spending much of her time preparing for her third pilgrimage to Norway.
GAZA, May 21--Israeli and Egyptian troops fought a twohour battle today with mortars, artillery and machine guns near Kisufim, the scene of two clashes in the Gaza Strip earlier this week.

MULCHING is a yeararound operation, not just for winter protection. It is outranked only by sun, water and fertilizer in terms of beneficial effect on plant growth. But even if mulching were not valuable to plants it would still rate as one of the gardener's greatest allies, for it is unsurpassed as a labor saver.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 21-- Cornell set a course record for Carnegie Lake today in winning the Carnegie Cup for the third successive year.

BALTIMORE, May 21--St. Vincent, who learned to race over England's grassy slopes, set an American turf course record today. He galloped to a two-and-a-half length victory over Kaster in the $31,300 Dixie Handicap.
Several of the nation's communities are teaching their residents how to clean up blighted areas and preserve the conditions of their better neighborhoods.
Stock market prospects have Wall Street analysts and the public wavering.
IN KAZAKHSTAN, U.S.S.R., May 3--A built-in samovar on a railway sleeping car is a handy thing--if you like Russian tea. And you can learn to like it in two days on a slow train through Kazakhstan.
PARIS, May 21--American political folkways, including guitar -playing, hillbilly electioneering and pledges to pay the voters $30 every Thursday, have amazed Europeans.

MEN are known by the symbols they keep. In modern times national symbols supplanted religious ones as the adhesives of society. America, lacking sufficient antiquity, made its patriotic symbols out of things or people rather than institutions, which only time's passage can sanctify.
BUENOS AIRES, May 21-- Late last night and early today the police arrested twoscore persons, including two Roman Catholic priests, on suspicion of "plot and conspiracy" against the Government.

A year and a half ago at mother left her daughter at Greer, a children's community at Hope Farm, N.Y., in the heart of Dutchess County. She arrived at Greer at 2 o'clock in the morning, woke the executive director, Dr. Randle Elliott, and announced that the school must take her child then and there.

The State Building Code Commission will hold a public conference Wednesday on the proposed state code applicable to general building or non-residential construction. The code is a voluntary one and will be promulgated this fall.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21-- Educators seeking methods of financing higher education were told tonight to stop trying to "keep up with the Joneses."

After twelve weeks of negotiations the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee has again suspended work without reaching agreement. As a result the whole complex disarmament problem, which has been under discussion for the past eight years, will have to be threshed out once more in the General Assembly and at the projected Big Power conference to determine whether and what further steps are possible under the prevailing circumstances.
There is little to indicate that Russia has given up its goal of dominating the world, Admiral Jerauld Wright declared last night.

LONDON. THE biggest annual poll of British filmgoers has placed Marlon Brando an easy first among the actors seen in the last year for his "On the Waterfront" performance, attracting some 2,000 votes more than his nearest rival, Rock Hudson, for his work in "Magnificent Obsession."

Here in Gotham the term commuter brings to mind the thousands who breakfast daily at their homes in Scarsdale or Great Neck or Montclair, come to our city for work and lunch, and then go home to dinner in the evening. Less well known, but by no means negligible, are those persons who commute here by air occasionally from Chicago, Detroit or cities similarly distant and follow a similar daily pattern at times.
MOSCOW, May 22--Substantial bonuses have been offered to Soviet farm workers to encourage the planting of corn. Penalties have been invoked on those who plant it improperly.

This is Teacher Recognition Day, so proclaimed by Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner. The Governor urges "the people in each community to join in tribute to teachers and in expression of appreciation for their services." He points out that "to our teachers falls the vital responsibility of helping to pass on to each new generation the wealth of the world's accumulated knowledge."
MILWAUKEE, May 22 (AP)-- Gene Conley gained his sixth victory for Milwaukee today, beating the Chicago Cubs, 5--1, with three-hit hurling.
VIENNA, May 22--Leaders of the world's free trade unions are concerned by the efforts of Yugoslav unions to infiltrate their ranks.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21-- A special commission is completing studies here for an investment totaling $1,000,000,000 in heavy industry by the SchneiderCreusot Group of France.
The "tinhorn politicians that La Guardia drove from City Hall ten years ago are back again." Councilman Robert E. Barnes, Republican of Queens, charged yesterday.

British sterling moved sharply lower last week, with the full impact of the selling coming on Friday, when it declined to $2.79, lowest since early March. Week's highest was $2.79 27/32, and the close at $2.79 1/16, a loss of 23/32 cent from the previous week. Forwards widened in sympathy with spot, and transferable sterling closed at $2.7705/.15.
Senator Irving M. Ives has warned Republicans in New York State to stop fighting over former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's role in party affairs.
CHICAGO, May 22 -- Delegates began arriving today for the fifty-ninth annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, which will open tomorrow and continue through Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, May 22--Total private and net public debt at the close of last year amounted to $606,000,000,000, a gain of 3 1/2 per cent compared with calendar 1953, the Government announced today.

If not New York's favorite dessert, cheesecake ranks very near the top of the list. And there always seems to be room for another, especially when it is as delicious as the airy-textured, smooth, "no-bake" cheesecake that Mrs. Anna Mason is introducing.

PARIS, May 22--The Popular Republican Movement, one of the parties in the coalition Government of Premier Edgar Faure, demanded tonight that the Government authorize an extension of the powers of the European Coal and Steel Community.
CHICAGO, May 22 -- Operations in May grain and soybean deliveries ended last week. Short covering gave the expiring futures a strong tone, but fluctuations were moderate.
Loans to brokers and dealers in securities by New York City member banks rose $55 millions in the week ended last Wednesday, to $1,870 millions, the highest figure touched in eleven years.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- Ambassador Leo Mates of Yugoslavia said today that he believed the coming visit to Belgrade of Soviet leaders would stimulate the Soviet satellites of Eastern Europe to "strive for increasing independence and freedom of action."

JERUSALEM, May 22 (UP)-- United States Ambassador Edward Lawson visited Premier Moshe Sharett today to express "grave concern" over recent Israeli attacks on Egyptian positions near Kisufim in the Gaza Strip.

Jack L. Sorensen of Cobb, Wis., bought thirty-two shares of General Motors stock only last March. Yesterday, he sat in Central Park enjoying the special dividend the corporation declared last week to honor him as its 500,000th current shareholder.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --The American Federation of Labor and its hotel workers union today asked for a Senate investigation of what they called "startling developments" in the forty-day-old Miami Beach, Fla., hotel strike.

BARNAUL, U. S. S. R., May 6 --A layman may conclude, after visiting the "new lands" of Kazakhstan and the Altai Krai, that there is a fair chance of success for the Soviet program to put into production 70,000,000 idle acres on the Eastern steppes.

Twelve honorary degrees will be awarded at Columbia University's 201st commencement exercises June 1. Recipients will include two United States Senators and others prominent in government, business, religion, science and education.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The right-wing Republican opposition in the Senate to President Eisenhower's new policy for negotiating with world communism has fallen upon meager days. Never a large faction, it appears to be shrinking and its collective voice to grow less articulate for these reasons:

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mme. Stavros Lambrinides of Athens of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna S. Lambrinidou, to Sperry Lea, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brooke Lea of New York, Lake Success, L. I., and Bellport, L. I. A July wedding in Paris is planned.
"Once Upon A Tailor," starring Oscar Karlweis finally reaches the Cort at 8 o'clock tonight. Baruch Lumet is the author of the comedy, based on Yiddish folklore.

MODESTO, Calif., May 22 (UP) --Athletes competing in the California relays last night today made application for three world records. The program furnished one of the most amazing onenight performances in the annals of track and field.
NEW DELHI, India, May 22 --Four hundred leaders of the bearded Sikhs have stood in front of policemen in the Indian Punjab, shouted a few words and marched off to jail.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You quite correctly point out in your editorial of May 11 entitled "Not All Giants" that all of us need constantly to "re-examine our preconceptions," particularly when interpreting statistics. You ask, "What about those 'giant corporations' which are supposed to have swallowed up most of the little businesses in the nation?"

KANSAS CITY, May 22 (AP)-- Dick Mayer of St. Petersburg, Fla., fired a 5-under-par 67 to pick up the winner's check of $4,000 in the Kansas City open golf tournament today with a 72-hole score of 271.
WASHINGTON, May 22--Du Mont Laboratories demonstrated today a new method of broadcasting live color television programs without conventional video cameras.

A house is the latest, and certainly the largest, object to be offered for sale at Westchester's Cross County Shopping Center. A model of this summer house, pictured above, is at the north end of the grounds, where it opens today for possible purchasers to investigate.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $67,637,538,548. They consist of Treasury bonds, certifiates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 22--The successes of a toy poodle, Ch. Wilber White Swan, continued today in the fifty-third show of the Long Island Kennel Club.

CINCINNATI, May 22 (UP)-- Southpaw Luis Arroyo of the St. Louis Cardinals needed relief for the last out of the game today, but snapped the Cincinnati Redlegs' six-game winning streak with a 5-2 victory in the second game of a double-header.
WASHINGTON, May 22--A panel of students agreed today that youth could and should accept responsibilities of citizenship whether the voting age he 18 or 21.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 --Paramount Pictures will put at least ten movies into production before the end of the year.

THE Interracial Fellowship Chorus is engaged in a ten-year project to do all of Haydn's masses. It already has given the "Theresien," the "Pauken" and the "St. Cecilia." Last night at its eighth annual spring concert at Town Hall, it added a fourth, the Great Organ Mass.
A manufacturing plant scheduled for formal opening in Naples, Italy, this week will demonstrate there effective transfer abroad of new American industrial techniques.

Most business histories are written at the behest of an industrialist who wants the warm hand of history to pat him on the back. There is a refreshing novelty in picking up the story of a company that earned nothing on its common stock last year.

An Ancient Family of Fish In the murky green water of a tank in the window of a pet shop on Nassau Street swims a family of black mollies. These little tropical fish, about as long as the bowl of a tablespoon, customarily keep house in the waters of Mexico and the southern United States.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 22--There is something about the traditional baseball game between prep schools that this modern age never has changed. It's the easy-going and friendly atmosphere that surrounds the diamond.

YONKERS, May 22 -- Nick Costes of Farrell, Pa., won the National Amateur Athletic Union marathon championship today. The 28-year-old grade school teacher raced over the 26-mile 385-yard course in 2 hours 31 minutes 12.4 seconds.
