New York's towboat industry has chugged its way out of the doldrums and is riding a business crest of squall-like intensity.

The directors of W. R. Grace Co. have elected as executive vice presidents Andrew B. Shea, J. C. Griswold and A. S. Rupley. J. Peter Grace, president of the international shipping and trading organization, said in a week-end announcement that the positions had been created as part of a realignment of executive responsibilities.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 22 (UP)--Maurice Trintignant of France drove a Ferrari to victory in the Grand Prix of Europe automobile race today at a record speed after the three favorites were forced out on the twisting circuit.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman again called on the United States yesterday to ratify promptly the United Nations genocide convention.

Wisconsin Power and Light Company is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe for 263,140 new shares of common stock at $25 a share at the rate of one new share for each ten shares held.
Gustave L. Becker, veteran music teacher and composer, celebrated his ninety-fourth birthday yesterday afternoon by presenting a program of his own compositions in Room 707 of the Steinway Building.
The nation's first "How to Invest Show" will open at 10 A. M. tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street. It will continue through May 30.
The assets of community foundations in the United States and Canada grew 10 per cent last year. Their charitable grants rose 6 per cent.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) --Don Freeland of Los Angeles was the fastest qualifier today in final time trials that filled the thirty-three-car field for the thirty-ninth 500-mile auto race next Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Aviation Week said today that Russia had displayed aircraft so advanced and so numerous it had shocked "even the top level and the most knowledgeable military aviation leaders in the Pentagon."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your May 11 issue reporting a change in the promotion policy in the New York public schools wherein children who are seriously retarded in reading will be "left back" is a major educational policy decision. The Board of Education of the City of New York should be commended for making this decision which under certain conditions will be beneficial for all of our children.

A Bronx housing development covering an entire square block is being acquired by B. H. Gordon, realty operator, who has signed a contract to buy 1312 to 1320 West Farms Road and 1011 to 1035 Freeman Street. The block contains 334 apartments and sixteen stores in twelve five-story buildings and is 430 by 318 by 500 feet.

CHICAGO, May 22 (UP)-- Johnny Groth drove in three runs with two doubles and a sacrifice fly today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 10-6 victory over the Kansas City Athletics in the second game to gain a split in the double-header before 8,878 fans.

LONDON, May 21--The wave of confidence that the Conservative Government will win the election on Thursday, which it sweeping through the city anc almost the whole country, has found substantial reflection in the stock markets.
LONDON, May 22--With only three days of campaigning left before the Parliamentary election, the Conservative party launched tonight a strong appeal for the support of Liberal voters.
The repercussions of last year's bitter proxy contest for control of the giant New York Central Railroad are still echoing.

All the Yankees were sorry that the American League schedule called for the Baltimore Orioles to move on after yesterday's double-header at the Stadium. None, though, regretted it more than Yogi Berra, whose three homers--two in the nightcap --led to the 5-0 and 7-5 victories over Paul Richards' cellar outfit.

LOS ANGELES, May 22--The president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. was sharply critical here today of the "isolationism and go-it-alone-ism" of "most" of California's public figures.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 22 --The leader of B'nai B'rith stressed tonight the need for international disarmament programs that "are not showpieces to be taken out at conferences once in a while."

WASHINGTON, May 22--Detailed designs for the hull of an atomic-powered merchant ship have been completed and sent to the White House. President Eisenhower has proposed that such a ship tour the world in the interest of peace.

DETROIT, May 22 (UP)--Early Wynn permitted only a clean single to right field in the fourth inning by Fred Hatfield as he hurled the Cleveland Indians to a one-hit, 4-0 triumph over the Detroit Tigers today.
The New York State Automobile Association yesterday again urged defeat of the proposed $750,000,000 highway bond issue despite pleas to reconsider its stand.
Ship charter market rates rose again last week, although the volume of business transacted fell off sharply.

A long-range program by which universities here would manufacture polio vaccine for the city's youngsters was suggested yesterday by City Council President Abe Stark. His proposal, based on the experience of Canada, would seek a safe and adequate supply for years to come.
LONDON, May 22--Thousands of dock workers in four of Britain's most important ports are scheduled to strike tomorrow at 8 A. M.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- President Eisenhower helped the Jewish War Veterans of the United States of America dedicate a National Shrine to the Jewish War Dead and new national headquarters in the capital today.
WASHINGTON, May 22--Government decisions to halt the poliomyelitis vaccination program and delay this year's immunization goals were deemed possible here tonight.

HONG KONG, Monday, May 23--After an eleven-day exploratory mission to Red China, the Indian diplomat, V. K. Krishna Menon said here today that, while there were "obstacles" in the way of a peaceful solution in the Formosa area, these were not "insurmountable."
POPLAR, Wis., May 22 (AP)-- The United States dedicated a school building memorial to its top ace of World War II, Maj. Richard Ira Bong, here today.
PITTSBURGH, May 22--If allowance is made for specific Summer curtailment because of vacations there will be no slump in steel activity.

A standardized street-litter fine of $10, payable by mail, was advocated yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh. He said he hoped to introduce the procedure in the fall. The plan will be similar to the payment of parking fines, and collections should be relatively high, he noted.

DADDY CHAYEFSKY'S new play, "The Catered Affair," seen last night over Channel 4, was not in the same league with his "Marty." This time, the playwright abandoned the stark simplicity that has been his trademark and tried to tell a family story from too many points of view.

PITTSBURGH, May 22--Beating an impending downpour of rain by a matter of minutes, the Giants today concluded this portion of their extended tour with a grand flourish. They trounced the Pirates in both ends of a double-header, 5--2 and 5--3.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- Ambassador V. K. Wellington Koo of Nationalist China said today a truce was possible in the Formosa area if the Chinese Communists would just stop shooting.
The Board of Higher Education is preparing a request for a two-year community college in the Bronx.

Four hundred Knights Templars paraded through the neighborhood of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) yesterday afternoon on their way to their twenty-eighth annual church service in the cathedral.
New York City's public school system is being harassed and sapped by increasing problems of discipline and delinquency.

PARIS, May 22--The Paris stock exchange has come out of its recent dip. However, the very rapidity of its recovery is a source of worry in financial circles, where this is looked upon as a sign of skittishness.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Government is expecting a communication from Moscow setting forth objections to the United States' position on the projected top-level Big Four conference.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 22-- No further large-scale movement of refugees from Communist North Vietnam to the south is foreseen here.

THE bronze plaques in the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown contain many superlatives. That's undoubtedly as it should be because the diamond immortals demand superlatives, so extraordinary were their performances. Yet only one tablet contains the descriptive words, "most graceful." This phrase is used for Napoleon Lajoie, and for him alone.

Alfred Duggan, author of "Conscience of the King" and several other historical novels, has a work of nonfiction on Knopf's list. Called "Julius Caesar," it will be issued June 13 as a volume in Great Life in Brief Series.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22-- The Argentine police continued their raids early today, arresting Roman Catholic priests and members of the Catholic Action. Peronista newspapers said there were numerous arrests.
A Federal Maritime Board member said here yesterday that a second American superliner, now in the planning stage, might be atom-powered.

Albert Harris of Cincinnati has purchased the Knickerbocker Hotel, a sixteen-story building containing 400 rooms at 120 West Forty-fifth Street, near Times Square. He operates the Harris chain of hotels in leading cities and plans improvements costing $250,000 at the Knickerbocker, which was sold by Samuel Rosen Associates through the Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation and Charles H. Moore, brokers.
WASHINGTON, May 22--India is ahead of Communist China in the race toward industrialization, two Stanford University economists reported today.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 22-- This seaside resort, having crowned many a beauty queen, saw a new title created today. Mrs. Sunday School Teacher of 1955 was proclaimed by the American Baptist Convention.
Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner will confer here this week in an effort to select a new Transit Authority and a committee to study state-city fiscal relations.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 22--The Dutch Government has begun a diplomatic offensive to win the release of about thirty-five Dutch nationals held for more than a year by Indonesia.
The Most Rev. Dennis Moynahan, Bishop of Kerry, Ireland, offered mass yesterday for members of the Kerrymen's Association in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
TOKYO, May 22--The Symphony of the Air, formerly Arturo Toscanini's N. B. C. Symphony, will end this week a triumphant three-week tour of Japan.

IN his introduction to the fourth volume of Boswell's journals, "Boswell On The Grand Tour: Italy, Corsica and France 17651766"* Frank Brady writes: "James Boswell's main concerns during the period of his life covered by this volume were sex, religion and politics--the three subjects of conversation forbidden by polite society."

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The Atomic Energy Commission proposed rules today under which it would give United States business men confidential or secret information to develop civilian uses of atomic energy.
PARIS, May 22--Experts in foreign affairs here are disturbed by the readiness of the public in Western Europe to assume that the "cold war" is about over.
The action of the House Appropriations Committee last week in sharply reducing the President's budget recommendations for shipping caused keen disappointment in the maritime industry here.

WINDSOR, England, May 22 (AP)--Billy Graham, 36 years old, is an ordained Southern Baptist minister, but he has always been at pains to emphasize an interdenominational approach in his crusades. Queen Elizabeth is titular head of the Church of England and "defender of the faith."
Men students in three Columbia University dormitories broke the Sunday afternoon calm of Amsterdam Avenue yesterday in what they described as a "riot."

"Hard to Get," a television play that starred Gisele Mackenzie on May 12, will be repeated with the same cast on the "Justice" program June 9. The "Kraft Television Theatre" is believed to be the only series that has previously repeated a play ("Patterns") only four weeks after the original showing.
Serge P. Scheer is a French business man of American connections who has just been made an officer of the Legion of Honor for raising French oil production to 11,000 barrels a flay.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 22--The sixty-five skippers appearing for the Beach Point Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today were greeted by fluky airs that made for trying sailing.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with dismay the letter of Simon N. Gazan in which he condemns bus drivers in his long list of complaints.

Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended down 1 to 25 points last week. The largest recession was in the near-by July delivery and the smallest in the distant July. In the week before the market showed gains of 21 to 26 points.
The annual memorial program of the Society of the 307th Infantry of the Seventy-seventh Division of World War I was held yesterday at the Regimenal Grove in Central Park.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 22--The Government crisis affected stock prices here last week. There were considerable offerings, especially in internationals, and as a result the index fell from 193.72 to 190.56.
WASHINGTON, May 22--An attempt to override President Eisenhower's veto of the postal pay bill and final action on his reciprocal trade program top Congress' agenda this week.

LONDON, May 22 -- Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, heard Billy Graham, American evangelist, preach today. He conducted morning service in the private chapel at the Royal Lodge, Windsor.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22--Many responsible diplomats here believe that not even President Tito knows what will turn out to be the main subject of his negotiations with the Russians.
For the first time in its fiftyseven-year-old history the Roman Catholic parish of St. Philip Neri, Grand Concourse and 201st Street in the Bronx, had a mass offered in the Russian rite yesterday.

PENRHYNDEUDRAETH, Wales, May 22-- Tradition insures that Wales will remain at this election a main rallying ground of the Labor party, and that her conservatism will express itself in ways that will not directly benefit the Conservative party.

TREDEGAR, Wales, May 22-- Half way between this dreary mining village and the iron town of Ebbw Vale is a great bare comb called Waunpound and locally known as The Mountain. Here the people of Wales used to hold their horse fairs and herds of closecoupled, thick-maned wild ponies still graze the naked heath.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A group prominent in public affairs urged today that the United States take the lead in organizing a "partnership" of industrial and underdeveloped nations to stimulate the economic growth of all.
WASHINGTON, May 22--A Girl Scouts memorial to Mrs. Herbert Hoover will be dedicated Tuesday at Rockwood, camping center of the organization in Maryland near here.

The British Government recently asked the British Council, a semiofficial body charged with supporting cultural relations abroad, to set up a special committee to promote closer cultural relations with the Soviet Union. The new committee has already proposed to the Soviet Embassy in London the exchange of British and Soviet delegations in ten different areas as diverse as law, engineering, and local government.

CHICAGO, May 22--The Chicago Transit Authority in April earned $195,240 in excess of operating expenses and other financial obligations the agency reported today. This compared with a deficit of $2,329 in April, 1954.

Though the ink is scarcely dry on the Paris pacts which make a sovereign and rearmed Germany a member of the Western European Union and the North Atlantic alliance, a new issue, which could nullify these pacts, is forging into the forefront of international discussion and appears likely to play a big role at the projected Big Power conference this summer.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 22 --The Chief Minister of Punjab Province was dismissed by the Provincial Governor today because he "no longer commands the confidence of the majority of the Legislature."

A few months ago certain critics of the Administration were directing harsh words in the latter's direction because it refused to intervene directly in the recovery effort with a huge program of deficit spending. It was imperative, they warned, that the gross national product keep rising at all times (regardless, one had to assume, of how this was achieved).

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) The Federation of American Scientists called today for a speed-up in dispersal of industries and populations to meet the danger of attack by atomic bombers or intercontinental missiles.
SEED-CORN-size transistors are being planted atop 8,400 street lamps on Manhattan and in the Bronx. They automatically switch the lamps on or off, according to the amount of light around them.
Abraham Feinberg, civic leader and philanthropist, was elected president of the Development Corporation of Israel by the organization's board of governors yesterday.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz, third ranking American from Long Beach, Calif., easily defeated England's Elaine Watson, 6--3, 6--2, today in the final of the Wiesbaden international tennis tournament.
The Festival of Music in New York's Summer Festival, June 21 through Labor Day, will offer more than 100 concerts to suit every musical mood.
A priority system of street repairs to minimize traffic snarls was proposed yesterday by Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan Borough President.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling defended yesterday the recently designated "cult of reassurance" and those Protestant ministers who are being identified as apostles of this "new religion."
The Dodgers chilled the Phillies, 8--3, before 15,459 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, giving Carl Erskine his sixth victory.

Thirty crews from twelve colleges were drawn for lanes yesterday in the intercollegiate championships. The fifty-third regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association will be held Saturday, June 18, on Onondaga Lake, Syracuse.
LONDON, May 23 -- A strike of 18,400 dockworkers seriously curtailed operations in six British ports today. But there was some hope tonight that the dispute would be settled quickly.
Tammany Hall, New York County's representative of the Democratic party, decided last night to make itself more democratic.

The Hertz Corporation, world's largest auto rental and truck leasing concern, will have gross revenues approximating, $35,000,000 this year, stockholders were told at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday. This would compare with $21,000,000 gross revenues in 1954 and $13,500,000 five years ago.
The Republican state chairman announced yesterday a new party goal for 1956 -- the election of a Legislature that can override the vetoes of a Democratic Governor.

Few of the 21,398 fans at Belmont Park yesterday could "see" the Sanford Stud Farms' Mohawk Valley in the feature race. That, of course, only made it better for those who liked the filly. Not only did she win, but she paid $40. $15.30 and $9 for $2 across the board in so doing.
Delinquency in the New York public schools is as hard to define as it is to evaluate or to control.

It is easy to forget that asking a girl to a dance is not, at a certain age, a simple business. Or to turn it around: it is easy to forget that it is not a simple business for a girl to persuade a boy to ask her to a dance.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today began a final revision of a report on its recent investigation of the stock market.
The rate at which children showed up for poliomyelitis vaccinations in New York City slipped again yesterday -- to 66.2 per cent.
The curtain was quietly lowered yesterday on a Marilyn Monroe fifty-two feet tall. The poster picture of the actress adorned the facade of Loew's State Theatre in Times Square.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- Ted Williams smashed a towering 395-foot home run and Norm Zauchin connected for two circuit clouts tonight to give the Boston Red Sox a 4-3 victory over the New York Giants. The exhibition baseball game was called after six and one-half innings.

JAMESBURG, N. J., May 23 -- Emery Thomas of the Forest Hill C. C. today led the New Jersey qualifiers for the National Professional Golfers Association tournament. Thomas' 36-hole score of 135 at the Forsgate Country Club included a course- record 65.
The port's longshoremen moved yesterday into the final phase of their court attack on the hiring regulations imposed by the Waterfront Commission on April 1.

A merchandising plan and store identification program for independent food stores throughout the country will be undertaken by members of the United States Wholesale Grocers' Association. As the first stage of the program, members of the association will be franchised to use the name "Shopworth Specials" as identification for a weekly sales program and promotional package for local stores.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Chester A. Bowles urged today an expansion of United States economic aid to under-developed countries to meet the challenge of a change in Soviet tactics.
MOSCOW, May 23 -- Despite the sharp tone of the Soviet press this week. Western observers in Moscow still expect the Kremlin to accept the West's invitation for a Big Four conference this summer.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 4 points higher to 4 points lower than on last Friday.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Hogs advanced around 25 cents today and the top price got back to $19.50. equalling the year's high set last Thursday. Salable receipts totaled 10 000.
The present febrile diplomatic activity of the Soviet Union has as it has always had one principal purpose: to force the United States out of Germany first and out of Europe at a later stage.
NEW YORK deer hunters can plan their fall safaris for venison now. The Conservation Department has announced the regulations for 1955, and they embody a few significant changes.

Just as different foods require different cooking temperatures, so various fabrics call for varying pressing temperatures. The problem of what temperature to use has been complicated by the increasing use of blends of fibers, says the United States Department of Agriculture after a recent study in Arizona.
Those inclined during the coming summer to follow that old Asiatic custom of eating hot curry on a hot day may do so very agreeably in the non-tropical cool of the air-conditioned East of Suez.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Warnings of "the vanishing countryside" around New York and other large metropolitan areas were voiced at a city planning conference here today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged two companies with misleading advertising of the Big Stinky Fly Trap and Big Stinky Control Fluid.

The American Arbitration Association has upheld Herman Shumlin on the major points of his dispute with Bruce Becker and Robert E. Miller, producers of this season's defunct play, "Tonight in Samarkand."
The Port of New York Authority borrowed $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday for the permanent financing of capital improvements.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today unblocked Government efforts to deport Joseph Accardi, Newark alien described by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. as a racketeer.
Open admissions that Soviet Industry lags behind American industry in key respects have appeared in much recent Pravda discussion of industrial problems.
Department store heads are being invited to take the carnations out of their buttonholes and go back to school this summer.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The United States received renewed assurances from Yugoslavia today that the forthcoming visit of the top Soviet leaders to Belgrade would not alter President Tito's policy of "firm independence."
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Adorned in all his wrath and majesty, Senator Walter F. George demonstrated today how to bend the United States Senate to his wishes.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A Chicago attorney conceded today he had been "in error" in charging that secret recommendations had been "leaked" months in advance by the Attorney General's Study Committee on Anti-Trust Law Revision.

MOST men in every one of the last twenty-five centuries have agreed on at least one point: the world is painfully imperfect, the times are out of joint, and men and women ought to be able to devise a happier scheme of living. Nobody knows how many tentative blueprints for a better world have been presented in books.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 23 -- President Tito will not endorse any Soviet effort to apply the Austrian version of neutrality to a possible united Germany, he was understood to have indicated today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 -- Bankers were advised today by the president of the American Bankers Association to speak out "boldly and publicly" on national and local problems.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- The vice president of the American Bankers Association said today that while the banking system must seek its share of the expanding credit market, "careful apraisal of loans will remain as one of banking's prime responsibilities."
TRENTON, May 23 -- Further evidence of a wide breach in Jersey Republican ranks was provided today by the State Legislature.
LONDON, May 23 -- A lively controversy of the election campaign centers on the late David Lloyd George, Britain's World War I Prime Minister.
Strategic implications of the new Soviet "peace campaign" were debated by intelligence experts in all the defense ministries of the West last week.
The Columbia Broadcasting System proposed yesterday that Congress modify one section of the Communications Act.

THE dice are beginning to get hot in Leo Durocher's hand and the gambling man from the Polo Grounds is rolling the sevens. They had looked like cold dice for the longest while but they suddenly warmed up in the last few days. The familiar pattern of a year ago would seem to have reappeared.

"The Public Be Damned?" advertisement which appeared in your May 16 issue is long overdue. A visit to the Museum of Modern Art for the current exhibit actually revolted me. I couldn't begin to satisfactorily express my reaction concerning it, but Huntington Hartford has done it for me.
Dedication of a new weathervane, commemorating the first United States steamship to cross the ocean, marked yesterday's observance of Port of Friendship Day and National Maritime Day.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- The fifty-ninth annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers was thrown slightly off course at its opening session today.
Issues of new public utility and industrial securities priced at more than $36,000,000 will be offered to investors today.
Ramiro Cortes, 22-year-old composer of Dallas, Tex., was named winner yesterday of the $2,000 first prize in the annual Student Composers Radio Awards sponsored by Broadcast Music, Inc.

OUTSIDE of the Cort Theatre last night around 10 o'clock the thunder and the lightning began, along with the rain -- a real nice spring storm. Inside, however, on the Cort's stage all was quiet and serene.
HSINCHU, Formosa, May 14 -- Science is giving the good earth a helping hand here to keep hunger away.
Virgil Akins ran his string of knockouts to four in a row last night by stopping Joe Miceli at 2:41 of the first round at the St. Nicholas Arena.
Next season New York will be without a regular series of Sunday afternoon chamber music concerts at Town Hall for the first time in nineteen years.
What has been the biggest financial story in recent years? As far as the general public is concerned, it has probably been the running series of proxy fights for control of American corporations.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Government summoned tonight additional scientific and medical experts to help pass on the future of the poliomyelitis vaccination program.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., May 23 -- Production was resumed today on a backlog of $20,000,000 worth of defense orders at the Sperry Gyroscope Company as unionized electrical workers ended a thirty-five-day strike.
LONDON, May 23 -- One of the great "unknowns" in the general election Thursday will be how 4,436,000 British old-age pensioners cast their votes.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided by a 6-3 vote today that workers who actually process cane into sugar were entitled to minimum wage benefits of the Federal Wage-Hour Law.
American and German business men heard a plea last night for more liberal trade relations and a declaration that a united Germany always would be allied with the West.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23 -- Brazilians are facing the possibility of a basic change in their Government by Congressional action and without a popular vote.

The Metropolitan Petroleum Corporation has sold its waterfront fuel-oil terminal and plant at Wreck Lead Channel and the Basin at Island Park, L. I., to Oilport Terminals, Inc. William and Harry Giffords are the president and secretary, respectively, of the purchasing corporation. Jerome Tannenbaum was attorney for the buyer and Leisure, Newton Irvine acted for the seller.

The largest classroom in Manhattan will open its doors today in the Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. In it, New Yorkers who are still kindergartners in buying securities will be instructed for a week in "How To Invest." The teachers will be representatives of a brokerage house, the textbooks will be exhibits.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- Frank A. Nelson of Racine, Wisc., a machinery parts manufacturer, was nominated today as president of the American Baptist Convention. The organization is holding its forty-eighth annual meeting here.

Dr. Wellington Koo, China's Ambassador to the United States, has put the question of a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait area into the fewest possible words. If the Communists want a cease-fire, he has said, all they have to do is to cease firing. At the moment they are firing less than they did and there is, consequently, less talk of an imminent great explosion in the Far East.

The Cosden Petroleum Corporation achieved record earnings of $3,625,000 in the fiscal year ended April 30. Directors yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 37 1/2 cents on the common stock, payable June 17. Previously shareholders received 25 cents quarterly.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 23 -- The Army invited its civilian advisory group here today to discuss military matters "of interest to the public" and then said the discussions could not be made public.
ROME, May 23 (AP) -- Rome's ancient Arch of Constantine has been put in splints to cure a modern malady -- too much traffic vibration.

The New York State Athletic Commission's hearing to investigate charges by Vince Martinez, Paterson welterweight, has been extended until this morning. Martinez claims that he had been unable to obtain bouts because of a boycott.
A quiet, intense Manhattan College law professor is now busy mapping the entries for Jasper track teams that will submit their cases in 1956, 1957 and 1958.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- A Government spokesman said today that the Aluminum Company of America had agreed to deliver to independent users 55,000,000 pounds of aluminum once set aside for the Government stockpile.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 23 -- Harry P. Cain, a member of the Subversive Activities Control Board, tonight denounced the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations as a "vastly misleading" security measure.
LONDON, May 23 -- British biochemists are investigating a group of chemicals believed to be effective against some of the seemingly invulnerable viruses.
BALTIMORE, May 23 (UP) -- Honeys Alibi, representing the W-L Ranch of California, outran three rivals at Pimlico today to win the Preakness Prep.
NEW DEHLI, India, May 23 -- The Indian Army is having trouble with forty-three reluctant guests.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower signed today without comment a $1,334,917,855 farm spending bill -- $106,000,000 more than he had requested in his budget.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23 -- The president of the Bank of Brazil has indicated that Brazil will return in the near future to a system of requiring licenses for imports.
LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- The 167th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. opened the door today for the eventual ordination of women as full-fledged ministers.
Sid Gordon yesterday returned to the New York Giants. They purchased the outfielder-third baseman from the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Stock prices fell 1 to 2 points yesterday and closed at their lowest level of the day. About the only comfort the technicians could draw from the session was that public participation appeared to be at a minimum.

In the world-wide speculation this past month about the reasons for recent Soviet foreign policy shifts, the factor of possible Soviet domestic difficulties, particularly economic difficulties, has received frequent mention This has obviously disturbed the Kremlin, as is evident from the latest issue of the Soviet magazine New Times to reach this country.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Department of Defense reported today that nineteen concerns, most of them in aviation, received more than one-half of the nation's military business in the eighteen months after the Korean War.

Lavoie Laboratories, Inc., Morganville, N. J., demonstrated at a press showing at Leone's Restaurant yesterday a new container said to be the "first near-perfect moisture barrier container." The new container can be made of a variety of metals, including aluminum, steel, brass, copper and stainless steel. It may be opened and reclosed without losing its moisture barrier protection.

Thirty-five longshoremen and merchants from the Greenwich Village area picketed City Hall for a half-hour yesterday morning to call attention to their plight as a result of vacant piers on Manhattan's lower West Side.

General Electric Company showed for the first time, at yesterday's preview of the "How to Invest Show" in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, a working model of its latest atomic reactor. The model is a miniature of the reactor that will be incorporated in an electric generating plant to be built for Commonwealth Edison Company near Chicago.

Automation probably will play a major role in the substantial increase in productivity in the next five years, Robert T. Collins said yesterday. Such productivity, he added, will be necessary if this country is to have a higher standard of living.

The five-story office building at 4 East Forty-sixth Street has been resold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to a client of Louis Scadron, attorney. The property, which adjoins the new nineteen-story Amoco Building at 555 Fifth Avenue, was sold for cash over a mortgage of $180,000. Fred H. Goodwin, vice president of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., was the broker in the transaction. E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the seller.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 23 -- Already stripped of his citizenship, Albert Anastasia, the gangster, now faces a possible ten-year term in a Federal penitentiary.

A two-story garage building at 194 South Eighth Street and 310 Roebling Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the Stanan Garage Corporation from Crestmor Builders, Inc. The structure is on a plot about 111 by 110 feet at the intersection of the two streets.

New York City shows up very well, in view of its great population, in the cleanliness of its air when compared with other large cities in the United States. Among the five largest cities it is second only to Philadelphia in freedom from air pollution. Detroit had the dirtiest air, with Chicago and Los Angeles next.

Kansas City Power and Light Company has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of 245,000 new shares of common stock to shareholders between June 9 and June 27. The shares are to be subscribable on the basis of one new share for each ten held.

"The Marshall Plan and Its Meaning," by Harry Bayard Price, will be published July 11 by Cornell University Press. Prepared under the auspices of the Governmental Affairs Institute, the volume sketches the crisis from which the Marshall Plan emerged, covers the highlights of the European Recovery Program, deals with associated programs in Asia and discusses lessons and insights to be gained from these operations.

A contract agreement was reached early today between negotiators for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and a union representing 13,500 of its employes. The accord averted a strike that had been threatened for tomorrow against 600 of the company's supermarkets in the metropolitan area.
ALBANY, May 23 -- Governor Harriman announced today that he would ask the 1956 Legislature to authorize tax increases providing for higher teachers' salaries.
Over the protests of three civic and business groups. Mayor Wagner signed legislation yesterday removing an item of $11,400,000 from the city's budget.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- The Borg-Warner Corporation plans to erect a research laboratory near Des Plaines, Ill., if it gets zoning approval from that city.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Extension of the doctrine of equality of opportunity to include the physically handicapped was urged today by President Eisenhower.

The consideration of Senator Lister Hill's committee to formulate a method of civilian achievement award and the recent epoch-making reception by the President for Dr. Jonas Salk point up the need for an American Nobel Prize.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- Hollywood is heading full blast into a new musical cycle with seven pictures, some factual and some fictional, about musicians and popular - song singers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 -- The United States advised United Nations members today against trying now, by international agreement, to ban restrictive business practices regarded as "harmful" to world trade.
HALIFAX, N. S., May 23 (AP) -- Unchecked forest fires leveled more than 100 buildings in Nova Scotia and destroyed 15,000 acres of rich timber land in Ontario.

Mrs. Harry Dorsey Watts will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 40 East Sixty-second Street for members of the awards committee serving with her in behalf of the Belmont Ball. The ball will be held on June 10, the eve of the Belmont Stakes, at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park.

Tony Holguin, head pro at the Midlothian (Ill.) Country Club, broke his own course record yesterday at he paced about seventy -five qualifiers into the Professional Golfers Association's championship with a 36-hole total of 131.

It may be literature down on the farm -- but in many retail circles it's a bellwether. That's the midsummer mail order catalog of Sears, Roebuck Co. It started on its way in the mails yesterday from Chicago to customers throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Army engineers, if Congress provides the money, will spend $22, 550,000 for navigation, flood control and shore protection projects in the Middle Atlantic area during the year beginning July 1.
John Golden, Broadway's dean of theatrical producers, received a "Handicapped Oscar" today from the patients of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, First Avenue at Twenty-third Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Mrs. Theodore S. Chapman, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, said here today that she felt there should have been more research done on the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine before its announcement.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Eisenhower told a cheering crowd of Republicans tonight that "we are not trying to go back to the horse car, we are not trying to fly to Mars."
A six-foot reproduction of the seal of the Medical Society of the County of New York was presented to the membership last night at the society's annual meeting.

Neighboring tradespeople re-question the basic advisability of higher education. Local policemen try to remember that they were once young -- although seemingly never so young as this. Faculty members smile or frown according to the state of their term-end tempers. And the malefactors themselves?
LONDON, May 23 -- The quiet, rural constituency of Wells, in Somerset, is apparently going to return a Conservative to Parliament with little fuss.
She who has never coupled hand knits with high fashion will change her mind tomorrow -- or so Macy's hopes.

ALBANY, May 23 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of winners of special New York State scholarships for children of deceased or disabled members of the armed forces. Competition for the awards was held in March.
The establishment of a development fund, with an immediate objective of $3,500,000, was announced yesterday by Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, Purchase, N. Y.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 (AP) -- Gallorette, racing's second leading money-winning mare, is the list-topper in Delaware Park's balloting to determine America's ten greatest race mares.

Five boys between 5 and 8 years old were given anti-tetanus shots at Roosevelt Hospital last night after they were discovered playing with three guinea pigs that had been taken from cages at the hospital.

The British general election take place the day after tomorrow, Thursday. It would be tempting to say that "it is all over but the shouting." As it happens, there has been no shouting except some of the customary ranting from the Labor party's ebullient and embarrassing Welsh firebrand, Aneurin Bevan.

ZACHARY SCOTT successfully defended his title as the dourest man in town last night. Mr. Scott, who has been taking a grim view of affairs for years on movie screens, was seen in the title role in "The Drifter" on "Robert Montgomery Presents" over the National Broadcasting Company's television network.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- A committee of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters laid aside today a resolution that could have brought the first step toward the organization's approval of pay-as-you-see television.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee voted 3 to 2 today to apprcove the Bricker Amendment to redefine the President's treaty-making powers.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's informal remarks tonight at a Republican "Kick-off for 1956 Dinner": Mr. Vice President, ladies and gentlemen:

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill repealing a 1954 provision of the Agriculture Adjustment Act denying Agriculture Conservation Payments to farmers failing to comply with acreage allotments on all basic price-supported crops.

America's foremost chess players will go to Moscow next month for a four-round match against a team of Russian experts. The United States squad of ten, led by the international grandmasters, Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., and Isaac Kashdan of Los Angeles, will fly from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, on June 23.

"STUDIO ONE" had itself a lark last night on Channel 2. It offered the late George M. Cohan's whimsical non sequitur, "Pigeons And People," the formless, witty and frequently bewildering theatrical tidbit on making a fool out of life.
LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- Under Secretary of State Herbert Hoover Jr. cautioned today against shifting the nation's foreign policy just as it showed signs of bearing fruit.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 23 -- The Government has stepped up its preparations for possible military action against insurgents in southwest Cochin China. Most of the commercial aircraft in South Vietnam were requisitioned yesterday to transport troops to the troubled area.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 23 -- Two Westchester professionals, Joe Moore Jr. and Bob Watson, today shared the low qualifying honors in the Metropolitan District's trials for the National Professional Golfers Association championship.
Riders on certain non-electrified portions of the Long Island Rail Road will find today that air-conditioning has been added to their trains.
VIENNA, May 23 -- The Austrian trade delegation that will leave for Moscow next week is expected to bring back an outline of the Soviet Union's economic plans for Austria's future.

ROME, May 23 -- Italy has joined the countries that receive agricultural surpluses from the United States. Under an agreement signed here today $50,000,000 worth of United States cotton, wheat and tobacco will be sent to Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- Harold Johnson wasn't drugged but was stopped by a terrific body blow in the first round of his nationally televised fight with Julio Mederos on May 6, the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission was told today.
MILWAUKEE, May 23 -- The possibility was raised today that isoniazid, the anti-tuberculosis drug, might be used to prevent rather than just treat tuberculosis.
The Queens police rounded up yesterday an armed gang of teen-agers on the prowl for members of a rival ring.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 23 (AP) -- Gen. Timur Bakhtiar, military governor of Teheran, has ordered the dome of the Haziratulghodes Temple, center of the outlawed Bahai religious sect, destroyed.

Today's new film is "The Magnificent Matador," starring Maureen O'Hara and Anthony Quinn, at the Astor. Manuel Rojas, Thomas Gomez and Richard Denning head the supporting cast. Charles Lang wrote the screen play of the bullfight drama, and Budd Boetticher directed the Twentieth Century-Fox release.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Supreme Court set aside today the contempt conviction of three witnesses charged with refusing at a House inquiry to answer questions on alleged Communist affiliations or associations.
LONDON, May 23 -- Sir Anthony Eden asserted tonight his belief that the Soviet Union would accept the West's invitation to talks on the highest level.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate Democratic leadership called on the Eisenhower Administration today for a "complete review" of this country's air strength relative to that of Russia.
VIENNA, May 23 -- A civil war in the ranks of Italian non-Communist unions threatens to complicate the task of keeping Italy free of Communist political control.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Democrats and Republicans of the Senate drew their battle lines today for tomorrow's test over President Eisenhower's veto of the postal pay bill.

The New York City Anti-Crime Committee, whose work was interrupted recently by internal disagreement and forced resignations of staff members, announced yesterday it would go forward with investigations of racketeering and questionable practices.

A constant broadening of the uses of atomic energy can significantly improve world understanding, according to Walker L. Cisler, president of Atomic Industrial Forum. Inc. He expressed this opinion last night at a Forum dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The bare stage of the old Belasco Theatre glowed yesterday with joie de vivre. At 2:30 P. M., a pair of incandescent leading ladies stepped out from the wings, and the first rehearsal of an extraordinary theatrical event got under way.
Action was deferred yesterday by the Board of Estimate on pay-rise proposals affecting five categories of city employes. The new date set was June 14.
PARIS, May 23 -- The end of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan tonight was marked by numerous acts of violence in French North Africa.
Taunted by friends who questioned his courage, a 17-year-old youth lost his life yesterday when he sought to prove his bravery by diving 180 feet from High Bridge into the Harlem River.
Shiny, new steel baskets were placed on sidewalks yesterday in the hope that they -- and not the streets -- will collect litter.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Southern domination of the machinery of Congress when the Democrats are in the majority has become automatic because of the seniority system. Since the South is Democratic and for years has re-elected its members of Congress more regularly than elsewhere in the nation they usually are senior in length of service.

A family of eight Arab refugees -- said to be the first Arab family to immigrate under the 1953 Refugee Relief Act -- arrived in New York by air yesterday. The family fled Jerusalem seven years ago, leaving behind a prosperous tourist trade.

Teddy Atkinson had to go to the stewards to rescue the favorite players in the crowd of 18,197 at Belmont Park yesterday. After finishing second on the Green-tree Stable's Diving Board in the feature race, Master Teddy lodged an objection against the manner in which Paul Bailey had ridden the first horse, Ashenden of the Clearwater Stables.
It is "highly unlikely" that any members of the Transit Authority will be appointed to the new authority that will take over on July 1, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.

With the example of Queens, Nassau, lower Westchester and near-by New Jersey before us, it is impossible to believe that Staten Island can hold out much longer from the sweeping wave of urban development that has pushed outward from the center of New York.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's informal talk to the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters today:
Textron American, Inc., should show a $10,000,000 profit this year on its combined textile and nontextile manufacturing operations, according to Royal Little, chairmain.
A bullet fired in a hold-up crossed Forty-second Street at chest level last night and miraculously missed the passing crowd.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- To get and hold a Government contract, a Brooklyn garment maker testified today, he played Santa Claus for a year to a squad of New York Government workers.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate backed today President Eisenhower's veto of an 8.8 per cent pay rise for 500,000 postal workers.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Federal Government has three methods of clearing drug discoveries for human use.

LONDON, May 24 -- Investors' hopes of a Conservative victory in Thursday's general election, plus hopes of settlement of the dock and railway labor disputes, brought a further rise in prices on the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today he was setting up a permanent committee to review all security cases in his department.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 24 -- Yugoslav sources indicated today that their country's desperate economic plight had compelled Belgrade to consider a settlement with Moscow.
CHICAGO, May 24 -- Grain pit activities were at a low ebb early today, but around midday there was some broadening of the demand for wheat.

International Drug Products, Inc., plans to sell 325,000 shares of common stock of Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, according to a joint statement made yesterday by Elmer H. Bobst, chairman, and Alfred E. Driscoll, president of Warner-Lambert.
A 32-year-old bosun aboard the cargo liner Mormacrio was designated as the "seaman of the year" yesterday in a noon-hour ceremony at the Battery.

BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) -- Nashua, more of a favorite than ever, and Traffic Judge stole a march on the entry list for Saturday's $100,000 added Preakness today by being named forty-eight hours before the deadline.

Zrazi is the formidable Polish name for savory beef rolls done in much the same manner as Italian veal birds. This would seem the time for home cooks to try their skill with zrazi, for the beef top round with which they are made is economically priced now.
Governor Harriman announced at a Citizens Union dinner last night that Workmen's Compensation insurance rates in New York State were being reduced $41,000,000 a year, starting July 1.
B. O. A. C.'s Flight 525 will bring into Idlewild International Airport around 10:30 A. M. today a gentle old lady from The Black Country around Walsall in S. Stafford, Britain.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A Democratic Congressional foreign policy leader declared today that the United States should walk out of the coming Big Four conference if the Russians made it "a farce."
Advertising agencies handling wine, beer and liquor accounts, and others who promote the beverages in one way or another may be happy to know their efforts are bearing fruit.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- Several Soviet writers who were once publicly denounced as "rootless cosmopolitans" are actively at work again in Moscow. The names of five of them appear in current publications.

CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) -- Chico Carrasquel and Bob Nieman drove homers in the eighth inning tonight as the Chicago White Sox chased Herb Score and whipped the Cleveland Indians, 4 -- 1. Billy Pierce held the Indians to three hits in a duel of left-handers.
The two big New York City area harness racing tracks had profits approaching three-quarters of a million dollars or more in 1954.

Gross operating revenues of the Great Northern Railway Company rose to $71,140,895 in the first four months of 1955 and the company managed to carry $4,286,159, or 71 cents a share, down to net income.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Mrs. Rollin Brown of Los Angeles was elected president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers today at its fifty-ninth annual convention. She succeeds Mrs. Newton P. Leonard of Providence, R. I.

State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits yesterday described Israel as essential for United States security. He cited it as the major reason why the Near East had not "crumbled" before the onslaught of communism, as have some nations in Southeast Asia.
EPSOM, England, May 24 (UP) -- A crowd of 250,000 will watch twenty-five 3-year-old colts compete in the 176th running of the English Derby tomorrow over Epsom's ancient, horseshoe-shaped track.
A SCRIPT based on a stimulating idea was presented effectively last night on the Circle Theatre from 9:30 to 10 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.
ROME, May 24 -- The Government said today no one should think Italy could be made to renounce her foreign policy just when it was beginning to bear fruit.
PARIS, France, May 24 -- The prospect of a new withdrawal of French troops from Europe to North Africa caused concern today at Supreme Allied Headquarters in Europe.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that the cotton spinning industry operated during April at 136.8 per cent of capacity on a two-shift, 80-hour week basis.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Supporters of President Eisenhower's highway program conceded today that they faced probable defeat in an expected Senate showdown tomorrow on the Administration's bill.
LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- An unfrocked Presbyterian minister, convicted last year of heresy and subversion of the faith, lost his final appeal here today.
PARIS, May 24 -- A move to facilitate the revision of the Constitution was approved by the National Assembly tonight by 404 to 210 votes.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, made a strong bid today to recover nearly a quarter of a billion dollars cut from his department's budget in the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Eisenhower told the nation's radio and television broadcasters today they had a "tremendous responsibility" inhelping to keep the American public informed on current issues.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office has authorized mail subsidy payments to airlines in Alaska and Hawaii and to the helicopter airlines as well as to domestic airlines generally.
Increased activity by every major division of the Greater New York Fund has resulted in total contributions of $4,070,250 since the campaign opened April 25.

The election of Richard Hazen as president of the Metropolitan Section of the American Society of Civil Engineers has been announced. Mr. Hazen is a partner in the consulting civil engineering firm of Hazen Sawyer, 122 West Forty-second Street.

HOLYHEAD, Wales, May 24 -- Anglesey, the island county of northwest Wales, "Mona's Isle" in song and story, may be the decisive battleground next Thursday in the Liberal party's attempt to gain a new lease on life.

The way to freedom for 23-year-old James Lawrence was blocked yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court by legal obstacles. However, the penitent hold-up man found himself surrounded by persons eager to help him.
MILWAUKEE, May 24 -- Isolation of a tuberculosis bacteria material that appears to provide a significant degree of immunity to TB in laboratory animals was reported today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 24 (UP) -- President Joao Cafe Filho reaffirmed his Government's determination to hold peaceful Presidential elections next October.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 24 -- The Soviet Union was said here today to be prepared to seek a general European settlement even through bilateral negotiations.
Along with the polo coat and the string of pearls, Best Co.'s "Shirtmaker" dress ranks as an American fashion classic.
Seventy-five women were added yesterday to the corps of civilian school crossing guards. Fifty will be assigned in Manhattan and twenty-five to Brooklyn.
I read The Times every day and that's why it hurts when you found it necessary to support the President versus the underpaid mailmen.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today recommended that the Treasury adopt regulations so that all publishers may defer taxes on prepaid subscription income until the year the publications are actually delivered. It said this would be "fair and equitable."
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared today that present peace moves from Moscow and Peiping might indicate the time was ripe to renew efforts for world armament control.
Jack Paar announced yesterday that he had asked the Columbia Broadcasting System to relieve him as host on "The Morning Show."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- A. Baptist minister called today for "new techniques of pastoral service" for men and women in armed forces overseas to combat immorality, suicide and other evils.
New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $128,000,000 will be offered to investors today.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 -- Bengazi won the one-mile Merrick Trot in 2:04 3/5 by two lengths from Insured tonight at Roosevelt Raceway and returned $28.70 for $2. Alayne Regent was third. Dick Williams drove the 5year-old bay horse for the .owner, Ralph I-I. Kroening of llwaukee. I The summaries:
Dick FitzGerald pitched a three-hitter as Lafayette blanked Fordham, 7 -- 0, at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday.

Last February Sol Cilento, former secretary-treasurer of the Distillery Workers International Union and a trustee of the union welfare fund, was indicted for accepting a bribe from an insurance agent, Louis E. Saperstein. Saperstein, it was alleged, had split the commissions with Cilento on the welfare fund's insurance which Cilento had arranged to be placed through him as agent.
AUGUSTA, Ga., May 24 (AP) -- A 100-foot section of a concrete wall at Augusta's baseball park collapsed under heavy winds tonight. Two persons were killed. A third was injured seriously.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee today approved a proposed investigation into the Federal Reserve System's role in buying and selling Government Securities.

After spending nearly seventeen months, on the anxious seat as a hold-over in office. Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain was "finally" sworn in at 11:30 A. M. yesterday. The word "finally" was used by Mayor Wagner in administering the oath.
Events tonight: All-City High School Chorus and Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:30, and Guilmant Organ School commencement concert, First Presbyterian Church, 8:15.

Relief pitching which had held up so steadfastly for the Yankees all through the early season, failed them tonight and the league - leaders dropped a 3-2 decision to Chuck Stobbs and the Washington Senators at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- Chairman J. William Fulbright of the Senate Banking Committee introduced legislation today to extend Federal regulations to stocks not listed on the major exchanges.

Imports of the United States, when compared with other pertinent statistics on our national economy, would appear to be of less than colossal importance. They are equal to only about 4 per cent of our national income.

LONDON, May 24 -- After an absence of four years, Danny Kaye has brought himself and his crazy-quilt of songs and drolleries back to the Palladium, where he opened last evening. To Judge by the pandemonium inside and outside the huge music hall, everything is likely to be jubilant for the next six weeks.
CHICAGO, May 24 -- The appearance in Chicago of two $100,000 United States treasury bills has added mystery to the controversy involving Mr. Mow.

The directors of Alco Productions, voted yesterday to redeem 100,000 of the 187,000 outstanding shares of 7 per cent preferred stock. They also decided to retire 13,000 preferred shares held in Alco's treasury.

The merry month of May gave a good impersonation of the August dog days last evening. After a morning and afternoon temperatures in the upper seventies, with high humidity, the mercury climbed to 83 degrees at 5 P. M.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- The Soviet Union celebrated today the fiftieth birthday of its most popular contemporary novelist, Mikhail A. Sholokhov, author of "Quiet Flows the Don."

A recent look at The New York Times Sunday Book Review made us wonder how many authors were on its Best Seller List by accident. We were aware that the reading public had put them there because it had been entertained (for it is always the duty of a novelist to entertain) but how many, we wondered, had dreamed of publishing from the time they were of an age to write school compositions?
BONN, Germany, May 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is ready to open a carefully prepared diplomatic offensive to protect West Germany's interests at the forthcoming four-power conferences.

In The New York Times of May 16 there appeared a letter from Jose Arce stating that a United Nations Charter Review Conference could modify or delete any provision of the present Charter. This, in his opinion, would make it possible to eliminate the veto as applied to Charter amendments.
BOB HOPE gave his final show of the season last night on Channel 4. If it was a profitable hour for the comedian, his experience was unique.

Not since last Columbus Day -- when many investors did not know the Exchange was open -- was there a slacker stock market than yesterday. Only 1,650,000 shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange against 1,900,000 on Monday.

LONDON, May 24 -- Sir Anthony Eden labeled a Labor poster "monstrous." Clement R. Attlee termed a mock ration card issued by the Conservatives "rather mean." The election campaign was trailing off today in a sputter of charges and counter-charges.
ALBANY, May 24 -- The Republican State Chairman accused Governor Harriman today of being "trigger-happy in calling for tax increases practically every time he turns around."
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Spokesmen for two of the nation's big three aluminum producers testified today they are shipping to smaller concerns metal that they could profitably use themselves.
A nine-man crew from the Norwegian freighter Lista rowed to victory yesterday in the International Seamen's Lifeboat Races held in the Narrows off Brooklyn.
In connection with the visit of Marshal Bulganin and Nikita Khrushchev to Belgrade, may I send you the following lines:
TORONTO, May 24 (Canadian Press) -- Metropolitan Opera Week opened here last night with an audience of 8,000 persons at Maple Leaf Gardens.

CHICAGO, May 24 (UP) -- Minnie Minoso, fleet outfielder of the Chicago White Sox, suffered a skull fracture as a result of being struck by a pitch thrown by Bob Grim of the New York Yankees last Wednesday, X-rays showed today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 24 -- A group of Amish -- the bearded men in plain black suits and the women in white prayer caps and aprons -- visited the United Nations today.
Varied divertissements will be features of the Summer for Children dinner dance to be held tomorrow night in the barroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the St. Seraphim Foundation.
PARIS, May 24 (UP) -- Budge Patty, Hamilton Richardson and Sid Schwartz won their first-round singles matches in straight sets in the French international tennis championships today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- A convicted narcotics violator was named today as the former manager of 22-year-old Julio Mederos. The Cuban boxer scored a technical knockout over "drugged" Harold Johnson in a nationally televised fight here May 6.

VIENNA, May 24 -- The chief spokesman for 15,000,000 United States trade unionists served notice today that no accord between the Western powers and the Soviet Union would soften labor's hostility to the Soviet regime.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 24 -- Westchester officials carried to Washington today their struggle to get funds for remodeling the crowded county parkways. They want $35,000,000 now and more later.
A center for all the arts, the fine as well as the popular, will be established as part of Columbia University on the Morningside Heights campus.
A move to end traffic snarls caused by street repairs was made yesterday by the staff of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The Senate welcomed back Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, today. He had been ill for several months from the results of World War II injuries.

A record of the maritime disasters off Montauk and eastern Long Island from 1640 to 1955 will be published June 6 by Coward-McCann, entitled "Ship Ashore." The author is Jeanette Edward Rattray, owner and editor of The East Hampton, L. I., Star.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The longer the Eisenhower Administration is in office the more apparent it becomes that it has not mastered the intricate and delicate problems of its relations with the public.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- Assistant United States Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz charged today that a price-support bill recently approved by the House of Representatives "would ineffect prolong the system of governmental interference in agriculture pricing and marketing which is bankrupting agriculture itself."

LONDON, May 24 -- It is proclaimed United States policy not to interfere in the elections of other countries. Prior to the Second World War we adhered to this principle except in Latin America. Since 1945 the scope of our political interests has widened.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The Giants, who arrived here with a six-game winning streak and high hopes of cutting further into the Dodger lead, were booby-trapped tonight.

TRENTON, May 24 -- Failure of the State Legislature to adopt an enabling bill has delayed to at least Oct. 1 construction of the proposed peripheral parking lot at the New Jersey end of the Lincoln Tunnel. Unless that body approves the measure by June 6, when it will recess for the summer, the new installation cannot be completed until June, 1956.

A total of 462 pints of blood was collected on Monday by the regional Red Cross blood program. Included were 136 pints given by employes of concerns at 1 Park Avenue and 119 collected at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, under the auspices of the board and Local 891, International Union of Operating Engineers, A. F. L.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson set up an eight member advisory committee today to help work out a program to increase export cotton sales.
DETROIT, May 24 -- The Ford Motor Company may answer Thursday union demands for a guaranteed annual wage.
Following is a list of 141 public, parochial and private schools in the city that will take part in the free inoculation to be given today.

All major questions of change in policy on state aid to education were deferred at the 1955 New York legislative session pending a report from the Heald Commission on Educational Finance. That report is still awaited, but Governor Harriman in an address on the occasion of Teacher Recognition Day has stated some policies of his own.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 24 -- Human rights must have the protection of the law in this country even though democratic traditions are strong, Gov. Dennis J. Roberts of Rhode Island declared tonight.

Five engineers received awards last night from the metropolitan section of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. The awards "for professional contributions to the public welfare" were presented at the seventy-fifth anniversary meeting of the society at the Officers' Club of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

MEXICO CITY, May 24 -- P. T. Mow, former head of Nationalist China's air procurement mission in Washington, was freed on bond today from Lecumberri Penitentiary. The Foreign Office ruled that he was a political refugee and thus was not subject to deportation.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 24 -- A judge today set free Mrs. Mary L. Kayes, who was convicted a week ago of monopolizing a party line telephone during a fire emergency.
Ninety-six athletes were honored at the annual Block M dinner at Manhattan College last night.

Not all of us may be able to af-afford original paintings by a contemporary French artist of the stature of Raoul Dufy. But in the fabric department at Lord Taylor is the next best thing. Four designs by Dufy have been reproduced on a heavy white repp fabric by the French fabric house of Corot.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Government pronounced safe tonight all Salk poliomyelitis vaccine already used or recleared except two lots from the Cutter Laboratories.
BUFFALO, May 24 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted today that "the number of men held in Chinese prison camps is not eleven or fifteen, but 481 uniformed men and twenty civilians."
PARIS, May 24 -- The official French reply to proposals for further European economic integration is expected this week.

A seven-race program, featuring the Connecticut Cup and Adjacent Hunts Cup steeplechase races, has been arranged for the eighth annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association. It will take place on Saturday at the Blind, Brook Turf and Polo Club in Purchase, N. Y.

LONDON, May 24 -- A Royal Air Force search party recovered today the bodies of two United States students missing on Ben Nevis, Britain's highest mountain, since Sunday. The searchers reported that both had apparently died almost instantly from severe injuries consistent with a fall.
Julius Helfand, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, charged yesterday that he was "getting a run-around" in his efforts to obtain records of the New York Boxing Guild.

IF the 1956 Olympic Games are earmarked for the Russians, as the experts insist, it's about time some one explained footracing's facts of life to the Americans. Not knowing any better, the homebred heroes go blithely ahead with one sensational performance after another. This has been a rousing track and field season.

The fundamental liberties of Americans may on occasion be severely buffeted by the winds of fear whipped up by the storms of controversy; but the Supreme Court of the United States has repeatedly demonstrated, with particular force in recent years, that it has the courage and the strength to stand as an immovable bulwark of Constitutional freedom.
The house at 146 East Nineteenth Street, which George Bellows, American painter, bought in 1910 and occupied until his death in 1925, has been sold by his widow, Mrs. Emma Story Bellows.
LONDON, May 24 -- Four hundred of the 18,400 dockworkers who struck at six British ports yesterday returned to work today. However, there seemed to be no prospect of a general back-to-work movement.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday the granting of sixty-four fellowships for study and research on the Near East and Asia. The fellows, including college seniors and graduate students, will receive up to eighteen months of post-graduate work here and abroad.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 24 (UP) -- Lewis L. Strauss, Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today it would be "an act * * * of the gravest folly" to accept without safeguards Russia's proposal for a ban on atomic weapons.

Commercial revenues of Pan American World Airways in the first quarter reached a record $44,697,000, up 21 per cent over the period a year earlier, Juan T. Trippe, president, told 250 shareholders here yesterday.

The resolution of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs brought a breeze of fresh air into the controversy on the subject of adding fluorine to the public water supply. The letter by Daniel L. Dyer in your issue of May 13 must not be left uncontradicted.
CLEVELAND, May 24 (UP) -- Attorneys for Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard declared today that the murder of Mrs. Marilyn Sheppard was a "perfect crime" -- with Sheppard himself the second victim.
BONN, Germany, May 24 -- West Germany and Italy have settled all important points of the stand-by agreement to import Italian labor.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Charles E. Wilson declared today that the United States was maintaining "a military capability superior to that of any potential enemy."

The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday disavowed responsibility for a thirty-five-man picket line set up before City Hall on Monday. Their placards attacked Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, as responsible for the idleness of some lower North River piers.
Mayor Wagner led the city's top officials yesterday in paying tribute to Maurice Couve de Murville, French Ambassador to the United States.

ALBANY, May 24 (AP) -- The temporary board of directors of the state's new Business Development Corporation has selected F. Raymond Coller of Amsterdam as temporary vice president and treasurer of the organization.
The Atomic Energy Commission's new program to release more nuclear information was described yesterday as one of its most significant understakings.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In his address to the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters today, president Eisenhower said:

ALBANY, May 24 (AP) -- The State Taxation and Finance Commissioner said today he had ousted two clerks in the Brooklyn office of the Motor Vehicle Bureau because they had refused to sign waivers of immunity.
MONTREAL, May 24 -- Claude Jodoin, president of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada, said today that strong new laws must be enacted to protect Canadian inland and coastal shipping.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Following are the texts of the original statement today by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General, and the clarifying statement by the Public Health Service, on poliomyelitis discussions during the last two days at the National Institutes of Health:

The National Association of Manufacturers yesterday attacked the purchasing power theories of Walter P. Reuther and Leon H. Keyserling. These ideas are an "economic menace" to the country, said the N. A. M. It warned that they would raise prices, lower the value of money, and lead toward unemployment and depression.

Winners of the 1955 Pulitzer traveling scholarships were announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. The $1,500 awards were established in 1911 under the will of Joseph Pulitzer, publisher.
BOSTON, May 24 -- For the third time in 231 years, workers began erecting a steeple on Boston's Old North Church today.
Graduating students of Union Theological Seminary were warned last night that ministers were not meant "to become physicians, psycho-therapists or political reformers."

The City of Chicago borrowed $6,000,000 yesterday on an issue of Park District serial bonds maturing on June 1 from 1957 to 1975. The obligations were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company at an interest cost of 2.10742 per cent.

Alexander Schneider, violinist and conductor who two years ago originated the Washington Square series of outdoor chamber music concerts, announced yesterday that he would not participate in or "hold any responsibility for" this summer's concerts.

The city's poliomyelitis inoculation program has passed the halfway mark in calling up children originally seeking Salk inoculations. Yesterday's reports showed nearly a third of enrolled youngsters were continuing to stay away.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -- Bette Davis will be back here in August from her home in Maine to star in "The Library," which Columbia inherited when Stanley Kramer ended his association as a producer with the studio.

Today's new film is Walt Disney's "Davy Crockett, King of the Wild Frontier," starring Fess Parker and Buddy Ebsen, at the Globe. The color feature was adapted from three programs in Mr. Disney's television series, as produced by Bill Walsh, directed by Norman Foster and written by Tom Blackburn.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Business activity generally is forging ahead, the Government reported today.

On behalf of the Congress of Industrial Organizations I should like to express our appreciation for your editorial commending our proposals to deal with abuses in the administration of health and welfare plans. It is a source of great satisfaction to know that The Times finds that the labor movement's proposals "are sound and very much in the public interest."
Chandler's Restaurant, in the twenty-five-story office building being built by Uris Brothers at 300 Park Ave through Cross Brown Co, agents -- David A. Bernstein Son, brokers.
The League of Women Voters of the City of New York, celebrating their thirty-fifth anniversary yesterday at their annual convention, voted to continue promoting more efficient city government.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Secretary of State Dulles rejected today the idea of a neutral Germany at the center of a European buffer zone between the East and the West.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower turned on the lights tonight in the Smithsonian Museum's new First Ladies Hall. The President was with her.
IN trout fishing, as in other interesting forms of piscatorial endeavor, success depends upon being at the right place at the right time with the right lures.

Benjamin Coates, Philadelphia financier, yesterday was elected president of W. J. Sloane, nation-wide furnishings chain. He succeeds W. E. S. Griswold, great-grandson of William Sloane, founder of the 112-year-old business.

The Amateur Athletic Union of the United States yesterday called upon its forty-seven district associations to increase their competitive sports programs. The A. A. U. is seeking to encourage interest and proficiency in Olympic events infrequently held in this country.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Eisenhower will spend the long Memorial Day week-end at his Gettysburg, Pa., farm.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- George M. Humphrey accepted today the resignation of Edward F. Bartelt, fiscal Assistant Secretary of the Treasury since 1945.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., has voted to "have no part of any merger with the C. I. O. National Maritime Union and its satellites."
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 24 -- Government sources said today that no general attack against rebel Hoa Hao forces in southwest Cochin China was planned unless the insurgents took the offensive.
The city schools are like islands in a changing sea. Their climate is determined by the shifting currents of metropolitan life around them.
