The American Export liners Independence and Constitution will embark on a series of eight twenty-day Mediterranean cruises in the fall, it was announced yesterday by W. H. McConnell, vice president in charge of traffic.

YONKERS, May 24 (AP) -- Scores of horrified onlookers saw a father hold a blood-smeared infant at knife-point today from a third-floor window and threaten to throw the child out if the police tried to seize him.

Sandau Hirsh has sold the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1172-78 Park Avenue to Henry Goelet, investor and builder. The property occupies a plot 100 by 105 feet at the southwest corner of Ninety-third Street.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 -- The usually hospitable "cousins" of the Dodgers turned on their "rich relatives" tonight. Opposing the Pirates, the Brooks suffered their worst beating of the season, 15 -- 1, at Forbes Field.
Hearings on the relationship between juvenile delinquency and the commercial traffic in pornographic materials opened here yesterday.

The resumption of activity at Circle in the Square, an important off-Broadway group at 5 Sheridan Square, is definite. Authorization was granted by the municipal departments involved, according to an announcement from the new management, consisting of Theodore Mann, Jose Quintero and Leigh Connell.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries in the first three months of this year achieved the highest sales and earnings of any quarter in their history. The report of the world's largest nickel producer was issued yesterday by Dr. John F. Thompson, chairman.
GENEVA, May 24 (AP) -- Europe's East-West trade last year reached the highest level since the war and continues to increase rapidly, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

When Mr. Gordon, in the film "What Makes a City Great" (issued by the Greater New York Fund), stepped off the sidewalk the last thing he was thinking about was what kind of facilities New York maintains for the care of a careless commuter.
Installment buying of health insurance should be as "fairly painless" as the purchase of automobiles and refrigerators, a health economist told insurance experts here yesterday.

Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., the research and development unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, yesterday announced the election of Estill I. Green as vice president in charge of systems engineering. Dr. James B. Fisk has been elected executive vice president. Both promotions are effective June 1.

New York's first investment show started at a pace yesterday that all but caught its sponsors -- Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane -- unprepared. Starting at 10 A. M., the "How to Invest" show was crowded all day.
The first "golden age" center to be operated jointly by the Department of Parks and a social service agency was dedicated yesterday on the lower East Side.
More and more cotton fabrics need less and less to do with ironing boards.

Plans have been completed by First National Stores, Inc., for its first outlet on Long Island. The company has leased more than 38,000 square feet of space for a supermarket in the new Green Acres shopping center on Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 24 -- Scientists may know more about the exact shape of the earth soon through the efforts of a Princeton University professor who does a lot of traveling but little sightseeing.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- An upstate New York delegation received assurances today that the Senate Appropriations Committee would back its request for funds to plan flood control projects in the Vestal-Westover-Endicott area.
NEWARK, May 24 -- The City Council voted unanimously today to require all city employes to take a loyalty oath and fill out questionnaires on possible past or present "subversive" activities
The city's polio inoculation program was running at an overall 69.4 per cent as the first week ended yesterday.
TOKYO, May 25 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said today he felt that South Korea was a committed ally" of the United States but that there was "less feeling of partnership" with the West in Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Silverware at the White House is counted once a year. The odd number of pieces -- 6,201 -suggests that some of the guests may have been souvenir minded. Anyhow, the White House needs $4,984 in its new budget for the replacement of "some small items."
LONDON, May 25 -- Stock prices advanced again today, the eve of the general election, though all gains were not held. Business expanded.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits proposed legislation yesterday to curb abuses his office has found in some employment agencies just outside the city. They are mostly in Nassau County.
A multimillion-dollar expansion program will be undertaken by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company if their proposed merger is consummated.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- It's a hard way to make a dollar -- harvesting corn on a Nebraska farm under a hot September sun. But thirty-five high school students from Norfolk, Neb., agreed today that it was worth it as they toured the airconditioned headquarters of the United Nations.

Directors of the Peekskill National Bank and Trust Company, Peekskill, N. Y., and the County Trust Company, White Plains, N. Y., approved yesterday a plan to merge under the name and charter of the County Trust.
LONDON, May 25 -- Britain will choose tomorrow between continued Conservative rule and return to a Labor Government.
BALBOA, C. Z., May 25 -- The Panama Canal Company today attached the 5,651-ton Norwegian motorship Lisholt while the vessel was in Miraflores Locks making a northbound waterway transit.
New York and its suburbs are suffering a midsummer dry spell in the middle of spring.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- United Artists has purchased screen rights to "Run Silent, Run Deep," a novel by Comdr. Edward L. Beach, U. S. N.

The number of Roman Catholics in the United States and its territories increased by 927,278 in 1954. Their total is now 32,575,702, according to the Official Catholic Directory for 1955, just published.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The United Press asked State Department cooperation today in obtaining a "full and fair" investigation into the death of Gene Symonds, United Press manager for Southeast Asia. He was fatally injured by a mob in Singapore May 12 while reporting a bus strike.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- Harold E. Stassen told the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers today that his office had been deluged with mail from Americans who yearned for peace.
PARIS, May 25 -- The French Cabinet decided tonight against asking Jean Monnet to remain as a member and chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Congress moved fast today to give a pay rise to 500,000 postal workers. The action came after the Senate had upheld yesterday the Presidential veto of an 8.8 per cent increase.
Republican officials here were promised more consideration yesterday in the filling of future vacancies in Federal offices.
VIENNA, May 25 -- Early ratification of Austria's state treaty was proposed today in the Austrian Parliament along with a declaration of Austrian neutrality.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -A former president of the American Hospital Association predicted here today that public opinion "will either up-grade or close our sub-standard hospitals."

The summer clothes are down from the attic now, and, to be blunt about it, all of them are far too small. They shrank during the winter, obviously. When they were put away last autumn they fitted perfectly, so that, standing before the mirror, the wearer could fancy himself as beau brummel, although perhaps in lower case.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- Holly Mims of Washington, fourth-ranking middleweight, tonight stood off a late rally by Charley Green of Los Angeles to gain a unanimous ten-round decision in their nationally televised boxing bout.
The women and men who reside at the Society of St. Johnland home for elderly persons will benefit from the annual Summer Day Fair to be held on June 29.

What Vietnam needs at the moment is a popular election at the earliest possible date. A "revolutionary committee" has circularized heads of government throughout the free world to state that Bao Dai has been deposed, but this committee has no popular mandate to depose anyone.

MEMBER of Annapolis, class of '23. Born Oct. 19, 1901, in Boulder, Colo. Served five years as turret, torpedo and plotting officer. While serving on U. S. S. Procyon in 1928, won letter of commendation for "rescue of shipwrecked and seafaring men."

GREAT RIVER, L. I., May 25 -- Two shared the lead at 71 in the initial round of the Long Island Open golf championship today. Jay Hebert of Woodmere, the defending champion, was one of the pair. The other was Jack Moran, a driving range instructor from Forest Hills, Queens, an "unknown" in tournament circles.
R. H. Macy Co., which operates a nation-wide chain of department stores, showed substantial increases in sales and earnings for the quarter and year ended April 30.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -Secretary John Foster Dulles warned today that "there could be no worse moment" than the present to abandon this country's foreign-aid program.

Orchids flown from Hawaii for the occasion will be presented by United Airlines to the women serving as hostesses this afternoon at the garden party on Governors Island for the benefit of the Army Young Men's Christian Association. The party will be held on the lawn of Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Herren, commanding general of the First Army, and Mrs. Herren, Fort Jay, Governors Island.

The J. C. Penney Research Laboratory at 330 West Thirtyfourth Street conducts more than 30,000 tests a year to determine the washability, wearability, warmth, or any number of other characteristics of a large variety of goods, most of them "soft" or "dry."
The heads of fifteen eastern women's colleges were told yesterday that they were not getting a fair share of financial support from American industry because their approach to the matter was wrong.
Four boys accused af participating in a series of burglaries were paroled to their parents yesterday for lack of space in a juvenile detention home.

BOSTON, May 25 (AP) -- James Cox Brady's Commonwealth won the $30,000 Suffolk 21 by half a length at Suffolk Downs today in 1:10 for the six furlongs -only two-fifths of a second slower than the track record.
NEW SUFFOLK, L. I., May 25 -- The problem at Peconic Bay is not that of finding a bait or lure acceptable to the weakfish, but of finding one that will be ignored by the porgies.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Eisenhower approved today the retirement of Albert L. Watson of Scranton, Pa., as Chief Judge of the United States District Court for the Middle Distinct of Pennsylvania, a post he has held since 1929.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Eisenhower Administration sustained a major defeat tonight as Democrats steered to Senate passage a vast highway expansion bill that differed sharply from the President's recommendations. The defeat came on a voice vote.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -There's something about the Phillies that throws the Giants completely off stride. The floundering world champions dropped both ends of a double-header tonight before 27,420 derisive fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

A DOUBLE bill presented as "2 for Fun' seemed to provide the audience at the Greenwich Mews Theatre with a measure of merriment last night. Following the current vogue of mixing together oneacters as an evening's entertainment, the off-Broadway troupe chose to serve up Chekhov's "The Anniversary" and a new comedy by Lola Pergament called "A Switch in Time."
The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that a union member need not stand trial before a union committee twice on the same charges.

No larger than a three-cent postage stamp, a new hearing-aid amplifier is inconspicuous yet efficient, according to its manufacturer. Three tiny transistors power the small aid, made by Acousticon International.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Government proposed tightened safety standards for Salk poliomyelitis vaccine today and drug manufacturers labeled them unacceptable.

BOSTON, May 25 -- The Crotched Mountain Foundation has received a $300,000 grant from the Charles Heyden Foundation to begin construction of a physical medicine rehabilitation center for adult crippled at Greenfield, N. H.
EPSOM, England, May 25 -Phil Drake, a French invader owned by Mme. Suzy Volterra, won the 176th running of the mile-and-a-half Epsom Derby today with a last-minute burst of speed.
Earnings of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries to Feb. 26 were the best for any half-year period since its divorcement in February, 1953, from theatre operations.

A journey along the western coast of Asia Minor is described by Freya Stark in her now book, "Ionia: A Quest." Miss Stark used Herodotus as a guidebook to "illuminate her explorations in time." She visited fifty-five sites in Ionia and Aeolis, now part of Turkey, to discover what "elements in that breeding ground of civilization can still be planted among us."
In the grim catacombs of East Harlem, American families -- Negro and white, Pro testant, Jewish and Catholic -struggle to rear their children. It's a tough neighborhood in which to rear children.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Cash dividend payments by publicly owned corporations last month reached $662,000,000, up 12 1/2 per cent from the April, 1954, level

HOME town, Keytesville, Mo. Born Aug. 26, 1901. Fourth in rank in West Point class of '22. Began Army career as student officer in the Engineer School at Fort Humphreys, Va. In mid-Nineteen Twenties, served as aide to Maj. Gen. William R. Smith, chief of Hawaiian Department.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Broadcasters were told today that radio, despite inroads of television, had made a dramatic comeback.

Plans are being formulated at meetings of the executive committee for the third annual Ball of the Roses. The event will be held on Jan. 5 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the free care program of Roosevelt Hospital.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- Former President Truman has rejected an invitation from Secretary of State Dulles to attend the United Nations anniversary meeting in San Francisco next month.
An apartment building housing 324 families soon will rise on the Fourth Avenue block-front opposite Grace Church and the old Wanamaker store block.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 3 points up to 8 down.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Jack Benny and Fred Allen, who have poked fun at each other for years, were honored by the Radio Pioneers of America tonight for providing more than twenty-five years of radio and television entertainment.
Standard Register Co, business record systems, in 250 Park Ave; Doyle, Kitchen McCormick Inc, advertising, in 380 Madison Ave, through Cushman Wakefield Inc -- Huberth Huberth, brokers.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Sale of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railway for $12,000,000 to Ben W. Heineman, Chicago attorney, reportedly was being considered today by trustees of the George P. McNear estate, which owns 82 per cent of T. P. W. stock.
VIENNA, May 25 -- An American proposal for a special agency to conduct a world-wide organizing drive and plan joint actions by world labor against totalitarianism was approved today.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- Activity on the buying side of wheat futures carried over today from yesterday.
All segments of this country's foreign commerce should cooperate to establish an effective clearing house for exchanging trade information, Vice Admiral Glenn B. Davis, retired, said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (UP) -- The linking of a mysterious "Peter Perri" as co-manager of Harold Johnson caused a stir today at the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission's investigation of Johnson's knockout by Julio Mederos.
Followings are some facts and figures on the election in Britain today:

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Whether the Supreme Court's directed acquittal of three Congressional witnesses convicted of contempt in the trial court will hinder House and Senate committees hereafter in getting legitimate and essential information cannot be known until the scope of the decision is tested by legal process.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 25 -Foreigners aiding the Binh Xuyen forces are subject to death penalties, a Vietnamese official warned today.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; members of the New York Philharmonic -Symphony, conducted by d'Artega, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Juilliard Orchestra, Jean Morel conducting, Sarah Fleming, soprano, Juilliard School, 8:30; Everett Anderson, bass-baritone, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- In about a year from now there will be approximately 50,000,000 television sets in this country haranguing the populace with political oratory in what will, of course, be "the most important, the most decisive, and the most historic Presidential election in American history."
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 25 -Abba Eban said tonight that the picture current here of an isolated Israel abandoned by her friends was completely out of focus.
SINGAPORE, May 25 (UP) -India qualified for the Interzone final in the Thomas Cup badminton tournament today. India advanced with a 6-3 victory over the United States.
Surrogate William T. Collins, after a trial of a day and a half, directed yesterday that the will of John A. (Fishhooks) McCarthy. Tammany contractor and builder, be admitted to probate.

Ted Shawn has engaged a group of ten leading dancers from the Royal Danish Ballet in Copenhagen as the principal feature of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, which opens its fourteenth season under his direction at Lee, Mass., on July 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- More than 13,000 refugees were transported from camps in Europe to new homes in other lands in 1954 and the early months of 1955, the United Nations was informed today. The figures were contained in the annual report to the General Assembly of Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations Commissioner for Refugees.
MILWAUKEE, May 25 (AP) -Five runs in the eight inning spiced the Cincinnati Redlegs' 13-2 victory over Milwaukee tonight. The Braves received little relief from their relief pitchers.
The vitality of American writing was praised yesterday by Orville Prescott, daily book reviewer for The New York Times.

The tension, and perhaps even anxiety, surrounding the proposal for a meeting of the heads of government of the "Big Four" Powers this summer seems unquestionable and understandable in view of recent events. Yesterday there was sharp disagreement between Washington and Paris on the question of whether a definite time for this meeting "at the summit" had been agreed upon.

FOR more than seventy years New Yorkers have been going to Luchow's for the specialties that have made that Fourteenth Street restaurant a gourmet's landmark. Now for the first time, some, of its traditional dishes have been frozen for retail distribution.
The staff of the Hospital for Special Surgery performed a fast and efficient moving job yesterday.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York rendered 2,200,000 medical services to insured persons during 1954 in New York City and Nassau County. Dr. George Baehr, president and medical director, in a report to the board of directors, said the services had been given in homes, doctors' offices, hospitals and in twenty-nine medical group centers.
CHICAGO, May 25 (UP) -- Paul Minner and Bob Rush hurled the Chicago Cubs to 1-0 and 3-1 victories over the St. Louis Cardinals today. The Cubs have won ten of their last twelve games.

BORN in Chicago Feb. 27, 1896. Graduated from Naval Academy in class of '16 and served aboard battleship South Carolina, which operated with Atlantic Fleet in World War I. Reported for flight training at Pensacola Naval Air Station in April, 1920, and was graduated seven months later.

Today's new film is "Love Me or Leave Me," a Metro-GoldwynMayer drama in CinemaScope and color co-starring Doris Day and James Cagney, at the Radio City Music Hall. Joe Pasternak produced and Charles Vidor directed.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Rumors circulated in Washington tonight of the actual or imminent resignation of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
The musical version of "Seventh Heaven," based on the play of the same name by Austin Strong, will have its premiere at the ANTA Theatre tonight at 8.
THE girl who picks a June date for her wedding is only doing as the Romans did.
Woodrow Wilson's refusal to "compromise on the heart of the League [of Nations]" should be an example to Americans not to "compromise on the heart of disarmament," Bernard M. Baruch said yesterday.
DETROIT, May 25 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., warned today that it would not give up previously won contractual gains for any "phony" economic package offered by the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 18:
National Department Stores, which operated sixteen units in ten large cities, is beginning a major expansion into the suburbs.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Clanging bells and flashing lights will greet the 165,000,000th American on Friday.

BERLIN, May 25 -- An undercurrent of hope for the early rebirth of Berlin as the capital of a unified Germany is developing here. This is the first time since the start of the "cold war" that such feelings have been entertained here.

Thirty-four of the London Stock Exchange's better-known stocks were given free access to the vast American over-the-counter market yesterday. The Irving Trust Com pany announced it would issue American Depositary Receipts for the securities.
Newbold Morris said yesterday that the New York City Center of Music and Drama had reached its soundest financial basis since it opened in 1943.

That the Government has pronounced safe all anti-polio vaccine already used or recleared except two lots from the Cutter Laboratories does something to clear the air. But the medical air needs further clarification. The Public Health Service states that there is "strong presumptive evidence" of a cause-and-effect relationship between vaccinations with the Cutter preparation and the cases of paralytic polio that occurred after it had been injected.

BELGRADE, May 25 -- Yugoslav officials appeared uncertain and worried today as they awaited the arrival of the leaders of the Soviet Union. The Yugoslavs have told Western diplomats they are on the alert for a surprise Soviet move.

The withdrawal of Russian troops from Austria and the accompanying Soviet "peace campaign" represent a change in Communist tactics, not in ultimate objectives, in the opinion of United States military and intelligence experts on the Soviet Union.
The Army, the Red Cross and the police helped a doctor arrange a blood transfusion yesterday in Brooklyn.

It is not too soon to begin thinking of what the hot days of July and August will be like for children living in the tenements of New York. To aid some of these children the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York, 122 East Twenty - second Street, has appealed to the public for funds to send underprivileged boys and girls to its two summer camps.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A Senate Rules subcommittee has proposed a new formula for Federal election campaigns. The new code would permit national political committees to spend up to $12,000,000 instead of the $3,000,000 allowed by present law.

The conflict over Cyprus shows no signs of ending. In fact, the dispute could go on forever as it shapes up today. It does seem to outsiders about time for Britain and Greece to come to terms or at least to seek a modus vivendi.
NORFOLK, Va., May 25 -- Rear Admiral Arleigh A. Burke paid tribute today to Admiral Robert B. Carney, whom he will succeed as Chief of Naval Operations.
" Morale Gets Lift in City's Schools" is an optimistic headline for Dr. Benjamin Fine's recent article in The Times, but unfortunately it is prematurely optimistic.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 25 -The Ministry of Finance today confirmed the intention of Minister Jose Maria Whitaker to revise the foreign exchange policy, but denied that any change was imminent.

MADRID, May 25 -- Angel Elardo, 44-year-old American tourist, left last night by train for France after having spent two and a half months in a Spanish jail. His crime, according to the police, was that he had repeatedly volunteered that he did not like the way Generalissimo Francisco Franco was running the country.
Mayor Wagner reappointed Charles J. Bensley of the Bronx, Vito F. Lanza of Queens and the Rev. John M. Coleman of Brooklyn to the Board of Education yesterday.

There has been a disturbing silence in the press concerning an Administration-sponsored bill introduced by Senator Butler, S. 681, to bar from so-called defense facilities individuals "as to whom there is reasonable ground to believe that they may engage in espionage, sabotage or other subversive acts."
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Roy A. Roberts, Kansas City newspaper executive, and Mrs. Florence G. Ross were married today at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament by the Rev. Carl Lyon.

A delegation of film technician from the United States, some of whom already have left, will attend the second meeting of the International Standardization Organization to be held in Stockholm, Sweden, June 11 to 16.

CHESTER England, May 25 (AP) -- The Bowater Paper Corporation plans to install a third newsprint machine at its Calhoun, Tenn., mill at a cost of $25,000,000. Sir Eric Vansittart Bowater, chairman, told the annual stockholders meeting today.

The Health Department issued its "usual and standard precautions on the protection of children against polio" yesterday, as it has in other years before the July. August and September seasonal rise of the disease. Last year's peak day came late -Oct. 28.
LONDON, May 25 -- For the last two or three weeks London has been infiltrated by visiting American journalists and television reporters in search of colorful material about the election.
Although available throughout the year, parsley is abundantly shipped to the city during this season, fresh from near-by farms. It is rich in vitamin A.
LINDEN, N. J., May 25 -- An increase in sales and a further improvement in earnings in 1955 were forecast for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) at the annual meeting held here today.

Coffee futures fell sharply in all positions except the spot May yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was extremely nervous under a series of rumors and denials of devaluation of the Brazilian coffee cruzeiro.
Newspapers are doing fine advertising-wise this year, judging by the latest Media Records figures released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Rear Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, a controversial officer, was nominated today by President Eisenhower to be Chief of Naval Operations effective Aug. 16.

LONDON, May 25 -- Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor party, drove with his wife into quiet Hazelwood Road in West Walthamstow today and gave a demonstration of old-fashioned door-to-door politics. It was the last day of a tough campaign.
Two unusually high awards were made yesterday in negligence suits in State Supreme Courts.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 -Christian churches were called upon here today to participate actively in political life. This appeal was linked to the assumption the purpose of "politics" was to promote the welfare of the community and the nation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 25 -- The Soviet Government seems to have outmaneuvered the Yugoslav Government for the dominant position in the bilateral conference that is expected to open here tomorrow or Friday.
Eddie Arcaro made a lot of complimentary remarks about a race horse when he returned to the jockey room after the running of the sixth at Belmont yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- Tonight's scheduled game between the Dodgers and Pirates at Forbes Field was called off at 10 o'clock because of rain. The score was tied at 1 -- 1 at the end of three innings.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., May 25 -- Usonia, a cooperative residential development near Kensico Reservoir, has decided to transfer its ownership of individual home sites to the members of the cooperative.

A survey among 347,690 junior and senior high school students by the Board of Education has turned up nine known narcotics addicts and three suspects. Six of the addicts came from Manhattan schools, two from Brooklyn and one from the Bronx.

The appointment of the new commission to advise the Government on polio vaccine was viewed in some scientific quarters as a major step in ensuring the Salk vaccine's safety and getting the inoculation program started again.
MILWAUKEE, May 25 -Strong new evidence that personal and social factors play a role in the onset of tuberculosis was presented here today.
ALBANY, May 25 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court today cleared the way for the New York Telephone Company to renew its bid for a $68,850,000-a-year increase in rates.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -President Eisenhower directed the Civil Aeronautics Board today to use all its powers to bring about a merger of Alaska Airlines and Pacific Northern Airlines that link the Pacific Northwest with the territory of Alaska.

PARIS, May 25 (UP) -- The New York Herald Tribune and an undetermined number of other morning dailies throughout France were unable to publish tonight because of a Communist-led nuisance strike that may close down most of the country's newspapers tomorrow.
President Eisenhower will appear on a color television broadcast June 7 from the United States Military Academy. The event is believed to be his first appearance on a color program.

NATIVE of Monroe, Wis. Date of birth Oct. 11, 1897. Called to active duty with Oregon National Guard in 1916, and saw service as corporal on the Mexican border. Graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1918.
The influence of the spoken word, for good or for evil, was underscored here yesterday by the president of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged three New York City concerns with selling dangerously flammable imported silk scarves. It was the first action by the agency under the Flammable Fabrics Act adopted by the last Congress.
THE Opera Workshop Department of the Manhattan School of Music proved last night that a group of this kind can mount productions with almost professional competence and credibility.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company had a net income of $11,182,564 in the first four months this year, compared with a deficit of $3,714,974 in the like period last year, the railroad reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Construction of a primary aluminum plant costing nearly $85,000,000 has been proposed to the Office of Defense Mobilization by the St. Joseph Lead Company and the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, it was learned today.

IT'S a rare day when a Board of Education directive to principals stirs up talk among the youngsters. However, as a result of the board's recent recommendation that children retarded two years in reading not be promoted, the awesome phrase "left back," well known to parents, once again is a working part of many youthful vocabularies.

MADRID, May 25 -- Twelve Spaniards charged with belonging to clandestine Communist cells and distributing anti-United States propaganda were tried today by a Madrid military court.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Federal Government's attic -- the thousands of places it uses to store articles ranging from ancient records to strategic materials -- has twice the acreage of Manhattan.

THIS morning's books throw clear light on the uncompleted work of democracy. They are: "The Strange Career of Jim Crow,"* a short, eye-opening account of segregation since the Civil War and Reconstruction, by C. Vann Woodward, and "Booker T. Washington," a short, illuminating biography of an influential American leader, by Samuel R. Spencer Jr.
PARIS, May 25 -- French representatives have consulted Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, concerning a projected transfer of French troops to Algeria.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 25 -- A program to combat juvenile delinquency was pledged here today by District 1 of B'nai B'rith. District 1 has a membership of 100,000 men and women in New York, New England and eastern Canada.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 25 (UP) -- The Ceylon Government announced today that it had refused to authorize United States television companies to televise the total eclipse of the sun from the air here June 20.

In connection with your recent editorial "Austria Is Free" I would like to take most serious exception to one of your points, and that is where you speak of seventeen years of subjective to foreign rule, first under Hitler and then under Hitler's conquerors, in particular the Soviets.

BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -Nashua arrived at Pimlico today, and those handling the five or six other colts expected to race him in Saturday's Preakness Stakes began consoling themselves with thoughts about the lesser prizes.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -The Hendy International Corporation, operator of chartered ore vessels, announced today that it had placed a $25,000,000 order for five new ore carriers with a German shipyard.

MENUS for the holiday week-end ahead must please guests without burdening the cook. They must satisfy the hearty appetites of golfers and ball-playing young fry. They also should make a pitch to the more delicate palates of those work- weary folk who plan no more exertion than climbing into a deck chair.
PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- America's "big three" of Tony Trabert, Vic Seixas and Hamilton Richardson swept through secondround matches without the loss of a set today in the French tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles cautioned today that the parley of the Big Four heads of government was designed not to solve East-West problems, but to point "a new approach" to their solution.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The United States Information Agency has been telling its foreign audiences about developments and problems in the Salk polio vaccine program. Henry Suydam, State Department spokesman, said news about the program had been carried abroard by the Voice of America.
Indications are that there will be a tripling of Canadian iron ore production within the next five years, according to the Bank of Montreal Business Review.

LONDON, May 25 -- Efforts to end the dock strike that has seriously curtailed operations in six British ports failed today. But leaders of the strikers said they would consider tomorrow suggestions for a settlement of the dispute.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -Hugh Bryson, former president of the defunct National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, was found guilty in Federal court here today of having filed a false Taft-Hartley affidavit with the National Labor Relations Board in 1951.

Issues of public revenue bonds totaling $41,500,000 were sold by California public irrigation districts yesterday at an interest cost of slightly more than 3 per cent. The borrowing is intended to finance the construction of water storage and power generation facilities on the Stanislaus River.

A one - story building at Thirty - seventh Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Rapid Film Technique, Inc., from the Pax Construction Company. Jack Bernard, president of the film concern, said the premises would be used as a film laboratory.
Casey Stengel is not one to play hunches. The manager of the Yankees always has a reason for every move he makes -on or off the diamond.

The five-story office building on lot 26 by 98 feet at 54 Pine Street has been sold by A. G. Becker Co, of Chicago to Simon Mogelof and Interboro Realty for investment. The property is valued at $200,000 and was sold in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker.
The battle is all over. Britons go to the polls today in their general election, and nobody seems to have the slightest doubt about a Conservative victory.
CHICAGO, May 25 (UP) -The Chicago White Sox reported today "hopeful signs" Minnie Minoso would recover satisfactorily from a skull fracture inflicted by a ball thrown by a Yankee pitcher, Bob Grim.
Big "Walk" and "Don't Walk" signs of improved design went into use yesterday at Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street.
The Long Island Transit Authority released yesterday its "final report" to Governor Harriman and urged that the next session of the Legislature terminate the agency's existence.

LAST night's attraction on the Kraft Television Theatre over Channel 4, "Million-Dollar Rookie," was a small yet human play on the subject of baseball. Its author, Mel Goldberg, wasn't swinging for the stands; as a result, he got on base.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson is expected to set the wheat support price at about 78 per cent of parity for 1956, Senator Milton R. Young said today.
MEXICO CITY, May 25 -- The World Health Organization is set to endorse its participation in a program of applying nuclear energy to medicine and of devising protection against atomic radiation.
As on Tuesday, aluminums and aircrafts helped lead the stock market upward yesterday while motors, oils and most steels lagged. Rails, which had dipped on Tuesday, were also among the pacemakers.
Waterfront truckers have rejected a proffer of a rate "adjustment" in handling truck cargoes on the piers.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- A New York bank economist said yesterday that interest rates on commercial bank loans are apt to go up in the second half of 1955.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -The General Federation of Women's Clubs refused today to support the lowering of the voting age to eighteen years.

After a shopper has found the sofa or chair with her name on it, she then ponders if it is a good buy. Such practical considerations as construction and value are of prime importance when making the major investment required today in furnishing a home.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Blackmail, browbeating and the bankroll of "a big butter-and-egg man" today occupied Senators delving into corruption in the garment industry. The chief witness before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was Mrs. Mella Hort, a pale, slender, black-haired woman with delicate features.

A BASEBALL is a lethal weapon. It catapults toward the plate at speeds up to 96 miles per hour. It can kill a man and once in big league history it did. Ray Chapman of the Cleveland Indians was hit on the head by Carl Mays of the Yankees and never regained consciousness. The remarkable thing is that the majors thus far have escaped with only one fatality.
PARIS, May 25 -- Pierre Pflimlin, French Finance Minister, said today he was worried by the prospect of a return to convertibility of currencies.

Dr. Paul R. Hawley, director of the American College of Surgeons, charged last night that "ambulance - chasing" doctors working with "shyster" lawyers in workman's compensation cases were a "disgrace" to the medical profession.

A decline last week of 357,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 170,677,000 barrels, compared with 171,034,000 a week earlier and 174,522,000 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- They had come to praise the steam locomotive, not to bury it.

SID GORDON will come home today. At least he regards New York as home. The presumption, of course, is that a guy who was born in Brooklyn can regard the Polo Grounds as his native soil, especially when he'll be playing for the Giants against the Dodgers. But Sid has done that before without a qualm.
Dr. Paul R. Hawley was challenged yesterday to produce evidence in support of his charges of unethical conduct by some doctors in workmen's compensation cases.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 26 (UP)--Waychamp won the onemile Fire Island Pace in 2:05 4-5 by a head from Mighty Jet tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Beau Maplecroft was third.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 --Ray Milland, who recently directed and starred in "The Hostage" for Republic, has signed with the studio to make four additional pictures at the rate of one a year. Mr. Milland will direct, produce and star in three of the films.

No "force" was applied in collecting assessments levied on longshoremen, who worked at the Leonardo Naval Base, a witness testified yesterday at a Waterfront Commission hearing. He said also that no "job threats" were made against any men who refused to pay.

"No Escape from Adventure," the autobiography of Sir Michael Bruce, will be issued June 6 by Hastings House. Sir Michael, eleventh Baronet of Stenhouse and Airth, is a descendant of Robert the Bruce and the Royal Stuarts.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have had housing rent controls for over twelve years. For at least five of the twelve the legislative committees appointed to prepare the current rent control laws have either recommended decontrol of' "luxury" housing or presented facts to the Legislature warranting decontrol action.

PARIS, May 26--Premier Edgar Faure said today France was sending to Algeria a division now under command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He explained that France's obligation would not be permitted to interfere with reestablishment of order by military force in Algeria.

MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP)-- Ted Kluszewski pounded his twelfth home run today to start Cincinnati on the road to a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. The triumph advanced the Redlegs to fifth place in the National League.
A new form of consumer credit arrangement may offer department stores and their patrons the combined advantages of the conventional thirty-day charge account and the installment plan.
MEXICO CITY, May 26--The World Health Organization adopted today the recommendation of its program and budget committee that it expand its fight on poliomyelitis.

WASHINGTON, May 26--The average caliber of oratory in the Senate, particularly since its members have been chosen by direct vote, is such that daily readership of its proceedings in the Congressional Record requires a durable conscience.
LONDON, Friday, May 27-- Several thousand Londoners gathered in Piccadilly Circus and Trafalgar Square last night, despite rain and television, to follow the election returns on big scoreboards.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a narow range all day and closed 3 points higher to 5 points lower (15 cents a bale up to 25 cents down).
LONDON, May 26--The stock market here today was quiet-- polling day--but prices generally were higher.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) --Senate investigators released hearsay testimony today alleging that a former Air Force buying officer was paid $50,000 to get a Chicago manufacturer a contract for 6,823,000 white sailor caps.

The Board of Estimate approved increases in the city's gross business and financial taxes yesterday. The gross business tax will rise from one-fifth to one-fourth of 1 per cent and the financial business tax from four-fifths of 1 per cent to 1 per cent. Approval by the Mayor is assured.
How the $350,000,000 pornographic trade takes advantage of legal loopholes to spread dirty pictures, books, films arid records across the nation was detailed here yesterday
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Government economists have made some rough calculations that indicate factory productivity rose 4 to 6 per cent in the last year.
SEOUL, Korea, May 26--Enraptured thousands of musichungry Koreans attended a concert today played by the Symphony of the Air.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The weekly average of member bank balances for the week ending May 25 decreased $180,000,000 to $18,673,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A local law increasing by three the number of justices of the Court of Special Sessions was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. At present there are twenty such justices and a chief justice.

We wish the city fathers of our neighboring community of Newark had read a speech delivered this week by former Senator Harry P. Cain of Washington before they tentatively decided to require all city employes to take a loyalty oath and fill out a questionnaire based on the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations.

WASHINGTON, May 26--A bipartisan majority of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported today that there had been "an increase in unhealthy speculative developments in the stock market since the fall of 1954."
THE fishermen who are willing to gamble with the weatherman over the holiday week-end should find real opportunities on both the fresh and salt water fronts.

TODAY'S bride and her attendants have all their problems solved by sympathetic bridal consultants. But what of the relatives and friends ? They turn to the pages of Emily Post or Amy Vandebilt for solace. Nobody else seems to care.
GENEVA, May 26 (Reuters) --Two California doctors reported today on a new anesthetic, Viadril, that was said to be safer and more effective than any other now known.
YESTERDAY (May 26, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Asked Congress for funds for atomic-powered merchant ship that would tour the world. Spoke at dedication of Armed Forces Institute of Pathology.
TUNIS, Tunisia, May 26--The Tunisian Government is running into stormy weather over the conventions of home rule.
The case against eleven egg dealers and a Department of Agriculture inspector charged with conspiracy to upgrade eggs was thrown out yesterday by Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves.

The five-story business building at 134 Newark Avenue in Jersey City has been sold by the Benjae Holding Corporation to Louis Schneider. The seller is a realty concern representing the estate of Louis Jacobs and the buyer is one of the owners of the New Jersey Furniture Company.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Senate Democrats finally began today on their long-heralded investigation of the Eisenhower personnel security program.

GEORGE ERDENBERGER has been Master of Lilliput the last eighteen years. In the sub-basement in the Architects Building at 101 Park Avenue he creates miniature versions of great housing projects, of industrial plants, atom laboratories, college campuses, hospitals, fair grounds.

BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP)-- The Baltimore Orioles made it three out of four in their series with Boston today, defeating the Red Sox, 2--0. Jim Wilson went all the way for the Orioles. He allowed only four hits and helped his own cause by driving in a run.

The New York State central school district composed of Dickinson, Fenton, Chenango and Kirkwood, in Broome County, borrowed $2,940,000 yesterday on an issue of serial bonds maturing from 1956 to 1984.
VIENNA, May 26 -- United States unionists won another victory today over neutralist forces in the ranks of free labor.
The writer of the following letter was formerly Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice.

ANOTHER television drama on the subject of human failure was presented last night. It was Robert J. Shaw's play, "The Kingdom of Andrew Jones," which unfortunately turned out to be less a play than a short story with illustrations.
The pilot project in Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley's sixyear program to construct $94,400,000 of off-street parking facilities was killed yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Friday, May 27--The six drug manufacturers licensed to produce Salk antipoliomyelitis vaccine agreed this morning to the Government's strengthened safety standards.

Three news developments brought sharp advances yesterday for aluminum stocks, aircrafts and a pair of steels. The rest of the list tagged along and the market registered its third solid advance in as many days.

CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP)-- The Indians lost their grip on second place for a short time today, but regained it by scoring six times in one inning and winning the second game of a double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 10--9. The thirdplace Sox took the opener, 3--1.
PITTSBURGH, May 26 -- Big Don Newcombe, the National League's "winningest" pitcher, pitched and batted the Dodgers to a 6--2 triumph over the Pirates at Forbes Field today.

LAST January when "Auntie Mame,"* by Patrick Dennis, was published I was so busy reading books about politics, diplomacy, escaping prisoners of war, Alexandre Dumas and Abraham Lincoln that I remained unaware of its existence. But if I was looking the other way others were not. In a few weeks "Auntie Mame" appeared on the bestseller chart which is published in the Sunday Bojik Review of this paper.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 26-- All seven directors of the Hugo Stinnes Corporation, the American holding company for the German business and industrial empire, were re-elected today. A standard American indemnification protection for directors also was adopted at the corporation's first stockholders meeting in ten years.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) --The Weather Bureau said today it gave at least an hour and forty-five minutes' warning on each of the fifteen tornadoes that hit Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas within the last twentyfour hours.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The United States welcomed today Moscow's assent to a meeting of the Big Four heads of government.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Safeguards against premature announcement of medical discoveries were urged in a resolution placed before the General Federation of Women's Clubs here today.

Television continues to be influential in reversing timehonored customs. The featured seventh race at Hollywood Park on Monday has been changed to the sixth so it can be televised on a National Broadcasting Company news program.
TOKYO, May 26--Political leaders here think the Soviet Union will seek a Japanese pledge of neutrality when their discussions on a peace treaty start in London next week.

CHICAGO, May 26 (UP)--The Chicago Cubs blanked the St. Louis Cardinals, 3--0, today behind the six-hit pitching of Howie Pollet, as they swept a threegame series. It was the Cubs' seventh triumph in eight starts and their eleventh in thirteen games.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- President Eisenhower will propose to Congress tomorrow ten specific amendments designed to "liberalize" the Refugee Relief Act and speed the admission of refugees to this country.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26--The United Nations was told today that the Communist nations were moving rapidly to integrate their populations into a compulsory labor system.
DETROIT, May 26--The Ford Motor Company offered its 140,000 production workers today a broad package of direct wage increases and other benefits, including a stock participation plan.

WASHINGTON, May 26--The Interstate Commerce Commission retained its jurisdiction of the Alleghany Corporation today. The decision came in an interpretation of the commission's responsibilities regarding railroad consolidations, mergers and, proxy fights.
LONDON, May 26 (AP)--Union leaders decided tonight to call off the dock strike that has crippled major British ports for the past four days.
WASHINGTON, May 26--Department store sales in the United States in the week ended May 21 were 8 per cent above those in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The makers of glass bottles and jars have gotten together for a $1,200,000 advertising and promotion campaign.
PARIS, May 26 (AP)--Roger Becker, Britain's 20-year-old Davis Cup hopeful, had the American champion, Vic Seixas, on the run when rain ended today's play in the French tennis tournament.

A report that Fred Waring and his celebrated musical aggregation called the Pennsylvanians are eyeing Broadway turns out to be correct. Mr. Waring, who hasn't appeared with his band in a Broadway show since "The New Yorkers" in 1931, said yesterday in Stroudsburg, Pa., that he had been planning a local visit for sometime.
WASHINGTON, May 26--An employe who fails to dissociate himself from a strike is in fact a striker, the United States Court of Appeals ruled today.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The heads of the country's four television networks looked at television from different angles today, but came to the same basic conclusion: There wag still much to be done.

Belgrade is an ancient city in which today the heroic modern architecture of Marshal Tito's planners mingles with the remains of the long history of Turkish, Slav and Habsburg struggle for control. Belgrade's walls have seen many strange events over the centuries, but few if any more strange than yesterday's spectacle.

WASHINGTON, May 26--Congress was asked today to vote $12,650,000 to start work on a $33,000,000 nulear-powered merchant ship proposed by President Eisenhower. The ship would be designed to cruise the world to demonstrate United States efforts to convert atomic energy to peaceful ends.
The State Department should be replaced in the immigration set-up by a Presidential commission, Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said last night.
FOR its end-of-season offering the A. C. A. Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, has gathered together a group of paintings and sculpture by twenty-eight of its artists.
A concert for the benefit of the French University of New York was presented last night by sixty members of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony, under the direction of d'Artega, at Carnegie Hall.
LONDON, Friday, May 27-- The first election returns last night sent a wave of unconcealed pleasure through Conservative party headquarters here.

A private dwelling on a lot 20 x 100 feet at 23 Beekman Place, overlooking the East River at Fiftieth Street, has been sold by Mrs. Georgia M. Williams in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. It formerly was owned by Katharine Cornell, the actress, and is the third property in the block sold through the Elliman agency within fifteen months. The buyer was not identified.
Traffic for twenty blocks north of the Grand Central Terminal was snarled worse than usual yesterday.

THAT sentimental confection that Austin Strong called "Seventh Heaven" and served to a palpitating generation following World War I is back among us in a new guise. As a musical play, created by Victor Wolfson and Stella Unger, and bedecked in a sweet and tuneful score by Victor Young, it arrived at the ANTA Theatre last night.

The results of the three previous general elections Britain has held since the end of World War II are given in the following tables. They show the number of seats won in the House of Commons by each party:

Commodity futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the Nek York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, hides, zinc and copper were stronger; sugar, cocoa, potatoes and burlap eased and wool ended mixed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The paramount objective of the United Nations--the most important concern of all mankind--is the creation of peace among the peoples of the world. The men who have been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize have made exceptional contributions toward the attainment of that objective.
MOSCOW, May 26--Moscow formally expressed its agreement today with the proposal of the United States, Britain and France for a Big Four meeting this summer.
As the Memorial Day holiday nears, the major transportation services and highway, tunnel and bridge officials are getting ready for a busy week-end starting today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate passed today a bill for the retroactive repeal of two provisions of the 1954 general tax revision law that have been unexpectedly costly to the Government.
ALBANY, May 26--The annual meeting of the New York Central Railroad Company today was an even more disorderly session than the one last year at which Robert R. Young won control.

Last night's returns from the British general election all pointed to the expected Conservative victory. In a British election the Laborites normally do better as the first returns come in than they do later, because their main voting strength is in the big industrial cities, whereas the Tories draw their traditional support from farmers, the professional middle classes, landowners and business men.

NEW DELHI, India, Friday, May 27--An Indonesian investigating commission charged this morning that a bomb blew up the Indian plane that carried a Chinese Communist delegation to death last month in the South China Sea.

The two private turnpike companies authorized by the Texas Legislature to build 850 miles of toll roads connecting the state's major cities have reached an agreement to unify their efforts in a single project.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7.000 head; market fairly active, 25 cents higher, in some instances as much as 50 cents higher on all weights or butchers and sows; most choice 190 to
BUENOS AIRES, May 26-- More than 125 persons, mostly Roman Catholics, were arrested yesterday in six provincial capitals as a result of disorders that the police said had been planned by priests.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday that it would end the fiscal year--and its existence --on June 30 with a $6,500,000 surplus.

ROME, May 26--Dr. Gaetano Martino, Italian Foreign Minister, indicated today that Italy had no objection to the transfer to Italy of the Western Allies' troops now stationed in Austria. He said Italy would comply with any decision the North Atlantic Council might take in the matter.

Once denounced by Soviet propaganda as "Judas," "murderer" and "fascist," President Tito is now being wooed assiduously by the present Moscow regime. No other Communist heretic has ever had such a triumph.

A slight upturn in the city's polio inoculation rates continued yesterday for the second day. The Health Department reported that in 109 schools 16,156 pupils had been vaccinated out of 22,899 for whom the vaccine had been requested.
Benjamin F. Fairless was elected yesterday president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the steel industry's trade association.
LONDON, May 26 (AP)--There were 1,409 candidates for the 630 seats in the House of Commons in today's election.

Herman L. Klein, vice president of Brown Bigelow Agency, advertising subsidiary of Brown Bigelow, was elected president yesterday to succeed Charles A. Ward, who becomes chairman. Mr. Ward, president and general manager of the parent company, was also elected president of the Western Lithograph Company of Los Angeles, another subsidiary.

Joseph M. Callahan announced yesterday that he would retire as a State Supreme Court justice on July 1. He is the senior Supreme Court jurist in the state in point of service, having served since 1927.
Miss Mary Donlon, former chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, was reported yesterday to be slated for appointment by President Eisenhower as a Judge of the United States Customs Court.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The Air Force has ordered a 35 per cent speed-up in production of jet - propelled intercontinental B-52 bombers, which are designed to deliver the hydrogen bomb.

AS their gesture in making the holiday week-end happy for householders, local butchers have decreased the price of beef rib roast to the lowest level reached this year. The city-wide average of 69 cents a pound represents a drop of 6 cents a pound since last Friday, according to the City Department of Markets.
Two youths were injured last night in a Brooklyn street clash reported to have started when a friendly greeting to a car driver was interpreted as an insult.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) --The Senate Armed Services Committee decided today to go ahead with a bill to extend the draft law separately from the Administration's new military Reserves program.
Loans to brokers and dealers by major New York City banks on non-Government securities jumped $85,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Laborers, assistant gardeners and sewage workers stayed away from their city jobs yesterday to stage a demonstration outside City Hall. The action, in which 4,000 men took part, was aimed at obtaining higher wages and other benefits.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the Administration's foreign aid bill.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26-- Marv Blaylock, who once drew his paycheck from the Giants, sliced a double to left field with two out in the eleventh inning to give the Phillies a 3-2 victory over the New Yorkers tonight.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 26--Yugoslav leaders were embarrassed tonight by the embrace of Nikita S. Khrushchev.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 26--The Soviet Union, openly appealed today to Yugoslavia to return to the Communist community from which she was ousted in June, 1948.

Playing politics with postal pay describes the Senate's performance in voting on the President's veto of the S.1 salary bill. But whatever the motives of the Senators, pro and con, the public--and especially the postal employes themselves--should be glad of the result.

There may be some surprise at the appointment of Rear Admiral Arleigh A. Burke to be Chief of Naval Operations. There can be no criticism. A splendid officer has been chosen for a big job whose needs he is eminently qualified to meet.

BUFFALO, May 26 (AP)--Governor Harriman declared tonight that the United States would be "navigating the narrow and treacherous waters between gullibility and distrust" in dealing with what he called the apparent new Russian willingness to "live and let live."
The Sweet New York Air To those New Yorkers who are really discerning, some say, the city's air is a sweet and tantalizing blend--a nectar, in fact, in vapor form.

Carafar toted 153 pounds just a little better than Ancestor carried 162, and as a consequence the former won the Belmont Spring Maiden Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. The $9,750 stakes event of about two miles attracted nine competitors representing seven interests.

TODAY, 4 P. M.: Two stories, "Mr. A and P" and "Baker's Daughter," will be told at the Saratoga Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, Hopkinson Avenue and Macon Street, for children 8 to 10. Story hours will also be given on Tuesday at the Saratoga Branch and Wednesday at the South Branch, Fourth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, at 4 P. M. on both days.

UDALL, Kan., Friday, May 27--Tornadoes that lashed and swirled across five states have killed at least 115 persons since they struck Wednesday night. Early today the twisters still were poised over the Midwest.
LONDON, Friday, May 27-- Morgan Phillips, general secretary of the Labor party, virtually conceded the general election to the Conservative party shortly after 3 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, May 26--Grain futures showed a decidedly heavy tone here today. Pressure on corn unsettled the markets and fairly general rains in the Northwest and also in Kansas and Oklahoma checked buying.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) --The Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives today chopped 21 per cent from President Eisenhower's request for funds to operate the White House and three minor agencies in the fiscal year 1956.

WASHINGTON, May 26--Representative Edith Green, Democrat of Oregon, introduced into Congress a bill today to require equal pay for equal work, whether performed by woman or man. Like the Fair Labor Standards Act, this would apply to production of goods for interstate commerce.
Any assumption that the St. Joseph Lead Company and the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company are all set to start building a jointly owned primary aluminum plant would be grossly premature.

YESTERDAY (May 26, 1955) ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Council completed action on restrictive business practices and wood pulp and paper. Nationalist China, whose United Nations membership has been challenged many times by Soviet bloc, received fourteen votes out of Council's eighteen in ballotting for seats in Transmission and Population Commission.

WASHINGTON, May26--Following is the text of the Senate Banking and Currency Commitee's report on its stock market study: Purpose of the Study The committee on Jan. 14, 1955, agreed upon a study of the stock market.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 774,419 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 17,086 cars, or 2.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 92,452 cars, or 13.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 4,801 cars, or, 0.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week of 1953.
Stockholders of the Sperry Corporation at a special meeting here yesterday approved its consolidation with Remington Rand, Inc. About 81.6 per cent of Sperry stock voted in favor of the merger.
Seven alleged members of a waterfront ring, which operated a profitable trade in foodstuffs pilfered from steamship lines, were indicted yesterday in General Sessions.

MOSCOW, May 26 (Reuters) --Following is the text of a Soviet note to Britain today accepting the May 10 invitation by the United States, Britain and France to a four-power conference of heads of government. (Similar notes were sent to the United States and France, except for the eighteenth paragraph as indicated by asterisk.

The Yankees concluded their sixteen-game home stand with a double triumph over the Washington Senators yesterday at the Stadium. By downing the Nats, 8--4 and 7--3, the Bombers soared to a two-and-a-halfgame lead over the runner-up Cleveland Indians.
KINGS POINT, L. I., May 26 --Government and state maritime training schools participated in ceremonies here today celebrating Merchant Ships Officers Day.

TRENTON, May 26--An appropriation of $150,000 requested by the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission to help finance a study of facilities in the metropolitan area received final legislative approval today.
LONDON, Friday, May 27 -- The Conservative party swept to a commanding position in the returns early today from the British general election yesterday.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses has asked the Board of Estimate for two abandoned municipal hospitals so that he can construct parks on the sites.
MOSCOW, May 26--A big drive to increase production of oil and natural gas in the Soviet Union seems to be foreshadowed by appointment of an oil expert as the country's long-range planning chief.
PARIS, May 26--It was reported on good authority that, barring a last-minute hitch, the conventions of Tunisian home rule will be signed in Paris tomorrow at midnight.
The Police Department has served 12,255 litter summonses since the city-wide cleanup campaign began March 15.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 26 (AP)--Dow Finsterwald of Bedford Heights, Ohio, set the pace for some of the nation's top pros today in the first round of the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament.

Plans for seven Federally aided low-rent housing projects costing $103,625,000 were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Accommodations for 6,830 families will be provided at a rental of $10.50 a room a month.
GREAT RIVER, L. I., May 26 --Art Doering of Inwood, a newcomer to the district, won the Long Island open championship today by a margin of two strokes.

Following are excerpts from the interview between Miss Margaret Truman and her parents, former President and Mrs. Harry S. Truman, on the Columbia Broadcasting System, "Person to Person," television show.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Prices received by farmers declined 1 per cent between mid-April and mid-May, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
A banking law that went on the books in the early history of this country may be on the way out at last.

An anthology that pays tribute to the City of New York will be published June 23 by Rinehart entitled "The Empire City: a Treasury of New York." The volume of 475 pages contains 105 essays, articles and historical highlights describing the places, the people and the reactions of famous foreign visitors.
NORFOLK, Va., May 27 -- The Navy designated today Rear Admiral Charles Wellborn Jr. as new commanding officer of the Second Fleet, with headquarters here.
Children from 450 Brooklyn Sunday schools will march in their annual parade in that borough on Thursday, June 9, wearing shoulder bands with the message, "Christ, the Great Teacher."
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Russians have agreed to turn back to the United States during July and August sixty-two of the small naval craft lent to them during World War II.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Directors of Montgomery Ward Co. met for two hours today in their first regular monthly session since Louis E. Wolfson and two associates won minority positions on the board. The meeting was described as routine.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway announced today that it had bought control of the 239-mile Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad.

A. O. Smith Corporation, manufacturer of automotive parts and a wide line of industrial products, increased its earnings in the quarter ended on April 30, as compared to the like 1954 period. Sales, however, were somewhat lower.

BOSTON, May 27 (UP) -- Norm Zauchin, a rookie first baseman, staged a spectacular hitting show tonight. He knocked in 10 runs, one fewer than the American League record for one game, with three homers and a double to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 16-0 victory over the Washington Senators before a crowd of 15,775.

Underwriters of securities are in for a breathing spell next week after one of the most active weeks this year in the distribution of new issues of stocks and bonds. The respite will not be unwelcome because the new-issue market is suffering at the moment from indigestion, largely because of the sharp pricing of high-grade corporate public utility and municipal obligations.

Wall Street's reaction to report of the Senate Banking Currency Committee on its "friendly investigation of the stock market" ranged from high praise to open annoyance. Expressions of praise were topped by Bache Co.'s assertion that the report had been "very constructive" and that the only sectors of the securities business that seems likely to be covered by future legislation were those that needed it.
The pick-up in Canadian exports comes as a promising sign of a reversal in the decline of this trade that has persisted in the two preceding years.
Nerve tissues may have mysterious abilities not heretofore known. This was suggested here yesterday by Dr. Edgar Douglas Adrian, the first Baron Adrian of Cambridge University.

MIAMI, Fla., May 27 -- Mr. Mack attended the elementary schools of Dade (Miami) County, Northwestern Military Academy and the University of Florida. He was graduated in 1932 with a degree of bachelor of science in business administration.
Cotton futures declined two to eight points (10 to 40 cents a bale) here yesterday, with the July delivery showing the most weakness.
Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech in Belgrade Thursday appears to have opened the door to a major change in the ideological relationships among the Communist parties of the world.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Justice William O. Douglas told an East - West interfaith religious conference today that discrimination was the greatest plague of civilization.

One important hurdle has been topped in the course of the Administration's Foreign Aid bill through Congress. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has given its approval by an overwhelming vote to the program in virtually the form in which it was submitted. The changes that were made are not crippling. The spirit of the measure has been endorsed and sustained.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Government admitted tonight that it had made a mistake from which three copper producers would profit to a considerable extent.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- A meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers during the United Nations tenth anniversary celebration in San Francisco became assured today.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- J. Edgar Hoover received the National Security Medal today for his contributions in intelligence and for bringing law-enforcement machinery to "a new height of effectiveness."
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Federal Judge Henry Schweinhaut said today he would order the State Department to issue a passport to Dr. Otto Nathan, executor of the will of Dr. Albert Einstein.
What articles of clothing do women like to be made of cotton ?

A sudden drop in business during the last couple of days plus a poor advance sale for next week. have prompted Charles Bowden and Richard Barr, co-producers of "All in One," to close the attraction after tonight's performance, the forty-seventh, at the Playhouse.
For a seemingly interminable period at the Polo Grounds last night, a deep gloom continued to envelop the Giants.
Inoculations of the city's school children with anti-polio vaccine dropped yesterday to the lowest daily rate since the program began on May 19.
Former President Truman expressed a belief last night that the end of the "cold war" might be in sight.

Memorial Day week-end signals the approach of another summer vacation period. It is the first of three great traveling holidays for the nation's motorists. Over a million automobiles will take to the road in the metropolitan area alone as the scramble for resort areas officially begins.
The New York State Power Authority approved yesterday a contract to sell power from the St. Lawrence project to the Aluminum Company of America.

May I suggest to Councilmen Morris J. Stein and Thomas J. Mirable, whose letter appeared May 11, that a city can only function properly through the agencies established for the protection, safety, health, education and other needs of its citizens? Mayor Wagner has shown a keen recognition of the city's problems by the caliber of his appointments to head the various city departments.

LONDON, May 27 -- Jubilation over the election of a Conservative Government sent prices of industrial shares soaring today. They rocketed to a new high of 199.4, as measured by Financial Times index, and added millions of pounds to share values.
On behalf of the Dental Society of the State of New York I should like to commend your May 19 editorial "Time for Fluoridation."

PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- America's favored Davis Cup players. Tony Trabert, Vic Seixas and Hamilton Richardson, had shaky starts today but snapped back to gain the fourth round in the French tennis tournament.

HUBERT VALENTINE, tenor, sang a recital at Town Hall last night that left no doubt of his innate talent as a vocalist. Mr. Valentine's voice is pleasing in texture, well-produced, aside from a constricted quality in the upper tones, and of ample range and volume.
The organization of a permanent citizens' group to prepare for future population and economic growth on Staten Island was proposed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Richard A. Mack of Coral Gables, Fla., a Democrat, for a seven-year term on the Federal Communications Commission, Mr. Mack would succeed Miss Frieda B. Hennock of New York, effective June 30.
" That must have been a bunch of impostors wearing our suits down in Philadelphia," Leo Durocher said exultantly last night after the Giants had beaten the Dodgers.
The New York County Medical Society appealed last night for the return of a series of recordings of heart sounds that apparently were stolen from a physician's office here Tuesday morning.

" The Joyless Street," Greta Garbo's first major film effort, made in 1924, will be shown at the Sunday evening meeting of the Group for Film Study at the Washington Irving High School auditorium. There will be a single performance at 8 P. M. and membership subscriptions may be obtained there.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., charged yesterday that high Government maritime officials were joining with the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., in a move to prevent C. I. O. maritime unions from improving their contracts.
LONDON, May 27 -- Politicians of all parties seemed agreed today that they had missed their opportunity to make television for the first time a real determinant in a British election.

CAKES for festive occasions are being baked for the first time by Vendome, the delicacy shop that moved to handsome new quarters at 15 East Forty-eighth Street last winter. The store has set up its own bakery to turn out flower-decorated cakes and similarly embellished confections for birthdays, bon voyage and graduation parties.
MILLBURN, N. J., May 27 -- Five teen-age boys have been arrested here for exploding home-made bombs on the lawn of a "strict" school teacher.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The entire spring wheat belt in the American Northwest has received a wetting-down that should be of immense benefit to the crop. As a result there was a further recession today in wheat future prices.

Unlike Davy Crockett, Mrs. Tina Ricci has never shot a bear. In fact, she has not even handled a six-shooter. Still, she is the queen of the not-too-wild frontier of the northeast Bronx near Mount Vernon.
The second-string Communist leaders suffered a double setback in Federal Court yesterday.
PARIS, May 27 -- French political reaction to the Conservative victory in Britain for the most part followed party lines.

WASHINGTON, May 27--Preliminaries for possible public investigation into profits made on military aircraft were under way today. Whether they will develop into full-scale inquiry depends on results of current checks of producing company books.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 27 -- Thomas Mitchell and Philip Clarke, jailed members of the militant Iris Republican brotherhood, Sinn Fein, were elected yesterday to the British House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Harold E. Stassen voiced confidence today that Yugoslavia would reject Russian enticements to return to the Soviet bloc.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- More than 350 Chicago longshoremen walked out late last night after union officials and dock owners had failed to agree on a new contract.

Communist party boss Khrushchev's speech in Belgrade Thursday must surely be one of the most amazing documents of its kind. Its combination of falsified history, simulated apology and implied threat is breathtaking in its audacity. One can understand why Marshal Tito chose to remain silent after Khrushchev had concluded.
LONDON, May 27 (Reuters) -- The Communists increased their total vote nearly 50 per cent, although their seventeen candidates were defeated in yesterday's British general election.
