WASHINGTON, May 27 -- At 8:51 o'clock this morning the Census Bureau's electric population computer twinkled like a pinball machine and registered an even 165,000,000 Americans. It was not precisely correct, of course, but it was close. The big board, which stands in the lobby of the Department of Commerce Building, is geared to register one addition to the population every twelve seconds.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Gene Conley of the Milwaukee Braves, calmly working out of frequent trouble, hurled his seventh victory of the season today. He defeated the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 5.

The Senate Banking and Currency Committee has just made public the results of its inquiry into the stock market carried out this spring under the direction of its chairman, Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas. A bipartisan majority consisting of eight Democrats and three Republicans agreed that there had been "an increase in unhealthy speculative developments in the security markets since the fall of 1954."

MELBOURNE, May 27 -- The West Australian Petroleum Proprietary, Ltd., in which the California Texas Oil Company, Ltd., has a major interest, announced in Perth today that oil had been struck again in the Rough Range area. The strike, at 3,603 feet, occurred thirty feet west of where oil was struck in November, 1953.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted today to sidetrack President Eisenhower's public housing program in favor of a Democratic substitute calling for 890,000 housing units during the next four years.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower pushed the starter button on a tiny atomic reactor today. He asked his chief adviser on atomic energy, "When it gets to danger, what do we do?"
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company must provide extra safeguards for residents of Westchester County along a projected sixteen miles of natural gas pipe.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- April marked the fourth consecutive month in which the number of factory workers hired exceeded the number who left the payrolls, the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, said today.
PALO ALTO, Calif., May 27 -- A new microwave laboratory at Stanford University was dedicated today by the General Electric Company.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 27 (AP) -- Two of the oldest Big Ten records were bettered and another was tied today in the windblown preliminaries of the fifty-fifth Western Conference outdoor track and field meet.
The 1955 Greater New York contract bridge championships started yesterday at the Hotel Park Sheraton with a combined field of 102 pairs competing in a one-session men's and women's pair event.

The seventy-ninth Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field championships opened on a quiet note yesterday. It proved a routine session as six defending titleholders qualified with little difficulty.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee on narcotics announced today a nation-wide investigation of the drug traffic which may include public hearings in New York.
This letter is in reference to the bill providing for a Ready Reserve (H. R. 5297).

Carmelo Costa moved up another notch in his bid for the featherweight title last night when he gained a unanimous decision over Lulu Perez, Brooklyn rival, in the main event of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- H. Struve Hensel resigned today as Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security affairs, effective June 30. He said he could not afford financially to remain longer in Government.

William L. Lindquist, former delegate for Local 1588 of the International Longshoremen's Association, denied yesterday that assessments paid by longshoremen working at the Leonardo Naval Base were a "personal gift" for him.

THE "June bride '55" is more likely to be "showered" with shiny copper, chromium or stainless steel electrical assistants for her new home than the traditional gifts bestowed on the newly wed couple of years ago.

It is a comparative rarity for any agency created by government to go out of business on its own motion. But that is what the Long Island Transit Authority, in its final report to Governor Harriman, proposes to do. Its work is done, and well done. The authority inherited a nightmare four years ago.

" PERSON TO PERSON" provided a half-hour of relaxed and charming entertainment last night as Margaret Truman, in New York, interviewed her parents in their home in Independence, Mo. The C. B. S. network presentation was carried locally on Channel 2.

In the spring a young gourmet's fancy turns to Paris. After a cold, hungry winter in New York restiveness afflicts the sensitive palate as the sky shades from gray to blue again and the sharp winds become soft breezes.

The Horn Hardart Company has signed a contract for the purchase of a large restaurant site on Mamaroneck and Chester Avenues White Plains, N. Y., according to Tankoos Co., brokers in the deal. Henry Krinsky, Irving Schatz and David Morgulas are the sellers.
It takes almost as keen a memory as Jack Coffey's to remember when Jack Coffey wasn't the baseball coach and graduate manager of athletics at Fordham.
VIENNA, May 27 -- The world's free unions posted a "keep out" notice today to Yugoslav labor.
DETROIT, May 27 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., began preparations today for a possible strike against the Ford Motor Company Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Administration proposed today a plan to stop further Congressional appropriations for power facilities for the Tennessee Valley Authority. The plan would let the agency rely on bond sales to private investors to finance these projects.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 27 -- Four United States Government economists arrived today for a week of discussions with Thai officials on problems arising out of the disposal of United States surplus rice crops.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Car and truck output in United States factories this week will total 198,373 units, Ward's automotive reports said today. The agency listed 167,743 cars and 30,630 trucks in the total. Last week 176,441 cars and 31,646 trucks were built. In the comparable week of 1954 119,004 cars and 22,162 trucks were assembled.

" ADMIRALS ON HORSEBACK,"* by Geoffrey Williams, is a cheerful, helter-skelter novel of Allied combined operations, rich in rugged naval grandeur. The characters in Mr. Williams' charade know their parts almost better than the author. They should. After all, they've been appearing in these footloose fantasies for a long time.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Salk vaccine will start flowing again next week for the fight against poliomyletis.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week that ended May 24, 1955, at 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Increases in average prices for farm products and processed foods were too small to affect the over-all index.
The weather man was the forgotten man late yesterday as tens of thousands of New Yorkers departed under a brilliant sun for the three-day Memorial Day week-end.

MONTREAL, May 27 (Canadian Press ) -- The Seafarers International Union of North America adopted today a resolution calling for immediate legislation to ban foreign-flag competition in the Great Lakes on the intracoastal trade in Canada and on the United States-Canadian lake port trades.

HILLBURN, N. Y., May 27 -- A fourteen-mile addition to the New York State Thruway was opened to heavy Memorial Day week-end traffic here today at 3 P. M. The road extends the southerly end of the Thruway from Harriman to Hillburn, only one mile from the New York- New Jersey state line.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A subscription radio system that leaves normal programs undisturbed was both patented and demonstrated here this week. William S. Halstead, presi dent of Multiplex Services Corporation, New York, got the patent (No. 2,709,254).

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs refused today to adopt a resolution "deploring premature announcement of medical discoveries," for fear that it might imply an unintended criticism of the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.

A site for an apartment house has been purchased at the northwest corner of Beekman Place and Fiftieth Street. Known as 20 to 28 Beekman Place, the property now contains five four-story dwellings. It will be replaced by a twelve-story and penthouse structure with ninety-eight apartments of 282 rooms.

The Board of Justices of the Domestic Relations Court has adopted a resolution urging a state-city conference to improve the handling of juvenile delinquency. A prompt end of over-crowding in detention homes for boys and girls is advocated by the board.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Rubber interests that acquired Government synthetic rubber plants last month have a promising, expanding market before them for years to come, the Government said today.
KEELUNG, Formosa, May 20 -- The U. S. S. Eldorado, bristling with radio masts, antennae and radar screens, is the nerve center of the United States Seventh Fleet.
There will be no New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collections of blood today, tomorrow or Monday, Memorial Day.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: ...

AN evaluation of current television programs for children, and a guide for parents who would like to do some evaluating of such shows on their own, have just been completed by two women's groups, working independently and miles apart.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen won last night what they regard as "a major victory" when the nation's railroads corrected a "wage inequity." Agreement was reached on a graduated rate of pay for the freight-conductors and brakemen in the union's 25,500 members.

Election of Theophil H. Mueller as a director of the Torrington Company and the promotion of eight staff executives in administrative changes was announced yesterday by Walter C. Thompson, president. Mr. Mueller, assistant to the president, joined the company last December.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- Keenan Wynn's first job since leaving Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer four months ago will be a co-starring role in "The Girl In The Cage," to be produced by Universal-International Filming on the story about juvenile delinquency will begin next week.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 27 -- The prospect of a fast, cold race faced the crews of fifty yachts this evening in the tenth Memorial Day contest of the Storm Trysail Club.
WASHINGTON, May 27--President Eisenhower recommended to Congress today speedy action to hasten the flow of deserving immigrants to the United States.

MONTREAL, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- The directors of Thrift Stores, Ltd., recommended today that shareholders accept an offer by Dominion Stores, Ltd., to purchase all outstanding shares of Thrift stock at $40 a share.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 -- Marathon runners from all over Yugoslavia arrived at Marshal Tito's birthday party Wednesday bearing symbolic torches of goodwill. "Where is Khrushchev?" inquired one of this country's leaders. "He should be here in track pants and carrying his own torch."

LONDON, May 27 -- Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden held an emergency Cabinet meeting tonight after railwaymen had refused to call off the nationwide strike set for midnight tomorrow. An attempt during the day to settle the dock strike failed.
Seven individuals and three corporations were permanently barred yesterday from engaging in the securities business in this state.

BONN, Germany, May 27 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer called on the United States today to take the initiative in proposing general and controlled disarmament to save the world from "complete destruction." He declared "there never has been a more promising time than now" for such a step.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Treasury reported today that its short-term borrowing costs had decreased slightly this week.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 27 (UP) -- The commander of large rebel forces in southwest Vietnam was reported today to have rejected Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's ultimatum that he surrender his forces or face annihilation.

The world needs a Crusade of the Commandments for its moral reconstruction, Rabbi Edward E. Klein said yesterday. He preached at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street, on the "ancient imperatives" revealed on Mount Sinai.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 27 (AP)--Dow Finsterwald of Bedford Heights, Ohio, reached the halfway mark in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament today with a four-stroke lead of 131, thirteen under par.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The Hendy International Corporation, operator of chartered ore vessels, reported today it would save about $22,000,000 by having five ore carriers built in Germany.

BUENOS AIRES, May 27 -- President Juan D. Peron signed today a decree calling for the election of a Constituent Assembly to revise the Argentine Constitution. The assembly with its powers limited to rewriting the articles of the Constitution concerned with state's relation to the Roman Catholic Church, must be elected by Nov. 26.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., May 27 -- Mrs. Betty Caroline Anderson celebrated her ninetieth birthday anniversary today as one of the only known living sets of nonagenarian triplets in the world.

The one-story building at 137 Bayard Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the Zion National Wholesale Grocers from E. Thypin. The structure, containing about 7,500 square feet of space, will be used for the warehousing and distribution of groceries and household products. The lease was made through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.
DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Walter Reuther, C. I. O. president, tonight invited Henry Ford 2d to attend tomorrow's meeting of the United Auto Workers' National Ford Council.
ST. LOUIS, May 27 (UP) -- Eddie Stanky said tonight he wasn't worried about a published report that his days as the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals wewe numbered.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 27 -- The General Assembly is preparing legislation to aid more than 600 families in the Stamford area. They will have to move from their homes by Sept. 1 to make way for the Greenwich-to-Killingly Expressway.
After an active and optimistic morning session, in which stocks almost crossed their historical highs, the market lost drive yesterday and closed with small losses.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 A loaded furniture van roared out of control down the steepest part of Nob Hill today, killing seven persons. The big truck gained a speed estimated at 100 miles an hour as it crossed the main street of Chinatown.

The Coaching Club American Oaks will be the big offering at Belmont Park today. For 3-year-old fillies that will be asked to go a mile and three-eighths, the Coaching Club is one of the most important races on the local board.
PASCAGOULA, Miss., May 27 -- U. S. S. Glacier, scheduled to sail next winter on Expedition Deepfreeze to the Antarctic with Admiral Richard E. Byrd in the task force, was commissioned here today.
BONN, Germany, May 27 (Reuters) -- West Germany is about to free another 10 per cent of her dollar trade with the United States and Canada, an increase of 67 per cent and 78 per cent respectively.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower today declared tornado-hit sections of Kansas a major disaster area and promised that state Federal rehabilitation aid.
" Mister Roberts," the Joshua Logan-Thomas Heggen drama of men aboard a Navy cargo vessel in the Pacific, will be saluted by Ed Sullivan's "Toast of the Town" on Sunday, June 19.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Conugress today proposing ten amendments to the Refugee Relief Act:

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 27 (AP) -- Remington Rand, Inc., and the Sperry Corporation will disappear as corporate entities July 1 under a merger agreement given final approval here today by stockholders of Remington Rand.

OTTAWA, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign trade, vital to her prosperity, rose sharply in April with exports increasing to $341,900,000 -- a three year high for the month and a gain of $43,700,000 from $298,200,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- William G. (Big Bill) Lias, 400-pound Wheeling, W. Va., race track operator, owes more than $2,000,000 in back income taxes and penalties, a United States Tax Court judge held today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 27 -- Fifteen Indian Government officials will leave New Delhi Tuesday for Moscow to study Soviet industry and agriculture. The Indians are the first to take advantage of a 3-year-old Soviet offer to supply technical help through the United Nations.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies ran their winning streak to five games tonight as they beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 5 -- 2. Andy Seminick of the Phils hit a two-run homer in the ninth to send the game into extra innings.
WASHINGTON, May 27--The Eisenhower Administration and Congressional leaders were elated today at the results of the British election.

BALTIMORE, May 27 -- Eddie Robinson admits his greatest inclination is to hit a baseball. The Yankees' first-base understudy for the sidelined Bill Skowron and Joe Collins hit one tonight in the first inning and when he did the Bombers had enough runs to beat the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 2.
LONDON, May 27 -- Women defeated men in twenty-four constituencies in yesterday's election. Two of their victories were outstanding -- one for a small majority and one for a large majority.

Once again the nation's cotton growers are preparing to do battle with a perennial enemy -- the boll weevil. This year, thanks to improved weapons, the planters hope for better success in repelling the annual invasion of the parasite.
ALBANY, May 27 -- The State Conservation Commissioner today accused critics of his department's employment policies of making "sensational untrue charges" for "partisan political purposes."
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter introduced a bill today to reduce from 65 to 60 years the age at which wives and widows might qualify for old age and survivors benefits.

BALTIMORE, May 27 (UP) -- Belair Stud's Nashua today remained the "big horse" for tomorrow's $116,600 Preakness Stakes at Pimlico but it was Sticks, flown in from Chicago for the race, who intrigued Maryland's turf fans.

HARTFORD, May 27 -- Seventeen years ago Chief Justice William M. Maltbie of the State Supreme Court of Errors wrote a decision condemning lotteries and other forms of "mass gambling." This decision has come back to haunt him -- he has won a car in a raffle.
The General State Authority of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania announced yesterday plans for borrowing $50,000,000 on six issues of serial bonds maturing from 1958 to 1982.

Team members, friends and former pupils, among whom were many track and field dignitaries, paid tribute to 70-year-old Dr. Harold Anson Bruce, retiring City College track coach, at the Hotel Vanderbilt last night.
The Junior Board of the Children's Recreational Center of Bellevue Hospital will give a dance on June 8 at the Town and Tennis Club, 430 East Sixty-fifth Street.
Popular support for President Eisenhower's trade program was urged yesterday by Roswell L. Gilpatric, former Under Secretary of the Air Force.

In its first full-dress debate on foreign affairs since it became the representative of a sovereign nation the German Parliament, through its decisive lower house, has given overwhelming approval to the Government's pro-Western policy presented by Chancellor Adenauer.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A "slow down and live" appeal was directed by President Eisenhower today to all motorists over the long Memorial Day week-ed.
PARIS, May 27 -- Jean Monnet, who invented the European Coal and Steel Community, will now leave it to try to salvage the principle and the ideal that it represents.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower is expected by some associates to name the Under Secretary of the Treasury, Marion B. Folsom, to succeed Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 -- The Soviet-Yugoslav friendship negotiations got off to a cool start today. They are designed to make up for past differences and, if possible, to establish a mutual understanding on international questions.
THE landlocked salmon fishing is now at its peak in Maine. Reports from most of the northern and eastern counties indicate that the fishing has never been better.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 (AP) -- The following communique on the first day of Soviet-Yugoslav talks was issued tonight:
LONDON, May 27 -- The Conservative party has won a decisive victory in the British general election. It has more than tripled its over-all majority in the House of Commons.
A controversial tanker construction program for the Navy will get under way in a few weeks, according to reports from Washington last night.

THIS week will see the first performance by William Dollar's new ballet group, and the first pair of public performances in two years by the advanced students in the School of Performing Arts. This latter organization is a branch of the Metropolitan Vocational High School and is the only public high school in the world devoted to the teaching of the performing arts on a vocational basis.

VISITORS to Central Park's Seventy-second Street lagoon last week were suddenly diverted from a serene contemplation of things pastoral by the unexpected arrival of an obviously exotic Hollywood production crew ranging from stars to "grips."
ALBANY, May 28--Following is the text of a letter sent by Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, to all upstate physicians.

If our national supply of physicians is to be increased to meet the growing demands for health services and keep pace with our expanding population it is obvious that the number of our medical school graduates must be increased.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 28-- G. Frederick Reinhardt, new United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, avoided any reference to Chief of State Bao Dai in presenting his credentials today.

PITTSBURGH, May 28-- The Philadelphia Phillies scored four runs in the eleventh inning today and beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8--4. The Pirates should have won, 5--4, in the tenth, but lost because a rookie, Gene Freese, forgot to touch second base.
The United States nuclear industry is preparing for a worldwide sales and propaganda battle that may develop this August at the Geneva Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy.

GARDEN State Parkway officials last week opened their bridge over the Passaic River to traffic, thus extending the Parkway northward to Route 46 and giving motorists using the George Washington Bridge almost direct access to the New Jersey highway.
MANHASSET, L.I., May 28 -- Many members of society on the North Shore are giving up the entire week-end of June 3, 4 and 5 to take part in and manage the fourth annual North Shore Hospital fair.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Democratic leaders in Congress have been playing their politics so subtly this year that some puzzled observers are beginning to wonder if the gentle spirit of bipartisanship now prevailing is to be carried over into the campaign of 1956.

THERE are almost as many credits in "Mr. Peepers" as there are on the TV original. It was written by Wally Cox, the star, "with the assistance of William Redfield." Mr. Redfield is an actor. Mr. Cox also makes "grateful acknowledgment" to David Swift, Jim Fritzell and Everett Greenbaum, "on whose scripts and ideas these chapters are based."

There were indications last week that divisive forces within the Republican party in New York were losing their momentum and that new pressures to restore cooperation between the party's component groups were beginning to make themselves felt.
POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD made available last week the design of the 3cent stamp for the centennial anniversary of the Soo Locks.

PARIS. ALTHOUGH the Paris Opera is a state-supported institution charged with offering opera and ballet entertainments eleven months out of every twelve, it has mounted few contemporary operas during the last decade.

FRESCO THOMPSON is now a sedate vice president of the Brooklyn Dodgers. Oh, well. Maybe he isn't so sedate but at least he's a vice president of the Brooks. Fresco's highest previous rank came a quarter of a century ago when he was captain of the Phillies. In that era they really were the Phutile Phils.

'THE MORNING SHOW," which has long sought an eye-opening format, faced a major upheaval last week. Jack Paar asked the Columbia Broadcasting System to relieve him as host in the midst of definite indications that the program may be split into two entities.

LONDON. AT THE moment there are two St. Joans on the stage in London in two plays written out of the same source material. The more recent one is Jean Anouilh's "The Lark" in an English text by Christopher Fry, with Dorothy Tutin in the leading part.

An 8 per cent gain in sales was registered by department stores throughout the United States in the week ended May 21, compared with the same week a year ago. Every district reporting to the Federal Reserve Board showed increased sales-- the gains ranging from 1 to 15 per cent.

The Air Force's announcement on Thursday of a B-52 production speed-up was a "shocking admission that we have been holding back in bomber production when the Soviets have been proceeding full speed ahead," Governor Harriman declared last night.

LAWN chairs whose fabric shows signs of age and wear can be thoroughly revitalized with a seat and back restoration. An effective method is to weave colorful plastic webbings over the chair's frame. These come in a variety of colors, including green, yellow, red and beige.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 -- The thirty-three qualifiers said two alternates for Monday's thirty-ninth annual 500-mile auto race on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway are ready.
Steamship passenger terminals on both sides of the Hudson River had their busiest period of the year last week as the annual summer exodus of Europe-bound tourists swung into high gear.
Members of every creed have a personal responsibility to strengthen the United Nations, Rabbi David B. Kahane said in a sermon yesterday.

ATOMIC POWER-- Manufacturers, electric-power companies, research institutions and other non-government organizations will spend approximately $300,000,000 of their own money in the next four years on atomic-energy research, according to a report issued by the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc.

AN expert on aeronautical safety called on an executive of a major airline not so long ago and showed him a photograph taken after one of those marginal crashes in which some passengers are killed, some survive.

DENVER, Colo.--Motorists gazing eastward this summer from the skyroad, 9,000 feet high, which ribbons its way north and south along the crest of the Rampart Range, will get a panoramic view of the site of the U.S. Air Force Academy which is soon to spread out over 17,500 acres of rolling foothills below.
MADISON, Wis., May 28 (AP) --Pennsylvania's oarsmen swept to a 1 1/2 length victory over the University of Wisconsin tonight, in a race finished under cover of darkness.
Nine years ago today the 1946 bull market hit its high. In five months thereafter it fell 28 per cent.

VIENNA, May 28 -- United States trade unionists are becoming experts in the arts of diplomacy. That was one of the explanations for the victories scored by Americans this week over the neutralist forces in the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

LONDON, May 28--One of the most magnificent mile races in history saw three men beat the four-minute mark today. A 24-year-old Hungarian soldier, Laszlo Tabori, won in 3 minutes 59 seconds. He finished six feet ahead of Chris Chataway and Brian Hewson, both of England.

Manhattan College's well-rounded squad captured the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field outdoor championship for the third time in four years yesterday. It was a notable triumph, the Jaspers edging Penn State after a keen race for team honors.

STANTON, Del., May 28 (AP)-- The Elkam Stables Ifabody sped to a convincing victory in the $10,000-added Wilmington Handicap today as Delaware Park launched its thirty-two-day race meeting before 17,379 fans.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 28-- Mrs. M.G. Walsh's Erin's Cottage captured the Connecticut Cup, the three-mile steeplechase feature of the Adjacent Hunts race meeting today.

A special Hoover commission under the direction of Gen. Mark W. Clark has been investigating intelligence operations of the United States all over the world. There was not the slightest clue in the news dispatches to what the commission's report contained and recommended, which is about what everybody expected, considering the highly secret nature of the findings.
PARIS, May 28 (AP)--Vic Seixas and Budge Patty, American tennis tourists, reached the quarterfinals of the French tournament as the two-week-long event proceeded at its leisurely pace.
WASHINGTON, May 28--Few of Washington's many untested political battlefields this year are so perilously mined as the Administration's employe-security program.

NAPLES is the scene of this novel--the grim Naples of Italo-German occupation, the Naples smashed by enemy bombs yet bursting with traditional joy during the pause of Allied occupation--and, finally, the atrophied city of hunger and despair as the war moved to the north.

IN discussing the individual works in a season as profuse as the recent "American Dance" series presented by the B. de Rothschild Foundation, it is necessary to be brutally selective. There were twenty-six productions (besides seventeen solos), and they fell into many categories as to novelty.

LONDON. FIVE powerful limelights cutting through a blue haze of cigarette and cigar smoke--five limes focused in a sharp-edged pool of light on the wooden boards of a bare stage-- five beams concentrated on one man who is telling a joke or singing a song or juggling dinner plates.

LOS ANGELES, May 28-- While controversy seethes about desegregation in public schools below the Mason-Dixon line, unspectacular but marked progress is being made toward elimination of racial discrimination in the West.
A new favorite of international smuggling rings has developed to plague United States customs officers. It is the Swiss watch movement.

VIENNA, May 28--A prediction that John L. Lewis' United Mineworkers Union would come into the merged American labor movement was made today. The forecast came from the head of the delegation representing the Congress of Industrial Organizations at the closing session of the biennial congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

THE timing and correlation of jobs around the house is a conjoint factor that has to be mastered. For the beginner it is seldom troublesome. He is feeling his way along; he is learning the techniques; he is content to take on one project at a time.

BUENOS AIRES, May 28-- The struggle between the Argentine Government and the Roman Catholic Church entered a new phase Wednesday when violence broke out in several of the provincial capitals. Police arrested more than 125 Catholics during the course of the day.

BALTIMORE, May 28--It took a spectacular catch by Chuck Diering to stop Mickey Mantle, but there was no stopping the Yankees tonight. Although Mickey's consecutive-game hitting streak ended at sixteen, the league-leaders continued to roll with a 3-2 squeaker over the Baltimore Orioles.
Two tracts of land will be opened for residential development soon in Brookfield, Conn.
There was more talk among the Dodgers and Giants yesterday about Eddie Stanky's dismissal by the St. Louis Cardinals than there was about the ball game that just had been played.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The Office of Defense Mobilization will decide within ten days whether to defer deliveries of aluminum, to the national stockpile in the last half of this year, Arthur S. Flemming, Administrator, said today.

The Governor Clinton Hotel, a twenty-eight-story building at Seventh Avenue and Thirty-first Street, opposite Pennsylvania Railroad Station, has been purchased by Lawrence A. Wien in a deal negotiated by Harry B. Helmsley, president of HelmsleySpear, Inc., brokers.

THE annual exhibition at the American Academy of Arts and Letters has just opened and the work shown by the newly elected members and grantees of its junior, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, has the most modern look of any of the long series of these events.
The raucous merchandising emphasis on home air conditioning has virtually obscured a boom in commercial and industrial air conditioning that grows bigger every year.

MANY a neophyte painter after doing a successful job in the living room or hall, goes on to tackle the kitchen in need of a fresh coat of enamel, and finds the results disappointing. All too often the solid color, glass-like finish is not achieved.

Three variations of the splitlevel design and a center-hall ranch home are offered at $26,990 to $35,000 at Elm Hill on Ridge Street in Rye, N. Y. The Bonwit Construction Company, headed by S. P. Bonan, is sponsoring the development, which will contain 150 dwellings.

MUCH of the pressure will be lifted from eastern trout streams during the next few weeks. As the bass seasons open in various states, thousands of anglers will concentrate their efforts on the smallmouth and largemouth.
RUMSON, N.J., May 28--A 4-year-old German shepherd imported by Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge a month ago from Germany made an impression in his first American appearance today.

EMOTIONAL intensity is a quality people love in music, and one reason early music declined in popularity was that it seemed tonally so pale in comparison with later music. Its limited sonority, especially in large concert halls, made it seem lacking in intensity.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 28 (AP)--Doug Ford made his bid to repeat in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament today by firing a third-round 65 for 200 during a 50-mile-an-hour wind.

Work is scheduled to be started next month on a big shopping center in the fastgrowing area around Islip in Suffolk County on Long Island. Pagliarulo Brothers of Copiague are sponsoring the project. They have built industrial buildings and many homes in the county.
Good business in apparel, notably in sportswear and dresses, has stimulated stores' buying activity, resident offices report.

SALES of television and radio sets in the Los Angeles signal area (where there are more than 2,000,000 TV sets in operation) were in close competition during April. More than 21,000 video sets and 19,000 radios were purchased, according to the Electric League of Los Angeles, Inc.
BOSTON, May 28--White tents and an outdoor stage have transformed the Public Garden into a cultural museum for the fourth annual Boston Arts Festival, which opens Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 28--Military courts may admit in courtmartial trials evidence obtained by wire-tapping that would be banned in civilian courts, the United States Court of Military Appeals has ruled.

AMERICANS and Britons sometimes use the same word or phrase to mean quite different things. With the travel season approaching, a knowledge of these distinctions may come in handy. Hero are some examples.

Plans whereby a company splits its profits with its employes are rapidly gaining popularity. About 8,000 are on record with the Internal Revenue Service compared with 6,000 in 1953 and only 500 a decade ago. The bases for split-ups vary all the way from 5 per cent to 50 per cent, with a typical cut ranging from 20 to 25 per cent.

Five weeks ago, only nine days after he had been made Prime Minister, Sir Anthony Eden asked the Queen to dissolve Parliament and call elections. Sir Anthony wanted a popular mandate. He also wanted a more authoritative majority than seventeen seats.

TO THE EDITOR: I was greatly interested in Mr. Stokes' article, especially in the following statements: "Why did tie popular vote bulge [in 1952] translate into so small a number of House seats for the Democrats?

Johnny Mize assumed his duties as batting coach of the Giants yesterday. Wearing civilian clothes (he has not yet been fitted out with baseball togs), Big John began work in the Polo Grounds at 10:30 A. M. He remained in clinical session until afternoon.

THE trial of the astronomer Galileo for heresy in 1633 has long been a "cause celebre." It has served throughout the years as the favorite warhorse of anticlerical historians of science and much that has been written about it is of little value.
The toll turnpike financing boom seems ready to get into high gear again after a sixmonth halt caused by litigation and second thoughts about routes and financing procedures.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) --Judge Harold M. Stephens, Chief Justice of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia since 1948, died here tonight. He was 69 years old.

THIS is one collection the general reader can relax with as comfortably as with some fat, family scrapbook. Whether the Daughters of the Confederacy here united all live up to the high title, "Heroines of Dixie," is beside the point.

FRANCK: Symphony in D minor; Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy (Columbia). Sumptuous sounds and a fervent performance. If you want a really juicy performance of this popular work, you need look no further.

The 1955 Greater New York contract bridge championships continued yesterday afternoon with 126 pairs entered in the two-session Open Pair championship. This was the blue ribbon pair event of the annual four-day metropolitan meet.

WHEN Robert E. Sherwood sits before a television set in New York tomorrow night to watch his play "The Petrified Forest," originating in Burbank, Calif., it will be the first time in twelve years that he will have seen it presented in any form.

THERE is a certain pitiless progress in a human being from the state of not-so-bad to that evil beyond recall. This awesome evolution, in a 15year-old boy in the jungle of Harlem's streets, is tersely, even terrifyingly, recounted in this perceptive novel about a group of youngsters engulfed by a world they never made.

THESE are some afterthoughts on the subject of last week's column--the differences and likenesses between literature and the other arts. One of the most obvious of the likenesses is that they are all dependent upon a medium: words, sounds, paint, clay, stone, wood or steel.

THE month of May is the time when apple trees blossom, when fishing rods splash into running streams in quest of uncooperative trout and when the Broadway auditors, pragmatically, make their final entries in the season's theatrical books.

Stocks extended their irregular recovery for the second successive week. Selected issues were strong, and the volume of trading improved moderately as prices advanced. Traders moved cautiously, however, as the approaching showdown in the automobile wage negotiations neared.

TWENTY of Louis Kronenberger's "occasional" literary pieces--shorter articles, appreciations, introductions, reviews --are collected in this book. Half deal with his favorite period, the eighteenth century; the rest deal mostly with modern literature.
DETROIT, May 28--The National Ford Council of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., called unanimously today for strike action against the Ford Motor Company.
LONDON, May 28--The Conservative party won its 344th seat in the new House of Commons tonight. It maintained its majority of fifty-nine over all other parties.

The Dodgers, on the strength of a three-run homer by Gil Hodges in the first inning, defeated the Giants yesterday, 5-3, and squared the current series at one victory apiece. A triple play by the Giants marked the action.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The National Institutes of Health, scene of the recent scientific conferences on Salk vaccine, loom up before a Washington visitor as sixteen major buildings on 300 landscaped suburban acres in Bethesda, Maryland.

ELMHURST, Ill., May 28 -- The Rev. Dr. Harold Holt, Episcopal church leader, died here today of a heart ailment in the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert Skiles. His age was 69. He retired Jan. 1 as rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church in Oak Park, where he had served for twenty-five years.
TORONTO, May 28--The curtain is about to rise on Canada's eighth annual International Trade Fair. The big show opens on Monday and will run through June 10.

ST LOUIS, May 28 -- Eddie Stanky was dismissed today as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals. Harry (The Hat) Walker, onetime National League batting champion and manager of the Rochester Red Wings since 1952, was named to replace Stanky.

NOW for a few dollars the book-buyer can have for his own most of what Marianne Moore has written about Wallace Stevens and William Carlos Williams and Ezra Pound, W. H. Auden and T.S. Eliot and Henry James--about old days on The Dial, and writing in general, and Jean Cocteau and Pavlova and the Sitwells' father.

INNSBRUCK, Austria-- Ringed on all sides by a magnificent crown of Alpine peaks, this 700-year-old capital city of the Austrian Tyrol provides a panorama of unusual contrasts. It offers a rich heritage of history and art and the spectacular sight of an almost limitless world of mountains.
BONN, Germany, May 28-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has come under renewed pressure to act promptly on the problem of German reunification.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)-- The Agriculture Department said today nine employes will receive distinguished service awards June 1 for outstanding research and administrative achievements.
At this time of year an auction sale in this city becomes an unusual event.

HONG KONG, May 28--Although it has not been invited to participate in a Big Four conference "at the summit," Communist China is still expacted here to play a substantial behind -the-scenes role on the Soviet side in helping shape the Communist position on such Far Eastern questions as may arise in these talks.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28--The leaders of the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia were understood to have reached agreement today on certain international objectives.

ANTS were particularly pesty last year from all reports of garden supply dealers, who were kept busy selling control chemicals. And it looks like the same situation may occur this year. For ants seem to get everywhere, inside and outside the house, in the lawns and in the borders.

WALTER KERR is a man of rich experience in the American theatre. He has directed plays both amateur and professional, taught playwriting and written plays. He was play reviewer for Commonweal magazine and since 1950 he has been the drama critic for The New York Herald Tribune.

TAKING inventory of his needs for a pleasant summer at the outdoor grill, the knowing kitchen amateur puts skewers near the top of the list. They may be merely lengths of heavy wire or elaborate "swords" of stainless steel with ornamental handles.

Art Today READERS of various newspapers could hardly have avoided the recent full-page statement of principles in the form of an advertisement by Huntington Hartford (A. P. heir, film and theatre producer and all-around, if tentative, patron of the arts).

Thomas E. Dewey, for twelve years Governor of New York, has since the beginning of 1955 been senior partner in a New York law firm--and a continuing force in Republican, politics. No clear leadership in the state party has emerged to replace his.
LONDON, May 28--From 1951 onward, Britain enjoyed two great assets in the conduct of international policy. One was Sir Winston Churchill and the other was Sir Anthony Eden.

THIS account of an expedition in the Ivory Coast country of West Africa is a weird one, and the reader must have a strong stomach to read parts of it. A story of cannibalism, told by an anonymous "fat old judge," introduces the book; the details are grisly to say the least.

WASHINGTON, May 28--Ten years after the war the peoples of the Free Nations seem to be going through a period of political moderation in which personalities rather than ideologies determine the outcome of elections.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Last Monday the Supreme Court made three decisions the vehicle for reminding Congress that it must not confuse its investigative functions with the powers of law enforcement.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28 --A downpour failed to slow Michigan's march to a smashing triumph today in the fiftyfifth Big Ten outdoor track meet.

THIS is the most comprehensive book yet written about the news coverage of the Civil War. Scholarly and at the same time highly readable, it tells the exciting story of those adventurous, picturesque special correspondents whose reports from camp and field made the war a living experience for the people of the North.

MORALIZING may have gone underground for most fiction writers, but not for Phyllis Bentley. In this, her seventeenth novel, she has revived the old tradition and taken the reader into her confidence from the start.

WHEN Edward Lear made his passage to India in 1873 he was in his sixties, racked by ill health, including epilepsy, asthma and bronchitis, and likewise by forms of selfdoubt which made him wonder whether he was, after all, an artist worthy of his salt.

WE judge the moral worth of two human friends according to which of them is ready to make the greater sacrifice without thought of recompense. Nietzsche, who, unlike most people, wore brutality only as a mask to hide true warmness of heart, said the beautiful words, "Let it be your aim always to love more than the other, never to be the second."
PRINCETON, N.J. May 28-- Princeton jolted Fordham's hopes for a berth in the National Collegiate district baseball tournament by defeating the Rams, 7--2, on University Field today.

IN 1893, two years before his death, Austin Dickinson, Emily's beloved brother, presented to Mable Loomis Todd a camphorwood chest containing the bulk of Emily's poems and a number of packets of family letters.

MAYBE it is because of the notion that an arbitrary quantity of an inert substance known as "sex" is necessary to make a novel sell. Maybe it is because the chief malady and hope of the human heart is too difficult a subject for most writers to handle.

To the Music Editor: MR. KLEES' letter, describing the frequent performances of Auber's "Fra Diavolo" in Germany, omitted to mention the successful performance of this work given by the Los Angeles City College Opera Workshop in 1951 under the direction of Dr. Hugo Stralitzer.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 28-- A great public "procession of wheat and grape" is being held here tomorrow afternoon to mark the final phase of preparation for the thirty-sixth International Eucharistic Congress.
New Yorkers continued to leave the city yesterday for a Memorial Day holiday at country and seashore resorts.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28-- Several bus loads of club women left here this morning for Idlewild International Airport in New York to fly to Geneva, Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, May 28--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, suggested today that President Eisenhower personally review the defense program in the light of new information on Soviet air power.

THIS is the time of year when insects begin raising large families with enormous appetites. It is also a time when plant disease-producing fungi shoot millions of spores into the air to search out the new growth for attack.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 28 (Reuters) -- The Shah of Iran and Queen Soraya today opened and dedicated a $3,000,000 hospital built by Mohammed Nemazee, an Iranian millionaire, at Shiraz, 400 miles south of here.
Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board and percentage comparisons with a year ago:

UNITED ARTISTS, which as been distributing the ilms of independent proucers aligned with it, finally has implemented a twoyear company plan to acquire properties suitable for filming by its producers.
COVENTRY, England--The name of Coventry is a symbol of British resistance during the blackest days of World War II. On a November night in 1940, 400 German bombers flattened the center of the city.

HOW does one photograph a village -- anywhere? Paul Strand supplies the answer of the classic documentary photographer in his "Un Paese" (Turin, Italy: Giulio Einaudi; New York: Museum Books, Inc. $7.50), a beautifully prepared volume of skillfully reproduced photographs.

AN opera for boys' voices has been written in England. Its name is "The Man From Tuscany" and it deals with an imaginary episode in the life of Bach and three of his sons. Christopher Hassall, who wrote the libretto for Sir William Walton's "Troilus and Cressida," has furnished the book.

DETROIT, May 28--In a Detroit suburb a salesman for electrical auto parts fumes about the possibility of a strike by auto workers. In a downtown clothing store the proprietor is worrying about what will happen to his business next month.

Cranesbill and buttercup now mark the meadow and the roadside, the lavender and the gold of May turning into June. They are weeds, both of them, in the farmer's calendar, and neither of them has any real standing with the flower gardener. Yet both belong to families highly respected.

REFUSING to acknowledge that the lilac season is over, the late-blooming lilacs are now near their peak of bloom. They rival the French hybrids in their range of colors, vary greatly in the size and character of their flower clusters and offer a choice of shrub habit.

WHY do you help the Communists who rule in Belgrade? Don't you realize Tito and his gang are no different from Khrushchev and his crew? Don't you understand that your massive economic and military aid is the only thing which has permitted Tito's Communists to continue enslaving my people?
The eventual development of a fleet of American-built turboprop airliners has been accelerated by the certification of a turbine-and-propeller power plant for commercial use.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 28 (AP) --M.S. Goldnamer's Royal Fan, a 14-to-1 shot, surprised 33,557 onlookers at Garden State Park today by scoring a neck victory over Another World in the $25,000 added Colonial Handicap.

THE imminent, or, at any rate, possible return to New York of burlesque, an art form of crumbled antiquity and varying degrees of piquancy, some of them sufficient to get it banned eighteen years ago, has caused a gentlemanly exhilaration in Thomas J. Phillips, a tall, white-haired individual of 68 with a marked platform manner.

Ten proposed amendments to the Refugee Relief Act have been submitted to Congress by President Eisenhower with an urgent appeal for prompt action. The amendments do not go far enough but they go in the right direction. Obviously in drafting them the Administration was obliged to concentrate not merely on what was morally right but also on what was politically possible.

WASHINGTON, May 28--Top experts wondered today whether they would ever solve completely the riddle of what happened to two small Cutter lots of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine. It was that vaccine that stalled the mass immunization of school children.

LONDON. AMERICAN folklore embraces the myth that any President of the United States conferring with European statesmen is in the predicament of a country boy cutting cards with a genial stranger in a checked suit--he can't win.

HARVARD--School News Schools and newspapers of ten cities will participate in a three week conference at Harvard University this summer on educational reporting. Newspaper staff reporters and educational administrators will join in discussions of the job of telling the story of education in their own communities.

BOSTON, May 28--The Washington Senators, held to one single for the first five innings, rallied for five runs on six hits in the sixth inning today to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 5--3. The first appearance of Ted Williams in the line-up failed to help the Red Sox.

HYBRIDIZING for new strains in double primroses is comparatively simple. In fact, it may be said that with a basic store of knowledge, proper planning and patience, success with hybridizing primroses is within the ability of many average home gardeners.
BONN, Germany, May 28 -- The West German Government submitted to Parliament today a bill laying the foundations for the future German armed forces of 500,000 men.
NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 28 (UP)--The United States Naval Academy crew won its second straight Western sprint championship today. Navy defeated a surprising Stanford crew by one length.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)-- The Defense Department is working on a global security plan for the long-haul defense of the free world against communism, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee disclosed today.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 28-- The Breakers Ball on July 9 will highlight the ten-day Washington -Rochambeau celebration to be held here beginning July 4.

IN 1939 Bruno Bettelheim came to America from Austria after a year in Dachau and Buchenwald. Shortly thereafter he published a brilliant study of the psychological effects of life in a concentration camp, "Individual and Mass Behavior in Extreme Situations."

HIROSHIMA, Japan, May 27 --What is the best thing to do in case of an atomic bomb attack? Scientists here are looking for an answer among persons who have survived one. They expect the data they are collecting to suggest effective civil defense techniques.
Construction work will get under way soon on a $3,000,000 shopping center in the South Farmingdale-North Massapequa area to meet the needs of families residing in Nassau and Suffolk counties.
No one knows better than Arthur H. Bunker the opportunities that lie in new fields, new problems, new horizons.

WHATEVER else this literary year of 1955 proves to be, it's a happy time for the cats -- the four-legged, furrytailed ones. First came Sandy Wilson's purring Sylvia. Now there's Mr. Lagard's spitting, slashing.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 20 --Australia is the southern anchor of Pacific defense, as Japan is the northern anchor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 8--Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party leader, was disputed tonight on Soviet United States relations by James W. Riddleberger, United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia.

HOLLYWOOD. ERIC JOHNSTON, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, spoke with marked confidence about the present and immediate future of the business during his recent tour of inspection here.

In the next fifteen years, college enrollment is expected to double. The questions and problems arising from this vast expansion are becoming of serious concern to persons responsible for higher education.

LONDON, Sunday, March 29--Britain's first serious railroad strike in more than twenty-nine years started early today. It threatened difficulties for millions on their annual three-day Whitsun holiday.

BONN, Germany, May 25-- German commercial airlines will begin regular paying trans-Atlantic service to New York for the first time June 8. The inaugural flight will be made June 1. The reborn Lufthansa, West Germany's government-owned airline, thus will fulfill a dream that neither its pre-war predecessor nor the wartime Luftwaffe was able to achieve.

THE often-damp basement, back-room or garage workshop is a constant threat to the home craftsman's tools and hardware. Tools in frequent use sometimes rust because they cannot be stored in protective grease.

AMBITION and love, pride and hate dominate Patricia Campbell's sturdy novel, set in the Pacific Northwest in the Eighteen Eighties. Port Garry, where the Cummings brothers came to found an empire, was a gloomy wilderness indeed.

Late last Thursday afternoon Dr. Jonas E. Salk walked out of a meeting at the Government's Public Health Service and, with an air of weary triumph, announced, "The fog is lifting." The Government had just turned effective control of the polio vaccine's safety over to the polio experts.

IMPROVED sealed-beam headlamps are likely to be factory -installed equipment on automobiles built after next July 4, according to the Automobile Manufacturers Association. By that time, it is forecast, the lamps will be legal in all states and all the states except Idaho and Georgia.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP)-- Jackie Collum pitched a fourhitter and Stan Palys drove in three runs with a home run and double tonight as the Cincinnati Redlegs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 5--1, to spoil the debut of Manager Harry (the Hat) Walker.

WASHINGTON, May 28--Fourteen Republican Senators today came quickly to the support of President Eisenhower's ten-point plan to facilitate the entry of refugees. The Senators, in a statement, said they "welcomed" the opportunity to endorse the proposals. One, Senator Arthur V. Watkins of Utah, said he was certain Congress would adopt them.
BELGRADE, May 28--What are the Soviet Union's highest leaders--Nikita S. Khrushchev, the party chief, and Nikolai A. Bulganin, the Premier--doing in Belgrade these days?
Whether the United States Government will subsidize cotton exports for the marketing year starting on Aug. 1 is a decision that is slated to be made within the next few weeks.

Writing in a recent issue of Ohio State's Health Center Journal, Dr. John A. Prior, assistant dean of Ohio State's College of Medicine, noted a steady decrease in the number of applications to medical schools throughout the nation over the past five years.
Harold E. Stassen said yesterday that women could do more than men to win world peace. He implied that their principal weapon was their right to vote.

I HAD thought or Benjamin Fine, education editor of The New York Times, as a talented reporter, a cool writer, the spokesman for the formalities of education. Here he appears in a new role--as the voice of the miserable, damaged and dangerous children who are America's juvenile delinquents.

DETROIT, May 28 (AP)--Following is the text of the statement by Henry Ford 2d declining the invitation by Mr. Reuther to the meeting of the union's Ford Council: Your telegram to me was delivered to my office at approximately 1:30 A.M.

UNCLE WILBERT ROBINSON, the head keeper of Brooklyn's unforgettable Daffiness Boys, never was more wrong in his life. When Mickey O'Neil, a henchman, wistfully remarked that he'd like to try coaching at third base some day. Uncle Robbie generously waved him down toward the bag.

The writer of the following letter is Professor of Bacteriology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, and is a specialist in virus research. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since publication of the Francis report the general public has been led to believe that advent of the Salk vaccine spells the conquest of poliomyelitis.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 28-- George Yeh, Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, said today he supported the idea of a conference between Presidents Eisenhower and Chiang Kai-shek.
DETROIT, May 28 (AP) -- Johnny Groth hammered two home runs and two doubles to pace a nineteen-hit attack and lead the Chicago White Sox to a 16-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

THE industrial indices are still pointing upward but the angle of ascent is tending toward the horizontal rather than the vertical. This flattening out of the upward trend is in line with predictions that the summer would bring some modification of the recovery movement.
Annapolis, Md., May 28--Si Ulcickas and Bob Pirie scored two goals each to lead Navy to a 6-2 victory over Army today before 6,000.
PERIGUEUX, France-- Where to begin, from a tourist's point of view, to consider the spectacular area of southwestern France of which this place is the capital, is a real problem.

WITH a retrospective exhibition of paintings by the late Arnold Friedman, the Marquie Gallery, which has been closed for several years, now reopens in new quarters at 236 East Sixtieth Street.

The fur district on the west side of Manhattan is to get a new office building. A sevenstory structure is planned for a plot of 17,500 feet at 216 to 228 West Twenty-seventh Street. It will replace a row of five-story structures.
The Toomey-Fountain Mortgage and Abstract Company of Hackensack, N. J., has announced a number of executive appointments effective June 1.

MOSCOW, May 28--Westerners in Moscow had still not quite recovered today from their astonishment at the speech made by Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief, on his arrival in Belgrade Thursday.

LONDON. WHAT makes a Great Power? If we want to find out, we must collect one or two living specimens for examination, and in our world today we can think, at once, of two vast countries whose title to rank as Great Powers would not be disputed by anybody.

BIDDING methods change little from year to year, but over the course of decades there are discernible trends. In the middle of the Nineteen Thirties fancy conventional bids had a vogue--aceshowing bids, asking bids, voidshowing bids, and various others.
PARIS, Sunday, May 29--The French were up against trouble across North Africa today despite their grant of internal autonomy to Tunisia.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 28-- John Matthews' Vim, the noted twelve-meter racer, led the fleet home in the Storm Trysail Club's tenth annual Block Island race tonight. The sloop, commanded by Don Matthews, the son of the owner, crossed the finish line at Stamford Breakwater at 9:50:51.

ARNE SUCKSDORFF'S "The Great Adventure," which came to the Paris last week, is this writer's estimation of a well-nigh perfect nature film. And it certainly shapes up as one of the finest and most sensitive ever shown.

Washington stewed and rumbled last week about a crisis of its own devising. A brief and obscure announcement two weeks ago about formation flights by some new Soviet bombers had burgeoned by the week-end into a first-class political hassle.

AMERICAN FORK, Utah-- In this topsy-turvy land of perpetual snowbanks, mud geysers, inverted mountains, balanced rocks, natural bridges and the like, it is still somewhat surprising to learn that explorers must climb 1,200 feet of mountainside to descend into a cave.

The rise in juvenile delinquency continues to baffle parents and disturb the experts. Here is a sampling of opinion, representing many fields, on what is behind the persistent problem and what may be done about it.
The display of model houses will mark the formal opening today of Jersey colonies in Park Ridge and Oradell. Other Bergen builders are developing new groups in Tenafly, Saddle River and Closter.
The possibility of a general increase in footwear prices faded last week when hide prices tumbled.

May has been a banner business month, according to the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The latest survey of the buyers' group also disclosed optimism regarding economic conditions for the rest of this year.

THE extraordinary career of Booker T. Washington was best summarized in the title he gave to his best-known book. "Up From Slavery." Born on a West Virginia plantation in 1856 and therefore able to remember what slavery and war were like.
