Joseph P. Godby will retire this week after twenty-one years as a Government space man.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP)--Ernie Banks' homer paced a three-run sixth inning that broke a 2-2 stalemate today and gave the second-place Chicago Cubs a 5-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
BARRE, Vt., May 28--Henry Hollister Jackson, an insurance actuary and educator, died last night of a heart attack. His age was 70.
One museum event and a number of group show in galleries make up the art attractions of the week, as the season heads into its summer calm.

VIENNA--Austria's sudden achievement of a state treaty and with it her freedom after ten years of occupation will affect the calculations of tourists and travel bureaus as well as those of soldiers and statesmen.
PARIS, Sunday, May 29--The conventions under which Tunisia is to achieve internal autonomy were initiated here early today.

The victory that the Conservatives won in Thursday's general election belongs, in a special sense, to Sir Anthony Eden. This will be his Government and his Parliament, with a good, solid majority in support. A great task and a great opportunity lie ahead.

Each year about this time, activity in the dairy industry spurts. Bossie starts producing milk at peak rates and supplies pile up. This calls for extra effort on the part of all hands in the industry to get these supplies moving into distributive channels.
Cardinal Spellman ordained thirty-four young men as Roman Catholic priests in a ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

In Europe, the talk about America commonly involves such adjectives as colossal, efficient, incredible, and such achievements as bridges, skyscrapers, super highways. Yet, on my first visit to New York, I have been amazed not so much by the technological marvels--as by the people. Particularly in the neighborhoods--downtown, Ninth Avenue, Harlem or the Bronx--where New Yorkers live, rather than where they work.
MOSCOW, May 28--A thoroughgoing revision of the Soviet wage structure seems to be in prospect. A new Government committee has been created apparently for that purpose.
BALTIMORE, May 28--The one, two, three order of favoritism was the one, two, three order of finish in the record-cracking seventyninth running of the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico today.

Long Island developers continue to open new colonies or expand existing ones in an effort to meet the sustained demand for houses in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Model dwellings are being opened today in a number of communities.

The Indochinese truce left France with a single important center of empire--Africa. Her holdings there are extensive and rich, but basically her position depends on three North African territories--Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco.

FRIDAY and Saturday are going to be busy days in Radburn, N.J., for the Garden Club has scheduled a two-day tour of homes and parks. Headquarters are at the Radburn Grange Hall and tour hours are from 12 noon to 5 P.M. on Friday and from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 28 --Army scored its first baseball victory over Navy since 1951 today, winning 5 to 1.

High Voltage of the Wheatley Stable made herself mighty popular with most of the 35,608 racegoers at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old daughter of Ambiorix was made the odds-on choice in the thirty-ninth running of the Coaching Club American Oaks, and she responded by registering a convincing victory.

CHICAGO, May 28--Non-farm employment in the Chicago metropolitan area recorded a substantial gain at mid-March compared with the month before, but it is still far behind totals achieved in March last year. The state employment service reported Chicago area non-farm employment totaled 2,223,500 persons at March 15, up 14,800 from Feb. 15 and off 23,600 from the year before.
UDALL, Kan., May 28--The task of recreating this shattered village after the worst torando in Kansas history was gaining headway today.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- United States foreign policy officials have tentatively conclude that the Russians may have blundered and unwittingly strengthened Yugoslav President Tito's independence by their behavior in Belgrade.

MEMORIAL, DAY brings to mind poppies and peonies. Though both plants generally bloom at this time in New York City, city dwellers more frequently think of the little red paper replicas of the one, and the huge, fragrant, gypsophila-dotted bouquets of the other.
Peter Doelger, Inc., is adding another chapter to a 75-year-old story in the Sutton Place area that started with brewing and continues in building.
RICHMOND, Va., May 28-- The Manuscript Society supported today the right to private ownership of certain historic Government documents.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) --The Air Force plans to ask Congress soon for more than $300,000,000 in extra funds to carry out its anounced speed-up in the production of B-52 jet bombers.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 28 (AP) --Lord Steward nosed out Stenographer in the one-mile $8,000 Bronx Trot in 2:03 3/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Katie Key, the favorite, finished third.

There is mounting dissatisfaction with the way the United States Public Health Service has been directing the utilization of the Salk vaccine. The reason is manifestly the vagueness of the announcements that the service has made ever since the Cutter vaccine was withdrawn.

MORE than 300 black-andwhite and oil-colored prints were submitted in the 1955 Inter-Hospital Contest of the Volunteer Service Photographers, judged here last week. In this class, the first grand prize of the S. Bayard Colgate Award and Posner Cup, permanent challenge trophy, went to Chris Burns, a patient at the Bronx V.A. Hospital, for the print reproduced here.

TO THE EDITOR: W.H. AUDEN in "Speaking of Books" writes: "I would gladly see a New Critic in every public school and high school; at the college level, however, the [critical] approach has serious limitations."

A merchandising plan for rental apartments has been worked out for a new development on the East Side. It will permit tenants to make a choice of decorator colors, kitchen cabinets and tile, ceramic and vinyl flooring.

THE piano, a versatile instrument, is being put to a variety of uses on records these days. It serves, for instance, to introduce Alistair Cooke, the debonair conferencier of "Omnibus," as a jazz musician of sorts in An Evening With Alistair Cooke at the Piano (Columbia).

AQUATIC plants in the right places and in the right proportions are desirable. On the other hand, they can present serious problems if they are abundant in the wrong places or wrong proportions. Aquatics can easily take over a pond or lake and ruin it for swimming, fishing and other recreational purposes.

THOSE who spend the summer within sight, sound and smell of the sea need not leave gardening behind, for the seaside garden can be as enchanting as its inland counterpart. Given some protection from high winds, salt spray and drifting sands, many of the summer garden's most indispensable flowers thrive luxuriantly only a short distance from seaweed -ribboned shores.

THE first recordings in a series by the Israel Philharmonic have been issued by Angel. They reveal an orchestra that obviously is a first-rank organization. Paul Kletzki conducts the group on these disks, in a repertory that consists of Mahler's First Symphony, Mendelssohn's Third Scotch and, on two disks, Mahler's Symphony No. 9 and Schoenberg's Verklaerte Nacht.

ENGLAND'S hottest film property of the moment is Kenneth More, a jovial 35-year-old actor who not long ago was quietly marking time as a London stage-screen commuter. Along came a lightning bolt--"Genevieve."

Thirteen thousand persons in Korea heard and acclaimed a concert of our American Symphony of the Air. The triumphs that had been enjoyed in Japan were repeated. There was the same eagerness to come more closely into touch with Americans and American thought and life.

At 5 P.M. last Thursday a twoengined Soviet plane taxied to a stop at the airport in Belgrade. Out stepped six Russians. In the lead, in a blue summer suit, was Nikita S. Khrushchev, stocky chieftain of the Soviet Communist party. Trailing behind was Soviet Premier Nikolai Bulganin, also in mufti.

Zinc does not paint well unless the surface is treated first. The most common zinc items around the house are galvanized steel and iron. To paint objects like garbage cans, fence posts, etc., the surface must first be "etched" so the oxide will give a porous surface for the paint to bond.

THE honey bee has been the subject of almost as many books as the supposed lost continent of Atlantis, for the bee has been during human life on earth a fascinating mystery, a faithful contributor to man's imagination and to his appetite, a poetic symbol and a moral example.
Columbia University will end its 201st academic year with the start of commencement week activities today.

LOS ANGELES. EVERY Sunday evening, for more than two years now, a strange assortment of human oddities, including shoplifters, prostitutes, childmolesters and con men -- have been parading before the eyes of an ever-growing Los Angeles television audience.

INNSBRUCK, Austria. FOR several months this correspondent, as a Fulbright Professor, has been lecturing on America and on twentiethcentury American fiction to audiences of Europeans, chiefly in Austria.

ALBANY, May 28--Inoculation of school children in the 5 through 9 group with Salk poliomyelitis vaccine should save at least twenty-five lives in New York this year if polio conditions were as had as in 1954. Two hundred and sixty cases of paralytic polio would be prevented.

A special panel of experts met last week and framed new specifications for the production and testing of the Salk vaccine. After some hesitation all six producers have agreed. Just what the producers agreed to is not clear, so that virtually nothing has been done to dispel public confusion.

Dr. LeRoy E. Kimball, vice chancellor and controller of New York University will retire June 30, 1956, it was announced yesterday. At that time he will have completed forty-five years as a financial officer in the central administration of the university.

WARSAW, May 15--In Warsaw a taximeter registers 3.60 zlotys (90 cents at the official exchange rate) before the car even starts. The taxi travels three blocks before the meter clicks for the first time. A trip of about eight blocks costs 7.80 zlotys, or 10 zlotys ($2.50) if a tip is included.

THE junior high is having its annual Field Day and boys and girls race about the town park like a swarm of high-speed ants. The ninth grade boys have won the baseball game and Gil, their captain and home-run star, is surrounded by his gallery.

EVERYONE who likes to take a holiday now and then, but preferably now, will be interested in the Monday Holiday Plan which is being urged by the NATO. Now, before a heckler springs to his feet to ask if NATO hasn't enough to do these days in Europe without meddling in American holidays, let it be stated instantly that this NATO is not the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Bowled over for four runs in the first inning, the Giants went to tremendous lengths at the Polo Grounds yesterday to try to make it two in a row over Manager Walter Alston's high-flying Dodgers.
RYE, N.Y., May 28--Seventyseven craft showed up for the opener of the American Yacht Club's Memorial Day week-end regatta today. Three days of racing are scheduled.

IN speaking before the convention of the nation's broadcasters last week, President Eisenhower stressed television's role in helping keep the American public informed. In particular he urged the radio and TV men to insure that broadcasting be as free as other media.
KANSAS CITY, May 28 (AP)-- Cleveland's long-ball hitters, paced by Vic Wertz's two-run homer, defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 7--2, tonight.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Scant rainfall in May means that lawns are turning brown, and even perennials are wilting. Soak the soil thoroughly wherever possible. Sprinklers on the lawn and a soil soaker or hose without a nozzle so water can trickle into the ground around plants are efficient. Deep soaking of any given area once a week is sufficient.
Department and specialty stores across the nation will stage what may be a recordbreaking buying spree in New York beginning a week from tomorrow.

DOROTHY L. SAYERS' best story--mysterious and exciting in the austere sense of both words--may well be the yet unwritten story of her life. She had been for many years the most successful author of murder-mysteries in the Englishspeaking world when, in the middle of the journey, she turned away from her secular gifts to explore and cultivate her spiritual ones.
BERLIN, May 28--1,000 demonstrators from the Soviet sector stormed a West Berlin reunion of a Wehrmacht tank division today and almost overwhelmed the police defenders.
REDDING, Conn., May 28-- Phillips Wyman, magazine publisher and expert on magazine circulation problems, died yesterday in his home here. He was 60 years old.

THE personal as well as the public reports on the visit of the Symphony of the Air to Japan have been coming in. They make clear that the American orchestra's twenty-one-day stay in that country, which ended last week, was a happy, exciting and touching occasion for everyone.

Makers of History We had a reminder the other day--one of many in recent years-- that a small city, enjoying that rank for a couple of centuries, notwithstanding a population count never above a modest four figures, is, in fact, a place where history has been made.

MOST of the pages of this book are devoted to Admiral William H. Standley's services as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union from February, 1942, to October, 1943. In addition there is an account of Admiral Standley's distinguished career in the Navy, which culminated in his service as Chief of Naval Operations in the mid-Thirties.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, warning against the dangers of "conformity," said yesterday that a child should not be permitted to become "a chip off the old block" lest he become "as wooden as the block off which he was chipped."
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- One of the livest and most perplexing problems currently besetting business and antitrust law enforcement agencies is that of mergers of industrial corporations.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 29 -- Encounters between Nikita S. Khrushchev and two representatives of smaller countries allied to the United States were described today by diplomatic sources.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 27 -- The stockholders of the former I. G. Farben Company met today for the first time since 1945 to hear a report on the last ten years in the life of the giant chemical trust. To their surprise they learned from a board of liquidators that the company's death throes would last "for many years to come."
New York's largest baseball crowd of the 1955 season witnessed a rare incident yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
The dilemma in which the problem of juvenile delinquency has placed organized society was depicted yesterday by Justice Nathaniel Kaplan of the Domestic Relations Court.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Foreign aid, foreign trade and a pay increase for postal workers top the agenda for Congress this week.

Mayor Wagner has chosen James J. Comerford for a ten-year term on City Magistrate's Court. Mr. Comerford, former assistant district attorney, has been serving as a temporary justice in Domestic Relations Court.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 27 -- Continental monetary authorities expect early action by the new British Government to reduce further the number of official restric tions on convertibility of the pound into other currencies.
The credit man in business has changed with the times.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 29 -- DeCoursey Fales' fifty-nine-foot schooner, Nina, today was named the winner of the tenth Storm Trysail Club Block Island race. Finishing late last night, along with two other Class A yachts, Nina took top honors with a corrected time of 27 hours 14 minutes 35 seconds for the 200-mile test.

MONZA, Italy, May 29 (AP) -- Jean Behra of France and Luigi Musso of Italy, today won the 1,008 kilometer (630 miles) super-Cortemaggiore Grand Prix in a race marred by three accidents. One driver was seriously injured.

Problems of milk pricing and distribution were discussed yesterday by Daniel Carey, State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, and Sol Chalek, general manager of Associated Food Stores, Inc. They spoke over WABD of the Du Mont Television Network on the program "Between the Lines." Lester W. Wolf was moderator.

RYE, N. Y., May 29 -- Corny Shields' International, Aileen, and Bob Chase's Lightning, Vee-Bob, won for the second straight day in the American Yacht Club's annual Memorial Day week-end regatta on Long Island Sound today.
A two-week conference for junior and senior high school teachers of social studies, English and related subjects will open at Hunter College on July 11.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 29 -- Neo-Destour (Nationalist) party adherents here welcomed the initialing of the Tunisian autonomy conventions in Paris early today. But they specified that they considered the projected home rule only a step toward the independence of the country.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Mike Fornieles scattered nine Detroit hits today as the Chicago White Sox beat the Tigers for the second straight day, 9-3.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senator William J. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, warned last night there was heavy speculation in the stock market and said stock margin re quirements should possibly be raised to 100 per cent.
CLEVELAND, May 29 -- Mayor Anthony J. Celebrezze and his new Cleveland Seaport Foundation will meet early in June to formulate plans to promote this city as a seaport and world trade center.

MADRID, May 22 -- The housing shortage is one of Spain's greatest social problems. About half of Spain's 28,000,000 inhabitants lack adequate living quarters, and the situation is becoming steadily worse.

The six-story apartment house on plot 75 by 100 feet at 960 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by Abe Mathews, operator, from the 3229 Broadway Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Curtis Solove, broker. There are thirty-eight apartments in the property, which is assessed at $130,000.
PARIS, May 29 -- At the same moment that the French Government seemed to turn its back on European union, one of its ministers expressed the fear that Britain would turn her back on it.
ST. ANNE'S, England, May 29 (AP) -- The sixtieth British amateur golf championship win start tomorrow with a field of 240 competitors.

Just as though New York City's budgetary problems are not in themselves complex, confusing and irritating enough, they are further bedeviled by misconceptions which are too often stimulated by many persons who should be seeking to shed light rather than smog.

BUENOS AIRES, May 29 (AP) -- Roman Catholic priests here labeled today as "dense anti-Christian propaganda" the Peron Government's dispute with the church. The country's Catholics were urged to "stand together in Christ."

THE city's -- and the nation's -- first Memorial Day was observed eighty-seven years ago today. It grew out of General Order 11 issued May 5, 1868, by Gen. John Alexander Logan, Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, said today he believed the offshore oil bill was passed by Congress and signed by the President "in return for the support which the Texas oil interests gave to General Eisenhower and the Republican party."

Of all our public holidays this, the one we observe today, is perhaps the one most solemn with personal memories. In its simplest traditional form it is observed by a visit to strew flowers on the graves of the war dead. The custom goes back to late Civil War days, and was formalized in 1868.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- Ralph De Palma, who won the 500-mile auto race here in 1915 at an average 89.84 miles per hour, predicted today that the victor in tomorrow's thirty-ninth event would have to do better than 132 m.p.h.
PITTSBURGH, May 29 -- There was no evidence last week of any slowing up in the steel boom. The volume of incoming orders was still above capacity and steelmakers continued to build bigger backlogs.

BONN, Germany, May 29 -- Several hundred thousand German refugees from the eastern provinces held mass meetings throughout West Germany today marking the tenth anniversary of their expulsion from their homes.
NEW DELHI, India, May 29 -- India believes the chances are good that the Chinese Communists will release the imprisoned United States airmen soon as a move toward negotiations with Washington.

Two five-story apartment houses at 1195-97 First Avenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, were sold by Peter Doelger, Inc., to the Cotswold Realty Corporation. The concern assembled a plot at that location for improvement with a fifteen-story apartment house with stores. Julian E. Gordon Co. were the brokers.
KARABUK, Turkey, May 17 -- Turkey is turning an economic monstrosity into the largest and most efficiently integrated steel mill in the Middle East.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 29--Yugoslav and Soviet leaders arrived today at secluded Brioni Island for the most crucial and secret part of their negotiations toward "normalizing" relations.

KANSAS CITY, May 29 (AP) -- -- Larry Doby hit a tremendous home run of about 500 feet today as Cleveland's Herb Score needed help from two relief hurlers in the ninth inning for a 4-2 Indian victory over Kansas City.

A bilingual edition of Baudelaire's "Flowers of Evil" has been scheduled for June 29 publication by New Directions. The volume contains the three versions of Baudelaire's preface never before published in English, as well as four poems that make their first English appearance.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 29 -- The University of Alabama Board of Trustees defended yesterday a veteran psychology professor against charges he had "brainwashed" students in lectures supporting racial integration.
CAIRO, May 29 -- Dr. Raymond F. McLain was installed tonight as the third president of the thirty-five-year-old American University at Cairo.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 29 -- Steps toward an accord were reported today in the dispute between Pakistan and Afghanistan.

THE highest point in the Vosges Mountains in eastern France is only 4,667 feet above sea level, but Pierre Moinot writes about the Vosges in his odd novel, "The Royal Hunt,"* as if they were the Alps. Or, perhaps it would be more accurate to say, he writes about them as if they were the Mountains of the Moon, where at any moment the horns of elfland might echo from the heights.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Trade in lard futures was not of large volume the last week, and price changes were rather narrow from day to day. At times there was a little buying on the strength shown in soybean oil, and late firmness in hog prices also stimulated some buying. For the week the hog market showed a strong tone.
JERUSALEM, May 29 -- Premier U Nu of Burma arrived in Israel tonight for a seven-day visit that is causing great public satisfaction.

PARIS, May 29--The population of France is increasing, but mostly because it is growing older. And the French economy is facing serious strains to make the population wiser and happier at the same time.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 29 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald capitalized on short iron shots in spite of high winds today for a 67 to win his first major golf tournament, the $15,000 Fort Wayne Open, with 269.
While thousands of New Yorkers relaxed in the country and at the shore yesterday, the city was thronged by visitors who also were enjoying the Memorial Day week-end.
LONDON, May 29 -- Prime Minister Eden assured the nation today that the Government would maintain essential public services during the railway strike.

PARIS, May 29 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, the defending champion; Ham Richardson and Herb Flam won today to join two other American players in the quarter-finals of the French international tennis tournament.

Prices of domestic cotton futures held to a narrow range last week. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the trading session on Friday up one point to down fourteen points from the close of the previous week. During the preceding week they had been down one to twenty-five points.
NEW HAVEN, May 29 (AP) -- A Yale physicist charged tonight that the Atomic Energy Commission had given what he called misleading information about the danger from atomic test blasts.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- The San Francisco Young Men's Christian Association has made known preliminary results of a five-year modernization program that it believes may have an impact on youth agencies throughout the country.
PARIS, May 29 -- A controversy is developing in official circles over the financial and budgetary situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- Inclusion of extra players in the motion picture industry's health and welfare plan benefits will be a primary objective of the Screen Extras Guild in forthcoming collective bargaining contract negotiations with the studios. The plan was established in 1952.
The Manhattan police ended last night their twelve - week campaign to clear the streets of so-called "undesirables."
An overflow audience attended a special dinner given last night by the Jewish National Fund of America, the land-development agency of the Zionist movement in Israel.
One hundred and two contract bridge pairs played through the first session of the 1955 Greater New York Mixed Pair championship yesterday afternoon.
Following is a list of eighty-four public, parochial and private schools in the city that will take part in the free polio vaccine inoculations to be given tomorrow:

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 29 -- Amsterdam financial circles welcomed the introduction in New York by the Irving Trust Company of dealings in leading Dutch and British shares. It is believed here this would stimulate trade in those securities in Europe and might be the first step toward their official listing in Wall Street.
LOS ANGELES, May 29 -- Settlement of the $60,000,000 estate of William Randolph Hearst is nearing completion rapidly.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- Stan Musial's three-run homer highlighted a six-run fourth inning today that gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-2 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs. The triumph was the Cards' first under the leadership of Harry Walker, who yesterday succeeded Eddie Stanky as manager.

The Government of Spain is negotiating a $30,000,000 unsecured loan from United States financial interests. Involved in the transaction are the First National City Bank, the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Manufacturers Trust Company and the World Commerce Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The race for the 1956 Democratic Presidential nomination appears to be turning into a dignified stroll to victory for Adlai E. Stevenson.
IN SUBURBAN gardens now the first roses of the season are coming into bloom. Roses and other flowers may be candied to "bloom," too, as decorations for cakes and other desserts.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 29 (Reuters) -- A leader of a Kenya expedition to climb 25,800-foot Mount Himalchuli died as he was being carried down the mountain after an injury, it was reported today.
The dynamic personality of Christ accounts for His perennial appeal, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday in a sermon at Riverside Church.

A new subcommittee on tax policy has been set up by the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report. The committee is headed by Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas. Whether it will come up with the right answers, it has started out, as The Journal of Commerce pointedly observes, by asking the right questions.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Wheat futures showed considerable strength at times last week, but buying enthusiasm was squelched late in the week as a result of the showery conditions that prevailed much of the period.

LONDON, May 29--Dominated last week by confidence in a Conservative victory in the general election, the stock markets here experienced boom-like conditions Friday when election hopes were abundantly fulfilled.

LONDON, May 29 -- Among the treasures of the British Museum, there is one that makes the imagination spin. It is the stained and faded manuscript of "The Booke of Sir Thomas More," three pages of which are probably in Shakespeare's hand.

VIENNA, May 29 -- Rumors that the financial burdens of the Austrian state treaty will require revaluation of the Austrian schilling and result in increased taxes were denied today by Chancellor Julius Raab in a radio speech to his people.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 29 -- The South Vietnamese Government still hopes the foreign ministers of the United States, France and Britain will meet here soon for a conference on Vietnamese affairs.

One muggy, overcast afternoon in 1926 the members of Choate's baseball team were unhappy. Rain in the morning had caused their game with Loomis to be cancelled. Most of the players strolled across the campus to watch the track meet with Taft.

A sudden storm that broke the moorings of a Hudson River excursion boat last evening galvanized 2,000 persons on the pier into a near panic. Strenuous efforts of half a dozen policemen averted a stampede. One patrolman was injured in the excitement.

WARSAW, May 16 -- It takes only five and a half hours to fly from Moscow to Warsaw, but there is a world between.

HONG KONG, May 29 -- The arrangements worked out by the Red Cross organizations call for semi - monthly shipments of food parcels to imprisoned Americans. Nelson Riley, American Red Cross information officer for the Far East, told the correspondents here today the agreed delivery dates were the fiftheenth and thirtieth of every month.

There was simply no stopping the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. At least, nothing the Giants were able to achieve sufficed to stay the progress of the Brooks as Walter Alston's National League pace-setters made off with the series finale, 8 to 5.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, May 30 -- V. K. Krishna Menon announced today that the Chinese Communists within a few hours will release four United States airmen as a move toward relaxation of tension in the Far East.
Three new films, including an import from the U.S.S.R., are booked in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
NEW DELHI, India, May 29 -- The Indian Government has decided to establish a Ministry of Iron and Steel.
Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, said yesterday that a United States Public Health Service inspector would be stationed in the plant of each manufacturer of Salk polio vaccine.

The increasing concern of educators over the problems of "mass production" in American education is reflected by John W. Gardner, president of the Carnegie Corporation, in his current annual report. It is the same problem referred to by President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University when he referred in a recent speech to "the rising tide of college students which seems about to engulf us."
PARIS, May 29 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, criticized today the home rule agreement for Tunisia.
HIROSHIMA, May 28 -- Scientists studying the effects of the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August, 1945, have reached the problem of why people grow old and die.
MADRID, May 29 -- According to a bill published today, all high Spanish public servants, including ministers and ambassadors, will be allowed to hold only one job.

The representatives of fifteen Latin-American coffee-producing countries and the Belgian Congo approved yesterday the creation of an International Coffee Bureau. The action followed a special two-day meeting here of coffee producers.
Twelve boys from Newark who took a junket to Coney Island yesterday for the amusement park rides got one they were not looking for -- a ride in patrol cars to a Brooklyn police station.
TELEVISION, which has covered just about everything else under the sun, finally got around yesterday afternoon to doing a program on the impact of TV. It was a little late with the story.

PITTSBURGH, May 29 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies notched their seventh straight victory today by downing the Pittsburgh Pirates 5 -- 2. However, the Phils were trailing, 8 -- 3, in the second game which was called in the last half of the seventh because of Pennsylvania's Sunday curfew law.
A dispute that may come to legal blows has broken out between Herman Shumlin and Margo Jones. They are the producers of Broadway's "Inherit the Wind," the hit courtroom drama starring Paul Muni.

In its very nature Memorial Day must be a day of mourning. It has grown out of the earlier "Decoration Day," whose central symbol was the graves of our war dead. Its aspect has broadened with the years but that integral part cannot be changed. We mourn our dead.
BALTIMORE, May 29 -- In the reporting of how the Yankees blanked the Baltimore Orioles today, 1 -- 0, at least half a dozen angles merited attention.

BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- Jackie Jensen blasted his ninth and tenth home runs and Ted Williams crashed a triple and a double today to pace the Boston Red Sox to a 12-to-7 victory over the Washington Senators.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 29 -- Brazilian complaints about World Bank delay in granting development loans here are multiplying.
An indoor and outdoor recreational center restricted to older persons will be developed in Central Park. It is being made possible by a $250,000 grant of the Florina Lasker Foundation.
ZURICH, Switzerland, May 27 -- Swiss banks have made a gentlemen's agreement to put part of their liquid assets in blocked accounts.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., !VayI 29--The governors of the Tuxedo Club have selected Mrs. William E. 1osle as chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball, to be held Oct. 22 in the Tuxedo Club.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that an examination of the facts behind the rise of stock prices "reveals the development of an unhealthy lack of balance within the economy."

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The proposed Federal Hell's Canyon dam was assailed today by a Chamber of Commerce group as being socialistic. A Representative termed it inferior as a power producer to other projects proposed in Columbia River tributaries.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senate Democrats planned today a fight to give the Administration standby controls over the distribution of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.

CHICAGO, May 29 (UP) -- Ernie Banks smashed his second grand-slam homer of the season and Ransom Jackson hit one with two on to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 9 -- 6 victory over the Milwaukee Braves before 22,796 fans today.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, May 29 -- The Amsterdam diamond workers' strike enters its twelfth week tomorrow, with no end in sight.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A permanent annual market for 100,000,000 pounds of butter processed into ghee has been found in the Orient by agricultural representatives of dairy countries, it was learned from authoritative sources here today.
J. Lauritzen Lines of Copenhagen has ordered a cargo ship that will be one of the world's most powerful icebreakers.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The whole inventory of war reserve equipment now in United States Army warehouses amounts to about $20,000,000,000. More than $16,000,000,000 is stored in the United States. In addition $5,000,000,000 of equipment is in the hands of United States troops here and overseas.
Optimism is the most serious casualty of the twentieth century, Columbia University seniors were told yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, May 29 -- Citizens of Los Angeles will vote Tuesday on a proposition aimed at turning their metropolis literally into a big league city.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The tide in the flood of letters to the Federal Communications Commission on pay-to-see television seems to have turned.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 29 -- The Philbrick Starch Company of Van Buren, Me., has promised to establish a $150,000 starch factory here provided growers sign five-year contract to deliver annually 700,000 bushels of culls and other low-grade potatoes.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., May 29--The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia and the New York Athletic Club shared honors today in the fifty-fourth annual regatta of the New York Rowing Association. The seventeen-event program was conducted on the Passaic River.

Y., from the Reliant Construction Company. The Thomas B. Sutton Corporation negotiated the sale in cooperation with Raymond D. Porter.

Two teen-age gangs forming for a battle in the Bronx were broken up by the police last night. Nine members of one gang called "the Devils" and a girl sympathizer with a rival group were rounded up in St. Mary's Park, 149th Street and St. Ann's Avenue.

The Feast of Pentecost, commemorating the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles fifty days after the Resurrection, was celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 29 -- June is the month for strawberry shortcakes -- and on eastern Long Island, which has more than 500 acres of strawberries -- the daily berry auctions are scheduled to start Wednesday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 (AP) -- Thomas F. Stallman, 22-year-old midshipman, lieutenant from Rochester, N. Y., will be at the head of the Naval Academy's 740-man graduating class next Friday.
DETROIT, May 29 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., modified its guaranteed annual wage demand for the first time today.

BUY the best furniture you can afford, then save money by doing a certain number of simple things yourself. This is the decorating formula applied by the young couple who furnished the apartment pictured here.
NEWARK, May 29 -- A new "war between the states" appeared to be in the making for a time today. It was over highway tolls and speeding fines.
DARIEN, Conn., May 29 -- A young Indian botanist and his family will arrive tomorrow afternoon to begin a week observing civic, social and government groups in action here.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29--Scott McLeod, State Department Security Administrator, has canceled an engagement to address the National Conference of Social Work here.

American shipyards have felt more acutely than shipbuilders elsewhere the sharp decline in orders for the construction of ocean - going merchant vessels during the last two and a half years, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

ST. ANNE, England, May 30 (AP) -- Three members of the triumphant American Walker Cup team and two former Walker Cup players paraded into the second round of the British amateur golf championship on the tight, tricky Royal Lytham and St. Annes course today.

BOSTON, May 30 (UP) -- Gene Stephens and Jackie Jensen provided the batting punch behind Ivan Delock's four-hit pitching as the Red Sox beat the Orioles in the second game, 8 -- 1, for an even break today. Baltimore downed Boston, 8 -- 6, by scoring two ninth-inning runs in the rain-spattered opener.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Statements that juvenile delinquency "spreads like measles," that "it can strike any child," that more and more youngsters from "good middle-class homes" are becoming law-breakers are causing undue concern among many parents, according to Dr. Dietrich C. Reitzes. Dr. Reitzes, sociologist at the University of Indiana, discussed middle-class juvenile delinquency at a recent meeting of the Association for Family Living.
Vaccinations against poliomyelitis will resume this morning in the schools after the threeday Memorial Day week-end.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, one of the screen's most durable comedy teams, have parted company with Universal-International. Their fifteen-year association with the studio ended with the production of "Abbott and Costello Meet the Mummy," not yet in release.
MOST anglers on both fresh and salt water had reason to be satisfied with the fishing over the week-end. The weather was right and the fish were cooperative.
DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production this week will show a sharp drop, reflecting the Memorial Day holiday, although some factories are scheduling overtime work next Saturday.

The appointment of Hugh Bullock as president of the Pilgrims of the United States has been announced by the society's executive committee. Mr. Bullock is an investment banker and the president of several corporations.

After several preliminary suggestions by India's Krishna Menon, the Peiping radio announced that four imprisoned American airmen were "sentenced to deportation" last Tuesday. This "punishment" has been meted out after a delay of only a week -- and several years' imprisonment -- and four men have come back into the free world.

The detailed endorsement of Deputy Mayor Epstein's report on juvenile delinquency in the editorial columns of The New York Times has undoubtedly helped to fix his major recommendations in the public mind.

A bunch of fire-worshiping young imps was changed into a crew of ardent firefighters the other day. The trick was turned by a quick-thinking Parks Department official. It was a muchneeded victory in the department's constant fight against damage to the city's parks.

PARIS, May 30 (AP) -- Italian and Swedish players jolted United States tennis prestige today when they sent Vic Seixas and Budge Patty to the sidelines in the quarter-finals of the French international tournament.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 (AP) -- Chile, Peru and Ecuador reaffirmed their claim to sovereignty over 200 miles of Pacific waters from their coastlines, the Foreign Ministry said today.
United States overseas information programs have won the praise of this country's Ambassadors to Britain, West Germany and Spain.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 30 -Private United States relief agencies are spending about $5,000,000 to assist refugees who have flooded into South Vietnam from the Communist North.
Generally gratifying business was enjoyed in the first-run movie houses over the Memorial Day week-end, with "excellent" attendance reported in some of the more likely havens for visitors.

The blessed turn of events that has permitted closing of two elderly tuberculosis hospitals, Neponsit Beach in Queens and Seton in the Bronx, offers New York City a rare and wonderful opportunity for taking a double dividend by adding to its park and beach assets.
Having displaced the horse, the automobile is now inexorably replacing the mass transit facility.

WASHINGTON, May 30--The Supreme Court will meet at noon tomorrow for what normally should be its last session of the term. The meeting will be watched for opinions in several important cases, including five on school segregation.

William G. Hellis Jr.'s Helioscope and High Gun of the King Ranch made a two-horse race of the $88,250 Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, with Helioscope winning by a head. There were nine competitors in the fixture of a mile and a quarter, but seven of them were forgotten during the tingling stretch encounter.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -Bill Vukovich, America's foremost auto-racing driver, was killed today while leading the field in the thirty-ninth 500mile classic at the Indianapolis Speedway. Vukovich plowed in to a four-car tangle of wreckage on the backstretch after having traveled 140 miles over the two-and-a-half-mile oval. 500 miles without relief. Tony Bettenhausen, spelled by Paul Russo at the wheel, finished second in a Chapman Special. He was more than a lap behind Sweikert.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -A reduction in Panama Canal toll rates was declared warranted today by the Pacific Coast Panama Canal Committee. It asserted that the rates would be reduced to about 63 cents a ton "if a tolls hearing were held today under present requirements of the Canal Zone code." The present rate is 90 cents a ton.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele told world health officials today that this country's poliomyelitis vaccination program was "back on the track."

Evidently it has not been easy to find the right men for the newly reconstructed Transit Authority, or if found to get them to serve. Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner have been conferring on the problem, and William R. Peer, the Mayor's executive secretary, says the appointments will be made this week.
PARIS, May 30 -- Controlled tests of a poliomyelitis vaccine developed by the Pasteur Institute in Paris have begun here. They will continue in other parts of France this summer.

RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- Corny Shields made it three straight today when he brought Aileen home first in the International Class race as the American Yacht Club concluded its annual Memorial Day week-end regatta off Milton Point.
The Bronx turned out an estimated total of 15,000 marchers and 120,000 spectators for its Memorial Day parade yesterday morning along the Grand Concourse.

Davy Crockett's popularity, merchandise-wise, is growing at such a pace that he soon will make "Hopalong Cassidy look like he was riding a lame horse and Space Cadet appear to need a new rocket ship."
The Memorial Day week-end came to an end this morning with the unenviable distinction of probably having set a new record in highway deaths.

Two hundred policemen were called out in the Bronx yesterday afternoon to prevent a clash of youths in Pelham Bay Park. Mounted patrolmen broke up a solid phalanx of 250 boys marching toward another group of 250 waiting under some trees.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -Automation is increasing man's insecurities along with his economic productivity, a nationwide meeting of social welfare leader was told today.

The contract bridge team headed by Dr. Kalman Apfel of New York came from behind last night to outpoint a thirtythree-team field and capture the Open Team of Four championship. This was the final event in the annual Greater New York Championship play.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., May 30 -- A 22-year-old college senior, finishing up his R. O. T. C. training and soon to get into Army uniform, won the Ocean City Memorial Day motor boat marathon today. The victor was William Ritner Jr. of Merion, Pa., and he used the same 225-cubic-inch class craft, Wa Wa Too, with its converted Mercury auto motor in which he had won last May.
OCEAN CITY, N. J., May 30 -- Word of the impending release of Lieut. Col. Edwin L. Heller of Wynnewood, Pa., was received joyously by his wife and two children here this morning.

Archbishop Stepinac's track and field team won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The White Plains school tallied 41 1/2 points, nine more than St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn, the runner-up.

A two-story factory building at 2926 White Plains Road in the Bronx has been leased for eleven years by the Century Products Corporation from the Almax Realty Corporation. At the expiration of the lease the tenant will become the owner of the property without further consideration, according to Morice Haymes Co., broker in the transaction.
CHICAGO, May 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson would accept the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- Sea O Erin won the Citation Handicap today for the Hasty House Farms' second stakes victory of Balmoral's meeting at Washington Park. A crowd of 35,716 wagered a record $2,181,820.

In your issue of May 18 Herman Stichman, trustee of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, wrote at length on that company's declining patronage and revenue. He attributed the financial plight of the H. M. to the use of the automobile for New Jersey-New York travel, encouraged by the vehicular facilities built during the past thirty years by the New York-New Jersey Bridge and Tunnel Commission and by The Port of New York Authority.
LONDON, May 30 -- The Archbishop of York declares there is more "hatred and bitterness" between Israelis and Arabs than there is to be found anywhere else in the world "in such a confined space."
DETROIT, May 30 -- The Auto Workers Union, in a bold bargaining maneuver today, proposed a secret ballot among Ford workers to settle its dispute with the company.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Republican leader in the Senate, is carrying his own campaign for the Presidency to the country.

If the Giants did nothing else at the Polo Grounds yesterday they at least proved to themselves that they can beat the Phillies once in a while. They toppled Mayo Smith's seventhplace team, 6 to 5, in the opener of the double-header.
CHICAGO, May 30 -- The first vessel to be used exclusively for the refueling of Great Lakes ore boats and other large vessels in the Chicago area will be placed in service this week.
TORONTO, May 30 -- Quick sales were the order of the day as the eighth Canadian International Trade Fair opened this morning to display the colorful wares of thirty-one nations.

Mothers who continually caution their sports-minded offspring to be careful are likely to hear themselves labeled "anxious neurotics" by these modernminded young. When sports heroes give the same advice, however, youngsters are inclined to listen and even to act upon it.
Gene Poirer, 146 1/2, Niagara Falls, triumphed over Miguel Diaz, 146 1/2, San Cristobal, Cuba, at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The International Labor Organization, a specialized agency of the United Nations embracing seventy countries on both sides of the Iron Curtain, meets in Geneva tomorrow for its thirty-eighth general conference to continue work dedicated to peace, prosperity and social justice.
SEVENTEEN months as New York's first hostess have done little to shake Mrs. Robert F. Wagner's apparent conviction that food for family and friends should be savory but very simple.

RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- Philadelphia players were named to seven of the twelve places on the 1955 United States team as the twenty-third annual tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association ended at Rye High School today.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter that Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O. United Auto Workers, sent to Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, today suggesting a nation-wide vote among Ford workers on a guaranteed annual wage:

Mayor Wagner, as official reviewing officer, led 100,000 residents and guests of Brooklyn yesterday in a Memorial Day tribute to the nation's war heroes. The ceremonies included a parade of 15,000 persons, for two miles along Eastern Parkway.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- Communist China's decision to release four United States jet pilots was welcomed today by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

The six-story apartment house for forty-one families at 244 East 117th Street has been sold by the Ed R. Wolfe Syndicate, real estate operators, to H. Cohen. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Government granted speedy tax amortization certificates covering $49,249,909 worth of new or expanded defense facilities in the two-week period of May 5-18.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Government officials said here today there would be no Federal aspect to the proposed vote by Ford Motor Company's employes on whether they preferred a guaranteed annual wage or the company's stock-surplus plan.
HIROSHIMA, May 29 -- Whoever survives the first direct heat, blast and radiation effects of an atomic bomb has a good chance of living a normal life thereafter, scientists here believe.
FAZANA, Yugoslavia, May 30 (AP) -- A joint communique issued late today from Brioni said:

Muffled drums beat a requiem for the nation's war dead here and throughout the world yesterday. There were many prayers for peace, in keeping with President Eisenhower's proclamation of Memorial Day as a national day of prayer for permanent peace.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, May 31 -- Nationalist China rejected today Peiping's reported offer of direct negotiations for a settlement of Far Eastern tensions.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 31 (Reuters) -- British mountaineers and geographers announced today they had set up a special foundation to promote exploration of mountain areas all over the world.
BUENOS AIRES, May 30 -The Ministry of Public Health and Social Welfare has ordered 113 Roman Catholic nuns to leave their posts in orphanages and homes for the aged, church sources reported today.

NEW DELHI, India, May 30 -- V. K. Krishna Menon will go to Washington with some suggestions for "lowering tensions" that India believes would lead to the freeing of eleven United States airmen still imprisoned by the Chinese Communists.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (UP) -- Bob Speake hit an eleventh-inning home run to give the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory and a clean sweep of a double-header today before 28,258 fans at Busch Stadium. Speake twice sparked rallies that toppled the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-5 loss in a teninning opener.
LAST night's revival of "The Petrified Forest," with a cast headed by Henry Fonda, Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart, was another hit for the "Producer's Showcase" on Channel 4.

DALLAS, Tex., May 30--The Scopes trial, re-enacted scores of times this year on Dallas and New York stages, will return to a genuine courtroom here at 9 A. M. tomorrow. And, depending upon the outcome of the real-life courtroom drama, it may come to life again on a stage courtroom in Dallas Tuesday night as well as in New York.

PANAMA, May 30 -- An official of Panama's Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare confirmed today that the Congress of Industrial Organizations would undertake to organize the Republic's labor on a nationwide scale.
SEOUL, Korea, May 30 -- Korean resentment against Japanese trade and diplomatic overtures toward Communist nations was organized today in a Memorial Day rally.

The beach season is back again, for swimming, for lying upon and for combing. The first two of these have many friends, but also have a certain number of enemies. Members of a few otherwise excellent professions -- sailors and fishermen, to name a couple -- can take swimming or can let it alone, and much prefer the latter.
Alex Segal, director of the "United States Steel Hour," will resign from the American Broadcasting Company because of a contract disagreement.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (UP) -- Swaps, the Kentucky Derby winner, toyed with a small field of 3-year-olds as he captured the $27,150 Will Rogers Stakes today at Hollywood Park. He scored by twelve lengths, finishing in a gallop.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 30 -Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart held its 114th commencement today before an audience of 1,000. Seventy Bachelor of Arts, two Bachelor of Fine Arts and ten Bachelor of Music degrees were awarded to young women.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Pinch hits decided both games as the Yankees and the Senators split their double-header before 24,080 fans at Griffith Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -With solemn promises to find the way to a permanent world peace, the nation's capital today honored America's war dead.
MOSCOW, May 30 -- Soviet newspaper readers were given to understand today that the first stage of the Soviet's Yugoslav negotiations had been "successfully concluded."

The front-running Dodgers swept a double-header from the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday, 8 -- 4 and 8 -- 3. Russ Meyer gained his third triumph in the opener and the unbeaten Don Newcombe his eighth victory in the nightcap.

VANCOUVER, B. C., May 30 -- The seventy airlines that are members of the International Air Transport Association are carrying passenger traffic thirtysix times greater and cargo traffic seventy times greater than just before World War II.

"We Poles are proud of our history," a Polish citizen recently told this newspaper's correspondent Clifton Daniel, who has just visited Warsaw. That sentence supplies the key both to the impressions Mr. Daniel secured in that city and to the problems facing the Soviet rulers of an oppressed nation.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP) -- The unofficial final standings of today's 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, showing speed averages or miles traveled and reasons for dropping out:
DETROIT, May 30 -- Following are the details of the United Auto Workers' and the Ford Motor Company's plans for a guaranteed annual wage:
CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stables' Gandharva romped to a two and one-half-length victory in the $31,850 Betsy Ross Stakes at Garden State Park today.
LONDON, May 30 -- Thousands of British holidaymakers were stranded at coastal resorts and in the country today by the rail strike.
DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, broke par for the fourth straight round today to capture the Wolverine women's open golf tournament.
MIAMI, Fla., May 30 (AP) -Louis (Little New York) Campagna, Capone gang member in the Nineteen Thirties, died today after a heart attack aboard a pleasure cruiser at sea.

CHICAGO, May 30 (UP) -- Billy Pierce shut out the Cleveland Indians on seven hits, 5 -- 0, as the Chicago White Sox gained a split in a double-header today. The Indians won the opener, 9 -- 1, behind Bob Lemon.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, May 31 -- The Hong Kong police announced today that four American fliers released by Communist China crossed the border from China at 2:33 P. M. [1:33 A. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time].

A bright future for those in the purchasing field was predicted yesterday by Hobart C. Ramsey, chairman of the Worthington Corporation. He spoke at the opening of the fortieth annual convention of National Association of Purchasing Agents in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MIAMI, May 30 (UP) -- A New York banker said today that banking could not continue to exist if banks accepted only "triple-A" risks. He urged fellow banking executives to grant "borderline" loans, too.
TRIESTE, May 30 -- The Communist party of the Free Territory of Trieste raised the flag of revolt today against the proTito policies of Nikita S. Khrushchev, secretary of the Soviet Communist party.

IN the spring of 1940, when the German Wehrmacht rolled over Holland, Belgium and France, Victor Velten found the spectacle surprisingly exhilarating. A successful Berlin lawyer attached to the army as a special officer and interpreter, Velten was a brilliant linguist, a cultivated intellectual and a highly intelligent man. In theory he did not approve of the Nazis nnd deplored war.

George Ball of New York and Irving Suntag of Brooklyn, reached the fourth round of the fourteenth annual Inter-American invitation tennis tournament at the Hispano Tennis Club, Whitestone, Queens, yesterday.
LONDON, May 30 -- Britain supplied about 70 per cent of all munitions used in World War II by the Commonwealth forces, it was disclosed here today. These forces totaled 8,750,000 men.

MAYO SMITH has passed safely through the decompression chamber and no longer is in danger of getting the bends. The manager of the Phils is now breathing pure, clean air after a terrifying plunge into the depths. He'd even thought for many despairing moments that he was sinking into a bottomless pit.

Stadium Concerts, Inc., which has been making piecemeal announcements through the last two months of artists who will appear this summer at City College's Lewisohn Stadium, yesterday announced the complete roster of conductors and forty-eight soloists who will participate.

Kuhn, Loeb Co., eightyeight-year-old investment banking concern, moved over the week-end into the new Seamen's Bank for Savings Building at 30 Wall Street, after a stay of fifty-two years at 52 William Street.

CHICAGO, May 30 (UP) -- The American Medical Association said tonight that it had been assured that problems of the "safe" manufacture of the Salk vaccine had been solved and the vaccination program would move ahead.

Norway had had a foreign service of its own for less than five years when Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne accepted his first diplomatic assignment as attache to the Norwegian Legation in Washington. That was in 1910, and Mr. Morgenstierne has been ably representing his country, off and on, in the United States ever since.

LONDON, May 30 -- The British Government, strongly reinforced for dealings over Germany by the general election, is hopeful but wary about the coming conferences of heads of government with the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, May 30 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals has retained the time-honored custom that permits "reading" in a law office to provide qualification for the bar.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower took a front-row seat but a bystander's role today in the eightyeighth observance of Memorial Day at Gettysburg National Cemetery.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30 -- An informed source said today that Yugoslavia had made up her mind, in advance of the current conference with Soviet leaders, not to accept military or economic aid from Moscow.

Prepayment should meet the entire hospital bill for all hospitalizationplan subscribers except those with unusually long illnesses, it has been suggested in a pamphlet published by the Public Affairs Committee.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -Bill Vukovich was killed today attempting to accomplish what no others had been able to do -win the 500-mile auto race here three times in a row. Only two others, Mauri Rose and Wilbur Shaw, had taken two successive 500's.

LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of the verdict of "the Military Tribunal of the Supreme People's Court of the People's Republic of China" ordering the deportation of four imprisoned United States airmen, as broadcast by the Peiping radio and recorded here:
LONDON, May 31 -- A gorgeous Whitmonday brought Britons out in a surge today to improvise ways of enjoying a holiday without trains. Railroad workers are on strike.

TOKYO, May 30 -- Pascual Perez of Argentina retained his world flyweight title tonight with a fifth-round knockout of Yoshio Shirai, the former champion. The 31-year-old Japanese fighter was floored four times before the Argentine's hand was raised after a disputed count.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- Sandor Iharos, a slim Hungarian Army lieutenant, today slashed seven seconds off the world two-mile track record.
A World War II memorial that was described as a "permanent testimony to the valor and humanity of the service" was dedicated by the Coast Guard at Battery Park yesterday.

PARIS, May 30 -- Even a short war, if it entailed the explosion of a few dozen hydrogen bombs, probably would throw man back to a prehistoric state, according to Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer. The United States physicist was quoted in an interview published today by the newspaper Le Figaro.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Agents of the Office of Defense Mobilization are still scouting the countryside to find a suitable place for Congress to meet in the event of threatened or actuel bomb attack on Washington.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 -President Carlos Ibanez del Campo announced the formation of a new Cabinet tonight.

The work of America's underseas demolition teams (also known as frogmen) will be the subject of a second book. Last week, Exposition Press published "Webfooted Warriors," by Edward T. Higgins in collaboration with Dean Phillips. It was an account of Mr. Higgins' experi-[ l ences as a member of Underwater Demolition Team 11, which saw service on the beaches of Okinawa, Borneo and Japan.
SALESGIRLS at Milgrim's are getting blase about shoppers who pick out a handbag, then ask a friend: "Do you think the gun will fit in here, or will it bulge?"
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 (AP) -- Following is the new Chilean Cabinet sworn in tonight:
The nation's biggest errand boy, the Railway Express Agency, will deliver some packages six times faster starting this week.

Walter W. and George W. Naumburg unveiled a plaque to their father, Elkan Naumburg, last night at the bandstand in Central Park. The occasion marked the first Naumburg concert of the season and teh fiftieth anniversary of the first Naumburg concert in Central Park.
WARSAW, May 17 -- It is an old story, but a continuing and fascinating one -- the rebuilding of Warsaw.

MONTREAL, May 30 -- Eleven Protestant churches -- ten of them in suburban Westmount -will show the film "Martin Luther" at a series of private performances beginning tonight. The film was banned by the Quebec Board of Cinema Censors seventeen months ago, but the ban applies only to public performances.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Korean war G. I.'s are not "milking" the unemployment benefits set up to help them shift to civilian life, a Labor Department official indicated today.

In The Times of May 20 The United Press article reporting the discovery of skeletons found in a cave at Wadi Habra near the Red Sea states that the Old Testament Book of Lamentations describes the sufferings of Jewish refugees "hiding in caves besieged by the Romans during the Bar Kokhba revolt."

A tract of about five acres on Highwood Avenue, in the East Hill section of Tenafly, N. J., has been sold by Benjamin Nitti to David Baratt. The new owner plans to construct three dwellings in the $40,000 price class. The sale was negotiated by the C. B. Snyder Organizations as brokers.

Three four-story store and apartment buildings at 608, 610 and 612 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn have been sold by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to A. Szauber. The property contains three stores and twenty-one four-room apartments.

A special sale will open tomorrow at the Opportunity Shop of the Community Service Society at 46 West Forty-seventh Street. It will continue there throughout the city's summer festival, which will end Aug. 31. During the sale, which will mark the thirtieth year of the organization, all merchandise will be sold at a discount of 25 per cent.

Production of men's clothing for spring, 1955, was back to "normal," well above last year's slow season, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.
Two leading American producers are competing for the privilege of introducing Joyce Grenfell, the spindly British comedienne, to Broadway audiences this fall.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The State Department "welcomed" today Communist China's decision to release four imprisoned Americans. It urged Peiping to free fifty-two others still held in China.

As summer nears, the Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund turns again to the public for assistance in providing two-week vacations for children who otherwise would not be able to leave the grime of the city and the monotony of sidewalk playgrounds.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30 -- Prof. John B. Carroll, Harvard University psychologist, will head a two-year study of the relations between language structure and thought pattern among the Indians of the southwestern United States.

The first training class for shop stewards initiated by Local 856, International Longshoremen's Association, independent, will be graduated tomorrow at the Standard Fruit and Steamship Company, Pier 13, East River.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -Senator Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, said today a Chamber of Commerce group's study report criticizing the proposed Hell's Canyon Dam was "riddled with deliberate distortions."
The network of voluntary agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund includes a vigorous program for helping senior citizens preserve mental and physical health. It helps the age of all boroughs.
The Ford Foundation made grants totaling $49,438,558 in the first nine months of last year, two-thirds of it for aid to education in the United States.
SWEA CITY, Iowa, May 30 -- The parents of Capt. Harold E. Fischer Jr. said the news was "like a prayer that's been answered."

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., May 30 -- The Women's Division of the Rockland County Democratic Committee attracted 5,000 bidders, including many Republicans, to its annual auction today. The event was held at Mrs. Dora V. Kellogg's training horse track.
MONTREAL, May 30 (Canadian Press) -- Prices were generally mixed in moderately active trading on the stock market here today.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 30 -- Nassau County residents honored their war dead today with parades and services in thirty communities.
LONDON, May 30 -- Queen Elizabeth II honored the First Battalion, the Queen's own Cameron Highlanders, in a colorful ceremony at Balmoral Castle in Scotland today.

Forty-four local housing authorities having subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration announced yesterday plans to borrow $94,137,000 on June 15 for the temporary financing of low-rent public housing projects.

A crowd of 300 persons looked on yesterday as Mayor Wagner swore in John M. Murtagh as a magistrate for a full ten-year term and redesignated him as Chief City Magistrate. The ceremony took place at City Hall.

LET'S first study the facts to see how impossible it all had to be. The primary fact, of course, is that Laszlo Tabori of Hungary ran a mile in 3:59 at White City Stadium in London last Saturday, with two Britons, Chris Chataway and Brian Hewson, doing 3:59.8 behind him. That adds up to a break-through of the four-minute mile barrier in triplicate.
PIERMONT, N. Y., May 31-- Dr. Price Adams Kirkpatrick, a New York City court psychiatrist, was arrested here today as a burglar.
HONG KONG, May 31-- Four happy and perky United States fliers headed home with great big smiles today, less than three hours after their "deportation" from Red China.
WASHINGTON, May 31--Depicting Christopher Columbus as a highly overrated discoverer, Senator Warren G. Magnuson appealed to Congress today to give Leif Ericson his due.

WASHINGTON, May 31--President Eisenhower announced today he would welcome United Nations delegates to their tenth anniversary session, opening in San Francisco June 20. Earlier the White House had turned down an invitation for the President to speak at the closing session June 25, the actual tenth anniversary of the signing of the charter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The suggestion of my countryman Ivo Duchacek that the Soviet proposals concerning free elections in Germany might be countered by an American proposal "to do exactly the same thing with respect to Central Europe" certainly deserves full sympathy.

STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP)-- Huahine, sporting the light blue and brown silks of C. V. Whitney, drove to a surprise half-length triumph today in Delaware Park's feature, the Junior Chamber of Commerce Purse, a mile and a furlong test for 3year-olds.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Unfinished business prevented the Supreme Court from adjourning today for the summer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31--European crude steel production reached new record levels during the first months of 1955, the Economic Commission for Europe disclosed today. The Commission's quarterly bulletin of steel statistics reported that even the record marks attained in 1954 were surpassed.

Bill Sanford of Hofstra College yesterday was voted the outstanding pitcher in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference. He thus heads a list of three hurlers on the league's 1955 All-Star squad. Sanford, a right-hander, won six games and lost two this year.

Fred Haney ought to be a firm believer in the old maxim "A friend in need is a friend indeed." Last night his righthanded relief star, Bob Friend, turned in the second victory the Pirates have achieved in their last nineteen games.
PLANS have been completed for the twelfth annual United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament, which will be held Aug. 9-11, with headquarters at Narragansett, R. I.

PARIS, May 31 (AP)--The defending champion, Tony Trabert, and his United States Davis Cup team-mate, Hamilton Richardson, finished powerfully today to gain the singles semi-final round of the French international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 31--The Attorney General moved today to dismiss the Government's case against the Joint AntiFascist Refugee Committee as a Communist front.

WHEN the annual "Know Your City" show opens on the Municipal Building's twenty -first floor this morning, only a handful of the thousands who will see it will have heard the name Emily Eaton Hepburn, yet it is more or less her show.
Continuing delays in clearing vaccine led yesterday to the removal of nearly 20,000 New Jersey children from the polio vaccination program until the fall.

Andre Siegfried's reassessment of the American, scene twenty-eight years after the publication of his study, "America Comes of Age," will be published June 9 by Harcourt, Brace. In "America at Mid-Century," M. Siegfried describes the United States in terms of its geographical aspects and the formation and psychology of its people, dealing with the economy, social background and formation of public opinion, the political structure and external relations.
ATLANTA, May 31--Georgia Government and education officials made it clear today that the state would continue efforts to maintain segregation in the schools.
ROME, May 31--More austerity, to reduce imports and so right the Italian trade balance, was demanded today by Donato Menichella, governor of the Bank of Italy.
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, warned yesterday that the morale of the city's teachers and school supervisors was "alarmingly low."
CAIRO, May 26--The site of the 5,000-year-old solar ship of the Pharaoh Cheops has been allowed to fall into neglect.

Stalling at Bedtime? It was high time for 9-year-olds to go to bed, and the family's fourth-grader was already appropriately garbed, but there was one more matter on his mind: "Pop, I've got to make a scrapbook on Russia for school.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Eisenhower spoke about the office of the Presidency today in more laudatory terms than at any time since he entered the White House.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 31 --John Davis Lodge, United States Ambassador, said today that more than 500,000,000 in military and economic aid had been allotted to Spain since the signing of the United StatesSpanish agreement in September, 1953.

THE controversy over the possibility of some connection between cigarette smoking and lung cancer was reported last night by "See It Now" on Channel 2. The program was the first of two installments and the evening's only undisputed fact was that Edward R. Murrow, television's most inveterate smoker, did not light one up.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 31--The South responded with mixed feelings today to the Supreme Court order giving local communities the responsibility for shaping public school desegregation programs.

DETROIT, May 31--Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., worked tonight to reach an agreement that would prevent a threatened strike by 140,000 of the company's workers.
Davey Williams, benched earlier in the evening by Leo Durocher because of light hitting, came through with the big blow at the Polo Grounds last night.

BALTIMORE, May 31--Dr. Thomas G. Pullen Jr., superintendent, said today the State Department of Education "will do its best to implement the latest decision of the Supreme Court on school desegregation in accordance with the provisions of the ruling."
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Congress responded on the whole with reserved satisfaction today to the Supreme Court's order for gradualism in ending racial segregation in the public schools.

DEVON, Pa., May 31--Two blue ribbon victories by Jazz Session, a 5-year-old bay gelding owned by Mrs. Morton W. Smith of Middleburg, Va., highlighted today's program at the fifty-ninth annual Devon Horse Show.
The American Federation of Labor longshoremen's union is planning another battle for control of this port's dockworkers and is now, through its Waterfront News, polling the men who work the piers.
AN apartment-dwelling child can grow plants just as green, almost as tall and usually as satisfying on a sunny window ledge as the suburban youth can grow in a backyard garden plot.

The news that the Latin-American coffee producers have agreed to form an "International Coffee Bureau," which some African producers will join, will be received in the United States with interest, sympathy and some slight misgivings.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP)-- Bob Sweikert received $76,138,63 tonight from a record prize fund of $270,050 for his yictory in yesterday's 500-mile auto race.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- President Eisenhower declined today to enter the guaranteed annual wage argument.
Cotton futures declined 10 to 20 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Volume was moderate.

A proposal for the establishment of an advertising campaign fund to promote the candy industry will be made next week at the annual convention of the National Confectioners' Association in Chicago. It is expected to be well received since studies show that per capita consumption of candy last year was three pounds less than in 1941, signifying that the industry is not getting its share of the consumer's dollar.

An undisclosed number of traders on the New York Mercantile Exchange defaulted yesterday on more than 27,000,000 pounds of potatoes they had contracted to deliver. The volume of defaults was by far the greatest in the more than fourteen years the exchange has functioned.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- West Germany's Ambassador to the United States said today his Government could not possibly agree to neutralization as the price of unifying the German people.

Forty-two young painters received awards from the Police Athletic League yesterday afternoon for their work, which is on exhibition at the Washington Square outdoor art show. The forty-five paintings on display were selected from several hundred entered by PAL members.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial demonstrating that young people of our city constitute a large percentage of those arrested for robbery, burglary and auto theft leaves no doubt of our need for the Police Athletic League (P. A. L.).
CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP)-- Sam Dente doubled home the winning run tonight as the Indians defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 2--1, in thirteen innings.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 31-- Nationalist China is viewing with growing apprehension the latest moves in Peiping's snowballing peace offensive.
Top purchasing executives of a utility and a large manufacturer intimated yesterday that copper producers may be pricing themselves out of the market.

The referendum by the Ford Company's employes, suggested by Mr. Reuther, as to whether they prefer the United Automobile Workers' "guaranteed annual wage" plan to the company's "counter-proposal" would seem at first glance to be a waste of time.
The heads of New York University and Fordham University praised yesterday's Supreme Court decision calling for desegregation in the public schools as quickly as feasible.
The booing directed at Jockey Eddie Arcaro diminished sharply as the racing program at Belmont Park progressed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Senator Prescott S. Bush, Republican of Connecticut, called today for an investigation to determine whether there is a "legalized larceny" provision in a law under which Federal savings and loan associations operate.

FOR June Dairy Month, which begins today, refreshing milk drinks served in tall, chilled glasses are suggested. Youngsters especially should like this way of cooperating with the dairy industry and the United States Department of Agriculture in their joint drive to increase use of fluid milk and milk products.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 31-- Gen. Juarez do Nascimento Fernandes Tavora appeared today to be gaining ground in Brazil's presidential race.
