Traffic fatalities over the long week-end in the nation reached a record high for a three-day Memorial Day holiday, according to figures compiled by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The Senate voted today to restore fund cuts made by the House of Representatives in the Government's propaganda and educational exchange program. The differences will be ironed out in conference.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 31 --The Benelux countries hope to convene a major conference of European states to take further steps toward European economic integration. The proposed conference would be held late this year or early in 1956.
WHILE the music of "The Ballad of Davy Crockett" goes round and round, products keyed to the song's theme are expected to ring up cash registers to the tune of $300,000,000 by the end of this year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 --The Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer studio will reach a five-year peak of production activity during the next two months, Dore Schary, vice president, announced today.
Preliminary competitions to the fourteenth Palm Beach round-robin tournament will be held today at the Deepdale Golf Club, Great Neck, L. I.
NEW DELHI, India, May 31-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru praised President Eisenhower and the United States today for helping to lower tensions in the world.

LONDON, May 31-Automobiles and buses were trying to do the job of Britain's struck railroad lines today in moving people to and from work. By and large, they succeeded, but the penalty in wasted time was nigh.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 31 (UP)--Up Top drew off to a three-length lead in the stretch to win the one-mile Farmingdale Pace in 2:05 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Hal Adam was second and Hugh Worthy third.
DALLAS, Tex., May 31-- lerman Shumlin, New York producer, lost his courtroom battle here today to halt four Dallas performances of his Broadway hit "Inherit the Wind."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31-- United States immigration policy is threatening the nation's world leadership, a leading social welfare executive said tonight.

Everybody is talking about "relieving tensions" these days. There could not be a better subject of international conversation, especially if something is done about it. The release by the Chinese Communists of four of the captive American fliers is, President Eisenhower feels, evidence that the Chinese Reds are sincere in trying to relieve world tension.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- President Eisenhower told World Health Organization delegates today that nothing the United Nations had done in its ten years better exemplified the hopes of its founders than their organization.
New financing in May was featured by a contraction in bond offerings and an expansion in stock flotations.

May, which in its first thirty days had run up a deficit in rain that seemed insurmountable, yesterday cut the shortage to more respectable proportions. A series of showers, some of neardeluge proportions, gave the city two-thirds as much rain in one day as had fallen in the previous thirty-day period.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, June 1 -- French Union troops in Saigon were scheduled to be reduced today to small units stationed at a few permanent French military installations. Responsibility for security in the South Vietnamese capital passed to the Vietnamese National Army and police.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- President Eisenhower cautioned today against "hit or miss" guesses on Peiping's motives in releasing four imprisoned United States airmen.

Following are excerpts from editorials in papers throughout the nation on the Supreme Court ruling on enforcement of school desegregation as gathered by The New York Times: East WILMINGTON A Sensible Decision The Morning News It was a pretty sensible decision. The court took a middle position. It set no deadline, but it emphasized that good faith and reasonable promptness would be required.
Ralph Bellamy has been reelected to a three-year term as president of Actors Equity Association. The results of balloting at last Friday's annual meeting were announced last night.
Kings County Surrogate Maximilian Moss signed yesterday a final order revealing that the estate of Lewis Luckenbach, founder of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, had a total value of $4,000,000.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 31 (UP)--Reconstruction work on the main stadium for the 1956 Olympic Games went into high gear today when officials mobilized extra manpower for the job.
WASHINGTON, May 31--A balanced Federal budget takes priority over any possible cuts in taxes next year, President Eisenhower told his news conference today.
A painted parchment map of Palestine, from the age of the Crusades has come into the possession of a New York specialist.
JACKSON, Miss., May 31-- The Supreme Court ruling was hailed by Mississippi political and educational leaders as a "very definite victory for the South."

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator Walter F. George opened debate on the Administration's $3,408,000,000 foreign aid request today with a warning that "this is no time for us to begin to trim a little here and a little there."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Following is the statement today of President Eisenhower on the polio vaccine situation: I would like to issue the following statement about the polio vaccine situation. The last week has been both eventful and encouraging.
A ninety-minute motion picture, recently completed under the supervision of Sir Alexander Korda, will be televised in color by the National Broadcasting Company before being shown in theatres.

"THE most alarming thing about the contemporary American theatre is the absolute rigidity of its march toward extinction." The holder of this emphatic opinion is Walter Kerr, who has been an instructor in the drama for eleven years, the director of three plays, a drama critic for Commonweal Magazine for two years and for the last five years the drama critic of The New York Herald Tribune.
The city's final assessed valuations for 1955-56 reached $21,021,108,321 yesterday, an increase of $743,264,789 over this fiscal year.
Southerners generally reacted quietly to yesterday's Supreme Court decision calling for publicschool desegregation as soon as feasible.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) --President Eisenhower and 15,000 other Government officials will "flee" Washington for a three-day civil defense test starting June 15 when the city will be "knocked out" by an enemy bombing attack.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Following is the text of the Supreme Court's opinion today on the public school segregation cases: These cases were decided on May 17, 1954. The opinions of that date (Footnote 1), declaring the fundamental principle that racial discrimination in public education is unconstitutional, are incorporated herein by reference.

Before long Wall Street, which weeps with great ease on occasion, will probably start its recurring lamentation over falling volume. This has happened so many times in the past that it is far more predictable than the market.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today upheld 5--3 an order for the deportation of Carlos Marcello of New Orleans. He is an alien convicted in 1938 of violating Federal narcotics laws.
Newly designated as Circle in the Square Cabaret rather than Circle in the Square, the theatre group will reopen at 8 o'clock tonight with "The King and the Duke" at 5 Sheridan Square.
Friday's total of 599 pints of blood collected by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program included 147 pints taken at the Gertz Department Store, 162-10 Jamaica Avenue, Queens.

BLED, Yugoslavia, May 31-- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party secretary, and Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin arrived here tonight after having concluded an agreement in principle with President Tito.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House has authorized direct quotation of the President throughout.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 31 --The Yankees, en route from Washington to Kansas City, were in high spirits as they passed through here today. One of the reasons for the Bombers' lation was the news that Bill Skowron, their hard-hitting first baseman, was almost, ready to return to action.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hoes 14.000 head; market moderately active and uneven: steady to 25c lower on butchers, mostly steady: trade fully steady on weights under 220 pounds; sows

BUENOS AIRES, May 31-- The Peronist newspaper La Epoca charged tonight that the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church "and its priests and acolytes are in open rebellion against the state and people."
LONDON, May 31 -- Queen Elizabeth II proclaimed a state of emergency today because of the nation-wide railway strike.
Rail and aluminum issues were firm yesterday but aircafts dragged down the industrial list and the stock market closed a trifle lower.
TORONTO, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Argus Corporation shareholders today approved purchase of 200,000 shares of St. Lawrence Corporation stock for $15,000,000.
Pornography is a definite factor in increasing juvenile delinquency, a Senate hearing reported yesterday.

An ownership of more than half a century has been terminated in the sale of the property at 673 'Madison Avenue. The five-story business and apartment structure has been conveyed by Mrs. George H. Shaffer as executrix of the estate of George H. Shaffer.
DAYTON, Ohio, May 31 (UP) --A gunman, firing wildly, shot and killed three persons and wounded five others today in two banks. He was shot by the police.

The City Council voted yesterday to create a city stabilization fund. The Charter amendment would provide a fiscal umbrella to protect New York on financial rainy days. In effect, the measure would give New York a limited surplus that could be used in any year when the city's revenues failed to come up to the amount anticipated.
MOSCOW, May 31--Six important retail trade chiefs in the Soviet Union were warned publicly today to put a stop to crooked practices in their organizations or face severe punishment.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Dick Haymes won a United States district court fight today to avoid being deported.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- The Hoover Commission, which has proposed cuts in many Federal programs, recommended expansion in one today--research and development.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Eisenhower said today the inoculation of all first and second grade school children with two doses of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine would be completed before mid-August. That is the peak of the polio season.
Bert J. Saperstone, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the five-story apartment house at 30-28 Thirty-fourth Street in Astoria, Queens. Nicholas Vanella was the seller.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 31 --Belgrade's current riddle goes like this: Question--Where is Stalin buried? Answer--Zemun Airport. Question--And under what rites? Answer--The Stalinist rites, of course. Zemun Airport is where Khrushchev, with all the grace of a walrus, apologized for the Cominform quarrel.
A permanently endowed lectureship named in honor of Alfred H. Barr Jr. has been established at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.
Commencement week at Columbia University will end today with the graduation of 6,050 students.

Senator John Marshall Butler has added his voice to those urging swift passage of a bill to put the United States Merchant Marine Academy, at Kings Point, L. I., on an equal footing with other service schools.

A syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Rauscher, Pierce Co., Inc., and Russ Co. is offering today a new issue of $6,000,000 of 4.6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Texas Industries, Inc., producer of masonry materials and metal pipe.
Joseph E. O'Grady was reported yesterday as a probable choice for one of the three places on the reorganized New York City Transit Authority. At present he is City Labor Commissioner.

NEWARK, May 31 -- This city's 7,000 employes are scheduled to receive tomorrow afternoon loyalty oaths and questionnaires about possible past or present "subversive" activities. The oaths and questionnaires must be signed, notarized and returned right away, according to Samuel B. Finkelstein, City Personnel Officer.
One of the principal links between post offices in the United States and their customers will soon be broken if recommendtions for ending the Postal Savings system are followed.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges were irregular in dull trading yesterday. Sugar, coffee, burlap, rubber and soybean oil were mixed; hides, silk, wool and copper declined, and cocoa, zinc, potatoes and cottonseed oil rose.
WASHINGTON, May 31--The Supreme Court directed the states today to end racial segregation in the public schools within a "reasonable" time.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) --The Department of Agriculture announced today that minimum 1955-crop wheat price support rates would range from $2.33 to $1.57 a bushel in commercial growing areas.
Joseph E. O'Grady was reported yesterday as a probable choice for one of the three places on the reorganized New York City Transit Authority. At present he is City Labor Commissioner.

NEWARK, May 31 -- This city's 7,000 employes are scheduled to receive tomorrow afternoon loyalty oaths and questionnaires about possible past or present "subversive" activities. The oaths and questionnaires must be signed, notarized and returned right away, according to Samuel B. Finkelstein, City Personnel Officer.
One of the principal links between post offices in the United States and their customers will soon be broken if recommendtions for ending the Postal Savings system are followed.

LONDON, May 31--The underlying stability of the stockmarkets here was demonstrated today by the fact that despite the railway strike prices were steadier when they closed than when they opened. Most share prices ended above the worst.
WASHINGTON, May 31--The Supreme Court directed the states today to end racial segregation in the public schools within a "reasonable" time.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) --The Department of Agriculture announced today that minimum 1955-crop wheat price support rates would range from $2.33 to $1.57 a bushel in commercial growing areas.
The President's reshuffle of his Joint Chiefs of Staff was completed last week with the surprising appointment of a junior rear admiral as the next Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- More than a century ago, when the Supreme Court was very young, Chief Justice John Marshall ruled a Georgia law unconstitutional. The state defied the court and was supported by President Andrew Jackson, who was quoted: "John Marshall has made his decision, now let him enforce it."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31--Dag Hammarskjold, the Secretary General of the United Nations, asked Peiping today for the release of eleven United States airmen "convicted" of espionage.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday hailed the Supreme Court decision on school desegregation as a clear-cut determination of the issue.
LONDON, May 31--An attempt to oust Clement R. Attlee and other elder statesmen from leadership of the Labor party has begun.

ST. ANNES, England, May 31 (AP)--Capt. Bill Campbell, a voluntary bench warmer during the 1955 Walker Cup matches, was returned abruptly to that role today, but the United States retained a strong hand in the British amateur golf championship with twenty-two survivors.
Ocean transportation of loaded railroad freight cars and truck trailers along the West Coast was forecast yesterday with the application of a Seattle shipping company for financing two train ships.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 31 (AP) -- Sixteen Yale and nine United States Military Academy athletes today were named to compete against an OxfordCambridge track team in London on June 13.

TALLAHASSEE, May 31-- Top Florida officials today generally praised the Supreme Court's desegregation decree but there were few who held any hope that any concrete steps toward eliminating segregation would be taken immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Clarence A. Davis, Under Secretary of Interior, proposed today that public and private local beneficiaries assume a "substantial" share of the cost of developing and conserving water resources.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on South-West Africa--WorKed on preparation of report to the General Assembly.

CHICAGO, May 31--No bullish developments were noted over the long week-end, and prices for all grains except rye were under pressure here today. Wheat declined 1 cent or more. The demand came largely from shorts, whose buying caused occasional rallies.

In the pleasant tradition of private benefaction to enrich the usefulness of Central Park the Florina Lasker Foundation has made a $250,000 grant for an indoor and outdoor recreation center restricted to enjoyment by older people. Fourteen acres in the Ramble, south of the Seventy-ninth Street Transverse Road, will be set aside for a variety of suitable purposes, and the Park Department will add $200,000 in expenditure for rehabilitation of the area.

President Eisenhower has wisely decided that it will be better for him to be in San Francisco when the United Nations opens its ten-year memorial program on June 20 than to be home getting ready for some fishing in New Hampshire or Maine.
A concerted effort to grapple with the twin problems of rising auto traffic and dwindling use of public transit facilities was started yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- Brazil and Colombia today became the second and third countries to enroll in President Eisenhower's atoms for peace program.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the smallest since last October. It was, however, the largest for a May since 1933.
A five-year police plan to study and combat juvenile delinquency was outlined yesterday by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.
LONDON, June 1--Investors returned cautiously to the stock market today and prices improved despite continuation of the rail strike. Buying embraced both Government securities and steel shares.
LONDON, June 1--Britain's trade union leaders intensified their efforts today to end the nation-wide rail strike, now in its fourth day.

Ten years ago New York University issued a report entitled "The Mission of a Medical School." This report proposed a new medical center to serve our community, our nation and science throughout the world. It was the blueprint for what is now the New York UniversityBellevue Medical Center.

It almost seems as if one would need a calculating machine to add up the number of Cabinet changes Chile has gone through since General Ibanez became President two and a half years ago. On Monday an entire new Cabinet was installed after a typically confusing struggle between personalities and political parties and between President Ibanez and Congress.
Four leading lawyers have been named to represent the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at the First International Congress of Jurists in Athens, June 13-18.

In 1878, when the Third Avenue elevated railroad went into operation, property owners along its path were compensated for their loss of light and air. Now with the "el" structure coming down and light and air restored present-day owners of these properties must hand back some of this money.

A banking syndicate headed by First National City Bank of New York offered yesterday to buy $27,150,000 of serial bonds of the New York City Housing Authority at a borrowing cost to the Authority of 3.0067 percent.

WASHINGTON, June 1--Major opponents in the recent battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co. agreed today that the public ought to get full information on all the financial interests invoved in rounding up stockholder proxy votes.
WENTWORTH BY THE SEA, N. H., June 1--Robert B. Wolfe, retail consultant of Lexington, Mass., today outlined ways in which retailers could help reduce expenses.
The International Harvester Company in the six months ended April 30 realized a 38.2 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of only 10.3 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

The country's chief civilian intelligence officer yesterday described the Soviet Union's leaders as a "troubled," "perplexed" and "probably unharmonious" group being forced into a policy of compromise.

Prices declined generally on the New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Volume continued light. Cocoa, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar and burlap fell; coffee, potatoes, zinc and wool were irregular, and rubber and copper advanced.
DENVER, June 1--The Governors of eight Missouri Basin and southwestern states were unable to agree today on which of two proposed Federal interstate highway programs they wanted.

TECHNICALLY, the Circle in the Square playhouse in the heart of Greenwich Village is back in business. Having made its peace with the Fire Department and having provided the necessary amount of space and adequate number of exits in the interests of its customers' safety, it reopened last night with Francis Fergusson's new play, "The King and the Duke."
WASHINGTON, June 1--An early conference of Yugoslav leaders with the Ambassadors of Britain, France and the United States in Belgrade is regarded here as a strong likelihood.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP)-- J. Paul St. Sure, president of the Pacific Maritime Association, gave the House Merchant Marine Committee "a general fill-in" today on labor troubles in the West Coast shipping industry.
THE versatile Ball Mason preserve jar is Often taken off the canning shelf to "preserve" the fisherman's bait, junior's pet frog or granny's sewing thread.
Cotton futures declined 3 to 15 points (15 to 75 cents a bale) yesterday in moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1-- A proposal to link the trading floors of the San Francisco and Los Angeles Stock Exchanges by direct wire is being submitted to the members.

Now that the warm weather is nearly upon us, Dr. Greenburg, Air Pollution Control Commissioner, logically and, we are sure, with the backing of the community, has warned the operators of the 10,000 building incinerators throughout the city that there will be a "crackdown" upon them if they do not take precautions to make certain that the incinerators do not smoke.

A group of commercial buildings near the downtown Civic Center has passed to new control with the sale by David S. Meister of four structures at 17 to 31 Vandewater Street through to 45-53 Rose Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The May 31 decision of the Supreme Court in the public-school segregation cases underlines the importance of a related issue now before the Congress. Both parties and a clear majority of both Senate and House support federal aid for public school construction.

WHILE the homemaker who serves as her own decorator may feel that arranging furnishings in a room is a house-size conundrum, she does not have to puzzle long about placing soundproducing equipment. If she would get the full tonal value of the radio, phonograph and television, her decision about their location in the room has been made for her by a group of experts.
A movement to save Carnegie Hall from being sold and torn down is being organized by John Totten, an employe for more than fifty years and now superintendent of the hall.
The story of New York's first twenty years of public housing was summarized yesterday in a report delivered to Mayor Wagner by Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.
A municipal court in Queens yesterday forbade the New York City Housing Authority to evict a tenant for nonpayment of rent.

The American Coastal Minesweeper MSC-130 became the Spanish Minesweeper Turia yesterday in a ceremony at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn. She was the first United States non-magnetic coastal minesweeper on the Sast Coast to be presented to the Government of Spain under the provisions of the Mutual Defense Assistance Program.
The name of Dr. Price Adams Kirkpatrick was removed from the Domestic Relations Court payroll yesterday. He had been arrested in Piermont, N. Y., on Tuesday on a burglary charge.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)-- The spotlight focused today on two rural counties in South Carolina and Virginia as Negro leaders worked toward ending school segregation in the South.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)--A short deck of closely sorted choice hogs sold at $19.75 today, best price here since last Nov. 22. Most butchers gained 25 cents while sows were mostly steady to strong.
WASHINGTON, June 1--A "sleeper" amendment that, in effect, would knock another hole in the reciprocal trade program was adopted without debate by the Senate today.
The Bawl Street Journal, satirical newspaper of the securities business, will make its anuual appearance this afternoon.

The first case of poliomyelitis in a child vaccinated in this year's school program in New York State was officially reported yesterday. The victim was 6year-old Donita Lent, vaccinated in Bethpage, L. I., on May 18.

Slowly but surely the ranks of those who think this will be the best business year on record are growing. Yesterday another important observer joined the optimists. Said the First National City Bank in its monthly business letter: "The economy in 1955 appears to be headed for its biggest year."

PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP)-- Luis Arroyo, an unbeaten southpaw, recorded his sixth victory tonight. He gave only six hits in pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-2 triumph over the cellardwelling Pittsburgh Pirates.

Discount houses, having captured a large share of department -store volume in hard goods, are beginning to wreak havoc in soft lines. A panel of retailers divided yesterday on the question of whether department stores should protect their mark-ups in linens and domestics, or slash them in all-out competition with the discount houses.

MESSINA, Sicily, June 1-- Rene Mayer, former French Premier, was chosen today as the new chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community. He was nominated unanimously at a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the community's six member nations.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 1 (AP)--The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company predicted today that in the foreseeable future atomic power would be complementary to rather than competitive with oil.

"FRONT ROW CENTER," a new hour-long drama series, made its debut last night on Channel 2 with a revival of "Dinner at Eight," the George S. Kaufman-Edna Ferber play. The production was not too satisfying, suffering as it did from the editing required by TV and from performances of somewhat too sharply varying quality.
The Broadway appearance next fall of the popular English comedienne Joyce Grenfell was assured yesterday.
CAIRO, June 1--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have rejected an urgent "suggestion" by the United Nations Palestine truce chief that he hold "pacifying" talks with Israeli leaders.

Current negotiations between the shipowners and the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., for a new contract when the present one runs out June 15 have brought into the news the "guaranteed annual wage" idea in a far less provocative form than in the auto workers' demands.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) --Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today there has been a "very disturbing" trend toward business mergers since the Korean War.
NEWARK, June 1--City employes, who received loyalty oaths and questionnaires about possible "subversive" activities this afternoon, will not have to face a loyalty investigation in the near future.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The Senate passed today, 78--0, a bill to increase the pay of 500,000 postal workers by an average of 8 per cent, retroactive to March 1. No mail worker would get less than a 6 per cent rise. The cost would be about $163,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, June 1--President Eisenhower formally submitted the Austrian state treaty to the Senate today for its approval. He termed it "another important triumph" for freedom and Western unity.

ST. ANNES, England, June 1 (UP)--Billy Joe Patton floundered on the outgoing nine holes of both his matches in the British amateur golf tournament today, but played spectacularly on the back nines to lead eleven Americans into the fourth round.

Resumption of new contract negotiations between the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. and Atlantic and Gulf Coast operators appeared imminent yesterday. They have been stalled since the opening meeting May 15.
Thirteen bewildered strollers in Foley Square were legally "shanghaied" yesterday by deputy United States marshals to complete a trial jury.
TRENTON, June 1--The Republican majority in the State Senate rejected today a strong appeal by the Republican State chairman Samuel L. Bodine, to vote an investigation of Democratic Hudson County.

DETROIT, June 1 (AP)--Billy Hoeft pitched his second straight shutout today. The southpaw hurled a two-hitter that ended the 'Detroit Tigers' four-game losing streak with a 9-0 victory over the Washington Senators.
A Queens youth was held without bail yesterday on charges of assaulting a physician, a policeman and a press photographer.

WASHINGTON, June 1--When President Truman moved back to the rebuilt White House in late March, 1952, the ghostly rappings on doors in the night that he had heard previously were heard no more. Since the rebuilding was done under the direction of Maj. Gen. Glen E. Edgerton, that officer should be of absorbing interest to spiritualists and to the learned societies that engage in psychical research.

RYE, N. Y., June 1--Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester and Gail Wild of Greenwich took a three-stroke lead in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's four-ball bestball two-day medal play tournament today. They scored a 40, 38--78 over the Apawamis course.
HONOLULU, June 1 -- Four happy American fliers spent their first day on United States soil today after two years in a Chinese prison camp.
WASHINGTON, June 1--An Air Force officer denied today that he had paid for a new home with bribe money given to him by a big Government contractor.

More than 500 members of society and persons prominent in business and civic life attended the Spring Party for the benefit of Boys Harbor in East Hampton, L. I. The event was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
A live "wish-you-were-here" type program from three countries will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Monday, June 27, from 8 to 9:30 P. M.

TUNIS, Tunisia, June 1-- Habib Bourguiba, whom the Tunisians regard as the father of his people, returned to his family today. His homecoming, after more than three years of exile, symbolized the self-Government that France has granted to this protectorate.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 26--The Dutch have achieved a theoretically improbable population surplus and labor shortage at the same time.
ABSECON, N. J., June 1-- Homes heated and cooled cheaply by miniature atomic energy reactors were forecast here today.
YESTERDAY (June 1,1955) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with leaders of Congress. Asked the Senate to give its consent to the Austrian treaty. Asked Congres for $2,500,000 in drought relief funds.

PARIS, June 1--Rene Mayer played a leading part in getting the treaty creating the coal and steel community ratified by the French National Assembly in December, 1951. For this reason he has long been classed among what the French call the "Europeans" --those favoring a European union on federal lines.

TOKYO, May 27--An elevenday, 11,000-mile flight up and down the Allies' defense perimeter from Japan to Australia inspires this conclusion: that the United States and its allies in the Far East are not carrying a very big stick with which to back up the loud talk of some United States leaders.

Project for Summer Well, here it is June the month which later on will officially bring on the summer. Since it is June, and summer is waiting, all costumed, in the wings, the time is as good as any to begin thinking of the Project for that season.

The essence of Dr. Konrad Adenauer's political philosophy is expressed in his forthcoming book, entitled "World Indivisible with Liberty and Justice for All." The Chancellor of West Germany "makes it plain" that his people are not ready to bargain away their freedom in return for Soviet pledges of a united Fatherland.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP)-- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today the Government hoped to compel some thirty organizations to register as Communist fronts during the new fiscal year starting July 1.
DETROIT, June 1--The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., postponed today until Monday a threatened strike against the Ford Motor Company. The strike deadline had been set for 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- The Government released today 200,000 shots of recleared Salk poliomyelitis vaccine for immediate use.

While turnover expanded to the best level since May 12, stock prices swung sharply upward and downward yesterday to create a highly irregular pattern. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 2,510,000 shares, compared with 1,990,000 on Tuesday.

The texts of citations used by Dr. John A. Krout, vice president and provost of Columbia University, in presenting the candidates for honorary degrees, and by President Grayson Kirk in conferring the honorary degrees at the Columbia University annual commencement exercises yesterday follow: DOCTOR OF SCIENCE Felix Andries Vening-Meinesz-- By DR. KROUT: Felix Andries Vening-Meinesz is presented for the degree of Doctor of Science.

The president of New York City's Board of Education has made an extraordinarily frank statement about teacher salaries. "I have found that the morale of the teaching and supervisory staff is alarmingly low throughout the system," says Charles H. Silver.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1-- National, state and city officials along with business, civic and cultural leaders took part today in the formal dedication of the new home of The Evening and Sunday Bulletin.
Last night's anticipated pitching duel at Ebbets Field between Gene Conley and Carl Erskine turned into a slugfest. Both star right-handers were knocked out of the game.
The Waterfront Commission completed yesterday the presentation of its case in a hearing into alleged kickbacks by longshoremen at the Leonardo Naval Base.
LIGHT winds and bright skies over next week-end should provide fresh and salt water anglers with plenty of activity on trout streams, bays and offshore waters.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)--Sherman Lollar's three-run homer in the seventh tied the score and Chico Carrasquel's run-producing single in the eighth tonight gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
CLEVELAND, June 1 (AP)-- Early Wynn pitched a four-hit shutout and Al Smith hit a tworun homer tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5--0.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The State Department added eleven names today to the list of fiftytwo United States citizens whom it has been prodding Communist China to release.
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, June 1 (AP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Soviet Communist party, described himself today as a "strong man" --physically, that is.

SYRACUSE, June 1 (AP)--A new member of The Central New York Commission on State Parks suggested today that "the entire park system of the state should be thoroughly investigated in regard to policies and controls."

IF Leo Durocher didn't express his thoughts in specific words, the implication was clear. When he first surveyed his qualitatively thin line of starting pitchers at the spring training camp, he gave the impression that the Giants could not win the pennant again unless they received extraordinary help from James Tolbert Hearn.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 1 (AP) --Communist propagandists have opened an intensive campaign here to woo workers and peasants.

OTZEM, Israel, May 22--This village was born at 11 A. M. today. Within fifteen minutes the surrounding countryside could tell that a vigorous infant had arrived, simply from the magnitude of the squalling.

BREAD pudding is the expedient--often a delicious one-- by which home cooks in many lauds make use of bread no longer fresh. In Germany, for example, pumpernickel may be used in combination with rum, whipped cream, grated chocolate and strawberry jam. Though unfamiliar to some Americans, chocolate with fruit is typically European.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We need only to compare dental health in persons of all ages in communities where fluorine is present in the water supply in quantities recommended by the medical and dental professions with dental conditions in people of less fortunate communities to prove that the benefits of fluoridation do not stop at age 8, as Dr. Leo Spira claims in his letter to The Times of May 25.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 1--The South, in the wake of yesterday's Supreme Court directive on how to desegregate public schools, was enmeshed in debate today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP)-- Henry Morgenthau, former Secretary of the Treasury, testified today he would have suspended Harry Dexter White if communist spy charges against the late Treasury official had been brought to his attention.

GENEVA, June 1 (AP)--Problems of the relationship between parents and their children were the theme of the secand plenary meeting of the convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs here today.

FOR the final event celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary, the Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today an impressive loan exhibition of 160 paintings from fifty-nine American collections.
LOS ANGELES, June 1--In an apathetic vote yesterday, Los Angeles residents rejected an opportunity to attract big league baseball here.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday that there was a great need for men in the higher ranks of the Police Department.
The retirement yesterday of Admiral Laurance T. DuBose brings an official end not only to a distinguished personal career but also to a naval--and military--epoch.
MEN who like to have evidence to back up a generality, especially when it has to do with women, may welcome the findings of two studies.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1--A statement summarizing the achievements of the negotiations between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia was completed by representatives of their Governments here today.
Retrolental fibroplasia, once a mysterious cause of blindness in prematurely born, children, may be virtually wiped out by 1957, the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind was told last night.

KANSAS CITY, June 1-- "Night and Day" is the title of a popular Cole Porter song. Reverse the order and it describes a long, sometimes wearisome, but nearly always profitable, vehicle for a two-admission baseball program.

A campaign intended to disabuse the minds of Americans that French champagne is solely for the rich is succeeding, reports the Champagne Producers of France. To support its contention the organization reports that during the first quarter of this year consumption of French champagne in this country was 25.28 per cent greater than in the 1954 period and imports were up 81 per cent.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1--Mr. Khrushchev paid a tribute today to the communism being developed under Marshal Tito.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Priceless mementos of World War II were presented today to President Eisenhower for the Eisenhower Museum at Abilene, Kan., by Sir Roger Makins, British Ambassador.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 1 (AP) --Homestretch Pappy, a 7-1 chance, won the $5,000 Riverhead trot in 2:07 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway by a half a length from Sister Song. Egyptian Boy, a Hambletonian eligible, was third in the event for 3-year-olds.

The first annual Florina Lasker Social Work Award will be presented tonight to Miss Jane M. Hoey, who served as director of the Federal Bureau of Public Assistance in the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations. The ceremony will take place during the National Conference of Social Work, which is being held in San Francisco.

PARIS, June 1 (UP)--America's top-favored team of Tony Trabert and Vie Seixas started slowly today but put on a highspeed finish to lead a march of Yanks into the semi-finals of the French international tennis tournament.
A Government defense planner specializing in raw materials called on private industry yesterday to make a greater effort on its own initiative to prepare for the possibility of war.
Adlai E. Stevenson charged last night that a "misguided" immigration policy had choked the flow of new talent and energy to this country.

Degrees in course and certificates of graduation were conferred upon 6,118 men and women yesterday afternoon, and honorary degrees upon twelve, at Columbia University's 201st annual commencement exercises.
Substantial gains in sportswear and improved results in home goods lifted sales of New York department stores in May an average of 7 per cent above those of a year ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1-- Ths reunion on the screen of Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart in "The Harder They Fall" is being sought by Jerry Wald.

Plans for a nation-wide poll of motion-picture patrons to select "the best picture, best performances and most promising young players of the previous year" were announced yesterday by the Council of Motion Picture Organizations, Inc.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 1 A third to half of the nation's labor force will have to be skilled workers to cope successfully with automation, Isador Lubin, state Industrial Commissioner, rned today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (UP) --Sam Jones pitched a two-hitter for seven innings tonight, but it was not good enough as the Phillies defeated Chicago, 3--1, to end the Cubs' fourth fourgame winning streak of the season.
Any further reductions in the retail price of coffee are highly unlikely for at least a year, according to Alkindar Monteiro Junqueira, president of the Brazilian Coffee Institute.

THE past is a looking glass. In it we see ourselves as we were or as we might or might not have been. This is the foreground. In the background, if we look attentively enough, we see many diversities of other men and women who help to give us perspectives on our own day.

Something more than a year ago the Supreme Court arrived at the unanimous decision that "segregation of children in the public schools solely on the basis of race * * * deprives the children of the minority group of equal educational opportunities."
Leo Durocher closed the sliding dressing room doors and raised riot with the Giants for ten minutes yesterday after their 5-2 loss to the Redlegs at the Polo Grounds.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a constant user of transit facilities in New York City I should like to comment on the article which appeared on May 31.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A formal court order directing the issuance of a passport to Dr. Otto Nathan was challenged today by the State Department. It carried the case to the Court of Appeals, which granted a temporary stay of the order.
ABOUT this time each year, American women used to pack their cashmere sweaters in moth balls and forget them until fall rolled around.
CHICAGO, June 1 -- Wheat, rye and soybeans futures declined in trading on the Board of Trade here today. Corn and oats gained slightly, with small receipts and firm cash prices helping the long side.

HONOLULU, June 1 -- Four United States jet pilots said today they had resisted "brain washing" during more than two years in Chinese Communist prisons, but had pleaded "guilty"' to "intruding" into China and "provocative attack."

WASHINGTON, June 1--An amendment to slash $1,000,000,000 from the Administration's foreign aid request was offered in the Senate today but supporters of the program predicted it would be approved without change.

CHICAGO, June 1--Voluntary and direct contributions of money to political campaigns by families were advocated here tonight by Philip L. Graham, publisher of The Washington (D. C.) Post and Times Herald.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The Government urged the Federal Court of Appeals today to reinstate a perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore.

CHICAGO, June 1--Sales of Beatrice Foods Company in March and April were higher than a year earlier and should remain above year-ago levels throughout the fiscal year which began March 1, William G. Karnes, president, said today.
The appointment of Brig. Gen. Robert E. Condon of the Air Force Reserve as New York City Director of Civil Defense is expected to be announced today by Mayor Wagner.
Barnard seniors were urged yesterday by Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, the college president, not to allow their intellect to be washed away with the laundry.

LONDON, June 1--Soviet and Japanese diplomats met here today to prepare the ground for peace and trade negotiations. The conversations will be the first official high level contacts between the-two powers since the end of World War II. The United States and Britain, as well as some of their allies, believe the Soviet Union will try to persuade Japan to adopt a neutral policy like Austria's
C. V. Whitney's Dispute, a $37.70-for-$2 proposition, popped up as the winner of the $20,000 added race that headed Belmont Park's program yesterday.

A major goal of the project is improvement of the Catania Plain, situated in Eastern Sicily south and west of the Etna volcano and the city of Catania. Irrigation will be the basic development. The objective is to raise the annual value of the area's farm production to $22,400,000, or three times its present value, by 1967.

THAT display of appetizers in a French restaurant known as hors d'oeuvre varies is as fascinating to most of us as a Swedish smorgasbord. So many tidbits artfully arranged cannot help but fill their function--that is, to awaken the palate and give it a lively interest in the courses to come.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 1-- Generalissimo and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek and all official Taipei turned out tonight at the Armed Forces Stadium here for a concert by the Symphony of the Air.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development approved today a $70,000,0000 loan to Italy. The money is to finance agricultural, industrial and power expansion in Southern Italy.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The Post Office Department carried forward its decentralization program today with the appointment of regional directors for New York and four other areas.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1-- Anti-immigration members of Congress are set "to give President Eisenhower the works" in his attempt to liberalize the Refugee Relief Act, Edward Corsi asserted today.

YESTERDAY (June 1, 1955) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on South-West Africa--Examined extent and manner in which specialized agencies and extra-budgetary organs of United Nations might contribute to advancement of territory.

CAIRO, May 25 -- Egypt's hopes for some sort of political unity with the Sudan, which controls the upper reaches of the life-giving Nile, have fallen almost to zero. This effect follows upon the visit here last week of the Sudanese Premier, Ismail el Azhari.

The reconstructed approaches to and exits from the Sixty-fifth Street transverse road through Central Park were opened yesterday. The $620,000 improvement is expected to eliminate bottlenecks at the outskirts of the park and thereby speed crosstown traffic.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 1 --Two teams tied at 61 in the pro-amateur celebrity tournament at the Deepdale Golf Club today. The event, in which seventy teams participated, served as a preliminary to the Palm Beach round-robin tournament that gets under way here tomorrow.
A socially prominent "playboy" was indicted yesterday for grand larceny. He was said to have bought a race horse and a Rolls Royce with money he obtained in a fraudulent stock deal.

The city put up 154 parcels of vacant and improved real estate in the five boroughs at auction yesterday and sold 137 for $1,003,185. The property, mostly taken over for tax liens, thus was returned to the city's tax rolls.
IT is harder to spend money than you may think. A recent study by students of City College shows that nine of every ten customers in New York stores tried to make purchases but only seven succeed.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that Senate amendments to the President's reciprocal trade bill represented a "return to the old protective tariffs."
Apparently all Johnny Antonelli needed to set himself right with the world was another good look at the Cincinnati Redlegs.

Those who deal with juvenile delinquency tend to two extremes: the spare-the-nightstick-and-spoilthe-child point of view or that which would change the child by improving his environment, especially his home. Police Commissioner Adams' plan to combat this evil takes a middle course--doubly commendable in a police official who might be expected to favor the nightstick policy.

Several hours after the Police Department started a special program to curb juvenile delinquency in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, twenty-one teen-agers were arrested in that area yesterday in the beating of a 16-year-old boy.

New York City occupies a unique position as a pioneer in public housing in this country. The record of accomplishment is spread over the five boroughs, but chiefly seen in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Now the New York City Housing Authority, in its twentieth annual report, traces the history of public housing from the small, tentative, experimental beginnings of 1934.
GREAT NECK, L. I., June 2 --Marty Furgol of Lemont, Ill., had a 1-point lead after the first round of the Palm Beach roundrobin golf tournament today.

KANSAS CITY, June 2-- When Lou Boudreau managed the Cleveland Indians he authored the "Williams shift" against the Boston Red Sox' Ted. As the pilot of the Kansas City Athletics, Boudreau tonight fashioned a "Mantle shift" against the Yankees' Mickey.

A decline of 1,304,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 169,373,000 barrels, compared with 170,677,000 a week earlier and 172,855,000 a year earlier.

CHICAGO, June 2, (UP)--The Chicago White Sox ruined Mel Parnell's first pitching appearance of the season today. They reached him for seven hits in six innings for a 4-2 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

Following is the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's address yesterday at the dedicatory exercises of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center: Mr. Rockefeller, Chancellor Heald, Governor Harriman, distinguished guests and ladies and gentlemen: For this honorary degree I am humbly grateful.
LONDON, June 2--Britain has gathered the equivalent of more than two combat divisions in the British Isles as a strategic reserve.
ALBANY, June 2--Assemblyman William F. Horan of Tuckahoe was elected chairman of the Legislature's new "watchdog" committee today.
WASHINGTON, June 2--Joseph Campbell, the Controller General, has attacked a proposal to stop further Congressional appropriations for Tennessee Valley Authority power facilities.
SURFCASTERS with confidence in their ability to lay out a long line will be gathering at Belmar, N. J., this week-end for a national casting tournament and an invitation surf fishing test.
The Board of Education appointed a psychologist and a Brooklyn elementary school principal yesterday to fill key posts on the Board of Examiners.

Cassius C. Mallory has been elected chairman of the board of directors and Lewis A. Lapham president of the Grace Line. Mr. Mallory succeeds J. Peter Grace Jr. and Mr. Lapham takes Mr. Mallory's former post.
A split in Democratic ranks over the sale of state-produced hydroelectric power seemed to be in the making yesterday, though it has not yet taken definite shape.
WASHINGTON, June 2--The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending June 1 decreased $177,000,000 to $18,496,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
HONG KONG, June 2--Fortyone persons have been executed and 172 sentenced to prison following the round-up of "counterrevolutionaries" completed two months ago in Shensi Province in northwest China.

The dedication yesterday of the Medical Science Building gave New York University-Bellevue Medical Center its second building in a $32,000,000 construction program. The first building, the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, was opened in January, 1951.

DETROIT, June 2 (UP)--Steve Gromek received credit for a 4-3 victory over the Washington Senators, but the 34-year-old right-handed pitcher hurt his back in the seventh inning and will be lost to the Detroit Tigers for a week or longer.

An investment syndicate headed by Milton Shoenholz and Leo Bruck has purchased the apartment property at 182 North Arlington Avenue in East Orange, N. J. The four-story structure on plot 100 by 175 feet contains thirty-four apartments of two two and one-half to five rooms.
Harold E. Stassen, the President's Special Assistant for Disarmament, set his sights last night on "favorable circumstances" for peace.

DUBLIN, June 1 -- After yielding the stage briefly to art, Paul Vincent Carroll's "The Devil Came From Dublin!" has returned to the Olympia for its fourth and final week. The interlude of art was Mr. Carroll's "The White Steed," with Liam Redmond and Maureen Delaney.
WASHINGTON, June 2--The governmental pay rise movement in Congress advanced a notch today.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 2-- The woman looked thoughtfully at the bizarre abstract painting in the shoe store window and suggested, "It might be some kind of new shoe they're selling."

The blockfront on the east side of Fifth Avenue from Fitty-fifth to Fifty-sixth Streets, and nine adjoining parcels on side streets, have been sold by Webb Knapp and associates to the Frezard Corporation, which leased back all the land to the sellers.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)-- Representative Sidney R. Yate Democrat of Illinois, today accused Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks of "callous and offhand" dismissal of the need of small aluminum fabricator for a share of the aluminum deliveries diverted to commercial use from Government stockpile schedules because of shortages.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, advised the public yesterday to avoid confusion over the value of the Salk vaccine, even though some vaccinated children would contract paralytic polio.

Mr. Robert Moses, Chairman New York Power Authority 270 Broadway New York 7, New York Dear Bob: I understand that the authority has been holding hearings on a number of proposed contracts for the disposition of St. Lawrence power.

WASHINGTON, June 2-- United States officials refused to comment tonight on the Soviet-Yugoslav communique issued in Belgrade but were obviously relieved that it contained no evidence of a rapprochement between the two estranged Communist countries.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 2 --New theories in apprentice training to meet the increasing need for skilled craftsmen were discussed today by representatives of labor, industry and government.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 2-- More than 2,700,000 Sicilians will vote Sunday for their third regional Parliament.

SASKATOON, Sask., June 2 (Canadian Press) -- When Mrs. M. P. Toombs heard that 70 percent of the mental patients in Saskatchewan hospitals never received a visitor, she decided something should be done.
Grocery coupons should be uniform in size and no larger than a dollar bill, according to a study of coupon promotions, begun last fall.
SEASIDE PARK, N. J., June 2 --Two huge watchdogs turned on their owner and chewed her to death at Island Beach State Park yesterday.

NEW CITY, N. Y., June 2-- The fiancee of Dr. Price Adams Kirkpatrick said today she believed there was no criminal intent in his alleged theft of antiques. She was said to have admitted accompanying the New York psychiatrist Monday night to the scene of the reported burglary.
Adlai E. Stevenson criticized the Eisenhower Administration yesterday for its handling of the polio situation, and for its overall health program.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2--The Soviet and Yugoslav foreign leaders professed identity of aims today on major issues affecting East-West relations.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)-- The House Commerce Committee reversed itself today and threw an amendment favored by the coal industry out of legislation to exempt natural gas producers from Federal controls.
ALBANY, June 2--Sixty-four pressure groups have reported that they spent $174,877 in trying to influence legislation during the 1955 session.

NOT many townfolk seem to know it, but there's a fullfledged college in lower Fifth Avenue that gets along with out a campus. Its annual commencement is to be held this morning in 110-year-old First Presbyterian Church, which lies just a little south of it.

Loans to brokers and dealers on non-Government securities declined $69,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Preserve Bank of New York. This was the first decline in a month and the biggest weekly decrease this year.

WENTWORTH-BY-THE-SEA, N. H., June 2--The nation's big department stores outshone the smaller ones in performance during 1954, the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was told today.
MESSINA, Sicily, June 2 -- The foreign ministers of the European Coal and Steel Community were deadlocked here today over proposals to create supranational agencies.
WASHINGTON, June 2--First action on desegregation by a state court since the new Supreme Court order came today.
WASHINGTON, June 2--The Administration's $3,530,000,000 foreign aid program was approved in full by the Senate tonight.
TRENTON, June 2--A sharp controversy has developed between Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, and the Republicancontrolled Legislature over the merits of closing an all-Negro vocational school.
Governor Harriman told the State Chamber of Commerce yesterday that an improvement in relations between the city and state governments was a major objective of his Administration.

There is good reason why Washington and, for that matter, other capitals in the free world should watch with some uneasiness the negotiations now taking place in London between representatives of Japan and the Soviet Union. The Japanese are not in a strong position.
New York Takes a Holiday The time to enjoy New York, said the stay - at - home inhabitant, firmly fortified against the wanderlust, is when everybody else is on the road going other places.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Louis E. Wolfson was criticized at a Senate hearing today for using assets of two companies he controls to buy Montgomery Ward Co. stock in a fight for control of that company.
OTTAWA, June 2 (Canadian Press) -- Canada tightened her anti-dumping laws today to protect Canadian producers against imports of competing products that are state-subsidized.

THE current chorus girl is a soft-spoken lass who dances by night and probably attends college by day. So observes Sheldon M. Cooper, a man in a fine position to survey guys, dolls and the passing scene on Broadway.
More Americans are expected to visit the Soviet Union this year than at any time since the end of World War II, according to Vladimir K. Lobachev, third secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

The old carpet manufacturing plant of Alexander Smith in Yonkers has been sold as one unit by the company to a syndicate planning an industrial center on the thirty-five acre property containing sixty buildings.
The Dodgers ripped into a trio of Milwaukee relief pitchers in the eighth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday to make a shambles of what had been a close contest.

DETROIT, June 2--The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., appeared today to have gained a concession from the Ford Motor Company on the question of pay for laid-off workers. The new Ford offer to the union this week, according to qualified sources, would provide for company payments to supplement unemployment compensation when workers are laid off.
CHICAGO, June 2--Grain and soybean futures all declined this morning, but wheat rallied in the afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2--The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia issued a joint declaration today proposing solutions of the German and Formosa questions. Among the proposals in the declaration were the following: A collective security treaty in Europe as part of a general system of collective security.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The Federal Court of Appeals ordered the State Department today to grant a hearing to Dr. Otto Nathan on his application for a passport. The ground rules for the proceedings were laid down by the court.
LONDON, June 2 -- Leaders of the left and right wings of the British Labor party today blamed each other's factions for Labor's defeat in the general election last week.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) --The Senate Armed Services Committee today unanimously approved nominations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff. These included the selection of Rear Admiral Arleigh A. Burke as Chief of Naval Operations.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 28--The Dutch think they may be close to the answer to the most troublesome problem of economic policy facing all industrialized free societies. This is the problem of how, without virtual enslavement of labor, to maintain full employment without inflation.
THE Lux Video Theatre was off its stride last night on Channel 4. Its video version of "The Suspect," a motion picture in which Charles Laughton starred, was pretty flat and uninspired TV.
A threat of a longshoremen's strike, based on predicted action by the Waterfront Commission, faded yesterday.
MOSCOW, June 1--Moscow's richest red carpet is now being rolled out for Jawaharlal Nehru, who will arrive here next week as a guest of the Government.
A new automatic system to speed credit reporting in the apparel industries was unveiled yesterday by Credit Exchange, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 2--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 790,176 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,757 cars or 2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 100,884 cars or 14.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week, last year, and 3,421 cars or 0.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Wistfully gazing at "A Day by the Sea" are Hume Cronyn and his wife, Jessica Tandy. Speaking for himself and the distaff side, Mr. Cronyn verified a report yesterday that they were impressed by the N. C. Hunter drama, which achieved an extended London run.
MADISON, N. J., June 2-A fawn and white boxer came out of the Middle West to win the highest award of America's most distinguished outdoor dog show today.
The Jockey Club, which is in the process of forming a Greater New York Racing Association, yesterday named three officials and six policy-making committees for the new organization.

DENVER, Col., June 2--A plan to classify land in the Dust Bowl and persuade farmers to use it properly was under consideration today at the close of a special conference on drought in the Great Plains.

The whole nation is happy to welcome back to freedom four American airmen who have spent more than two years in captivity in Communist China. Shot down during the Korean war, imprisoned in Communist jails and then suddenly "tried" and sentenced to "deportation," they are now enjoying their first thrilling days of liberty in paradisiac Hawaii in the company of family members flown there in a grateful gesture by the Air Force.
Hon. Herbert H. Lehman United States Senate Washington, D. C. Dear Herbert: I have your letter of May 14 with reference to St. Lawrence power. Let me reply promptly.

CHICAGO, June 2--The forthcoming meeting of the Big Four heads of government "could be the world's last chance to settle differences peacefully and avoid a catastrophic war," Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared here today.
LONDON, June 2--"Tiger at the Gates" by Jean Giraudoux opened tonight at the Apollo Theatre and received warm, although sometimes qualified, praise from London critics.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP)-- The House Merchant Marine Committee said today that Harry Lundeberg, president of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., had refused to appear at a closed committee hearing on maritime labor problems.

DR. CARY MIDDLECOFF was a few strokes off the pace when the flamboyant Tam O'Shanter open roared into its final round last summer. But the tension within him was mounting until he was as brittle as an electric light bulb. He exploded. Finishing with a horrendous 80, the smoldering Middlecoff sought out his wife in the clubhouse.

Shipboard handled the top burden of 156 pounds easily in the $11,375 Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Under the guidance of Albert Foot, the Montpelier 5-year-old won by six lengths in the test of about two miles and a half, which had its fortieth running.
Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, appealed to nurses being graduated at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center yesterday to be patient with volunteers.
SCHEVENINGEN, The Netherlands, June 2--The United States and Communist China are sitting down together at a full-fledged international conference in this resort.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 2-- Bright hopes have been aroused here by an agreement signed Tuesday in Washington to give Brazil access to United States information on atomic energy for peaceful purposes.
The cooks and waiters were the only diners in two New York hotel restaurants last night. Sitdown strikes by fifty-seven unionized culinary employes were responsible for the upset in normal service.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2-- Lung cancer was declared here today to have become an epidemic disease that still had not reached a peak.
LONDON, May 23--The cost of power from Britain's atomic reactors is expected to be lowered considerably if present experiments on what are called "fuel recycling operations" are successful.

PARIS, June 2--The American evangelist, Billy Graham, will start the first "Crusade for Christ" he has undertaken in a predominantly Roman Catholic country when he appears Sunday evening at the Velodrome d'Hiver, Paris' great indoor arena.
A deepwater fuel-oil terminal expected to insure an adequate year-round supply of oil in Manhattan is to be erected along the North River waterfront between West Fifty-fourth and Fiftysixth Streets.
Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner conferred for an hour yesterday, but parted without announcing the composition of the new Transit Authority.
RICHMOND, Va., June 2--A top-ranking Southern Presbyterian emphasized to his fellow churchmen tonight that all in the human family were "brothers -- regardless of races and classes."
Seven hundred alumnae of Barnard College held their sixtyfirst reunion yesterday in a celebration dedicated this year to the faculty.
Baltimore borrowed $24,725,000 in the public market yesterday on bond issues to finance incinerator and other improvements.

A new "inside" book by John Gunther is planned for September publication by Harpers. It will be called "Inside Africa." In preparation for the writing of his book Mr. Gunther traveled 40,000 miles, visited 103 localities and interviewed more than 1,500 persons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2--Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Chief of Staff, today thanked Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, for his work in obtaining the release of four United States jet pilots by Communist China.

LONDON, June 2--Prices of industrial shares soared here today to a historic peak. American buying of leading issues stimulated a boom atmosphere, in which considerations of the national railway strike were brushed aside.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A Senate subcommittee voted unanimously today to take the Government's security problems out of politics and put them under scrutiny of a bipartisan commission.
The appointment of Joseph A. Sarafite as City Treasurer at $15,000 a year was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Mr. Sarafite is now Chief Assistant District Attorney of New York County at $14,000.

Yesterday's joint Yugoslav-Soviet declaration issued in Belgrade climaxed the colorful visit of the Khrushchev delegation to that historic capital. Preceded a week ago by Mr. Khrushchev's expression of regret over the 1948 rupture between the two countries and their respective Communist organizations, this document will be studied with great interest by diplomats seeking to answer two questions:

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., June 2-- Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Gordon of Englewood and Seaview, Fire Island, N. Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Gordon's daughter, Miss Ruth Lean Armour, to Elliott Kamen. He is a son of Mrs. Mild. ed F. Kamen of Pittsburgh and the late Moses A. Kamen of San Antonio, Tex. A summer wedding is planned.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 --Peggy Lee, singer turned actress, has signed to make three pictures for Jack Webb's Mark VII Productions.
Two series of children's programs, one to be produced in cooperation with the Board of Education of the City of New York, will make their television debuts the middle of this month.

Stocks turned in a highly selective performance yesterday. Gains were larger than losses, however, so that The New York Times' combined average of fifty stocks touched its highest point since Oct. 16, 1929, and the industrial average made its best mark on record.

HONOLULU, June 2 -- Four Americans freed from Communist Chinese prisons and their families were completely happy today for the first time in more than two years. They were together and they were at peace.
BOONTON, N. J., June 2--J. Walcott Brown of Manasquan River won the qualifying medal in the fifty-fourth annual New Jersey state golf championship with a two-under-par 34, 35--69 at The Knoll today.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 2--A report by a group of pathologists suggesting the possible discovery of changes in the bronchial tree that might be associated with smoking was presented here tonight.
Two Komodo dragons made their not-too-reluctant American debut at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

As labor negotiations enter the showdown stage in the auto industry, the immediate production outlook is uncertain. There's nothing uncertain, however, about the record-shattering performance of car makers in the first five months of this year.

CLEVELAND, June 2 (UP) -- Although he weakened after a blazing start, Herb Score registered his sixth victory today as the Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 9 to 3. The triumph gave Cleveland a sweep of the three-game series.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 2--An auld-lang-syne atmosphere envelops the campus of Irving School on Broadway here.

The President of the United States had a thought the other day about "equality of opportunity." We usually take it to mean an equal chance for all regardless of race, color or religion, he remarked. But, he continued, we might extend the concept in our hearts and minds to include the physically handicapped.
Eighty-three subway riders were injured yesterday morning when a southbound IRT express rammed a standing train in the Bronx. No one was critically hurt, but nine were hospitalized.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Friday, June 3--In a high-spirited mood Nikita S. Khrushchev this morning labeled correspondents "dangerous" and then offered to let them into the Soviet Union "tomorrow if you wish."
LONDON, June 2--The Trades Union Congress failed today to find a solution to the nationwide railway strike.

Prices of commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume continued light in most markets. Sugar and cottonseed oil moved mixed; rubber, potatoes, soybean oil and zinc eased, and coffee, cocoa, hides, wool and copper rose.

PARIS, June 2 -- The North Atlantic Council plans neither to contest nor approve the withdrawal for service in Algeria of a French division now under Allied command. Nor will Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, take any decision in the matter.

THE love of reading comes before the love of writing and all writers learn much of what they know about their craft from the works of other writers. They learn what great authors have done before them and the technical methods they used to tell their stories, to bring their characters to life and to impose their own vision of the world upon their books and upon their readers.
The bill passed by the Senate for a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was sharply criticized yesterday by a veteran spokesman for the importing trade.

CHICAGO June 2 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 10,000 head: general market fairly active, averaging around steady on both butchers and sows: some opening sales weights under 230 pounds weak to 25c lower:
A number of Chinese students and scholars are being returned to their homeland from the United States under conditions that are said to threaten to impair their pro-American sympathy.
THE PRESIDENT Met with some members of Congress on legislation to expand military survivorship benefits.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 3-- One fact stood out in the joint declaration of the Soviet and Yugoslav Governments as issued here today: It does not mention relations between the Communist parties of the two countries.

MUNICIPAL Applications for the following examinations can be obtained at 96 Duane Street: CIVIL ENGINEER. There are at present nine vacancies in four city departments. Under the proposed career and salary plan, which is effective July 1, the salary range for this position is $7,100 to and including $8,900 with annual increments of $300.
Two brothers of a man who died in a plane crash in 1949 were arraigned yesterday in General Sessions Court in the alleged forgery of his will.

HOME cooks doing their marketing this week-end will notice that the produce stalls are taking on a welcome look of summer. Certain fruits and vegetables are appearing for the first time this year; others are increasing in supply.
WASHINGTON, June 2--Poliomyelitis cases are running at a higher rate this year than the median figure for the last five years in all but five states, the Public Health Service reported today.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 2 -- Gen. Paul Ely assured French residents of Vietnam today that France still had a role to play here.
PITTSBURGH, June 2 (UP)-- The Pittsburgh Pirates reached five St. Louis Cardinal pitchers for seventeen hits today to rout the Redbirds, 12--3.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 (Reuters)--Following is the text of the joint declaration signed tonight by representatives of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union meeting in Belgrade as issued by Tanjug, the Yugoslav news agency:

Blum's First-quarter sales and earnings of Blum's the California confectionery company, are ahead of the similar period last year, Robert T. Beattie, president, informed shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The Federal Narcotics Commissioner estimated today that there were about 60,000 narcotics addicts in the United States--9,458 of their in New York State. Their average spending for the stuff is $10 a day.

A 16-year-old Brooklyn boy was convicted of first-degree murder yesterday in Kings County Court. Since there was no recommendation for mercy, it is mandatory that he be sentenced to the electric chair.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was quiet and steady, with closing prices up 5 to 17 points (25 to 85 cents a bale).
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) --Andy Seminick's first-inning grand-slam homer started the surging Philadelphia Phillies on the road to an 8-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 2--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 10 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The creation of special courts to deal with social offenders was described yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh as the "most significant development" in the Magistrates' Courts in recent years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Bricker stated to the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on constitutional amendments on April 25: "To repeat, the advocates of world government seek to repeal the American Declaration of Independence." He sounded the alarm that these advocates of world government are the primary opponents of his amendment and should they prevail "the United States would cease to be a sovereign independent nation."
ROME, June 2--The celebration of Italy's national holiday today was marked by coolness between recently elected President Giovanni Gronchi and the Government.
A total of 182,449 children received injections in the ten-day first round of the New York City polio vaccination program that ended yesterday.

ST. ANNES, England, June 2 (UP)--Don Bisplinghoff, Billy Joe Patton and Lieut. Joe Conrad carried the United States hopes into the quarter-finals of the British amateur golf championship with fourth and fifth-round triumphs today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your May 21 issue you editorially condemn the New York State Automobile Association's stand against the highway bond issue to be voted upon this fall and say that, since the battle to prevent diversion of the gasoline tax has been lost, the voter should give up and vote for the bond issue.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., a leading producer and merchandiser of textiles, had a greater profit in the six months through April than in the entire fiscal year through last October.

BOONTON, N. J., June 3-- Chester Sanok of the home club. the defending champion, led the way into the quarter-final round of the fifty-fourth annual New Jersey state amateur golf championship at The Knoll today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3-- With a rousing godspeed from their shipmates, their officers and even the sun, 740 first class men tossed their caps in the air today and became the 115th class to be graduated from the United States Naval Academy.
MOSCOW, May 24--In the Soviet Union, newspapers are "so to speak, a direct continuation" of the Communist party apparatus.

Jean Monnet, France's doughty champion of European federation, would have reason these days to feel that a prophet is indeed honored save in his own country. The French Government rejected his candidature to return as head of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community.

CHICAGO, June 3--Jack Harshman's pitching and batting carried the White Sox to a 3-2 victory over the league-leading Yankees tonight. The former first baseman drove in two runs while outlasting Manager Casey Stengel's right-handed ace. Bob Turley, before 40,020 fans at Comiskey Park.
WASHINGTON, June 3--President Eisenhower vetoed today a private bill granting permanent residence status to Kurt Glaser, a Czechoslovak national.
ALBANY, June 3--John B. Johnson of Brooklyn, a former State Supreme Court justice, was appointed today as administrator of the State Judicial Conference at a $25,000 annual salary.

The decisive majority by which the Senate authorized the Administration's foreign-aid program is encouraging. The final ballot was more than three to one for the unimpaired project. Restrictive amendments had been defeated by an even more lopsided vote.
