Plans seem to be firming up rapidly for a new railroad station and what is described as the world's largest commercial building on the site of the Pennsylvania Station. There will be a signing of papers next Tuesday between James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and William Zeckendorf for Webb Knapp, which will doubtless be the occasion for the fuller revelation of plans still in the making.
Mayor Wagner proclaimed yesterday as "Student Day" and turned the official spotlight on the cream of the city's student crop.
RAGUSA, Sicily, June 3-- The Communists and their allies have placed American oil interests at the center of the election campaign in Sicily.
SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., June 3--The green turf of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club was dotted today with the financial district's bond experts, togged in sport regalia.
A woman cashier, suspected of having stolen $45,000 to $100,000 to play the horses, was arrested yesterday as she was released from a woman's prison in Clinton, N. J.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif:, June 3 --Screen rights to "The Actor," a novel by Niven Busch published this week, have been purchased by Henry Ginsberg, independent producer. The book has a Hollywood background and its principal characters are a rising young movie director and his father, fading hero of Westerns.

New York City, the subject of an anthology to be published this month, is also the background for two novels to be issued within a short time. One novel is William Ard's "Hell Is A City" (Rinehart, June 13), which deals with politics and "honest and dishonest" cops during an election year.
WASHINGTON, June 3--Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday at 110.2 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Underwriting activity will continue on a broad scale next week, with an unusual array of new common stock to be offered for subscription by company stockholders.
NYACK, N. Y., June 3--"The long Way," a new opera by Alec Vilder to a libretto by William mgvick, had its first performnce tonight in the Nyack High chool auditorium.
WASHINGTON, June 3--President Eisenhower recalled today with evident feeling the plight of the victims of Nazi tyranny.
DETROIT, June 3--Union negotiators pushed today for improvements in the Ford Motor Company's offer to make payments to laid-off workers.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 3--Albert Anastasia, reputed executioner for Murder, Inc., the notorious Brooklyn gang of the Nineteen Thirties, was sentenced today to one year in prison and fined $20,000 on income tax evasion charges.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 3-- Here's a grim race-track story beyond any ever dreamed by Damon Runyon: On May 26 Samuel I. Brandt of 41 Park Avenue, Manhattan, a retired lingerie manufacturer, went to Belmont Park Race Track in a car driven by his brother, Nathan, who lives at 1916 Avenue K in Brooklyn.

The annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Quartermaster Corps Association has been canceled because of the Army's objections to officers' being entertained by companies with which they do business.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (UP) --Billy Bruton smashed the first pitch of the tenth inning over the right-field wall tonight to give the Milwaukee Braves a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. It was Bruton's fifth homer this season.

Stan (The Man) Musial hit the 300th home run of his major league career at Ebbets Field last night. But the Cardinals tied the National League record by using eight pitchers and the Dodgers won, 12--5, with Duke Snider, Roy Campanella and Gil Hodges also belting homers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 10 points higher to 5 points lower than on Thursday.
CAIRO, June 3--Premiers Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and Nuri as-Said of Iraq have begun to patch up the quarrel between their countries.
MESSINA, Sicily, June 3--The six nations of the European Coal and Steel Community have agreed to proceed cautiously on the road toward European integration.
WASHINGTON, June 3--A thorough overhaul of benefits to survivors of service men was proposed by a special House committee today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 3-- Japan and West Germany are bidding for greater trade with and investment in Brazil. Their emissaries have been conferring with officials here for some time.

COMPTON, Calif., June 3 (UP) --Horace Ashenfelter of the New York A. C. set an American two-mile record of 8:49.6 in the Compton invitation games tonight. But Wes Santee failed even to lower his one-mile meet mark of last year.
The pay of New York City's 40,000 public school teachers will be increased by $300 in 1955-56 and by an additional $150 in 1956-57.

IN far-off Finland little girls grow up wanting to be models. It seems a more achievable goal there than here. And, according to Mme. Tabe Slioor, Finland's leading model and the director of the Helsinki School for Models, a fatless frame is not the fashion in Finland.

The National Council of Seamen's Agencies yesterday adopted resolutions that would lead to a comprehensive study of the needs of seamen and possible world-wide cooperation of marine welfare organizations.

MEXICO CITY, June 3--The Tijuana Industrial Fair, which was scheduled to be held early this month, has been postponed until a tentative date in late August and there is a possibility it will be canceled entirely.

PARENTS today hear more and more about their rights, as individuals, to have time to themselves. Fourteen weeks ago, twenty-seven mothers with youngsters 3 to 5 years of age were given an opportunity to put this privilege to happy use-- two free hours a week to call their own.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 3 --What was forecast as the 1955 version of the Cherokee land rush turned out today more like a Vassar bird walk.
Dollar economy, not combat effectiveness, has been the theme song, so far, of most of the Hoover Commission reports dealing with the military services.
SAN QUENTIN, Calif., June 3 (AP)--Two professional killers and a woman who got mixed up in one of their murders died in San Quentin prison's gas chamber today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is with sadness that I read the statement by Dr. Cyril F. Garbett, the Archbishop of York, in The New York Times of May 31. With sweeping generalizations he indicted the people of Israel for the problems that trouble Arab-Israeli relations today.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 3-- Peter Thomson, 25-year-old Australian, led after the third round in the Palm Beach round-robin tournament today. Continuing his sub-par play at the Deepdale Golf Club, the British open champion had a point total of 22.
KAOHIUNG, Formosa, May 26 --In less than ten years, Kaohiung has risen from the rubble of war to the nearest thing to a boom town on Formosa.

The directors of four diverse companies yesterday called special meetings of shareholders to vote on various proposals. The companies and the proposals follow: Bankline Oil Company A special meeting will be held on June 14 in San Francisco to vote on issuance of 75,000 shares of $25 par convertible preferred stock and an amendment to the profit-sharing plan.
WASHINGTON, June 3-- Leaders of ten veterans organizations pledged to President Eisenhower today a determined fight to revive and pass the Administration's military Reserve program.
Prospects that a Ford Motor Company strike will be averted sent the stock market to new highs yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to express my concern at the incompleteness of the biographical sketch of Justice Owen J. Roberts published in the May 18 edition of The New York Times. There was not even a passing reference to the cause dearest to the Justice's heart--the federal union of the free peoples of the world.
The Board of Education is considering the fate of a school principal who has admitted past membership in the Communist party but will not identify others in the party with him.
Not the least important by-product of the Soviet-Yugoslav meeting in Belgrade was the opportunity it gave the world to take a relatively close look at Nikita S. Khrushchev.
A discovery in a cave in South Africa has clearly established a point on the evolutionary ladder at which man's ancestors first learned to use tools.

WASHINGTON, June 3--A machine to assist nature in the fertilization of alfalfa was patented this week by a Kansas professor. The inventor is Dr. William. S. Chepil, Professor of Agronomy at the Agricultural Experiment Station, Kansas State College of Agriculture, Manhattan, Kan. His apparatus beats the blossoms open, promoting cross pollination and production of fertile seeds.

LONDON, June 3--V. K. Krishna Menon, India's intermediary between Communist China and the West, predicted today that the recent release of four United States airmen might lead to settlement of outstanding issues. His efforts in Peiping were directed toward "lowering of tension," Mr. Krishna Menon said, and "American fliers or Chinese students are all items in that."
A 16-year-old high school student was arrested in the Bronx last night in the beating of a 17-year-old youth in the gang-ridden Morrisania section Wednesday night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rumors of continued unrest in Guatemala highlight the problem of Communist infiltration and propaganda for all the people of the Americas. For the poor economic condition of some of these people makes them particularly vulnerable to Communist and Fascist propaganda.
BONN, Germany, June 3 -- After three years' delay, the West German Government is about to embark on a three-year civil defense program.
"HAPPY FELTON'S KNOTHOLE GANG," the program presented on Channel 9 just before each home game played by the Brooklyn Dodgers, performs a valuable service for youngsters interested in baseball.
Demand for monkeys to perform vital functions in the production and safety-testing of polio vaccine has stirred trade activity throughout the Far East.
HARTFORD, June 3--Connecticut moved today to Increase its gasoline tax from 4 to 6 cents a gallon July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)-- Lobbyists for labor groups, farmers and utilities reported the heaviest spending on their "legislative interests" during the first three months of the present session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 3--Senate investigators unearthed a rare species of Americana today, --a man who refused to be proved innocent of tax-fraud.

CHICAGO, June 3--Stockholders of Sunbeam Corporation voted today at their annual meeting to increase authorized capital stock to 8,000,000 shares from 3,000,000. The action paved the way for payment of a stock dividend of one share for each two held.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 3--Executive committeemen of the Westchester County Republican organization voted today not to confine themselves to the judicial nomination limitations set by a powerful nonpartisan citizens committee on Children's Court judge.
Observant fans in third-base vantage points at Ebbets Field must wonder what is going on in the Dodger dugout across the way.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have followed with some interest the controversy concerning the increase in corporate franchise tax on the New York Central's right to use Park Avenue. I know this is not a new tax, but its sharp increase has opened the way for public comment and I see fit to add my opinions.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21-- Marriage and divorce are developing into a political issue here with the approach of the national elections scheduled for July 25.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 3 --The Central Government withdrew today its administrative control over East Pakistan.

Two buildings containing forty apartments and occupying a plot 60 by 102 feet at 203-05 East Seventy-seventh Street were bought by Abraham Hirshfeld from the 203 East Seventy-seventh Street Corporation. They were then resold to a client of Jacob S. Berliner, co-broker in the resale with Julian E. Gordon Co.

A truck that was too big for a tunnel created a traffic bottleneck yesterday morning. The truck, twelve feet high, tried to get through the tunnel under Park Avenue between Thirty-third and Fortieth Streets, where the clearance is ten feet three inches.
OHRBACH'S says we'll be living in velvet this summer, and is providing the means with a collection of velvet hats priced from $3.99 to $22.98. It was previewed by the press earlier this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3-- Technological advances will have to increase productivity about 50 per cent in the next ten years just to maintain the country's present standard of living, an industrial research engineer said today.
WASHINGTON, June 3--Sales by wholesalers in April fell 4 per cent below the March levels, according to unadjusted figures released by the Government today.
ICE cubes variously flavored and colored are a bit of summer frivolity for tall, chilled drinks.
WASHINGTON, June 3--Findings of President Eisenhower's Committee on Transportation were assailed and defended today in a panel discussion by spokesmen for the railroad and trucking interests.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 3 --A plan to organize a national coordinating committee for a continuing study of skilled trades was adopted today at the eleventh annual Eastern Seaboard Apprenticeship Conference.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3--Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet Communist leader, said in Sofia, Bulgaria, today that the period of unfriendly relations between the Soviet bloc and Yugoslavia had ended.

LONDON, June 3--The stock market lost a little of its brilliance here today in the face of the gathering interruptions to industrial output. But the reaction still left most industrial shares with the greater part of yesterday's remarkable gains intact.
CLEVELAND, June 3--Former President Truman charged the Eisenhower Administration today with "bungling" the Salk polio vaccine program.
ALBANY, June 3--Governor Harriman today called a public hearing on the controversial contract between the State Power Authority and the Aluminum Company of America.

Chicago's Bob Rush cast a malign spell over the Giants for the third time this season last night. The big right-hander held the New Yorkers to five hits in pitching the Cubs to a 4-1 victory at the Polo Grounds.
This port's sporadically turbulent waterfront boiled over again yesterday as longshore union officials chided the Waterfront Commission and each other.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 2 Belgian business and financial leaders are thinking anew about the basis of their country's economic future. One of them summed it up today by saying that "there has been a marked decline in complacency here."
DETROIT, June 3 (AP)--Ned Garver scattered six hits and drove in two runs with a single and double while pitching the Detroit Tigers to a 7--2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
MOSCOW, June 3--Pravda said today the Soviet-Yugoslav declaration had "tremendous significance" not only for the two signatory states but also for the world as a whole.
CHICAGO, June 3--Weakness in the coarse grains, with corn especially heavy on free long liquidation, unsettled the grain futures markets today.
Christmas arrived yesterday for many Democrats. For many it was somewhat tardy; for others it was six months early.

ST. ANNES, England, June 3 (UP)--Joe Conrad, a hardy Texan who enjoys playing in Britain's rugged weather, reached the final of the British amateur golf tournament today. Thus the United States will be represented in the championship round for the tenth straight year.

"MANIFEST Destiny was not an invention of President Polk (1795-1849) and his generation, or of any American, for that matter," Louis B. Wright shrewdly observes in his excellent new book, "Culture on the Moving Frontier."*--"Seventeenth -century English Puritans were convinced that they were God's saints destined to inherit this world and the next.

Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner estimated yesterday that inoculations with Salk vaccine had saved forty-two of the city's children from paralytic polio. This will be so, she predicted, if the vaccine proves effective in 70 per cent of inoculations.
Shipping by "thermos bottle" is becoming an important industrial activity. This is the technique by which such materials as sulphur and steel are transported in a hot, molten state.
Prices on the New York commodity exchanges generally rose yesterday. Volume was light in most markets, limited to evening of holdings for the week-end.
PARIS, June 3--A bill authorizing the President of France to ratify the conventions of Tunisian home rule was approved by the French Cabinet at its meeting tonight.
CLEVELAND, June 3 (AP)-- Mickey McDermott held Cleveland to three hits tonight as the Washington Senators beat the Indians, 3--1, on homers by Mickey Vernon and Roy Sievers.

An agreement was signed in Rome on May 23 that will transfer to Italy $50,000,000 worth of United States surplus cotton, wheat and tobacco. The accord also includes a provision for a substantial long-term loan for the development of depressed areas in southern Italy, Sardinia and Sicily.
Robert Moses declared yesterday that Brooklyn is "at the moment without adequate leadership in the great essentials which make a community outstanding."
WASHINGTON, June 3--The Defense. Department upheld its present and proposed security system in industry against heavy attacks today.
LONDON, June 3--Hugh Dalton, who was Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Labor Government, challenged the Labor party today to rejuvenate itself as a result of its election defeat.
LONDON, June 3--Leaders of Britain's striking railwaymen and dockworkers said today they saw no prospect of an early return to work.

MANCHESTER, England, June 3 (UP) -- Dons Hart and Louise Brough, the two topranked United States women advanced today to another of their many showdowns. They won semi-finals tests in the Northern Club lawn tennis tournament.

Immigration Commissioner J. M. Swing promised yesterday that his agency would not compel any Chinese student to interrupt his education in the United States unless his presence "endangers national security."

WASHINGTON, June 3-- For the first time in history, a President of the United States flew in a twin-engined aircraft. Until now Air Force and Secret Service regulations have required not fewer than four engines in a plane carrying the President.
Elia Kazan's recent eight-week visit to Southeast Europe may result in a production of a Greek classic on Broadway next season, possibly under the auspices of The Playwrights Company.
WASHINGTON, June 3--The general counsel of the Defense Department accused Communist China today of violating international law as well as the Korean armistice by detaining United States fliers.

TRIESTE, June 3--The full implications of the Tito-Khrushchev talks cannot yet be gauged. The Yugoslavs seem to have gone a long way toward harmonizing relationships with Russia. But they avoided ideological readjustments. And they maintain that their concepts of independence are unaltered.
ALBANY, June 3--State Controller Arthur Levitt presented evidence today that New York City was exerting more "tax effort" than cities or school districts upstate.

ROME, June 3--Excommunication of President Juan D. Peron of Argentina is believed under consideration by the Vatican. He has been repeatedly accused by the Vatican newspaper L'Ossevators Romano of "persecuting" the Roman Catholic Church.

The nation's seamen must correct any impression they find abroad that the United States is a militarist nation, Benjamin H. Namm told the graduating class of the State University of New York Maritime College yesterday.

THE PRESIDENT Vetoed a private bill granting permanent residence status to Kurt Glasser, a Czech national. Flew to Gettysburg, Pa., in a twin-engined plane. Received an antique lamp from officials of the United Jewish Appeal.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
RICHMOND, Va., June 3-- Southern Presbyterians voiced grave concern here today over what they described as a growing interest among churchgoers in the most "spectacular" aspects of faith healing.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 (AP) --The San Francisco Chronicle said today that it deliberately had violated an order by Federal Judge William C. Mathes forbidding reporters to talk with jurors in the Hugh J. Bryson case after they had returned their verdict.

LONDON, June 3--Three liners with 1,800 passengers for the United States and Canada were strikebound tonight in Liverpool. They are the Cunarders Ascania and Britannic and the Canadian Pacific's Empress of Australia.

The Peter Pan Handicap will be the main attraction at Belmont Park today. A field of eight 3-year-olds has been entered for the sixteenth running of the mile-and-an-eighth test, with the Cain Hoy Stable's Flying Fury having drawn the top weight of 121 pounds.

Driver Alone Is Ready The week-end travel season is here again, trailing like the tail of a tote a long streamer of anguish through the house. There is nothing new about it, even though the season, is new, for it has been held over, despite popular demand to the contrary, for many years.

KANSAS CITY, June 3 (UP)-- The Kansas City Athletics broke a seven-game home losing streak tonight on Bobby Shantz' fine clutch pitching and his brother Wilmer's seventh-inning homer that shaded the Boston Red Sox, 4--3.
WASHINGTON, June 3--The world supply of narcotics is so large that it is regarded as impossible to keep all of it put of the United States.

A justice who called for the return to "common sense" in the rearing of children sent three parents to jail yesterday for neglecting their offspring. He said he thought that action also might help curb juvenile delinquency.
Appellate Division justices took interrogatory potshots yesterday at the city's plan to develop Washington Square Southeast.
Paddy Young of Greenwich Village won a unanimous decision from Billy McNeece of Central Islip, L. I., in the tenronnd main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, which, dedicated its Medical Science Building Thursday, is soon to erect another building. This will be a fifteen-story residence for students. Bids for the $1,800,000 structure have been taken, a contract is to be let within the week, and ground will be broken the first week in July.

It has been emphasized more than once that while the Government, given time, may be able to reduce its huge surplus of farm products to manageable proportions, the problem would be pretty hopeless unless the major cause of the surplus --high, inflexible, price supports --was permanently removed.
Modern means of combating disease around the world will be reported and discussed at the annual Conference on Medical Missions opening in Atlantic City next Thursday.

MR. MICHEL, top hair stylist for Helena Rubinstein, has been defying convention since 1951 when he dealt the long bob a fatal clip with his "poodle cut." Now he is defying the elements by presenting two coiffures designed to withstand summer heat and sport.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (UP)-- Harding Peterson, a rookie pressed into service because of injuries to Pittsburgh's two regular catchers, singled home the winning run with the bases loaded in the ninth inning tonight as the Pirates edged the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7--6.

Parking was prohibited on the north side of East Ninety-second Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues late yesterday to facilitate the arrival and departure of guests at a golden wedding anniversary party.

BRANFORD, Conn., June 3 (AP)--Two Yale freshmen and two young women died early today after their convertible was in collision with a trailer truck on Route 1. The police said they were returning from a beach party in Pine Orchard.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)-- The Army announced today a reshuffle of generals that left in doubt the future of Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, hero and prisoner of the Communists in the Korean war.

A taxpayer site on the northwest corner of West 235th Street and Netherland Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been purchased by the 236th Street Riverdale Realty Corporation from Abe and Alice Spirer.

MONTAUK, L. I., June 3-- A good charter boat skipper must know where the various fish are available at an conditions of wind, tide or weather. While a bad guess may be excused by the mate, it does not enhance the skipper's reputation with his paying anglers.
Manhattan and Bronx members of the Knights of Columbus will contribute blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today at Aquinas Council, K. of C., 2165 Powel Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 3--Federal experts were confronted with another bit of puzzling information today in their study of poliomyelitis cases that developed after injections of Salk vaccine.
William King, a newsdealer forty years in the same spot, sold his last paper there yesterday. He was not happy about it, particularly as the old green boards of his stand came down.

To the screen Editor: Hollywood's most vulnerable point being its bank account, Britain's refusal to book recently produced American films overly embellished with gore and bloodshed may, in the long run, have a a salutary effect.

THE plastic laminates are generally recognized as an ideal finishing material, particularly for the home handyman. Their assortment of colors or natural-appearing wood graining, and slick, stain-proof surface give any project a perfect finish.

To the Art Editor! On the Saturday afternoon I went to the Metropolitan Museum to see the exhibition of Goya prints, drawings and paintings, it was a delightful 70 degrees outside; but it must have been close to 90 in the second floor galleries where the exhibition was being held.

How varied are the fabric designs that Americans wear? The patterns run into the millions; if these are multiplied by possible color combinations the number becomes astronomical. Patterns and colors are something that American textile manufacturers specialize in, since they hold the key of newness, which in turn is a basic factor in style changes.

The Pro Meritis Medal, the trucking: industry's highest award for heroism, has been awarded to two truck drivers who saved the lives of four men. Oscar O. Merritt of Whittier, Calif, and Winfred Moses of Denver, Colo., last week became the twenty-eighth and twentyninth recipients of the medal, which is offered by the American Trucking Associations.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, manager and captain of the United States Senate "Odd Sox," had only three other Senators today lined up to play with him against a National Press Club softball team tomorrow.
TOKYO, June 1--The prospect of a sharp increase in their income taxes here has led many Americans and other foreigners to consider leaving Japan this year.

A system of integrated planning is essential to the orderly growth of communities on Long Island, in the opinion of Howard J. Teas of Teas Steinbrenner, land planners.

WASHINGTON, June 4--A House Education, and Labor sub committee is making a deter mined attempt to write a com promise School construction toil acceptable to the full committee. The program involved in the bill has been the subject of weeks of controversy in the full committee.
CLEVELAND, June 4 (UP)-- The Washington Senators hit their high-water mark of the season in runs and hits today while crushing the Cleveland Indians, 14--5. with a barrage of eighteen safeties.

PHOENIX '55,'' the hit revue that -has been charming the customers at the downtown Phoenix Theatre, seems to have enchanted a moviemaker, too. Grant Leenhouts, a local independent producer, is negotiating with representatives of the musical and United Artists to film the revue here in its entirety.

CHATTANOOGA, TENN., June 4--Faced with the problems raised by the Supreme Court's decision on implementing its desegregation ruling, the South responded this week in obedience to regional pressures, following long-established patterns of reaction to the racial issue.

THERE is a new anthology around, TEN CENTURIES OF SPANISH POETRY, edited by Eleanor L. Turnbull (Johns Hopkins, $5), that I believe to be an extremely intelligent job. Ten centuries, just on the face of it, is a very long time, but Miss Turnbull, with the help of the late Pedro Salinas, has resisted clutter.
English antique furniture and decorations at the Plaza Art Galleries and garden and terrace furniture with decorative accessories at the Parke-Bernet Galleries take the auction spotlight this week.
NEW DELHI, India, June 4-- The first announcement that the four United States jet pilots were to be freed by Communist China was made in India by an Indian. That was no accident.
MEXICO CITY, May 24-- Technical assistance experts from the United Nations office here left Mexico this week to establish a Central American center of technological research in Guatemala.

Many women are aiding in furthering the success of the sixth annual Belmont Ball to be held Friday night, the eve of the running of the Belmont Stakes, at the Turf and Field Club, Belmont Park. Proceeds will be donated to the Maternity Center Association.

Arnold Holzer, builder of Bay Terrace, a cooperative apartment project in Bayside, Queens, yesterday announced the opening for sale of an additional group of 325 suites. The development is one of the largest of its hind in the East, and will house 3,700 families.

OF the nation's 2,500,000 college students, roughly 2,000,000 axe now engaged in--or testing the efficacy of--the ancient and only slightly less than honorable practice of cramming. To cram, according to Webster's, is "to press, force, or drive * * * one thing into another."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to comment upon the article on the power controversy in the Pacific Northwest, written by Lawrence E. Davies and appearing in your issue of May 22.

A combination of two agents can fight off the itchy rash of poison ivy even if it is applied to the skin eight hours after exposure, according to Drs. G. A. Cronk and D. E. Naumann (Syracuse University). A form of zirconium oxide and the antihistamine drug, phenyltoloxamine dihydrogen citrate, are combined.

WURTSBORO, N. Y., June 4 (AP)--Two cars collided on a rain-swept highway near here tonight, bringing death to a mother and her son. Mrs. Mildred Hyman, 31 years old, of 1826 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx, and her son, Jeffrey, 7, were killed in the accident oh Route 17.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 24 --A political and religious battle is raging in this little country over a parliamentary bill seeking to curb the privileges of Roman Catholic schools. The Government laid the bill before Parliament May 17.

VALERY LARBAUD'S work is representative of a type of poetry which flourished in the first decade of the twentieth century. It is poetry of voyage and adventure and experience in exotic lands. Baudelaire and Gide had both contributed, before the beginning of the century, to this poetic theme.

Is cigarette smoking a cause of lung cancer? Those who contend that it is rely largely on statistics that correlate the growing incidence of lung cancer with the steady increase of sales of cigarettes in the last few decades. Conservative physicians demand pathologic proof, that is, comparative microscopic studies of tissue taken from the lungs of smokers and non-smokers.

DETROIT, June 4 (AP)--Catcher Bob Wilson hit his first home run since opening day--a two-run drive over the left-field screen in the sixth inning--as the Detroit Tigers trimmed the Baltimore Orioles by 5--2 today.

LONDON, June 4--It just won't do to advertise for a husband on commercial television, when that service starts in Britain this autumn. You can't even advertise a marriage bureau, much less a marriageable individual.

Two co-owners of a Queens furniture store were charged with arson last night after a fire had broken out in their shop and spread to eight other stores. Their store--the Hillside Furniture Salesroom Corporation-- is at 172-27 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica. The blaze, which was spotted at 1:03 A. M. yesterday, was put out by the Fire Department in thirty minutes.

MORE and more it is evident that the major entertainment forms--the stage, motion pictures television, concert and the dance --are becoming increasingly interdependent, not rivals. Ironically, it is TV, the monster that was supposed to devour everything else, that is stimulating a new and potentially far-reaching unity in the family of the arts.

IF Cordelia Riley had not run away from home to go upriver in her father's steamboat, the song of the river witch, a lonesome ballad by an itinerant fiddler, would never have been sung. But Cordelia did run away from home, and thereby hangs this tale.

PARIS, June 4 (AP) -- The World Committee on Professional Boxing today made conciliatory gestures toward the National Boxing Association of the United States in an effort to prevent the withdrawal of the American group from the committee.

William Welling Corlett, a member of the New York law firm of Wise, Corlett Canfield, 122 East Forty-second Street, who was formerly General Solicitor for the United States Steel Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 25 East Eighty-third Street, after an illness of several months.

However, only onefifth of the engineers and firemen are N. U. R. members; 80 per cent, about 70,000, are in the Associated Society of Locomotive Engineers and Firemen.

LOS ANGELES, June 4--The paramount facts of California politics are that the state has the second largest bloc of electoral votes--thirty-two--and no substantial political organizations. These facts took on special significance this week as battle lines for the 1956 Presidential election were drawn closer.
Schwab House, a $10,000,000 apartment development at Riverside Drive and West Seventythird Street overlooking the Hudson River, has been sold by its builder to a syndicate of investors.

A LITTLE more than ten years ago the General Assembly of North Carolina passed the "Horn-Tootin Bill," which gave the North Carolina Symphony an annual subsidy of $2,000. The state soon found that this was a happy investment, and increased the size of the grant, Now it is $20,000 a year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- The fifth floor of the United Nations skyscraper -- a quiet area customarily reserved as a lounge for secretariat workers --burst with activity here today. The establishment of a Federal Board of Education whose members would be appointed by the President of the United States is proposed in the report of a study made at Teachers College, Columbia University. The main purposes of the agency would be to promote educational policies of general importance and value to all states, reduce inequalities of educational opportunity and stimulate educational growth and progress.

MORE than 600,000 American tourists are expected to be in Europe sometime during 1955; and half of them probably will travel by ship, at least in one direction. Seniors at Fordham University were urged yesterday to make their Christian education an integral part of their lives and to further the cause of social justice in the world. The Rev. Vincent J. Kearney, associate editor of America, the Jesuit weekly magazine, addressed 1,000 undergraduates at a baccalaureate mass on the Bronx campus.

The rapid expansion of the Liberian tramp fleet with former United States tonnage could undermine world shipping freight rates should the present boom charter market experience a reversal. ELLENVILLE, N. Y., June 4 --Scores of show people, usually sophisticated, found themselves stranded in this bucolic area this week because they listened to a country boy.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 4-- The elections throughout Sicily tomorrow will give the semi-autonomous island its regional Parliament for the next four years.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 (UP) --Ed Furgoi, the national open champion, carded a two-over-par 72 and Patty Berg a three-overwomen's-par 77 for the rest of the world to shoot at today in the National Golf Day competition.
KANSAS CITY, June 4 (UP)-- Power hitting by Norm Zauchin, Ted Williams and Jim Piersall beat the Kansas City Athletics, 5-1, today for Frank Sullivan and the Boston Red Sox.

FARGO, N. D., June 4--The Advisory Committee of the North Dakota Agricultural College began deliberations during the week on testimony presented during nine and a half days of hearings on ouster charges against four professors.
NEW DELHI, India, June 4 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru left here today for the Soviet Union. He will also make side journeys to about a half dozen other countries.

THE National Broadcasting Company has completed general plans for its lineup of television programs in the Tuesday evening 8-to-9hour next season. ONE thing that is becoming increasingly apparent in the continuing boom market is that retail and wholesale prices are not keeping pace with the rise in sales volume. WASHINGTON, June 4--The food industry is prepared to tell Congress that a price freeze in event of a national emergency would prove ineffective. The industry believes such controls would give rise to black markets, especially in perishable commodities.

PITTSBURGH, June 4--Rudy Minarcin, a rookie right-hander for the Cincinnati Redlegs, beat Pittsburgh, 6--0, with a onehitter today. Dale Long's single to right in the second inning was the lone safety off the 25-year-old hurler.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 4 (AP)-- An All-America swimming team doubly honoring Ford Konno and Yoshi Oyakawa, both of Ohio State, was made public today by the College Swimming Coaches Association of America.

PARIS, Juna 4--Tony Trabert of Cincinnati won the men's singles crown In the French Tennis Championships for the second year in a row today. He defeated Sven Davidson of Sweden, 2--6, 6--1, 6--4, 6--2.

CHICAGO, June 4--The strike of Local 833, United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., against the Kohler Company, plumbing manufacturers in Kohler, Wis., enters its fifteenth month tomorrow, despite an unusual Senate effort this week to settle it.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 4--The American Society for the Study of Sterility today approved artificial insemination as a "completely ethical, moral and desirable form of medical therapy."

Six teen-age boys were rounded up in near-by communities today and charged with the theft Thursday night of forty aerial bombs from the Neptune Fireworks Company here. The police said the bombs were dangerous. The boys had apparently set off ten of them without harm to themselves.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sunday, June 5--Twenty National battalions began the long-awaited offensive against the Hoa Hao religious army today.

LONDON, Sunday, June 5-- Bernard Cardinal Griffin, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, spoke today of his "concern" at the difficulties besetting young Roman Catholic immigrants into this country from Ireland.
TOKYO, June 4--Japan's Foreign Minister said today his country would refuse any Soviet request for Japanese neutrality made during the peace talks now under way in London.

A NEW miter guide has magnets instead of a slot to hold the saw blade in line. The guide provides two protractor adjustments for vertical as well as horizontal angles. This is the first time such a tool has been marketed for the home craftsman, according to the manufacturer.

JERUSALEM, May 15--Hundreds of workmen are converting a stony ridge in the Israeli sector of the city into the new home of the Hebrew University. The first building of the campus, Canada Hall, was opened last week.

THE joys of summer are tempered for many otherwise fearless folks by the knowledge that a small group of plants can make gardening, hiking, birdwatching rolling down hillsides and other warm-weather pleasures a kind of calculated risk.
RICHMOND, Va., June 4-- Warring factions within the Southern Presbyterian Church were called upon here today to "bury the hatchet."
The repatriation provision of the Soviet-Yugoslav declaration issued Thursday has aroused concern for the fate of anticommunist Russians living in Yugoslavia.
BERLIN, May 24--The Moscow radio, using "American" English, is filling the nightly gap after the American Forces Network (AFN) station in Berlin signs off.
The author of a widely discussed report on juvenile delinquency issued by Mayor Wagner three weeks ago calls himself a "leg man" for Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 4 --A court action that has attracted the attention of medical and hospital associations throughout the nation was in progress here last week.

To the Screen Editor: YOUR recent article on motion picture advertising has jolted some of my colleagues in the gentle art of drumbeating the movies! It impels me to unleash a few opinions, especially on Hal, Stebbins, who did the hatchet work for The Screen Producer's Journal and whom you quote with huzzahs! Mr. Stebbins fired a thundering salvo of criticism in our midst.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is reported that the United States is considering giving away some of its burdensome surpluses of wheat to Soviet Russia. This may be a wise and humane policy toward a foolish and inhumane adversary; but is not this a tacit acknowledgement of the failure that has befallen the American policy of interference with the price mechanism? Is it not the result of price-fixing and subsidization ?

A FRIEND of ours was asking, in a reminiscent mood, the other day what has happened to the oldtime movie gangster who was such a frequent and conspicuous character some few years back. What's become of those ruthless desperados, those tommy-gun Jupiters and Thors, who evoked such, a curious fascination?

The prescription for success in the proprietary drug business requires many more ingredients than a good product--the basic one. Many companies and individuals who have not recognized this fact--as well as the need for proper mixing of all the ingredients in such a prescription--have fallen by the wayside.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 4--Evacuation tests will be conducted in at least twelve cities r communities during the nationwide Civil Defense exercises scheduled for June 15 to 17.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Senate authorization of the Administration's $3,530,000,000 foreign aid program marks the first step along the road to one more year of overseas spending by the United States--speeding which many members of Congress would like to see ended, but which they know cannot be as long as communism remains a threat to the free world.
HANOVER, N. H., June 4-- Dartmouth College announced last week that two professors would seek evidence of the Cape Dorset Eskimo culture, said to be the most ancient in the Arctic.

BETHEL, Conn., June 4--This peaceful village, where Phineas T. Barnum, the master showman, was born, is having the jitters. It faces the prospect of being host to the biggest, noisiest, and doubtless one of the gayest conventions of volunteer firemen in Connecticut history, would appear to have some reason for concern, since Bethel is one of the smallest places ever to entertain the visiting firemen.

GARDENS that are inhabited by children surely should have a spot somewhere allotted to sunflowers. When the flowers open, it is interesting to watch, them follow the sun's orbit each day. At the end of summer each head with the striped seeds packed tightly in perfect rows is a study in functional design.
MOSCOW, June 4--A bold defense of jazz and a plea for freedom in the composing of light music appeared here this week in the official Soviet musical magazine.

A new model has teen opened by James D'Agostino in his Stonehurst Manor development in Tenafly, N. J. Designed by Harsen Johns, architects, the house is in ranch style and will be available to six exterior elevations.

BY now even the easily shocked have become blase about news stories detailing new instances of police corruption throughout the nation. Frequency has dulled the impact of these disclosures, and most of us view police scandals as a part of life in the United States.

THE original cast recording of Kurt Weill's Dreigroschenoper for many years was a collector's item. Then it was reissued on LP by Capitol, some years ago. Capitol let the disk run out. Now it can be obtained on a ten-inch London-Telefunken release.

Nance's Lad, the favorite, won the $31,50O Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. He clicked oft nine furlongs in a frisky 1:48 2/5 and scored with four-and-a-half lengths to spare. The mutuel: $4.90. The placing judges didn't have to do any peering at the finishline pictures.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 4--Horace Ashenfelter, the F. B. I. agent, long has been noted for his performances as a distance runner. Today, the former Perm State star completed a two-day long distance stint that should furnish a conversation piece in track circles for some time.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Hoover Commission believes the Government has opened too many uneconomical stores across the street from the tax-paying entrepreneur and that the time has come to close or lease many of them.
CAIRO, June 4 (UP)--Egypt warned today that if Israel attempted to seize the Gaza Strip it would mean a new war.

The Giants performed enough heroics at the Polo Grounds yesterday to win a ball game with comparative ease. Instead, they dropped their second straight to Stan Hack's Cubs in twelve innings, 9 to 8. Earlier, Willie Mays had finally broken the spell that Chicago pitching; had woven around him by cracking a homer.
A sudden increase in Puerto Rican migration to the United States mainland developed in the first quarter of 1955.
DETROIT, June 4--The Ford Motor Company rejected late this afternoon a proposal by the auto union for resolving their dispute by arbitration, if direct bargaining failed.

PARIS. THERE was a time when the Paris drama critic lookad forward to May as the end of the theatre season. Three summer months of idleness allowed him to get the theatre out of his system and brought him back to Paris a new man in September.

Several substantial companies are counting heavily on the ability of the fastest-growing member of the plastics family --polyethylene--to keep right on expanding its markets. They have poured millions of dollars into new polyethylene plants during the last year or so.

THE Rip Van Winkle Flyer will roll through the Catskills once more on Saturday, June 25. Loaded with rail fans, camera enthusiasts and just ordinary folk out for a oneday holiday, the special will leave Weehawken over the West Shore Railroad at 9 A. M., proceed to Kingston and then strike westward through the mountains on the tracks of the former Ulster Delaware to Oneonta, where there will be a ninety-minute layover.

NATIONAL ROSE WEEK --the second in United States history -- starts tomorrow. But it doesn't take an official proclamation by the governors of some twentyeight or so states to make gardeners, rose hobbyists or anyone with eyes aware of roses in June.

More than twenty art exhibitions, many of them final exhibitions of the season in the galleries, are opening this week. The outstanding event, perhaps, is the exhibition of sculpture, paintings and drawings by the much-discussed Alberto Giacometti at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue.
SOUTH COVENTRY, Conn., June 4--A dash of the Revolutionary War era was relived here today amid the green rolling pastures and woodlands where Nathan Hale began life 200 years ago.

TWO characters uncommon to American fiction fall in love in this novel. Be is 19, she 26, he is a callow youth, she wise for her years, he Nordic in appearance, she an American of Japanese descent. Both are beautiful people, with matching sensitive souls.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4--The power of the Soviet bloc is not waning, Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, asserted in Bucharest, Rumania, today.

WHEN a group of young vandals runs wild in a city park, smashing benches, scarring trees and ripping up the grass plots, headlines tell the story. Adult citizens, justifiably concerned, shake their heads and wonder what's to be done about such outbursts.

THERE is a limit to the amount of walking even the most ambitious tourist in Europe can do; and a limit, too, to the number of summer days when the weather is cool enough to encourage sightseers to spend prolonged periods traipsing about to get close-up views of monuments, or museums and their contents.

while talks are still proceeding in preparation for the Big Four conference at top levels the new masters of the Kremlin have started to display a new mobility and flexibility of policy which is already softening and shifting the fronts of the cold war.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 (AP)-- A high Roman Catholic Church source said today the Argentine Government apparently had cut off all financial subsidies to the church in advance of formal separation of church and state.
George Sutton of Nyack, N. Y., will depart tomorrow for the heart of Africa, where he will devote a year to studying earth tremors.

NEW roses usually don't just happen. By far the majority of new roses start from a seed formed as a result of cross-pollination by man. The rose hybridizer takes all of seven to ten years or painstaking work to produce a new rose variety.
A. sub-critical reactor may be used by New York University students this fall for laboratory experiments if the Atomic Energy Commission gives its approval.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- Admiral Arthur Radford will enter his second two-year term as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff with a reputation as the "tough guy" among American military leaders.

BOSTON, June 4 (UP)--The Greentree Stable's Maharajah defeated in three previous starts on grass, set a Suffolk Downs record of 2:31 3/5 for one and one-half miles today in winning the $28,350 John R. Macomber Memorial Turf Handicap.

TO Americans who hope that some day the United States Government will support the drama, the experience of the Arts Council of Great Britain is enviable if not conclusive. About thirty theatres and theatre organizations throughout Great Britain share in approximately u72,000 ($201,600) appropriated by Parliament.

GERTRUDE MACKENZIE was fed up with business luncheons and cocktail conferences and sales promotion in a New York advertising shop. So, late one spring eight years ago. she accompanied her friend Dorothy Mignault to open her vacation home at Goose Rocks Beach; and thus began her love affair with the State of Maine.
The job of innoculating New York children against paralytic polio continued yesterday despite the week-end school recess.

When, for the first time in three years, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, R. A. Butler, appeared in person last fall as that country's representative at the annual meeting of the International Bank and Fund, many persons were persuaded he had a major announcement to make.

Gibel Homes, a proposed development of fifty dwellings for one and two families, is under construction for fall occupancy at East Fifty-fourth Street, between Foster Avenue and Glenwood Road, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Abraham Gibel is the builder.

Long-term implications of an apparent yielding to union demands for income guarantees during lay - offs may worry economists, but last week the stock market appeared to be looking only at evidence of high auto production and high steel use.

KAOHIUNG, Formosa, May 27--Harold G. McConeghey, a tall Iowan whose Chinese is as impressive as his Midwestern twang, has devoted four years of his life here to the proposition that Americans should not take their allies for granted.

TO THE EDITOR: IN view of Stephen Potter's past services to Reviewmanship, one may forgive his unaccountable failure to acknowledge in his article ("The Art of Reviewmanshlp") the more recent work in this difficult field.

In the long and turbulent history of U. S. industry-labor relations, one of the most dramatic chapters has been written in the past eighteen years by the auto industry and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.
BOSTON. CULTURE - CONSCIOUS Boston has been sampling educational television for more than a month. There is a growing impression that the viewers like its taste.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 4 (UP) --Adios Harry, the favorite for the fourth consecutive time, won the $8,000 Huntington Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in 2:03. He scored by three and three-quarter lengths over Philip Scott.

To the Music Editor: IN the fall of 1952, while things were still anything but settled in Korea. I was flown from our Forty-fifth Division Headquarters near Ch'-ondo-ri, and was assigned to Tokyo, on temporary duty to illustrate a book on the division's history.
MEXICO CITY, May 27--Cotton, through a series of circumstances largely attributable to the United States, is taking a dominant position in the economies of Mexico and most of Central America.

HONG KONG, June 4--Communist China's release this week of four imprisoned United States fliers has been interpreted by the Indian diplomat V. K. Krishna Menon, who helped obtain their release, as a "first step" toward "relaxation of tension" in the Far East.
Three teen-agers were paroled by Magistrate John E. Prendergast in Youth Part of Bronx Court yesterday for hearing tomorrow on charges of unlawful assembly.

Thrift plans have become increasingly important to employe welfare planning in recent years. High wages, employment and corporate earnings have helped to promote this type of benefit program for workers.

Last week a group of 300 medical and health leaders from forty nations participated in what was undoubtedly not only one of the most unusual but profitable meetings ever held in public health. The nucleus of the group was the delegation and technical advisers returning from the recent Eighth World Health Assembly in Mexico City.

WEATHER reports have become as popular as any radio or television program, and the weather man is the target of much derision if every day is not sunny. Those who broadcast for weather services seem to feel called upon to name the day that is ahead as good or bad, as well as sunny or showery. Why they should do this is a mystery to their listeners who are also gardeners.
A variable mortgage plan whereby payments are governed by the borrower's income or the property's earnings is suggested by Saul Fromkes, president of the City Title Insurance Company of New York.

TOO much current criticism sees literature as a form of testimony rather than of talent, as something that explains far more than it enriches; as, in other words, education rather than culture. As intellectual deep-sea fishermen, many of our critics have all sorts of useful psychological and philosophical tackle and gear; what they seem to lack is a very vital artistic sense, a distinguished or even a decent command over words.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4--"The puppy is feeling so good it barks at the elephant," said a Soviet note to Yugoslavia at the height of the great Cominform struggle.

Some Turning Points this spring mark a turning point in European history, as has been hopefully suggested, will be known much more certainly a hundred years from now. Secretary Dulles saw great possibilities opening at the NATO meeting when Germany took her place alongside France at the council table.
HARTFORD, June 4 -- A bill legalizing bazaars and raffles in Connecticut, but limiting their operation to certain groups, has been approved by the General Assembly.

BRANCH RICKEY has always insisted that there never was a greater ballplayer than the George Sister of 1922. It's never easy to argue against a man as persuasive and knowledgeable as the Mahatma. In this instance it's almost impossible.
ZION NATIONAL PARK, Utah.--A jet-age innovation will ba on view for tourists this summer neat here, as a contrast to the immemorial and fantastic natural scenery of this mountainous parkland.

DETROIT, June 4.--The Ford Motor Company, now faced with a major labor crisis, has been setting new production and sales records. The Ford car is challenging Chevrolet as the world's best-selling car. The company's expansion and development plans appear to be preparing the way for the firm to make an even greater bid for the nation's auto business, possibly through a new car in the medium or upper medium price field.
MILWAUKEE, June 4 (AP)-- Michigan, the Big Ten titleholder, gained another track championship tonight in the thirtieth Central Collegiate Conference track and field meet. Two meet records were set.
Religious prejudice is more difficult to overcome than racial, the commission on religious organizations of the National Conference of Christians and Jews has found.
WINNERS in the Tenth Annual National High School Photographic Awards, just announced by Eastman Kodak Company, sponsor, total more than 250 high school students, who share the $5,000 prize money.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 4 --Light airs that floated all around the compass and a couple of rain squalls gave fifty starters in the New York Yacht Club's spring regatta an afternoon of exasperation today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 4 --The top award for excellence in athletics was presented to Godwin Ordway of Chevy Chase, Md., at the annual athletic review held in conjunction with June week festivities at the United States Military Academy today.
BOONTON, N. J., June 4 -- Robert J. Jacobson of Hollywood and Jules Gatesy of Shackamaxon gained the final of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship at The Knoll today.
FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., June 4 (AP)--The world's only pastel-tinted fort, where the WACS found a home in the Army, boast thirty barracks kitchens for cooking "a little something."

YOU may not care to fluff up a chair cushion and discover a Hognosed snake. Lizzards, turtles, Spadefoot toads and Congo eel salamanders may not appeal to you as much as a chipmunk or a chickadee. However, this story of faunal life on a half acre of Florida hammock is a unique and fascinating account of wild life in a natural setting.

Following are the texts of letter by Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, to Henry fa 2d, according to a dispatch from Detroit to The New York Times and a statement by John S. Bugas for the Ford company, as carried by The Associated Press:

MOUNT HOLYOKE--Awards The fellowship and scholarship funds of Mount Holyoke College (Mass.) have been increased by a $100,000 bequest. Five Mary Vance Young scholarships for study in either Italy or France have been awarded for the year 1955-56, from the gift of the late Miss Bertha Young of Asheville, N. C.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah. June 4 (AP)--A research specialist said today that live poliomyelitis virus had been found in samples of Cutter vaccine received from the Idaho State Health Department.

NORFOLK, Va., June 4--In a joint series of tests this month the Navy and Civil Aeronautics Administration will study the latest techniques in evacuating passengers from an aircraft that has crashed in the water.

CHARLES E. SKINNER Productions, Inc., which makes television, industrial and theatrical movies, has taken a four-year lease on the Westfilm Studio here in anticipation of expanding its TV activities. The company has contracted with Quaker Oats to make a series of twenty-six half-hour films titled "Sergeant Preston of the Yukon."

ONE of the standard complaints of visitors to New York is that there is so little art to see in the summer. Most galleries are closed and the museums lapse into a state of somnolence. But three of the recently opened exhibitions at the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art make this year quite exceptional.

TO THE EDITOR: EMILE CAILLIET'S "The Dawn of Personality," which was reviewed toy James A. Pike, is not "a painted canvas, with a daub here and daub there," as Dean Pike suggests. It is a lesson in severe logic, a coherent psychoanalysis of the formation of a "person."
IT was almost a year and a half ago that Martha Wright ended her career as Nellie Forbush, the Navy nurse in the Broadway musical hit, "South Pacific" after 1,047 performances.

TO THE EDITOR: "Can Morality Be Legislated?" (by John P. Roche and Milton M. Gordon, May 22) certainly answered in sane and logical fashion the popular doubts and questions concerning the chances of success for attempts to attain morality through law.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., May 25-- Of the seven nations that make specific claims to territory in the Antarctic, New Zealand has been the most dilatory in reinforcing its position by occupation.

THE title "Doing the Truth." taken from St. John's gospel, sums up the standpoint of that collection of existentialist literature (the Bible) which may still be regarded as the world's best. The truth in question is the truth which sets men free --not what is usually meant when this motto is placed over the entrances of science buildings.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 4 (Reuters)--The French high command in Indochina has asked shipping companies here to move 30,000 French troops from Vietnam to France in the next two months, shipping sources said today.

The greatest search for oil in history is taking place in virtually every section of the free world. With the aid of many scientific developments of recent years, areas with even remote possibilities of producing petroleum are now being thoroughly explored.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 4--Bill John's Dodger won the International Class race today in the Orienta Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound. A fleet of seventy-five sloops sailed in shifting airs.
Accommodations for 117 families will be available in three Westchester developments during the summer months.

The Office of Defense Mobilization, in its drive for 150,000,000 kilowatts of installed electric -generating capacity by the end of 1958, has come to the aid of two electric power companies in the last two weeks.

The Community Service Society of New York announced yesterday that it would begin a study of ways to speed assistance for persons with troubled minds. In its 106th annual report, the agency explained the reason for the study by remarking:

Every now and then Lady Luck smiles on Letters and a copy of a book deemed lost is found and resurrected in a new edition. So too here. Had it not been for the collecting hobby of Thomas W. Streeter of Morristown, N.J., specialist in Western Americana, the original Ridge story of Joaquin Murieta, first published in 1854, might never have been reprinted.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The United States, Britain and France have agreed on Geneva as the place and July 18 as the date they will propose to the Soviet Union for the opening of their heads-of-government conference.

DARIEN, Conn., June 4-Representatives of a Harlem church visited an estate here today and decided to go through with its purchase despite the objections of some residents. The objections so far have been voiced only in anonymous telephone calls to the pastor of the church and to the present owner of the property.

The Sochaux Football Club of France opens a six-game tour this afternoon when it opposes a German American League allstar soccer team at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. A New York State Cup final between the Lithuanians and Calabria will precede the feature.
PARIS, June 4--The next step toward the free exchange of currencies will be discussed this week in Paris.
As a justice in the Children's Court, Justine Wise Polier daily reviews the wreckage of broken homes and tries to deal with the damage in the best interests of society as well as of the individual.

CHICAGO, June 4 Steady Eddie Lopat, sometimes called "The Junkman" because of his assortment of slow, slower and still slower deliveries, pitched the Yankees to a 4-3 victory over the White Sox today. The 36-year-old southpaw--he'll be 37 June 21--did not go all the way in the contest before 19,899 fans at sun-baked Comiskey Park.
Merchant marine industry spokesmen yesterday urged a Senate Subcommittee on Appropriations to approve the full budget requests made by President Eisenhower for maritime affairs.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 4-- The $13,000,000 Broadway Bridge will be opened late next summer as the third Missouri River crossing at Kansas City provided in three years. A barrier that for decades has slowed this city's northward expansion is being cleared.
ENTRY forms for the 1955 International Photographic Exhibition sponsored by the Photographic Society of America are now available through Arthur B. Falkson, chairman, 825 Summer Street, Boston 27.
Guy Lombardo said yesterday he would resume speed-boat racing. He will enter the Gold Cup fixture. This cup has been cornered in Seattle since 1950 by Stanley S. Sayres' fleet of Sio-mo-shuns.
VIENNA, June 4 (UP)--Austrians and Germans returning from Communist captivity said today there were "many" Americans in Soviet slave camps, including at least four United States airmen.

John H. Niemeyer of Temple University. Philadelphia, has been elected president of the Bank Street College of Education. For ten years Mr. Niemeyer has been headmaster of the Oak Lane Country Day School, the laboratory school of Temple.

JUNE is a wonderful month. To some it means roses, to some weddings and to others graduation or vacations. But to those who love the outdoors and the fresh clean smell of the woods, it is the season of laurel and rhododendron.

THOMAS MANN'S eighteith birthday--June 6--might suggest an aged Olympian gazing distantly upon the world from his Lake Zurich retreat. The picture, however, is not entirely accurate. Before meeting this writer, for example, the Nobel Prize winner had just delivered speeches on Schiller in Stuttgart and Weimar, negotiated possible film sales of "BuddenbrooKs" and "The Magic Mountain" in Goettingen and spoken on the North German radio.
LONDON, June 4--Britain's trade union movement traditionally is left to manage its own affairs to the fullest possible extent without Government interference.
NEW DELHI, India, June 4-- The Indian Government expects the eleven United States airmen held by Communist China to be freed within a month.

TO THE EDITOR: Few will disagree with Kenneth S. Davis thesis in "The Challenge to the Country Church" (May 22) that a valuable spiritual and social loss is suffered in the abandonment of charming rural churches.
MOSCOW, June 4 -- In its campaign to enlarge the area under cultivation, the Soviet regime is moving more quickly than ever before in its thirtyseven years of existence.

To the Screen Editor: It strikes me as a little odd that the British should be getting so terribly excited over brutality in American films. I have long thought that the British far outdid us on that score. During the late Forties a raft of films was produced in London that still stand as the last word on brutality in films.
TORONTO, June 4--Thursday's election will mark the first time Ontario's Indians have taken part in provincial voting. About 3,000,000 persons are eligible to vote.
Whatever else happens in Detroit, the guaranteed annual wage --or a reasonably accurate facsimile thereof--appears to have become part of the American collective bargaining picture.

"MY poor husband!" wailed the young, blonde French actress Jacqueline Pagnol. "He's been so Dusy that he's completely exhausted." The anxiety of the dewy-eyed Mme. Pagnol was understandable as she listened to her husband's recital of his recent hectic activities.

DETROIT'S most successful failure is the description applied to the Chrysler Corporation's Airflow series cars of 1934-37, yet today the styling pattern rejected almost two decades ago is reflected in the smart lines of 1955 automobiles.

IN older homes, floors often become dry and shrink badly. This causes those unsightly cracks between hardwood strips or planks. To fill these openings, clean them thoroughly first with a blunt bladed putty knife and brush out the wider ones.
Nation-wide department store sales in the week ended May 28 were 10 per cent higher than in the comparable week of last year.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 4-- A record-equalling 68 carried Sam Snead into the lead of the Palm Beach round-robin tournament at the Deepdale Golf Club today. Snead, who has won this event with its unique system of scoring three times, gained 20 credits by dint of his 4-under-par golf.

A raid early yesterday on an unoccupied two-family dwelling in the Parkvilie section of Broklyn smashed the "biggest floating dice game in the city," according to the police. Thirty men with a total of $25,000 in their pockets were seized when the police broke down the front j door at 112 Beverly Road.

THE pooling of effort among neighbors for certain projects has been discussed previously in these columns, in terms of sharing tools and skills. There is yet another aspect that crops up, especially among neighbors in newer homes. This is the matter of joint or abutting interests.
SAIGON, June 4--Indications of more active fighting between the Government and Hoa Hao forces in southwest Cochin China increased today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 5 (UP)--Lieut, Joe Conrad was little known in national golf circles before his victory today in the British, amateur at St. Annes, England. But In Texas he was generally regarded as the state's top amateur.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 4-- A member of the Soviet Embassy here escaped to West Berlin in March but "voluntarily" went to Moscow two weeks ago, Mirza Sikander Ali Baig, Acting Foreign Secretary, disclosed today.

NEWARK, June 4 (AP)--A thunderstorm struck New Jersey unexpectedly tonight, causing two fatal auto accidents, forcing down two planes and felling power lines. Northeast winds, reaching forty-five miles an hour in some sections of the state, accompanied the heavy showers, which began early in the evening.

NEWS of the retirement of Albert M. Day after thirty-six years of Federal service seems strangely appropriate at this period when the philosophy of conservation is at so low an ebb in Administration circles in Washington.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP)--The United States motorist this year has been on the biggest spending binge in all automotive history.

EACH spring at rose-pruning time I sputter about what the winter has done in some gardens and what gardeners have done in others. But this year in northern New Jersey, despite a seemingly hard winter which killed back many more canes than usual, and despite uncertain or insufficient care by home gardeners, all types and varieties of roses have burst into astonishing bloom ten days ahead of schedule.
The Police Department explained, yesterday why two patrolmen had banned parking on an East Ninety-second Street block Friday for the benefit of guests arriving at a party.

MOST writers of guide books think it best to throw in a little history, and this Charles Duff does in his present volume. As a matter of fact, tie throws in a lot of history, leaving about one-third of his book for directions as to what to see, and how.

Holes and cracks in ceiling plaster are sometimes difficult to patch because the plaster has a tendency to drop or flow from large areas. One way of preventing this is to fill the hole, then place a piece of waxed paper, backed with a flat board, over the spot.
NORFOLK, Va., June 4--This city has announced plans for the annexation of forty-one square miles of territory in adjacent Princess Anne County.

IN November. 1936, the author of "Face of a Victim" found herself in a cell in the Solovetsk Monastery, on an island in the White Sea. Having become acclimated to the new place, she started tapping on the wall and soon established communication with her neighbors.

During July and August a group of eighteen psychologists, anthropologists and linguistic scientists will be at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque to plan the first phases of an investigation which will subsequently be carried out in the Southwest among various Indian and other cultures.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 4-- Senator Estes Kefauver said today he did not believe the nation's medical profession was "prepared for a thermonuclear war."
After a house, nothing seems to interest home-seeking families more than a cooperative apartment.

An artist, who was "discovered" in 1932, lost sight of after that and rediscovered only recently, is to have a retrospective show of her paintings. The exhibit opens Tuesday at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 15 East Fiftyseventh Street.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 4--On July 29 the annual East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Society Fair will be held again on the grounds of the Seventeenth Century Mulford Farm.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 (AP)--Seven records were set today in the thirty-seventh annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association track and field championships. Three teams retained their titles and two lost them.
TRENTON, June 4--The Legislature will reconvene on Monday and then recess until August after acting on some important measures and at least sixty minor bills.

In the address which he delivered at the dedicatory exercises of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center Adlai E. Stevenson effectively summarized the case "for making medical services better available to all who need them and without crippling cost to anyone."

A parking Infraction led to a wild police auto chase yesterday morning through the heart of Manhattan, including Central Park. Five shots were fired by a policeman before the fleeing driver was caught.

"THE LIBRARY," scheduled for late summer filming by Phoenix Productions, is a story that has accumulated quite a history since the idea for the drama first was discussed by Daniel Taradash and Elicit Moll in October, 1950.

LONDON. A TELEVISION Renaissance seems imminent on the Continent of Europe. While conferring the benefits of commercial competition, it may put singing commercials into a dozen languages and produce French, German and Italian versions of J. Fred Muggs, the breakfast-time chimpanzee.

EUROPE'S network of regularly scheduled international bus services will be expanded next year as a result of decisions just taken by Governments in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, with headquarters in Geneva.

June is the year at the altar, a bride with a bouquet of roses and forget-me-nots, veiled with morning mist and jeweled with dew, gowned with sunrise and romantic as a full moon. June is cornflower blue and day lily gold and white lace of daisies in the fields.
Baseball games and 500-mile automobile races are alike in one respect--they cannot be won without teamwork.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP)-- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives is expected to ask United States Ambassador James W. Riddleberger next week for an "onthe-spot" report on Yugoslavia's recent talks with the Soviet Union.

THE airlines, buying new airplanes for rapidly expanding operations, are having a tough time finding enough men to fly them. Personnel officials, who up to a couple of years ago could count on a bulging basket of pilot applications, are finding it necessary to go out looking for prospects.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves collected four circuit drives for their best single game home-run total of the year today as they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 11 to 3. It was the second victory in a row for the Braves over the local club.

IT would seem these days that the dictators of literary consumption (if not taste) have placed a disproportionate emphasis on plot. But, barring certain classics which were encountered later in school, which of us can remember a single plot from a single childhood book? It wasn't the plot which delighted us; it was vicarious experience-the campfires at evening as the cowboys trailed rustlers, the boat exploring a deserted island for trace of smugglers.
The Banking industry received greater attention from the lawmakers in Albany this year than last. A total of twenty-two banking bills became law this year, in contrast to only fifteen in 1954.
THE late Charles Ives is represented on a new disk from Overtone Records by Twenty-four Songs, performed by the soprano Helen Boatwright, with John Kirkpatrick at the piano.

BROADWAY Beat... That's the story behind the story of "Danton's Inferno," the autobiography of -- you guessed it--Dant Walker. Daily News (N.Y.) colyumist....He tells how he played piano as a boy in Pensacola, Fla., in a house that was not a home....

THE author of this rear-echelon novel of World War II served in the 99th Infantry Division and is now on the English faculty at Columbia. He tells the rather painful story of a lieutenant torn by guilt because he feels responsible for the death of one of his own friends, killed by an artillery barrage directed by the lieutenant.
VANCOUVER, B. C., May 20 --A tiny group of devoted clergymen and doctors has completed half a century of seagoing missionary work along the southern coast of British Columbia.

SINGAPORE. ON one of the opening days of the recent Asian-African Conference in Bandung, I was strolling along the sidewalk down one side of the Conference Hall--legitimately, since I was wearing a press badge and this section of the city was in bounds for journalists.

The first mass--a nuptial mass --was celebrated yesterday in the new Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Skies at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The Rev. Walter Missbach, chaplain of the Catholic Guild of International Airport, under whose auspices the chapel was built, was tha celebrant.
Thirty-five members of the Police Department, who performed acts of heroism in the line of duty, will be recognized with medals in a noon ceremony at City Hall tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Presidential campaign of 1956 is beginning to take form at the usual time--one year before the event itself. In some respects the emerging pattern resembles those that have preceded it since Cleveland's first election in 1884. In others there is deviation.

THIS is not another Everest story, nor la it primarily a mountaineering record. Rather it is the story of a man, a man who can neither read nor write but who is great in spirit and in mind and in comprehension of the many values which are found in the sharing of adventure and danger.

CONRAD RICHTER is the author of a number of interesting novels with mystical overtones. The present volume is an attempt to state explicitly the beliefs which underlie these novels--to sound, as it were, the fundamentals to which the overtones relate.
LONDON, June 4--The wave of strikes that is slowly strangling British commerce prevented the sailing today of the liner Mauretania for New York.

Leases of two units of space in the West Side Airlines Terminal rising at Forty-second Street and Tenth Avenue were announced yesterday by Irving Maidman and Floyd Del Brown, sponsors of the development.

THERE is growing realization today of the need for a more unified approach in the Western world to the republic of learning and the ideal of man. Confronted by an ideology hostile to our civilization, we are now creating common military, economic and to some extent political institutions within the Atlantic Community.

ALEO TEMPLETON AND HIS MUSIC BOXES: Comin' Through the Rye, The Last Rose of Summer, Stars and Stripes Forever, Toreador Song, Waltz from Faust, Anvil Chorus and others (Ficker). The pianist tells of his hobby and the rest of the disk records some of the boxes he has collected.
