MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (UP)--Hugh Stewart of Pasadena, Calif., used spectacular cannonball serves to win the men's singles crown in the northern tennis championships today. But Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., had to summon her entire court variety to nail down the women's title.
TOKYO, June 4--Japan's historic antipathy toward Russia remains unaffected by the opening of peace negotiations between the two countries.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 4-- Negro leaders of sixteen Southern and border states agreed today that Federal court suits should be filed against any local public school authorities who have not started racial desegregation programs by September.

TO THE EDITOR: Professors Roche and Gordon do a fine job of challenging the cliche that morality cannot be legislated. However, they begin with references to the Supreme Court desegregation decisions, but throughout the remainder of the article discuss the question in terms of legislative action.

LONDON, June 4--As the conferences of the heads of government and foreign ministers of the West and the Soviet Union approach it is apparent that preliminary meetings among the Atlantic powers to agree on a policy will be essential to success.

The public should be deeply concerned with what Congress is doing about the Weather Bureau appropriations for the fiscal year beginning July 1. Unfortunately, the record so far is distinctly poor--especially in view of what may happen this summer from hurricanes that hit us with insufficient advance warnings.

JEAN-ANTHELME BRILLAT-SAVARIN, lawyer, writer, violinist and the most celebrated of France's gastronomes, was born two hundred years ago, at Belley, in the district of Bugey, which is now in the Department of the Ain. His father, MarcAnthelme Brillat, a distinguished lawyer and procureur du roi, or king's counsel, had adopted the name of Savarin from an aunt.

TO THE EDITOR: Alarming, that's what! I mean the "Mailbag Diplomacy" article. It says that, "according to postal authorities" most of the "nearly 331 million personal letters" which Americans sent abroad last year "were written to friends and relatives of the thirty million Americans who are immigrants or children of immigrants."

WHILE surely a "Hollywood novel," "The Actor" falls completely outside the usual deadly pattern. The Industry (to use the Southern California term and orthography) serves as a colorful, interesting and authentically drawn background; but the story is concerned, as a proper novel must be, not with institutions but with people.
Almost any railroad stock is a good buy these days. Wall Street has been saying for some months. Judging by the rail stock averages, investors have been taking the seers at their word.

THE United Nations will issue 3-cent, 4c, and 8c stamps on October 24 to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the day the United Nations Charter came into force. The World Organization's Postal Administration will release on the same date a commemorative souvenir sheet comprised of the same three values.

THE hose is considered well nigh indispensable in order to water the garden. In recent years the functions of this tool have been multiplied by the invention of nozzle attachments for spraying and fertilizing plants.
ITHACA, N. Y., June 4--Cornell University's historic dynamo will be turned on once more next Saturday.
ROME. WHEN Charles F. McKim, champion neo - classic architect in the 1890's, planned the American Academy in Rome, he was inspired by an end-of-century nostalgia for other, more classical times.

HERE comes summer, here come vacations. Here come millions of children let out of school. Some of them bear with them lists of recommended summer reading. A few will actually read all those excellent books, and even enjoy them-- at least.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 4--The development of interstate compacts to pool graduate and professional training resources has become a major innovation in education.
Transitional cotton dresses continue to dominate retail ordering activity, resident buying offices report.

During each day of the first seven years of its existence the Military Air Transport Service (M. A. T. S.) has airlifted an average of 1,200 passengers and 200 tons of cargo. This information was disclosed last week by Lieut, Gen. Joseph Smith, the commander of the world-wide transport service, which celebrated its seventh anniversary on Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4-- A program to intensify and expand cargo solicitation for the Port of San Francisco was announced this week. The Board of State Harbor Commissioners, which operates the port, also announced a multi-million dollar long-range modernization program to be pursued as the funds become available.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- American aid to displaced persons in the post-war period was stressed tonight as a contribution to the security and welfare of the United States.

France has just made one of her most important political and diplomatic moves to date in the relationship with the newly independent state of Vietnam. General Paul Ely, who served with distinction in the dual role of Commissioner General and Commander in Chief of the armed forces, has resigned his positions and left for Paris.

REMINISCENT of diaries written in the middle years of the nineteenth century by women arduously making a covered-wagon trip across the vast American continent, this brave and charming book comes from the wife of a modern pioneer.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Fast-growing annuals and perennials need staking so that they will not topple in the least bit of rain. Delphinium spikes are best tied to inch-square, four or six foot stakes; columbine can be slipped through the neck of a metal support. Twigs will prop up double-flowered petunias so they don't get either dusty or muddy.

This country faces a severe shortage of engineers and technically trained personnel. The critical ture of the shortage was emphasized last week by Allen W. Dulles, rector of the Central Intelligence Agency. Speaking before the Alumni Federation of Columbia University, Mr. Dulles said that in the decade from 1950 to 1960, the Soviet Union would graduate 1,200,000 scientists and engineers, compared to 900,000 in the United States.
The Soviet Army, quite possibly its political commissar system and some of its leaders appear to be involved in the continuing struggle for power in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON. "I BELIEVE it is perfectly legitimate for us to talk to the Chicoms about stopping firing," declared President Eisenhower at a recent press conference--thereby puzzling a lot of Americans who don't know what "Chicoms" are.
Two of the three members of the reorganized Transit Authority were named yesterday.
LUXEMBOURG, June 3--Opposition to the completion of the economic union between Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg has almost disappeared in private industry and agriculture.

THERE is a lot of activity in White Plains, N. Y., this week, for the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., are busy organizing their first All-State Flower Show, The gala event will open June 16 in the County Center and continue through June 19.

NEW DELHI, India, June 4 (AP)--An ambitious program to make India a major steel producer is pitting private industry against promoters of nationalization, Western capitalism against Russian communism.
In Guelph, Ont., the raffle prize of the local Lions Club-- a year's supply of ice--was won by the wife of the town's electric refrigerator dealer.

THIS spring the weather has not been cooperative. Rainy week-ends and cool, cloudy spells have delayed maintenance work and made a shambles of orderly planting schedules. Now, with June really here, more than one garden still has bare patches where seeds would have been planted except for lack of time and proper soil conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP)-- Dave Beck, head of the Teamsters Union, A. F. L., said today he planned to combine forces with the two rival East and ulf Coast longshoremen's unions. He is mapping a giant organizing drive, mainly in the South.
LONDON, June 4--Clement R. Attlee assured the Labor party today that although it had lost the battle of the general election it had not lost the campaign.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- Joseph Campbell, Controller General, has ruled that two retired generals hired by the Immigration Service as $50-a-day consultants have been overpaid.
WASHINGTON, June 5 --A notable term of the Supreme Court is scheduled to end tomorrow. Opinions are expected in ten cases, several of which involve issues of outstanding national interest.
The 102d Engineer Combat Battalion of the New York National Guard honored yesterday three men who had risen through the ranks to become commanding officers.
Five of the six panel members of the New York Times Youth Forum admitted yesterday that they did not normally eat breakfast.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The Hoover Commission divided today in recommending that foreign aid continue as essential to free-world security.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Americans for Democratic Action asserted today that the Democratic leadership in Congress was "affably acquiescing in the Republican assault upon liberalism."
PARIS, June 5--In his first evangelistic effort in France, Billy Graham persuaded 451 Parisians to dedicate themselves to Christ.
IN its current preoccupation with the pay-as-you-see issue, television seems to have forgotten last year's subject of debate: color TV. How does it look now?

In tone of voice, Ralph Epstein's "How to Invest Your Money"* is almost perfect for the present moment. Throughout its clearly written length it emphasizes the risks of common stocks. It whips up no enthusiasm, discovers no one-way streets.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (UP) --Two home runs by Eddie Mathews, another by Johnny Logan, and one-hit relief pitching by Ernie Johnson for six and two-thirds innings gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today in the first game of a double-header.

The Sochaux Football Club of France made its first New York appearance a winning one yesterday. The team from the Franche-Comte region turned in a fine performance as it beat an all-star soccer squad from the German-American League, 4--1, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

LONDON, June 5--To say that the stock markets falsified predictions is but to express mildly what actually happened in the last week. The excited rise that occurred as the result of the election was expected to fade away under the influence of the railway strike when business was resumed after the Whitsuntide holiday.
The physical task of converting the congested intersection of Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street into a model traffic corner was completed yesterday.

Obviously, the Soviet Union will roll out the reddest of red carpets for Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru when he makes the official visit upon which he has now embarked. India can play an important role in world affairs, and the Kremlin is conscious of that fact.

BABY turkeys weighing only about six pounds arc a new ucculent specialty of Candlewood Farms of Connecticut. The mall - family - size birds are neaty and have a juiciness often acking in bigger, older specinens. They differ from Beltsilles of the same weight in that hey are younger--real babies.
GROUP exhibitions in art galleries, some of them seasonal finals and others to extend into the summer, include work by both European and American artists, mostly in contemporary veins.

The Western Powers are now preparing a formal invitation to the Soviets to join them in a Big Power conference at the heads-of-government level in Geneva starting July 18. The Soviets have already accepted the idea of such a conference, proposed by the West immediately after the implementation of the Paris pacts, but they must still agree to the place and time.
The Rev. Terence J. Finlay will become rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, on Oct. 1.
General Matthew B. Ridgway praised yesterday our military service programs for training young Americans to be good citizens.

ALTHOUGH the United States has fought four foreign wars during the last ninety years most Americans remain faithful to the Civil War. Without a rival, it remains their favorite. They feel more strongly about it. They know more about it. And they read more books about it than about any other subject except prepackaged panaceas for happiness and success.

CHICAGO, June 5--The declining trend in wheat prices was halted temporarily after the announcement of the Galvin June Crop Report, estimating the winter wheat crop at 631,000,000 bushels. This would be a drop of about 21,000,000 bushels from May 1, whereas the general expectation had been for a yield estimate considerably larger than the forecast of a month ago.
The city's usual activities will come to an abrupt halt for ten minutes on June 15 when New York takes part in a nationwide air raid exercise. The alert will be sounded at 12:05 P. M.

Pan American World Airways will seek permission from the Civil Aeronautics Board to establish a service pattern of flights between New York and Miami, Fla. Such service, the airline asserts, would benefit 177,000 air travelers each year to Europe or South America.
An adventure program depicting exploits and accomplishments of the Navy will make its debut over the Columbia Broadcasting System, television network in the fall.

PITTSBURGH, June 5--When final figures are in, they will show that May steel output exceeded 10,000,000 tons. This will be the first time since early 1953 that the 10,000,000-ton mark has been passed.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 6 --Sam Snead, who at the age of 43 is considered a member of golfs "old guard," scored a stunning victory in the Palm Beach round-robin tournament today. The triumph was Sam's fourth in the event.

Critics of present-day Christianity were advised yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary, to re-examine the church of the first century carefully before recommending a return to its practices.
The Rev. John Walter Houck preached yesterday his thirtieth anniversary sermon as pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, 175th Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has sent a new appeal to Egypt and Israel asking them to refrain from committing any acts that would increase tension in the Middle East.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 5 (UP)--The fifty-second American Bowling Congress tournament, which opened in a snowstorm March 26, ended in 90-degree temperatures today.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 5-- A University of California faculty committee assailed today the Government's security-loyalty system for universities engaged in classified research. It termed the program a "needless" threat to academic freedom.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, accused Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, today of not being "candid with the American people" about United States air strength.
When blond, hazel-eyed Doris Louise Mehan went to high school she wanted to be a journalist.
The projected coordination of Communist economic planning from the Elbe to the Pacific poses difficult problems for the leaders of the Soviet bloc.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 5-- The annual spring regatta of the New York Yacht Club ended today with the silverware being wraped up by Robert L. Hall's cutter Nimrod V in Class A and George R. Hinman's yawl Sagola in Class B.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 5--To provide employment for its ever growing population, Dutch industrial production by 1970 must be raised 40 per cent, and industrial exports by 35 per cent. In addition, investments totaling 5,000,000,000 guilders a year are needed so that production of goods and services can be increased by 13,000,000,000 guilders.

LONDON, June 5--Sir Anthony Eden warned Britain's striking railway workers tonight that "work must begin again." The Prime Minister in a national broadcast on the "disastrous" situation arising from the strike, made what was probably the Government's last appeal for resumption of negotiations.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 5 -- President Eisenhower returned to the United States Military Academy today for the fortieth reunion of "the class the stars fell on"--the Class of '15. Accompanied by Mrs. Eisenhower, the President flew from Washington in his four-engine Constellation, the Columbine, and motored the sixteen miles from Stewart Air Force Base along roads lined by cheering crowds.

East German Communist leader Walter Ulbricht's speech last weekend throws more light, on the extent to which the Communist world, through the Warsaw Treaty, attempts to build up a counterpart and counterweight to the North Atlantic Alliance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 --The British Board of Film Censors has seconded the decision of the Production Code Administration in demanding elimination of Gwen Verdon's dance sequence from "Gentlemen Marry Brunettes," a forthcoming United Artists release.
A chairman for the new Transit Authority will be chosen tomorrow or Wednesday.
LONDON, June 5--Hannibal's classic route of march across the Alps with thirty-seven battle -elephants has been retraced step by step by a distinguished British scholar.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) --Mrs. Perle Mesta, former Minister to Luxembourg, has established seven scholarships at American University here.
A record outlay of $127,250,000 for school construction and major improvements in 1956 was recommended yesterday by the Board of Education's committee on buildings and sites.

The church must revive an effective ministry to individuals if it is to have "wholeness of life," the Rev. John W. Pyle, canon pastor of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), said in his sermon yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The Yankees gained a split with the White Sox today. They did it the hard way, winning the nightcap, 3--2, on Billy Hunter's insidethe-park homer in the tenth inning. The Pale Hose took the opener, 5--3, behind Dick Donovan's five-hit pitching.
The American Civil Liberties Union has appealed to state governors to provide "full due process" in using confidential information from Federal Bureau of Investigation files.
CAIRO, June 5 (UP)--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt has proposed the creation of a demilitarized zone around the Gaza Strip to end border fighting.

The bond men who make a living buying and selling the bonded debt of local and state governments are putting the finishing touches to "The Daily Bond Crier," their annual effort at self-examination and reproof.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 5 --The Swiss Federal Council has sent a message to Parliament recommending the prolongation of the membership of Switzerland in the European Payments Union until June 30, 1956.

Thomas Mann, who celebrates his eightieth birthday today, has a new novel on Knopf's list for September. Titled "Confessions of Felix Krull," it id a continuation and expansion of a short story ("Felix Krull") published in English in 1936 in "Stories of Three Decades."
OLYMPIA, Wash., June 5 (AP) --Otho G. Bell, an American prisoner of war who chose to remain behind the Iron Curtain, wants to come home.
The typical American department store in 1954 sold the same amount of merchandise as it did the year before, but was unable to earn as much either before or after taxes.

Although Thomas Mann is 80 today he can scarcely be characterized as the conventional octogenarian. That his creative vigor is unimpaired the recent publication of his novel "Felix Krull" attests. And from Frederic Morton's interview with him in yesterday's Book Review we can see no lessening in spiritual and physical energy.
MOSCOW, June 5--The Soviet delegation that visited Yugoslavia returned today by air to Moscow.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 26 --The Republic of Indonesia, a land blessed with a multitude of natural resources, is plagued in the infancy of its national independence by a host of problems.

BOONTON, N. J., June 5--A victory that Robert J. Jacobson had been trying to achieve since 1934 finally came his way today. The 37-year-old player from the Hollywood G. C. turned in a sparkling exhibition at The Knoll to win the New Jersey State amateur golf championship.

Animal lovers at the Bronx Zoo wish city folk would learn not to do favors for fawns they think are lost in the woods outside the city. The latest instance of mistaken kindness has added a twoweek-old male deer to the zoo.

Whether or not a Ford strike is averted, it is clear that the contract negotiations between the company and the United Automobile Workers have added a new dimension to collective bargaining. Agreement has been reached on the principle that an employer has an obligation to provide financial protection for jobless workers beyond the limits of state unemployment insurance systems.
MOSCOW, June 5--The Soviet Union's biggest single tourist attraction, the All-Union Agricultural Exhibition, reopened for its second post-war season today.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 5 --Sam Snead, who celebrated his forty-third birthday on May 27, is one of the best known professional golfers in the world. He has also been one of the most successful in tournaments and exhibitions that have taken him to many parts of the golfing globe.
Slow business and a quickly bolstered dip in rates characterized the ship charter market last week.
A port practice often criticized by steamship passengers along "luxury liner row" will go into limbo under a new traffic control plan now in the making.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, confirmed tonight that live polio virus had been found in "one instance" in vaccine produced by the Cutter Laboratories in California.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Disarmament is likely to be the big topic of controversy with the Russians over the next few months.
The Giants were within one out of making their first appreciable gain in days at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Then Leo Durocher stepped in with a piece of strategy that went off at the wrong end.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- The Republican and Democratic National Chairmen argued today over whether the Republicans would win in 1956.

The best place for the juvenile delinquent to solve his problem is "under the glow of the sanctuary lamp," the Rev. John Cunningham said yesterday. He is Roman Catholic chaplain for the Employes Welfare Association of the New York City Department of Marine and Aviation.
Week-end motorists returning to this city late yesterday encountered jammed traffic on several key highways.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Judge Schweinhaut's decision directing the State Department to issue a passport to Prof. Otto Nathan may well become a landmark of the law.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Monday, June 6--Vietnamese National Army troops made quick progress yesterday in the first day of their clean-up drive against the Hoa Hao forces of Gen. Tran Van Soai.
David Sarnoff, chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, said yesterday that subscription television "would degrade and ultimately destroy the present system of television."
CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP)-- The Cleveland Indians, after losing three straight to the Washington Senators, bounced back in the second game of today's double-header for a 6-3 victory.
EDDIE STANKY, who chooses his words with precise circumspection, had a fanciful way of describing his blossoming into a manager.

Mayor wagner took off yesterday on a trip to seven foreign lands. He said he expected to bring back with him next month several ideas for the betterment of New York City and expressed special interest in England's vast projects in public housing.

After the "EI" Gone It is no longer possible to ride on the Third Avenue elevated, but on a summer's day one can still walk in its speckled shadow and wonder if strollers in future summers will miss the protection it gives from the sun.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 5 -- The Sicilians went to the polls in peace and quiet today to elect the third regional Parliament in their history.

A nation-wide program, to encourage secondary school youngsters to become scientists, engineers, physicians or other technical specialists was announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York.
An experimental plan to improve the "scandalous" living conditions at the New California Hotel, 226 West Twenty-seventh Street, was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The United Jewish Appeal announced today it had raised $31,196,000 in cash in the first five months of the year to meet urgent Jewish needs throughout the world.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5--A "letter of instruction" read from the pulpits of all Roman Catholic churches in this capital today threatened President Juan D. Peron, his Cabinet and Congress with excommunication.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Soviet drive for breaking up virgin lands in Kazakhstan by "volunteers" has by no means evoked such an enthusiasm among the Communist youth as the official Soviet propaganda is prone to proclaim.
A fireman commended for a rescue in December was credited with saving two more persons in a Brooklyn blaze yesterday. He is Henry Grimm, 39 years old, of Ladder Company 111.

Now that the British elections are over and the Eden Government has been returned to office with a fairly decisive majority, it is not surprising to find that the issue of sterling convertibility, muted for the past eight months, is coming back into the news.
Webb Knapp, Inc., the big realty development organization, has three more big projects on the fire.
MEMO: TO HOMEMAKERS (particularly those who find salesmen confusing).

Plans by Whitehouse Hardy for a large men's wearing apparel shop in Rockefeller Center have been announced with a lease of space in the British Empire Building at 620 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fiftieth Street.
The Dodgers yesterday lost their first game at Ebbets Field to a Western club this year. The Cardinals beat the Brooks in the opener of the double-header, 9--4, in ten innings.
National advertisers spent $594,120,000--the second highest amount on record--on newspaper space last year.

British sterling moved irregularly last week. At the outset it was buoyed by the favorable influence of the Conservatives' victory at the polls on the preceding Thursday and got up to $2.79 17/32, a gain of 3/32 cent over the long holiday (Friday to Tuesday).
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 5 -- The University of Notre Dame's 110th graduation was held today in the massive stadium of the Roman Catholic institution founded by French missionary priests.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) -- Ramon Mejias' ninth-inning single broke a tie and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 7-6 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs in the first game of today's doubleheader. However, the Redlegs :ame back behind the nine-hit pitching of Jackie Collum to win the nightcap, 5--1.
Five minutes a day in communing with the Holy Trinity was urged in a Trinity Sunday sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

TRIESTE, June 5--When, dusk settles over Trieste the fishing boats put out with flickering lanterns and lay their nets along the wide road of light leading over the Adriatic toward the moon. Nightingales chuckle in the escarpments rising above and behind the city and the air is perfumed by carefully tended banks of flowers.

As long as fifteenth century Gothic armor is heavy, noisy, expensive and inclined to rust, it is unlikely to replace chino slacks and the striped tee-shirt as favored summer playwear for boys. To judge, however, by the envious glances shot recently at a twentieth century "knight" thus attired, many a six or eight-year-old would gladly turn in even a coonskin cap for a suit of the steel-plate battle dress.
The nation's largest liner, the United States, will pass another milestone today when Miss Claude Riviere comes down the gangway at the end of a voyage from Europe.

The largest graduation class in the history of Brooklyn College marked its twenty-fifth commencement yesterday on the Quadrangle. The graduates totaled 2,268, including 1,783 who received baccalaureate degrees and 265 who got master degrees.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- Three Congress members, two Republicans and a Democrat, cautioned Americans today not to expect much--if any--easing of world tension in the proposed Big Four conference.
DETROIT, Monday, June 6-- Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., bargained throughout the night in an effort to avert a strike.
More subscribers flocked to the entertainment supplied by the Theatre Guild-American Theatre Society in eighteen road cities for the year ended May 31 than turned out for the preceding one.

The writer of the following letter, minority leader of New York City's Council, was a member of the executive committee of the Citizens Housing Council and vice president of the City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem.
Statistical evidence pointing to shortcomings in care as an important cause of infant deaths was presented yesterday. But "unavoidable disaster" was cited as an even more prevalent cause.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 5--Cornelius Shields' International Class racing sloop, Aileen, made her fourth start of the season today and won for the fourth time. The greenhulled yacht with the whitethatched skipper was first at every mark of the seven-and-aquarter mile course on Long Island Sound laid out by the Harrison Island Yacht Club race committee.

The twenty-one-story store and office building at 501 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-second Street, has been bought by Louis J. Glickman from Charles F. Noyes and others for cash over mortgages amounting to $2,900,000.

If Russia and her satellites want to raise the Iron Curtain shutting them off from the West, they will have to find some way to co-exist with bondholders and other sources of investment capital from the outside world.

PARIS, June 5--A general straightening of prices has been in progress here since the Government decided to use its authority to counterbalance the increased cost of bread by making various basic commodities cheaper.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP)--Cal Abrams rapped a two-run homer and a triple as the Baltimore Orioles snapped a seven-game losing streak by defeating the Detroit Tigers, 6--5, in the second game of a double header today.

United States exports to Soviet Russia and her East European satellites recently registered their first rise since 1950. This country's, imports from the bloc also are reaching the highest levels in years.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 5--Yugoslav official sources said today there was positively no chance that Yugoslavia would join the Soviet-led projects initiated at the Warsaw conference last month.

OSAKA, Japan, May 23--Japanese cotton textile leaders here in the country's spinning center express puzzlement at the determination of United States interests to raise tariffs on cotton goods from Japan.
GAZA, June 5--It has been an average day today here in the Gaza strip.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Congress is entering upon a period of quiet crisis over the legislative implications of the race segregation issue.
Prices of domestic cotton futures were mixed last week, but closed on a note of firmness.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $67,637,500,548. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes a follows: June 9--Discount bills.......$1,499,898,000

BERLIN, June 5 (UP)--Mayor Otto Suhr of West Berlin accused the East German Communists today of exerting political pressure on Berlin by refusing to abolish "unbearable" tolls on trucks supplying this isolated city from the West.
BOSTON, June 2 -- College graduates appear to be checking a trend toward race suicide.
RICHMOND, Va., June 5-- Presbyterians in this country can get along together musically, if not theologically.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, renewed today his proposal that Scott McLeod, State Department security chief, be stripped of his power to administer the Refugee Act.

JERUSALEM, June 6 -- A proposal that military forces be withdrawn from contact along the Egyptian-Israeli line will be discussed tomorrow by Premier Moshe Sharett and Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, chief of the United Nations truce staff.
The Queens Democratic organization decided yesterday that it would not consider T. Vincent Quinn for renomination as District Attorney -- but Mr. Quinn was not taking "No!" for an answer.

Chandler Harper of Portsmouth, Va., the 1950 professional Golfers Association champion, produced a pair of 67's for a 6 under par 134 at Washington yesterday to lead the nation's players shooting for places in the United States open golf championship scheduled at San Francisco June 16-18.

Dr. Charles F. Rank, newly elected vice president of the Board of Education, will serve as chairman of the board's finance and budget committee. He succeeds Vito F. Lanza, who, together with Dr. Rank, represents Queens on the school body.
TRENTON, June 6 -- A comprehensive interstate study of smoke and air pollution in the metropolitan New York area was assured tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold suggested today that member states might agree to hold a United Nations charter-review conference but not set a specific date for the parley.

MRS. MARIAN TRACY introduces her latest volume, "The Peasant Cookbook" (Hanover, 224 pp., $3.50), with the remark that "as existence becomes more complex there is an increasing tendency to the simple things of life."

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 6 (AP) -- Helen Caise, 16 years old, was accepted today for the summer term at Lafayette High School. She will be the first Negro in fifty-one years to enter a white school below college level in Kentucky.

An ownership of twenty years has been terminated by Mabel Jurgens in the sale of the six-story apartment house at 10 Cooper Street, in the Inwood section of Manhattan. The Goodman-Herman Company, real estate operators and investors, acquired the property for cash above mortgages of $251,000.

GIORDANO'S one-act opera "Mese Mariano" ("The Month of Mary") was presented last night by Erberto Landi at Carnegie Recital Hall. The event was billed as, and may well have been, the first performance in this country of the Giordano work.

As its name implies, the Maternity Center Association is concerned with "the safe and happy coming of America's new crop of babies each year." The work it does is so broad and stimulating, however, that its effects have been felt far beyond the borders of the United States.
CHICAGO, June 5 -- Corn futures sold at new low levels for the crop on scattered liquidation at the start today, but rallied quite sharply.
The United States, Great Britain and France should join in a demand that the difficulties between Israel and Egypt be mediated, State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said yesterday.
Employes of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will have an opportunity starting Sept. 1 to become stockholders of the company at no cost to themselves under a new thrift program.

Varig, the Brazilian airline, has completed its first -- flight -- a survey one -- from Rio de Janeiro to New York. One of its new airliners was at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday being prepared for the return trip to the Brazilian capital later in the week.
DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- Ford workers, impatient outside the River Rouge plant, greeted the compromise guaranteed wage plan today with shouts, screams and applause.
The pock-marked and torn-up condition of several of the city's streets caused some intensive official soul-searching yesterday at a City Hall top-level conference on traffic.
The Pelham Bay Little League is in danger of being shut out even before its baseball season starts.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Supreme Court decided today that the Government had wrongfully dismissed Dr. John Punnett Peters on loyalty grounds.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Colonial Airline, Inc., was the lead-off company today as a hearing opened on applications by fourteen airlines to serve additional cities between New York City and Miami, Fla.
There is a big gulf between theory and practice in teaching, Katherine Mary Sinclair has found.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Public Health Service cleared for immediate use tonight about a million doses of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine. This was the first release of vaccine in substantial quantity since May 15.

The first legislative proposal to be offered in Congress as a result of the recent stock market inquiry by the Senate Banking Committee has lately been introduced by Senator J. W. Fulbright. The purpose of the measure is to bring about equality of requirements in the way of disclosure as between certain securities traded in on the organized exchanges and those traded in on the over-the-counter markets.
ROME, June 6 -- The Vatican branded a new French book, "Les Cles de Saint Pierre" (The Keys of St. Peter), as "lewdly libelous" today.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will discontinue "The Morning Show" after July 1. Plans for a replacement are incomplete.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The State Department granted Dr. Otto Nathan today the passport he had applied for two and a half years age.

The cold war has taken a new turn. Instead of Soviet and American soldiers facing each other across the frontiers of East and West, the battle has moved to the fair grounds, with merchants and manufacturers the combatants.

A bilateral agreement is being negotiated at Washington under which an experimental atomic reactor program could be undertaken in Japan within six months, John Jay Hopkins, chairman of General Dynamics Corporation, reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- No ill effects of latent radiation have developed in the inhabitants of the Pacific islands that were in the path of atomic fall-out fifteen months ago, the United States reported today.

YONKERS, June 6 -- Sal Di Buono and David Molloy of Bonnie Briar fashioned a 63 to capture the best-ball honors in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-senior amateur competition at the Hudson River Country Club today.
An assistant fire marshal accused of having sold fire insurance as a sideline has been suspended and faces a departmental trial, the Fire Department disclosed yesterday.

ROME, June 6 -- The world's oil men convened here today. Texas wildcatters, Soviet state geologists, desert prospectors and about 3,000 other experts from forty-five nations rubbed elbows at the opening of the fourth World Petroleum Congress in Rome's City Hall.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 6 -Costa Riea s new internation-{ al airport, with a 6,600-foot run-{ way, was opened for traffic to-{ I day when the Lacsa Internation-! l al Airlines began a Convair-340{ service to ]V[iami, Fla. {

WHEN Dixie Walker was advanced from the Cardinals' Houston farm team to coach the St. Louis varsity under Eddie Stanky this spring, there were suspicions in some quarters that Dixie was being groomed to step into the top job when, as and if the rug would be yanked from under the Brat. It made a rather embarrassing and uncomfortable situation for the one-time Peepul's Cherce in Brooklyn.

The National Labor Relations Board and the Waterfront Commission are investigating charges of unfair labor practice filed by a Brooklyn truck operator. The cases involve the handling of coffee from piers in Brooklyn to the trucks.
BONN, Germany, June 6 -- Three of West Germany's most dedicated "Europeans" were nominated for high policy-making posts in the Federal Republic today.

DETROIT, June 6 -- If the Yankees are on the verge of consummating a deal to exchange a New York first baseman for a Detroit Tiger pitcher, that first baseman had better not be Eddie Robinson. The Texan today hammered two homers, each with a mate aboard, to lead the Bombers to a 7-5 victory over the Bengals at Briggs Stadium.

Space in the Chanin Building at 122 East Forty-second Street has been leased by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, for a consolidation of its executive headquarters staff.

That the Yiddish theatre, its literature and language may continue to live, fifty individuals, representing national trade unions and cultural organizations, have banded together and provided the resources for the re-establishment of the once renowned Yiddish Art Theatre.

The City Housing Authority found itself yesterday in the unexpected situation of hungering for tenants, although it had on hand more than 100,000 active applications for apartments in public housing projects.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Congress closed a loophole today in tax laws to prevent businesses from reaping an unintended windfall.

THE latest survey of the Canadian duck factory (the prairie provinces of Manitoba, Alberta and Saskatchewan) indicates that the duck crop this year will equal that of 1952, which was an outstanding year.

The Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company, announced last night that holders of more than 130,000 of its 136,744 shares of Series A 5 1/2 per cent preferred had tendered their certificates in exchange for new 6 per cent convertible preferred. The exchange offer expired yesterday.
A million and a half door-to-door sales persons are planning to give store-bound retailers a rough competitive battle for the consumer's dollar.

I agree wholeheartedly with Roger C. Walcott, who, in his letter of May 12, stresses the important influential effect which the glamorization of unhealthy attitudes has upon the encouragement of juvenile delinquency. Movie ads in particular seem to be sinking to lower and lower depths in this respect.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, June 6 -- With Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh in residence for the season, the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre here is bulging at the seams. Everybody from all over, including America, is trying to squeeze in at the same time.
Delegates of sixteen Latin-American nations reached agreement here last week on a system of coffee export quotas to stabilize the world market.

The 1955 award of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver was presented last night to Andrew Goodman, president of Bergdorf Goodman Company. The award is "for exceptional service to the needy tuberculous of all faiths."

Both the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers deserve the highest praise for having reached an agreement without a major strike. This is free American collective bargaining at its best -- without governmental interferences. The achievement is especially notable in view of the extraordinary gap between their positions when the bargaining began.
State Senator James F. Murray Jr. of New Jersey proposed last night his state acquire Ellis Island and turn it into a cultural and recreational center.

As a boy Jules Verne tried to run away from home for a life at sea, but was caught and punished by his father. It was then that he promised in the future to seek adventure only in his imagination. With his good friend Phileas Fogg he made a trip around the world in an unheard-of eighty days.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate approved more than $8,000,000,000 of general Government operating funds in less than three hours today.
MANILA, June 6 -- American culture, no stranger to the Philippines, made a special bow tonight with the first of five concerts by the Symphony of the Air, which is on tour in Asia.
OTTAWA, June 6 (UP) -- One of Canada's top Air Force officials was ordered demoted today for proposing in jest that the Army should be abolished so more money could be spent on the Air Force.

" The One Remains: A Report on Jerusalem," by Stewart Perowne, has been scheduled for Aug. 6 publication by Dutton. The author at present assisting the Anglican Bishop Jerusalem to build villages to house Arab refugees created by the partition of Palestine by the United Nations in 1949.

LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- Seaborn P. Collins Jr., national commander of the American Legion, attacked communism in a speech before Veterans of the British Empire Service League today. Then he drew a mild rebuke from Admiral Earl Mountbatten, the league's president.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Supreme Court in a 6 to 2 decision ruled that the wage and hour law applied to work on new construction designed for an interstate waterway.
A leading candy maker said yesterday that replacement of the "little store around the corner" by modern supermarkets was cutting this country's candy eating.

KOBE, Japan, May 22 -- Top Japanese business interests, concerned with the future economic stability of their country, are looking to Southeast Asia rather than Communist China as a permanent major outlet for Japan's products.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by First National Stores, Inc., in its fiscal year ended April 2.
A luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day, Nursery will be held on June 16 at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that thirty-seven of its sixty-eight plants across the country had been shut by strikes while the company and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., still were trying to agree on a new contract.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Following are the texts of the opinions in the Dr. John P. Peters case:

Ed Johnson of St. Ann's Academy in Manhattan, blanked Bishop Loughlin High of Brooklyn, 3 -- 0, on one hit yesterday to gain the Catholic Schools Athletic Association baseball championship. The contest was played at the Polo Grounds.
The abandoned Stagg Street police station in Brooklyn, where law breakers once were locked up overnight, will be converted into a youth center to combat juvenile delinquency.

Consumers Power Company announced plans yesterday for registering 100,000 shares of preferred stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company proposes to sell the issue through a negotiated underwriting by a group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., with the public offering to be made on or about July 21.

The New York Mercantile Exchange, plagued by sharp fluctuations in potato prices all year and now under investigation by the Commodity Exchange Authority, is confronted with a new problem. What should be done, if anything, to prevent defaulting on delivery commitments?

TOKYO, June 6 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama said today Japan would ask for the return of the Kurile Islands and the southern half of Sakhalin Island in the peace treaty negotiations with the Russians now being held in London.
Ford was the last of the big automobile companies to yield to unionization. But when it did, it went all the way.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 27 -- Indonesia's foreign policy of active neutralism is so firmly rooted in the experiences of her colonial past that there is little likelihood that the country will, in the foreseeable future, become a part of the free world bloc.
PARIS, June 6 -- An issue that is more than monetary will arise Thursday when European finance ministers meet here to discuss a new step toward the free exchange of one currency for another.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 6 -- Adlai E. Stevenson gave advice on how to be a wife and mother in addressing the graduating class of Smith College today.
LONDON, June 6 -- A four-point plan for speedy settlement of the railroad strike was evolved today at a six-hour meeting of the General Council of the Trades Union Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today ordered re-argument next fall of an appeal contesting the right of the armed forces to court-martial former service men for crimes committed while in service.

COLUMBIA, S. C., June 6 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that it would take "more than words and more than one meeting" of the Big Four Governments to create conditions in which this country could justify relaxing efforts to build strong international security policies.
Subscription television was described by a group of its oppotents yesterday as a system that would cost the average family $1,156 a year for the kind of programs now received free.

DETROIT, June 6 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., reached a historic three-year agreement today providing cash benefits for laid-off workers and other contract improvements.

It was a pleasure to read in The New York Times of May 30 of the splendid plan of the Florina Lasker Foundation for the establishment of an old people's recreation center in Central Park. There are several fine sites available for such a project in the park.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- Following is a transcript of a joint news conference held by John S. Bugas, vice president in charge of industrial relations of the Ford Motor Company and Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers C. I. O., today at the conclusion of the negotiations on a new contract between the company and the union:
For the June bride making her own lingerie, the Pfaff Sewing Institute has some suggestions on the sewing of synthetics.

NETWORK radio is showing signs of perking up. A new musical program, "The Woolworth Hour," made its debut on Sunday afternoon over the Columbia Broadcasting System (880 kilocycles in the New York area).
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6 -- Tension between the Government and university students continued unabated today despite a compromise accepted by other students groups.
" TREASURE your heirloom laces" is the battle cry of a gentle lady named Mary Albert Ellis. Mrs. Ellis deals in heirloom laces. Her despair is the woman who wants to rid herself of them.
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz sentenced a 16-year-old boy to the electric chair yesterday and used the occasion to criticize law enforcement agencies for failing to cope with juvenile delinquency.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- The Administration opposed a long-range airport construction program today even though it conceded that present airports were inadequate.
Jackie Robinson hit a ball deep into the lower left-field stands at Ebbets Field in the ninth inning last night to give the Dodgers a 5-4 victory over the Cardinals.
RICHMOND, Va., June 6 -- The Southern Presbyterian Church politely closed the door here today on further direct negotiations toward a merger with two sister communions.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration today urged Congress to put up more than a third of the money to create the International Finance Corporation, a sort of small loan agency for the free world.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon made two brief public appearances here yesterday. He presented an award for the George Washington Carver Memorial Institute and made a newsreel recording for the American Legion flag exhibit that will open in the Chrysler Building Thursday.

The Federal Maritime Board was asked yesterday for an operating-differential subsidy for four steamship services of States Marine Lines. This could result in the largest single private venture in the history of shipping.
The city's Division of Analysis is to be transferred immediately from the office of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame to the Division of Administration, headed by City Administrator Luther H. Gulick.
The New York Times of May 31 carries a short article on Panama stating that the C. I. O. "would undertake to organize the republic's labor on a nation-wide scale."

The guaranteed annual wage agreement reached yesterday between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., brought an expression of dissatisfaction from the National Association of Manufacturers.

European unionists, reared in the Socialist tradition, always wonder why United States labor is so enthusiastic about a competitive economic system. Yesterday's settlement at Ford should help supply the answer.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 6 -- President Eisenhower cautioned today against confusing name-calling and desk-pounding with leadership.

GENEVA, June 6 -- The sustained economic expansion of West Europe is endangered by resistance in many countries to increased imports of West European products, the Secretariat of the Economic Commission for Europe warned today.
SYRACUSE, June 6 -- Governor Harriman called today for greater management, control and planning of the nation's economy to meet "the fastest pace of change known in history."

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Bradley won the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. The performance was a satisfactory one for many in the crowd of 23,753, since the 5-year-old son of Bimelech was the favorite, returning $5.10 for $2.
DETROIT, June 6 -- Following are some of the important provisions in the new Ford agreement with the United Auto Workers, C. I. O. as summarized by the Ford company:

A quiet stock market livened up in the early afternoon yesterday on the news that the Ford Motor Company and union negotiators had reached an agreement. Motors, steels and some chemicals and metals pushed ahead and the market set new highs.

Fifty-six waiters passed the supreme test of serving slippery food successfully to their employers yesterday. The exercise opened the graduation ceremony for the waiters, who are completing a twenty-session course on the finer points of restaurant service. Although the meal was served in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, most of the waiters wore uniforms of their own places of employment.

May I enlist your interest in rescuing from oblivion the name of one of the world's great bridge builders? Of course the Brooklyn Bridge, one might say, is a monument to his memory -- but an anonymous monument. Few of the millions who see it and use it know that it was designed by John Roebling, that he supervised its construction until illness compelled him to watch progress with a spyglass from a Brooklyn roof.

Women's apparel buyers for the nation's stores began crowding into Seventh Avenue showrooms yesterday, amid predictions that the fall selling season would produce a significant increase in retail volume.
DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- A continuing rush to buy new cars is one of the results expected from the newest agreements between management and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.

LONDON, June 6 -- British Government securities weakened on the stock market here today with the growing seriousness of the rail and dock strikes. Losses between one-eighth and three-eighths of 1 per cent were general.
Awards were given last night to outstanding seniors of the Fordham University School of Education at senior class night.

The election of Mrs. Concetta C. Roy as president of the High School Teachers Association was announced yesterday. She succeeds Raymond F. Halloran, who will now serve as member ex officio of the association's executive committee.

Warren Furman of Pratt Institute advanced to the semifinals of the first metropolitan college tennis conference singles tournament yesterday. He beat Jerry Benyo of New York State Maritime College, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, at the Boulevard Gardens Courts, Woodside, Queens.
NEW HAVEN, June 6 (AP) -- Dr. John P. Peters was happy but disappointed tonight over a United States Supreme Court decision that wiped out a finding of "reasonable doubt" as to his loyalty.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- Basil O'Connor tried again today to persuade the Federal Government to issue a report on the controversial Salk poliomyelitis vaccine manufactured by Cutter Laboratories.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield opened today the new certified mail service as a regular part of postal operations.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 6 -- Bob Rosburg of San Francisco today led the metropolitan district qualifiers for the United States open golf championship. Rosburg posted a 36-hole score of 138, six under par.
HARPERS FERRY, W. Va., June 6 -- One of the country's oldest colleges for Negroes today became a casualty of the United States Supreme Court ruling on desegration.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 6 -- H. Bruce Palmer, president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, said here today that the business world "is looking for executive talent among the well-rounded liberal arts graduates, realizing that too frequently specialization tends to narrow human beings."
BOSTON, June 6 -- The election of Mrs. Gertrude W. Eiseman as president was announced today at the annual meeting of the Mother Church, The First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston.
KILCHBERG, Switzerland, June 6 (AP) -- Thomas Mann celebrated his eightieth birthday here today among his immediate family and closest friends.

Debate on the question of raising the minimum wage often seems to be guided by a complex of political considerations. Perhaps some of the economic considerations of minimum-wage fixing should also be kept in mind.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 6 -- U Nu, Premier of Burma, arrived here by plane this afternoon on state visit.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 6 -- A majority of cancer researchers, chest surgeons and pathologists believe that heavy cigarette smoking may lead to lung cancer, the American Cancer Society reported here today.

Because the age breakdown of the country's population is changing with the years, corresponding changes will be necessary in advertising media, the Advertising Federation of America was told yesterday in Chicago by Dallas W. Smythe, University of Illinois research professor.

Thirty-four members of the Police Department, and the family of one who died in the performance of duty, were honored yesterday at City Hall Plaza. Acting Mayor Abe Stark and Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams led the ceremonies.
DETROIT, June 6 (UP) -- The nation avoided a $35,000,000 daily reverse with settlement of the Ford dispute with the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today.
SINGAPORE, June 6 -- A taxicab driver testified here today that the police had ignored his repeated appeals to go to the aid of an American correspondent who was being beaten to death by a mob.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 6 -- The Christian Democrats easily won yesterday's Sicilian regional elections.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 27 -- One of the Netherlands' largest department stores is inviting its customers to "Discover America." The store is De Bijenkorf (Dutch for "beehive"). Shoppers in the Hague, Amsterdam and Rotterdam were startled recently when De Bijenkorf's three units were draped with stars-and-stripes bunting, the United States seal and pictures of New York City street signs.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6 -- Delegates representing ten Israeli international chambers of commerce urged the Government tonight to liberalize economic policies.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Senate today passed by voice vote and sent to the House a bill to continue the Small Business Administration another two years, with authority to make bigger and longer loans.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- A proposal to acquire the Sinclair group of eight coal companies was announced today by Otto Gressens, president of the Peabody Coal Company. If the plan goes through, Peabody will be second in the nation only to the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company.
BONN, Germany, June 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer resigned today as Foreign Minister to devote himself to the arming of the Federal Republic and the unification of Germany.

" The Bed," a multi-lingual, four-part romantic drama produced on the Continent, will have its local premiere today at the Plaza. Richard Todd, Martine Carol, Vittorio De Sica, Dawn Addams and Bernard Blier are among the principals in the romantic drama.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- Prof. I. I. Rabi, United States physicist, declared today that the atoms-for-peace conference to be held in Geneva in August "is already a success."

Rafael Merentino, 160 1/2, of Argentina, knocked out Hardy Smallwood, 157, Brooklyn, in 2:36 of the second round of the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The contest was scheduled for ten rounds.

HONG KONG, June 6 -- The Communist-led North Vietnamese regime declared today it was ready to open "consultations" next month on organizing the 1956 general elections for all Vietnam. The elections were agreed on at the Geneva conference last year.

The advertising fraternity was urged yesterday to include promotion for New York State in copy where feasible. The suggestion was made by Edward T. Dickinson, State Commissioner of Commerce, in an address to the Advertising Men's Post, 209, American Legion, at the group's weekly luncheon in the Lexington Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, majority leader, made today an unusual appeal to the House to end a dispute over racial segregation and pass a military reserve bill.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States will meet in New York June 16 and 17 to prepare for Big Four conferences of heads of government.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The country's railroads said today that failure of the Government to make permanent the temporary freight rate increases authorized three years ago could "bring financial disaster" to the entire industry.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 11 to 43 points (55 cents to $2.15 a bale) yesterday. The weakness was most pronounced in the far months.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -- Ed Mathews and George Crowe hit two-run homers tonight as the Milwaukee Braves took the finale of a five-game series, 5 -- 2, from the Philadelphia Phillies. Before the regularly scheduled contest, the Phillies wound up a suspended Sunday twin bill nightcap with a 4-2 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- In clearing the loyalty record of Dr. J. P. Peters of Yale a Supreme Court majority of seven today furnished an interesting reminder of the breadth of its assumption of judicial supremacy in our government system. It based its decision on an issue -- the jurisdiction of the President's Loyalty Review Board -- that was never raised by the lawyers on either side.
NORFOLK, Va. June 6 -- More than 3,000 midshipmen sailed from here today on eighteen warships for a two-months training cruise in the Atlantic and Caribbean areas.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration asked the Senate today for more money for intercontinental bombers and for emergency military research.
The rainbow shadings of cars on the roads today can be of real use, as two dauntless Brooklyn women can testfy
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 6 -- A Canadian health expert said today that it is "likely" that poliomyelitis will virtually disappear as a community problem.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Yonkers Committee for Peace lost in the Supreme Court today an attempt to compel the school board of that city to allow it the use of a school building for a peace rally.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 6 (UP) -- The Oklahoma State Board of Regents for Higher Education today opened the doors of all state colleges and universities to Negroes effective in September. The vote was 8 to 1.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 6 -- One of the last primeval forests in the East is to be saved from the forester's axe.

Having completed within a few short years the amazing task of leading Germany from defeat, subjugation, chaos and international ostracism to renewed sovereignty, prosperity and equal partnership with the Western Powers, Chancellor Adenauer has reorganized his Cabinet to free himself for the next big task ahead.

GENEVA, June 6 -- The United States employer delegates boycotted all the committees of the International Labor Conference today because Communist employer delegates were given seats in the committees.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- Bob Hope will be starred in a film adaptation of "King of Hearts."
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 7 -- West Point alumni got a preview today of Coach Red Blaik's plans for Amy's 1955 football team.

The Appellate Division denied a change of venue yesterday for Frank Santana, 17 years old. As a result, he will go on trial at 10 o'clock this morning before Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett and a special jury, on a first degree murder charge for the slaying of William Blankenship Jr., 15 years old.

So-called makeup injections of Salk polio vaccine were given to 725 children here yesterday. They had been absent during scheduled injection periods. Make-up clinics are scheduled to continue through this week.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of the American - British - French note delivered in Moscow today on the proposed Big-Four meeting:
Steel production dipped last week to the lowest level since the end of April, reflecting the Memorial Day holiday, but was expected to pick up this week.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Supreme Court sustained today the right of the Federal Power Commission to license the construction of a hydroelectric plant on the Deschutes River in Oregon.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Tuesday, June 7 -- Gen. Tran Van Soai was reported this morning to be attempting to rally his scattered and disorganized forces in a forested pocket north of Cantho. National Army troops were continuing their drive against the rebel Hoa Hao military chieftain.

Federal Judge Lawrence E. Walsh ruled yesterday that Mrs. Marion Bachrach, 56-year-old public relations director for the Communist party, is now well enough to stand trial for conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government.
An insect invasion calls for an insecticidal war, according to the American Cyanamid Company.

A vacant irregular plot of about 35,000 square feet at the northwest corner of Tenth Street and Forty-third Road in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Plasmetal Realty Corporation to the 43-05 Tenth Street Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Mr. Wilson was asked about a Hoover Commission report critical of the military research and development program. He said that "I don't think it is really fair to say we are lagging, "when, as he said, half of the scientists in the United States were working on military research and development.

The big splash Duke Snider made at bat last week poses a recurrent baseball question. Is the Duke of Flatbush ready at last to ascend the throne as king of diamonds? There's reason to believe his long-foreseen accession is at hand.
A 73-year-old Brooklyn widow was bilked out of $16,250 in savings by two strange women yesterday.
A double celebration was held in the Gold family apartment at 4038 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, last Sunday.
An issue of $21,000,000 of revenue bonds of the Dade County, Fla., Port Authority will be sold on June 16, Smith, Barney Co., financial adviser to the Authority, announced yesterday.

TENZING NORGAY, the Sherpa mountaineer who two years ago stood on the summit of Mount Everest while Sir Edmund Hillary took his photograph, "went up the mountain as a simple man, but he came down a hero." This brief summary of an adventurous life is made by James Ramsey Ullman in his introduction to Tenzing's autobiography, "Tiger of the Snows."*

The Inter-American Press Association voted at its annual General Assembly in Rio de Janeiro last October to celebrate June 7 as "Freedom of the Press Day." It was recommended that publishers in each country hold some appropriate ceremony on that day -- presuming they are free to do so.

Stockholders of New Haven Clock and Watch Company will be asked at a meeting on July 26 to approve a plan of recapitalization, it was announced yesterday by John J. Bergen, chairman, and Seymour Ziff, president. Directors of the company approved the plan yesterday.
Cardinal Spellman conferred degrees yesterday on eighty-four graduates of the Roman Catholic College of Mount Saint Vincent, Riverdale, during exercises in the campus auditorium.

The United States Public Health Service is being urged by some scientists to disclose all the facts concerning the Salk anti-polio vaccine made by the Cutter laboratories. These scientists believe that a full statement would clear up the confusion about the Cutter situation.
A $175,000 punitive libel award to Quentin Reynolds, writer, against Westbrook Pegler, columnist, and two Hearst corporations was unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York yesterday named Victor J. Herwitz as chairman of the speakers bureau. Mr. Herwitz is assistant corporation counsel in charge of general litigation for New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Congress completed action today on a compromise pay rise averaging 8 per cent for 500,000 postal workers. It was deemed certain to be approved by the President.

Children seem to be growing up faster than they used to. Child-development experts are not alone in this opinion -- they share it with parents who see their 12-year-old off to a formal dance or receive the news from her that she is going steady.
A new appraisal of French motion pictures by film men in this country is needed, a French movie official said yesterday.

Like many a tourist, Mayor Wagner did not find it easy on his first day of vacation to shake off the cares of office. One of his first comments on arriving in London was: "I'd like to hear from the Lord Mayor if he knows of any popular new taxes I can introduce." So travel may have broadened, but hasn't changed, the Mayor.
Ground was broken yesterday for a thirteen-story office building to be erected at 3325 Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles, Calif., by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (UP) -- Pennsylvania's inquiry into the Harold Johnson-Julio Mederos bout closed tonight after a police inspector testified he had a "suspicion" concerning the drugging of Johnson before the May 6 fight fiasco here.
Four public utilities offered new securities yesterday.

Thomas E. Rohan, chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, said yesterday that if Edmond FitzGerald, chief probation officer of Kings County Court, had any information of violations of the liquor laws he should send it to the authority for prosecution.
CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Labor and management must work in harmony if America is to win the cold war, David Sarnoff told the convention of the American Federation of Musicians today.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A new high for May employment was reached last month.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox today reacquired Jim Busby, an outfielder, in a three-for-one trade with the Washington Senators.
The Rivoli Trucking Corporation of Brooklyn returned yesterday to the practice of using regular longshore labor to load incoming coffee on its trucks, Maurice Graham, president, said last night.

The State Council of Parks announces the good news of the opening on June 18 of the new $2,000,000 Anthony Wayne recreation site, thirty-eight miles north of the George Washington Bridge and four miles west of Bear Mountain on the new Palisades Interstate Parkway.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 7 -- Louis Kaufman of Shore View and his son, Harry, won low gross honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's father-and-son tournament today.

LONDON, June 7 -- A Royal commission today rejected a capital gains tax for Britain. It also advised against the attempt to tax gambling profits. The absence of taxation in these two areas is the biggest difference in the United States and British tax systems as they apply to individuals.
OMAHA, Neb., June 7 (AP) -- Three Air Force jet fighter pilots, weary from two years' confinement in Chinese Communist prison camps, returned to their home folks today.
BONN, Germany, June 7 -- The Federal Cabinet will discuss tomorrow the Soviet invitation to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to visit Moscow.
Bids for $36,040,000 of short-term loan notes of the New York City Housing Authority will be opened at the Authority's office, 299 Broadway, at noon today.

DETROIT, June 7 -- The Ford Motor Company was hit by walkouts at seven plants today as officials of the corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., put the finishing touches on their agreement of yesterday.
Net income of the New York Central Railroad reached $4,784,142 last month and earnings for the first five months this year rose to $21,120,798, or $3.27 a share.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 7 -- Governor Harriman said today he hoped to know "by the end of the week" what the course of the state's future poliomyelitis vaccine program would be.

HARTFORD, June 7 -- The House of Representatives tonight approved a biennial general fund budget for the state totaling $298,488,219, an increase of $40,000,000 over the present budget expiring on June 30.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Eisenhower will be host tomorrow at a White House luncheon to discuss effectuating some of the Hoover Commission's 239 recommendations for changes in the Government's structure and functions.
Coffee prices fluctuated sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. called on Israel and Egypt today to cooperate "promptly" in United Nations efforts to restore peace in the Gaza area.
THE sultry American summer forces the hand of a home cook. It compels her to develop cool dishes that alert appetites even when, according to common claim, it is too hot to eat.
LONDON, June 7 -- Clement R. Attlee's retirement as leader of the Labor party before October was predicted tonight by his closest parliamentary associates.
OTTAWA, June 7 -- Canada expects defense costs to rise this year by $125,621,000, chiefly to strengthen the air defenses of North America.
A small-fry United Nations is operating in the West Eighties to encourage neighborly feelings among the many racial and religious groups living in the area.
The election of Mrs. Henry A. Loeb of 812 Park Avenue as president of the Council Child Development Center was announced yesterday.
ST. LAWRENCE ISLAND, Bering Sea, June 1 -- The visitor to an early warning site comes to the borderland of the fantastic and the frontier between the Communist empire and the free world.

GENEVA, June 7 -- The United States contingent at the International Labor Conference split openly today on the issue of letting Communist employer delegates sit in conference committees without votes.

The Administration in general and Mr. Dulles in particular are leaning over backward in their anxiety to curb what they suppose to be dangerous overoptimism on the part of the public in regard to the possible accomplishments of the Big Four meeting.
Record sales and higher earnings were attained by McKesson Robbins, Inc., in its fiscal year ended March 31.
DETROIT, June 7 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., agreed today to extend it contract with General Motors Corporation until midnight Sunday.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The United States, Britain and France will begin their combined staff work tomorrow for the meeting of the Big Four heads of government.

The degree of Doctor of Medicine was awarded yesterday to 116 graduates of New York Medical College. Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, at exercises in the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. The degree of Master of Medical Science was awarded to seven post-graduate students.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission examiner has ruled that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company must refund $36,380,665 to fifty gas utilities in Kansas, Indiana, Missouri, Ohio, Illinois and Michigan.

Charges of conduct unbecoming a member of the Fire Department and of conduct tending to bring reproach and discredit on the department will be preferred against Assistant Fire Marshal Irving Rothenberg of 219-35 Seventy-fifth Avenue, Bayside, Queens.
TELEVISION brought surgery into the living room with questionable effects once again last night. The program was "March of Medicine," presented over Channel 4.
ARMONK, N. Y., June 7 -- The International Business Machines Corporation announced today that it had contracted to buy a 432-acre estate at the head of Kensico Reservoir for ultimate business use.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Department of Agriculture charged the Winn Lovett Grocery Company and six officers today with attempting to depress the price of potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 -- The new Salk vaccine against polio is difficult to manufacture, and no batch can ever be proved to be 100 per cent safe before it is given to children.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- This country is in the midst of a booming economy without parallel in its history, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today.
Since the end of World War II ten years ago, the scheduled commercial airlines have flown the equivalent of 18,000 round trips to the moon, or five a day to outer space.

Universal-International and the National Broadcasting Company will combine forces to produce an hour and a half "spectacular" telecast on July 2. The show, utilizing facilities and stars of Universal. will have Steve Allen as master of ceremonies.

WHEN nominations closed for the Belmont Stakes, 118 horses had been named. If all started, the field would be slightly crowded. But all won't start in the turf classic at Beautiful Belmont on Saturday. It's almost embarrassing to have to report that there will probably be only four colts in the race.

" Porgy and Bess" is going to South America. Having distinguished itself abroad, the musical will begin a series of engagements over a four-month span, starting at the Teatro Municipal in Rio de Janeiro on July 4.
Fashion is just as important in selling apparel for infants, children and teen-agers as it is in selling to adults, buyers were told yesterday at a Kirby, Block Co. clinic.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- Federal District Judge Edward M. Curran today took under advisement a petition to reinstate John Stewart Service, ousted career diplomat, in his $11,000-a-year job on the basis of a new Supreme Court ruling.
The stone steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral burst into sudden and colorful blossom yesterday as the Outdoor Cleanliness Association staged its annual one-day flower mart on Fifth Avenue.
PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- Negotiations to set a wage pattern for 600,000 steel workers opened today. Both sides were hopeful for a quick and strike-free settlement.
What is the proper way to play "The Star-Spangled Banner?"
Six United States weight lifters, who will compete with eight teams in the Soviet Union, left here by plane yesterday. They were off to Helsinki after last-minute scurrying for Finnish visas.
Monday's total of donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was 270 pints of blood.
Max Baker in his letter to The Times of May 25 stated that he felt that murder movies should be banned. He said "They are the school for future criminals."
Mrs. Liza Granick, 82-year-old artist, presented one of her paintings yesterday to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and then said the experience had "added twenty years to my life."
TORONTO, June 7 -- Exhibitors from a number of countries have reported buoyant sales at the present Canadian International Trade Fair.

GENEVA, June 7 -- Six more countries signed tariff agreements with Japan here today. They are Denmark, Finland, Italy, Peru, Sweden and Uruguay. Canada signed yesterday and the United States will sign tomorrow.
ROME, June 7 -- Premier Mario Scelba's position paradoxically appears to be weakened rather than strengthened by the victory of his Christian Democratic party in the Sicilian elections.
