Eleven graduates of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion were ordained as rabbis last night. Five rabbis, alumni of the school, received honorary degrees as Doctors of Divinity.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Assistant Attorney General Stanley N. Barnes outlined today a coordinated antitrust campaign against the automotive industry. It ranges from giant General Motors to local dealer associations engaged in price-fixing.

A study of the twenty-one United States servicemen who elected to stay in Communist China after they had been taken prisoner in Korea will be published June 22 by Farrar, Straus Cudahy, entitled "21 Stayed." The author is Virginia Pasley, a reporter for Newsday, who traveled more than 15,000 miles, visiting and talking to families and friends of the servicemen.
Columbia University announced its intention yesterday of compiling, editing and publishing the complete writings of a celebrated alumnus, Alexander Hamilton.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- A prediction was made here today that a Government victory in the pend- the civil antitrust suit against the country's principal newspaper publishing and advertising groups would not bring about any major change in the advertising business.

The questions of how good is New York City's future and what is the nature of that future are of intense interest to all of us who live or do business here. Unfortunately, it has been hard to determine, because the city government did not pursue the facts, whether we were gaining or losing ground in some important respects.
Employes of the city's Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn ferry to Staten Island have voted to accept a 4.3 per cent wage increase.

The recent letter of Dr. Mary Stewart Goodwin recognizes that "the emotional impact of failure in reading is enormous and may be associated with profound behavior disturbances." She suggests that "the problem calls for a fresh attack, using the combined talents of educators, parents, psychologists, neurologists, ophthalmologists and pediatricians."

A damaged noodle slicer, three pairs of leg irons, sixty mateless shoes, slippers and sneakers and twenty-nine jars of "scented water from the River Jordan" were among items auctioned yesterday by the Post Office.

RYE, N. Y., June 7 -- The Department of Public Works of the state offered to this city today a $5,020,000 plan for relieving congestion on Boston Post Road. Burdened with 13,000 cars and trucks a day, the Post Road is one of the busiest suburban highways for combined local and express traffic.

Spring moves on apace; summer is coming. The lady of the house, in charge of supply and transportation, is looking ahead to school's end, to vacations -- in addition to anticipating the day-to-day physical and social needs of the household.

THE first comprehensive museum exhibition of sculpture, painting and drawing by Alberto Giacometti will open today to the public at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue. James Johnson Sweeney, director, has assembled forty-seven pieces of sculpture, twenty-four paintings and a score of drawings by this controversial sculptor, covering his production from 1925 to the present.
Fordham University will hold its 110th annual commencement exercises today at 4:30 P. M. on the Bronx campus. Cardinal Spellman will preside at the ceremony on the terrace of Keating Hall.
SCRATCH an ardent varmint hunter and you are virtually certain to draw blood from a thwarted ballistics expert.
The International Longshoremen's Association asked the Waterfront Commission yesterday to close the register of dock workers to bring jobs and men into closer balance.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, vice chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, in effect, repudiated today an A. D. A. attack on the Senate Democratic leadership.

The world record for four and a half furlongs was equaled yesterday by the Woodley Lane Farm's Reneged on the Widener Course at Belmont. This 2-year-old colt, a son of Revoked, covered the distance in 0:49 4/5. He carried 118 pounds.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox, tougher with Ted Williams in the line-up drove the rookie fireball pitcher Herb Score, from the mound in the first inning tonight and beat the Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 5.

This is the time of year when man's aquatic instincts come to the fore. The pull of surf or lake, the push of the hot summer sun have an almost overwhelming effect. This is as it should be, for this is the season for swimming, boating and fishing.

SINGAPORE, June 7 -- A police radio operator testified today that he had erroneously reported the place where Gene D. Symonds, United Press correspondent in Southeast Asia, was being fatally beaten by a mob. The testimony was offered on the second day of the coroner's inquiry.

Defense witnesses sought yesterday to disassociate Gus (Dolly) Wreiole, suspended hiring boss at the Leonardo Naval Base, from longshore union activity and kickbacks as his defense resumed in a Waterfront Commission hearing.
Stocks swept forward to new highs yesterday under the leadership of steels, rails, metals and airlines.
" Producers' Showcase," which has never done an original television play, will do one Aug. 22. Titled "The King and Mrs. Candle," the play will be a satire with music starring Cyril Ritchard.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 7 (AP) -- The Toledo Boxing Commission today suspended Johnny Lombardo of Mount Carmel, Pa., for life because he failed to show up for a weigh-in for a welterweight bout with Pat Lowry of Toledo.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -IIOB and some[ cattle offerings encountered declining] ,market today. Losses extended to as much[ :as 50 cents hundred pounds. BuusI ivealers and Iambs. however, moved higher.

The Soviet bid to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to go to Moscow caps a ten-year Soviet drive to avert or delay the reconstitution of German military power. Every known trick in the diplomatic bag has been used in this campaign.
Our enemies do not want war any more than we do, George F. Kennan, former chief of the State Department's planning division and former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, declared last night.

The Big Board a little more than three months away from being investigated at the hands of Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, and his colleagues, is doing a little investigating of its own.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The nation's business men expect industry to spend substantially more for plant and equipment in this and the next quarter than they did in the first three months of this year.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- The Soviet Union invited Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today to visit Moscow.

Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, was cited yesterday as a distinguished public servant for his part in preserving and restoring City Hall and the building of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
Misfortune smacked the Giants from all sides at the Polo Grounds last night, to the dismay of 23,457 fans who had braved a chilly evening.

Civil war in southern Vietnam is especially tragic at this time. The country must be put into administrative order to meet the test of a popular election one year hence that will, presumably, determine its future status. Every Vietnamese should be enlisted now to prepare for that critical test.
The jail sentence of William J. Keating, former counsel to the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division.

A three-story factory building at 394 Oakland Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the Continental Coffee, Inc., of Chicago from the Eastern Farms Products, Inc. The structure, containing 21,000 square feet of space, will be used for the processing of coffee and allied products. Don Lieberman was the broker in the transaction.

For the first time in thirteen games, the Dodgers failed to hit a home run. Johnny Podres made the omission seem quite incidental yesterday by shutting out the Redlegs, 4 -- 0, before 4,481 chilled customers at Ebbets Field.

AT 80, Andre Siegfried gives his recreations in the British Who's Who as "tennis, skating, swimming." These are ideal diversions at any age. Metaphorically speaking, they are also appropriate, since M. Siegfried has been batting the ball of international relations for fifty or sixty years. He swims around the planet with skill.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The American Nursing Association was put on record today as opposing the Bolton bill to create a Congressional joint commission on nursing services.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Harry Lev, millionaire and connoisseur of turtle steak, declared today that he was not "the biggest chiseler in the world."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers whistled a sharp warning to slow down the "one-big-union" express today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, June 8 -- The resistance to a National Army clean-up drive among the forces of Gen. Tran Van Soai, leader of the rebel Hoa Hao sect, crumbled further yesterday. A rebel battalion of several hundred men surrendered, bringing the number of Hoa Hao troops who have capitulated to more than 1,000.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 7 (AP) -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, playing in a drizzling rain today, shot a par 73 for the first-round lead in the Women's Eastern Golf Association amateur tournament.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 28 -- When this young republic won independence six years ago there were joined together 80,000,000 people living on more than 2,000 islands stretched over an expanse of sea as great in area as the United States.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 7 -- Dr. Charles Malik, Lebanon's Ambassador to the United States, said today that "one cannot sit back and relax in the deluded hope that peace, real peace, is humanly either certain or possible."

LONDON, June 7 -- Soviet and Japanese diplomats began here today discussions on "normalizing" the relations between the two countries and ending the technical state of war between them. Their previous meetings have been on questions of procedure.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's commencement address at the United States Military Academy yesterday recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A tiny instantaneous skin thermometer was shown here today. It was proclaimed as the forerunner of a body-temperature thermometer that would both take and register temperatures in writing in a matter of seconds.
Four new cases of non-paralytic poliomyelitis were reported in the metropolitan area yesterday, three in this city and one in Nassau County.
The Prison Association of New York urged yesterday that the state adopt more scientific methods for treatment of prison inmates, particularly juvenile delinquents.

PARIS, June 7 -- Ever since the signature of the Austrian state treaty, resulting from a visit to Moscow by the Austrian Chancellor, the French have expected a Soviet invitation to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer for a similar visit.
Establishment of special Sanitation Department service bureaus for the disposal of bulky litter was announced yesterday by Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain.
The Presbytery of New York voted yesterday to establish a minimum annual salary of $3,600 for all new ministers.

In discussing the transit woes that beset this city neither your editorials nor your correspondents indicate that the present fares contribute to this situation. Yet passenger transit like any other service or commodity has its point of diminishing returns.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7 -- The United Nations made public today the program for the first five days of its tenth anniversary commemorative meeting at San Francisco this month.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 5 -- Royal Dutch Airlines would like to buy part of the Government's 95 per cent share and dispose of it to private interests.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Republican baseball team ended tonight the Democrats' seven-year unbeaten string in the "world series" of Congress with a 12-4 triumph.

BECKENHAM, England, June 7 (UP) -- Tony Trabert, the newly crowned French tennis champion from Cincinnati, got only a light workout today in the Kent grass court tournament. He began his bid for the men's singles title with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over Australia's G. W. Radford.
VIENNA, June 7 -- The Austrian Parliament ratified the Austrian state treaty today and approved a resolution pledging Austria to neutrality.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 (UP) -- Marvin (Bud) Ward, a former national amateur champion, won the medal today in the race for twenty qualifying positions in the San Francisco district for the national open.

The twenty - two - story Lowenstein Building at 1430 Broadway has been sold by M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., to a syndicate formed by John J. Reynolds, real estate broker. The seller took back a long-term lease on ten floors.
DETROIT, June 7 -- A pitcher with patience is Ned Garver. The right-hander had not beaten the Yankees since Aug. 31, 1949.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- It was incredible, the reception organized for Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India when he arrived here today on an official visit.

The distributive industry must find more effective means to channel the growing output of American industry to the consumer, the new president of the National Association of Direct Selling Companies declared last night.
RICHMOND, Va., June 7 -- Despite the vigorous opposition of a strong and vocal minority, the Southern Presbyterian Church upheld today its year-old stand against racial segregation.
The first leg of the Sunshine State Parkway got its financial start yesterday in Wall Street.

United States Lines Company is studying future uses of atomic power on its ships, John M. Franklin, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. However, the company has no firm commitments and no definite plans at this time to build any atomic powered vessels, he said.

KANSAS CITY, June 7 (AP) -- The Washington Senators, finally solving Alex Kellner' southpaw delivery tonight, served a 3-2 ninth-inning victory over Kansas City in the first game of a twilight-night bill, then gained a 7-3 decision over Art Ceccarelli.

PARIS, June 7 -- Less than a month ago the armies of Ho Chi Minh occupied Haiphong, last island of North Vietnamese territory held by France and surrendered under the Geneva agreement. A United States officer who witnessed the take-over reported as follows: "The chill gray light in Haiphong on May 13 illuminates one hard and disquieting fact.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 7 -- The Douglas Aircraft Company announced tonight it had under construction a 500-mile - an - hour jet transport plane which would be ready for service by 1959.

In one of the most ancient and colorful rites of the Roman Catholic Church, Msgr. Edmund Joseph Reilly yesterday was consecrated a Bishop. The ceremony took place at Our Lady of Angels Church, Fourth Avenue and Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, of which he is pastor.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A sharply divided Congressional conference committee completed action today on a reciprocal trade bill The measure represents a clear-cut victory for "protectionist" forces in the Senate.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Richard Widmark has signed for the fall expedition to Mexico's jungles to film "Run For The Sun."
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate rejected the Eisenhower Administration's housing bill today and adopted instead a more liberal Democratic program.
LONDON, June 7 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of today's Soviet note to West Germany inviting Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to visit Moscow, as broadcast from Moscow tonight:

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7 (AP) -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk, described as a "humble scientist," was given a $10,000 check and gold medal by an insurance company today for his development of a polio vaccine was was advised:
PARIS, June 7 -- A member of the High Council of the French Union said here today he had proof of continuing slave traffic between French West Africa and Arabia.

LONDON, June 7 (UP) -- Brian Hewson, one of three men who ran a mile in less than four minutes in the same race May 28, today set an unofficial world record of 2 minutes 55.4 seconds for three-quarters of a mile during a meet at the Paddington track.
Following are editor comments by newspapers throughout the country on the contract agreement between the Ford Motor Company and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., as gathered by The New York Times:

There are good reasons for Italy and the whole democratic West to rejoice at the victory of the Christian Democrats in the Sicilian elections on Sunday. The final vote gave the Demo-Christians thirty-seven of the ninety seats in the regional Parliament.

BAYONNE, France, June 7 (AP) -- All charges have been dismissed against a group of priests and laymen accused of spiriting two Jewish boys across the Spanish border two years ago in an attempt to keep them Roman Catholics.
A one-year option, looking toward building a $100,000,000 "Palace of Progress" atop fifty-year-old Pennsylvania Station, was signed here yesterday in a railroad car.
LONDON, June 7 -- The business of governing Britain halted for an hour this afternoon when the new House of Commons elected its Speaker in dignified ritual.

A HEART with tender places is quickly touched in the children's wards in Bellevue Hospital. Sadness born of pain shows too readily in child faces. Minds curtained by injured or twisted brains betray a child more quickly than they do a grown-up.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today much could be achieved in the Big Four meetings this summer if the Russians came in a new "spirit of accomplishment."
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 7 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that a generation's effort might be needed to obtain the kind of world peace this country was seeking.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 7 -- One hundred and sixty-four players participated in the annual pro-amateur golf tournament staged at the Piping Rock Club as a benefit for the North Country Community Hospital today. Prominent leaders of the pro circuit had three partners in a best-ball handicap competition.
Cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices were unchanged to 3 points up on all months except the October, 1956, delivery, which declined 23 points.
LONDON, June 7 -- Proposals by the Trades Union Congress to end the national strike brought the first signs today of a break in the deadlock between the rival unions and management.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Merchant Marine Committee of the House of Representatives voted today for two nuclear-powered merchant ships. The Administration wants only one at this time -- the "peace ship" announced by President Eisenhower a few weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Dr. Leonard Scheele, the Surgeon General, told a national television audience tonight that the Salk anti-polio vaccine was as safe and effective as science could make it. He urged parents to consult their family physicians before having children inocculated.

The copy department and the research workers sometimes see things differently, and an agency's end-product suffers accordingly. This is a situation that gradually is being remedied by increased cooperation between the two branches.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- Senator W. Kerr Scott, Democrat of North Carolina, called today for a sharply expanded Government tobacco research program to help determine whether smoking caused lung cancer.

LONDON, June 7 -- Stock market prices rose today on increased buying induced by hope of settlement in the railway strike. Steel shares were especially strong. Government securities were helped by the recovery in sterling and most prices rose 2 1/2 to 7 1/2 shillings (35 cents to $1.05).
Allen Jong of City College gained the singles final in the fist Metropolitan Collegiate Tennis Conference tournament at the Boulevard Gardens Courts in Woodside, Queens, yesterday.
STANTON, Del., June 7 (AP) -- Willie Hartack went on a riding rampage at Delaware Park today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee today threw a major roadblock in the way of the controversial Dixon-Yates power project. It denied President Eisenhower's request for $6,500,000 in transmission line funds.

Television "dominance" by giant networks was attacked yesterday by Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures Corporation. At a stockholders meeting, he reaffirmed his support for "pay-as-you-see" TV entertainment.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill to raise the minimum wage from 75 cents an hour to $1.

James E. Davis, chairman of Winn Lovett, said yesterday that Winn Lovett had nothing to do with the alleged manipulation of potato futures. Potato Distributors, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary, did purchase potatoes for the group but had only a minor participation in the transaction, he said.
ST. LAWRENCE ISLAND, Bering Sea, June 1 -- Continental and Civil Defense begins on a frozen ridge, with a kid from Missouri hunched over a radar-scope. He is the sentry of the atomic age.

LONDON, June 7 -- The Soviet invitation to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to visit Moscow and establish diplomatic relations between West Germany and the Soviet Union is regarded here as the first major move in a campaign to win Germany's unity in neutrality.

The Supreme Court's refusal to rule on the constitutionality of the Loyalty Review Board's dismissal of Dr. John P. Peters does not alter the fact that Dr. Peters' constitutional rights have actually been reaffirmed. There is no doubt that the court would have invoked the Fifth Amendment if there had been no other way of reversing the action taken against Dr. Peters.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- With an informal cease-fire in effect, the best short-term approach to the Formosa problem may be to leave things pretty much as they are, Secretary of State Dulles suggested today.

RUSSEKS, long famous for its furs, has its own factory right on the premises. Complete with whirring sewing machines, a full complement of skilled workers and its own showrooms, the factory occupies the entire ninth floor. The store, its officials say, began life as a fur concern, and now not only produces fur garments for its own salon but sells them to other stores.
TRENTON, June 7 -- New Jersey has decided to ratify ten leases illegally negotiated in its behalf by the late Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

Personal income, which set an all-time record in March when it was reported at an annual rate of $294.6 billions, pushed a billion beyond that mark in April. The peak of personal income before the 1953-54 recession set in was reached in July of the former year at $287.5 billions.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- The Curtis Publishing Company announced today the sale of Country Gentleman-Better Farming magazine to Farm Journal, Inc. The purchaser will merge the magazine with its own publication, Farm Journal, in the September issue.
WASHINGTON, June 8--Senate investigators unfolded a tale of smoked sturgeon and chicken feathers today.

MOSCOW, June 8--Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov conducted a long and exhaustive review of world affairs today with India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, before leaving Moscow for meetings with Western statesmen.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Federal officials are considering the need for new legislation to require the Public Health Service to make sure its standards for drug products are adequate for mass production techniques.
Small department and specialty stores may lack the resources of their bigger competitors, but they believe they can take up for it by having a sharp eye for promotional opportunities.

A decline last week of 388,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 158,985,000 barrels, compared with 169,373,000 a week earlier and 173,735,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts. House Republican leader, predicted today a drastic cut in the public housing program pushed through the Senate by Democrats yesterday.

BECKENHAM, England, June 8 (UP)--Slippery courts proved a great leveler in the Kent grass courts lawn tennis championships today as Tony Trabert and Herbie Flam, the top-seeded Americans, were hard-pressed to reach the quarter-finals of the men's singles.
Nancy Davids confirmed a report yesterday that she had acquired "The Happy Ant Hill," the Franz Spencer comedy with a European background, for Broadway presentation next fall.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Administration insisted today that the Federal Power Commission be given unconditional authority to award a contract for developing the United States share of the Niagara Falls power resources.

BONN, Germany, June 8-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer agreed in principle today to accept the Soviet invitation to discuss the establishment of West German-Soviet diplomatic, economic and cultural relations.
PITTSBURGH, June 8 (UP)-- Dale Long's one-out homer in the ninth inning tonight gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The State Department has asked Congress to pass legislation making the settlements of war claims more equitable.
AN old stage and screen success and a new script were presented without distinction on two television programs last night.
The 20,092 customers at Belmont Park yesterday saw the 1954 champion 3-year-old filly set a track record for a mile and a sixteenth.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges turned irregular yesterday in generally dull trading. Coffee, hides, rubber, burlap, wool and cocoa declined; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes and zinc rose, and sugar and copper ended mixed.
In announcing that the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers won't join the merged A. F. L.-C. I. O. Grand Chief Guy L. Brown has raised some challenging questions as to American labor-union policies.

KANSAS CITY, June 8 (ap)-- Enos Slaughter's ninth-inning pinch single drove in Gus Zernial with the winning run tonight as the Kansas City Athletics gained a 3-2 decision over the Washington Senators.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has asked former President Truman to speak June 24 during the United Nations tenth anniversary celebration in San Francisco. Mr. Truman said he would give his answer Tuesday.

FROM West Twelfth Street to Park Avenue, by way of Gracie Terrace, informal discussion groups dealing with such diverse matters as art, books, the news and feminine finances will be in animated session this month.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I do not think that the results of the Sicilian elections were a great victory or even a substantial advance for democracy.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- The Government announced today a compromise policy on sugar legislation to provide some increase in marketing quotas for domestic producers, but not so great a cut in Cuba's sales in this country as United States producers had asked.

If a merchandise man can be described as a retail executive with brains, a buyer might be characterized as a lesser executive with brains and feet. This week the feet will prove essential in carrying buyers from showroom to showroom in the frantic selection of fall merchandise.
Longshoremen of the Port of New York will oppose legislation to set up a new Federal agency to deal with maritime labor.
The stalled anti-polio inoculation program in New Jersey was revived yesterday with the arrival of a new supply of Salk vaccine.

OSSINING, N. Y., June 8 -- Philip Persehetz, a pharmacist here, was killed this afternoon at his home, 25 Ferris Place, when the gas furnace exploded while he was leaning into it. The police and Dr. Victoria A. Bradess, Westchester County Medical Examiner, listed the death as a suicide.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6-- A yearling that is twice in size of the mother cow is being talked about here as a sample of United States aid on the hoof.
The National Broadcasting Company has a new home-grown television star -- its president, Sylvester L. Weaver Jr.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 8-- The Government of Kenya announced today that its offer to accept surrender of Mau Mau terrorists without penalty would be withdrawn July 10.

Once more phenomenal growth in the use and usefulness of our civil air-transport system is revealed in "Air Transport Facts and Figures," recently issued. Both the domestic and international airlines set alltime high traffic records in 1954. The scheduled airlines carried more than 35 million passengers more than 20 billion passenger-miles, a gain in excess of 12 per cent over the previous year.
Export shipments of cotton have dropped below the level of last season for the first time in several months.
William J. Keating, who broke the wiretap scandal, will surrender tomorrow to start serving a five-day jail term for refusing to divulge his sources of information.
Business should be very good for at least the next few years, leaders said yesterday at the opening sessions of the twentieth annual International Distribution Congress in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Three corporations announced yesterday that they had filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of stock.

AMONG the thousands of hunting and fishing groups in this country, the Feather Dusters Club is one of the most interesting. It accepts into its circle only anglers and hunters who have pursued their sports successfully by legitimate and unorthodox methods.

Hearings have been in progress before the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency on the President's proposal for United States participation in the so-called International Finance Corporation. The latter would be an affiliate of the Intel-national Bank for Reconstruction.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Eisenhower appealed urgently to the Senate today to revive and enact the Administration's military manpower reserve program pigeonholed by the House.

New York City is accustomed to being startled by the daring and magnitude of William Zeckendorf's plans. But nothing in the past quite prepared us for the $100,000,000 Palace of Progress which he would like to erect on top of a rebuilt Pennsylvania Station.

MOSCOW, June 8--For the first time in twenty-five years a group of American Quakers, who twice in the early years of the Soviet regime brought food relief to this country, is visiting the Soviet Union.

A 28-year-old teacher was stabbed twice in the back last night when he tried to oust a teen-age intruder. The youth was disturbing a night study group at Joan of Arc Junior High School, 154 West Ninetythird Street.

SINGAPORE, June 8 --The coroner found today that the police were not criminally negligent in the death of Gene D. Symonds, United Press correspondent. The newspaper man was beaten by a rioting mob May 12.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 8 --A growing need for governmental control of the use of radiation was reported here today to delegates attending the Fiftyfirst Annual State Health Conference.
American Airlines has ordered a fleet of newly designed Lockheed turbine-propeller planes, this country's first challenge to Britain's huge lead in the field.

DETROIT, June 8--When 3 hours and 4 minutes are needed to complete a big-league, errorless, nine-inning ball game, in which only four runs are scored, someone must be wrong. And Bob Turley, the right-hander ace of the Yankees, was far from right tonight at Briggs Stadium, where the Tigers upset the league leaders, 3--1.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The March-April hearings before a Senate subcommittee on proposals to change the Presidential electoral system are now available in printed form. The document consists of 469 pages, many in small type. But, considering the importance of the subject and the long span of years in which electoral reform has been agitated, it is probable that public interest in a major constitutional amendment has never been less.
Ferryboat operators in the New York metropolitan area are looking for Congressional relief of the burdensome accounting task now imposed upon them under the Internal Revenue Code of 1954.

WASHINGTON, June 8--President Eisenhower came out today against the whole principle of attaching riders to legislation to achieve indirectly what might not be achieved directly. He thus did what some Congressional leaders in both parties had hoped he would do lest important aspects of his program be lost in the complications arising from the racial segregation issue.

CHICAGO, June 8--Advertising will face the problem of creating year-round markets for seasonal items because "the guaranteed annual wage is coming," a New York merchandising consultant declared today.

MONTREAL, June 8 (UP) -- Hector (Toe) Blake became the thirteenth coach of the Montreal Canadiens today. He said he hoped to succeed where others had failed in making the jump from player to coach of the colorful National Hockey League club.

The laying of the world's first transoceanic telephone cable will begin June 22. When the first call is completed late next year, it will crown with success a quarter-century of research and two years of international business negotiations.
The new headquarters of the secretary for education and affiliated activities of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York at 31 East Fiftieth Street, was dedicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8--President Eisenhower took an optimistic line today about the Soviet Union's recent diplomatic offensive. He said he would extend the length of the forthcoming Big Four headsof-government conference if he thought it would do any good.
Jack F. Briscoe has been appointed merchandise manager of the decorative fabrics division of Dan River Mills, Inc.
NEW HAVEN, June 8--The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced tonight that it would risk a strike if necessary to retain women employes on its grill cars.
A raw June wind whipped academic tassels yesterday as degrees were awarded to members of the fifty-eighth graduating class of the Cornell University Medical College.
The outging Transit Authority warned its successor yesterday that more economies must be found if subway fares are to stay at 15 cents.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 8-- The days when Princeton University graduates came back to reunions to relive the experiences of carefree undergraduate life appear to be virtually ended.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

ATLANTIC CITY, June 8-- Persons accidentally showered with radioactive fall-out in the nuclear detonation in the Pacific on March 1, 1954, recovered in six months from their major ailment--skin damage.

OTTAWA, June 8--Important changes in the leadership of the Canadian armed forces were announced today. The appointment of Air Marshal Frank R. Miller as civilian Deputy Minister of Defense can be taken as evidence of Canada's growing concern about the air defense of the Arctic to protect the North American Continent.

Britain's Parliament opens today in a mood of mingled hope and exasperation. The hope comes from general prosperity and the prospect of five years with a popular Conservative Government and a Labor Opposition strong enough to hold it in line.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- Following is a, stenographic transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, all of it released by the White House for direct attribution: PRESIDENT EISENHOWER --Please be seated.

FORT WILLIAM, Ont., June 8 (Canadian Press)--Cyrus S. Eaton, Canadian - born United States financier and chairman of Steep Rock Iron Mines, Ltd., said today establishment of a lakehead smelter was not beyond the realm of possibility.
The city is making a broad survey of its prisons to determine how bad conditions are and what corrective steps should be taken.

RYE, N. Y., June 8--By use of a little sorcery, ornithologists have taught Canada geese to live happily in bulrushes here among weasels, foxes, minks, turtles, skunks, rat and other potential predators.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The liberation of Austria, talk of disarmament, and negotiations for a top-level Big Four conference have sweetened the atmosphere of the "cold war." Nevertheless, Civil Defense will continue to be a great national problem.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 8 (UP) --Galophone, one of the leading candidates for the Hambletonian Stake at Goshen on Aug. 3, beat seven other 3-year-old trotters, including three Hambletonian eligibles, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

"The Pitiless Jungle," by John L. Brom, a best-seller in six languages, will be published in an American edition by David McKay June 24. It is an account of the expedition M. Brom took into the heart of French Equatorial Africa with five other men and women to make a movie, a stay that lasted one year.
WASHINGTON, June 8--Nowhere is banking competition keener than in New York City despite recent bank mergers there, the New York State Superintendent of Banks declared today.

Nominated if Not Elected Harry Reynolds of Nominated, Winona, Minn., was if Not not elected president Elected of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers the other day in Chicago, but the fact that he was nominated for the presidency suggests that one year before too long the national P. T. A. will be addressing not "Madam President" but a "Mr. President."

WASHINGTON, June 8--President Eisenhower expressed complete confidence today in Dr. Konrad Adenauer, the West German Chancellor, as a man who would "stand by his allies and friends" in any direct negotiations with the Soviet Union.
NORMAN, Okla., June 8 (UP) --The University of Oklahoma dropped its ban against undergraduate Negro students today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP)-- Spokesmen for the American Legion and the American Veterans Committee clashed briefly today on the issue of whether more refugees should be admitted into the country.
DETROIT, June 8--Leaders of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., warned General Motors locals today to end unauthorized strikes. They said the walkouts were "sabotaging" national negotiations.
CHICAGO, June 8 (UP)--Hoot Evers' homer in the eighth inning sparked the Baltimore Orioles to a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

LONDON, June 8 --A brief preliminary meeting of the heads of the Western governments prior to their conference with Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, has been discussed in diplomatic circles here.
The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. may send a deputation of American church leaders to Russia.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP)-- The value of new construction reached a new high level in May, continuing the upswing that started late last year, the Government reported today.
LONDON, June 8--About 2,000 Britons were rewarded for public service in Queen Elizabeth's birthday honors list, published today.
Frank Santana, 17 years old, was permitted to plead guilty yesterday to second-degree murder in the slaying April 30 of William Blankenship Jr., 15.
A group of visiting municipal officials ridiculed yesterday this city's antiquated system of permitting street repairs to interfere with traffic.
An investigation was begun yesterday into a report that one of the jurors who doomed a 16year-old Brooklyn boy to the electric chair last week had boasted of prejudging the case.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP)-- A majority of Tennessee Valley Authority directors has urged the Administration to abandon the disputed Dixon-Yates power project on the ground it would be useless.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Senate quickly passed today a bill sponsored by Democrats to raise the national minimum wage from 75 cents an hour to $1. The action came only a few hours after President Eisenhower had renewed his recommendation that the increase be held to 90 cents.
The Public Service Commission upheld yesterday the right of patrons of Purdy's station on the New York Central Railroad to have freight service.
PARIS, June 8--The United States repaid part of its cultural debt to France tonight.

PARIS, June 8 (UP)--Lieut. Joseph W. Conrad, the British amateur champion from San Antonio, won two matches today as twelve United States players grained the third round of the French amateur golf tournament The airman was under par in both contests.
The compulsory military reserve bill was the subject of intensive artificial respiration by the Administration this week.
CLEVELAND, June 8 (AP)-- Jim Piersall doubled in the twelfth and scored the winning run on an error tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat Cleveland, 5--4, and dropped the Indians into third place.
FORT WILLIAM, Ont., June 8 (Canadian Press)--A $20,000,000 expansion program at the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., here was announced today by Lands Minister Mapledoram.
LONDON, June 8--A small patch of blue sky appeared in Britain's stormy labor situation tonight. The two parties to the nation-wide railroad strike agreed on a formula for resuming discussions.

KIMBERLEY, Union of South Africa, June 8--The demand for both gem and industrial diamonds--usually associated with American prosperity--has continued unabated during the first five months of 1955. This was reported by Sir Ernest Oppenheimer, chairman, at the annual meeting of De Beers Consolidated Mines. Ltd., here today.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference with 208 reporters today were: Big Four Conference--He felt several Soviet moves, including efforts to woo India, Yugoslavia and West Germany, indicated the atmosphere of world tension was changing. It might lead to an accommodation in which the United States could have confidence that would lighten the armament burdens of the peoples of the world.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- Fifty top golfers from twentysix countries received a hearty greeting today from President Eisenhower. The nation's Chief Executive expressed the hope, that they all break par in the $150,000 international golf championship beginning tomorrow.
The First National Bank and Trust Company of Tulsa, Okla., offered its stockholders rights to subscribe to 160,000 additional common shares yesterday at $25 a share.
WASHINGTON, June 8--Harold E. Stassen sought today to head off growing House criticism of Marshal Tito that could threaten continued United States aid to Yugoslavia.
The century-old Bible House on Astor Place will fall to progress, it became known last night.
The controversial Dixon-Yates power plant at West Memphis, Ark., will be completed on schedule, according to Edgar H. Dixon, president of Middle South Utilities, Inc.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : There are some facts which I believe it important to point out in connection with your June 2 editorial "The Seamen Ask a Bit More."

JUST a year ago in this space I wrote that novelists and historians had unaccountably neglected the Civil War west of the Mississippi. This oversight was already partly repaired, for my comment was part of a review of Daniel O'Flaherty's "General Jo Shelby: Undefeated Rebel," which is a biography of a Missouri soldier, the most flamboyantly picturesque of all the Confederacy's cavalry Commanders.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The Atomic Energy Commission has informed Congress it is making "rapid strides" toward an atomicpowered plane as the result of a "new approach" to the problem.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 8-- According to competent South Vietnamese sources, it is not up to the Saigon Government to reply to the North Vietnamese proposal for consultations on allVietnam elections next year.
Don Newcombe became the major leagues' first ten-game winner of 1955 last night.

AN Hawaiian luau, the island feast featuring suckling pig roasted in a pit, will be catered for large groups by the newly formed party division of Orchids of Hawaii. The porcine piece de resistance, other Hawaiian delicacies, music on steel guitars and even grass skirts for hula dancing are provided in this service, suitable for country club cook-outs, office picnics and other big, al fresco gatherings.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee approved today a bill to exempt producers of natural gas from direct Federal control over their prices. The vote was 15 to 5.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (UP)-- Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion, used bobbing, close-quarter tactics tonight to score a unanimous ten-round decision over Johnny Holman of Chicago in their return bout.

WASHINGTON, June 8--William White, former president of the New York Central Railroad Company, accused the Securities and Exchange Commission today of exercising unwarranted "censorship" in proxy contests.
Persons undergoing deportation proceedings here are still being imprisoned.

Control of the six-story apartment house on the south side of Glen River Road and Laurel Place, in Yonkers, N. Y., has been acquired in a stock-sale transaction. The stock was purchased by a syndicate headed by Irwin Halpern, attorney, from Sam and Lillian Schwartz and Irving and Daniel W. Pepper.

The three-story garden-type apartment house at 92-06 Sixtythird Avenue and 63-19 to 63-43 Austin Street in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by the Columbia Gardens Corporation to Edward Kummer of Wallingford, Conn.
Gains were bigger than losses yesterday and the stock market closed irregularly higher after setting new tops for The New York Times industrial and combined averages.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 8--Far - reaching changes seem likely, but the United States should be equal to giving some "constructive leadership," Dr. Lewis Webster Jones told graduates of Rutgers University tonight.

Advertising volume for the seven major New York daily newspapers came to 15,661,439 lines in May, which was 9 per cent more than in the 1954 month. The figure for five months of 1955 came to 69,131,016, a rise of 7.14 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Nervous price swings within moderate limits were the rule in wheat, corn and oats today. But rye was definitely weak, reflecting recent profit taking and a slower demand. Soybeans held in a moderate range, with no heavy selling in evidence.

Sales and earnings of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the March quarter this year were slightly below last year's levels. Prospects for the rest of the year are for somewhat lower earnings, Robert E. Gross, president, said in issuing the firstquarter results yesterday.

OAK RIDGE, N. J., June 8-- The great Ringling mansion, once a circus winter quarters will become the nerve center of a Roman Catholic organization dedicated to aiding the "Church of Silence" behind the iron curtain.

The Maritime Administration in Washington took its final step yesterday to get under way a long-delayed tanker construction program for the Navy. The agency approved the applications of four private companies offering to build the tankers for long-term charter to the Military Sea Transportation Service.
THAT the garden and terrace may present decorating opportunities almost equal with interiors for imaginative homeowners will be amply demonstrated today at an auction sale starting at 1:45 P. M.

A superb 49-second quarter mile by Ralph Bass sparked Boys High to the team championship at the fifty-first annual Public Schools Athletic League senior track and field games at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- The struggle between the Argentine Government and the Roman Catholic Church entered a showdown phase today.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the federal reserve board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 1:

THERE appeared to be only one inference to draw. When the news leaked that six directors of the Madison Square Garden Corporation had resigned, it almost had to be interpreted as a protest against Jim Norris, the man slated to assume active control of the Garden as its president.

LONDON, June 8--The boom in industrial stocks continued in full force here today. A new bookkeeping account opened with heavy buying by big investors. Prices soared, gaining up to 5 shillings (70 cents).

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 8-- The Government last night issued a new list of import articles considered essential. These may be imported at the official exchange of 2.50 pesos to the United States dollar. Everything else must be imported with free exchange," which is now about four pesos to the dollar.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation has been reorganized and a new regime will take office today. Changes announced at the sports arena yesterday included: Resignation of six directors, including Bernard F. Gimbel, board chairman.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 8-- Joe Kryla Jr. of Leewood and William J. Mangin of Aldecress tied for top honors in the 18th annual thirty-six-hole William Rice Hochster memorial golf tournament today.

Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday a day of special prayer and communion for victims of oppression in Communist-dominated countries, and particularly for Roman Catholic victims of "tyrannical oppression" in Argentina.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 --Ernest Borgnine, whose career is moving rapidly ahead since his success as Marty, has received a co-starring role in Columbia's "Jubal Troop."
MADRID, June 8--The air bases and port facilities that the United States is building in Spain are expected to be in full operation four years from now.

A property containing six buildings and measuring 80 by 120 feet at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Sixtythird Street has been purchased for future improvement by a syndicate headed by I. Jerome Riker.
JUNE brings roses, wedding's and, of greater importance to this epicure, an abundance of fresh shrimp.
HARTFORD, Thursday, June 9--The General Assembly, which had to close down at midnight last night by constitutional provision, failed to pass two important tax measures.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, with a moderate amount of business. Prices were 8 to 10 points (40 to 50 cents a bale) higher than Tuesday.
CHORWON, Korea, June 8-- It was a sunny warm afternoon in the plain north of this once bustling city, which is now an uninhabited ruin in the demilitarized zone.
North Korea is beginning to emerge from the ruins of the Korean war, but still has much reconstruction to do.
The path has been cleared for construction of the natural gas pipeline through Westchester County.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 8 (AP)--Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore increased her lead to eight strokes today in the Women's Eastern Golf Association amateur tournament. She carded one-over-par 74 for a thirty-six-hole total of 147.
NEW DELHI, India, June 8-- The Indian Government announced today a comprehensive compensation plan for the rehabilitation of millions of Hindu refugees from West Pakistan.
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, heard some shocking reports of extracurricular activities of schoolage children yesterday.

The Northern Trust Company and associates bought $2,050,000 of Joplin (Mo.) school district bonds yesterday. The group bid a net interest cost of 2.2809 per cent on the 2 1/4 and 2 3/8 per cent bonds, which mature on July from 1956 to 1975.
Two 20-year-old Queens youths were arrested early yesterday morning as they were towing a one-ton cement mixer behind a Cadillac convertible.
Darius Milhaud, French composer, received last night an honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Letters at graduation exercises of the Hebrew Union School of Sacred Music.
As the Giants arrived at the Polo Grounds yesterday after their drubbing by the Braves Tuesday night, Leo Durocher gathered his players about him for a clubhouse meeting.
YESTERDAY (June 9, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Talked with Admiral Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Met with the National Security Council.
THOSE who phophesied an early and abundant bluefish season apparently interpreted the signs correctly. The fish are plentiful from Cape Hatteras to Sandy Hook.
The sugar bill now before Congress would maintain a healthy domestic industry and still encourage foreign trade, according to Representative Edwin E. Willis, Democrat of Louisiana.

MAKUNG, Pescadores Islands, June 9--A gentle westerly breeze blew over this rocky archipelago today as fishermen rode their boats out of tiny harbors and women with covered faces laboriously drove wooden plows in sweet potato patches.

MONTREAL, June 9 (UP)-- A. V. Roe Canada Ltd., whose 16,000 workers make jet fighter planes in three plants near Toronto, has offered to buy all the stock of the Canadian Car and Foundry Company, Ltd., for $22,223,400.

The fourth at Belmont Park yesterday was a Widener chute sprint for 2-year-old fillies that never had won a race. The winner was C. V. Whitney's Aiming High, the $5.90-for-$2 favorite. Because of what happened prior to the start, it was an extraspecial performance.

YESTERDAY (June 9, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council took up report of petitions committee, and began review of Australianadministered Nauru. Standing Committee on Petitions --Continued examination of appeals from Italian Somaliland.
WASHINGTON, June 9--The disclosure last February of the immense power of the thermonuclear bomb has jolted some of the inertia out of official and public attitudes on Civil Defense planning.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 9-- Major land reforms and a pattern for future economic development of East Africa were recommended today by a British Royal Commission.
ALBANY, June 9 (AP)--The State Committee on Refugees unanimously endorsed today President Eisenhower's proposals to relax restrictions on immigration under the 1953 Refugee Relief Act.
More than 100,000 children held their annual Sunday School parades in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday.

THE boom is on in the busted beak industry. But the take-off spot was not the dreary Ezzard Charles-Johnny Holman waltz at Cincinnati the night before last. A fellow had to exercise great self-restraint to keep from spinning the television dial to something lively, such as a 1937 movie. This fight was a real clinker.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Our legislative history bristles with denunciation of "riders" from the time when, forty years after the Government was formed, the practice began of adding them to money bills. But the available records indicate that President Eisenhower's attack on this parliamentary maneuver was the broadest ever made because he castigated riders in general.
Talks "at the summit" among the leaders of great nations and outside the framework of the United Nations are "fraught with danger" for the democracies, Ernest A. Gross said last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an effort to interpret Edward Kardelj's "essential doctrines that established Titoism," C. L. Sulzberger does not take into consideration some basic facts. Titoism--if it ever existed--and certainly it did not exist in the minds of Tito or Kardelj, who consistently denied it --is now as dead as the Cominform.
The State is investigating complaints of fraud against "upward of a dozen" automobile driving schools in New York City.

Edwin O'Connor of Boston was awarded the 1955 Atlantic $5,000 Prize for his new novel, "The Last Hurrah." It is a story about the Irish in America with a protagonist who is "half hero, half rascal" and the dominant leader in his city.
WASHINGTON, June 9--The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending June 8 increased $152,000,000 to $18,648,000,000, the Federal Reserve board reported today.
KANSAS CITY, June 9 (UP)-- Art Ditmar pitched brilliantly today after a shaky start and hit a game-winning single with the bases full as the Kansas City Athletics beat the Washington Senators, 4-2.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Department store sales in the United States last week were 5 per cent above sales in the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, June 9--The stock markets boiled over today after prices had risen further on hopes of a settlement of the national rail and dock strikes. Prices closed on a rising note after the reaction and gains outnumbered losses.
Assistant District Attorney Andrew McCarthy of the Bronx said yesterday he was "amazed and flabbergasted" by reports of "false and fantastic charges" made by William Blankenship Sr.

CAIRO, June 9--Egypt was reported today as willing to appoint a high-ranking officer to discuss with a responsible Israeli official means of halting the sporadic fighting on their common frontier. These talks must be, in Egypt's terms, in the presence of the United Nations truce supervisory chief.
Steel producers in this country turned out more steel in May than ever before in a single month.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senate leaders set out today to find a way to rescue the Administration's program for creating a trained military Reserve.
The New York cotton futures market closed 6 points (30 cents a bale) down to 11 points (55 cents) up yesterday.
UDALL, Kan., June 9--How do you go about reconstructing a village that has been swept off the map?

DOBERT M. CAMPBELL, vice president of Rogers Peet, a suit and accessories concern with a reputation for conservative wares, believes there have been greater changes in men's fashion during the last eighteen months than any in the rest of his forty-seven years in the field.

REDUCED shipments of fresh pork and lamb have pushed up retail prices of these meats, the City Department of Markets reports. This week's pork receipts have been the lightest since last August. Lamb arrivals have been the smallest this year. Housewives doing their marketing this week-end will find pork loin roast up 8 cents a pound to a most general figure of 73 cents and leg of lamb up 4 cents to 69 cents.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 9-- G. W. Blunt White, chairman of the New York Yacht Club's ocean race committee, got less than half his job of distributing last-minute instructions done in the wind, cold and rain today.
Most Safeway food stores in the city and neighboring counties were closed yesterday after a union struck at 7 A. M. in a wage dispute.

Widespread rumors of impending action by the Federal Reserve Board to tighten margin requirements for stock purchasers resulted in numerous local and long distance calls to the agency's Washington headquarters yesterday.
A traffic package that will combine peripheral parking in New Jersey with scheduled express bus service to Manhattan was authorized yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
The newly formed American Institute of Men's and Boys' Wear, promotional group for the industry, will hold a series of regional meetings to put the program into action.

Attorneys for Raymond Holley, the 16-year-old youth sentenced to the electric chair after his conviction of first-degree murder, will seek a mistrial before Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz next Monday.

PARIS, June 9 (AP)--Finance Minister Pierre Pflirnlin of France warned Europeans and Americans today that making all their currencies freely exchangeable with the United States dollar might be a technical success but a "political failure."

Even though she ranks with those at the top of her profession, Deborah Kerr isn't averse to improving her art. Interviewed yesterday in San Francisco, where she is appearing in "Tea and Sympathy," the star confirmed a report that she would join the Old Vic, London's renowned repertory group.
Two generator stators weighing 236 tons are aboard ships heading for Japan and Puerto Rico.
The New York State Thruway Authority announced yesterday that it will sell $125,000,000 of State-guaranteed bonds on July 12. The obligations will come due from 1984 to 1995.

The Fabre Line yesterday warned that its expulsion from a ship conference might break up the group and bring about a rate war. The warning was delivered to the Federal Maritime Board and the Gulf/Mediterranean Ports Conference.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Following are the text of Surgeon General Leonard A. Soheele's letter to Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby. Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, transmitting his report on the status of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine, and a portion of the report itself:

SYRACUSE, June 9--Carmen Basilio, a welterweight boxer from near-by Canastota, will make a bid for the world championship of his division tomorrow night. He will engage the titleholder. Tony DeMarco of Boston, in a fight scheduled for fifteen rounds.
LONDON, June 9--The liner Queen Elizabeth sailed from Southampton today with 1,300 New York-bound passengers after the crew had refused to join the unofficial seamen's strike.
Stocks hit new highs yesterday morning and bounced back abruptly. The decline on the day was the largest since May 23. Only the metals, as a group, showed much resistance to the downturn.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Payto-see television was attacked today as a real threat to present free programs and also defended as essential for top-quality shows.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) --Robin Roberts pitched a threehitter tonight as the Phillies beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0. The Philadelphia right-hander struck out nine in gaining his ninth victory. He has lost four games.
The city's high school pupils will be "short-changed" next year, the High School Principals Association of New York City charged yesterday.

A 17-year-old boy was arraigned in Youth Part of Felony Court yesterday on charges of stabbing a school teacher. The attack took place Wednesday night in Joan of Arc Junior High School at 154 West Ninetythird Street.

When the Ford Motor Company signed the new contract with the United Auto Workers this week the big news was the "guaranteed annual wage" as labor called it, or the "supplemental unemployment benefit plan," as management preferred to label it.

Nathan Kaminsky purchased the five-story apartment house for twenty-one families at 1350 Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, from the Mikay Realty Corporation. Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers. The attorneys were Abraham Reichel for the seller and Sol H. Cohn for the buyer.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Philip B. Perlman called the Eisenhower Administration's employe security program "a national disgrace" today.
An eighty-three-year-old women's organization admitted its first male member yesterday. And, just as women usually do when they take part in a marriage, the organization changed its name.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 9 (AP)--Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore survived a poor round today to win the annual Women's Eastern Golf Association amateur championship. She had a 54-hole total of 230, eleven shots over par.
TRENTON, June 9--The Republican -controlled Legislature voted tonight to raise maximum weekly unemployment and temporary disability benefits from $30 to $35. It then recessed until Aug. 8.
Japanese raw silk producers soon will put into effect new standards designed to improve quality and to make the product more acceptable to weavers abroad.
WASHINGTON, June 9--The United States and West Germany are maintaining the closest contact about the Soviet Union's move to "normalize" its relations with the Adenauer Government.
MOSCOW, June 9--Anastas I. Mikoyan expressed confidence today that as far as the Soviet Union was concerned an agreement could be reached to establish diplomatic relations between Moscow and Bonn.
MOSCOW, June 9--Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, congratulated the Soviet Government tonight on steps it had taken "for the furtherance of peace."
Five defendants were found guilty yesterday of conspiracy and fraud in a Laurelton, Queens, sewer scandal. A sixth was acquitted. Twelve male jurors had deliberated two and a half days.

LONDON, June 9--Persuaded by the eloquence of Aneurin Bevan, who twice has challenged him for the post. Clement R. Attlee decided today to retain the leadership of the Labor party "for a further period."
WASHINGTON, June 9-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 713,673 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Edward J. Corsi, ousted State Department special adviser on immigration problems, pledged his support to President Eisenhower last night "if he will lead the fight" for a truly democratic American immigration policy."
Recent disclosures by Soviet economists appear to have shed new light on the magnitude and nature of internal economic pressure that may be behind the current Soviet peace offensive.

SEOUL, Korea, June 9--Five years ago the North Korean army attacked across the Thirty -eighth Parallel and overwhelmed the internal security force the United States had helped the Republic of Korea raise and train.

WASHINGTON, June 9--The State Department said today the new tariff agreements with Japan would strengthen that country's economic ties with the free world. They will also reduce the danger that Japan will become dependent on trade with Communist China, according to the department.
The story from the Transit Authority was as usual yesterday: Fewer passengers and less revenue.
PARIS, June 9--A hint that France might act as conciliator between the Soviet Union and the West was dropped here today by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister.

LONDON, June 9--Sir Anthony Eden asserted today he would exclude no method and no machinery from the search for peace in the coming series of four-power meetings. Negotiations among the heads of government of the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union and France will demand time and patience, the Prime Minister told the House of Commons, but "this series of meetings in prospect offers us all an exceptional opportunity."

THERE are ten short stories in Flannery O'Connor's second book, "A Good Man Is Hard to Find,"* and two of them are mediocre. The eight others are quite wonderful in a gruesome way and should confirm Miss O'Connor's claim to a high rank among our most talented younger writers. I haven't read anything that has impressed me more in several months.

DETROIT, June 9--Ask anyone with a sacroiliac condition merely to stand erect, let alone pitch against the Yankees, and it's asking a lot. It was then, hardly a surprise that the Tigers' Steve Gromek, bothered all week by an aching back, failed to survive four inning against the league leaders today at Briggs Stadium.

New Jersey's anti-polio inoculation program got off to a belated and stumbling start yesterday. Many communities held to earlier decisions to put it off until school reopened in the fall, despite a stern warning from Dr. Daniel Bergsma, State Health Commissioner, against further delay.
WASHINGTON, June 9-- Harry Lev, Chicago cap manufacturer, lamented today that he had been undone by "disefficiency" and business competitors who yearned to see him dead.
The American Cancer Society announced yesterday that no more of its local units would be permitted to participate in federated appeals or community chests.
The Fencers Club captured the foil team title as the annual national fencing championships started yesterday. The competition will continue through next Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Robert R. Young, chairman of the New York Central Railroad as a result of an epic proxy battle last year, stoutly defended today the transaction by which 800,000 shares of stock were voted in his favor.

The Kansas City Power and Light Company is giving its common stock holders rights to subscribe for 245,000 additional shares on the basis of one new share for each ten shares held. The subscription price is $37 a share.

PARIS, June 9 (UP)--Lieut. Joe Conrad, a little Texan who likes to play golf in the rain, scored two victories in a steady downpour today. He led five Americans into the quarterfinals of the French amateur championship.
A new business administration at Madison Square Garden was installed yesterday at a special meeting of the board of directors.

PATROLMAN Redmond L. O'Hanlon, who had millions in suspense the other night as he answered eight questions on Shakespeare on the Revlon "$64,000 Question" TV show, is the scholarly type of cop you find in astonishingly increasing numbers of the city police force now.
It was not the sort of day one would pick for a cruise. It was cold, and a wet wind swept over the Hudson River.
An integrated passenger and cargo terminal on the North River will be created through the linking of Piers 58 and 57 in the Chelsea district.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics eased to 89.5 on Wednesday from 89.6 on Tuesday. The figure for June 9, 1954, was 92.5.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP)-- Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, called today for a Congressional investigation of an Air Force contract that permits the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to operate a heavy press extrusion facility at Halethorpe, Md.
Cardinal Spellman is weighing a scheduled visit to Buenos Aires next month. It would come only three weeks after the day of special prayers he had ordered for the church in Argentina.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 9 (UP) --Quick Chief, the 3-10 favorite, posted a ten-length victory tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the Prince Adios Pace for 3year-olds.

Contract talks between the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., and major East Coast tanker companies were abruptly halted yesterday as the union negotiating committee walked out of a meeting with shipowners in the Roosevelt Hotel.

DETROIT, June 9 (AP)-- What it termed the world's largest blast furnace was placed in production today by the Great Lakes Steel Corporation at its Zug Island plant in the River Rouge. The new furnace has a hearth thirty feet three inches in diameter and a rated capacity of 50,000 tons of pig iron a month.

The retiring New York City Transit Authority has issued a farewell report on its stewardship, approved by four of the five members. Three of the members have served for the full two years; two of them, including the persistent dissenter, Harris J. Klein, filled vacancies for a lesser term.
Loans to business by seventeen leading New York City banks declined $7,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 9 --The colors of Australia were first today in the golf competition for the Canada Cup that brought players from twenty-six countries here. Twenty-five twoman teams began the four-day tournament at the Columbia Country Club.

Acting with complete loyalty toward its Western allies, the German Government headed by Chancellor Adenauer has "welcomed" the Soviet proposal to establish diplomatic, economic and cultural relations between the two countries as another step that might reduce international tensions.

Lufthansa, the revived German airline, has formally resumed international operations. Its first scheduled trans-Atlantic flight since World War II was completed yesterday at 10:08 A. M. when one of its Lockheed Super-G Constellations landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
ETHEL "MERMAN almost rescued "Shower of Stars," the lavish revue seen over Channel 2 last night, from being a dull hour of broadcasting.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 9-- Boxing was described today as brutal and dangerous by a British surgeon. He said it should be made obsolete along with chain gangs and galley-slaves.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Representative Abraham J. Multer today described the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Real Esstate Boards as "irresponsible lobbyists" against public housing.
WASHINGTON, June 9--An urgent assignment to speed up the lagging refugee immigration program was handed today to Pierce J. Gerety, 41-year-old New York and Connecticut lawyer.
BONN, Germany, June 9-- Seven West German journalists have received visas for a visit to the Soviet Union. One group already has arrived in Moscow. Another will leave soon for the Soviet capital.

ALBANY, June 9 (AP)--Thomas J. Watson Jr. of New York, president of International Business Machines Corporation, was appointed by Governor Harriman today as chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Juvenile Delinquency.
Radioactive fall-out is a shower of dust after a thermonuclear explosion.
Clement Attlee, leader of Her Majesty's Opposition, has agreed to remain as leader of the Parliamentary Labor party, and hence of the British Socialist movement, "for a further period."

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,500 head: general trade moderately active to slow and uneven; butchers generally steady to strong with Wednesday's average; sows mainly steady

CHICAGO, June 9--Grain futures had a firmer tone after fractional declines were registered early in today's session. Corn futures dropped to new low marks for the crop before rallying, but selling was mainly of a local character in all pits.
William J. Keating, who begins today a five-day term for contempt of a grand jury, will be feted at a luncheon Tuesday immediately after he leaves City Prison.
The future of the United States depends on its willingness to share its economic and political wealth with other nations, Gardner Cowles asserted yesterday.

Television coverage of sports events by WPIX at Madison Square Garden will not be affected by the Garden's executive reorganization that took place this week. It was learned yesterday that the station had signed a new contract covering the 1955-56 season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 --Universal - International has eleven pictures in various phases of production including six before cameras on the lot. This is the studio's greatest production spurt over a five-year period.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 9--Governor Harriman took the Eisenhower Administration and the Republican party to task here tonight.

TIME was when a flood-lit garden was a luxury, found only on large estates with a ready crew of landscape gardeners handy. But as more and more families move from crowded city apartments to crowded suburbs, garden lighting is appreciated for its practical advantages.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews has sold the property at 328-38 East Fortysixth Street, where it once planned a national headquarters building. The new owner is an investment builder planning an office building on the site.

President Eisenhower's strong and forthright support of the program for the establishment of a trained reserve force is needed and welcome. He has made his appeal to the Senate, where something can be done, after the dismal story of the sacrifice of national interest to local and partisan interest in the House.

WASHINGTON, Friday, June 10--The Public Health Service placed major blame yesterday for the breakdown of the mass antipoliomyelitis program on the incompatibility of the original Salk formula with mass production methods required for its widest public use.

The four-story apartment house accommodating nineteen families at 50-05 Forty-fifth Street in Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York. The buyer is the Jopar Realty Corporation, represented by Bernard Buchwald, attorney.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Robert Moses, chairman of the New York State Power Authority, threatened today to fight "all the way to the Supreme Court" against private development of the vast electric power resources at Niagara Falls.

RAMSGATE, England, June 9--A Swedish tanker erupted in a towering mass of flames in the English Channel early today after a collision with a Panamanian freighter. Nineteen seamen from the 10,788 ton tanker Johannishus were missing and feared dead in the blazing, oil-covered waters.

Rambling Into Romance Already notice has been taken on this page of the plan for a "recreation center restricted to the enjoyment of older people" to be placed in Central Park's rustic preserve called the Ramble.
Use of a single television station to broadcast two images simultaneously was announced yesterday by Paramount Pictures, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that American long-range air power was "better and more effective" than the Soviet Union's. It would guarantee Soviet defeat if Moscow started an attack in Europe, he declared.
CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP)-- Frank Sullivan, who was aided in the ninth inning by Ellis Kinder, beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, today to give the Boston Red Sox a sweep of a threegame series.

As was to be expected, a sharp discussion has broken out in Congress over whether United States economic and military aid to Yugoslavia should be continued. President Eisenhower has requested that $40,500,000 in economic aid, plus an undisclosed amount of military help, be given Yugoslavia during the next fiscal year.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP)--The Board of Health canceled today Chicago's program of administering Salk anti-polio vaccine to first and second graders at least until fall.
DETROIT, June 9--The General Motors Corporation said today it would be forced to shut twenty Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants tomorrow because of parts shortages caused by wildcat walkouts.
EASTON, Pa., June 9 -- Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, was honored tonight by Lafayette College for his "exaltation of the court."
Joe Black, who pitched the Dodgers to a pennant in 1952, yesterday was sold to the Cincinnati Redlegs. He will join his new club in Philadelphia tomorrow.
A gay parish outing sailed close to tragedy yesterday when a Queens youth fell overboard into the Hudson's choppy waters.

LONDON, June 9 (AP)--The text of the speech by Queen Elizabeth II opening the new session of Parliament today follows: The grave situation created by the interruption of the railways services has made it necessary to advance the date of the opening of Parliament.
Bickford's, Inc. Bickford's, Inc., has purchased three restaurants of the Oliver

Future prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly higher yesterday in generally dull trading. Coffee, zinc, rubber, hides, potatoes, cocoa and tin rose; sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool and burlap eased, and copper ended mixed.
Assistant District Attorney Andrew McCarthy of the Bronx said yesterday that threats of violence had been made against him and his family.

CLEVELAND, June 10 -- A five-and-a-half-length lead over their nearest pursuers in the American League race belonged to the Yankees tonight. Casey Stengel's pace-setters soared to their biggest margin by downing the Indians, 3 -- 2, before 35,614 fans at Municipal Stadium.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- "The Baker's Wife," Marcel Pagnol's French-language success shown here in 1940, will be remade in Italy.
MARIETTA, Ga., June 7 -- Generals who have to worry about moving troops and cargo in an atomic war are putting great stock in a new Lockheed turbo-prop airplane in production here.

TORONTO, June 10 -- The Progressive Conservative party returned to power yesterday for its fifth straight term as the Government of the Province of Ontario, increased its seats in the Legislature today to eighty-three.
One of the fundamental substances of life has been laid bare in its living state through X-ray studies by British, French and American scientists.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 10 -- Larchmont Yacht Club's diamond jubilee race, a highlight of the club's seventy-fifth anniversary celebration, had thirty-two starters this evening.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- Eleven newspaper men from the United States have been awarded Nieman Fellowships for a year of background study at Harvard University.
