The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. has named the Rev. Dr. Hubert C. Noble as general director of its Commission on Higher Education.
Twenty clergymen -- eleven from the United States and nine from Britain -- will participate this summer in the twenty-ninth annual "preacher exchange" between the two countries.

In these days of confused and bewildered international sophistication, complicated by involved philosophies of world intrigue, we seem inclined to disregard the admonition in the Declaration of Independence which states that our governments derive "their just powers from the consent of the governed."
NEWPORT, R. I., June 10 -- One thing the beginning of tomorrow's ocean race to Sweden provided this afternoon was a clinical study of those who go down to the sea in small yachts.

Two Mexico City residents have been indicted in Brooklyn for smuggling five and three-quarters pounds of pure cocaine into this country. The cocaine had a value of more than $2,000,000 among narcotics addicts, according to Assistant United States Attorney Howard B. Gliedman.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 10 -- General White began his formal military career on Jan. 5, 1923, when he was commissioned a second lieutenant of cavalry in the Regular Army.
Big Jim Hearn and Gail Harris, the Giants' rookie first sacker, combined their talents at the Polo Grounds last night to bring down the Cardinals in the opener of a three-game series.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation announced today it was building a train that will be able to carry 400 passengers in comfort at sustained speeds of more than 100 miles an hour. The train will be low-slung, lightweight and low cost, Harlow H. Curtice, G. M. president, said.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 3 -- The major planning assumption of Civil Defense officials here is that the Soviet Union can strike any target in the United States.

A group of bondholders yesterday charged "gross incompetence" in the operation of the New York, Ontario and Western Railway during its eighteen years of bankruptcy. Earlier this week another bondholder group made similar charges.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- The Soviet Union has complained that its offer to supply experts and equipment to needy United Nations countries has not been taken up. The protest was made in a letter to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A possibly fatal blow was struck at the long-disputed Dixon-Yates contract by the House Appropriations Committee today.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 10 -- President Eisenhower will be beaten if he should run for reelection, J. Bracken Lee, Republican Governor of this state, said yesterday.

TECHNION CITY, Israel, June 10 -- Here on Mount Carmel, according to the First Book of Kings, Elijah called down fire from the heavens. Soon modern Israeli engineers will be causing winds to blow at 1,500 miles an hour on the mountainside, and temperatures to fall to minus 210 degrees Centigrade.

PLYMOUTH, England, June 10 (UP) -- The captain of the British coastal vessel Apollo told today how his crewmen rowed through a flaming sea for ninety minutes in a wooden lifeboat to pick up survivors from a flaming Swedish tanker.
TRENTON, June 10 -- The American President Lines will purchase Pier 9 in Jersey City from the Erie Railroad for $1,250,000. The sale is to be completed within sixty days.
THOSE delightful institutions, the German pork store and the French charcuterie, customarily stock a piquant assortment of cured and smoked meats ideal for summer cold cuts.

RECENT charges by a few conservation groups that there had been relaxations in waterfowl regulations and enforcement were denied this week by John L. Farley, chief of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
Said Frank E. (Jimmy) Kilroe, the racing secretary, at Belmont Park yesterday. "There are a lot of strange weeds in the garden."

BOSTON, June 10 (UP) -- More than 135,000 cubic centimeters of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine were shipped to five foreign nations before the start of the United States inoculation program, Representative Torbert H. MacDonald, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- V. K. Krishna Menon of India arrived today for top-level conferences with United Nations and United States officials.

The six-story apartment house accommodating forty-eight families at 1085 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Samdor Realty Corporation to a client of Isidore Katz, attorney. The property occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet near 165th Street. Wishnow Horowitz were the brokers and Harold Kohn was attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission were notified today that Federal Judge Paul Leahy, at Wilmington, Del., had approved a fee of $861,000 for the New York law firm of Guggenheimer and Untermyer.
Two bookkeepers for Brooklyn companies reported hold-ups to the police yesterday afternoon after the robbers got away.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India had more than two hours of political negotiations with the leaders of the Soviet Government today.
OMAHA, June 10 (AP) -- Wake Forest opened the National Collegiate world series today with a 1-0 victory over Colgate.

The 700-acre Federal housing project at Shanks Village, N. Y., will be put up for sale by the Government on Tuesday as an entity seeking a single buyer. It is expected to be one of New York's biggest real estate deals.

One of that legion of Canadians who make their careers in the United States, Clarence Alan Howell, who died yesterday, gave the land of his adoption an equal place in his heart with the land of his birth. He served both well. A lieutenant in the Canadian Expeditionary Force in the First World War, he was promoted on the field to a captaincy.

LONDON, June 10 -- For many years the four-day race meeting at Ascot, due to open Tuesday, has been the culmination of the London social season. The Derby and the Grand National are more spectacular and more popular with the general public, but Ascot is a "must" for the socialites and for the connoisseurs of race horses.

FLORENCE, S. C., June 10 (UP) -- A 67-year-old flying great-grandmother thrown off course by a storm while racing from Washington to Cuba was guided to a safe landing by a competitor tonight just before her gasoline gave out.
The week-end guests have returned again. On Friday afternoon they spread out from the hub of the city until all of the suburbs are filled with pale, urban faces and gay country clothes.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- Georgi M. Malenkov declared today that the Soviet Union's second atomic power plant would be completed ahead of those now being built in Britain.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration today announced the opening of the second round of its fight to recover so-called "windfall profits" which it says were "illegally milked" from post-war apartment projects.

STOCKTON, Calif., June 10 (AP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas defeated Arnie Sowell of Pittsburgh by three yards tonight in a special 880-yard run at the Pacific Association of the Amateur Athletic Union track meet. The time was 1:49.1.
CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 10 --The United States team of Ed Furgol and Chick Harbert moved into the lead in the Canada Cup golf competition today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The State Department said today that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, would meet with the foreign ministers of France, Britain and the United States in New York June 17.

MONTEBELLO, Que., June 10 (Canadian Press) -- T. H. Atkinson. retiring president of the Canadian Bankers' Association, said today more than 23,000 homes have been built or are under construction in Canada on bank credit under terms of the National Housing Act.

DETROIT, June 10 -- Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., rolled up their sleeves for hard work today in efforts to reach a new agreement by midnight Sunday.

Two books are published today. One is "The Campaign for the Sugar Islands 1759: A Study of Amphibious Warfare," by Marshall Smelser, with a foreword by Samuel Eliot Morison. It is published by the University of North Carolina Press for The Institute of Early American History and Culture, at Williamsburg, Va.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation has asked the Board of Estimate to make Seventh and Eighth Avenues two-way streets again. In support of its petition the company made public yesterday the results of "several thousand" traffic checks. They proved the one-way trial "had failed completely to relieve cross-town traffic, which was the express purpose of its inception," the company said.
LONDON, June 10 -- Peter Thorneycroft, president of the Board of Trade, gave a buoyantly optimistic picture of Britain's material outlook today as Parliament debated economic policy.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The American Natural Gas Company today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to issue 736,856 common shares for sale to its stockholders.
The Hupp Corporation has purchased 65,000 shares of the common stock of Perfection Industries, Cleveland, it was announced yesterday by John O. Ekblom, chairman of the executive committee of Hupp.
The Society of Television Lighting Directors has been formed to spotlight techniques of their profession for the information of the public, the performers and the directors themselves.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas and his bride of six months left today on a globe-girdling vacation.
LONDON, June 10 - Clement R. Attlee was re-elected chairman and leader of the Labor party today.

Several hundred members of society attended last night the sixth annual Belmont Ball, the fiftieth anniversary fete of Belmont Park. They dined and danced in a large marquee set on the lawn beside the lake, which was aglow with golden light.

Two small transatlantic travelers who had been stranded here for a day resumed their interrupted journey yesterday afternoon. Thin-legged but stout-hearted, they took up their one piece of luggage and set out for Pittsburgh.
SEOUL, Korea, June 10 -- High military officials here say the pattern of North Korean political and military affairs since the armistice of 1953 resembles that of the pre-Korean war years.
The attorney for Victor P. Clemente and his son Dominic, who were convicted of defrauding the city in a sewer construction scandal, indicated yesterday that his clients would appeal.
Five prominent Americans, all members of the Council on Foreign Relations, left here by air yesterday to attend a special meeting of the Nobel Institute in Oslo, Norway, opening Monday.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, charged yesterday that the Government report on the Salk vaccine apparently had thrown no light on the Cutter Laboratories "situation."

Selwyn Lempert, 14-year-old Brooklyn junior high school student, recently completed a fifty-page brochure of the Netherlands as a classroom assignment. He thought it was a pretty fair piece of work. After all, he had spent three months on it.

PARIS, June 10 -- The Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I., has expressed interest in France's newest jet passenger liner, the Caravelle, and is considering producing it under license in the United States.

A group of French fashion specialists yesterday doffed their hats to American women as being more style-conscious than their countrywomen, who are widely assumed to be the world's most fashion-minded.

The arrival of warmer weather, with summer just around the corner, inevitably has turned our attention once more to water. The problem right now is not one of water supplies -- our Catskill and Croton reservoirs are nearly full -- but of pressure.
New negotiations for the sale of the name and goodwill of The Brooklyn Eagle have broken down, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, June 10 -- Francois C. Erasmus, South African Defense Minister, arrived today to discuss the possibility of creating an alliance for the defense of Africa. He stressed his interest particularly in the area South of the Sahara.
Budget Director Abraham D. Beame lost his thirty-man, $200,000-a-year Division of Analysis to City Administrator Luther H. Gulick yesterday, but he won a consolation prize.
DETROIT, June 10 (UP) -- Ted Williams blasted home runs his first two times at bat today to lead the Boston Red Sox to their fifth straight victory, a 5-2 decision over the Detroit Tigers.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 -- There appears to be no good reason for the customary medical practice of limiting to three the number of children delivered by Caesarean section, doctors were told here today.

KATMANDU, Nepal, June 10 Reuters) -- Lionel Terray, French climber, said here today that he ate a hearty lunch of sardines, crackers and coffee on the narrow summit of Mount Makalu after he conquered the 27,790-foot peak last month.

With President Eisenhower's authority to cut tariffs under the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act expiring tomorrow, the Congressional conference committee has agreed to a compromise bill which extends the act for three more years. This compromise bill must still be approved by both houses and must then be signed by the President.

IF there is any doubt that college boys are not swallowing goldfish these days, then "Five Against the House," which arrived at the Criterion yesterday, is a farily exciting indication that they are more imaginative and practical.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Private differences between the Government on one side and advisory scientists and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis appeared headed for a public airing today.

LOS GATOS, Calif., June 10 (UP) -- A newly ordained Jesuit priest who wants to express "the continuity between our atomic age and that of Jesus Christ" will say his first mass tomorrow using a chalice made partly of uranium and cobalt. These are two of nature's most powerful elements.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 9 points up to 2 down, with business rather light.

A closed hearing on the proposed Maritime Labor Stabilization Act and other maritime matters ended in Washington yesterday with the appearances of John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, and Solon B. Turman, president of Lykes Bros. Co., Inc.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 10 -- Formosa has become a fully operational base for the United States Air Force.

A modified Guaranteed Annual Wage plan received tacit approval yesterday from the board of directors of National Sales Executives, Inc. The board met during the closing day's sessions of the group's twentieth annual international distribution congress in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The United States agreed formally today to sell the Swiss Government the small nuclear reactor it is installing at Geneva for the United Nations atoms-for-peace conference in August.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Total sales of retail stores in May were $15,300,000,000, according to estimates made public by the Department of Commerce in its monthly "flash" report on retail volume.

David and Robert Zuckerman, realty operators, have purchased the seven-story and loft building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 242 West Twenty-seventh Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. The property was sold by Cuyler Co., brokers, for 100 Franklin Realty, Inc.

It's beginning to look as if Manager Walt Alston can give the rest of the Dodger ball club a summer vacation and let his pitchers take care of what remains of Brooklyn's opposition for the National League pennant.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, received a patent this week for an idea he got an a sailboat trip.

LONDON, June 10 -- Leaders of Britain's two major railway unions conferred separately today with the British Transport Commission in a bid to end the national rail strike. Sessions will go on tomorrow.

GUATEMALA, June 2 -- The principles of freedom of worship and education have been preserved in the draft of the new Constitution in spite of the fact that Roman Catholic pressure for favored treatment forced a review of the articles dealing with these issues.

The Gallo Original Iron Works has leased the one-story building at 441 Wythe Avenue in Brooklyn from T. Gallagher. The lessee, manufacturer of wrought iron furniture, will use the building as a warehouse and distribution center for its outdoor and patio furniture.
PARIS, June 10 -- The conflict between European solidarity and Brritain's interests outside Europe appeared tonight to be on the way to one more temporary settlement.
The Board of Estimate yesterday appropriated $7,697,650 for the construction of a new upper-deck roadway for the Queensboro Bridge, together with new Manhattan and Queens approaches.
Commodity futures moved irregularly higher on the New York exchanges yesterday. Most of the markets were quiet, with trading limited to evening holdings for the week-end.

The public market for new capital is in for an interval of lessened activity after the strains of recent weeks. The absorption of big corporate bond issues at yields slightly lower than those prevailing a fortnight or so ago has given a better tone to the market.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe said today there was no reason to suppose that long-range Soviet plans for world conquest had been changed.
A memorial museum honoring a medical authority who never completed high school and who holds only an honorary degree will be built at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary.

A MAP that appeared in the financial pages of this newspaper last April would have surprised our greatest historian, Francis Parkman. The map showed the route through the Rockies of a pipeline intended to take natural gas to the American Northwest. And the course of that line seemed to shadow the immortal pioneering path that Parkman wrote about in "The Oregon Trail" more than a hundred years ago.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., and Atlantic and Gulf Coast dry cargo and passenger ship operators made some progress yesterday on a new contract. The present agreement expires Wednesday midnight.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today set 1956 wheat price supports at the lowest dollar level since 1946. Congressional Democrats immediately accused him of trying to destroy the farm program.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Scott McLeod, State Department security chief, said today he still would have final authority over the controversial refugee program despite the appointment of a new program chief.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Gordon Gray, long an office holder in the Truman Administration, was named by President Eisenhower today Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Administration opened a drive today to dislodge its bogged-down Reserves training program by hooking it to a pending four-year draft extension bill.
John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co of Boston, Mass., office space in the Wurlitzer Building, 120 W 42d St -- Julien J. Studley, broker.
Stocks opened weak yesterday, steadied during the morning and then climbed toward the end of the session. They gave a good show of power just before the close.

CHERBOURG, France, June 10 (AP) -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov sailed for New York today aboard the liner Queen Elizabeth after a twelve-hour delay caused by Britain's strike wave. He is en route to the tenth anniversary meeting of the United Nations in San Francisco.
BLACKWELL, Okla., June 10 -- A final drive was under way here today to clear out tons of debris that still remained in the wake of the tornado that smashed into Blackwell two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A move to cushion the impact of last year's increase in the United States tariff on Swiss watches was announced today by the State Department.

Ontario's Progressive Conservatives swept to an overwhelming victory in the elections in Ontario Province on Thursday. The only surprise in the election was that the results conformed so closely to the predictions. The Conservatives now have eighty-three of the ninety-eight seats in the Legislative Assembly.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Eisenhower signed today the compromise bill to give an average 8 per cent increase in pay to 500,000 postal field workers.
The guaranteed annual wage does not solve the problem of unemployment, Dr. Jules Backman, Professor of Economics at New York University, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The United States is "very actively" considering whether to ask the Russians to remove their troops from Rumania and Hungary when the occupation of Austria is ended.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- So many plan to travel abroad on credit that President Eisenhower was forced today to ask for more money to handle the rush of passport applications.

The disclosure that the Immigration and Naturalization Service has reversed its previous policy and is again throwing into jail aliens held while their cases are pending calls for a frank explanation by whoever is responsible. As reported in our news columns on Thursday, seven such are now incarcerated in the federal prison on West Street.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 -- There is a bright star rising in the Chilean political skies: Brig. Gen. Eduardo Yanez Zavala.

MANCHESTER, N. H., June 10 (AP) -- Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New Haven Railroad, proposed today formation of a single authority uniting all the New England ports.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Hoover Commission will recommend to Congress that the rates of all Federal power projects be raised to cover costs that private companies must pay.
An unofficial stretching of hands across the sea was described yesterday by an Army sergeant, who told of a project to aid German orphans.

Atomic energy applied to vacuum cleaners may lighten the homemaker's cleaning lot in about ten years.
A plucky upper West Side physician was beaten into submission with a pistol butt and shoe last night by a woman "patient" and two men seeking narcotics -- but not before he put up a determined fight.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The rise brought the index, based on the 1947-49 level as 100, to 100.3.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 10 -- No preachment or counsel for the college graduate in June was intended, but marriage got some attention last night at Brandeis University's third Festival of the Creative Arts.
HONG KONG, June 10 -- Red China still holds that negotiations with the United States to "ease tension" in the Formosa area cannot be based on the "prerequisite" of a cease-fire.

The power to deny visas to Western reporters wishing to visit the Soviet Union has been one of the Kremlin's chief weapons in maintaining the Iron Curtain. Moscow is an important news center, yet at most times during the past decade there have been fewer than a dozen non-Communist correspondents in that capital, others being kept out by the Soviet Government's refusal to grant a visa.
From your editorial of May 20 entitled "Italy Stands Firm" I quote: * * * "perhaps not knowing what little real power the Italian President exercises" * * *.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 10 -- Princeton University's eight crew members of the class of 1910 rowed again today and made it look easy.
GUILFORD COLLEGE, N. C., June 10 (AP) -- Residents expressed shock today over the unexpected dynamiting Wednesday night of the Revolutionary Oak in New Garden Cemetery here.
BONN, Germany, June 10 -- The Government's bill for raising volunteers for the new armed forces was criticized in the Bundesrat today as vague and imprecise.

Readers who applauded The New York Times' editorial position against holding deportation detainees in prison will be interested in the circumstances surrounding the arrest and imprisonment of Cedric Belfrage, British-born editor of the weekly National Guardian.

BERLIN, June 10 -- East Germany's Communist Government is contemplating three-year universal conscription and increased emphasis on heavy industry to spur rearmament. Simultaneously an intensive recruiting drive has been opened to overcome widespread resistance to military service.

Cola G. Parker, chairman of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, has been nominated for the presidency of the National Association of Manufacturers. His election is regarded as certain at the annual meeting of the association's board of directors in December.
Two men were injured when they tried to escape from the police who had surprised them assertedly ransacking an apartment at 1325 Park Avenue near 101st Street at 1:30 P. M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Thomas E. Dewey re-entered New York's fight for state authority to develop Niagara power resources today in the face of a strong bid by private utilities for the $400,000,000 project.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Grain futures showed a stronger tone today, but trade was still small. In wheat there was a disposition to stay on the sidelines pending the June crop estimate, issued after the close.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 10 -- A closing sprint that Cornell was unable to match carried Pennsylvania's finest crew in years to victory on Cayuga Lake today. It will go to the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association at Syracuse next week as the definite favorite.

PARIS, June 10 -- When Moscow annulled the Anglo-Soviet and Franco-Soviet treaties of alliance on May 8 it seemed as if the Kremlin, in a pique, was slamming the barn door after the West German horse had already escaped into NATO. Communist propaganda had long been warning the French Parliament that the wartime treaties would be denounced if Germany's rearmament was approved.
Alexander H. Cohen verified yesterday a report that he had withdrawn as producer of the forthcoming "Cyprienne," the Dorothy Monet adaptation of Victorien Sardou's "Divorcons."
CHICAGO, June 10 -- The Illinois Supreme Court denied a rehearing today on its decision requiring Montgomery Ward Co. to elect all nine of its directors every year.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Harry Lev, Chicago cap manufacturer, told his groggy Senate investigators today that they ought to give him "a Congressional medal."
GENEVA, June 10 -- The International Labor Organization is seriously threatened by the quarrel over how to treat worker and employer representatives from Communist countries.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- William J. Montgomery, Lakewood, Ohio industrialist and investor who was elected a director of the Chicago and North Western Railway last month, was chosen a member of the railroad's finance committee today, official sources reported.

PARIS, June 10 (UP) -- Don Bisplinghoff, a young Florida golfer who came to Europe to prove he should have been on the United States Walker Cup team, and France's Henri de Lamaze, the defending champion, gained the final of the French amateur championship today.

Rowland, chairman of the Art Department at Johns Hopkins University, will speak at a celebration marking two notable events in Mason's life.
OTTAWA -- The country immortalized in Longfellow's epic poem, "Evangeline" this summer will commemorate the 200th anniversary of the expulsion of the Acadians from their settlements in Nova Scotia.
LIMA, Peru, June 11 -- Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez, president of Venezuela, completed a week's goodwill visit to Peru and left today for Caracas, his capital.

EUROPEAN travel is approximately as difficult nowadays as commuting or going on a Sunday picnic. But a little over a hundred years ago it was an adventure, and each trip was an expedition. A look at travel literature of the Eighteen Thirties shows that the problems have changed not in kind but in degree.

SET in Lebanon shortly after World War I this is part outdoor story, part family and part mystery. It tells of the growing friendship of an English girl, an Arab boy and four American boys. There's also a puppy and an unusual governness, a sort of down-to-earth Mary Poppins. Most of the action takes place around a strange ruined house on Crystal Mountain where the children picnic and explore.

NIAGARA FALLS -- A succession of crises within the year, in and around the famous cataract here -- traditionally the most frequented honeymoon resort on this continent -- should only whet the appetite of sight-seers for the place, in the opinion of Falls authorities.

The annual Blue Grass Ball, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, will be held in the Persian Room of the Plaza on Sept. 29. Committee members have been meeting at the Plaza recently to plan the event.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Tradition to the contrary, Vermont is not entirely a bucolic paradise. It has its eccentrics, its snobs and its local super-patriots. It has deer poachers in its forests, and divorce cases in its courts, although it has less of this kind of trouble than most places.
LONDON, June 11 -- Great Britain announced three months ago a "complete overhaul of our home defense plans" as a result of the development of the hydrogen bomb as a war weapon.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 11 (AP) -- Ten athletes in track suits formed the guard of honor today as Dr. Roger Bannister married Moyra Elver Jacobsson, a Swedish portrait painter. Bannister was the first man to run a mile under 4 minutes.

A 7,000-ton passenger-auto ferry boat, the Princess of Vancouver, arrived last week at Victoria, B. C. She went into drydock at Esquimalt on Vancouver Island to permit repainting of ner bottom and thorough inspection of her engines after a 9,000-mile voyage.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- Mr. Krishna Menon conferred for ninety minutes today with Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General. THIS week a dream comes true for the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc. For many years the group has hoped to have an All-State Flower Show, and on Thursday it will become a reality.

President Eisenhower at Penn State University yesterday made what is certainly the most unusual and possibly the most important commencement address that has been delivered in our long academic and oratorical history. To a graduating class be unfolded a major national and international policy program, some of which will shortly be submitted to Congress.

CONCORD, N. H. --- The cost of a vacation has leveled off in New Hampshire in recent years, but everything else -- in quantity and quality -- has continued to go straight up. Nashua won the $119,800 Belmont Stakes by nine lengths at Belmont Park yesterday. The favored Belair Stud colt paid $2.30 for $2. He was ridden by Eddie Arcaro. Blazing Count was second in the mile-and-a-half race and Portersville third.
The ice-cold lemonade industry in The Netherlands is hot, and getting hotter.

It is encouraging for the coffee-producing countries to read in such an important organ of inter-American public opinion as The New York Times the opportune editorial which appeared in its edition of June 1. It begins with the significant observation that the news of a Latin-American agreement to take steps to stabilize the price of coffee will be received with interest and sympathy in the United States.

THE controversy over pay-as-you-see television took an intriguing technical turn last week with the proposal of Paramount Pictures to transmit simultaneously two pictures from a single station. The proposal was made Thursday night to the Federal Communications Commission.
CHICAGO, June 11 (UP) -- Prof. George W. Hartmann, 51 years old, head of the Roosevelt University psychology department, hanged himself in a closet of his home today.

A year ago at this time, when business men assembled, the principal topic of discussion was likely to be, "How far can we expect the recession to carry?" or "Have we touched bottom? And if so, where do we go from here?" In strange contrast to that recent atmosphere of uncertainty concerning the future was the state of mind that pervaded a typical gathering of the same kind in this city last week.
FURTHER proof, if any were needed, that television and the film industry have long since been married came in this week's announcement of plans for the summer series on Lux Video Theatre.

PARIS, June 11 -- Behind the resistance of continental nations to Britain's proposed steps toward freer exchange of currencies lies the conviction that Europe must retain its preferential trade system.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- An expanded resort-promotion program, a new summer theatre in Sharon, a new 400-acre dude ranch in Newtown and a remarkably full calendar of summer events, including a week-long centennial celebration in Putnam and the opening of the long-awaited American Shakespeare Theatre at Stratford, are a few of the items which might appropriately be listed under the heading of what's new in old Connecticut.

LOS ANGELES -- This is the time of year when motorists in this region divert their children by challenging them to spot two successive passing cars with license plates from the same states. The vacation stampede is on, and the Pacific Southwest has slipped again into its accustomed role of playground to the nation.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., June 11 -President Eisenhower proposed today to remove two obstacles from the "broad avenue of world progress" toward a more abundant life through peaceful uses of atomic energy.
CAIRO, June 11 -- The Egyptian-Israeli frontier is like a fused powder keg on which both parties sit glaring, each betting that the other will run away first.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11 -- Forty-five hundred delegates, including housewives, educators, clergymen, business men and generals, will take part in the thirtieth national American Red Cross convention that opens here Monday.

The New York Pioneer Club squad thwarted the New York Athletic Club's bid for its thirty-seventh straight team title by taking the senior Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union track and field crown yesterday.

DETROIT, June 11 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers spotted the Boston Red Sox a five-run lead today, but rallied for a 7-5 victory. The relief pitching of Werner Birrer and timely hitting by Al Kaline and Ferris Fain paced the Tigers triumph.

THE "blue line" that encircles the Great North Woods, or Adirondack Park, is primarily of cartographic interest. But the chromatic variety of greens that daub this area of wilderness and scenic grandeur each year is an enchantment to millions of vacationists.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Swaps raced to victory in the $109,800 Californian at Hollywood Park today and set a world record for a mile and a sixteenth.
The American Civil Liberties Union asked Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson yesterday to withdraw a pamphlet, "How to Spot a Communist."

ART-LOVER, bibliophile, conversationalist extraordinaire, litterateur, government emissary, speculator, mathematician, drama patron, and above all, master economist, John Maynard Keynes was truly a figure of Renaissance proportions in a twentieth-century setting.

LONDON, June 11 -- A message from President Eisenhower to the Consultative Conference of Jewish Organizations today praised the contribution of its participants to "the development of understanding and respect between peoples of differing persuasions."

A grandmother and poet, Mrs. Liboria B. Romano, will be graduated from Hunter College Thursday. She became a "college girl" after she had reared her family of three sons and seen them happily married and starting families of their own.

THE city of Mantua is borrowing the America idea of presenting statuettes for outstanding performances in the arts. But its statue will not have a folksy name like "Oscar," "Emmy" or "Tony." It will be an "Orpheus" -- or, to give the full Italian title, an "Orfeo d'Oro."
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- Two meet records fell as three Penn State athletes dominated the Middle Atlantic Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The United States and the Soviet Union, who are not only the most powerful but the least experienced of the Great Powers, are about to enter into the most important series of negotiations since the war.
PARIS, June 11 -- According to Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, Minister of Defense, the French Government has proof that Communists have infiltrated the nationalist guerrillas in Algeria.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- The "vanishing Indians" seemed like a good appellation for the Tribe of Al Lopez when the Yankees sprinted to five quick runs in the first inning today. At this moment Municipal Stadium had the appearance of a morgue. Some two hours later the entire picture had changed.

BERLIN, June 3 -- The Hamburg newspaper Die Welt is seeking printing facilities to bring out an edition in Berlin. It would be the first nationally circulated private newspaper to be printed in Berlin since World War II.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 11 -- The dainty laces worn and accumulated by early generations of the Gardiner family on their island off eastern Long Island are being shown to the public this year for the first time.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 11 -- Former President Truman in a preview of the 1956 campaign called tonight for the election of a Democratic Administration to turn back the "tricky and devious" private raiders on public power.
TWELVE denominations of United States stamps which are new to the current regular series inaugurated last year are to be released during the coming month, it was announced last week in Washington.

IN this somewhat rambling but always absorbing historiical novel Don Tracy gives his readers a finely spun tale about a brandy-swilling English pirate, Edward Teach, better known to the more odious annals of freebootery as Black-beard.
HAIFA, Israel, June 8 -- Three new plants at Fertilizers Chemicals Ltd., entering production this week, moved Israel another leg along the journey to self-sufficiency.
St. John's University will award degrees to 1,300 students at 4 P.M. today in the Second Corps Artillery Armory, Eighth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn.

This month the vanguard of 800 "Ford scholars" is being graduated from colleges all over the country, and a preliminary evaluation of the "early admissions" project which this group represents is now possible.

Name-calling is a handy tool of many to whom children in trouble with the law are "hoods" and "yoots" who should be thrown into jail or have their heads shaved as object lessons. But venom never got results, as social and Youth Board workers helping to turn delinquent youths into good citizens can testify.

The crucial point in Thomas P. Whitney's exceptionally perceptive article on factors that will shape Russian diplomacy at the forthcoming Big Four conferences -- "What We Can Expect of the Russians" (May 22 ) -- is contained in his anecdote about the reception for General Eisenhower in the American Embassy in Moscow in August, 1945.
DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- For the second time within seventy-two hours the Detroit Tigers paid a reported $35,000 today to sign a youngster to a major league bonus contract.
People who stash their excess cash away in mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations have been digging into their deposits and withdrawing some sizable chunks.

EIGHTEEN photographers of the documentary school and one pictorialist are included in a group show which opened last week-end at A Photographer's Gallery, 48 West Eighty-fourth Street. The prints will hang through Aug. 27.

MEN and women of the United Nations specialized agencies -- experts in public health, social welfare, agriculture and engineering -- are carrying their skills and knowledge to underdeveloped areas around the world. They go on the invitation of the governments in these areas, on the greatest adventure of all -- helping mankind.
A suggested selling range of 50 to 60 cents a pound for green coffee delivered in New York Harbor has been recommended by the International Coffee Bureau.
BOSTON, June 11 -- Ernest R. Breech, chairman of the board of Ford Motor Company, said today that the new Ford labor contract was a good thing for the workers, the company and the entire nation.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 11 -- A Sealyham terrier, Ch. Robin Hill Brigade, owned by Mrs. Robert B. Choate of Danvers, Mass., was named best in the Greenwich Kennel Club show today. Joe Thompson handled the winner. Walter H. Reeves, Canadian all-arounder, judged.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, today closed hearings on alleged graft in military uniform purchases. He said that Harry Lev, Chicago hat maker, "has failed" to disprove charges he had paid $50,000 in bribes to a suspended Air Force captain.

BEAVER, W. Va. -- The biggest show in West Virginia is an open-air theatre of wonder known as the Canyon of New River. "Folks go crazy when we park at scenic lookout points," a driver of one of the big through-state buses said recently.

THIS season's candidate as "the real Shakespeare" is Marlowe of the mighty line. The idea of him as the gentle bard makes one gasp like Little Red Ridinghood, "Why, Grandma, what big teeth you have!" Did he wither and grow sweet? Or should we reappraise Rosalind, Cordelia and Miranda as Marlovian superwomen, fit mates for Tamburlaine, Faustus and the Jew of Malta?
ROME, June 11 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII urged the world's oil-rich nations, in a speech made public today, to share their wealth with less favored peoples.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Business recovery continues through most sectors of the economy in the Third District. Retail sales, construction, particularly in home building, and weekly earnings of factory workers all reflect a rising trend that first appeared last midyear.

A REVIVAL of what might be termed the "pioneer spirit" is becoming apparent among a large percentage of anglers and hunters who are planning to set up their own fishing and hunting camps this summer and fall.
Thousands of "cured" patients are crowding the country's men-mental hospitals because they have not been fitted to hold a job.

Bank Street College of Education, a private institution in New York City, has received a grant from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education to institute a new pattern of graduate teacher training designed to help alleviate the nation's critical teacher shortage.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- John J. Mullen, director of political action for the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., denied today that he was or ever had been a member of the Communist party.

CERTAIN of the greatest criminal cases have been treated so often and so well that able writers shy away from them, fearing that there is nothing more to be said. But Edgar Lustgarten, with casual audacity, selects four of the most familiar of all murder trials in THE WOMAN IN THE CASE (Scribner's, $3) and proves that a combination of insight and virtuosity can make the tritest material seem fresh.

If a lower East Side boy runs hard enough, long enough and keeps his eye firmly enough on his goal of being a great merchant banker, he can grow up to hand around scores of millions of dollars among industrialists and investors.

DETROIT, June 11 -- Following are the texts of a letter sent today from Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, and John W. Livingston, vice president of the union, to Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, and Mr. Curtice's reply:
WALTHAM, Mass., June 11 -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared today that Americans had lost the "spirit which founded America."

LAUREL, Md., June 11 (AP) -The English Jockey Club has given its official sanction to the Washington (D. C.) International at the Laurel race course and will help John D. Schapiro, the track president, pick England's representative in next fall's race.

HUMMELSTOWN, Pa. -- Pennsylvania's nine commercial caverns, which attract around 200,000 visitors in a summer, are so scattered about the state that on almost any trip into Pennsylvania the motorist is likely to find one or more of them within close range.

"NOT houses finely roofed or stones of walls well builded, nay, nor canals nor dockyards make the city, but men able to use their opportunity." Thus wrote Alcaeus in the sixth century B. C. and, guided by the wisdom of these words, Freya Stark -- repeating somehow her tour de force of "Perseus in the Wind" -- has managed to bring alive the long-dead and nearly forgotten civilization of Ionia.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 11 (AP) -- Lester Frazier, a 25-yearold Kansas University graduate, took the lead today in the Olympic Development Eastern decathlon.

CINCINNATI, June ll--"The law and the press stand today as the public's chief bulwark against the march of secrecy in public affairs geflerally," J. 'W. Wiggins, managing editor of The Washington Post and Times Herald, told a seven-state American Bar Associatior meeting toi day.
AMHERST, Mass., June 11 -- Sabrina, wandering 300-pound bronze statue that has been an object of class rivalry at Amherst since the Eighteen Eighties, returned to the college today.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A $25,000,000 five-year study of "community air pollution" was proposed today by an interdepartmental Federal committee created last December.
The Knights of Columbus will open the recreational facilities of its Long Island City, Queens, clubhouse to the Police Athletic League to help combat juvenile delinquency.

VACATIONISTS desiring the comforts of home on the road are turning to trailer travel in increasing numbers. This mode of touring is expected to reach new highs this summer with thousands of the mobile homes taking to the highways.

AS long ago as the first century A. D. the Roman Governor of Judea, Archelaus, asked by a prating barber how he would be trimmed, replied snappishly, "In silence!" This little exchange, reported by Plutarch, marks the first known instance of man's rebellion in the barber chair.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 11 (Reuters) -- Workmen are going into action throughout Alaska to complete $97,000,000 worth of defense construction projects during the few months before the autumn freeze stops work.

A 7-2 victory in the final match gave Salle Santelli the women's team title in the national fencing championships last night at the Fencers Club. The week-long event continues today with the men's saber competition on the same strips.
New contract demands will be pressed tomorrow by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., at a meeting with major East and Gulf Coast tanker operators.

Two new members have been elected to serve seven-year terms on the twenty-five-member Barnard College board of trustees. They are Robert L. Hoguet Jr., vice president of the First National City Bank, and Robert S. Hutchins, architect and partner in the firm of Moore Hutchins.

FRED, his sister Janey, and friend Hank of "Deer Mountain Hideaway" are back again in more brisk adventures. At the opening of the fishing season, Fred and Hank are intent on building a raft to cross to the island in Deer River where they can camp out.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- A guaranteed annual wage is ancient history in Chicago. Twenty years ago when the big depression was still a national headache, the William Wrigley Jr. Company put into effect such a wage, though it called it "income assurance."

PITTSBURGH, June 11 (UP) -- Billy Bruton and Johnny Logan hit successive home runs in the ninth inning today to drive in three runs. These led the Milwaukee Braves to a 7-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Five days of academic ceremony and social celebration will begin here tomorrow with the start of Harvard University's Commencement Week.
In an attempt to improve the medical care of its people, the Government of Pakistan is working for closer ties with this country's medical profession.

One thing is certain, that the weather has nothing to do with it. For Dr. Bernhard Haurwitz, chairman of the Department of Meteorology and Oceanography at New York University, is an inveterate hiker, rain or shine.

Frank Sullivan's interesting and amusing article on the Monday Holiday Plan -- "The Unlost Week-End -- Three Days" (May 29) -- suggests that the early Thanksgiving idea of President Roosevelt was a failure. This has turned out to be not so.
A large quantity of furniture and two fine sets of Paris tapestries, antedating the Gobelin manufactory, will be auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday at Convent, N. J.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 11 -- An archaeological find in Nevada indicates that men lived there at least 23,800 years ago, the Southwest Museum reported today.

TEX, whose full name is Francis Lexington Jr., is graduated from high school with mediocre grades and the belief that a rich man's son deserves special privileges, a fast sports car and a deluxe camping trip to Yosemite.
The women's apparel trade detects the first signs of a major swing back to soft goods in consumer buying.
SYRACUSE, June 11 -- A battered but happy Carmen Basilio was busy today making plans -- for an extended hunting and fishing trip.

The free world is at the threshold of the most stable and promising period since the end of World War II, in the opinion of the economic staff of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
LONDON, June 11 -- Chris Chataway, one of Britain's three four-minute milers, set a British 2,000-meter record today beating the mark made three weeks ago by Gordon Pirie at Manchester.

Striking waiters, bartenders and kitchen employes at the Turf and Jack Dempsey's Restaurants, both at Broadway and Forty-ninth Street, will return to work today under an agreement reached late Friday night.

WHEN the family is about to uproot itself from an established home, bundle into the car and head for far-off places, it must be prepared ahead of time for problems. A proper frame of mind is important before the tour is begun.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 11 -- Despite intermittent showers, more than 4,000 Princeton University alumni turned out today for the colorful parade that marked the climax of Old Nasser's annual class reunions.

THE Chicago Cubs were a sorry excuse for a major league ball club last season. They were so horrendous that even the perpetual smile worn by their manager, Stan Hack, had almost vanished. In spring training this year there was no reason to suspect that The Smiler would be making with the full incandescent glow again.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- As in recent years, an excellent summer tourist season is anticipated for Florida's west coast; indeed, the best ever. Communities, which only a decade ago never dreamed of visitors during July and August, are preparing for a summer rush.
MOSCOW, June 11 -- A contest with an unusual scoring system is now being played in the international political arena. Every time a point is made both sides cheer.

HONG KONG, June 11 -- An American Roman Catholic Bishop, deported on charges of subversion, declared today that Premier Chou En-lai's assertion of religious freedom in Communist China was "absolutely false."

WELLSBORO, Pa. -- Once a year this town goes in for one of those big rousing civic festivals calculated to publicize a community's fair name and ginger up the tourist trade. Usually the excuse for such a thing is the glorification of a local product or possibly an event connected with nature -- the flowering of something or its harvesting.

LONDON, June 11 -Clement R. Attlee, Labor party leader, told a miners' rally in Northumberland today that the Labor movement was not depressed over its defeat at the general election. The Conservative victory was based on foundations laid by the last Labor Government, he said.
A labor arbitrator ruled yesterday on hurricanes and vacations.

DESIGNATE June 27 as B-for-Buffalo Day. In South Dakota's Custer State Park, cameras will be turned on 1,500 buffalo, the largest herd in this country, for sequences in Metro - Goldwyn-Mayer's outdoor project, "The Last Hunt."

A GOOD number of Ludwig Lewisohn's sixteen novels seem to be dedicated to his proposition that the "relations between the sexes constitute the deepest and sorest problem of American life." Continuing to explore this proposition, he turns "In a Summer Season" into a wreckage-strewn battlefield where humans mangle one another emotionally -- in and out of marriage.

By the end of next week the largest cruiser starting fleet in East Coast history will have been assembled. This will be for the Huckins Memorial predicted log race on Long Island Sound on June 25. The start and finish will be the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club waters at Port Washington and the Port Jefferson Y. C. down to the eastward.

Donald Lipton, 11 years old, decided the time had come to expand his thriving lawn-mowing business in Hollywood. He was cutting six lawns a week at $1 each. With a power mower, he could step that up to fifteen lawns a week.

Two critics from musical magazines heard first performances of their compositions at yesterday's "Twilight" concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. They were Ezra Laderman of The Musical Courier and Marvin Levy of Musical America.
The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Advent, Westbury, L. I., will hold its annual Parish Fair on the church grounds on Jericho Turnpike on Friday from 2 to 6 P. M.

This year's meeting of the American Medical Association, which was held at Atlantic City, N. J., was of unusual interest. The reason is to be found in the discussion of the merits and defects of Dr. Salk's vaccine and in the presentation of statistics that seemed to indicate a cause-and-effect relationship between cigarette smoking and cancer of the lung.

MOZART'S Clarinet Quintet, one of the loveliest of all chamber works, has not lacked representation on LP, but what is in this estimation the finest microgroove version to date comes from London, on a disk played by Alfred Boskovsky and members of the Vienna Octet.
The State Court of Appeals has reversed an assault conviction against John G. (Steve) Broady, a private investigator under indictment in a wiretapping case. A new trial was ordered.

GUARDS for table circular saws are not only considered useless for fine work where blade action must be seen, but they are optional equipment on most saws, even though a number of workshop accidents are traced to unguarded power saws.
TED SHAWN'S annual festival at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass., has become not only the largest dance event of the summer season but also one of the most important of our native institutions.
Several physicians' groups in New Jersey, mostly in Union County, indicated yesterday that they felt the administration of Salk anti-polio vaccine should be postponed.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 11 -- A commencement speaker at Seton Hall University urged today that its new medical and dental schools "avoid like a contagious disease any solicitation of Federal aid."

ELIZABETHTOWN, N. Y. -- History, geology and folklore of the Adirondack Mountains have been gathered at Elizabethtown at the recently opened Adirondack Center. Sponsored by the Essex County Historical Society, the collection is largely the work of the center's newly appointed curator and county historian, Mrs. Marjorie Porter.
Fifty-six corporation executives from this country and abroad will convene today at Columbia University's Arden House at Harriman, N. Y.

THE first camera-cycle train to set forth from New York for the Berkshire Hills in fifteen years is scheduled for next Sunday. About 500 photographers and bicyclists are expected to be on the one-day outing.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 6 -- Another chapter in the dispute that followed one of history's most spectacular cases of art forgery was punctuated with the death in Switzerland last week of Daniel-Georges van Beuningen, a renowned Dutch industrialist and art collector.

CHISELS and other tools with sharp edges can be stored in a tool box without fear of dulling or accidental cutting when an unwary hand reaches for something in the cluttered bottom of the chest. Simply cut a piece of cellophane tape a bit longer than the width of the blade and then fold the tape over, not against the cutting edge but about 1/16 of an inch beyond.

IN our family, which we like to believe is typical of most American households, a sort of war was carried on for several years over the big question of where to go on the annual summer vacation. Eventually we hit on our Five Year Vacation Plan, truly an inspiration, which restored domestic tranquility, provided for more comman interests and promoted in general a new appreciation of the wonders of our country.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 11 -- Former President Truman said today he might address the tenth commemorative session of the United Nations in San Francisco.

BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- President Juan D. Peron's current No. 1 opponent, the Roman Catholic Church, displayed its strength today. In defiance of a Government ban, at least 100,000 Catholics held a six-hour demonstration.

Since many New Yorkers are confused about the boundary between Manhattan and the Bronx it is no surprise to see a Parisienne confused. The picture "Subway Snooze" by Sabine Weiss was taken in Manhattan, not the Bronx.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- Previously expressed disapproval from student and faculty quarters failed to manifest itself as Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas made the main commencement address at the University of Southern California today.
PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, the state with the smallest area and longest name, is ideal for vacationists or tourists who like variety within short distances.

A REPORT that Thai school children are to be taught to shake hands caused quite a stir in Bangkok recently. The traditional "wai" greeting (palms pressed together at brow level when greeting a superior, at chest level for an inferior) is "old- fashioned," some Thais alleged; shaking hands would give "a more modern outlook."

NEW HAVEN, June 11 -- Yale University announced today its 245th commencement program. It will begin tomorrow at 11 A. M. The president, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, will deliver the baccalaureate address in Woolsey Hall.

CONCORD, N. H. -- High up in Vermont's Green and New Hampshire's White Mountains, thousands of feet above the buzz of vacation traffic, there is a world of alpine trails and lightheaded effort and pure air, of lean-to's and log cabins and solitude.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks hurled his fourth straight victory today as the Chicago White Sox triumphed over the Washington Senators, 10 9 Chicago scored four runs in the first inning.

IN an unlikely road company including Helen Hayes, Mary Martin and Florence Reed, booked to fly to Paris on Friday, there is an actor who last acted twenty-one years ago. He is, nevertheless, reasonably well known in the theatre.
CINCINNATI, June 11 -- In the little cemetery adjoining the church where he worshiped during his visits home, a bronze plaque has been erected in memory of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

ALONG with British Henry Moore the Swiss-born Alberto Giacometti is perhaps one of the two most controversial figures in sculpture today. In putting on the first comprehensive museum exhibition of his work -- paintings and drawings besides sculpture -- James Johnson Sweeney continues his program at the Guggenheim Museum of bringing forward the most controversial work of the time.

FOR the first time since the Indian wars, America has "live frontiers" -- frontiers of the sky and the sea -- exposed to serious assault by enemy aircraft, missile-firing submarines and guided missiles with nuclear warheads.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- "Remember, I promised to serve with honor" is the slogan displayed conspicuously in the City Hall office of Morris B. Sachs, the City Treasurer.
Neither rain nor the Chicago Cubs could stop the rampaging Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday. Despite more than an hour's interruption, the affair went the limit, with the Brooks winning, 4 -- 3.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., June 11 -- The solidly entrenched Republicans in Suffolk County were on notice today that the purely local character of the county elections this fall might undergo a change.

England's railway strike gave early arriving American tourists a hard time in that country, but the shipping strike last week made the shipping situation in New York -- normally a peak of confusion and crowded departures this time of year -- even more confused. Several ships were cancelled on the North Atlantic runs to New York and Canada.

FOR many home workshop projects, doweling is the quickest and most effective method of fastening wood joints. Dowel joints are strong, do not tend to split the wood as metal fasteners sometimes do, and are inexpensive.
