MR. WILLANS is described on the fly-leaf of this, his latest book as "an already recognized master of comedy." Here he has written a treatise on admirals of the upper or NATO category which, despite some frivolous episodes, is a pretty serious thing.

THE natives of Kayseri in central Turkey are renowned or sharpness. Once the Devil, having been swindled by a local merchant with whom he had gone into partnership, challenged the Turk to a duel. The fiend had choice of weapons, and picked the longest pole. But the merchant, allowed to choose the battleground, placed the Devil in front of a hidden well and quickly backed him into it.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 11 -- The Formosa Strait no more has a cease-fire than it ever has had Communist-NationaIist warfare. In the last year there have been artillery, naval and aviation skirmishes along the coast of China, occasionally punctuated with an isolated action of somewhat larger scope.

TELEVISION, which has flirted with ballet only momentarily, will allot a ninety-minute program to the art Dec. 12. And in prime evening time, too, paid for by sponsors interested in the widest possible audience.
Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, assailed yesterday the Immigration Department's "reprehensible practice" of jailing aliens awaiting the outcome of deportation proceedings.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 11 (Reuters) -- A long-term plan for the development of education, health, irrigation, agriculture, industry and social welfare in Iraq has been approved by the Iraqi Cabinet.

A special effort should be made to relieve the financial problems of rapidly growing suburban communities, State Controller Arthur Levitt said last week. Mr. Levitt, former president of the New York City Board of Education, suggested that the Legislature might consider at its next session a revision of the present method of allocating state aid for general purposes.
The winning of his fifth $100,000 added race of the year was an easy bit of business for the Belair Stud's Nashua yesterday at Belmont Park.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Next week United States diplomacy enters the most intensive period of consultation and negotiation since the start of the "cold war."

THE airplane has been offering the tourist some wonderfully unfamiliar views of the world. Since last summer, the Arctic's awesome landscapes have been brought within range of the everyday traveler by two commercial airlines.

TRENTON, N. J. -- New Jersey will spend $1,248,000 during the fiscal year beginning July 1 mostly to mostly and expand facilities in several of its state parks and recreational areas. A small part of the money will be set aside to provide for the restoration of historic sites.
The hopes of the German people for unification are unsatisfied today, ten years after the war.
TRENTON, June 11 -- The New Jersey Legislature recessed Thursday, but it will reconvene Aug. 8 to consider plans for alleviating the state's serious shortage of potable water.
Golf's most important championship, the United States open, will be played at the Olympic Club, San Francisco, starting Thursday.

The naming of Gordon Gray as Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs is a splendid appointment. It will be welcomed throughout the country as one of the best choices that this Administration has made for an important and sensitive post.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board said today it was permissable for unions or employers to lie to workers in trying to convince them to vote for or against a union.

SIR ANTHONY EDEN chose his moment for the recent British general election with great skill. Prospects for a lessening of international tension were at their peak with top-level talks in sight. At home the Conservative Government had been helped by shifts in world prices favorable to Britain.

The Kosciusko Foundation's sixth annual $1,000 Chopin scholarship was won by Daniel Pollack, 20-year-old pianist from Los Angeles. Last Monday he was named a winner of the young artists contest of the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
OSSINING, N. Y., June 11 -- Sixty young deacons were ordained at Maryknoll Seminary today as priests of the Roman Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Commencement address at Pennsylvania State University yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

The architectural firm (McKim, Mead White) which designed Manhattan's Pennsylvania Railroad Station in 1904 took as their model the ancient Roman Baths of Caracalla and the Basilica of Constantine, which they considered the best examples in history of large, roofed-in structures for public use.

OTTAWA -- The special combination of assets which makes Ottawa an interesting place to live also makes it an attractive place to visit. As the capital of the second largest country in the world, it has an impressive collection of public buildings, many of which are built in Gothic style.

NOORDWIJK, The Netherlands, June 11 (AP) -- The International Lawn Tennis Club of the United States led the International Club of the Netherlands today, 7 -- 1, at the end of the second day's play in their twelve-match series.
SILVER BAY, Minn., June 11 -- Forty-three years ago a young mathematics instructor at the University of Minnesota was assigned a seemingly impossible task.

ATLANTIC CITY -- New Jersey's more than fifty shore resorts, scattered along 120 miles of coastline from Sandy Hook at the north to Cape May Point at the south, are prepared to house and entertain a record number of vacationists and week-end visitors. Advance reports seem to justify the optimism. Most shore-side communities, large and small, began entertaining holiday-bound folk in late April although they did not officially open their summer season until Memorial Day.

ROBERT MITCHUM is a big man with as polished a veneer of cynicism as one might hope to find in a business sometimes termed a "celluloid asylum." When he was recently run to earth, a few hours before he and his wife were to sail to Europe aboard the tramp steamer Fern River, he was politely encouraging a telephone operator to connect him with the West Coast.
Wedding gowns and formals bearing tags showing they meet the modesty requirements set by a Roman Catholic priest, are being made and sold in New York.

Two Kremlin moves last week threw the grand design of Soviet foreign policy into focus more sharply than ever before. One move was the Soviet suggestion that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, go to Moscow to re-establish diplomatic relations.
Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week ran about even with the comparable week last year, with perhaps a slight decline.

THERE are two choruses in the background of this compelling novel. One is nature -- the land and the river and the sky. The other is the steel mill. One is by turns capricious and kind, but consistent. The other is noisy, insatiable, erratic and threatens to overwhelm everything and everyone in its path.

The Marionette Theatre of the Parks Department will begin its summer tour tomorrow and run through Sept. 8. The Park Puppeteers have scheduled eighty-nine performances of "Hansel and Gretel" at sixty-nine parks and playgrounds in five boroughs.
SARANAC LAKE -- More than $2,000,000 has been spent in new building in the Adirondacks in the last year.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: It isn't too late to plant annuals for bloom this summer. Seed of portulaca and Lilliput zinnia come along quickly and so do the quick and short blooming candytuft, Phlox drummondi, nigella and poppies. Calendula and sunflower seeds can be sown this month for late summer flowers.

STANTON, Del., June 11 (AP) -- Saratoga, a temperamental but classy colt from Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott's Montpelier establishment in Orange, Va., today earned the biggest purse of his career by splashing to a half-length triumph in the $48,085 Leonard Richards Stakes at Delaware Park.

LONDON, June 11 -- Efforts today to end the strike of 67,000 locomotive men failed. Day-long talks were held between the British Transport Commission and the Associated Society of Locomotive Engineers and Firemen.

PARIS, June 11 -- Henri de Lamaze, a man who knows every knoll and sand spit on his home Chantilly course, won the French amateur golf championship today for the sixth time. The 36-year-old Paris businessman defeated Don Bisplinghoff of Orlando, Fla., 5 and 4.

ROME, June 11 -- The Sicilian regional elections resulted in a great triumph for the Christian Democrats. Premier Mario Scelba can rightly claim a share in this triumph, having participated actively in the campaign. His position at the head of the Italian Government may, therefore, be considered to have improved. But it is still shaky and insecure.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Charles Bacon of New York, a member of the 1908 Olympic track team. was elected president of the United States Olympians today.

Entries will close tomorrow for the first separate specialty show on Long Island for dachshunds in ten years. The event will be run by the Dachshund Association of Long Island on the Phipps polo field at Old Westbury on June 25. The Foley Organization of Philadelphia is handling the entries.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 11 -- They were going 3,450 nautical miles to Marstrand, Sweden, in the first trans-Atlantic race from the United States mainland in twenty years. That didn't prevent the skippers of the seven yachts of three countries from hitting the starting line today with a precision not always matched in mere week-end triangular events.

DESPITE the advances in kinds of paint and equipment in the past few years, the work involved in getting ready to dip the first brushful and in cleaning and storing brushes after the job is done is still mostly the same as it's always been.

Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf will be the sponsor of the Second International Powder Metallurgical Congress to take place in Reutte, Tyrol, Austria, from June 20 to June 23. He will lecture on "High Temperature Materials by Powder Metallurgy." Other lecturers will come from Germany, France, Austria, England, Sweden Switzerland, Holland, Liechtenstein and the United States.

APRIL and May are the big months for setting out or sowing annuals. But within a few short weeks after planting, other chores which affect their growing will come to the gardener's attention. Though simplicity is the keynote in the care of annuals, a routine is advisable, the same one basically that any well-tended garden area would need and receive.

CASEY McKEE arrives at Uncle Bounce's for a visit just after the house has been raided. Nothing of value has been stolen but a packing case of trinkets from Afghanistan is missing -- also a broken Mickey Mouse watch, a fountain pen, a comic book and a deck of cards.

LE MANS, June 11 (AP) -- The entire Mercedes-Benz team withdrew from the Le Mans twenty-four-hour road race tonight as a gesture of mourning for Pierre Levegh, a French driver for the company, who died in the crash.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 11 (AP) -- The defending champion, Allan Morris of Atlanta, scored an upset by beating the Mexican champion. Gustavo Palafox, in the Blue-Gray tennis tournament today.

In Detroit last week Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, and John S. Bugas, vice president of the Ford Motor Company, held a press conference. They had just agreed on a contract giving Ford workers a modified "guaranteed annual wage." These exchanges took place:

TWO years ago a scabby crew of latter-day pirates shuffled before the State Crime Commission to give reluctant testimony on waterfront rackets. Their account of conditions in the Port of New York made such legendary hellholes as Calcutta and Marseilles sound like Newport on Regatta Day.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -The Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks, said today that a new round of wage increases in Government and industry might bring some slightly higher prices.
HOUSTON, June 11 (UP) -- A North Texas State collegian stole the spotlight in the Texas Amateur Athletic Union track meet today.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 11 -- The intervention of national party leaders may be necessary to settle a bitter dispute over control of the Republican organization in Missouri. The party gave a slim margin to President Eisenhower in the 1952 election, while the Democratic state ticket swept in by an overwhelming majority.

Secretary Dulles has now officially described the situation in the Formosa area as a de facto cease-fire. This has in fact, been the position for more than two months; the consequent decrease in public interest can be gauged by the absence of any reference to either Formosa or Communist China at the President's press conference Wednesday.

THE smallest fruits of summer are perhaps the best. We refer, of course, to the berries, diverse in flavor and color but uniformly luscious. Strawberries, blueberries and raspberries come to the mind of the city-dwelling cook.

THIS is a good book. It's about the simplest kind of human situation -- simple enough to furnish the plot for a classic drama or a woman's magazine serial. Gladys Schmitt, author of "The Gates of Aulis," has written neither.

IN the newer city apartments, as in country houses, windows are much more prominent than they used to be. Generally they are both taller and broader, and frequently dominate an entire side of a room. For this reason, window treatments now tend to be more decorative than they were not long ago, when floor to ceiling draperies were the rule.
TAICHUNG, Formosa, June 3 -- Something akin to a miracle in budgeting motion pictures is being accomplished here in the studios of the Central Motion Pictures Corporation.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 11 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, former United States tennis champion, became a bride today. She was told by the officiating Catholic Bishop that she had "chosen the better part" -- to become "queen of a home."

When I returned from my first trip to Europe two years ago. I wondered how a European visiting America for the first time would react and what he would find most interesting and different. Sabine Weiss' delightful pictures of my own home town and her enthusiastic comments were an answer to my questions -- "A Parisienne's New Yorkers" (May 29).

IT will soon be festival time in Prades, the little town in the Pyrenees-Orientales section of France near the Spanish border. Friends and admirers of Pablo Casals, the remarkable 78-year-old musician of uncompromising moral integrity, will gather once again to make music with him and to draw inspiration at the deep sources of his knowledge, experience and sensibility.

TUBEROUS-ROOTED begonias are among the handsomest of summer flowers. They bloom in all shades of pink through rose and red, in yellows through apricot and orange besides white and bicolors. For the shaded or semi-shaded spots, they are ideal and will flower all summer.

Much is known about the structure of the universe; far, far more remains to be discovered. It will take thousands, probably millions, of years to explore this great unknown -- so long, in fact, that answers may never be found to searching questions.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Officials of the Atomic Energy Commission said today they expected to have signed twenty atomic energy agreements with foreign countries by June 15.

City College will confer an honorary degree of doctor of laws on Dr. Jonas E. Salk at the 109th commencement exercises Wednesday night. Dr. Salk, a graduate of City College in 1934, also will receive a specially designed medal struck by the college.

The New York Public Library's program of recorded concerts is making its annual move from the Fifth Avenue building to Bryant Park on Wednesday. But, instead of a weekly concert, the library will offer daily musical fare from noon to 2 P.M.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 11 -- The cumulative report of all in-indebtedness for all units of Nassau County's government, published this week by County Controller Theodore Bedell, shows a total of $342,570,922, an increase of $59,000,000 over last year.

ST. MARY'S CITY, Md. -- St. Mary's County is the southernmost in Maryland. It is a watery wedge, squeezed to a tip at Point Lookout where the Potomac River flows into Chesapeake Bay. (Let no one confuse Point Lookout with Point Look-In, about five miles up the bay, or Point No Point, about five miles further.)
A plan to provide practical off-campus experience for faculty members, similar to a work-plus-study plan for students, will be inaugurated this fall at Antioch College.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Government security and press officers are worried about an experiment in peacetime censorship next Wednesday to Friday. They are worried about the problem of preventing "leaks" from small towns and cities when 300 or more Government workers descend on a community, bustle about for three days, then leave in obedience to rules set down for Washington's first drill in operating the Government from emergency headquarters.

GOUNOD'S opera Mireille, just issued by Angel in a three-disk set, is based on Frederic Mistral's epic poem in the Provencal language, "Mireio."' As an opera it exhibits the virtues and shortcomings of Gounod's style.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 7 -- An American who has been fighting the Mau Mau terrorists of Kenya is under State Department pressure to return to the United States.

Dartmouth College has established a program to help combat the great shortage of men trained in mathematics in this country. The shortage exists both in business and industry as well as in various research establishments of the Government.

THE great cities of Europe have undeniable appeal, but a lot can be said for the villages, too. Villages have much that is not found in capitals and the famous resorts. They offer simplicity that is disarming, leisure that is satisfying and charm that leads people to return many times.
A former truck driver last week was named vice president in charge of over-all operations of the country's largest trucking company.
Some East Harlem neighborhood youngsters took a lesson last week on how to care for a $30,000,000 "baby."

BARNSTABLE, Mass. -- A new sports fishing and powerboat center here is expected to uncork the bottlenecks of tides and distances which heretofore have prevented full development of Cape Cod Bay's prolific tuna, striped bass and bottom fishing grounds.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A full investigation of the poliomyelitis vaccine controversy was projected today by the chairman of a Congressional committee.
MORAN, Wyo., June 11 -Laurance S. Rockefeller declared tonight that private capital and philanthropy were unable to finance badly needed accommodations in the nation's overcrowded national parks.

IN his first twenty years as writer of recognized eminence, from 1925 to 1945, Louis Bromfield wrote eighteen books, all fiction. One of the most durable of his novels, "The Farm," written abroad and published in 1933, was in some part autobiographical, a robust lament for the decline of agriculture in the American midland; and "The Farm" belongs on the shelf with the four autobiographical narratives of agricultural regeneration that he has written since 1945.

Thirty women in a beauty parlor found themselves yesterday in a hair-curling situation for which they had not made appointments. A thug bent on a hold-up invaded the place and touched off a wave of hysteria and near-fainting.

TORONTO, June 11 (UP) -- Ace Marine, an $8,500 purchase as a yearling, won the ninety-sixth and richest running of the historic Queen's Plate at Old Woodbine today. He led from start to finish to defeat sixteen of Canada's best 3-year-olds.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Pan American World Airways and New York Airways have filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board a plan, effective July 7, for a helicopter exchange service.

The National Labor Relations Board broke precedent last week in its dismissal of a complaint against employers of longshore labor here. It was the first time in the board's twenty-year history that such an action was taken without first holding hearings.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Louisiana descendants of the Acadians, whose eviction from Nova Scotia nearly 200 years ago was immortalized by Long-fellow, are expected to appeal to the Senate Monday to save them from what they fear will be another "Tale of Acadia."

HISTORIES of the South's bid for independence seem in fair way of becoming annual events. Last spring Clement Eaton's "History of the Southern Confederacy" was published. Now comes a book in the same field by Clifford Dowdey, author of "Bugles Blow No More" and other novels and of "Experiment in Rebellion," an earlier excursion into Confederate history.

MIAMI BEACH -- The sun continues to shine on late spring vacationists here, as it undoubtedly will upon the thousands expected during the summer months, but the hotel strike that has been going on since April 13 is beclouding the summer outlook.
When the city moves to eliminate public porters from its main passenger liner piers about June 27, it will be hitting at an ancient occupation.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The State Department called off today a scheduled signing of an agreement between the United States and West Germany that would give extensive air routes over the Western Hemisphere to the German airline Lufthansa.

Edwin Miller made a mistake. He got tangled up with women shortly after noon on Friday. According to the police, he robbed the apartment of Mrs. Sarah Kneapler at 597 East Ninety-fifth Street, East Flatbush, Brooklyn.
New York University's 123d commencement season begins today at 4 P. M. with the baccalaureate service.
A NOTE of deep regret accompanies the opening of the last show of the season at the Curt Valentin Gallery. For this is, in truth, the last of the gallery's exhibitions.

The next day three men of Mexican origin were shot in that county. Texans had known of the border-country political machine which was manipulated by herding Latin-Americans to the polls as vaqueros toll cattle to feed.

MADRID, June 11 -- The remains of a Neanderthal man were reported today to have been discovered in a cave at Pinar, near Granada, in southern Spain.

Could Mr. Pleasants be talking about the same Germany where I have been spending the last few months as the recipient of a Ford Foundation fellowship grant, studying contemporary trends in opera production?
TO live in Nebraska it is necessary that you love it, for it is a state of extremes in heat, cold, dryness and wetness. You have to be good to survive at all, and Nebraskans are proud of it.

OTTAWA -- To anyone who likes to take his vacation remote from other tourists, Canada still offers almost unlimited opportunities that are unique on this continent. These opportunities almost always lie in the north, far from the civilized and cultivated belt of cities along the United States border, and, because of the strangeness, their other-world atmosphere, they have a strong fascination that makes travelers want to return.

ATHOUGH the tone of Jean Giraudoux' "Tiger at the Gates" is light, the idea is profoundly serious. When Giraudoux wrote it in the middle Thirties, he ironically called it "The Trojan War Will Not Take Place."

MOSCOW, June 11 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India flew from Moscow to Stalingrad today to begin a ten-day tour of provincial Russia that will include a visit to the Soviet atomic power station.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- It is widely assumed that the Ford Motor Company settlement with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., has set a pattern for all industry; that this pattern will immediately be adopted or imposed; that hundreds of concerns will be forced out of business.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 11 -- Sailboat racing usually connotes sun, blue skies and sparkling spray. Today Western Long Island Sound was wet, rainy, foggy, murky and lonesome. Except for a few tugs, sand barges and Coast Guard picket boats, there wasn't much afloat.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa. -- From the summit of Big Pocono (elevation 2,131 feet), the sweeping view that commands many of the 980,000 green acres below is vibrant with summer stirrings. The smaller peaks in the rolling Pocono Mountains, the long crescent-shaped plateau on the north, the vista of lakes, golf greens, the Delaware Water Gap, Wind Gap and criss-crossing highways all seem deceptively near.
LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- A labor dispute that had caused a part shut-down of the long-haul trucking business in eleven Far Western states for twenty-three days ended today.

Last week's contract between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers embracing the guaranteed annual wage principle, raised the question of the applicability of G. A. W. to other industries. Correspondents of The New York Times were asked to report on the probable effect of G. A. W. on industries in their areas.

There was one rather surprising omission in Gilbert Millstein's otherwise acute article on current night life -- "Lament for New York's Night Life" (May 22). Using the good old days of prohibition speakeasies, gangster battles and torrid jazz as a base for comparison, Mr. Millstein concludes that night life, for the middle and upper middle classes, has lost its guts in New York.

Italy knocked Denmark out of the running, France led Sweden, Belgium led Chile and rain halted play in the decisive match of the England-India series in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis quarter-finals yesterday.

Nine years ago Willard F. Libby of the University of Chicago predicted that cosmic-ray bombardment of the atmosphere would produce certain radioactive isotopes. One such isotope was carbon 14, which Libby discovered in organic remains.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 11 (AP) -- Tom Skutka, who set a national mark of 4:19.5 in the schoolboy mile last week, plodded to a slow and easy victory in the water-logged Conover Mile today in 4:56.1.

WHEN June Lockhart opened on Broadway in 1947 as the ingenue in the comedy, "For Love or Money," she was acclaimed by the critics. They described her performance with terms like "enchanting" and "captivating" and soon she was advanced from featured player to star.

WHEN June Lockhart opened on Broadway in 1947 as the ingenue in the comedy, "For Love or Money," she was acclaimed by the critics. They described her performance with terms like "enchanting" and "captivating" and soon she was advanced from featured player to star.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Americans for Democratic Action came out this week with a long and fiery indictment, not of its traditional target, the Republicans, but of the Democratic leaders in Congress.
Buyers continued to fill in their summer stocks of popularpriced apparel last week while shopping fall lines, resident offices report.

In August, 1954, this organization opened to the public the former home in Lexington, Va., of Gen. T. J. "Stonewall" Jackson. It is intended not only to maintain the home as a shrine to the memory of the Confederate leader but make it also a repository of as large a collection of Jackson material as we are able to acquire.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- One thing the tourist in Maine can be sure of is that there will always be plenty of big woods and all that goes with them, wild creatures, fish, rivers and ponds, mountains and forest trails. This is because so much of Maine is an enormous state park whose virgin forests and other elements cannot be spoiled by man.

Arrangements are being made for the sixteenth annual Mayfair Assembly subscription ball for debutantes, former debutantes and their escorts. The event, which will take place in the ballroom of the Ambassador on Dec. 16, will be preceded by a Dutch treat dinner for members of the assembly and their escorts in the Maisonette of the St. Regis.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 11 -- A dynamo built at Cornell more than three-quarters of a century ago generated current once more for the dedication today of the university's $1,650,000 electrical engineering center, Phillips Hall.

AT the end of Act III Karl Malden, the undespairing paterfamilias of "The Desperate Hours," takes his bows and walks a few steps to, of all places, the star's dressing room. This is something of a switch.

TENAFLY, N. J., June 11 (AP) -- It took John H. Wilson and J. i Henry Arras twenty-one holes, but they overcame the medalist jinx today in the Westervelt memorial golf tournament and advanced to the semi-finals.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -Sirens warning of mock atomic devastation will be the evacuation signal for President Eisenhower and 15,000 Government officials and employes Wednesday.

TOKYO, June 11 (AP) -- Former Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, urged the United States Government today to free all Japanese still serving prison terms as war criminals under United States military court sentences.
Probably the greatest plague for householders is the soiling of furnishings by dust and loose dirt.
Probably the greatest plague for householders is the soiling of furnishings by dust and loose dirt.
WE hope it will not seem too ungallant if we make so bold as to observe that Marilyn Monroe does not perform as a great actress; she performs as a great physique.

FORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique -- One of the most satisfying ways of traveling in the Windward and Leeward Islands, or for that matter the whole of the West Indies, is the primitive way that prevailed in the area after it was first discovered in 1492 -- by small inter-island sailing vessel.

CALGARY, June 6 -- The hottest election campaign in fifteen years is under way in Alberta, Canada's oil province, which votes June 29. The Opposition has raised the question of whether members of the provincial Parliament should deal with government - operated "treasury branches."

LE MANS, France, Sunday, June 12 -- Seventy-one persons have died and seventy-five more were seriously injured from the crash of a flaming sport car in front of the grandstand yesterday in the Le Mans auto race.

Bay Park House, a two-story garden apartment development in Hewlett, L. I., has been sold by the Franklin Gardens Corporation, George Rabinor, president. It is on a tract of four and one-half acres and was built by the seller.

George Worth, the defending champion, led a field of eight fencers into the final round of the national individual saber tournament last night. Worth won four bouts and lost one in the semi-finals held at the New York Fencers Club.
A month-long deadlock between House and Senate conferees over the Administration's Reciprocal Trade Bill (H. R. 1) was finally broken last week.

ZURICH, Switzreland, June 12 -- By reviving hopes of the reunion of West and East Germany, Russia's invitation to West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to go to Moscow for talks has started a boom in German securities having interests in the East Zone.
The editorial in the issue of May 31 "Hospitals Into Parks" seems to have been inspired.
Major league baseball players went on an into-the-stands hitting spree during the week-end. Nineteen games were played; half a hundred home runs were whacked.
C. L. Sulzberger's article on troubled Trieste interested me very much, as I was stationed in the Army in that city in 1953 and 1954.
Two thousand persons gathered at the chapel of Fordham University in the Bronx yesterday afternoon for a eucharistic rally arranged by the Bronx Nocturnal Adoration Society.
Members of the debutante committee for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball will be guests of honor at a luncheon tomorrow at the Delmonico.

KANSAS CITY, June 12 (AP) -Art Ceccarelli, a rookie southpaw, defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 0, with three-hit hurling today. The victory enabled the Kansas City Athletics to split a double-header, Baltimore having won the first game, 7 -- 2, on a six-run rally in the last two innings.

THE ancient custom of presenting an object in silver on a a special occasion has survived in many of its forms. Back in the early days of the country, however, the custom had a variety that, coupled with present-day appreciation of the antique and historical, puts presentation pieces of that time in the front rank of interest in silver.
The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike urged yesterday the adoption of a Trinitarian approach to life and the development of personality.
ALBANY, N. Y., June 12 (AP) -- Governor Harriman said today that his administration had saved more than $300,000 so far this year by easing bidding requirements on state contracts.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 (AP) -Vernon Law struck out ten batters and allowed only five hits before weakening in the ninth today as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Milwaukee Braves, 5 -- 3, in the first game of a doubleheader.

The market in shipping held its own last week and in some quarters continued the upward trend of recent months. Brokers said the only uncertainty or show of weakness could be traced to the continued restriction of the London market by strikes in England.

HONG KONG, June 12 -- Police in this British colony offered a reward of 100,000 Hong Kong dollars (about U. S. $17,200) today for information leading to the arrest of saboteurs of the Indian airliner Kashmir Princess.
CHICAGO, June 12 -- Radioactive fall-out after a hydrogenbomb explosion could make an area unsafe for months, an atomic physicist warned today.
New Yorkers will be paying a 20-cent subway fare within three years unless the trend away from mass transit riding is checked, Theodore W. Kheel warned yesterday.

LONDON, June 12 -- The stock market boom in industrial shares here continued last week with unabated vigor in spite of the fact that the railway and dock strikes have continued to drag on with ever-increasing damage to British business.
Chinks in New York City's Civil Defense armor are big enough to drop a hydrogen bomb through.

Motorcycle escorts and details of detectives will see to it this week that the foreign ministers of the Big Four powers and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer keep both their good health and a crowded series of appointments.
A major article in Pravda last week charged that the United States was seeking to monopolize the non-Communist world's supply of uranium.
PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (UP) -The Philadelphia Phillies scored seven runs on two hits with two out in the sixth inning to defeat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 12 -- 8, today.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., June 12 -- The Massapequa Farmers Market was destroyed by fire this afternoon. It had been famous among epicures before and during Prohibition, when it was the Chez Panchard Restaurant.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy called today for a "substantial increase" in the number of persons permitted to enter this country under the 1953 Refugee Relief Act.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 12 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton, N. J., defeated defending champion Allan Morris of Atlanta to win the Blue-Gray tennis tournament today. Moylan, seventh-ranked nationally, downed the Presbyterian College star, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 15 -- 13.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 12 -- The most extreme case of evolution "ever witnessed by man" has recently come to the attention of biologists.

BONN, June 12 -- Receipt last Tuesday of the Soviet invitation to Dr. Adenauer has added even greater importance to the Chancellor's forthcoming conference with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles. The problem, which originally embraced reunification, has now been widened to include West Germany's relations with the Soviet Union.
Lively differences of opinion on national and world affairs were expressed yesterday by six elementary and junior high school pupils on The New York Times Youth Forum.
It is to the interest of business and industry to give financial aid to higher education, G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday.

PORT HURON, Mich., June 12 (AP) -- Representatives of the C. I. O. United Auto Workers and the National Association of Manufacturers differed today over whether the union had won the "principle" of a guaranteed wage in the contract negotiated last week with Ford.

An ambitious survey of West-I ern art in terms of architecture, !sculpture, painting, literature land music will be published Wednesday by Holt. entitled "Arts and Ideas." The author is William Fleming, the founder and chairman of the Department of Fine Arts in the College of I Liberal Arts at Syracuse Unii versity.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 12 -- The festival-goers are crowding the football and racetrack fans for ranking as the hardiest of the breed.

I was delighted to read in The Times of the flower sale sponsored by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. There is a great need for color and nature in New York City and the annual flower mart is a fine step in this direction. Having traveled to many cities in the United States and Europe, I have always been dismayed that New York, the leading city in the world, is so lacking in "dressing up."

Conceived in controversy but dedicated to the principle that the game is never over till the last man is out, the Pelham Bay Little League opened its season yesterday with a parade, speeches, and thunder.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer, wife of the chairman of the board of The Washington Post and Times Herald, said today the United States has allowed itself "to be jockeyed into a defensive antiCommunist position instead of maintaining a positive, clearly reasoned attitude of intelligent leadership of the free world."
New York University seniors were advised yesterday to end the search for a "perfect" solution to world problems or be "paralyzed by perfectionism."
Department stores can't keep a psychologist at the door to analyze every customer as she walks in, but some researchers think stores should take account of the factors that motivate people to buy.
OMAHA, Neb., June 12 (AP) Karl Thomas, Arizona pitcher, tied a National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament strikeout record today as the Wildcats defeated Springfield (Mass.) College, 6 -- 0.
LIMA, Peru, June 12 -- Students of Lima's San Marcos University have voted to end their strike and return to classes if the Government frees six students now under arrest.

BUENOS AIRES, June 12 (AP) -- The Argentine Secretariat of Information said tonight President Peron would make a nationwide radio broadcast tomorrow night. The announcement said General Peron would "speak to the people" after the regular 8:25 P. M. Government news broadcast.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 12 -- Raymond Paige registered his first triumph with his International Class sloop, Prelude II, in the New York Yacht Club's regatta on foggy Long Island Sound today.

LE MANS, France, June 12 -- The death toll in what is believed to have been the world's worst automobile racing accident climbed to seventy-eight today. Of seventy-seven other victims hospitalized, eight were still in grave danger.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he planned to investigate "the lobby business" in the State of New York. State law requires lobbies to report the amounts they spend in trying to influence legislation.
BOSTON, June 12 -- The Jewish National Fund of New England today honored Mendel N. Fisher of New York, national executive director, on his completion of twenty years' service to the fund.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The magazine Aero Digest said today Russia reportedly had developed a missile that can be fired from a submarine almost 300 feet underwater and reach surface targets 140 miles away.

Americans are not the only people who practice Christian charity the Rev. Dr. Earle H. Ballou said yesterday. The executive director of the Congregational Christian Service Committee made this point in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Administration is making gradual progress in its program of removing the Federal Government from rivalry with private business.

Forty-two young musicians, ranging in age from 5 to 18, performed at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. They were the first of two groups of audition winners the Music Education League is presenting at the hall this week.
Five thousand passengers are expected to arrive this morning at New York International Airport on a flight from Paris.

BONN, Germany, June 12 -- Following is the text of questions submitted to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany by James Reston, Washington correspondent of The New York Times, and Dr. Adenauer's replies.
An increase in commerce in the Port of New York is reflected in customs collections for May.

Executives don't come off too well in "Behavior in a Selling Group,"* by George F. F. Lombard. Professor of Human Relations at Harvard University, the author moved into children's wear in a large department store with a group of researchers and made an intensive study of "interpersonal relations."
Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly said yesterday that "this is the time of year when Christians must do battle for their salvation."
The Rev. Dr. William B. McAlpin delivered his first sermon yesterday as minister of the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- A Roman Catholic priest who disregarded his own safety to give aid to troops in the Korean fighting today received the 1955 award as Army chaplain of the year.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 12 -- Former President Truman's attack here last night on Republican "raiders" of the public domain set in motion what promises to be one of the most intensive and costly Senatorial campaigns in the Pacific Northwest's political history.

Golf has been looked at in a new and different light since the arrival of the current Administration in Washington, and "Let's Play Golf Week," now in, so to speak, full swing, takes on added interest.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, urged Congress today to put sharp teeth in the enforcement provisions of the Clayton Anti-Trust Law by voting stiff day-to-day cash penalties for violators.

PARIS, June 12 -- Habib Bourguiba, leader of the Tunisian Nationalists, warned the workers of his country today against Marxism. He said its essential goal "is to set the workers against the rest of the nation."
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Moscow again has the rest of the world guessing, this time about its intentions at the Big Four foreign ministers meeting in San Francisco.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 12 (AP) -- There is a possibility, perhaps a strong one, that the nation's two outstanding colts, Swaps and Nashua, will meet in a $100,000 winner-take-all race at Hollywood Park this summer.
ANYBODY but anybody can afford European fashion items these days. Witness the collection of same at Gimbels, one of the stores featuring imported items at a price.

Jackson L. O'Leary, who bought the four-story dwelling on lot 18 by 100 feet at 251 East Forty-ninth Street a month ago through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, has resold it through the same brokers to Mary Negreponte.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Congress is expected to give final approval to the President's foreign trade program this week. There were growing indications, however, that his foreign aid program might run into trouble over the question of Yugoslavia.
Unions were urged yesterday to keep their billions of dollars in pension and welfare funds out of banks or insurance companies whose office staffs are not unionized.

BUENOS AIRES, Monday, June 13 -- President Juan D. Peron has put on the biggest public display of repressive police measures since he came to power in the Nineteen Forties. Special squads of policemen, including mounted troopers, and seven units of firemen made the historic Plaza de Mayo a No Man's Land during the night.
TAICHUNG, Formosa, June 4 -- At 72 East Model Lane here the State Department is bringing in a new crop of "China hands."
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 12 -- Colonial Williamsburg, once primarily concerned with the physical restoration of this eighteenth century town, will undertake a study of life in colonial America.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America ordained twenty-five graduates as "rabbi, teacher and preacher" yesterday at its sixty-first annual commencement exercises. The graduates received the degree of Master of Hebrew Literature.
Packaged brassieres will help to increase sales of foundation garments to a new high this year, in the opinion of an executive in the industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- Edmund G. Brown, the State Attorney General, ruled today that the Bible might be read as literature, but not for religious purposes, in California public school classes.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Last week saw much evening-up of operations in all pits on the Board of Trade. The market has been affected by the generally favorable weather, which has given the corn and soybean crops a good start, as well as improving wheat prospects, especially in the Northwest spring wheat areas.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 12 -- A boxer that has caught public attention more than most in the breed became best in show today in the event of the Longshore-Southport Kennel Club.

This area is to be exposed next week to a campaign for Mexico's tequila. The Young's Market Company of California, United States distributor of Jose Cuervo Tequila, has appointed Julius Wile Sons Co., Inc., as exclusive distributor in New York and New Jersey.
BERLIN, June 12 -- Evidence available here indicates the Soviet Union now considers the East German Communist regime expendable in the interest of detaching West Germany from the North Atlantic pact.
MADRID, June 12 -- Six anarchists, including two women charged with editing and distributing anti-Government publications have been arrested in Barcelona.

GAZA, June 8 -- If the gunfire flickering along the frontier kindles a war, the Egyptian forces holding the Gaza strip could only hope to make the Israeli Army pay as dearly as possible for this refugee-crowded remnant of Palestine.

RYE, N. Y., June 12 -- America's older linksmen began converging on the Apawamis Club today as the fifty-first annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship started. Setting the pace after 18 holes was Weller Noble, a 64-year-old retired business executive.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- Hecht-Lancaster productions has borrowed Tony Curtis from Universal-International Studios for an important part in "Trapeze.''

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -Leaders of the American Association for the Advancement of Science decided today to go ahead with plans to hold the organization's 1955 meeting in Atlanta despite protests against racial segregation there.

BILL VUKOVICH quit racing on dirt tracks a couple of years back because he decided that it was much too dangerous. But he was killed in the "safe" Indianapolis 500-mile classic a fortnight ago. Was his death necessary? Is this race a needless waste of human lives?

The largest single shipment of grain ever to move through the port of Boston -- 850,000 bushels -- will be loaded on a tanker July 1, according to William H. Gulliver Jr., Chairman of the Port of Boston Commission.

BALTIMORE, June 12 -- Max Hochschild, a penniless German immigrant boy who became a founder and head of Hochschild, Kohn Co., one of Baltimore's biggest department stores, will be 100 years old on Tuesday.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 12 -- Aviation's first jet-powered executive airplane will be unveiled at Westchester County Airport here on Tuesday. The sleek, twin-engined monoplane was built by Morane Sauliner, a French concern, to suit the needs of speed-conscious industrialists.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 -- non-automotive steel customers who had expected a slight windfall in steel deliveries because of the automobile labor controversy are going to be sadly disappointed. While there have been hints of cutbacks in automotive steel orders, actual cases turn out to be purely academic. Some companies are cutting back on deliveries of insignificant tonnages.
Eight Negro congregations have been invited officially to join the New York East Conference of the Methodist Church.
HAVANA, June 12 -- Four yachts sailed this morning in the 4,200-mile Havana-to-San Sebastian, Spain, trans-Atlantic yacht race.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12 -- Consuming hatred of communism is dangerous, as undesirable as submission to it, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University said here today in his baccalaureate address.
May was a good month for mutual funds, according to the National Association of Investment Companies.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that we must make an "extra effort" to let the other people of the world understand us better.

LONDON, June 12 -- Thousands of lemurs, monkey-like animals, are threatened with extinction by uncontrolled hunting and large-scale forest-clearance projects in Madagascar, according to reports received here from the International Union for the Protection of Nature.

Dr. Munawar Ali, president-elect of the Pakistan Medical Association, is now our guest in this country. He will visit, in the course of several weeks, about a dozen cities and medical centers. His trip has had an auspicious beginning in Boston and New York.

Both Don Newcombe's and the Dodgers' winning streaks were broken at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Cubs beat the Brooks in the opener of a double-header, 9 -- 5. The Brooks' string was snapped at six games.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 (AP) -- Coin - operated drunko-meters with which you could give yourself an intoxication test are a future possibility.
The city's new radar motor patrol will turn ninety-seven miles of dangerous highways into hunting grounds for speeders early next week.

Adios Boy and Adios Harry, regarded as the best pacers in harness racing today, will meet in a special one-mile match race at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., next Saturday night. They will race for a winner-take-all purse of $7,500.

PARIS, June 12 -- The French Government has been asked by the South Vietnamese Government to clarify its policy concerning the "military, economic and cultural presence of France in Indochina." The Vietnamese note is being studied by the Secretariat of State dealing with Indochinese affairs.
Three officer unions of the merchant marine have decided to negotiate jointly this year for new bargaining agreements with tanker companies.

Domestic cotton prices held to a narrow range last week. At the end of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, from July, 1955, through July, 1956, were up 1 to 8 points from a week earlier.
LONDON, June 12 -- The American Jewish Committee pledged full support today to plans by European Jews for development of communal needs.
DETROIT, Monday, June 13 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., reached an agreement on a new contract early today.

SYLVESTER L. (PAT) WEAVER Jr., broadcasting's most unpredictable president, started something yesterday afternoon over his National Broadcasting Company's radio network. Just what it is, however, he may be the only man to know for a while.

CLEVELAND, June 12 -- Weatherwise and otherwise, this was a dark, dismal day for the Yankees. They concluded the season's longest tour with a double dose of defeat, losing, 10 -- 2 and 7 -- 3, to the Indians before the season's largest crowd, 69,532 fans at Municipal Stadium.

MOSCOW, June 12 (AP) -- Soviet newspapers denounced Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther as a hysterical war planner today. They charged that Westerners were trying to prevent Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coming to Moscow.

We congratulate General Motors and the United Automobile Workers on their success in working out a new contract in the same harmonious manner that characterized last week's pattern-setting accord at Ford. The two pacts will bring nearly half a million hourly-rated workers within the protection of an unemployment insurance system that combines privately financed benefits with those paid by the state.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Third-inning home runs by Bob Nieman and Bob Kennedy, the former's with the bases filled, enabled the Chicago White Sox to gain an 8-to-4 victory and a sweep of a double-header with the Washington Senators today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 12 -- Shamrock, a Hinckley sou'wester owned by I. Austin Kelly of Rye and manned by a youthful crew captained by Garry Corwin, won the Larchmont Yacht Club's diamond jubilee race that ended early today.
LONDON, June 12 -- A leading Laborite politician charged today that Conservative Ministers wanted to "get tough" with Britain's trade unions.

PARIS, June 12 -- To all intents and purposes West Germany is now one of the Great Powers. When the Big Three Foreign Ministers confer in New York this week they will seek the advice of Chancellor Adenauer. He will also discuss the European situation with President Eisenhower.
Mary Martin and Helen Hayes are expected to co-star in "The Skin of Our Teeth" over the National Broadcasting Company television network Sunday, Sept. 11, from 7 to 9 P. M.

That there is no "season" for good music is a known fact. That New York City can become mighty uncomfortable during the summer months, especially indoors, is equally true. The Lewisohn Stadium Concerts, now in their thirty-eighth year, have been a boon to Gothamites precisely because they offer, in the open air, all the attractions of good music.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 12 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo in effect reminded the Big Four today that the peoples of Asia and Africa had declared their right to a "voice and a vote" in the solution of problems that affected them.
MOSCOW, June 12 (AP) -- Pravda printed a correction today in which it apologized for erroneous criticism of the Ministry of Electric Power Stations headed by former Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.
The giant Unilever organization, one of the largest manufacturing companies in the world, plans to become even larger.
The granting of fifty-one Opportunity Fellowships for 1955-56 was announced yesterday by the John Hay Whitney Foundation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- There must be an inescapable connection of education to religion if the effect of education in mankind is not to wither and die, Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, said today in his baccalaureate address there.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The National capital is a model of the muddle in Civil Defense planning.
HARTFORD, June 12 -- Demands for reform of the Connecticut legislative system have arisen.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, charged today that commercial banks made a "spectacular" $377,000,000 profit last year buying and selling Government securities.
SINGAPORE, Monday, June 13 -- A general strike that threatened to paralyze this great port city when it took full effect gripped Singapore today.

The century-old, red-brick, three-story Studio that cowers in darkness between the Union Square Savings Bank and a tall building just east of it, in East Fifteenth Street east of the square, will be reduced to brickdust next month. The bank will put a three-story addition on the site.
Officials of the Socialist party have asked Congress not to end the requirement that radio and television stations give all political parties "equal time" for free political broadcasts.

PARIS, June 12 -- The French Government is preparing a plan for the economic development of the more backward regions of France. The plan includes the removal to the provinces of industrial plants that have congested the Paris area, diverting land from building purposes.

BONN, Germany, June 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer reaffirmed West Germany's loyalty to the Western alliance prior to his departure tonight for Washington. He will confer there Tuesday with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles.

The Giants appeared on their way toward winding up their home stand at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a grand flourish and two sparkling victories over the Cardinals. But one errant pitch, by Sal Maglie, no less, gummed things up in the seventh inning of the nightcap.

In his letter Dr. Emerson Schmidt writes "Imposition of a $1 minimum wage could have substantial unemployment effects." This is hardly the optimism which should come from a leading spokesman for the Chamber of Commerce.

HANOVER, N. H., June 12 -- For the first time in its history, Dartmouth College today gave to the same man a second honorary doctorate degree at commencement exercises that closed the college's 186th year.
THE sweetest meat lies closest to the bone. So goes an old saying that seems to apply particularly to spareribs.

BANMETHUOT, Vietnam, June 12 -- A new relationship between the highlands of South Vietnam and the Saigon Government was celebrated here yesterday and today. Thousands of tribal inhabitants of the plateau regions thronged into this regional capital to join in colorful games and ceremonials.

Out of the dirty gray yonder and onto the automobile parking lot at Jacob Riis Park, Neponsit, Queens, came Stewart J. Perry at 12:45 P. M. yesterday. Despite the low ceiling, he landed his single-engine plane with no trouble -except for two police summonses.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 12 -The Karachi Union of Journalists demanded today "immediate repeal of laws that have conferred upon the Government unrestricted powers to toy with the democratic rights of the press and strangle its freedom."
CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 12 -- The United States golfing team of Ed Furgol and Chick Harbert won the Canada Cup today.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 12 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, today urged the graduating class of '55 to develop a "healthy nonconformity" in life.
New Jersey has asked the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis for more anti-poliomyelitis vaccine.

Plans for an International celebration next year of the 250th anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin moved forward yesterday with the naming of Anthony Drexel Duke as chairman of the New York sponsoring committee.

A new global effort to end the cold war and establish either a firm peace or at least a modus vivendi with the Communist world that might rid mankind of the specter of atomic war gets under way this week. It will begin with preliminary conferences tomorrow between President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer on the German and European situation, and between the President and Mr. Menon on the prospects in the Far East.

Since 1936, following the passage of the original Social Security Act, the Children's Bureau has operated a grants-in-aid program to assist the states in providing services to crippled children. Last year, under this program, diagnostic, medical and surgical, hospital or related services were given 250,000 children whose parents could not afford private care.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -A Brookings Institution study concluded today that effective control of armaments would never be achieved until the Soviet Union and the Western powers developed international conditions of confidence and trust.
Americans across the country will observe Flag Day tomorrow, the 178th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes by the Continental Congress.
UNITED NATIONS, June 12 -- Former President Harry S. Truman has agreed to speak June 24 at the United Nations tenth anniversary celebration in San Francisco.

Samuel Reshevsky, who will lead the American team in the matches with Russia at Moscow on June 29, gained his second victory in the series of practice games with team members at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

Central Park has one of its hundredth anniversaries coming up next year, marking completion of acquisition in 1856 of much of the land that now makes a Manhattan treasure of 840 acres. The work of transforming this suburban wilderness into a park for the people's benefit began in 1857.
A new English adaptation of the late Arthur Schnitzler's controversial play, "La Ronde," involving ten episodes of illicit love, will be the next offering at the Circle in the Square.
LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- The nation's electric power resources are growing so fast that they are fourteen years ahead of even recent predictions.

A new global effort to end the cold war and establish either a firm peace or at least a modus vivendi with the Communist world that might rid mankind of the specter of atomic war gets under way this week. It will begin with preliminary conferences tomorrow between President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer on the German and European situation, and between the President and Mr. Menon on the prospects in the Far East.

Since 1936, following the passage of the original Social Security Act, the Children's Bureau has operated a grants-in-aid program to assist the states in providing services to crippled children. Last year, under this program, diagnostic, medical and surgical, hospital or related services were given 250,000 children whose parents could not afford private care.
The Netherlands accused Indonesian authorities yesterday of "shocking abuse" of thirty-four Dutch citizens arrested eighteen months ago on charges of conspiracy and subversion.

Mrs. Maxine Mitchell, the defending champion, and eight others dueled in the final round-robin for the national women's individual fencing title at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx last night. Mrs. Mitchell qualified for the big test by sweeping nine bouts in the quarter-final and semi-final rounds during the day.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee tentatively approved a four-year extension of the draft today. It delayed final action pending developments in the battle over the President's reserve bill.
Bank marriages, once quiet, dull affairs, have in recent months provided the financial community with all the excitement and intrigue of elopements, as well as the magnificence of formal ceremonies.

Bryant High School captured the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship yesterday by defeating New Dorp, 8--0. Fred Van Dusen's slugging and Frank Piccola's five-hit pitching marked the Queens school's victory.
New Yorkers by the millions will take to the bomb shelters tomorrow afternoon.

Emerson had a good idea when -- in his "Essay on Manners" -- he said, "Let us leave hurry to slaves." These days, although that thought may be highly regarded, even Emersonians seem to pay little attention to it.
PARIS, June 13 -- Officials here said today Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam had asked for full military control there.
KWANGJU, Korea, June 7 -- The Rev. Francis Lee Woods was talking with three elderly Korean farmers. They asked if it was true that the Americans were leaving Korea.

NASHVILLE, June 13 -- President Eisenhower and his "White House advisers" were denounced today by speakers at a five-state rally in support of a self-financing program for the Tennessee Valley Authority.
HARTFORD, June 13 -- Reform of the system under which the Legislature functions is in prospect.

The Senate bill to raise the federal minimum wage from 75 cents to $1 an hour, passed last Wednesday, represents a compromise between two forces of great political power. On the one side are the President and his Administration team who have recommended 90 cents; on the other is a formidable array of labor's cohorts who have urged that the floor be upped to $1.25.

The present visit of Chancellor Adenauer again brings to this country one of the great statesmen of the postwar world. He comes this time as the governing head of a sovereign Germany which, though still dismembered, disarmed and legally handicapped, is again rising to the rank of a Big Power whose voice and interests must be considered in the councils of the nations.
Although aircrafts took a heavy pounding in the closing hour of yesterday's stock market, coppers and steels continued strong and the close was the best since Sept. 21, 1929.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford asserted today that a superiority of American war weapons had not reduced this country's dependence on Allies.
DALLAS, Tex., June 13 (AP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Paul Butler turned down today an offer by Gov. Allen Shivers to talk over Texas Democratic differences.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk asserted today that the Government's revised manufacturing standards and plans would prevent further difficulties with his poliomyelitis vaccine.

TRENTON, June 13 -- The right of Jersey City to seek to recover $15,000,000 from Frank Hague was upheld today by the State Supreme Court. The city alleges that its former Mayor and two others had extorted this sum from municipal employes over a thirty-year period.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Treasury reported tonight an increase in its short-term borrowing costs.

A colony of 5,000 bees, scheduled to arrive here from France yesterday for an unusual scientific experiment, had their trip postponed a day. The plane they awaited was delayed in a flight to Paris from Rome and upset nicely calculated procedures for the experiment.

R. M. Marshall has been elected chairman of the board of Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company and Henry L. Hillman was elected president. J. H. Hillman Jr. was named chairman of the finance committee.

Byron Palmer will portray a band leader who is the object of Margaret O'Brien's adulation in "Glory," a feature with a horse racing background. It will be produced by R. K. O.-Radio Pictures. . . . "Back of Beyond" has been put on Republic's production slate.
A new stage adaptation of Franz Kafka's disquieting novel, "The Trial," will open a limited engagement at the Provincetown Playhouse tonight at 8 o'clock.

The five-story store and apartment building at 1080 Park Avenue has passed to new ownership in the first sale since 1913. It has been acquired by the Sterling Investing Corporation from the Empire Trust Company and others and executors of the estate of Jacob Mayers.
The Citizens Budget Commission Medal for High Civic Service was presented to Bernard F. Gimbel yesterday at a luncheon attended by 150 business and civic leaders.
The newest in the familiar series of four-engine Douglas airliners, the DC-7B, took off for Paris late yesterday on its first passenger run.

LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- Aspen Pictures, Inc., which complained that it had lost $176,200 in the production of "Return to Paradise" because of shipping delays, today lost a suit for recovery of that amount.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee today rejected President Eisenhower's proposal for an atomic-powered merchant ship that would tour the world in the interest of peace.
NORFOLK, Va., June 13 -- The Virginia State Ports Authority has requested the Federal Maritime Administration to establish a passenger-freight steamship route between Hampton Roads and Europe.

Coffee, cocoa and rubber futures soared yesterday in active trading on the New York exchanges. Coffee rose as much as the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit, cocoa was up the 1-cent limit in most positions in the heaviest trading in a month and rubber quotations climbed as much as 2 cents on the largest volume since September, 1949.
The Mayor's Interdepartmental Committee for a Clean City recommended yesterday a program to clear the city's tenement areas of "filth and unsightly conditions."

Harry Schwartz reported recently that "Soviet refugees in the United States * * * have become objects of a Communist campaign to induce them to return to the Soviet Union." I am one of those "Soviet refugees."

The appointment of Dr. John Bartky as director of the Public Education Association, 20 West Fortieth Street, was announced yesterday. Dr. Bartky has taken a leave of absence from Leland Stanford University, where he is dean of the School of Education, to accept the post with the civic organization.
The backyard gardener, wishing to preserve some prize summer fruits or vegetables for a mid-winter treat, can do so with the aid of new "Vapocans," made by the Container Corporation of America.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- Douglas M. Pratt, president of the Philadelphia Transportation Company, proposed today a $45,225,000 modernization program for its rolling stock.
OMAHA, Neb., June 13 (UP) -- Oklahoma A. M. made only two hits today but took advantage of five errors and thirteen walks to oust Colgate from the National Collegiate world series 4 -- 2.

RENO, Nev., June 13 (AP)--Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks suggested today that it might be a good idea to revise regulation of the electric and telephone industries to let them earn higher profits.

A rooster put a policeman on the sick list yesterday. A solid peck while he had his back turned sent Patrolman John R. Spagna of the East Fifth Street station to Bellevue Hospital for treatment, then home for the day.
A traffic policeman yesterday bent to watch a stylus draw a thin red line on a graph, as a car zoomed by.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- Advances of 30 to 75 cents a hundred pounds moved hogs to their highest prices since September. The top on butchers was $21.25, highest since Sept 8. Trading was active and uneven. Cattle were unevenly 25 cents higher to as much lower. Reports on livestock trading here today by the Department of Agriculture:

The flag whose 178th anniversary we celebrate today is not a quiet thing. It is not a design on a tapestry. It has seen much history, has been carried in many desperate battles -- even, and unexpectedly, including those of the Second World War.

LONDON, June 13 -- Britain does not expect agreement on substantive problems at the forthcoming Big Four heads-of-government conference, Harold Macmillan, Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today.

LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- A four-point plan for Federal and local legislation to correct "tax inequities" in the field of electric power was demanded today by the president of the Edison Electric Institute.
MOSCOW, June 13 -- The Soviet Union agreed today that the proposed four-power conference should begin July 18 in Geneva.
CONVENT STATION, N. J., June 13 -- Florham, one of New Jersey's most elaborate estates, was thrown open to the public today for the first time since the turn of the century.
CINCINNATI, June 13 (AP) -- Cincinnati hit three home runs tonight, including Ted Kluszewski's eighteenth, to beat the Milwaukee Braves, 6 -- 4.

HAMILTON, N. Y., June 13 (AP) -- Plagued by showers, the thirty-third annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament got under way today. Only four matches were played and there were three defaults.

An agreement has just been worked out calling for export of instant grapefruit and orange crystals -- add water, make a drink -- under the McKee label by the Florida Citrus Exchange. Orange Crystals, Inc., the processor, retains domestic marketing rights, while the exchange handles foreign sales and contractual arrangements.
ALBANY, June 13 (AP)--Governor Harriman renewed today his call for legislation to require periodic medical examinations for New York State drivers.
Billy Graham, the evangelist, was invited yesterday to conduct a full-scale soul-saving campaign in New York during the fall of next year.
I have read with serious misgivings the publicized plans for a "Palace of Progress" in our city. I can't help but feel that these misgivings are shared by others.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- Representative Herbert C. Bonner, Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the House Merchant Marine Committee, urged industry and labor today to help Congress re-establish "the kind of a merchant marine America needs and deserves."

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- A House Interior subcommittee agreed today to vote tomorrow on a bill to authorize $760,000,000 for the Upper Colorado reclamation project. Representative Wayne C. Aspinall, Democrat of Colorado and subcommittee chairman, predicted approval of the measure.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- Grain futures showed a strong tone today.

Ammon Hennacy, associate editor of The Catholic Worker and author of the "Autobiography of a Catholic Anarchist," said yesterday he would continue to sell the periodical and the book in city streets without a license.
DETROIT, June 13--The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., counted a new victory today in its drive for a guaranteed wage and turned toward further conquests.
New York's buying offices will be used as "loss leaders" to attract exhibitors to the proposed "Palace of Progress" structure atop Pennsylvania Station.
ART CARNEY got top billing last night and rose to the occasion with a splendid performance in an unusual and fascinating play.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a statement issued today by Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors Corporation, and Harry W. Anderson, vice president, and of a joint statement by Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., and John W. Livingston, director of the union's General Motors department:

Chief Justice Warren has received much praise in the public press for giving an atmosphere of unity to the Supreme Court. This was accomplished in the desegregation case by a restatement of high-sounding principles which were inadequately implemented -- lip service without teeth.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 13 (AP) -- Emmet Lavery, the playwright, predicted today that the growth of automation -- production by untended machines -- would cause theatres to flouish as never before.

RYE, N. Y., June 13 -- Frank D. Ross of West Hartford, Conn., who won the title in 1953, and S. W. Creekmore of Fort Smith, Ark., tied for the lead today in the fifty-first championship of the United States Seniors Golf Association.
Brooklyn's 12,000 longshoremen have been organized to seek to oust Capt. William V. Bradley as president of the International Longshoremen's Association at the union's convention here next month.

PARIS, Tuesday, June 14 -- The French cabinet decided at a meeting that ended early today to ban motor car racing in France "for a short period" pending the drafting of new international safety regulations.

H. Irving Pratt, a partner in the firm of Charles Pratt Co., was elected chairman of the Wall Street Investing Corporation yesterday in a reorganization move designed to broaden distribution and to improve the group's competitive position in mutual funds.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 13--President Eisenhower today praised the service of members of the American Red Cross. He said their work "as volunteers in the service of humanity sets in motion far-reaching currents of goodwill that extend through all 'curtains' to the far corners of the earth."
NOW that the farmers are beginning to gather their first harvest of hay, the varmint shooters have an opportunity to improve the woodchuck scores.

The Brookhaven (L. I.) National Laboratory shipped yesterday four one-pound slabs of cobalt 60, reportedly the largest package of atomic material designed for industrial research. Destined for scientific use at the B. F. Goodrich Research Center, Brecksville, Ohio, the package was wrapped in a five-ton, lead and steel "pig."
TRENTON, June 13 (AP) -- The New Jersey Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission resigned today.

James J. Moran, former First Deputy Fire Commissioner, went on trial yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on an income-tax charge. It was also the 54-yearold defendant's twenty-fifth wedding anniversary.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- If Congress wants a steam power plant built at Fulton, Ky. the Tennessee Valley Authority could start construction promptly, the T. V. A. chairman, said today.

Shipments of rayon and acetate yarn, staple and tow during May totaled 102,000,000 pounds, a decrease of 9 per cent compared with April but 11 per cent more than in May, 1954, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Of last month's total shipments, exports accounted for 1,500,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Presidential commission appointed to dispose of the Government's war-built synthetic rubber monopoly said today it had sold Government holdings to private industry for $10,000,000 more than the taxpayers put into them.

CALGARY, Alberta, June 8 -- The struggle between Canadian Pacific Railway telegraph linemen and a fish-eating osprey that nested on the telegraph lines has ended in a draw. The outcome apparently is satisfactory to both sides.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- Princeton University's graduating class of '55 today observed Class Day with traditional ceremonies dating back to the mid-eighteenth century.
TOKYO, June 13 -- Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu said today negotiations with the United States for the lease of uranium concentrates would be concluded this week, probably by Wednesday.

THAT meat is best broiled at moderate temperature is an opinion expressed by an increasing number of experts. Latest to say so is Miss Reba Staggs, for many years director of home economics for the National Live Stock and Meat Board, educational agency of the meat industry.

Two women authors of distinguished historical novels, both British, are visiting this country. One is Hope Muntz, author of "The Golden Warrior." She is doing research for a new book. The second is Edith Simon, author of "The Golden Hand" and "The Twelve Pictures." She accompanied her husband, Dr. Eric Reeve, who is attending a medical meeting in Cold Spring Harbor.

MOSCOW, June 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of Soviet note to France (similar notes were sent to the United States and Britain) accepting the Western invitation to a Big Four heads-of-government conference and of a statement by Tass, Soviet news agency, concerning remarks made by Secretary of State Dulles about the conference:

PARIS, June 13 -- The Communist - led General Confederation of Labor is seeking to heal the split that took place in it in 1947. In that year Moscow-inspired strikes to block the Marshall Plan led to a separate Socialist-led federation called the Workers' Force.
NEW HAVEN, June 13 -- The sun was shining on Yale this morning when, in a pleasant blending of pomp and circumstance with good humor, the university held its 254th commencement under the elms.
The excitement over the unemployment-pay aspects of the Ford and General Motors agreements obscured a second development almost as far-reaching in its impact.

Fabulist of the High Tide Stable won the $29,450 Queens County Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. A crowd of 23,266 watched the race, which served as the main attraction on the opening day of the twenty-four-day meeting.

No one can say positively which shell will win the intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on Saturday at Syracuse. However, most followers of rowing can tell you whose boat will cross the finish line first.

PARAMUS, N. J., June 13 -Mrs. Marge Mason of the home club won the qualifying medal in the fifty-second annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship. The competition was held over the West and East nines of the Ridgewood Country Club today.

Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd, Commandant of the Marine Corps, will be one of six persons to receive honorary degrees at the 104th commencement exercises of Manhattan College this afternoon. Cardinal Spellman will preside at the outdoor ceremony on the Riverdale campus.
The Soviet Government has begun to tell its people the secrets of nuclear weapons and the magnitude of hydrogen bomb explosions.

For the first time since February, 1954, New York Stock Exchange customers' net debit balances -- the amounts of money they have borrowed from their brokers in order to carry stock -- have shown a decline.
