William J. Keating, former counsel to the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, will be released from jail today in time to attend a luncheon in his honor at the Roosevelt Hotel.
ROME, June 13 -- Premiere Mario Scelba received his party's approval today for another attempt at strengthening his Center coalition Cabinet.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- A resurgence of injurious business practices is threatening the existence of many independent food retailers, Alvin V. Hokanson, president of the National Association of Retail Grocers, said today.

When one goes shopping for a stock, it's usual to buy it at the lowest price available. The new stock of the Sperry Rand Corporation is one of those exceptions encountered from time to time. This is the company being formed on July 1 from the merger of Remington Rand, Inc., and the Sperry Corporation.
BUENOS AIRES, June 13 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from a radio speech made tonight by President Juan D. Peron, as recorded by the Associated Press:
BORDENTOWN, N. J., June 13 -- State policemen, stopping a car on the Jersey Turnpike for a routine traffic check at 9 A. M. today, turned up a traveling arsenal.

ROME, June 13 -- The day when atomic energy will be a common commercial source of power still is a long way off, an American chemical engineer declared today. Warren K. Lewis, professor emeritus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, told the fourth World Petroleum Congress that barriers to prompt commercial use of atomic power were high initial plant cost, disposing of radioactive waste, provisions against hazards and fuel re-purification.

One doesn't know whether to laugh or cry at the contents of a pamphlet on "How to Spot a Communist," issued by the First Army for the guidance of intelligence officers in this area. If any intelligence officers are so naive as to be guided by it, we can only fear for the security of the installations they are supposed to protect.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 2 points up to 9 down.

A parked ten-ton trailer truck was stolen here yesterday and looted of clothing and dry goods valued at $100,000, the police said. The truck was taken from in front of its West Side terminal. It was found later, empty, in Maspeth, Queens.
LONDON, June 13 -- The first real signs of progress toward ending the seventeen-day-old rail strike occurred here late tonight after a day of intense behind-the-scenes negotiations.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- New anti-monopoly controls on banks were proposed today by the Federal Reserve Board.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 13 (AP) -- Directors of the Travelers Insurance Company today approved a 20-for-1 split of the company's stock, plus a 1-for-4 stock dividend, and indicated a higher dividend rate on the new issue.
THIS is the month for blushing brides and sweet girl graduates. It's also the month for pearls, a June birthstone, and the traditional wedding or commencement gift.
Only about half of New Jersey's school children were turning out yesterday for poliomyelitis inoculations after off-again, on-again announcements in various areas.

SYOSSET, L. I., June 13 -- Take a cow like Grinstead Black Magic, showing off her newborn calf, and it's a sight to stampede the ghosts of cowhands and rangy longhorns clean off the Old Chisholm Trail.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee today approved a bill that would set a ceiling of about $12,000,000 on campaign spending in behalf of a Presidential nominee. It would require public disclosure of how the money was spent.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, arrived today to confer on plans for the Big Four conference and on the Soviet invitation to him to visit Moscow. He will see President Eisenhower tomorrow and will be on hand during the meetings of the Western Big Three foreign ministers in New York later in the week.
LONDON, June 13 -- Price movements were generally narrow on the stock market today. Many of the industrial leaders advanced modestly although labor troubles inhibited the volume of trading.

Rarely has this newspaper printed an account more disturbing than the series on this nation's civil defense unpreparedness concluded yesterday. Confusion, lack of leadership, inadequate information, public apathy and major gaps in our warning system are among the key features unearthed in this examination of our readiness for the awful emergency of nuclear attack against our cities and people.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 13 (AP) -- The Woodland Farm's To Cash, prepping for the $20,000 Regret Handicap here Saturday, scored an easy victory in the Dapper Dan Purse at Monmouth Park today.

Equitable Gas Company earnings for the first four months amounted to $1.42 a share, compared with $1.28 a share a year earlier, A. W. Conover, president, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at Pittsburgh. Operating revenues increased by $2,000,000 to $18,200,000 he added, while gas sales totaled 34,500,000.000 cubic feet compared with 31,800,000,000 in the like 1954 period.
The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an injunctive petition filed by four trucking companies against the new Pier loading rates.
ALBANY, June 13 (AP) -- Governor Harriman appointed today a forty-six-member citizens advisory committee to help organize this fall the Governor's Conference on Problems of the Aging.
William Woodward Jr., owner of Nashua, will not send the star 3-year-old to California to compete against the Kentucky Derby winner, Swaps.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 13 -Prime Minister Sir John Kotelawala of Ceylon has asked Indonesian Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo to call on Asian and African members of the United Nations to sponsor a demand for immediate and full membership for seven countries.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 13 (Reuters) -- Belgium's Lower House passed the Socialist-Liberal Government's controversial school reforms bill tonight in the second and final reading. The vote was 111 to 1. The Roman Catholic Opposition had walked out in protest.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, and Senator John M. Butler, Republican of Maryland, exchanged some hot words at a Senate hearing today. The dispute arose over Air Force plans to move its Research and Development Command from Baltimore to Dayton, Ohio.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 -- The Screen Directors Guild of America has called on the motion picture industry to "vigorously resist" efforts by special interest groups for deletions in pictures bearing the industry's Production Code seal of approval.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -The Olin Mathieson Chemical Company has obtained a year's extension of its tax-easing certificate of necessity for construction of an aluminum plant in West Virginia, the Office of Defense Mobilization reported today.
SINGAPORE, Tuesday, June 14 -The general strike here today entered its second day. No reports of violence reached police headquarters through the early hours of this morning.
Shipbuilding contracts valued at $25,000,000 and calling for the construction of 172,500 deadweight tons of shipping have been placed in Japan by Triton Shipping, Inc.
JACKSON, Miss., June 13 (AP) -- Mississippi's Supreme Court upheld today a circuit judge's opinion that newspaper delivery boys were not independent contractors.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a bill to authorize immediate appropriation of the full United States share of funds needed to complete the Inter-American Highway.

BUENOS AIRES, June 13 -- President Juan D. Peron told the Argentine nation tonight he now knew that his twelve-year attempt to have the Roman Catholic Church cooperate fully with the policies of his Government had failed.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is planning to raise about $50,000,000 through the sale of new common stock, P. W. Litchfield, chairman of the Goodyear board, said yesterday.
Atlantic and Gulf Coast passenger and dry cargo operators met for three hours yesterday with officials of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., but made no progress toward signing a new contract.
MOST of the newly opened art exhibitions as the season closes are group events including work shown during the season. But a few last one-man shows at galleries are also in progress.
The $356,000 goal that recently was set to finance the American "Salute to France" in Paris is expected to be reached within the next few weeks of fund raising.
Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer upheld yesterday a petition by the Citizens Union to bar the restoration of pay cuts taken by Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons in the depression era.

Sales by the nation's chain and mail order houses during May were 9.3 per cent above those for the similar month of 1954. May was the ninth consecutive month to show a gain. For the first five months of this year sales were 8.4 per cent ahead of the corresponding period of last year.

ALBANY, June 13 (AP) -- A special State Council of Parks subcommittee said today that Edward A. Hanna of Utica was unfit to serve on the Central New York State Parks Commission. It urged Governor Harriman to oust him.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 13 -- Katharine Cornell and seven other persons received honorary degrees at the 155th commencement exercises of Middlebury College this morning.
HAMBURG, Germany, June 13 (2P) -- West Germany plans large-scale efforts to build atomic-powered merchant vessels.
LONDON, June 13 -Representatives of Jewish communities in Europe reported today on heir serious problems in keeping religious and communal traditions alive.

Apparel market activity was in full swing yesterday as showings of new fall merchandise continued to draw capacity crowds. Perhaps more significantly, buyers began to drift into back rooms to put their stores' money down on selections for fall selling.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- The development of the atom for peaceful purposes promises the world great benefits and scant danger, a panel of scientists agreed today.
A 10-year-old boy died early yesterday morning in an airliner returning him and his parents to New York from a pilgrimage to the Shrine of Our Lady of Lourdes in France.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company in the six months ended with April achieved the highest sales and second highest earnings for any similar period on record.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- One thing the Federal Government urgently needs, the Hoover Commission said today, is improved real estate management.

DON NEWCOMBE lost his first game of the season the day before yesterday and the situation has taken an ominous turn for the faltering Dodgers. It becomes increasingly obvious that they no longer will clinch the National League pennant by the Fourth of July. The best they can do for a clinching date now must be St. Hippolytus Day.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations appealed yesterday to Governor Harriman to reject a tentative contract between the State Power Authority and the Aluminum Company of America.
SEWANEE, Tenn., June 13 (AP) -- University of the South seniors were told today that education in the liberal arts must be preserved and that private money could help.

Walter L. Rothschild, real estate operator and investor has purchased the two five-story store and apartment buildings at 226 and 238 West 238th Street in the Bronx. The seller was Augustus Van Cortlandt, whose family has been identified with property in the neighborhood for many years and for whom Van Cortlandt Park was named.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 13 (AP) -- Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General, said today that citizenship participation was "the critical ingredient" in any effort to meet the problem of delinquency among youth.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 13 (AP) -- Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told the Vassar College graduating class today that "a new, high quality of statesmanship and skill" had blocked the Soviet "timetable of conquest" at every turn.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 13 -- Studies of many generations of fruit flies, discussed here today, suggest that the genes, or carriers of heredity, are not just scrambled together by chance.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 12 -- In eight-column headlines the people of this placid city were informed last week that Echo Park Dam had been dropped from the Colorado River storage project.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (UP) -- The conviction of Steve Nelson and four other Communist party leaders for having conspired to advocate violent overthrow of the Government was upheld today by the United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals.

The philosopher's stone, which in the Middle Ages was believed to have the power to transform lead or copper into gold, and for which our ancestors searched for many centuries, was never actually found. Now, however, according to Pueblo of Madrid, an East Indian, a Dr. Saraswati, says he has located a variant of it, a philosopher's herb, whose juice can transmute metals. Copper rubbed with it, he asserts, changes into pure gold.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles declared today he was "glad they have accepted" when informed that Kremlin officials had agreed to the Western proposals for the time and place of a Big Four conference.

Belgian women, Scandinavian, American, English and even French women love Horrockses cotton dresses. Pronounced "Hor-rock-sez," they are made in England and clamored for on the Continent. Because of the demand, B. Altman here has recently put its collection of Horrockses in a special corner of its dress department.

The continuing jurisdictional struggle beween the city's Budget Director, Abraham D. Beame, and the City Administrator, Luther H. Gulick, is regrettable and by no means resolved. Both are able men. Both have the best interests of the city at heart.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- The United Nations Charter will return tomorrow to San Francisco, where it was signed June 26, 1945.

BUENOS AIRES, June 13 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron warned in a nation-wide broadcast tonight that his supporters would suppress "with all energy" further riots between Roman Catholics and their opponents.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 13--The South Vietnamese Army's two-week-old drive against the rebel forces of Gen. Tran Van Soai has become a campaign of guerrilla warfare. Army troops, aided by combat river boats, continue mop-up operations over a wide area of rice fields and waterways sixty to ninety miles southwest of Saigon.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 13 -- Adlai E. Stevenson urged today that President Eisenhower's hands not be tied by an uncompromising United States position at the forthcoming meeting of the Big Four chief of government.

The city of Indianapolis borrowed $1,000,000 on serial bonds maturing over seventeen years yesterday at an interest cost of 1.9278 per cent. Public sealed bidding competition for award of the issue resulted in a tie. A bid of 100.77 for obligations bearing 2 per cent interest was submitted both by First National City Bank and a joint account consisting of Guaranty Trust Company and Salomon Bros. Hutzler.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 13 -- Wellesley College announced today it had received $1,271,061 in gifts and bequests during the last eleven months. President Margaret Clapp made the report at the college's seventy-seventh commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Letters coming to this department from political scientists reflect the belief that an old issue embedded in the Constitution is rising again. This concerns the veto power of the judiciary over the other two branches of the Government.

The blockfront property on the east side of Second Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets is to be improved with a sixteen-story apartment house. The parcel was sold last April by Beth David Hospital.
Thousands upon thousands of excited New York children will soon be crowding through our railway and bus stations, bound for vacations in the green hills, away from the grime and sounds of the city.
TOKYO, June 12 -At least to outward appearance, Japan's gloss of Westernism has deepened since the end of the Allied Occupation three years ago.
A Bronx teacher who was stabbed in the back last week by a 15-year-old boy said yesterday that he and his family would move to Long Island.
The Giants left on a western trip yesterday with their manager, Leo Durocher, still fuming about the loss to the Cardinals in the second game of their Sunday double-header.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Two young American tennis players put on the liveliest struggle of the day as the London grass courts tennis championships, the final tune-up for Wimbledon, got under way at the Queen's Club today.

Robert Montgomery has selected a new cast of players for his television stock company this summer. The summer drama series of ten shows will be presented over the National Broadcasting Company network beginning Monday, July 4, from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -Delegates to a Middle Atlantic conference of highway experts were advised today that a complete, integrated national road system would save 3,500 lives and prevent 120,000 injuries a year.
OTTAWA, June 14 -- A small number of minor tariff reductions affecting trade between Canada and the United States have been agreed to after prolonged negotiations in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House Civil Service Committee approved today a 7.5 per cent pay increase for more than 1,000,000 Federal workers. They had hoped to get 8 per cent and might get it yet.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- Two Western power company executives endorsed in ringing terms today the Eisenhower "partnership policy" in the development of natural resources.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- (UP) -- The Senate shouted its approval today of legislation to authorize the United States to join Canada in a survey of possible tidal power projects in Passamaquoddy Bay.

New York University will graduate 6,384 students today and will confer honorary degrees upon eight prominent individuals. The ceremonies, to be held on Ohio Field, University Heights campus at 181st Street and University Place, the Bronx, will mark the university's 123d commencement.
HONG KONG, June 14 -- Despite the following Hu Feng had in left-wing Chinese literary circles, he was a relatively obscure writer and critic not long ago.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 14 -- The Legislature, by 37 to 2, adopted a resolution today to "censure, reprimand and condamn" State Senator Sam Klaver of Omaha. It was the first time such action had been taken by the Legislature.

Bavaria of the Brookmeade Stable won the $9,750 Aqueduct Spring Maiden Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday. There were only five in this event of about two miles, and Bavaria had an advantage of three lengths over Manton B. Metcalf Jr.'s Beau Sir at the end.
An imaginary hydrogen bomb drop -- equivalent to 5,000,000 tons of TNT -- will be the keynote of the city's participation in a nation-wide Civil Defense test today.
GENEVA, June 14 -- The basis is being laid in Western Europe for economic expansion "exceeding anything previously achieved," according to the Bank for International Settlements.

"The Purple Mask," a period adventure in color produced by Universal-International and starring Tony Curtis, will have its local premiere today at the Mayfair. Colleen Miller, Gene Barry, Dan O'Herlihy, Angela Lansbury, George Dolenz and John Hoyt are among the principals.

The day is not far off when food stores will be 100 per cent self-service, H. V. McNamara, president of the National Tea Company, told the New York Society of Security Analysts at chwartz's Restaurant yesterday.

IF the partisans of pay-as-you-see television and free advertising - sponsored video cannot put up more interesting arguments for their respective causes, the poor viewer at home is going to succumb to ennui of the eyelid.
The program of United States official participation in international trade fairs abroad has succeeded well in its first year, it was asserted yesterday by a trade association official.

The Department of Agriculture announces the Government support level for next year's wheat crop will be 76 per cent of parity. With the parity ratio at its present level this means that the "floor" under wheat prices will be $1.81 a bushel -- a big drop from the present crop year price of $2.06, and the lowest support price for wheat since 1946, when it was pegged at $1.49.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House of Representatives voted, 347 to 54, today to approve a conference committee report on the Reciprocal Trade Bill.
For the first time in its history the Metropolitan Opera is building and painting its own scenery for next season's new productions.
MILWAUKEE, June 14 (UP) -- Mrs. Beatrice Trostel Rathborne, 42 years old, widow of a Louisiana newspaper director and business man, hanged herself today in her brother's home here.

Sewall Shurtz, a yeoman third class in the United States Navy and the defending champion, reached the final round of the national individual epee championship at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx last night.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- Coincident with the visit of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru to this country the Soviet Union is giving warm support to India's claim upon the Portuguese Indian colony of Goa. Moscow is blaming the United States for Portugal's refusal to yield the territory.
A 26-year-old thug, fleeing with a $4,000 payroll, was shot and killed in a pistol duel with a policeman on crowded lower Manhattan streets yesterday.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley started yesterday to develop a new pattern for Columbus Circle to meet the traffic demands that will be posed by the Coliseum there. The $35,000,000 convention and exhibition hall and its related skyscraper will not be in use until next March but the Commissioner said it was essential to start redesigning the complex interchange now.

BONN, Germany, June 14 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, Foreign Minister, said today West Germany intended no broad-scale discussion of the question of Germany's frontiers in the forth-coming negotiations with the Soviet Union.
LONDON, June 14 -- Britain's No. 1 isotope salesman, Dr. Henry Seligman of the Harwell Atomic Research Station, launched an impressive nuclear by-product industry in atomic waste today.

The encouraging sales of spring and summer apparel will carry over into a strong fall season, buyers were told yesterday at the closing session of a two-day fashion clinic and forum sponsored by the Steinberg-Kass resident office in the New Yorker Hotel.

The Church-State quarrel in Argentina has reached a new and important stage in what will doubtless be a long struggle. It has already lasted seven months. President Peron, as expected, is showing diabolical brilliance in the way he is handling the matter.

An apartment house at 838 Riverside Drive, near 160th Street, has passed to new ownership. The six-story building containing twenty-four suites has been purchased by I. Krimer. The seller was the 5 East Nineteenth Street Realty Corporation, of which Irving Hirsch is president.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- If Ben Hogan wins the United States open golf championship that starts here on Thursday it is likely to be his last tournament appearance.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A $31,836,521,336 military program, including provision for a one-third expansion in the intercontinental bomber arm, was approved today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

In Isiah Thomas' Boston Journal, or Massachusetts Spy, appeared the lines that first documented the appearance of stars in the American flag. It was on March 10, 1774, and read in part: "The American ensign now sparkles a star which shall shortly flame wide from the skies.

There was no prisoner for Judge Edward F. Breslin to sentence in the Court of General Sessions yesterday because the prisoner had died in City Prison. Instead, the judge read a letter the prisoner had written four days before he died of a heart attack on June 5.

The steam locomotive, picturesque symbol of the nation's questing growth, is about to vanish from the Long Island scene. The last dozen of its kind will be out of use by early autumn, the Long Island Railroad announced yesterday.

HAMILTON, N. Y., June 14 (UP) -- Colgate's second-string doubles team turned in the only upset by tripping Cornell's first-string duo today in the thirty-third annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships. Hipkins and Marv Pomerantz beat Jerry Barrack and Craig Fanning, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, to gain the quarter-final.

ON BOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH, at Sea, June 14 -- Since this ship called at Cherbourg last Saturday. Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, has been the passenger most consistently stared at in the first-class accommodations.

LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) -- The United States Government was criticized at a Jewish international conference here tonight for being "hesitant" about pushing the adoption of United Nations human rights covenants.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The House voted today for Federal regulations on bank holding companies and to require them to divorce banking from unrelated business.
Discussions of a merger between the $280,000,000 Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the $48,000,000 Bell Aircraft Corporation are under way, according to a spokesman of Lockheed.
Rubber and coffee futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York exchanges, wiping out most of Monday's gains. Cocoa, however, continued to rise sharply. Trading was active in the three commodities.

"I believe everyone will agree that our farm and other rural families can and should have the same*** ready access to books, newspapers, magazines and other sources of information which our well-developed city library systems provide." So said Senator Hill of Alabama in reintroducing the Library Services Bill this year.
Brooklyn Law School conferred 164 degrees of Bachelor of Laws at graduation exercises last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Twelve hundred persons attended the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) The Civil Service Commission ordered today a Houston, Tex., railway mail clerk suspended for ninety days because he publicly opposed the renomination of Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas last year.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Outside buyers of hogs took to the sidelines today and the market turned steady to 50 cents lower. Faced with the nine-month highs in the Monday trade, shippers thought better of pursuing further price rises for wholesale pork. Cattle were steady to strong and vealers steady to S1 higher. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
LONDON, June 14 -- An important British shipping line gave a shock to the shipbuilding trade here today by announcing that it had ordered three new fast freighters from West Germany.
Shipments of copper to domestic frabicators rose to 124,853 tons last month from 119,863 in April, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Despite a flood of protests from United States airlines, the Administration still hopes to sign a recently completed commercial air agreement with West Germany "reasonably soon."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- The Netherlands is preparing to bid for a place in the international entertainment market. The country is one of the few that has made no special effort to establish native production of motion pictures.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby branded a Democratic plan for free poliomyelitis vaccine to all children today as a possible "back-door" approach to socialized medicine.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Charges that employe security procedures were improperly used to get rid of employes who should not have been discharged were laid today against an official of the Small Business Administration today.
Two parcels on the East Side have been sold after an ownership of more than fifty years. One is on Thirteenth Street near Third Avenue, the other is on Park Row near Mulberry Street.
A three-day round-the-clock vigil by scientists began yesterday when 5,000 bees arrived here from France to be studied in an unusual experiment.

FATE, in grimly whimsical fashion, has rigged things so that two newspaper landmarks -- the old World Building on Park Row, and The Brooklyn Daily Eagle plant at the other end of Brooklyn Bridge -- will lose their golden domes and go to dust at about the same time.

PARIS, June 14 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee (I. O. C.) approved reports from three nations -- Italy, Sweden and Australia -- today on 1956 Olympic preparations. The I.O..C then began looking ahead to the problem of where to hold the 1960 games.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- Another new development in Soviet military aviation has appeared recently in the skies over Moscow. It is a big twin-rotor troop-carrying helicopter, apparently capable of transporting fifty to sixty men.
At this time it is fitting to reaffirm our belief in free public higher education. For Dr. Jonas E. Salk, City College '34, is receiving an honorary degree from his alma mater on June 15.

Brig. Gen. Robert E. Condon, Director of the New York City Office of Civil Defense, swore in Fire Capt. James J. Costigan as Deputy Director yesterday at its headquarters, 425 Avenue of the Americas. Captain Costigan, who is on leave from the Fire Department, was acting director from last December until June 3, when General Condon was appointed Director by Mayor Wagner.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- The Dodger hurricane, which already seems to have made a shambles of the National League flag race, tonight struck the West for the second time this season with no apparent let-up in its devastating force.
Offerings of new corporate securities valued at more than $33,700,000 will be made by underwriting syndicates today as follows:
Somebody, former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said yesterday, has been using his name in vain.

The Child Study Association of America elected Mrs. Clarence K. Whitehill of Scarsdale, N. Y., as president at its annual meeting yesterday. The meeting was at the French Institute, 20 East Sixtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- A House Labor subcommittee tentatively approved today a bill that would authorize Federal grants of $1,600,000,000 in the next four years to help the states build adequate schools.
ROME, June 14 (AP) -- The world's oil industry is going into the chemical business in a big way, experts reported today.
The auditorium of Carnegie Hall should be preserved for its acoustics, its tradition, its atmosphere, its inspirational value and the position it has earned in the civilized world.

Four publications of Time, Inc. -- Time, Life, Fortune and Sports Illustrated -- henceforth will be handled for newsstand distribution by the S. M. News Company. At present they are being distributed by the American News Company.

A former member of the Fire Department testified in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that James J. Moran, former first deputy fire commissioner, had accepted $2,500 a week for former Mayor William O'Dwyer's re-election campaign in 1949.

RYE, N. Y., June 14 -- All but one of the singles quarter-final brackets were filled in the Manursing Island Club's twenty-fourth Eastern interscholastic tennis championships today. One seeded player fell by the wayside.

PARAMUS, N. J., June 14 -- Mrs. Allan Ryan of The Creek upset Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century in the fifty-second annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today at the Ridgewood Country Club.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 14 -- One of the nation's most prominent political figures resigned last night from the Moslem League, the ruling party.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 14 -- Governor Harriman bustled across heavily Republican Nassau County today to try to infuse more Democratic sentiment.
Five men were arrested yesterday in thefts of $100,000 in merchandise from the Yale Transport Corporation terminal, 460 Twelfth Avenue.

LONDON, June 14 -- The national railway strike was called off today. The Government agreed to appoint a referee of "impartiality, integrity and acknowledged judgment" to settle two outstanding issues between the nationalized railways and the trade unions.
HONG KONG, June 14 -- The second lot of Red Cross parcels for Americans imprisoned in Communist China is scheduled to be delivered tomorrow morning at the Hong Kong-Kwang-tung border.

Bil and Cora Baird, the husband-and-wife team of puppeteers, will star in dramatic roles Aug. 8 on "Studio One Summer Theatre. They will portray a husband-and-wife team of puppeteers, but under another name.
The organizing of millions of white-collar workers is the most urgent task facing the merged labor movement, George Meany asserted yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 -- Bruce Hammond of Belmont Hill carded 38, 36 -- 74 at the Greenwich Country Club today for the half-way lead in qualifying play of the thirty-ninth Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship tourney.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The New York Central Railroad's employe stock option plan was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- John W. Roberts of Columbus, Ohio, marked his debut in United States Seniors' Golf Association competition today by becoming the No. 1 challenger of the defending champion, J. Ellis Knowles of Rye.

Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama will address a joint luncheon meeting of the international trade and the transportation sections of the New York Board of Trade on June 29 at the Hotel Commodore. Mr. Sparkman, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations and the Banking and Currency Committees, will speak on "America's Future in International Trade."
AURORA, Ill., June 14 -- Northern Illinois Gas Company plans to spend $60,000,000 on new construction through 1958, Marvin Chandler, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today.
DARIEN, Conn., June 14 -- Darien wrestled with its conscience for two hours tonight before coming up with a new set of regulations that may block the plans of a Harlem church for an estate here.

SEVERAL years ago, when Jeno F. Paulucci was traveling about the country as sales representative for a food company, he noted that virtually every city and town of any size had a Chinese restaurant or one that claimed a Chinese cuisine.

According to newspaper reports the Secretary of State indicated in his recent press conference with regard to my passport case that "some of the furor over the matter arose out of a lack of awareness of procedures for review of passport denials" on the part of the federal District and Appeals Courts and of myself.

Allen B. du Mont Laboratories, Inc., announced yesterday its entry into the radio and high-fidelity phonograph fields. The company also showed at a regional distributors' meeting in the Statler its new line of sixteen TV sets, priced from $169.95 to $500.

Texas joined yesterday the states building toll express highways. It borrowed $58,500,000 to finance a six-lane, thirty-mile turnpike between Dallas and Fort Worth. The road is scheduled to be in use by July 1, 1957.

ONCE school is out, Mother need not be at a loss for an answer to her child's inevitable question: "What can I do now?" In fact, she can join her youngster in some projects that may well fill the leisure-time vacation bill.
Metal Box Company, Ltd, London, England, announced yesterday that its net income for the year ended March 31 rose to 2,227,000 ($6,235,600) from 1,541,000 ($4,314,800) in the previous year.
The International Society for the Welfare of Cripples opened its new headquarters at 701 First Avenue yesterday with a housewarming and a message from President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- An Upper Colorado River development bill, modified sharply to cut ground from under much of the expected House opposition, was approved today by a Reclamation subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- V. K. Krishna Menon of India reported today to President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles on the prospect for easing tensions between the United States and Communist China.
IN Florida last spring Manager Bucky Harris remarked of his youthful Detroit Tigers, "If these kids get hot, it could be like a forest fire. There'd be no stopping them."
Successive singles by Irv Noren and Mickey Mantle after a two-out walk to Joe Collins gave the Yankees a 7-6 ten-inning victory over the Tigers at the Stadium last night.

Volume in fashion accessories should accelerate during the fall season, giving department and specialty stores increases of 5 to 7 per cent, Kirby, Block Co., 128 West thirty-first Street, resident buying office, said yesterday. Some 250 merchandise managers and buyers attending the office's accessories clinic heard reports that sales to date this year have been running from 3 to 10 per cent higher than in 1954.

BUENOS AIRES, June 14 -- Two leading prelates of this capital's Roman Catholic archdiocese were dismissed today from their municipal posts by an executive decree. They were Msgr. Tato, Previsor, Vicar General and Auxiliary Bishop, and Msgr. Ramon Pablo Novoa, Diocesan Canon.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Eisenhower and Republican Congressional leaders mapped strategy today to save four Administration projects that are in trouble on Capitol Hill.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) "Mr. Speaker!" cried the House doorkeeper. "The flag of the United States!"

When Robert Penn Warren as doing research for "All the King's Men," a novel that won the Pulitzer Prize, he came across an incident in Southern history that intrigued him. It is the basis of his newest novel, "Band of Angels," which Random House will publish on Aug. 22.

William J. Keating, freed yesterday after a five-day term for contempt of court, was honored at a "coming out" luncheon. Speakers likened him to Galileo, Konrad Adenauer, Gandhi and other historic figures who went to prison rather than compromise their con sciences.

BALTIMORE, June 14 (AP) -- Pitcher Paul Rogovin of the Orioles walked in the only run tonight as the Chicago White Sox beat Baltimore, 1 -- 0. Jack Harshman limited the Orioles to three singles, but needed help from Sandy Consuegra in the ninth.

CHESTER, Pa., June 14 (AP) -- The Scott Paper Company disclosed today that it would exercise an option to buy 100,000 acres of timber lands in Franklin and Somerset Counties in Maine from the Great Northern Paper Company.
DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., made it plain today it expected the industry's "independent" companies to come up with a guaranteed annual wage plan.
In what shape is the nation's vital uranium program?

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 14 (UP) -- Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., the 1954 winner, shot a women's-par 72 today to take a 9-point lead in the first round of the triangle round-robin golf tournament at the Grossinger Country Club.

OMAHA, June 14 (AP) -- Wake Forest subdued Western Michigan, 10-7, tonight in the National Collegiate World Series and will meet Oklahoma A. and M. tomorrow night in a game to decide who will face Western Michigan for the championship Thursday night.

Apparently, everything is set for a brief New York visit of "The Skin of Our Teeth" under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy. Utilizing such luminaries as Helen Hayes, Mary Martin, George Abbott and Florence Reed, the Robert Whitehead production of the "Salute to France" offering is due here in mid-August.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Eisenhower accepted "with deep regret" today the resignation of Charles F. Willis Jr. as a White House staff member, effective June 30.

Harry J. Leddy, formerly executive vice president, has been appointed president of Shippers' Car Line Corporation, a subsidiary of ACF Industries, Inc. He succeeds Samuel M. Felton, who has been named president of another ACF subsidiary. Douglas Atlas has been elected as vice president in charge of sales of G. Barr Co., Chicago, manufacturer of chemicals. Gene Riegler has been elected assistant secretary.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- The major railroads face "a definite threat of a strike" by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen.
THE espresso shops in Greenwich Village have no doubt already begun buzzing with earnest discussion of "The Trial." It opened last evening at the old Provincetown Playhouse on Macdougal Street.
PRESSURE is again being exerted by some coastal states for legislation requiring salt-water anglers to be licensed.
No lady likes to hear she has hair of a "different" color. But women who are planning a European tour this summer may face the possibility of a two-toned top if they color their hair.
HOBOKEN, N. J., June 14 -- Mayor John J. Grogan tightened his control of the city administration today when a four-ward run-off election put into office only one anti-Grogan councilman.
State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray proposed yesterday that New York City experiment with single-block housing projects.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 14 (Reuters) -The expansion of international trade will remain on !a precarious basis until the principal currencies of the world are freely convertible, according to the twenty-fifth report of the Bank for International Settlements, published here today.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has called its $13,600,000 of 4 per cent Canadian dollar bonds for payment on Aug. 1. The bonds which have a stated maturity of 1962, will be retired at 101 1/2 and accrued interest at any Canadian office of the Bank of Canada.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Edward Corsi, ousted April 10 as a special adviser to Secretary of State Dulles, today praised President Eisenhower's proposal for speeding immigration under the 1953 Refugee Relief Act.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Two major steel companies informed Congress today they might seek court approval of their merger plans over objections of the Department of Justice.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 14 (AP) -- The Dutch Second Chamber (lower house) today unanimously approved the International Tin Agreement.

New styling has played a major role in the high demand for consumer goods and will continue to do so if business exerts "strong promotional and selling efforts." This view was expressed yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review.
Bishop William A. Scully of Albany told graduates of Manhattan College yesterday that lack of reverence was at the root of juvenile delinquency and that religion was the cure.
ALBANY, June 14 -- A ticklish political problem involving the disposal of state-produced St. Lawrence River hydro-electric power was left with Governor Harriman for decision today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today the treaty by which Austria regains independence and becomes an armed neutral.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Owen Lattimore won another round today in his long fight to escape trial on perjury charges.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Wheat showed a little disposition today to continue the advance ,started yesterday. But buyers were reluctant to follow rallies and prices had recessions on local selling. Corn was inclined to sag and rye, which was strong yesterday, reacted sharply on long profit taking.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger introduced today a resolution to set up a special Senate committee to study Canada's "baby bonus" program to see if a similar plan would be feasible for this country.
MANILA, Wednesday, June 15 -- The Philippine Government has reached an arrangement with Japan on a formula for World War II reparations.

There is no better prescription for New Yorkers about to prepare themselves for another year of whirlwind business activity by taking another plunge into the whirlpool of vacation "resting" than a dose of reflection on the unexcited, unhurried ways of the Dutch founders of New Amsterdam, the quiet forerunner of our feverish metropolis.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 9 to 15 points (45 to 75 cents a bale) higher than Monday, with a moderate volume of business.
G. R. Kinney Co Inc, shoe stores, in 225 4th Ave through Boyd E. Wilson Co Inc -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton Inc, brokers.

City College will confer 2,444 Bachelor's and Master's degrees at its 109th commencement exercises this evening. The ceremony Wilt be held in the college's Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. Governor Harriman will give the commencement address.

The Hungarian Communist regime has provided another important clue to help evaluate the meaning of the Soviet-Yugoslav rapprochement for the Eastern European satellites. By 1960, the Hungarian Communists have ordered, collective farms must be expanded to include over half the country's agricultural area.

Your front-page review on May 31 of the mass transit study by Theodore W. Kheel strikes a poignantly familiar note with me. Mr. Kheel finds that the woes of the public transit facilities are directly related to the excessive use of personal automobiles by people traveling within the city.
PARIS, June 14 -- It has been proposed that the North Atlantic Council hold a special meeting as a preliminary to the Big Four negotiations in Geneva beginning July 18.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on temporary loan notes totaling $36,040,000 to finance construction of two State-aided projects, Carver Houses in Manhattan and Forest Houses in the Bronx.

The new relationship between the United States and a sovereign Germany has again been emphasized by the joint statement issued on the conference between President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer. Going beyond the usual diplomatic courtesies, the statement declares that the bonds of friendship between the nations have become "very close" and that there is a "very broad field of understanding" between them.

Train marker lights on all I. R. T. lines except one will be changed at midnight tonight, the Transit Authority announced yesterday. The only train that will not be affected is the Broadway-242d Street-New Lots Avenue express, which has two red lights.
LONDON, June 14 -- Rising hopes of a settlement of the railway strike -- later fulfilled -- spurred further buying of industrial shares today. However, some of the early gains were not fully held.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- A bill that would provide Federal school aid to local school districts carrying out, or preparing to carry out, racial integration programs was introduced today in the House of Representatives.
The Greater New York Association, Inc., yesterday asked the State Racing Commission to approve its certificate of incorporation.
Richard H. Balch of Utica is quitting as Democratic state chairman to accept appointment by Governor Harriman as a member of the Public Service Commission.
NEW DELHI, India, June 14 -- The East Punjabi Government has arrested more than 5,000 Sikhs so far for agitating for a separate Punjabi-speaking state.
SINGAPORE, Wednesday, June 15 -- This key port of Asia remained in a state of unrest as the general strike here entered its third day.

A strike that would tie up half of the privately owned American merchant fleet was threatened yesterday as officials of four maritime unions warned shipowners that they would not work without contracts.
A two-day blood donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will begin today at the New York Telephone Company, 140 West Street.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the appointment of Edward J. Sparks of New York as Ambassador to Guatemala. James Weldon Jones' appointment as a member of the tariff commission also was confirmed. He is from Farmersville, Tex.

A 3-year-old daughter of blind parents fell from a window of her fifth floor home at 41-14 Twelfth Street, Long Island City, Queens, yesterday afternoon and suffered skull injuries and a fractured leg.

A new hiring agreement covering Brooklyn's more than 12,000 longshoremen was reached yesterday in a two-hour meeting between employers and representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association. Officials of the New York Shipping Association and the Waterfront Commission also participated.
An Army pamphlet listing words like "vanguard," "colonialism," "progressive" and "materialist" as clues that their users may favor communism has been rescinded.
BERLIN, June 14 -- Kurt Fehling, one of East Germany's best-known film directors, has taken refuge in West Berlin with his family.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- Hamilton Richardson, young Davis Cup player from Baton Rouge, La., and Bob Perry of Los Angeles emerged today as the United States hopes to turn back the strong Australian challenge in the singles of the London grass courts tennis championships.

The four-story apartment house accommodating sixteen families at 2107 Beverly Road in Brooklyn has been sold by Joe Boyke and others to an investing syndicate represented by Samuel K. Beier, attorney. The property occupies a plot 67 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer urged today that President Eisenhower and Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin use the Big Four conference to advance disarmament.

A Board of Estimate committee scheduled to meet today has an opportunity to prepare the way for two valuable additions to our New York City park acreage. This committee, on acquisition and disposition of property, is composed of Abe Stark, president of the City Council; Lawrence E. Gerosa, Controller, and a representative of Mayor Wagner in his absence.
Events tonight: Golden Hill Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Dessoff Choirs' Summer Sing, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, 8, and Greenwich House Music School chamber music concert, 46 Barrow Street, 8:30.
Labor suffered a first - round setback yesterday in its fight for state approval of supplementary unemployment benefits.
BOSTON, June 14 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox enjoyed their most productive inning of the season today, scoring eight runs in the third en route to a 12-4 conquest of the Kansas City Athletics.
Kansas City, Kan., borrowed $7,000,000 yesterday to finance water and electric power improvements at an interest cost of 2.0595 per cent.

GENEVA, June 14 -- There has been "a turn for the better recently" in international affairs, Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, said in a message read today at the International labor conference.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 14 -- The meeting next month of the Big Four hears of government is being welcomed here. It is seen as a step that could ease the "cold war" in Europe without bringing any loss to the momentum of Allied unity.

The first meeting of the New York committee for the 250th anniversary celebration of Benjamin Franklin's birth was held yesterday as luncheon in the Racquet and Tennis Club, Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

WHEN a man meets a girl who looks like his mother, the stage is set for a romance. The same rule -- familiarity breeds contentment -- plays an important role in the psychology of buying, according to Everett Brown, the man who modernized the oriental rug.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman said today proxy fights for control of corporations "seem to be increasing in frequency and in intensity." Thus, he said, "it is evident that new rules are necessary" to regulate such contests.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Willys-Overland Export Corporation was put on probation today for six months by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce for violation of that agency's export regulations. This followed the Federal agency's discovery that 100 jeeps purchased for use in Lebanon had found their way into Rumania.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The largest undeveloped land tract in downtown Washington was acquired today for a private multi-million dollar building project.
Alumni of Elmira State Reformatory joined prominent business men last night in honoring Msgr. Francis J. Lane on the thirty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 14 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem said today his Government was willing to discuss with North Vietnam the question of elections to unify the nation.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- Princeton University held its 208th commencement exercises today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The United States will conduct tomorrow the first nation-wide Civil Defense test based on an assumed hydrogen bomb attack in which millions of Americans would be killed.
The Four Knights of Harmony from Queens won the Greater New York championship for barbershop quartets last night.

BALTIMORE, June 14 -- International service has become an "obligation as well as a privilege of all," Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, declared today in a commencement address at Johns Hopkins University.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Obviously there were no "lazy" Giants operating at Wrigley Field today. Leo Durocher's world champions (circa 1954) opened the Western tour on a high note by trouncing the Cubs, 5 -- 0.
Although early gains lifted The New York Times combined average to within 7 points of its historic 1929 high, late selling overtook the stock market yesterday and the close was lower.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 -- The dollar fell today in the free exchange market here to the lowest point since December -- 75 cruzeiros.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Congress was told today that this country should seize every reasonable opportunity to work for peace while remaining prepared for "less favorable contingencies."

PARIS, June 14 -- France is our oldest European friend and at present relationships between Paris and Washington are good. But they are going to deteriorate and possibly quite soon. The reasons are apparent. But it is not equally clear what preventive steps can be taken.
PARIS, June 14 -- New York's Mayor Wagner, with guidebook in hand, turned typical American tourist this afternoon.
About 90 per cent of New York's young polio pioneers who received Salk vaccine in the 1954 field tests have applied for booster shots this year.
A new issue of $8,000,000 of Hackensack Water Company debentures is being offered to investors today by an underwriting syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and White, Weld Co.

Nassau County, N. Y., announced plans yesterday to borrow $19,187,000 in the public bond market for the permanent financing of public improvements. Bids on the bond issues will be opened on June 29. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1955, and will come due annually on July 1 from 1956 to 1985.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 15 -- The Government is in a quandary over appointment of an Ambassador to Washington. For the third time in a few weeks, the Chilean Congress has rejected the Administration's nominee on the ground that he lacked the qualifications.
PARAMUS, N. J., June 15 -- Four former champions reached the quarter-final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-second annual championship today.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz set aside yesterday the first-degree murder conviction of Raymond Holley, a 16-year-old boy who had been sentenced to die in the electric chair.

The sweet strains of Handel and MacDowell filled a corner or Bryant Park yesterday, and noontime wanderers there were refreshed with an hour or so of music. It was the opening of the summer series of recorded concerts from the collection of the New York Public Library.

The directors of the United States Fire Insurance Company voted yesterday to split the company's stock two for one with the declaration of a 100 per cent stock dividend. Subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting on July 12, the authorized stock will be increased to 2,000,000 from 1,000,000 shares of $3 par value.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- A new $2,000,000,000 program to put the Air Force's home defense communications on a semi-automatic basis was unveiled today. But questions have been raised about its financing.
After participating in the air raid drill in New York yesterday, Governor Harriman accused Federal authorities of "shirking responsibilities" in civil defense.
BUENOS AIRES, June 15 -The Argentine Government today deported two Roman Catholic monsignors accused as ringleaders of demonstrations against the regime last weekend.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 (UP) -- Billy Peacock broke Raul (Raton) Macias' jaw with a knockout left to the head at 2 minutes 29 seconds of the third round in a scheduled ten-round non-title fight tonight. More than 8,000 fans saw the bout at the Olympic Auditorium.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 15 -- Foreign Minister George Yeh of Nationalist China left for San Francisco today on what may be the most difficult diplomatic assignment of his career.
A strike of seamen against the major oil tanker operators of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts was called early this morning after all-night negotiations collapsed.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 -- The development of atomic power in the United States might be greatly speeded by the encouragement of atomic power development abroad, one of the nation's foremost nuclear experts said today.
Increased buying of women's accessories was noted yesterday as New York's fall fashion markets continued to draw intense interest from retail buyers.
A round or oblong loaf of cake, home-baked or purchased, is a favorite impromptu dessert. Some simple toppings:

The ACF-Brill Motors Company expects to end up in the black this year, the annual meeting in Philadelphia was told yesterday by William Nelson, acting president. The company had a net loss of $54,657 for the initial quarter.
MOSCOW, June 15 -- Pravda called on the Western powers today to prove their desire for positive results from the forth-coming Big Four conference.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Public Housing Commissioner Charles E. Slusser announced the results of the competitive sale today of $92,954,000 in short-term loan notes by forty-four local housing authorities.
NASTAETTEN, Germany, June 15 (AP) -- Mayor Wagner of New York visited the birthplace of his father today, and this little old Rhineland community near Wiesbaden made it a holiday.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume in most markets eased, but the domestic sugar contract registered the third highest number of sales of the year. Coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, cottonseed oil and soybean oil rose; sugar, wool, silk and zinc closed mixed, and burlap, tin and lead eased.
VIENNA, June 15 (AP) -- Elmer Rice, writer and dramatist, said yesterday that the frustrations of this age have given the hero's place in the modern play to the villain.

"State sovereignty" may be dwindling on many a front but in banking it is still more than a phrase. At least that's the way the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks sees it. The organization takes a dim view of proposals now advanced in Washington that virtually all banks -- national or state -- require approval of a Federal agency before effecting mergers.

The city's millions faced up to a simulated hydrogen bomb attack yesterday for the first time. On a gloriously warm and sunny day traffic was stilled and citizens generally moved indoors for ten minutes. For their disciplined cooperation they won the praise of civil defense leaders.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- The fifty-fifth United States Open golf championship will start tomorrow over a course that still has not been completely diagnosed by the entrants. A field of 162 leading golfers will tee off in the first of four rounds at the Olympic Country Club.

A man is truly old when a carnival comes to town and he does not go. It is the final, ultimate proof of a situation he has long suspected. Back a bit he found he preferred watching a ball game on television to battling his way up to the Polo Grounds, and this gave him pause.
A RARE collection of glass drinking vessels from all of the major glass-making sections of the world went on display this week at the Corning, N. Y., Museum of Glass of the Corning Glass Center.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 15 -- Adelphi College graduated 232 students and conferred honorary degrees upon nine men and women at its fifty-ninth commencement here today.
Through the year, favorites win one race in every three at the nation's race tracks. Yesterday was a fattening-of-the- average day for the favorites at Aqueduct. Five of the eight made the grade.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 15 -- The University of California announced tdoay "a major milestone in hormone research on ACTH."
HANOVER, N. H., June 15 -- John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth, announced today the establishment of a new administrative post and five other changes in administrative offices at the college.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Edward F. Howrey said today the Federal Trade Commission planned to make a "priority" study of the manufacture and sale of antibiotics, especially from the standpoint of pricing.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Yugoslavia is still "a good risk" for United States aid, the American Ambassador to that Balkan Communist nation said today.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Trading was slow in all grain pits today but there was expansion in wheat buying on early setbacks and corn also developed buying resistance, as did oats and rye. Buying activity broadened in the final hour of trading in all pits.
A loan of $15,900,000 was made to the Colombian National Railroads yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank).
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- The jury trial, more than any other factor, is the root of the log jam in the courts, a New York jurist said today.
Rockefeller Center, one of the most photographed sights in New York City, offered a rare picture yesterday -- the Channel Gardens deserted on a bright, sunny, summer afternoon.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 15 -- The president of the American Red Cross said here today that if war ever came to this country "what the Red Cross does could well tip the balance of morale in our favor."

Vyacheslav M. Molotov got his first look at modern American abstract art during an impromptu tour of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday. Like many other tourists, the Soviet Foreign Minister had a puzzled look and asked his guide: "What

PARIS, June 15 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, left by plane tonight for New York. He will meet there with Secretary of State Dulles and Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, Thursday and Friday.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 2 points (10 a bale) lower to 11 points (55 cents a bale) higher. The strength was most pronounced in the far months.

Governor Harriman presented safety poster awards yesterday to eleven teen-age artists. They won the prizes in a contest sponsored by the American Automobile Association. The first-prize winners, whose drawings will be distributed to 150,000 elementary schools, were Leonora Tarantino, 16 years old, 2025 Seventy-first Street, Brook lyn, and Andrew Vinci, 14, of 185 Boulevard, New Rochelle, N. Y. Miss Tarantino, whose poster warned children to "Play Away From Traffic," received $75.
STRIPED bass have reached Montauk almost on schedule. Most fish being brought in by trollers are in the "bull" class.
LONDON, June 15 -- Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan said today the West must avoid both appeasement and cynicism in the new phase of relations with the Soviet Union.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 15 -- Business conditions in New York State in the second half of the year should continue at the present high level, according to representative New York bankers. This may well produce a rise in interest rates.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that Dr. Lloyd G. Reynolds had been appointed director of its program in economic development and administration. He is Sterling Professor of Economics and chairman of the Department of Economics at Yale.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The American Medical Association questioned today the justification for "rushing" Salk poliomyelitis vaccine into wide use.
A huge "red light" brought city traffic to a halt at 2:05 P. M. yesterday.
At a standstill these last several months for want of a director, "Delilah" is expected to move apace with the signing of Robert Alton to handle its staging and choreography.

FRUIT and vegetable stands present a handsome picture for shoppers this week-end. Greens from near-by gardens have a dewy luster that denotes fresh succulence. Jersey strawberries are perfection -- fat, deep red, with a flavor as memorable as that of a precious vintage wine.

CHICAGO, June -- 15 -- Fears that automation will cut down employment are especially unwarranted in the retail food business, Mrs. Marie Kiefer, secretary-manager of the National Association of Retail Grocers, asserted today.

A decline last week of 2,752,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 166,233,006 barrels, compared with 168,985,000 a week earlier and 171,370,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill authorizing a study of ways to minimize loss of life and property in hurricanes, tornadoes and other severe storms.

Hunter College will confer 940 degrees at its 108th commencement today on the Bronx campus at Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, will preside. The exercises will be held at 5 P. M.

HONOLULU, June 15 -- Government workers in the only American city ever hit by foreign bombers scurried to shelter during today's nuclear bombing drill, but most islanders paid scant attention to sirens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15 -- The United Nations cooperated with city officials by providing shelter today for New Yorkers caught outdoors when defense test sirens sounded. Blue-uniformed guards stayed at their posts outside the building after directing a few dozen passersby to shelter in the United Nations basement garages.
EMERGENCY WHITE HOUSE, June 15 -- President Eisenhower took personal command tonight of a nation supposedly devastated by a mock surprise atomic attack that smashed more than fifty of its cities.
Governor Harriman promised yesterday to put through an integration of public and private unemployment benefits in New York State.

The Queens Distributing Company has leased a one-story building at 24-27 Forty-fifth Street in Astoria, Queens, through Queens Industrials, brokers. The lessee, distributor of Cantrell Cochrane products, will occupy the property as an executive office and warehouse.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- A barking dog led a child to a suburban thicket today and disclosed the bodies of two teen-aged girls who had been shot or stabbed to death.
NEWTON, Iowa, June 15 (AP) -- The Automatic Washer Company of Newton today announced its merger With the Washer- Dryer Corporation of Skokie, Ill., subject to approval of stockholders.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -The Senate approved and sent to the President today a bill extending the reciprocal trade program to June 30, 1958.

LONDON, June 15 (UP) -- Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., reached the men's singles quarter-finals of the London grass-court tennis tournament today by defeating Bob Perry of Los Angeles, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 15 -- Shortly after 11 A. M., Eastern standard time today, the commanding general of the Thirtieth Air Division, United States Air Force, warned of an impending but hypothetical attack in the Michigan area.
Three robbers acquired a choice arms collection yesterday.

If our civilization cannot prevent the use of atomic or nuclear bombs then it deserves to perish by them. When the first bomb falls in any country civilization will have ended for everyone everywhere.
SOUTHVILLE, Conn., June 15 -- The postman made his last round here today, dropping mail into four boxes for construction workers. Southville is now truly a place that was.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15 -- A native of Saipan, who never before had left the Pacific islands, appeared before the United Nations Trusteeship Council today. He told the international diplomats that Saipan's big problem was snails.

The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France meet here today to consider the subjects their chiefs wish to discuss with Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin next month. The Western heads of government will confer with the Soviet Premier in Geneva July 18.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The United States agreed today to an exchange of data on atoms-for-peace in agreements signed with Belgium, the United Kingdom and Canada.

A GOOD tip on care of cashmeres comes from Jerome Ohrbach, president of Ohrbach's. Mr. Ohrbach has watched the canny Scots (who make a good share of the cashmere sweaters produced) at wash, and offers these suggestions:
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The University of Pennsylvania conferred 2,023 degrees in course, 104 diplomas in nursing and seven honorary degrees at its 199th commencement today.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 15 (UP) -- Patty Berg, the 1954 winner from St. Andrews, Ill., shot a 3-over-women's-par 75 today in the second round of the triangle round-robin golf tournament at the Grossinger Country Club. That enabled her to keep a 9-point lead with plus 38 points, despite a 72 by Louise Suggs of Atlanta.
BUENOS AIRES, June 15 (AP) -- The police raided all of the 120 homes and offices of parish priests in the capital and its suburbs.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Chairman J. Sinclair Armstrong said today the Securities and Exchange Commission would tighten its rules requiring both sides in proxy contests to disclose the identity and interests of themselves and their backers.
BUFFALO, June 15 -- Greater home rule and taxing powers for ties were urged today. The recommendation was made by former mayor Stowell P. Fournia Massena.

While those of us who live on the Eastern seaboard have been forced to become acutely hurricane-conscious during the past few years, we tend to forget the weather scourge of the inland areas -- tornadoes. Figures compiled by the Weather Bureau and released this week should go far to restore our perspective.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The basis of the settlements reached between the United Auto Workers Union and automobile manufacturers was not a "guaranteed annual wage," a manufacturers' conclave decided here today.
Rises in sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the May Department Stores Company.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn and other House Democratic leaders decided today to open a drive soon for passage of a three- point program to "liberalize" Social Security benefits.

ROME, June 15 -- At the close here today of the fourth World Petroleum Congress its chairman, Prof. Marcello Boldrini of Milan, said nobody yet could say whether atomic energy represented a threat to the petroleum industry.
Hundreds of American women shoppers will invade the high fashion salons of Europe this summer to splurge on a made-to-measure outfit, according to a recent United Press dispatch from Rome.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Department of Justice appealed to the Supreme Court today to reinstate its civil anti-trust case against E. I. du Pout de Nemours Co., Inc., and General Motors Corporation. The appeal sought reversal of a decision by Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Chicago last Sept. 3.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 15 -- Federal Civil Defense authorities got a practical lesson in news dissemination here today from more than a hundred reporters, radio and television newscasters and their technical crews and newsreel and still cameramen.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- Robert Mitchum and Robert L. Jacks, independent producer, have joined forces to form Bandido Productions. They will make a melodrama called "Bandido" for United Artists release from a story and screen play written by Earl Felton.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- Radcliffe College graduated one of its most brilliant classes at its seventy-third commencement today.

A 12-year-old boy who was wading yesterday in Great Kills Harbor, S. I., lost his life when he stepped into a deep channel. Two of his companions flailed their way back to safety and a fourth boy was rescued.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Whenever a new development is reported in the effort to reform the Presidential electoral system there is immediate response from members of the devoted band which for years has vainly pressed for action. It is a pity this band is small.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 15 -- The Yugoslav Parliament reconvened today to take up a plan for achieving pure socialism.

Britain's railway strike is over, after seventeen days, without the nation having had to pay a disastrous price for it. Everyone must be thankful on that score, but if the cost was not prohibitive it was high.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- Paul Giel, the Giants' $60,000 bonus pitcher, gained his first major league victory today. The Giants beat the Cubs, 7-2, with five-run rally in the ninth inning.

Four men charged with substitution in efforts to obtain drivers' licenses were arraigned yesterday in Vehicle Accident Court. They were the first to be taken to court since the Motor Vehicle Bureau began its crackdown two weeks ago against persons who try to get licenses through misrepresentation.
Dr. David Dodds Henry, executive vice chancellor of New York University, urged the graduating class yesterday to hold firm against the pressures that scholars have always faced.
LONDON, June 15 -- Having anticipated the ending of the railway strike yesterday, the boom in industrial shares came to halt today. Early prices were lower but the markets closed firm.

ROME, June 15 -- L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, implied today that the Argentine President, Juan D. Peron, had incurred excommunication. The gravest censure of the Roman Catholic Church was brought on him by his measures against two high prelates of the Archdiocese of Buenos Aires, according to the paper.
An airline rule that has irritated many air travelers was discarded yesterday on most domestic airline routes. Known as reconfirmation, the regulation has never applied on overseas flights.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Officials of two major United States airlines contended today that a recently negotiated agreement with West Germany would cost American taxpayers millions of dollars in extra subsidies to domestic air carriers.

THIS morning's books are about Sir Winston Churchill, an imaginary British murder case and American railroads. Big wheels, little wheels and wheels within wheels, as it were. They all make good reading for summer or any other season.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15 (UP) -- Four Yale student editors began today a ten-week globe-circling trip that will take them to seventeen countries.

Stock prices rose 1 to 4 points yesterday until about 2:05 P. M., when the Civil Defense Air Raid Drill caused a thirty-minute suspension of business. When trading resumed investors appeared more cautious and some profit taking was in evidence near the close.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 16 (AP) -- Japanese press reports today said the Soviet Union had laid down tough terms for Japan at the London peace talks.
New Jersey and Westchester are introducing larger and simpler directional signs to make it easier for the motorist.
The city yesterday announced plans to use the Salk vaccine left over from the first round of injections this year to provide second shots for children who got only placebo (dummy) ones last year.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 15 -- The nation's ability to cope with a hydrogen-bomb attack was tested today for the first time.

James O'Farrell, the 28-year-old teacher who was stabbed by boy in the Joan of Arc Junior High School at 154 West Ninety-third Street last week, said yesterday that he would not move out of the city. He said he had been misunderstood earlier this week when he spoke about moving to Long Island.

NEWARK, June 15 -- The New Jersey Division Against Discrimination has scheduled a public hearing for June 28 on charges or discrimination by the Erie Railroad Company against Negro dining car waiters.
PARIS, June 15 (UP) -- A Detroit official seeking the 1960 Olympic Games today offered to pay the traveling expenses of all visiting athletes out of television proceeds.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 15 (UP) -- The Christmas family -- father, mother, son and daughter -- went into an underground hydrogen-bomb shelter earl tonight, sealed the two-by-four-foot steel door behind them and settled down for a three-day stay.

A 225-ton, electronically and hydraulically controlled "skin mill" able to sculpture jet aircraft wing panels in a fraction of the time required by conventional machining methods was shipped yesterday from the Albany plant of the Simmons Machine Tool Corporation.
The new trade agreement between the United States and Japan was termed a "super hoax" yesterday by Claudius T. Murchison, economic adviser of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.

ALBANY, June 15 (AP) -- Governor Harriman confirmed today reports that he would appoint Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, to the Public Service Commission. He did not say, however, when he would do so.
PARIS, June 15 -- Mixed reviews and audience reaction greeted Judith Anderson tonight in her interpretation here of Robinson Jeffers' "Medea."
NEW YORK STATE CONTROL CENTER, June 15 -- Some 3,567,000 persons "died" today in "hydrogen attacks" on eight cities in New York State.

MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, June 15 (Reuters) -- An infra-red photograph has revealed the signature of Rembrandt on a hitherto anonymous painting returned to a Dutch museum from the Goering collection of art looted by the Nazis.
ROME, June 15 (Reuters) -- Three United States scholars were tonight awarded prizes of 5,000,000 lire each (nearly $8,000) by Rome's Academy of Lynxes.
STEAKS, chops and the ready-to-heat dinners, both canned and frozen, stand by the cook-in-haste, giving her many a meal in minutes.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 15 -- Cities subjected to imaginary air attacks today, as listed here, included fifty-five within the continental United States and six in its territories.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 15 -- The wags are saying of today's Civil Defense test that everything is simulated but the confusion.

NASHVILLE, June 15 -- The Tennessee Board of Education approved today a program of gradual desegregation in the state's colleges beginning with graduate schools next fall. The program is subject to approval by the Federal District Court.
Communities near New York reported yesterday's air raid drill as the most successful so far.
Plans of the Traffic Department for a 353-car lot for metered parking in the business section of Jamaica, Queens, were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
With the advent of the summer recess in the New York City high schools and colleges thousands of students will seek summer employment in the city.

The possibility of using Ellis Island as a temporary shelter for delinquent boys was explored yesterday by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, and a group of educators and jurists.

ALBANY, June 15 (AP) -- The New York Telephone Company sought permission today to raise monthly charges for most home phones by 30 cents and for most business phones by 75 cents. Court action on a bid for greater increases is pending.
