DETROIT, June 15 (AP) -- American Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., ended a series of talks on economic matters today. The corporation makes Nash and Hudson cars.
PATERSON, N. J., June 15 -- A breathless story with an O'Henry ending was enacted in the streets today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- An H-bomb, fifty times as powerful as the atom bomb that fell on Nagasaki, "exploded" over midtown Philadelphia this afternoon during the ten-minute national air-raid drill.

Passage by the House and Senate of the bill which started out as "H. R. 1" reduces to a formality now the writing into law of the measure regarded by the Administration as the most important item on its agenda for the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress -- the extension for an additional three years of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program.
A fight was rapidly shaping up yesterday between forces favoring and forces opposing two new parks projected by the Park Department.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 8:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., June 15 (AP) -- One of Florida's circuit judges, C. E. Chilling-worth, and his wife diseappeared today and the police feared they had been kidnapped and possibly slain.

Charles Pope Day, New York realtor, was killed in a plane accident June 8 while on a fishing trip in northern Ontario, Canada, it was announced here yesterday by the real estate firm of Joseph P. Day, Inc.

Friends of music will be interested to know that the University of the State of New York has accredited the Hebrew Union School of Sacred Music, training center for cantors, to grant the Bachelor of Sacred Music degree on the basis of life experience, in addition to those who qualify in course.
Major league baseball teams, battling against last night's midnight trading deadline, completed several deals yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A make-believe hydrogen bomb "fell" on the nation's capital today at 3:25 P. M. However, President Eisenhower and 15,000 other Government officials had fled to safety.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The House turned down a plea today by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, to investigate what he called "crapshooting in the Government bond market." By a roll- call vote of 214-178, it defeated a resolution by Mr. Patman to direct the House Banking Committee to investigate the Federal Open Market Committee, which determines Federal Reserve monetary policies.

Columbus Circle has always been a traffic problem because of the many roadways that feed in there and make their exit. The complexity will increase tremendously when the new Coliseum and skyscraper office building on the western fringe open for business next spring.
Governor Harriman told 2,444 candidates for degrees last night at City College that the nation must think "big thoughts" and carry out "great projects" to maintain prosperity and promote peace.

The Greater New York Safety Council has issued a word of warning about a safety hazard at this time of year -- the abandoned refrigerator. Caution is given to families going on outings to unfamiliar areas where youngsters, tempted to do some exploring, may come upon a refrigerator, lock themselves in it and run the danger of suffocation before they are found.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- The Democratic-controlled Senate Rules Committee over-rode Republican objections today and approved a bill to permit political parties and candidates to spend more money on election campaigns.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 15 (AP) -- The two prelates, who were hustled out of Argentina today without even a change of clothing, told on their arrival here of their ordeal with the police and the Peron regime's campaign against churchmen.

ALBANY, June 15 -- Dr. T. Norman Hurd announced tonight his resignation as a fiscal consultant to the State Senate. He had been former Governor Dewey's budget director from 1950 until Governor Harriman took over this year.
The Queen Elizabeth, the world's largest liner, set a new turn-around record here for a major passenger ship when she sailed at 6:25 last night. She had docked at 1:16 yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Former Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, Republican of California, was fined today for manipulating his office payroll in a salary kickback scheme.
At the sound of yesterday's air raid sirens Wall Street locked away its billions of dollars of stocks, bonds and currency.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 15 -- Following are the texts of the White House announcement today on the test proclamation by President Eisenhower and the announcement by the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson:

CHICAGO, June 15 -- A mock hydrogen bomb was dropped on this city this afternoon as part of the nation-wide civil defense exercise. Theoretically, it destroyed the heart of the city, but almost three-fourths of the 3,600,000 population survived unhurt in the blast and fire of 5,000,000 tons of TNT power.

In your editorial of June 10 on the military reserves bill it is a source of some little gratification that you grant that the anti-segregation amendment proposed "was not entirely extraneous." In this small and passing delineation you differ -- and soundly -- from Arthur Krock's assumption in his column of the same date, and from President Eisenhower's sweeping characterization in his press conference of June 8.

CINCINNATI, June 15 -- The Dodger pennant express tonight ran full tilt into the sturdy right farm of Rudy Minarcin, Cincinnati's 25-year-old rookie hurler. The result was a rather startling crack-up that brought the Brooks to a grinding halt.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The United States and West Germany have agreed on the procedures to be followed in the forthcoming conversations with the Russians. It is under stood that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and President Eisenhower reached full understanding on the following points:
New York Masons are making blood donations at the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue. They began donating yesterday and will continue through next week.

The Courtley line of men's toiletries has been purchased by Lee, Ltd., from the Hudnut Sales Division of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, Inc. The line consists of after-shave lotion, men's cologne, antiseptic and deodorant body powder, shaving cream, hair dressing and shaving soap.
LONDON, June 15 -- Francois C. Erasmus, South African Defense Minister, began talks here today with Lord Home, Commonwealth Relations Secretary, and Selwyn Lloyd, British Defense Minister.

The writer of the following article devised the European Coal and Steel Community. He was chairman of its High Authority until last week. He left to persuade European opinion to continue on the path toward "a United States of Europe."

Led by President Eisenhower, some 15,000 key officials of the Government dispersed from Washington yesterday to secret relocation centers, while millions of people all over the country hurried into shelters in the first nation-wide test of our defenses against potential hydrogen bomb attacks.

Detroit's fierce early attack on Johnny Kucks and Tom Sturdivant proved an insuperable handicap to the Yankees yesterday. The Bombers struck back valiantly. But they accomplished too little too late to turn the tide and had to accept an 8-6 loss.

A collection of quotations encompassing America, its people, its characteristics and its history, is planned for publication on Nov. 2 by Harper, entitled "American Treasury 1455-1955." The work will be edited by Clifton Fadiman with the assistance of Charles Van Doren.
How stable is the national economy? Judging by one important statistical barometer -- the wholesale price index -- it is enjoying the most prolonged period of stability in the last decade.
A Federal Court yesterday upheld a group of stockholders in their fight against a capital-stock reorganization of the Western Maryland Railway Company.

While Deputy Mayor Epstein's study and recent recommendations on juvenile delinquency have had the well-deserved editorial endorsement of The New York Times and the appreciative acceptance of many responsible civic organizations and individuals, we should like to urge the adoption of a course of positive action looking toward the translation of Mr. Epstein's proposals into tangible accomplishments.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15 (AP) -- The Indonesian Government today denied Dutch charges it had tortured twenty-three Dutchmen arrested eighteen months ago.

The maritime industry must not fall into the error of indulging in dreams of push-button ships because of the apparent proximity of nuclear power for merchant craft, G. Joseph Minetti of the Federal Maritime Board warned yesterday.
PARIS, June 15 -- The French Cabinet gave qualified approval today to a draft plan for the administrative reorganization of Algeria.
Our most potent weapon against totalitarianism is the "miraculous power of spiritual force," Dr. Albert C. Jacobs, president of Trinity College, said last night.

Twenty-nine men and women, members of religious pacifist groups, were arrested yesterday in City Hall Park for refusing to take shelter during the air raid drill. The group, including writers, editors and professional persons who openly have objected to this country's manufacturing of atom and hydrogen bombs, were seated in the park when the drill began.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Fred A. Seaton, former Nebraska Senator, was named today deputy assistant to the President for administrative liaison between the White House and all other Government departments and agencies.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack advertised yesterday for bids to demolish and remove the Third Avenue elevated structure.
World diplomats were urged yesterday to explore ways to resist communism without resorting to a showdown between the American and Russian stockpiles of atomic weapons.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Home economics research has been reinstated by the Department of Agriculture under the prodding of Congress.
LONDON, June 15 -- A sharp drop in wool consumption in the United States was blamed today for a decline in the wool textile industry of the world.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 15 -- The Westchester County Association, an organization of business executives, asked the State Thruway Authority today not to open any part of the New York-Buffalo Thruway in Westchester untill all can be opened.

RYE, N. Y., June 15 -- Roy Moore of Waterville, Me., and John W. Roberts of Columbus, Ohio, today finished in a tie for the lead in the United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The Al-Malik Saud Al-Awal, the world's largest tanker, unloaded her first cargo today after completing her maiden voyage from Hamburg, Germany, via the Persian Gulf.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Factories produced more goods in May than in any other month in the country's history, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

Television and radio will give extensive coverage throughout next week to the tenth anniversary meeting of the United Nations in San Francisco. Most broadcasts will be carried live from the Opera House, where the U. N. charter was signed in 1945.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee charged today that private power interests were banding together to destroy the Tennessee Valley Authority and related projects.
NO finer description of the game of golf was ever offered than the one credited to some philosophic phrase-maker whose identity, unfortunately, has been lost to posterity. Said he:

The five-story building on lot 21 by 100 feet at 67 Liberty Street has been sold by the Reynhol Realty Corporation to Liberty Shelby, Inc., a restaurant, in a deal negotiated by Stanley W. Kempner Son and Hanford Henderson, brokers.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Negotiations for the sale of the Mandel Brothers stores have been broken off because the prospective buyers failed to arrange financing within a period agreed upon, Leon Mandel announced today.
The program of the Eisenhower Administration to revamp and enlarge the United States career diplomatic service was sharply criticised today by George F. Kennan.
When theoretical disaster struck the city at 2:05 P. M. yesterday, 695,245 school children were assumed killed or injured.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Muscovites had a new sports hero tonight -- an American. In the presence of 15,000 of them, Paul Anderson of Toccoa, Ga., a lad of 22, weighing 340 pounds, set two world weight-lifting records.
The Kroger Company, the $190,000,000 Cincinnati retail food chain that operates about 1,680 stores, has acquired the twenty-five-store supermarket chain of Krambo Food Stores, Inc., of Appleton, Wis.
An exhibition of art and antiques that, outside of a museum, is probably the most notable ever staged in New York, opens today for the benefit of the New York City Cancer Committee.
LONDON, June 15 -- About 500 crew members of the Cunard liner Queen Mary left the ship at Southampton today, some of them to join the strikers whose wildcat walkout has tied up six Atlantic liners.
LONDON, June 15 -- According to a survey by the American Jewish Committee, a vast majority of American Jews want to maintain their identity as Jews and as Americans.
Jed Harris and Michael Myerberg have leased Warner Brothers' Brooklyn studio for the filming of "Patterns," which will star Van Heflin, the independent producers announced yesterday.

A block of common stock of Pioneer Natural Gas Company valued at $21,923,864 and held by Sinclair Oil Corporation until last July was placed on the market yesterday by an investment banking syndicate headed by Union Securities Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Civil Service Committee voted today to make retroactive to March 1 about $325,000,000 in annual pay increases for more than 1,000,000 Government workers.

Distillers Corporation - Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries increased its earnings in the quarter ended April 30 over a year ago, but showed a decline for the nine months' period, according to the report issued yesterday.

BOSTON, June 16 (UP) -- Billy Klaus' two-run homer in the ninth off a relief pitcher, Johnny Sain, lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 7-6 victory and a sweep of their three-game series with the Kansas City Athletics today.
CINCINNATI, June 16 -- The Dodgers were able to weather one Ted Kluszewski home run tonight. But when the big fellow hit another, it proved one too many.

Among such items as red and white striped silk broadcloth shorts for $12.50 (with garters to match for $2.50), and a gold plated chain belt for $20, a black wool "Admiral's Throw" is found at Gourielli's gentlemen's apparel department, 16 East Fifty-fifth Street.

We in the West Side Branch of Americans for Democratic Action have been highly pleased by the constructive manner in which The Times has dealt with the question of juvenile delinquency. The Times provides particularly valuable service by publishing in detail the reports of professional groups which have studied the problem and which depend upon an enlightened public to support the programs which they recommend.
Employes of Atlantic Division, Pan American World Airways, will give blood today to the regional Red Cross at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Among the many suggestions advanced to alleviate tension on the Egyptian-Israeli border along the Gaza strip there is the suggestion made by the Egyptian Government and frequently reported in The Times that an area along that strip be demilitarized on both sides of the border. Allow me to comment on it.

An employers association started a suit yesterday in Supreme Court to enjoin a union from alleged acts of "association busting." The term was defined as activities on the part of a union that, if undertaken by an employer, would be described as "union busting."

BUFFALO, June 16 -- Governor Harriman announced tonight a plan for a joint city-state study aimed at broadening municipal home rule. He said he would appoint a special committee of state officials to work with representatives of cities.
Regents Week -- a sort of academic judgment time -- will begin today for 300,000 pupils in the public, private and parochial schools in this state.

The St. Joseph Lead Company increased the price of zinc one-half cent a pound yesterday, to 12 1/2 cents, East St. Louis basis. Other sellers soon matched the new quotation. Zinc now is at the highest level since January of 1953. In February last year it sold as low as 9 1/4 cents.
CHICAGO, June 16 -- The Giants' climb toward the distant mountain peak of first place in the National League was interrupted by the Cubs at Wrigley Field today.
STRANGERS are too apt to take up the legend that city people are like their pavement and their skyscrapers -- cold and hard.

Charles Frederick Worth (1825-95), who for thirty years was arbiter of Paris fashions, is the subject of a biography by Edith Saunders. Called "The Age of Worth," the story tells of Worth's introduction of crinolines, the influence they had on his life and develops the background of the court of Napoleon III.
As required by law, the outgoing Transit Authority produced yesterday a plan for sale of its surface lines to private operators.
Members of the Board of Education heard protests yesterday that the proposed record outlay of $127,525,000 for school construction next year was only a scratch on the surface.

Stock prices closed irregularly higher yesterday after the list, as measured by The New York Times fifty stock average, pushed to within 3.72 points of the 1929 high. Almost all the upward movement centered on industrial issues, while rails were genrally ignored.

ROME, June 16 -- Pope Pius XII excommunicated Juan D. Peron, President of Argentina, today along with all others who "trampled on the rights of the Church" and "used violence" against ecclesiastical dignitaries in that country.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 16 -- British East Africa has been awarded $4,161,700 in economic aid by the United States.

The city's civil defense workers ended yesterday the mass phase of their twenty-six hour drill against a hydrogen bomb attack. The wind-up came as suggestions were made for improving the monitoring of deadly rays that might persist for years.

RYE, N. Y., June 16 -- The final segment of 122 players failed to produce a threat to Roy Moore of Waterville, Me., and John W. Roberts of Columbus, Ohio, at Apawamis today. A play-off was fixed for Sunday afternoon to determine the fifty-first United States Seniors' Golf Association champion.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, still trim and soldierly at 74, came out of retirement long enough today to reminisce about the beginnings of the Marshall Plan for the recovery of Europe.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau signaled the opening of the hurricane season today by hooking up its new coastal warning system. Ten bureaus have been added.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Wheat rallied after an early dip today, but the bulge did not hold, and the tone was weak in late trading. Some hedging by mills against Southwest purchases was indicated, but there is little country selling of cash wheat except at high premiums over the support level.
The United States, Britain and France agreed yesterday on the procedure they will propose to the Soviet Union for the meeting of the Big Four heads of government in Geneva starting July 18.

We have been warned to expect a rise in transportation fares. This is the first weather vane, and more can be expected into a built-up psychologically planned sugar-coating of the final news that the subway fare is to be 20 cents and a year later it will be 25 cents. This is the pattern.

PARIS, June 16 (AP) -- Rome was picked as the site for the 1960 summer Olympic Games today. The International Olympic Committee rejected Detroit's offer to pay the athletes' traveling expenses if the games were awarded to the Michigan city.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- An export credit of $4,235,000 has been established by the Export-Import Bank of Washington for the Columbian Steel Tank Company of Kansas City. The credit is to help finance the sale of grain storage equipment to Turkey.

The Dade County, Fla., Port Authority borrowed $21,000,000 in the public market yesterday to refund $8,870,000 of outstanding debt and to finance expansion and improvements at the Miami International Airport.

ROD SERLING is the author of "Strength of Steel," the play presented on "Star Tonight" last evening over Channel 7. Since Mr. Serling also wrote "Patterns" and "The Rack," two of the outstanding television plays of this year, there was reason to look forward with some anticipation to his latest script.
GENEVA, June 15 -- The Communists seem to be attempting to drain the growing strength of the drive to improve productivity in west Euorpean industry.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 19 points (95 cents a bale) higher to 6 points (30 cents a bale) lower yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Demands that the United States warn President Juan D. Peron of Argentina that the United States would not tolerate persecution of the Roman Catholic Church were made in Congress today.

The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau is in business at a new stand, a cheerfully attractive Visitor Information Center at Pershing Square just across Forty-second Street from Grand Central Terminal. Thus the increasing interest in promotion of New York as a place to convene, to visit on vacation and to enjoy on the week-end takes on substance and form.

CINCINNATI, June 16 (AP) -- Chester G. Gifford, president of the Crosley and Bendix home appliances division of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation, said today it "is simply not true" that the Automatic Washer Company of Newton, Iowa, would acquire all of the Bendix patents.
A major segment of the strikebound merchant marine reached a settlement last night with the National Maritime Union.
LOS ANGELES, June 16 -- The electric utilities industry was urged by some of its leading figures today to unite in an aggressive campaign against advocates of governmental power generation.

HAMILTON, N. Y., June 16 (UP) -- Two more Yale men reached the semi-finals of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today. The Elis also took a commanding lead in the team point race for the Tod Backe Cup.

ROME, June 16 (AP) -- A Chamber of Deputies commission lifted last night the parliamentary immunity of Signorina Laura Diaz, a Communist Deputy, for a rehearing of charges that she had defamed the Pope.
WHITE PLAINS, June 16 -- People and flowers from all parts of New York State converged today at the County Center here for the first All-State Flower Show.
The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday called for the elimination of the remaining "pockets of discrimination and segregation" in the Navy.
Production of newsprint in Canada and the United States continued at a record rate in May, according to the report yesterday by the Newsprint Servce Bureau.
BUENOS AIRES, June 16 (AP) -- Following is a translation of President Juan D. Peron's speech in Spanish to the Argentine people tonight:

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 16 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, said today that in his twenty years in the field of public health he had never seen anything like the confusion over the Salk vaccine.
EMERGENCY WHITE HOUSE, June 16 -- President Eisenhower moved swiftly today to keep practice Operation Alert from fouling up the serious business of the nation's foreign relations.

The seamen's strike, only one phase of which was settled last night, is the resultant of extremely complicated forces far too little understood by the public at large. Yet the public is deeply involved: through the inconvenience and loss of business caused by demobilized ships and through the money it contributes in federal taxes to subsidize some merchant marine operations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold indicated today he was hopeful of the early release of the eleven United States airmen still held in Communist China.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Diplomatic authorities said today Israel had asked the United States for a mutual defense and security treaty.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 -- The Federal Government would declare a moratorium on debts and other legal obligations immediately after a mass nuclear attack.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Today's packaged, easy-to-serve foods may be less work for housewives, but it means more work for the Federal Food and Drug Administration, George P. Larrick, Foods and Drugs Commissioner, said today.
Dresser Industries, Inc., improved sales and earnings in the quarter ended April 30, but half- year figures were still lower than those of a year earlier.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 -- Federal press officers worked at fever pitch tonight trying to correct an impression among farmers across the nation that acreage restrictions and marketing quotas on all major crops except tobacco had been canceled.
LONDON, June 16 -- Reviewer of London newspapers admire Orson Welles' blank verse adaptation of Herman Melville's "Moby Dick," which opened tonight at the Duke of York's Theatre.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 16 (AP) -- A United States correspondent, John Graham Dowling, and thirteen other persons were killed or unaccounted for in the crash of an airliner in a fog early today. Only ten aboard are known to have survived.

The racket of automobile horn-blowing in the streets has an adverse effect on the average person. It causes a faster pulse rate, heightened blood pressure, irregularity in heart rhythm and an interference with the efficiency of the brain.

LONDON, June 16 -- Prime Minister Eden turned down in Commons today fresh Laborite demands that all tests of thermonuclear weapons be banned while the United Nations Disarmament subcommittee was in session.

According to Foreign Minister Shigemitsu Soviet peace terms for Japan are "almost identical" with those presented in San Francisco in 1951, the rejection of which prompted the Soviets to reject the San Francisco treaty. These terms, listed in a draft treaty revealed in Tokyo, call in effect for the abrogation of the American-Japanese defense alliance, the withdrawal of American defense forces from Japan and the neutralization of the country.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate approved tonight a four-year extension of the regular military draft.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 16 (Reuters) -- The leader of an alleged underground organization said to have aimed at restoring a separate Fascist state in Slovakia has been sentenced to death, it was announced here tonight.
Now comes the birch leaf miner to add to the chores of folk in Suburbia.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower's program to inject private enterprise into the Government's vast production of electric power won a major victory in the House of Representatives today.
Communications with Buenos Aires were cut off for several hours yesterday during the revolt in Argentina.

Today's new film is "Las Vegas Shakedown," an Allied Artists melodrama starring Dennis O'Keefe, Coleen Gray and Charles Winninger, at the Palace. Heading the supporting cast are Thomas Gomez, Dorothy Patrick and Mary Beth Hughes. Steve Fisher wrote the screen play and Sidney Salkow directed.
THOSE who enjoy angling solitude should find it without too much trouble on even the more popular trout streams this week-end. The big pressure for the dry fly angler has been lifted.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
BOSTON, June 16 -- An advisory committee of medical experts recommended today that Massachusetts postpone further anti-polio inoculations.
" The Trombone Player," a musical comedy that was to have a San Francisco story by George Abbott and William Saroyan, has been dropped. The cancellation was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Abbott.

EMERGENCY WHITE HOUSE, June 16 -- President Eisenhower accepted today with "real regret" the resignation of Preston Hotchkis of California as the United States representative to the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations.
NEWPORT, Pa., June 16 (UP) -- Billy Cox, traded to the Cleveland Indians by the Baltimore Orioles, passed up a possible $10,000 world series check today when he decided to quit baseball.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 16 -- The council of the Nguyen Phuc family, to which Bao Dai belongs, has struck another blow at the standing of South Vietnam's Chief of State.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Scientists representing different points of view on technical problems posed by the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine have been invited to appear before a Congressional committee.
A threatened strike of 10,000 oil workers was averted early yesterday by a wage increase of 10 cents an hour and liberalized sickness and accident benefits.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 16 -- The Brightside Farms' Jamie from Springfield, Ill., scored a three-quarter length victory over Faber Hanover in the tenth annual $25,000 invitation American Trotting Championship tonight. He stepped the mile-and-a-quarter distance at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:33 3/5.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 16 (UP) -- Patty Berg, the 1954 winner, increased her lead in the Triangle round-robin golf tournament to 18 points today. She shot a women's par 72 in the third round at the Grossinger Country Club.
The clash between President Juan D. Peron and the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Argentina, which forms the immediate background for yesterday's revolt, came into the open Nov. 10.
PARIS, June 16 -- Francois Mauriac, Nobel Prize winner for literature in 1952, has accused the French Government of allowing French counter-terrorism to run rampant in Morocco.

Three young Colombians on a thirty-month goodwill tour of the hemisphere rolled into Times Square yesterday in a flag-decorated automobile. They immediately created at least one isolated iota of bad will.
JERUSALEM, June 16 -- A meeting of Egyptian and Israeli representatives concerning the Gaza border may take place next week.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 786,707 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 73,034 cars or 10.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 89.124 cars or 12.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 10,545 cars or 1.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago. Increases were reported for all commodities.
The first medium-term private bank loan from this country to an Italian industrial corporation without any kind of government guarantee since World War II was announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, June 16 -- Motion pictures portraying sex, violence and crime have a bad influence on the public, but are not necessarily responsible for establishing low standards of juvenile behavior.

Samuel Reshevsky gained his fourth victory in the last round of the practice series among members of the American chess team that will be sent to Moscow. His opponent at the Marshall Chess Club, where the series ended yesterday, was Arthur B. Bisguier, United States champion.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged the National Food Brokers Association and its 1,750 members with operating an illegal trade conspiracy "to the prejudice and injury of the public."
The city's basic real estate tax rate for 1955-56 will be $3.85 for each $100 of assessed valuation. This is a rise of 17 points above the current rate of $3.68.
Business loans of New York City banks rose $431,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the greatest such increase ever reported.

During the sometimes confused and confusing Senate hearings on the stock market, most of the participants were able to agree on one point -- the need for tighter regulation of the unlisted or over-the-counter market.

CLINTON, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- A conference on missionary work was told today that the Christians have the greater truth in Jesus Christ (as against Communists) but we don't have the moral discipline to make it the world truth."
Secondary shots of anti-polio vaccine will be given today in Westchester and Nassau Counties to pupils who received the placebo (dummy) vaccinations last year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Batjac Productions, independent company headed by John Wayne and Robert Fellows, has announced two new projects for late summer filming.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges closed irregular yesterday. Coffee, sugar, zinc and wool were mixed; cocoa, rubber, burlap, lead and copper rose, and hides, silk, potatoes, cottonseed oil and soybean oil eased.

THE trade winds had been expected to strike with the force of Hurricane Hazel but they didn't blow hard enough to rustle a flimsy curtain. The June 15 deadline slipped quietly past and left behind nothing but disappointment. The Giants, who desperately needed a slugging catcher, didn't get one. The Yanks, who were hurting for additional pitching, received no reinforcements.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ended June 15 increased $30,000,000 to $18,678,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor, was indicted yesterday by a Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn on a charge of cheating the Government of $24,177 in personal income taxes for a three-year period.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Eisenhower in a message tonight underscored that the United States Government "attaches great value to its firm friendship with Israel and seeks the establishment of an enduring peace in the Middle East."
BONN, Germany, June 16 -- Some of the permanent chiefs of the newly created West German Defense Ministry have been selected by the Government.

Nations of the free world, particularly in the Far East, were urged yesterday to adopt a "Point Five" program that would produce for them more dollars from American tourists and make them less dependent on American economic aid.

BUENOS AIRES, June 16 -- Armed revolt flashed out against President Juan D. Peron today and bombs rained on the Government House area in two air raids. Tonight the President declared the rebellion had been put down.
LONDON, June 16 -- An explosion in a Royal Navy submarine in Portland harbor this mourning trapped thirteen men. Hope for them was abandoned late in the day.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 -- the fifty-member board of governors of the American Red Cross at a special meeting here today named three vice chairmen to assist E. Roland Harriman of New York, chairman.
A collection of the writings and personal files of the late Anne O'Hare McCormick, New York Times writer, has been given to the New York Public Library.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 16 -- A survivor of the "white coolie" prison army that built the Burmese "railway of death" in World War II has been appointed dean of the Princeton University Chapel.
EMERGENCY WHITE HOUSE, June 16 -- A five-year certificate for the Seaboard and Western Airlines to fly cargo over the North Atlantic was approved today by President Eisenhower.

For the second time in a three-game series with Detroit, the Yankees yesterday came through with a last-ditch rally to salvage an apparently lost cause. Three runs in the ninth inning gave them a 3-2 victory over the Tigers at the Stadium.
LONDON, June 16 -- The Consultative Conference of Jewish Organizations wound up its five-day meeting here today with a report that skirted controversy with the Zionists.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, Republican Senate leader, repudiated today an attack from the Republican far right wing on the forthcoming Big Four conference.
The New York Law School conferred three honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws and awarded eighty degrees of Bachelor of Laws last night at its commencement in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization has delayed for a month its decision on sponsoring a third round of expansion for aluminum production.
State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits suggested new sources of revenue for this city last night based on services rendered. In this category he listed:
Twenty-one leading engineering educators and industrialists proposed yesterday the organization of a national committee to solicit funds for a new engineering headquarters building.

Harold Macmillan, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said here last night that the West was prepared to take account of the Soviet Union's security and "legitimate requirements," but was determined to reject appeasement or surrender.
Juan Domingo Peron, President of Argentina, clings to the theory that neither nations nor men have permanent friends. His idea is that they have merely permanent interests.
LONDON, June 16 -- R. A. Butler promised Britain today that the Conservative Government would seek better methods of conducting industrial relations.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 16 -- Oil production for May in Venezuela amounted to 2,041,234 barrels a day, according to figures released by the Government today. This is a drop of about 100,000 barrels daily from the April figure -- a drop which authorities attributed to lesser demand for fuel oil in the United States at the end of the spring season.

PARAMUS, N. J., June 16 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair rallied to defeat Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood in the quarter-finals of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today.
Construction of a $63,000,000 fleet of modern vessels for the coastwise transportation of loaded truck trailers was proposed yesterday by a domestic steamship operator.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 -- Following is the official transcript of the news conference remarks here today of George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury:

The tenth anniversary session of the United Nations, convening in San Francisco on June 20, should obligate every American citizen to make himself an essential participant in this international birthday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- Tommy Bolt put together a great round of golf today. The former carpenter, who became a links professional, led the field in the first round of the United States Open championship with a 67. He beat par at the Olympic Country Club by three strokes.
Louis Hoffner, who was wrongfully imprisoned for almost twelve years, won an award of $112,291 yesterday in the State Court of Claims.
THERE is gold at the end of the trail for the automobilist who enters the bumper-to-bumper competition that is week-end driving around New York City during summer.

United Gas Corporation revenues from sales of natural gas, liquid hydrocarbons, crude oil and potash in the first five months this year were higher than the 1954 period, but earnnings were lower, N. C. McGowen president, told stockohlders at the annual meeting yesterday in Shreveport, La.

A few shopping days still remain to Father's Day, and an increasingly tense household drama is unfolding throughout the land. Chief protagonist is Father. Morally required to foot the bills of our patriarchal society 364 days in the year, Father is discovered secretly looking forward to the one day of financial solace officially permitted him by the calendar.
The current national Civil Defense test merely emphasizes weaknesses already known and underscores needs long apparent.
Yesterday was a day of high drama in Argentina -- a military revolt and the excommunication by the Holy See of President Peron and other Government leaders.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UP) -- The Senate passed today a $1,317,117,300 appropriations bill for the Commerce Department and related agencies. It defeated moves to cut subsidies to airlines and merchant ships.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 16 -- The Neiman-Marcus Company, nationally known specialty store of Dallas, has merged with Ben Wolfman, Inc., a Houston women's specialty store, it was announced jointly today.

The impact of recent revelations concerning unexpected Soviet progress in long-range bomber production is manifest in Tuesday's action by the Senate Appropriations Committee on military appropriations for the next fiscal year. The Senate group approved a $356,000,000 increase in Air Force funds, a sum which will permit a 35 per cent rise in output of B-52 bombers.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- A leading authority in the grocery industry said today that Americans were now spending a smaller percentage of their income for more and better foods than they did thirty years ago.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 16 -- Civil Defense officials labored today to cope with hypothetical disaster problems greater than the country has ever faced.

In a mail referendum beginning today, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L., will ask 5,000 members here whether they want to sustain or revoke a resolution that condemns AWARE, Inc.
BRIDES are going to look like Queen Victoria this fall, crowned with tiny coronets and sweeping to the altar in full-skirted gowns plumped out with hoops and crinolines.

The nationwide civil defense test this week may have had its soft spots, but it could hardly have failed to impress the interested observer with two things: the almost unimaginable destructiveness of the hydrogen bomb and the absolute necessity of preparation to meet a sudden enemy attack.

The Treasury's issues of longest-term bonds -- the 3s due in 1995 and the 3 1/4s due in 1983 -- were marked down in price drastically in the dealers' market yesterday on reports that the Treasury is considering resuming some long-term financing in connection with Federal Government borrowings in July and August.

Fulton of the Sanford Stud Farms carried the "feather" to victory in the $10,450 Hitchcock at Aqueduct yesterday. The 8-year-old son of Head Play remained in front all the way to take the steeplechase of about two miles by more than two lengths.
LAKE PLACID, June 16 -- New York State bankers were urged today to re-examine their consumer lending activities and practices.

The fifteen-story apartment hotme for sixty-two families on j plot ?0 by 10O feet at 639 West l End Avenue, northwest corner of Ninety-first Street, has been I purchased for investment by Mercaz Equities, Inc., from Samuel Knepper.
LONDON, June 16 -- The stock markets remained unsettled today though a firmer tendency developed in later business.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 -- Konrad Adenauer today urged the United States to take the lead in pushing discussion of "controlled" disarmament with the Soviet Union at the forthcoming Big Four conference.
A television repairman in Queens pleaded guilty yesterday to making excessive and fraudulent charges for his work.

The Ambursen Engineering] Corporation of New York hasi purchased a one-story industrial building and adjoining land at 95 SchuyIer Avenue in North Arlington, N. J., from Jyle Schwartz. The property will be used for the storage of engineering and building equipment. Lehman Associates, Inc., were the brokers in the transaction.

Seatrain Lines, Inc., has !leased the tenth floor and about half of the eleventh floor in the twenty-story office building going up at 711 Third Avenue, between East Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16 -- The Harvard and Yale varsity crews had light spins on the Thames today, ending preparations for their annual clash tomorrow.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 -- Private purchase of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine would be cheaper for most parents than a Government program of free vaccinations, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby said today.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 -- The Government restated today its policy with respect to American prisoners of war who chose to remain with their Chinese Communist captors.
TOKYO, Friday, June 17 -- Moscow has offered Tokyo a draft peace treaty that in effect would neutralize Japan in the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- In the few days that have elapsed since the Supreme Court exercised its agreeable privilege of adjourning for the summer, members of its embattled bar have been going over the citations of merit, or licking the wounds, they acquired from the black-robed brethren during the 1954-55 term.
LONDON, June 16 (UP) -- Mervyn Rose eliminated Ham Richardson in the London lawn tennis championships today as Australians gained the four semi-final berths at the Queen's Club.

JERSEY CITY, June 16 -- Showing plenty of the fighting spirit that made him New Jersey's undisputed Democratic leader for three decades, 79-year-old former Mayor Frank Hague returned today to do battle with his critics.

In the recent controversy on polio vaccine I was somewhat intrigued by the fact that the formerly much heralded gamma globulin was never mentioned in any of the official reports on the fight against polio. Yet only a short time ago this serum was represented to the worried parents of this country as an effective protective against polio.

There's an old saying in the railroad equipment industry that "the roads order today for yesterday's needs and receive delivery tomorrow when the need is gone." Yesterday at a meeting in Nashville of the Southeast Shippers Advisory Board, William E. Callahan, president of American Railroads Car Service Division, made some remarks that seemed to bear out at least part of that statement.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 16 -- Under mock martial law, the nation practiced recovery today from a simulated hydrogen bomb attack. It was assumed the bombings had wrecked sixty-one cities, killed about 8,200,000 people and injured 6,550,000.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy offered jobs yesterday to all 940 graduates of Hunter Colege if they pass the necessary Civil Service examinations.
TOKYO, June 16 -- Japan's largest federation of lawyers has charged that the United States Army administrators on Okinawa are violating the human rights of the native population.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Another rise in hog prices, amounting to 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight, edged the top up another notch to $22, highest since last Aug. 27.
MOSCOW, June 16 -- Israel has received a Soviet warning against making any military alliance with the United States.

The General Electric Company of Germany is making a formal offer to settle its pre-war debt to dollar bondholders. In return for the defaulted 7, 6 1/2 and 6 per cent obligations it is offering new bonds bearing three-quarters as much interest and due in 1968.
Advertising for Puerto Rico's rum in this country has been so successful that the insular legislature has increased its advertising appropriation for the 1955-56 season to a new high of $1,300,000.
QUEBEC, June 16 -- A delegation from the International Civil Aviation Organization and Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec conferred here today in secret over diplomatic rights and privileges.
Against a backdrop of strike-stilled ships, organized labor has established a second major beachhead in its fight to make employers responsible for supplementary unemployment benefits.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The United States has approved a permit for shipping 500 automobiles to Bulgaria.

Today was yesterday in Bangkok, Thailand, because of the international date line. Accordingly, friends of the Symphony of the Air, formerly the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, celebrated its first birthday one day ahead of time.

RYE, N. Y., June 17 -- The fifty-first United States Seniors Golf Association championship ended a six-day run at Apawamis today with Roy Moore, 64, of Waterville, Me., and John W. Roberts, 56, of Columbus, Ohio, still tied for the title.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 -- By way of setting the folks back home at ease, the Dodgers really went to town tonight as they crushed the Cardinals, 12 to 1, before an awed gathering of 25,661.

John Golden was known as the dean of Broadway producers and considered the patriarch of New York show business. But what show people, as well as other people, long will remember will be his many benefactions in behalf of the theatre, which he greatly loved, and individuals.

Psychologists demanded yesterday that Superintendent of Schools William Jansen rescind an "order" compelling them to work without extra pay during future school vacations. They said he was using poor psychology.
TOKYO, June 17 -- The Soviet refusal to discuss the fate of thousands of Japanese still missing since World War II has aroused bitter feelings here.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate approved overwhelmingly today the Austrian state treaty. By this pact Austria regains independence and becomes an armed neutral in the center of Europe.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17 (AP) -- The world's only atomic powered submarine, the Nautilus, has completed a six-week shakedown period successfully, the Navy reported today. The tests included a 1,400-mile voyage submerged.
Bargaining committees in the coast-wide seamen's strike were reliably reported early this morning to be near a settlement.
Self-examination on Operation Alert occupied local Civil Defense officials yesterday in cities throughout the country.

The Brooklyn police brought the fighting careers of seventeen Puerto Rican game cocks to an abrupt close last night. The birds were taught peaceful coexistence after the Morals Squad had raided their training camp in a Williamsburgh cellar and their trainer was booked on three charges.
MOSCOW, June 17 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, who was in charge of the 1950 program for consolidating Soviet collective farms, has suggested that some of them should be broken up.
MOSCOW, June 16 -- A spokesman for the Warsaw Government challenged today proposals made in the United States to "liberate" Poland from communism.

LONDON, June 17 -- Industrial shares resumed their advance today, stimulated by the Chancellor's speech in economic debate in the House of Commons yesterday and by announcement of several higher profit and dividend statements. Oil shares were especially strong, British petroleum gaining 3 shillings 9 pence (52 1/2 cents) followed by other issues.
BOSTON, June 17 (UP) -- Larry Doby's eighth-inning single scored the decisive run in a 3-2 Cleveland victory over the Red Sox tonight.
As the mother of a fine American boy I was naturally interested in two items which appeared on the front page of The Times of June 15, eloquent as they were by contrast.

The agreement between the seamen and the "dry cargo" and passenger shipowners gives a foretaste of the future for employer-financed unemployment benefits to supplement state compensation plans. The marine settlement is an augury of widespread employer acceptance of some direct responsibility to protect employes from financial losses due to lay-offs.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 17 -- The possibility of a "golpe" or coup d'etat in Brazil is again the center of discussion on politics here.

HAMILTON, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- Yale clinched the Tod Backe team championship trophy in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament today. The Elis defeated Colgate for the doubles title and sent Bill Cranston into the singles final against Tim Coss of Swarthmore, the defending champion.

A cycle of animated cartoon films from the studios of United Productions of America will be the highlights of a two-month exhibition of that studio's art work at the Museum of Modern Art. The exhibition, which will open at the museum on Tuesday, will feature displays of materials used in the creation of U. P. A. films.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate Government Operations Committee unanimously approved today a resolution calling for creation of a twelve-member commission to investigate the Federal security program.
BUENOS AIRES, June 17 -- Peace returned to this city today after yesterday's bloody revolt had been crushed.

GENEVA, June 17 -- A United States labor leader paid tribute today to the memory of the East German workers who, June 17, 1953, revolted against Communist rule in several East German industrial centers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- A United Nations special committee recommended today prompt establishment of the proposed fund for aid grants to underdeveloped countries.
New York City's defense test Wednesday was criticized yesterday as displaying an appalling lack of understanding of the problem of radioactivity.
The New York Academy of Medicine suggested yesterday a program to "take the profit out of the illicit drug traffic" as the most effective way to eradicate addiction.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- Strikes at all but two General Motors plants were settled today. Walkouts and parts shortages made idle 64,900 employes on the day shift.

Veterans of World War II receive this intelligence with mixed emotions: Their Selective Service records have been converted into paper napkins and paper towels. Two million individual files have been so converted.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Jimmy Durante is "toying," as he put it, With the idea of having another go at motion pictures.
PARIS, June 15 -- Paris' halls of high fashion were being cloaked in secrecy today as the couturiers sought to frustrate subversion by a corps of clever spies.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.2 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
BERLIN, June 17 -- The leaders of West Germany and West Berlin pledged today to restore this city as the capital of a reunited Germany.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 17 -- The Government placed an imaginary embargo on exports today. It was one of a variety of actions illustrating the problems in a mass nuclear attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- A plan for settlement of the Formosa problem was presented today by Li Tsung-jen, former Acting President of the Chinese Republic. The plan is based on the demilitarization and "democratization" of the island.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The city of Memphis, Tenn., opened a new round in the Dixon-Yates fight today. It threatened to generate its own electricity if the Administration insisted upon a private power contract.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 17 -- George A. Mooney, State Superintendent of Banks, told bankers today the stage was being set for possible large-scale revisions in the banking law.

I was very much interested in the item which your paper carried on June 12 concerning Carmine DeSapio's comments on the Puerto Rican situation in New York. I agree that there are thousands of desirable persons from Puerto Rico who have come to the city, and to blame the many for the actions of a few is hardly the democratic way of approaching the situation.

Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, informed the United States, Britain and France yesterday that he did not plan to go to Moscow until outstanding issues between his Government and the Soviet Union had been settled. This means that he will not go before September, or more than a month after the meeting of the Big Four heads of governments in Geneva begins July 18.
The nation's first graduate institute for study of the problems of alcoholism will open Monday to clergymen of all faiths.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- Mayor Elmer E. Robinson of San Francisco presides over a city of more than 800,000 population and an annual city budget of more than $200,000,000 but during the past few days his regular duties have seemed to him comparatively light.

The Right Rev. John Seville Higgins, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island, announced yesterday that Canon Darby Wood Betts of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) had been appointed executive director of the Episcopal Charities Fund in the Rhode Island Diocese. He also was named director of promotion and publicity for the diocese.

PARIS, June 17 -- Everybody remembers the nursery tale about the kingdom that was lost for want of a horseshoe nail. The French are beginning to wonder if a similar chain of logic may not soon be applicable to the lack of eight helicopters they consider necessary to end an armed insurrection in North Africa.

T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton, who are in charge of the Phoenix Theatre, the highly regarded downtown theatrical venture, have signed Jack Landau to stage "The Fourth Son," a fantasy drama by Aldyth Morris based on a Chinese legend.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 17 (Reuters) -- East and West met in perfect harmony here today and agreed on a different pitch, not political but musical.
After fifty-two years in the city school system, Dr. Gabriel R. Mason, principal of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, will retire at the end of the term.

Following is a communique issued yesterday by Secretary of State Dulles; Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, after their two-day conference in New York:

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- Jerry Church, Oregon State javelin thrower, and Jim Golliday, Northwestern sprinter, set the pace today in the qualifying phase of the thirty-fourth annual National Collegiate track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The dependence of Israel on American Jewish funds and United States governmental aid was stressed today at the fifty-eighth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America.
Northrop Aircraft, Inc., in the nine months ended April 30, realized an increase of 385 per cent in earnings on a 96 per cent gain in sales, Whitley C. Collins, president, said yesterday.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 17 (UP) -- Marlene Bauer of Sarasota, Fla., set a women's course record of 70 today at the Grossinger Country Club. As a result, she moved within 5 points of Patty Berg in the Triangle round-robin golf tournament.
The scale, one of man's oldest measuring tools, is being used in hundreds of new and improved ways by American industry.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 17 -- President Eisenhower appealed directly to the people today to rescue his stalled military reserve program.

DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today United States factories will build 146,121 cars and 23,446 trucks this week. Last week 134,673 cars and 25,023 trucks were built and in the comparable 1954 week 113,626 cars and 20,267 trucks were assembled.

The Pleasantville Realty Corporation, headed by Phillip P. Zipes, has purchased the Roosevelt Gardens apartment house which occupies a block at 1475 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. Clients of Elias A. Nathanson, attorney, were the sellers and Wood, Dolson Company, Inc., were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- A House Small Business Subcommittee today invited Government and industry officials to confer next week on an "equitable" distribution system for aluminum diverted from the government's stockpile. Chairman Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois, said the Subcommittee is opposed to any further diversions unless small manufacturers get a fair share of supplies.
Completion of arrangements to build a large uranium ore processing mill at Moab, Utah, was announced yesterday by the Uranium Reduction Company and the Utex Exploration Company.

The Communist daily, "Nepszava," published in Budapest, carries the following advertisement in its issue of May 14, 1955: "We buy your surplus furniture for ready cash or on commission. We come to your home for appraisement and provide for transportation.

Because of the great public interest in the problem of juvenile delinquency it might be of interest to your readers to learn that a proposal now before the City Board of Estimate will have a devastating influence, if it is passed, on the city's whole program for preventing and fighting delinquency.

The front line troops of our diplomacy over the world are the members of the Foreign Service. They are the eyes and ears of our policy makers and represent our nation to the peoples of the world. On both counts their importance can hardly be exaggerated.
JERUSALEM, June 17 -- Israel proposed tonight that a mine security zone be established along the Gaza Strip.

A seaman being deported to his native Spain leaped from a ship as it passed through the Narrows yesterday and struck out for the shore. It took a show of force by twenty Coast Guardsmen to compel him to resume his enforced voyage.
Three youthful members of a Brooklyn gang were charged yesterday with homicide. They had been arrested in the killing Thursday night of a 16-year-old member of a rival neighborhood gang.

CAIRO, June 17 -- After two weeks of mounting tension in Western capitals, concurrent with the quietest period in months on the Egyptian-Israeli armistice line, military and Government leaders here are wondering how all the diplomatic commotion got started.
Some lessening of the schedule of new issues is noticeable, but not on any scale suggesting an inactive summer.

Five painters and five sculptors have received $1,000 each to submit small-scale models of their work to the National Council for U. S. Art, Inc. They were selected as semi-finalists last week in a competition sponsored by the council.

The apartment house accommodating sixteen families on a corner plot 100 by 100 feet at 189-30 Thirty-seventh Avenue in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by I. Popliwsky to the Lenoir Realty Corporation.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert. June 17 -- A State Department report received here today said violence in Buenos Aires had subsided and the Peron Government had the situation under control.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The issuance of a patent this week revealed a Navy device that was long held secret -- a submarine decoy. The decoy is a small, propeller-driven cylinder to be discharged from the torpedo tube of submarine. It runs for fifteen minutes or so, making a noise like a submarine to fool the enemy, while the real submarine escapes by another course.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- General demand for wheat was slow today and prices continued the recession which started a couple of days ago. Commission demand was of disappointing volume. The cash trade developments that stimulated buying of wheat futures early in the week seemed to have little influence today although conditions were unchanged.
NORWOOD, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- A one-car Diesel-powered passenger train crashed into the rear of a standing freight train on a siding tonight injuring nine persons, at least one of them seriously.
ROME, June 17 -- Pope Pius XII received today from the two prelates expelled from Argentina an account of the prelude to yesterday's revolt against President Juan D. Peron.

The First National Bank of Arizona, controlled by the Transamerica Corporation, plans to raise $4,800,000 in new working capital through sale of 160,000 shares of new stock to present stockholders at $30 a share. The sale would be on the basis of one new share for every three held.
BUFFALO, June 17 -- The State Conference of Mayors called on the State Government today to stop favoring unincorporated areas over cities and villages.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- One of the nation's leading amateur golfers, Harvie Ward, shared the lead in the United States open championship today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- James Butler, who was president of the old Empire City Racing Association, confirmed today that a group of Rochester business men were planning to build a thoroughbred running track twenty miles southeast of this city.
ALTHOUGH the season is still young, twenty-eight anglers have qualified for the Maine Development Commission's "One That Didn't Get Away Club."
A casual glance at the social calendar suggests that the months of May and June indubitably are the popular ones for weddings. This is reasonable enough, for the months are pleasant indeed.
SINGAPORE, June 17 -- A five-day general strike was suspended tonight, but with language that promised more trouble.

DETROIT, June 17 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that the auto industry's trail-blazing wage contracts were possible "only because of the unprecedented prosperity" under the Eisenhower Administration.

How one is "vested" can have a lot to do with one's financial comfort. A little-understood term in pensioning, vesting has come in for more attention since the new Ford and General Motors wage pacts were signed, giving such benefits to their workers.
LOS ANGELES, June 17 -Motion picture industry spokesmen inferentially cast doubt at a Senate inquiry today that films contributed to juvenile delinquency.

It is clear that the revolt in Argentina is failing. Temporarily, at least, President Peron seems stronger than ever. A wave of persecution and arrests must be expected. Nothing has been gained and much appears to have been lost. However, in the long run it may well prove that the Peronist regime has been weakened, for this was a serious uprising, involving high naval and air force officers who were giving expression to deep-seated disaffection.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- President Eisenhower appointed today an emergency board to investigate a dispute between the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen and the country's major railroads.

The Committee of American Steamship Lines, which held an all-day meeting at the Westchester Country Club in Rye yesterday, selected a new chairman. He is A. R. Lintner, president and general manager of American Mail Lines of Seattle.

Charitable, educational and social organizations share nearly all of the $3,768,377 left by Joseph E. Lopez, former president of the Continental Insurance Company, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
Blood will be given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Monday at 70 Columbus Avenue by employes of the Atomic Energy Commission and of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, proposed today the creation of a nine- member "National Freedom Board" as an arm of the White House to develop a program for combatting communism on ideological grounds.

An amended plan of reorganization for the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its subsidiaries will be filed today with the United States District Court. That was announced yesterday by Lester T. Doyle, trustee in reorganization.

ASPEN, Colo., June 17 -- In a situation dominated by a spectacular landscape, a group of experts gathered here today to criticize its less-agreeable counterpart, "the cityscape." Defining it as "a setting in which man-made structures are predominant," they agreed that its current condition was discouraging.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 17 -- Civil Defense officials here acknowledged today that the nation was far from being ready to withstand a hydrogen bomb attack.

In Casey Stengel's lexicon, to be smart is to be "slick." The manager of the Yankees would be the first to concede that he had been outslicked last night at the tadium, where the Chicago White Sox won a 2-1 thriller from the Yankees.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 17 -- Informed sources said today National Army battalions had boxed in several thousand rebel Hoa Hao troops 100 miles southwest of Saigon.

"THE Brokenshire Show," seen over Channel 4 from 1 to 2 P. M., was in the hands of a substitute pilot yesterday. With Norman Brokenshire on vacation, Kenneth Banghart, the veteran announcer and news broadcaster, was conducting the program.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower relaxed at his country home here today after concluding Operation Alert.
MOSCOW, June 17 -- On the heels of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's declaration of loyalty to his alliance with the United States a two-fold warning about the future of Germany was delivered here today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today awarded a five-year certificate to Seaboard and Western Airlines for a scheduled freight service across the Atlantic.

SEOUL, Korea, June 12 -There were a few children in the central assembly hall of Buk Han San Orphanage on the outskirts of Seoul as the fire wagon red jeep of O. H. P. King pulled into the dusty courtyard. They recognized it before it had cleared the gate and came running out, calling greetings.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The case of a Virginia mountain boy who got into trouble in Korea was argued today in the "G. I.'s Supreme Court."

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges drifted irregularly yesterday in generally light trading. Coffee, sugar, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, wool, lead and copper were mixed; cocoa, potatoes and zinc eased and rubber, hides and burlap rose.
DARIEN, Conn., June 17 -- The Rev. James P. Roberts, pastor of the Harlem congregation that sought to buy the Phillips estate at 5 Middlesex Road, called off the purchase today.
The defense rested in James J. Moran's tax evasion case in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday without the former first deputy fire commissioner taking the witness stand.
Oyster Bay, L. I., Central School District 2 announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 28 on $2,100,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1955, and due serially on June 1 from 1956 to 1978.

SYRACUSE, June 17 -- For the first time since 1900, Pennsylvania is favored to win the championship in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Senate Armed Services Preparedness subcommittee said today that the United States watch and clock industry was in a "dangerous situation."
LINVILLE, N. C., June 17 (AP) --Billy Joe Patton of Morganton, N. C., and unheralded Charles Harrison of Atlanta gained the final of the Southern Golf Association amateur tournament today.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17 -- In a sparkling exhibition of pace, Yale swept the river today in its traditional rowing regatta with Harvard. It was the first Eli sweep since 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra ended its fifty-fifth season with a $20,684 net deficit. C. Wanton Balis Jr., president of the orchestra association, reported today the actual deficit was $134,634, but contributions to the orchestra fund campaign reduced the figure.
Five hundred days in jail or a $5,000 fine was the birthday present handed to twin sisters yesterday. They are 34 years old today.

Turnpike engineers are sometimes off on their cost and traffic estimates. In some cases, authorities have had to go back to the public for additional financing. In others, heavier traffic than anticipated has caused congestion and required new outlays for extensions.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The Defense Department's new director of publicity policies believes military officials should decide whether information is "useful" or "interesting" before giving it to reporters.

Visitors to the Bronx Park Zoo who address the new baby rhinoceros as Klein Josef rather than Little Joe are apt to get a grateful response from the 1,200-pound fellow. Klein Josef or Little Joe, whichever you prefer, made a somewhat timid debut yesterday at the zoo. He never did get past the head of the ramp that leads to his own little back yard, although carrots and rye bread awaited his pleasure.
MILWAUKEE, June 17 -- Danny O'Connell made a wild throw that put the Giants in the ball game in the eighth inning tonight, then lined a single to right in the tenth that put them out of it.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee heard final witnesses declare their support for the Administration's $3,408,000,000 foreign aid request today. The committee hopes to complete work on the bill and send it to the floor for debate next week.

LONDON, June 17 (UP) -- Lew Hoad of Australia and Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., the defending singles champions in the London tennis championships, reached the finals today with straight set victories.

Ralph (Tiger) Jones pounded his way to a knockout victory over Ernie Durando of Bayonne at Madison Square Garden last night. The Yonkers middleweight was scheduled to go ten rounds with his new Jersey rival, but he belabored him so badly that the fight did not go beyond the sixth round.

The report of the Mayor's Committee for a Clean City on its "tenement test area survey" gives real promise of ultimate success in the coordinated campaign against the city's dirt. The report is based on the findings of a house-to-house and lot-to-lot inspection of two square blocks in Harlem by teams recruited from the seven city agencies most concerned.

Visual defects have been found in 400 of 1,700 motorists examined by the Greater New York Safety Council. This report was made yesterday at the end of five days of free tests given by the council at the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, 80 Worth Street.
ROME, June 17 (AP) -- Msgr. Tato tonight disclaimed any knowledge of yesterday's revolt against the Peron regime. He spoke for himself and his assistant at a news conference.
The constitutionality of the State Defense Emergency Act of 1951 will be challenged in the courts, it was learned yesterday.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 17 -- The Ulster Unionist (Conservative) party invoked today an old and little-used legal instrument to try to unseat an imprisoned Irish Sinn Feiner who was elected to the British Parliament.

Libby Rosenberg sold the four-story loft building at 524 West Fiftieth Street to Sam Kraus. The buyer will modernize the structure and occupy it for his roofing and tinsmithing business. The property occupies a plot about 25 by 100 feet near Tenth Avenue. Schimmer, Kerner Feder were the brokers. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

Appointment of Dr. Lawrence R. Hafstad as head of the research staff of the General Motors Corporation, effective later this year, was announced yesterday by Harlow H. Curtice, president. Dr. Hafstad will succeed Charles L. McCuen, 66 years of age, general manager of the research laboratories division since July, 1947, who is retiring later in the year after twenty-nine years' service.

A biography of Kaiser Wilhelm II by Joachim von Kurenberg is planned for August publication by Simon Schuster, entitled "The Kaiser." The author is a journalist who knew the Kaiser well and was appointed his official biographer.
The second round of anti-polio vaccinations will begin in the city Monday.

The New York Board of Trade urged Congress yesterday to end "discrimination" against American insurance companies in the placement of marine insurance on foreign-aid shipments.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- An expectant San Francisco, birthplace of the United Nations, was ready tonight to welcome delegations from the member states for a tenth-year reunion, starting Monday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, 4 points (20 cents a bale) higher to 15 points (75 cents a bale) lower.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Something new in meteorology, a world thunderstorm map, is nearing completion, it was made known here today.
LONDON, June 17 -- British public opinion is being prepared for a sharper Government attitude toward unofficial and jurisdictional strikes and a tighter system of industrial bargaining.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 17 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines warned today of the Soviet Union's new strategy of "winning by numbers."

The Siegler Corporation, Illinois manufacturer of gas and oil home heaters, has bought all of the outstanding stock of the Hallamore Manufacturing Company. Hallamore is a California producer of electronic devices.

The students of form bet the Wheatley Stable's Misty Morn down to 13 to 20 in yesterday's main event at Aqueduct. When the race had been run, many of the students were more than a trifle unhappy. For Misty Morn finished second.
The first American news broadcaster from a major network to enter the Soviet Union in seven years arrived in Moscow yesterday.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has achieved record sales for the ninth consecutive year. Earnings increased 6 per cent in the year ended on Feb. 28, largely reflecting a 5.7 per cent drop in the tax bill.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- A foreign language newspaper editor refused to tell Senate investigators today whether he was a Communist. Two other witnesses refused to say whether they were editors.
PARIS, June 17 -- The city of Paris honored Mayor Robert Wagner today with a traditional welcome to City Hall.
The strike of Safeway food store employes in the metropolitan area, which has closed 135 outlets, threatened yesterday to spread to New Jersey.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 17 -- President Juan D. Peron of Argentina has not completely suppressed the revolt against him.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee has voted to build President Eisenhower's proposed atoms-for-peace ship and an atomic-driven merchant vessel as soon as possible.
HARTFORD, June 17 -- The Connecticut Public Expenditure Council urged today sweeping reforms in the powers and procedures of the Legislature.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, June 17 -- President Eisenhower said today he had found "great encouragement" in Operation Alert. The exercise was a test of Civil Defense in a simulated thermonuclear bomb attack on the country.
The stock market developed some strength in the late dealings yesterday and closing quotations were irregularly higher.

The Japanese Federation of Bar Associations has charged in a formal report that American administration is violating the human and civil rights of the population of Okinawa. This complaint should not be dismissed with a perfunctory denial.
The Powerful Katrinka of the airways has received the greatest weight-lifting chore ever assigned to her.

SCIENTISTS at the Minnesota Agricultural Experiment Station report they were forced into research on home-freezing cheese because of many inquiries from householders. These householders asked what varieties could be frozen and how should the cheeses be packaged.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States has withdrawn three Army officers from its embassy in Moscow at the request of the Soviet Government.
THE pleasant summer custom of hearing band music on the Mall in Central Park was resumed last night when the Goldman Band played its first outdoor concert of the season.

MENDON, Mass., June 18 (AP) -- A carpenter-farmer who came with his wife from the British Isles 277 years ago and founded the distinguished Taft family here will be honored by his descendants this August.
