WHEN publication of this book was announced several months ago, this reviewer's reaction was a surprised query. Can there possibly be anything new, he asked, on the overwritten subject of George Armstrong Custer and the Battle of the Little Big Horn?
PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, today was awarded the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the commencement exercises of Drexel Institute of Technology.

AS summer arrives this week, life in the suburbs and cities, gardenwise at least, tapers off to a slower pace. Vacations will start for some and others waiting their turn will begin to take life easy.
PARIS, June 18 -- Sleek-wing jets crashed through the sound barrier today over the airfield where twenty-eight years ago Charles A. Lindbergh set down the Spirit of St. Louis.

UNITED STATES and foreign airline executives have been busy, the pas\ week stewing over decisions that will not tolerate much more postponement. With the Lockheed-American Airlines contract for the turbo-prop Electra and the Douglas decision to build the pure-jet DC-8, the deadline for all first-round bets on turbine-era equipment appears to be just about now.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- State Department documents released today told of the "colossal miscalculations" of Japanese authorities in failing to foresee the Hitler-Stalin nonaggression pact before the outbreak of World War II.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General said tonight that a defense system to guard Israel and the Arab states would air the United States and strengthen the Free World.

CONCORD, N. H. -- When President Grant journeyed to the White Mountains of New Hampshire eighty-six years ago, as President Eisenhower plans to do this week, he enjoyed "a most elegant entertainment" in the shadow of the Old Man of the Mountains at Franconia Notch, drove about unescorted in a buggy, was rushed by admirers, placed in the care of the state's most daring coach driver and had an encounter with a whiffle-tree.

JOHN DOLLARD writes in his review of Benjamin Fine's "1,000,000 Delinquents" that, in dealing with delinquents, we are often urged to "throw the book at them." And he adds, "We throw the book, but it is the wrong book -- the Old, not the New Testament." Certainly Mr. Dollard shows a lamentable lack of understanding of the Old Testament when he makes such a statement.

DALLAS, June 18 -- Southwestern business last week continued to hold a better pace than last year. Rains and thunder showers improved farm-ranch outlooks, the construction industry still was booming, employment in metropolitan areas like Dallas was at peaks for the year, and department store sales volume still was above last year.

Forty-two United States Customs Appraisers from over the country will meet here Monday through Wednesday in the second half of a national conference that began in Washington last week.
BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- The Argentine Army today took over the task of "safeguarding public order" throughout the nation.
Edward S. Silver, Kings County District Attorney, said yesterday in his annual report that juvenile delinquency had become the most serious criminal problem in Brooklyn.
LOS ANGELES, June 18 -- Los Angeles was described today as the nation's leader in the sale of nude pictures.

STAIRS can develop several types of trouble quite unlike anything else around the house. Because of their complicated construction and frequent use, the ailments are often difficult to identify, but are always noticeable. Stair trouble is fairly common even in new houses.

BLUE flowers are scarce at any season of the year. In fact, they are almost non-existent in late summer when the garden most needs their cool accent. Now is the time to solve the shortage by planting perennials which provide that refreshing color.
Jim Konstanty has that "old feeling" again. That's good news for the Yankees, bad news for the rest of the American League.

JARVENPAA, Finland, June 18 (UP) -- Jan Sibelius dramatically broke his long isolation today. He invited Eugene Ormandy and the entire Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra into his home as a thank-you salute to the American people for appreciating his music.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 18 -- Voters will go to the polls here Monday to decide whether they want a $6,600,000 general high school built in the northeast part of the city. It would replace two old downtown high schools and accommodate 2,500 pupils at once and 3,000 later.

THE annual exhibition of American folk art, at the Downtown Gallery, includes several unusually interesting examples by craftsmen-artists of the last century. Among these are a wall hanging, oil on sailcloth, by a sailor, which looks as if it had been inspired by a Persian miniature or illuminated manuscript illustration.

The nation's retailers, who have long complained of competition from military post exchanges, are broadening their attack to include nonmilitary retail operations de signed to benefit Government employes.
MADRID, June 18 -- A Spanish court ruled today that Roman Catholics may contract civil marriage in Spain with non-Catholics.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- An incredible finish marked the fifty-fifth United States Open golf championship today. Ben Hogan, in a bid for a record-breaking fifth triumph in this tournament, was tied by an unheralded 32-year-old Davenport (Iowa) professional, Jack Fleck.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 18 -- Only one of the eleven incorporated villages that will have annual elections on Tuesday shows evidence of a contest. In most of them it will be a routine matter of re-electing the Mayor and Trustees now in office.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. -- Most tourists think of California as composed of two areas: San Francisco and Los Angeles. Some are familiar, additionally, with the "Redwood Empire," the coastal belt of towering forests extending northward from San Francisco into Oregon.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- Australia's Ken Rosewall and Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., today swept to impressive victories in the finals of the London grass court tennis championships. As a result of winning their final tune-ups for the Wimbledon championships, they became sentimental favorites to score upsets in the big tournament that starts Monday.

When representatives from Canada met at a conference here last week, their discussions were in French and English. The real language of the meetings, however, was the universal tongue of rehabilitation and services to the handicapped.
Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week showed an increase over the comparable week last year.

THE whole art and concept of lawn making is going through a series of changes, many of them radical in comparison with the practices that were once fully accepted as correct and stable. The near future will see many more old-time lawn concepts abandoned as new facts emerge.
UVALDE, Tex., June 18 (AP) -- John Nance Garner sheds his old khaki loafing breeches and dons a pin-stripe gray suit for a front-porch reception here tomorrow.

IF confirmation was needed, the Federal Reserve Board last week reported that the historic peak of industrial production was reached in May. The production index of the board touched 138, one point above the previous record, attained in July of 1953.

LOWESTOFT, England, June 15 -- The Russians finally got their ship here today, but not until it looked like the whole business would founder on snafus.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 18 -- Business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District was rolling toward the half-year mark at a pace well ahead of 1954, reports to the Minneapolis conditioning units, which were Reserve Bank showed.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- South Korea will make a strong bid here next week for an increase of $250,000,000 in United States allocations for economic and military aid.

ISTANBUL -- The Istanbul Hilton, a sparkling white, eleven-story, 300-room hotel, took in its first guests last week-end, inaugurating something in the way of a new tourism era for the Middle East. The $7,000,000 skyscraper, which reminded many members of the inaugural party of the Caribe Hilton Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, does more than extend the Hilton Hotels chain twenty-six hours of flying time eastward from New York.

A FEW years ago, in a Cincinnati hotel, a pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers, Cletus Elwood ( Baron Boots) Poffenberger, touring the West with his team, got a message that his manager, Leo Durocher, expected him to attend a special morning meeting of the squad out at the ball park.

IN a monumental building spanning a whole short block of Vienna's celebrated Ringstrasse, an army of workers is reconstructing a landmark of the past in the style of the future. For the past eight years they have been performing a major architectural operation on the battered body of their distinguished patient, the famed State Opera House, built to the order of Franz Josef in 1869 and bombed by the United States Air Force in 1945.
GENEVA, June 17 -- A State Department official is here preparing for the visit of President Eisenhower next month. He is Harold Kissick, director of the Office of International Conferences.

SUBSCRIPTION television appears certain to be the subject of the most hectic and widespread controversy in broadcasting's three decades. In interest, complexity and duration it should easily be the spectacular of disputes over use of the airwaves.

THE Symphony of the Air wants to emulate the Boston Symphony in running a summer music school at a site where it will also give a summer music festival. Needless to say, the Berkshire Festival being the success it is, there are a number of places that would like to become new Tanglewoods.
CHICAGO, June 18 (UP) -- Sam Jones hurled a seven-hit shutout as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Philadelphia Phillies and Robin Roberts, 4 -- 0, today before 16,543 fans.

LOS ANGELES, June 18 -- The University of Southern California rallied today to capture its seventh straight National Collegiate track and field championship. Five records were set in the meet and one was tied.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, led a big delegation into the San Francisco Bay area today.

CELIA BERTIN has set down, in the febrile Mediterranean coastal zone between Grasse and the sea, a believable a family of intellectual derelicts as is to be found in new French fiction. Closer to Moravia than to most of her co-nationals, she comes promptly to grips with this emotionally raddled family, headed by Brigitte Touray, widow of one of France's great modern poets.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 18 -- Within a month, Rhode Island has been visited by two alien birds.

The Summer Institute for Social Progress will have as its theme "Human Relations in an Era of Change." Formerly at Wellesley College, it will be held in cooperation with the Foreign Policy Association July 1 to 15 at Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N. Y.

TO the reader who is surfeited with the new high-level historical novel and who longs for something less demanding, Rosamond Marshall's "Rogue Cavalier" offers all the relaxation that a tabloid does to one who normally reads more serious journals.

LEYDEN, The Netherlands, June 18 -- Queen Juliana declared today that Western civilization must take on the task of spreading its prosperity and ending the hunger and poverty in the rest of the world.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Prospects of bringing the Administration's military reserve plan to a vote in the House brightened somewhat today.

EVERY contributor will be represented by one slide of his own choice, more if the judges approve, in the First International Color Slide Salon of New York, according to last week's announcement by Wellington Lee, president of the sponsor, the Photographic Society of New York.
BOSTON, June 18 -- Judge Joseph L. Hurley in Suffolk Superior Court has taken under advisement a plea for dismissal of a suit that seeks to prevent publication of a book about krebiozen, a drug.
SYRACUSE, June 18 -- The Cornell varsity crew that won the intercollegiate rowing championship today is largely the same eight that finished first here in the freshman race a year ago.
LONDON, June 18 -- Jaroslav Drobny, the defending champion, was cautioned today against writing newspaper articles during the Wimbledon championships.

Archie Moore will risk his light-heavyweight championship of the world against Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night. Olson is the holder of the world middleweight title, but his crown will not be at stake.
PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies tonight signed three young players for assignment to minor league clubs.
THE week-end weather has generally been almost unspeakable, but not quite. So there is room to talk about it a little, in relation to indoor and outdoor work.

PELHAM, N. Y., June 18 -- Historic houses in this land of early French Huguenots and Sir John Pell will be opened to the public next Saturday. The tours will be managed by the Westchester County Historical Society for the benefit of its Hammond House Museum in East-view.

ACHIEVING success in one field may be a trying, sometimes impossible, chore, but tripling in brass seems to be just what the doctor ordered for Peggy Lee. The tall, blue-eyed, platinum blonde hardly needs an introduction as a singer of popular songs, to judge by the myriad number of records her singular voice has helped to sell.

ROME, June 18 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano said today that the Roman Catholic hierarchy had not prompted or approved this week's revolt in Argentina. Catholics, it said, are the first to lament the deaths caused by the revolt.

IN recent years thoughtful historians of culture have accepted the necessity -- and have demonstrated the utility -- of organizing their material by periods. Without such categories it is impossible to discuss or even to think about historical development.
The country's biggest electrical manufacturer has put on record its ideas on what local communities ought to do to attract and keep "good employers."

Manufacturing of knitted cloth entails several risks, despite the fact that knitting is one of the fastest and most economical means of turning yarn into fabric. The whirling knitting machines speak a language of their own in the textile business, and it is only the initiated who can understand it.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Eisenhower will span the continent twice this week. He also will visit New England in one of the most active travel weeks he has en countered since entering the White House.

BOSTON, June 18 -- More than 1,200 engineers, including several hundred from abroad, will attend the Diamond Jubilee semiannual meeting of The American Society of Mechanical Engineers. It opens here tomorrow and continues through Friday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 18 (UP) -- Porterhouse, who demonstrated his sprinting ability in stakes company earlier this year, today captured the seven-furlong, $28,300 Lakes and Flowers Handicap at Hollywood Park. He won by about two lengths.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 18 -- Top leaders of the West Cochin China rebellion were reported here tonight to have fled into Cambodia. High Government sources said Gen. Tran Van Soai, Gen. Nguyen Van Vy, Col. Nguyen Van Hinh and thirteen other insurgent leaders had taken refuge in the Cambodian town of Takeo, just over the border from the Cahudoc region of Vietnam.

PARIS, June 15 (UP) -- Delegates to the International Olympic Congress ignored the wishes of the United States and other Western nations today by sidestepping the issue of "state amateurism" for another two years.

CHICKENS are one of the few food-producing animals that can be easily raised and cared for by children, require comparatively little space, and (where zoning regulations permit) are a possible hobby for both town and country.

THE glory, if such you can call it, of the old-time nickelodeon theatres -- once as rampant in the realm of entertainment as television is today -- will be fondly recalled and celebrated in ceremonies today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 18 -- Air transport to Argentina still is suspended and radio and phone services are irregular. The feeling prevailed here today that settlement of the revolutionary activities in the neighboring country was proceeding slowly.

PERHAPS one day an erudite sociologist will write an essay definitely linking the Industrial Revolution with the art of writing long fiction and the beauty of women. The Port of New York Authority has taken up the cause of cheaper fresh fruits and vegetables.

Yeshiva University will confer 220 degrees and diplomas and five honorary degrees on Tuesday. The commencement exercises will be held in Nathan Lamport Auditorium, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 3 P. M. State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits will deliver the address.
KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., June 14 -- A long-deferred program for severing Indians from Federal supervision and giving them first-class citizenship is on trial on the -acre Klamath Reservation.

IT was just a week ago today that Bob Turley, the Yankee fireballer, had the Cleveland Indians shut out with three skimpy hits in five innings. Then the roof toppled in. The Tribe shelled him for eight hits and ten runs in the next two innings for his fourth straight defeat. How come?

STANTON, Del., June 18 -- Early last week, James Fitzsimmons went to the trouble of shipping the Wheatley Stable's High Voltage here from her Aqueduct barn. This afternoon, the speedy 3-year-old filly endorsed her trainer's judgment by capturing the $49,625 Delaware Oaks before 23,958 at Delaware Park.
The bond market has had many ups and downs since World War II, and another memorable experience seems to be in the making.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 18 (UP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta sank a 25-foot putt for a birdie 3 on the eighteenth hole today to win the Triangle round-robin golf tournament with 44 points.

New sources of financial support must be found for America's private elementary and secondary schools, according to a recent report issued by the National Association of Manufacturers. N. A. M. points out that the high standards of the independent schools are threatened because of inadequate income to meet the rising costs of operation.
Music under the trees has become a Monday through Friday treat since the New York Public Library moved its recorded concerts outdoors to Bryant Park for the summer.
A LUSTY outgrowth of the nation-wide surge of population from cities to suburbs is the increased need for two cars to a family.
NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 18 -- An unusual poll next Saturday will decide whether a 250-acre section of this township is to be annexed by the adjoining town of Brookfield.

MANCHESTER, England, June 15 -- The erection of a super-radio-telescope at Jodrell Bank, twenty-five miles southwest of Manchester threatens to start a first-class feud between the 8,000 inhabitants of a small adjacent township and the scientists responsible for the instrument.
The United States Coast Guard Academy of New London will be host to the North American intercollegiate dinghy sailing championship starting tomorrow. The races will continue through Thursday.
EVER conscious of its cultural heritage, Japan has launched an extensive program to refurbish and maintain its national treasures.

THE final flicker of activity in the local galleries as summer comes in provides a number of group exhibitions of more than passing interest. Outstanding among the new displays is the benefit exhibition arranged for the New York City Cancer Committee at the Parke-Bernet Galleries by the New York Antique and Art Dealers Association.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 18 -- Phil Hanna of Jackson Heights, the national senior indoor champion, won twice today and gained the third round of the New Jersey state tennis championships. Hanna, who is seeded third, defeated William Mackey of Nutley, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, and Charles Mansuy Jr. of Montclair, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- When the Indian diplomat, V. K. Krishna Menon, met here this week with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles it was assumed that he discussed the prospects of freeing eleven United States Air Force men held prisoner in Communist China.

THIS week the delegates of sixty countries will meet in San Francisco to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the signing of the Charter of the United Nations. Many of the hopes that prevailed at that time have not been fulfilled, and it is time for all who believe in the organization to examine the reasons for its limited success and to determine what can be done to make it operate more effectively in the future.

KUTZTOWN, Pa. -- Here, in the heart of Berks County, the sixth annual Pennsylvania Dutch folk festival is to commence on Friday, July 1, and continue through July 4. Its officials believe it will be the largest such festival ever held in this country.

PARAMUS, N. J., June 18 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair scored her first major match play victory today. She defeated Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, 2 and 1, in the listed thirty-six-hole final of the fifty-second women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.

Benjamin Chu and Betty Ton were chosen king and queen of Chinatown's children yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, June 18 -- Ready-to-wear sales, especially hot weather items, were adversely affected by the abnormally cool temperatures last week. Father's Day promotions were well patronized and accessories moved well.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Manufacturers showing at the homefurnishings market here beginning Monday are going after a larger shore of the consumer dollar this fall, according to Wallace O. Ollman, general manager of the Merchandise Mart.

THE New York State Thruway will mark its first birthday on Friday. In its first year the Thruway took in $7,500,000 in tolls and established one of the best safety records of any major toll road in the country.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 18 -- The Midwest Research Institute, formed here a decade ago to help erase the disparity between agriculture and industry in the Great Plains region, has settled down in its new $1,250,000 home.
HAVANA, June 14 -- The Soviet Union is wooing Cuba as part of a plan to "neutralize" Latin America and isolate the United States, according to information here.
MAIZURU, Japan, June 18 (AP) -- Fifteen ships, ten of them returning lend-lease craft -- manned by aloof but smartly dressed Soviet seamen, steamed into curving Maizuru harbor five hours late today.

A SOUND American policy for China can only be based on a clear understanding of the actual situation there. The bitterness and confusion of the debate over China and our self-defeating vacillation of the past several years are the price we have had to pay for our ignorance about Chinese realities.

Savings provide the foundation for consumer credit, which in turn has made possible today's economy of mass production and mass consumption, according to David Ford, president of the Savings Association League. of New York State.

CLEVELAND, June 18 -Vessels and barges are being pressed into service as floating storage elevators and additional tonnage is being sought in an effort to relieve serious congestion at Buffalo grain elevators.

Tomorrow tens of millions who live along a narrow strip of earth from the Indian Ocean across Ceylon, Bangkok, part of the Philippines and the Pacific Ocean north of the Solomon Islands will behold one of the longest possible total eclipses of the sun. Observers from Arabia to New Zealand will see only a partial eclipse, and residents of the United States none at all.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., June 18 (UP) -- The president of the company that owns 90 per cent of Squaw Valley declared today that drastic changes would have to be made in the present plans for its development as the site of the 1960 winter Olympic Games.

MUCH has been written about the effect of the horse on Indian culture on the American Plains. Some have argued that the coming of the horse completely revolutionized the Indian way of life, raising the red man from an abject state to one of proud arrogance. Others have found that it was the horse, in the hands of ruthless Indians. more than any other factor, which helped wipe out the great herds of buffalo.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Bureau of Indian Affairs announced today termination as of July 1 of Federal supervision over two tribes of Texas Indians.

After five years of research, carried on at a cost of $250,000 provided by the United States Public Health Service, the Eli Lilly Laboratories and the Lasker Foundation, Dr. C. H. Li of the University of California, and his associates, Drs. I. I. Geschwind, J. S. Dixon, R. D. Cole and I. D. Raacke, have found out just how the ACTH molecule is constituted.
Two further departures from the Stalinist pattern have appeared in the Soviet Union recently. One involves religious leaders and the other, heads of industry.

Representative Katharine Price Collier St. George, Republican of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., who so far as we know has never in her life been accused of radicalism, put some timorous souls of the House Appropriations Committee in their place the other day with these remarks:

MOSCOW, June 18 (AP) -- Soviet newspapers published prominently today excerpts from the United States magazine Iowa Union Farmer. It was quoted as saying that Iowa and other American farmers were having hard times under declining incomes.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- Vic Raschi, not so speedy as when he was a Yankee, but dependable in the clutch, pitched the Kansas City Athletics into sixth place today. Raschi posted a ten-hit 9-4 victory over the Washington Senators, who dropped to seventh.

WILLIAM WALKER, that ambitious man -- ex-lawyer, ex-surgeon, ex-California gold miner, extraordinary opportunist -- tried at various times to take over and rule Lower California and Sonora, in Mexico, and Honduras and Nicaragua.

LOS ANGELES, June 18 -- Hugo Kirchhofer, the man who named the Hollywood Bowl and who for thirty-six years conducted the Living Cross Chorus for Easter sunrise services there, died today at Monte Sano Hospital of complications resulting from an appendectomy performed last May 21. He was 73 years old.
Dyed-to-match sportswear ensembles, new fabrics in junior wear, and three-piece costumes in the coat, suit and dress markets are producing greatest activity, resident offices report.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 18 -- Mayor Wagner and his wife arrived in Israel tonight by plane from Paris. He told a welcoming group at Lydda airport that he had long been "anxious to come here and see what is being done."

TEN years ago this June, President Truman, a humble and startled man who had recently come to the White House upon the sudden death of his predecessor, rose in front of a bank of flags at the Memorial Opera House in San Francisco to talk about the United Nations Charter, which had just been completed and was about to be signed.
Glass, one of mankind's oldest manufactured products, is now being produced, sold and used, at a record-shattering rate.

ANYONE who fears that the detective story has exhausted itself and is bound to be, at best, artistic reworking of familiar material is urged to secure at once THE TOOTH AND THE NAIL (Harper, $2.95), in which Bill S. Ballinger presents us with a completely new trick.
MANHATTAN, Kan., June 18 (AP) -- Four records fell today in the first nine events of the all-Army track and field meet. About 180 entries from Army stations all over the world are competing.

LONDON -- Britain's booming tourist industry probably suffered less from the seventeen-day railroad strike that ended last Tuesday than did any other industry, Few American vacationists who had planned to spend part of June in the British Isles altered their plans because of the strike.
The nation's supply of engineers and scientists is in jeopardy, according to leading educators.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 18 -- The largest fleet of the spring turned out today for the tenth of the succession of week-end regattas of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. But more than 100 sailing ships learned that windjammers need wind.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner berated the Republican-controlled New Jersey Legislature tonight for its failure thus far to adopt measures he considers of paramount importance.

THE season just coming to a close has been a strange one. Has any other equivalent period offered so many shows retrospective in nature? It is almost as if the local art world, somewhat worn down by the outburst of extreme expressionist and abstract work in the last few years, had by tacit consent decided to have a look backward before taking further steps.

THESE are the restless, breathless, eager days of graduation. In high schools all over America young men and women are running the feverish race called Commencement Week -- exams, proms, parties, class breakfasts, class nights, graduation exercises and other rituals to be enjoyed furiously now and recalled sentimentally in the years ahead.

The sixth and final "Twilight" concert of the season yesterday at Carnegie Recital Hall proved to be one of the most charming of the series. It presented two modern and three eighteenth century chamber works, all virtually unknown and all having graciousness.

LEON EDEL, the distinguished biographer of Henry James, says in his foreword that he had sketched out a "quite primitive" version of "this essay" so long ago as 1928. "But the subject then was too 'new'; to attempt it was to find one's self in the very laboratory of fiction."
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- President Eisenhower's $3,408,000,000 foreign aid bill seemed headed today into a sharp partisan fight over jobs in the new International Cooperation Administration.
The auction market for art and antiques is awakening sufficiently this week from its summer doze to offer some attractive items to buyers.
The text of the statement issued yesterday by medical authorities at a conference called by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis follows:

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: After the rains it is time to cultivate, before weeds crowd desired plants. Use a hand cultivator in a rock garden and around young seedlings, a long-handled hoe or cultivator around established plants. Cultivate shallowly to loosen soil and uproot weeds, which will die in the sun. AND IF THERE IS TIME: Adjust the lawn mower to cut grass three inches high during summer. . . .

A SMALL, powerful, straight-line sander provides big-machine performance at low cost. A sixty-cycle reciprocating motor gives 14,400 back-and-forth strokes per minute. Straight-line rather than orbital action sands into corners and permits a choice of sanding with or against the grain.

LIKE Marty Greenberg's four previous anthologies, his latest is concerned with a common theme, this time a glimpse into man's future cultures. Of the nine items in this excellent anthology, two are classed as "Introductions,'' the first a lucid, exciting and convincing extrapolation by Robert A., Heinlein called "Where To?", the second a short-short end-of-the-world story by Isaac Asimov.

ALTHOUGH Macbeth may have been a baneful influence on Scotland, he is a stimulating man in the theatre. In Shakespeare's tragedy he has provided Sir Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh with the best parts they have had so far this season.
THE summer theatres once again are being heard from:

The average undergraduate at Douglass College, the women's college of the State University of New Jersey, devotes a forty-hour week to academic pursuits. This includes 16 hours 40 minutes attending classes and 26 hours 22 minutes in class preparation.

ATHENS, June 18 -- The International Congress of Jurists published today a statement designed to rally lawyers everywhere to a common code of principles. The statement, called the Act of Athens reads:
BOSTON, June 18 -- Jackie Jensen's tie-breaking home run and clinching sacrifice fly marked the Boston Red Sox 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.
TOKYO, June 18 -- The Chinese Communist radio said today that three Americans and two Belgians who had chosen to live in Communist China after their capture in the Korean War would leave China.

THE seventh room of my house is one that requires no painting and no plastering. It is the terrace. For me the terrace is one of the most important living spaces I possess. For, while a terrace is not particularly a place to sit in the heat of the midday sun, it is a spot linked to many hours of satisfying comfort and beauty.
MOSCOW, June 18 -- Konstantin E. Zinchenko, a former Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations, has accused the United States of systematically flouting the organization.
Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer is serving as chairman of a seventy-two-member concert committee in charge of the thirty-eighth season of Stadium Concerts.

A group of prominent atomic, political and social scientists tonight will discuss employment of atomic energy to ease international tensions. They will speak at a dinner forum at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
RYE, N. Y., June 18 -- The Continental Baking Company has announced that it will begin construction at once of central office and laboratory buildings here to cost more than $1,000,000.
As a former resident of a Far Eastern land for five years, I cannot resist taking vigorous exception to some of the nonsense in Mrs. Durdin's article on the white man in Asia.

It is a rare student who successfully combines honors in scholarship and excellance in virtually every other phase of college life. Edward White, who was graduated summa cum laude from New York University's Washington Square College last Wednesday, has demonstrated that it can be done.
A child psychiatrist who has spent much of his life observing the vagaries of youth believes that the young upstarts of today are worse than they ever have been.
The outlook for men's hat sales is better than it has been in many years according to Frank H. James, president of the Hat Corporation of America, producer of Dobbs, Knox and Cavanagh hats.

Umpire Larry Napp, whose play it was to call, was probably the only person in Yankee Stadium yesterday who didn't see that Sherm Lollar's third-inning drive bounced rather than carried over the left-field railing.

BALTIMORE, June 18 (UP) -- Duke Maas, one of the Detroit Tigers' pitching "finds" this season, hurled a two-hitter today. The rookie right-hander shut out the Baltimore Orioles for the second time this year, 7 -- 0.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 -- Support for an international conference designed to review and to strengthen the United Nations was given today by the results of a poll conducted by the National Planning Association among its members.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- Adlai Stevenson of Illinois is finding that it is extremely difficult to run for the Presidency without the facilities and trappings of public office.
The first company to enter the primary aluminum field in this country since 1946 will begin turning out ingots in the next few weeks.
HONG KONG, June 18 -- An increasing number of arrests of "counter - revolutionaries" in Communist China is being reported in delayed official dispatches from the mainland.
Establishment of a New York City Personnel Department under a competent director was hailed as a "landmark of progress'' last week by the Civil Service Reform Association.

THE portable type of 35mm enlarger, with which Simmon Brothers entered the enlarger manufacturing field thirteen years ago, was introduced at a press preview last week in a considerably advanced version. The new enlarger, the Omega Portable A-2, like the first, is designed to be taken apart for storage or carrying in a specially fitted carrying case.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- One of the largest bequests ever made to the Art Institute of Chicago was disclosed this week with the filing of inheritance tax returns in the estate of Joseph Winterbotham, an industrial engineer. He died April 19, 1953, at the age of 76.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, June 18 (AP) -- Tyrolean newspapers today bitterly accepted the defeat of Innsbruck in the competition for the 1960 Olympic Winter Games yesterday. The winter events were awarded to Squaw Valley, Calif.

BRUGES -- There may be those visiting Belgium for whom soft lights on old stones, the glimmer of canals and the resonance of the world's finest bells hold no charm on a summer evening. But it can be confidently predicted that among the tens of thousands who will have seen these sights and heard these sounds in Bruges by the end of this summer, such insensitive persons will constitute only a small, grumpy minority.

WHEN the Big Four meet, no one will doubt that Eisenhower speaks for America, that Eden speaks for England and that Faure speaks for France. But whom will Premier Bulganin speak for? Does he, in fact, represent the Soviet "summit" or is the peak of the Russian power pyramid actually held by Party Secretary Khrushchev, alone or possibly in some combination involving Marshal Zhukov?

The problems of war and peace in the atomic age came to a dramatic juxtaposition during the past week. On the one hand, our "Operation Alert" revealed the almost inconceivable havoc that a hydrogen bomb attack would visit on any country exposed to it.

WE are always happy when language that should be denotive is connotive. You'd think when the Supreme Court makes a ruling it would be in language strict in quantities and devoid in qualities. But it wasn't so the other day when the highest court in the land ruled that school segregation must be ended with "deliberate speed"

JUNKET was an Airedale terrier who, after five years with one family, suddenly found himself stuck with a new one -- the McDonegals. He was still on the same farm, but even that had changed horridly, now that the hens, pig, cow, geese, cat and pony had disappeared.

Your article of May 20 concerning the highly successful tour by the Symphony of the Air was both informative and challenging. Two major impressions remain with me: the cultural impact and good will engendered by this outstanding ensemble's concerts and the potential bewilderment likely to infuse Oriental minds as to our appreciation of our musical assets in the event the orchestra is compelled to disband because of adverse economic factors.

In your article on Casals last Sunday, reference is made to "a pianist named Ansorge, who believed in the 'exclusive Germanism' of Bach." I couldn't help wondering what Ansorge's version of the story might be.

TOWARD the end of 1784 Mozart became a Mason. In the remaining seven years of his life he provided a good deal of music for the use of his lodge. Five years ago Vox issued a two-disk set that contained all that music.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 18 -- J. Howard Lyons' Adios Harry from Greenwood, Del., set a world record for a 4-year-old pacer on a half-mile track tonight. He raced one mile in 1:59 2/5 in a $7,500 match with Adios Boy at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- The International Whaling Commission will meet at Moscow July 18 to consider problems related to conservation of the world whale population. Representation from seventeen countries is expected.

At a conference on heredity, arranged by half a dozen scientific organizations, among them the National Science Foundation, the Atomic Energy Commission and the Rockefeller Foundation, and held last week at Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., Drs. E. B. Ford and P. M. Sheppard of the University Museum, Oxford, England, reported what they called "the most extreme case of evolution ever witnessed by man."

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The Dodgers tried to blast the Cardinals with a delayed-action bomb tonight, But the thing backfired and the Redbirds, to the cheers of 27,569, upended Walter Alston's Brooks, 5 to 4, in a blistering ten-inning battle.

Assets of the nation's investment companies will more than double their present net value of $8,000,000,000 by 1960, according to Arthur Wiesenberger, senior partner in Arthur Wiesenberger Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.
DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- Bud Saile scored his first major speed-boating triumph today by capturing the Maple Leaf regatta in Miss Cadillac.
A special committee of polio experts recommended yesterday continued inoculations with Salk vaccine throughout the peak of the polio season this summer.
LONDON, June 18 -- Legal action to break the unofficial strike of seamen, now in its nineteenth day, was taken today by the Cunard Line.
LONDON, June 15 -- Smog investigators are burning irradiated coal in an attempt to trace the most dangerous constituents of urban smoke during the combustion process.

CHILDREN of today, America's backbone of tomorrow, are experiencing a high standard of living. They are provided with facilities in and around the home that their parents saw only in pictures or at a public playground. And now that play yards and play equipment have reached the home, little Johnny and Mary can really have a big time right in their own back yard.

PARENTS who have been exasperated by keening, coonskin capped small fry frontiersmen in their midst in recent months, may expect no help from Walt Disney. The fact is that the producer of "Davy Crockett" already has a sequel series in the works in his Burbank studios titled, "The Legends of Davy Crockett."
